Foreign investors, who account for about a third of trades, are driving the market higher, but analysts expect a more cautious approach compared to mainland markets.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close 2.69% lower
summary: Tokyo stocks closed 2.69% lower on April 30, 2015, as the yen strengthened following the Bank of Japan's decision not to add to its stimulus program. US growth data fell short of expectations, contributing to the decline. The Nikkei 225 index dropped 538.94 points to 19,520.01, while the Topix index fell 2.13% to 1,592.79. The declines were attributed to a combination of factors, including weaker-than-expected US growth data and the yen's appreciation.

site_title: Hot stock: Newly listed GCCP Resources hits high of 19.4 S'pore cents before easing
summary: GCCP Resources, a Singapore-listed company, made its trading debut on the Catalist board of the Singapore Exchange (SGX) on April 30, 2015. The company rose to a high of 19.4 Singapore cents before easing to 18.2 cents. GCCP is a limestone producer in Malaysia and sold 122 million new shares at 23 cents each. The company aims to leverage its growth strategy to meet demand for calcium carbonate, a key industry application.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Boustead Projects rises to 99.5 Singapore cents in SGX debut
summary: Boustead Projects, the real estate arm of Boustead Singapore, made its debut on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) mainboard, rising to a high of 99.5 Singapore cents. The firm, which has constructed and developed over 80 projects in Singapore, Malaysia, Vietnam, and China, opened at 88 Singapore cents and saw 266,500 shares traded by 9:56 am. The listing brings the total number of SGX-listed property companies to 80, with a market capitalization of over S$180 billion.

site_title: Abu Dhabi sovereign wealth fund to buy HK hotels in US$2.4b deal
summary: Abu Dhabi's sovereign wealth fund, ADIA, agreed to purchase three Hong Kong hotels from New World Development Co Ltd in a HK$18.5 billion deal, marking ADIA's largest Asian property investment. New World will sell its interests in Grand Hyatt Hong Kong, Renaissance Harbour View, and Hyatt Regency Hong Kong to a 50-50 joint venture with ADIA. The deal also involves a minority holder, Chow Tai Folk Enterprise, receiving about $500 million. This marks the second real estate-related investment by a Middle Eastern fund in Hong Kong in six months, as sovereign wealth funds seek stable returns.

site_title: Airbus keeps targets as jet programmes on track
summary: Airbus reported its commercial jet programmes are on track, confirming its full-year guidance despite a dip in underlying first-quarter profit. The company expects higher deliveries and a higher order book for 2015, with production goals and asset sales to be reviewed by the end of the year. Revenue fell 5% to 12.078 billion euros, while operating income before one-off items fell 7% to 651 million euros. Airbus aims to achieve breakeven in free cashflow in 2015 and expects slightly higher deliveries and revenue for the year.

site_title: Australia: Shares extend decline, NZ steadier
summary: Australian shares fell 1.4% to their lowest level in seven weeks, with the S&P/ASX 200 index closing at 5,754.3. Iron ore prices weighed on mining shares, while uncertainty over the Reserve Bank of Australia's interest rate decision kept banks under pressure. New Zealand's benchmark NZX50 index edged up 0.3%, driven by consumer- and construction-related shares.

site_title: Nomura Q4 net profit climbs to 9-year high on strong retail performance
summary: Nomura Holdings reported a 5.2% increase in annual net profit to 224.8 billion yen, a 9-year high, driven by strong performance from its retail and investment banking divisions. The Japanese bank's overseas operations, however, remained in the red for a fifth year. Despite US$1 billion in cost cuts since the purchase of Lehman Brothers' assets in 2008, Nomura has struggled to turn around its European and Asian operations. The bank's shares have risen 12% year-to-date, in line with Tokyo's market gains.

images.alt_text: Nomura Holdings on Thursday said annual net profit rose 5.2 per cent on a strong performance by its retail and investment banking divisions although its overseas operations were in the red for a fifth year in a row.

site_title: Panda bonds capture foreign interest
summary: Foreign interest is growing in China's Panda bond market ahead of potential rule changes that could encourage more foreign issuers. The People's Bank of China's monetary easing has driven onshore renminbi bond yields below their offshore equivalents, making Panda bonds more appealing. Chinese regulators may relax restrictions on capital movements and accounting standards for entities in the Shanghai Free Trade Zone, which could boost the market. Only one foreign company, Daimler, has issued a Panda bond since 2010, and corporations have complained about the onerous regulatory framework and lack of currency convertibility.

images.alt_text: Foreign interest is building in China's Panda bond market ahead of potential rule changes that bankers expect to encourage more offerings.

site_title: More upbeat business sentiment in manufacturing sector for April-Sept: poll
summary: Singapore's manufacturing sector is expected to experience more positive business sentiment from April to September, according to a survey. 13% of manufacturers anticipate an improvement, while 8% expect a decline. The electronics sector is the most optimistic, with 19% projecting improved business conditions. Output is also expected to increase, with 9% of manufacturers anticipating higher production. The sector also plans to invest in plant and machinery, with 55% expecting higher or similar capital expenditure.

site_title: Oil prices mixed in Asian trade
summary: Oil prices were mixed in Asian trade on Thursday, with US benchmark West Texas Intermediate rising 8 cents to $58.66 a barrel, while Brent fell 27 cents to $65.57 a barrel. The US economy's first quarter growth fell short of forecasts at 0.2%, citing deep-lying problems including slowing exports and consumer spending. Weaker dollar and cutbacks in US oil output also supported prices, with inventories at the Cushing oil terminal hub declining for the first time since November.

images.alt_text: Oil prices were mixed in Asia Thursday after first quarter US economic growth fell short of forecasts but a weaker dollar and easing US crude production provided support, analysts said.

site_title: China shipbuilding sector set to contract: Yangzijiang
summary: China's biggest privately owned shipyard, Yangzijiang Shipbuilding Holdings Ltd, expects the country's shipbuilding industry to contract significantly over the next three years, potentially reducing the number of active shipyards from over 100 to 30. Orders have fallen 77% in the first quarter, with the industry's utilization rate at 60% this year, lower than the global average. Yangzijiang is reviewing a proposal to buy a stake in the shipbuilding and offshore engineering businesses of China Huarong Energy Co, which is seeking to sell its assets amid a slump in contracts and competition with state-owned vessel builders.

site_title: Nokia's telecom network profit drops in first quarter
summary: Nokia's telecom network profit dropped to 85 million euros (S$124.4 million) in the first quarter, 3.2% of sales, below market forecasts of 226 million euros. Sales at the networks business were 15% ahead of forecasts, but core operating profit fell due to lower software sales and higher costs. The company's full-year networks profitability forecast remains at 8-11% non-IFRS operating margins.

site_title: Singtel tops Asean governance ranking for second year
summary: Singtel has topped the Asean governance ranking for the second consecutive year, with an average score of 70.7 out of 128 points. Singapore companies scored an average of 67 points on basic governance requirements, with modest improvements in shareholders' rights and stakeholder treatment. The top 10 Singapore companies in the assessment include Singtel, Singapore Exchange, and DBS Group Holdings. Associate Professor Lawrence Loh warned that Singapore companies risk falling behind their Asean counterparts if they don't strengthen their governance performance.

site_title: Asia: Stocks down after weak US data, Tokyo hit by strong yen
summary: Asian stocks declined after weak US growth data, with Tokyo falling 1.91% and Hong Kong losing 0.39%. The dollar slipped to a near two-month low against the euro due to reduced expectations of a US interest rate hike. Greece's potential bailout deal with creditors also boosted the euro. The US economy grew at 0.2% in January-February, far below forecasts, but the Federal Reserve still expects a moderate pace of expansion.

site_title: Air China says Q1 net profit surged due to cheaper fuel
summary: Air China reported a 1.8 billion yuan surge in Q1 net profit, largely due to a significant decrease in jet fuel prices. The airline's fuel expense accounts for about 40% of its operating costs. Despite this, the company's Hong Kong-listed shares declined 1.85% ahead of the earnings announcement. The favorable fuel prices helped offset the decline in the airline's shares, which lagged the Hang Seng index's 0.15% fall.

site_title: Billionaire Valencia owner Peter Lim said to hire LVMH dealmaker Teo
summary: Singapore billionaire Peter Lim hired LVMH dealmaker Christina Teo as CEO of his investment unit, Catpital Pte, to source overseas investments and increase value at his existing portfolio companies. Teo, former managing director at L Capital Asia, will focus on industries where Lim has experience such as sports, automobiles, healthcare, and hospitality. Lim's investments include Valencia soccer team, McLaren Automotive, and Singapore property developer Rowsley Ltd. The move is part of Lim's effort to diversify his portfolio and increase value in the long term.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks stabilise; techs, banks flat
summary: Taiwan's stocks remained stable on Thursday, edging up 0.2% to 9,869.47, after a 1% decline in the previous session. The main TAIEX index was driven by a 0.612% increase in the Taiwan dollar to T$30.507 to the US dollar. The financial and electronics sectors were flat, with no significant changes reported. Markets in Taiwan will be closed on Friday for Labour Day.

site_title: CIMB plans further cost cuts before switching to revenue focus
summary: CIMB Group Holdings Bhd, Malaysia's second-largest lender, plans further cost cuts before shifting its focus to revenue growth next year. The bank, led by CEO Tengku Zafrul Abdul Aziz, aims to achieve cost reductions on top of previous savings from office closures and job cuts. Following the abandonment of a three-way merger with domestic rivals in January, CIMB will focus on building loan growth and customer base this year, with revenue growth to follow in 2016. The bank's CEO emphasized the need to balance cost reduction with revenue growth to achieve long-term success.

site_title: In China, focus of monetary easing turns to surgical strikes
summary: China's central bank is shifting its focus to targeted monetary easing, rather than implementing broad quantitative easing like its counterparts in the US, Japan, and Europe. The People's Bank of China has taken steps to bolster local-government bonds and recapitalize policy banks to boost lending to preferred projects, aiming to contain overall financing while channeling funds to key sectors. The strategy aims to avoid a credit crunch and growth slump, while reducing debt in an economy reliant on investment-driven growth. However, economists warn that more conventional easing may be needed to address slowing growth.

site_title: Thai central bank relaxes curbs on capital flows
summary: Thailand's central bank relaxed curbs on capital outflows to weaken a strong baht that hurts exports. Thais can now freely purchase foreign currencies up to $5 million and properties overseas up to $50 million per year. The bank also removed restrictions on capital inflows. The move aims to boost the economy by encouraging investment.

site_title: Google's YouTube touts growth in mobile users at New York event
summary: YouTube reported a 40% year-over-year increase in daily visitors and an 80% jump in time spent on mobile, according to CEO Susan Wojcicki. The growth is seen as a key factor in attracting more marketers and competing with rivals like Hulu, Facebook, and Yahoo. The company is investing in features to draw marketers and keep pace with the growing competition. The "Brandcast" event in New York featured performances by popular artists, showcasing YouTube's efforts to engage users and advertisers.

site_title: Bank lending down for fourth straight month in March: MAS
summary: Bank lending in Singapore fell for the fourth consecutive month in March, with loans standing at S$601 billion, a 0.4% decline from February. Business loans dropped 0.8% to S$364 billion, while consumer lending rose 0.2% to S$238 billion. Year-over-year growth was 2.3%, weaker than the 3.3% gain in February.

site_title: Sino Construction drops contracts worth S$122.5m in revamp (source amendment)
summary: Sino Construction, a Singapore-based construction company, has dropped contracts worth S$122.5 million as part of a corporate revamp. The company aims to invest in low-risk, low-to-medium capital-intensive projects in the energy sector, with a focus on renewable energy. This move is expected to enable the group to pay a consistent dividend over time, following a S$7 million net loss in its latest quarter. The company is restructuring its business by selling non-performing assets and plans to explore opportunities in regional energy networks.

site_title: McDonald's supplier gets Beijing's biggest pollution fine: Xinhua
summary: A McDonald's joint venture in China, Beijing Simplot Food Processing, has been fined a record 3.9 million yuan (S$832,000) for water pollution, the largest fine ever issued by Beijing. The fine was levied by the municipal environmental watchdog for the supplier's failure to meet environmental standards. The joint venture, which supplies French fries to McDonald's outlets in Beijing, is a partnership between US agribusiness J.R. Simplot Company, McDonald's, and the Beijing Agricultural, Industrial and Commerce General Company.

site_title: BOK says oil prices stunting inflation, dismisses deflation concerns
summary: The Bank of Korea (BOK) stated that low global oil prices have reduced inflation in South Korea by an average 1.1 to 1.3 percentage points per month this year. This has prevented inflation from rising by 1.3 percentage points above current levels. The BOK dismissed concerns of deflation, citing that oil prices have a limited impact on future inflation forecasts.

site_title: DBS peddling higher yield boosts structured note sales in Europe
summary: DBS Group Holdings, Southeast Asia's largest lender, has expanded its structured note sales in Europe, with European sales increasing after forming an alliance with Leonteq AG. Investors are seeking higher yields, with Asian credits offering 4.01% and European investment-grade corporate bonds at 1.02%. DBS has seen a 200% increase in transactions since signing the partnership, driven by demand for Asian products from European-based institutional investors. The trend is expected to persist as investors seek yield in the euro zone amid quantitative easing.

site_title: 'We are all Chinese!' Mainlander anger over Hong Kong curbs
summary: Residents in Shenzhen, China, are outraged by new restrictions on travel to Hong Kong, citing "one country, two systems" as strained. The influx of mainland tourists has raised tensions, with protests by Hong Kongers against Beijing's influence and the economic strain on the territory. The restrictions aim to curb the flow of people and goods, but have sparked anger among mainlanders who consider themselves part of China. The tensions reflect the model's strain at both ends, with demands for greater democracy in Hong Kong and concerns about China's growing influence.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open 0.39% lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened 0.39% lower on Thursday, following the release of US data showing a slower-than-expected economic growth in the first three months of the year. The Hang Seng Index fell 111.20 points to 28,289.14. In contrast, the Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.27% and the Shenzhen Composite Index added 0.81%.

site_title: Brazil's central bank raises rates again
summary: Brazil's central bank raised its key interest rate to 13.25% for the fifth consecutive time, aiming to curb inflation despite a slowing economy. The move, the highest level since 2009, follows inflation of 6.41% in 2014. President Dilma Rousseff has responded by cutting the budget while protecting social programs. The economy has been slowing since booming growth, with 2014 growth at 0.1%.

site_title: Malaysia's Malakoff raises US$769m in IPO priced at top of range
summary: Malaysia's Malakoff Corporation Bhd raised US$769 million in an initial public offering (IPO) priced at the top of expectations, fetching 2.74 billion ringgit. The strong demand comes despite economic headwinds, including slumping global energy prices. The IPO was oversubscribed 14 times by institutional investors, with the majority of proceeds used to repay debt.

site_title: South Korea March manufacturing output misses forecasts, recovery ongoing
summary: South Korea's industrial output fell 0.4% in March from February, missing forecasts, but officials attribute it to a strong February growth. The economy is expected to recover in the second quarter, with growth forecasted to be stronger than the first quarter. Industrial output was dragged down by a decline in electronic goods production, particularly LCD panels. Despite this, the country's economy grew 0.8% in the first quarter, slightly beating expectations.

site_title: Taiwan GDP growth accelerates on consumption, technology exports
summary: Taiwan's GDP growth accelerated to 3.46% in the first quarter of 2015, driven by improved consumption and electronics exports. Strong global demand for tech products, including the iPhone 6, boosted exports, despite a decline in petrochemical shipments due to cheaper oil. The country's economy is expected to expand 3.55% this year, surpassing 2014's growth rate. This growth is attributed to manufacturing improvements, low unemployment, and rising wages, which will likely boost consumer confidence.

site_title: Japan March factory output down 0.3% mth/mth
summary: Japanese industrial output fell 0.3% in March, marking a second consecutive decline. The drop was smaller than the 2.3% forecast. Manufacturers expect a 2.1% rise in April and a 0.3% decline in May.

site_title: IndoAgri ends Q1 with negative working capital as profit tumbles 80.7% on weak sales and rupiah
summary: IndoAgri's Q1 net profit plummeted 80.7% to 35.03 billion rupiah due to weak sales and foreign exchange losses. Revenue fell 16% to 2.66 trillion rupiah, with its plantation division experiencing a 24% drop in revenue. The company reported negative working capital of 979 billion rupiah and negative net cash flows from operations of 25 billion rupiah. Despite low season and high working capital, IndoAgri expects long-term demand for palm oil to remain strong and is reviewing its funding arrangement to optimize its capital structure.

site_title: UOB posts 1.6% increase in Q1 net profit to S$801 million
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) reported a 1.6% year-on-year increase in Q1 net profit to S$801 million, slightly under market expectations. Net interest income rose 8.3% to S$1.2 billion, driven by improved loan pricing and higher securities yield. Loans grew at 7.8% to S$203 billion, while the loan-to-deposit ratio was 83.4%.

site_title: Yangzijiang's Q1 net profit slips 12% on weaker shipbuilding market
summary: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding reported a 12% decline in Q1 net profit to 706.88 million yuan due to a weaker shipbuilding market. Revenue fell 14% to 3 billion yuan, with shipbuilding contributing 2.75 billion yuan (90% of revenue). The company delivered 10 vessels in Q1, a 26% increase from the previous year. Yangzijiang attributed the decline to China's shipbuilding industry's overcapacity issue, with a utilization rate of 60% in 2015. The company's order book is expected to keep yards utilized until the end of 2016.

images.alt_text: Yangzijian Shipbuilding reported on Thursday that its net profit for the first quarter ended March 31, 2015 fell 12 per cent from a year ago to 706.88 million yuan.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks fall 1.05% at open as Honda, Takeda drop on weak earnings
summary: Tokyo stocks fell 1.05% at the start of Thursday, with Honda plummeting 7.6% and Takeda dropping 5.6% on weak earnings reports. Honda's profit drops were linked to air-bag recalls, while Takeda agreed to pay $2.4 billion to settle US lawsuits over its diabetes drug Actos. The US economy nearly stalled in the first quarter, with growth at 0.2%, below projections. The Bank of Japan's meeting concluded without rate hikes, and the dollar slipped to 118.95 yen.

site_title: Yahoo CEO's compensation jumps 69% to US$42.1m
summary: Yahoo CEO Marissa Mayer's compensation increased 69% to $42.1 million in 2014, driven by stock and option awards. The value of her compensation rose as Yahoo's stock price rose, according to a US Securities and Exchange Commission filing. The majority of the grants were made in 2012 and 2013 but must be considered 2014 grants under compliance rules. Mayer's total compensation includes $10.5 million in base salary and $31.6 million in stock and option awards.

site_title: Raffles Education to issue S$30 million of fixed rate notes due 2018
summary: Raffles Education Corp plans to issue S$30 million of fixed-rate notes due 2018 with a 5.9% annual interest rate. The maturity date is May 3, 2018, and funds will be used for general corporate funding, refinancing existing borrowings, working capital, and capital expenditure. Interest is payable semi-annually, starting from November 3 this year.

site_title: Bank of Japan holds fire on stimulus despite tepid inflation
summary: The Bank of Japan maintained its easy monetary policy despite weak inflation, which has remained flat despite massive stimulus measures since 2013. The central bank voted to keep its stimulus program unchanged, with Governor Haruhiko Kuroda warning that bringing Japan's inflation to 2% could take time. Economists expect further easing measures later this year to meet the inflation target. Japan's factory output fell 0.3% in March, highlighting an anaemic recovery in the country's economy.

images.alt_text: The Bank of Japan held off more easing measures after a policy meeting Thursday, despite flatlining inflation that is defying massive stimulus launched two years ago.

site_title: South Korea housing prices rise for 20th month in April
summary: South Korea's housing prices rose for the 20th consecutive month in April, with an annual growth of 2.62%, the fastest gain in nearly three years. This is according to Kookmin Bank's housing purchase price composite index, which increased 0.49% from March. The previous fastest annual growth was seen in June 2012, when prices rose 3.04%. This marks the 20th month of rising housing prices in South Korea, with no indication of a decline in the near future.

site_title: Britain's Sun newspaper comes out for Cameron's Conservatives in election
summary: Britain's best-selling newspaper, The Sun, has endorsed Prime Minister David Cameron's Conservatives in the upcoming election, citing economic concerns and a promise of a EU referendum. The newspaper, which previously supported Labour, made the decision after a five-year wait and an "appalling" Labour performance. With the election neck and neck between Conservatives and Labour, The Sun's endorsement is seen as a significant boost for Cameron's party.

site_title: mm2 Asia enters MOU to buy two cinemas in Malaysia for RM40m
summary: mm2 Asia has entered into a non-binding MOU to acquire two cinemas in Malaysia for RM40 million (S$14.9 million). The cinemas, Cathay Cineplex City Square and Cathay Cineplex Damansara, have a total of 30 screens. The acquisition is aimed at diversifying and expanding into the film production value chain, providing a source of recurring income. A one-per-cent payment is due upon signing, with the remaining amount paid in phases upon completion of the acquisition.

site_title: Singapore: ST Index falls 0.46% at Thursday opening
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) fell 15.88 points or 0.46% to 3,471.27 in early trading on Thursday, following declines on Wall Street and European markets. Losers outnumbered gainers 93 to 65, with shares in UOB and OCBC Bank declining despite their respective Q1 profit rises. The volume of shares traded stood at 144.4 million, worth about S$361.8 million.

site_title: Stocks to watch: OCBC, UOB, Yangzijiang
summary: OCBC Bank reported a 11% year-on-year increase in net profit to S$993 million, beating expectations. UOB posted a net profit of S$801 million, 1.6% higher than the previous year, but narrowly missing market expectations. Yangzijiang Shipbuilding reported a 12% decline in net profit to 706.88 million yuan due to a 14% decrease in revenue. The Chinese shipbuilder delivered 10 vessels in the first quarter, but faces an overcapacity issue in the industry.

site_title: Twitter pins ad revenue hopes on new partnership, acquisition
summary: Twitter Inc has cut ad rates for its new "direct response" ads, impacting quarterly revenue by $4-5 million, following a revenue warning and 8.9% drop in shares after the announcement. The company's CEO, Dick Costolo, attributed the move to the ads' failure to deliver as promised. Twitter is hoping to reassure disaffected ad buyers with the success of two new deals announced alongside the revenue warning.

site_title: BOJ seen keeping policy steady barring big cut in inflation forecast
summary: The Bank of Japan is expected to maintain its current monetary policy, keeping interest rates steady despite trimming its inflation forecast to 1.0% for this fiscal year, down from 1.0% previously. The BOJ hopes rising wages will boost spending and sustain economic recovery. Despite weak data, policymakers are hesitant to ease monetary policy due to concerns about yen depreciation and offsetting benefits. The central bank's inflation target of 2% by March 2016 remains unchanged, with forecasts suggesting a 2% target in the following two years.

site_title: OCBC beats expectations with 11% rise in net profit for Q1
summary: OCBC reported an 11% increase in net profit to S$993 million for Q1 2015, beating analyst expectations of S$911 million. Strong earnings growth across key markets drove the increase, with net interest income rising 15% and customer loans growing 20%. Customer deposits increased 26% to S$250 billion, but net interest margin declined 8 basis points. OCBC's annualized earnings per share were 99.7 Singapore cents, down from 101.6 cents a year ago. The bank plans to invest in its businesses and leverage synergies to pursue sustainable growth.

site_title: Federal Reserve leaves open timeframe for interest rate rise
summary: The US Federal Reserve left interest rate hikes open-ended, citing a winter slowdown that stalled US economic growth. Despite a 0.2% annual growth pace in the first quarter, the Fed expects the economy to resume expanding at a "moderate pace" and may begin rate rises in the coming months. The central bank believes labor market improvement and inflation picking up over the medium term will justify rate increases. The Fed also noted a strength in consumer spending and expected jobs market to continue improving.

site_title: Beijing support emboldens critics among China's businessmen
summary: China's government has been emboldening private entrepreneurs to criticize the state-dominated economy, with Premier Li Keqiang's policies and rhetoric supporting small businesses. Critics, such as air conditioner and home appliance maker Zheng Jianjiang, are speaking out against unequal business opportunities and favoritism towards state-linked enterprises. The private sector is also targeting government bureaucracy, citing lengthy approval procedures and corruption. Experts say the criticism is a recognition that the government is trying to help, with non-state sector accounting for 80% of employment and economic activity, but still facing skewed bank lending and higher interest rates.

site_title: Oil rises as dollar eases, Cushing stockpiles fall
summary: Oil prices rose as the US dollar weakened, with US benchmark West Texas Intermediate (WTI) increasing $1.52 to close at $58.58 a barrel. The decline in US crude inventories at the Cushing terminal, the first in over four months, also contributed to the price increase. The dollar's drop, which made dollar-priced crude oil cheaper for international buyers, provided additional support.

site_title: Microsoft courts app makers with dive into Windows 10
summary: Microsoft is courting app developers with its upcoming Windows 10 operating system, promising a potential audience of over 1 billion people. The company has opened up its platform to allow developers to reuse code written for Apple or Android devices, saving time and money. Microsoft plans to give Windows 10 away as a free upgrade for a year after its release, with the goal of reaching 1 billion devices within two to three years. The company also showcased its HoloLens augmented reality headgear and Azure data handling services, highlighting its vision for a flexible and adaptable platform.

site_title: Fiat Chrysler pushes to boost margins as CEO pitches for a deal
summary: Fiat Chrysler Automobiles (FCA) CEO Sergio Marchionne is pushing for industry consolidation to boost margins as the company reports lower-than-expected first quarter results. Marchionne argues that large-scale integrations are required to sustain capital investments in cleaner, safer vehicles. He also considers a deal with Silicon Valley companies like Google or Apple, which could assemble vehicles as contractors, to change the paradigm. FCA aims to increase North American profit margins to GM and Ford's levels by 2018, starting with a target of 5.5-6% by the end of the year.

images.alt_text: Fiat Chrysler Automobiles Chief Executive Sergio Marchionne on Wednesday made a plea for shrinking the number of players in the global auto industry as the company reported lower-than-expected first quarter results and outlined new plans to boost North American profit margins.

site_title: Greek deal possible, little contagion if not: Irish fin min
summary: Ireland's finance minister Michael Noonan suggests a Greek deal is possible, with little contagion effect if not reached. Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras reshuffled his team handling talks with creditors, a move seen as an effort to relegate embattled Finance Minister Yanis Varoufakis. Noonan believes Greece's problems can be fixed without debt write-offs, and the euro zone is better positioned to withstand a Greek default, with "very little contagion effect" for Ireland and Europe.

site_title: Buffett serenades Coca-Cola investors to quell growth concerns
summary: Warren Buffett, Coca-Cola's top shareholder, reassured investors that the company will be fine as long as it listens to consumers. Buffett appeared at the company's annual meeting, stating that Coca-Cola's products, including its iconic brand since 1886, will continue to thrive. He countered criticism that the company's products are unhealthy, citing his own consumption of Coca-Cola as evidence of his health. The meeting came as Coca-Cola faces slowing global sales and a 3.4% decline in shares this year. Buffett's endorsement boosted investor confidence in the company.

site_title: MAS removes hurdles for simple investment funds
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has simplified its rules for retail investors to invest in simple investment funds, excluding those that use derivatives for hedging or efficient portfolio management purposes. The changes aim to boost ETF trades, and the Singapore Exchange (SGX) will waive ETF clearing fees from June 1 to December 31, 2015. This move is expected to increase accessibility to retail investors, with up to 12 more ETFs potentially converting to exempt investment product status, accounting for 80% of assets under management on SGX.

images.alt_text: Retail investors no longer have to run the gauntlet just to invest in simple investment funds.

site_title: Solar yieldcos hit a bump as US$242m IPO pulled in France
summary: Solar yieldcos face a setback as a French developer, Solairedirect SA, postpones a US$242 million IPO due to investor concerns over funding developments in subsidy-free regions. The decision marks a road bump for the industry, which raised US$5 billion in the past year. Analysts attribute the delay to investors' discomfort with the industry's long-term, low-risk profile and lack of subsidies. Despite this, Solairedirect may reattempt the IPO later and remains committed to its growth plans for this year and next.

site_title: UK consumer confidence holds at 12-year high ahead of election: GfK
summary: UK consumer confidence remains at a 12-year high in April, staying at +4 according to GfK. Despite a slight improvement in views of the economy and personal finances over the past year, optimism about the coming year remains unchanged. The mixed news presents a challenge for Prime Minister David Cameron ahead of the May 7 election, with the Conservative Party facing a deadlocked opinion poll with the Labour Party. Recent economic data has been mixed, with economic growth slowing in the first quarter.

images.alt_text: British consumer morale held steady at its highest level in more than 12 years in April, mixed news for Prime Minister David Cameron before the May 7 national election, according to researchers GfK.

site_title: Moody's cuts Greece rating further into junk: Caa2
summary: Moody's downgraded Greece's debt to Caa2, one step above junk territory, citing high uncertainty over reaching a new agreement with creditors to make upcoming debt payments. The rating agency expresses concerns over the country's ability to meet budget requirements and targets, given its weakened economy and fragile domestic environment. Moody's left Greece on a negative outlook for another possible downgrade, citing the high uncertainty of negotiations and the potential for a policy accident resulting in default.

site_title: You might call shale a bust, but Franklin calls it opportunity
summary: Franklin Resources Inc is investing heavily in the US shale energy sector, despite declining oil prices, as its lead manager Ed Perks sees it as an "opportunity" for investors. The firm has increased its stake in energy stocks and bonds to 16.3% of its flagship fund, targeting struggling energy companies with shrinking credit lines. Franklin's investments aim to give it a seat at the negotiating table in the event of bankruptcies, with the firm potentially becoming the largest creditor to distressed energy companies.

site_title: US news industry struggling with shift to mobile: study
summary: The US news industry is struggling with a shift to mobile, with digital revenues remaining a "wish list" for news organizations, according to a Pew Research Center report. The industry saw declines in print circulation and advertising, with television news being a rare bright spot. Newspapers experienced a 3% drop in daily and Sunday circulation, and advertising revenue fell 4% to $19.9 billion. Digital ad revenue grew to $50.7 billion, but mobile ads account for only 37% of all digital ad spending.

site_title: Europe: Equities sink on slowing US growth
summary: European stocks plummeted on Wednesday, with Frankfurt's DAX 30 index falling 3.21% and Paris's CAC 40 index losing 2.59% due to weak US economic growth data and anticipation of the Federal Reserve's monetary policy meeting. London's FTSE 100 index also declined 1.20%. The decline was attributed to concerns about US growth and potential policy changes.

site_title: Samsung regains lead over Apple in smartphone market
summary: Samsung regained its lead in the global smartphone market in the first quarter, selling 82.4 million units for a 24.5% market share. This surpassed Apple's 61.2 million units and 18.2% market share. Despite a 7% decline in sales, Samsung's gains in emerging markets drove its success. The global smartphone market grew 16.7% to 337 million units, with Lenovo and Huawei trailing behind. The lead is attributed to Samsung's midrange and lower-priced smartphones and its new flagship Galaxy S6 and S6 Edge models.

site_title: Francois Michelin, who took French tiremaker global, dies at 88
summary: Francois Michelin, the grandson of Michelin & Cie.'s founder, has died at 88. As head of the French tiremaker for almost half a century, he expanded global operations, opening 25 factories outside France, and introduced the radial tire, boosting revenue outside Europe. Michelin sold Citroen to Peugeot in 1976, buying Uniroyal Goodrich Tire Co. in 1990 to strengthen his company's position in America. He was praised by former employees, including Carlos Ghosn, for his values and vision.

site_title: China's Tencent to buy stake in mobile game maker Glu Mobile
summary: China's Tencent Holdings Ltd is buying a 14.6% stake in mobile game maker Glu Mobile Inc for $126 million. Tencent will acquire 12.5 million shares immediately and an additional 8.5 million shares in a future transaction. The deal aims to expand Tencent's presence in the mobile gaming market and enhance Glu Mobile's global reach.

site_title: BlackRock warns of emerging market rout after Fed raises rates
summary: BlackRock warns of a potential emerging market rout after the Federal Reserve raises interest rates, citing a painful sell-off similar to 2013. The US central bank's rate hike could lead to a 10% decline in developing nation debt and currency plunges. Nations like Mexico, Poland, and South Korea are seen as better prepared due to strong balance sheets, while countries like India and Indonesia may experience significant stress despite their dynamic economies. Flexible exchange rates across developing countries may help limit the fallout.

site_title: Apple finds defects with Apple Watch component
summary: Apple has found defects with a key component of its Apple Watch, the taptic engine, which produces the sensation of being tapped on the wrist. The component, supplied by AAC Technologies Holdings Inc, started to break down over time, prompting Apple to limit its availability and source nearly all components from another supplier, Nidec Corp. This may take time to increase production, affecting the already limited supply of the product. The issue does not impact sales figures, with demand outstripping supply, according to CEO Tim Cook.

images.alt_text: Apple Inc has found defects with a key component of its Apple Watch, prompting it to limit availability of the product, the Wall Street Journal reported on Wednesday, citing people familiar with the matter.

site_title: Indonesia coal miners move on as cash runs out
summary: Indonesian coal miners are diversifying into other businesses due to a collapse in demand from China, resulting in the lowest free cash flow in months. The 15 biggest coal miners and contractors averaged $10.7 million in free cash flow in December, with six firms experiencing negative cash flow. Industry leaders expect a 24% decline in coal production this year, citing China's slowdown and the government's plan to double coal royalties, which has sparked criticism from the industry.

site_title: Does size matter?
summary: Philippine conglomerate Ayala Group's president, Fernando Zobel de Ayala, suggests that investing in mega cities is costly and often unsuccessful, citing examples like Myanmar. In contrast, CT Corp's Chairul Tanjung believes investing in smaller, secondary cities can offer better returns. Singapore's CapitaLand, which operates in China, notes that factors like government support and master planning are also crucial. Experts agree that the size of a city alone is not enough to determine its potential, and that other factors such as government quality and local support play a significant role.

site_title: Parkway Life Reit posts 14% rise in DPU
summary: Parkway Life Reit, a Singapore-based healthcare real estate investment trust, reported a 14% year-on-year increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to 3.21 Singapore cents for the first quarter of 2015. The Reit's distributable income grew 14% to S$19.46 million, driven by gains from divestment and foreign exchange. The Reit expects new properties acquired in Japan to contribute to revenue from Q2, with gearing remaining at a healthy level of 34.4%. The company attributed its strong performance to its first-mover advantage in the growing Japan elderly healthcare market.

site_title: US: Stocks fall on poor Q1 growth
summary: US stocks fell on Wednesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 74.61 points (0.41%) to 18,035.53, and the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Indexes also declined. The economy grew 0.2% in the first quarter, below analysts' 1.0% projection, due to harsh winter weather and a West Coast port strike. The Federal Reserve hinted at possible rate hikes, but not in June. Twitter fell 8.9%, while Salesforce rose 11.6% and Mondelez International gained 5.2%.

site_title: Baidu revenue climbs while profit slips
summary: Baidu reported a 34% increase in quarterly revenue to $2.053 billion, driven by strong use of smartphones to access its services. However, net income dropped 3.4% to $395.1 million. Mobile revenue accounted for 50% of total revenue, a 42% increase from the same period last year. Baidu CEO Robin Li attributed the growth to the company's comprehensive and robust platform, which is well-suited for mobile users.

site_title: Qatar launches plant to capture wasted gas
summary: Qatar has officially unveiled a US$1 billion plant to capture wasted gas, dubbed the Jetty Boil-Off Gas Recovery Project (JBOG). The project aims to capture enough gas to power 175,000 cars or 300,000 homes annually, making it the world's largest environmental project.

site_title: Nepal ruin was waiting to happen: expert
summary: Nepal's devastating earthquake, which killed over 4,300 people and caused $2 billion in economic losses, was preventable with better oversight of the country's building code. The code, formulated 20 years ago, includes information to prevent buildings from crumbling, but its implementation has been hindered by lack of political will and inadequate verification. Experts say that Nepal's rapid urban expansion, coupled with its high seismic risk and mountainous topography, made the disaster inevitable. Implementing stricter building codes, like those in Japan and New Zealand, could help mitigate future disasters.

site_title: China moves to let market play bigger role as economy slows
summary: China is moving to let its market play a bigger role in the economy as it slows down, aiming to integrate its markets with global counterparts to raise its international status. Financial reforms include easing foreign participation in the interbank market, streamlining IPO procedures, and liberalizing interest rates. The government also plans to make Shanghai an international financial center by 2020, with the goal of making China a more capital-driven economy. These reforms are part of a long-term plan to generate growth and globalize its markets.

site_title: ISDN's Q1 net profit up from S$0.1m to S$2.9m
summary: ISDN Holdings' Q1 net profit surged to S$2.9 million from S$0.1 million, driven by 20.8% increase in group revenue to S$52.2 million, mainly from its motion control business segment. Sales in this segment rose 28.9% to S$40.7 million. The group's earnings per share jumped to 0.81 Singapore cent and net asset value per share rose to 38.15 Singapore cents.

site_title: 'Knife-edge' UK election to be decided in Scotland
summary: The UK general election on May 7 is expected to be a "knife-edge" decision, with Scotland's shift towards the Scottish National Party (SNP) potentially influencing the outcome. The SNP's surge in support since last year's independence referendum could lead to a significant increase in its seats, threatening the UK's territorial integrity and potentially leading to a second independence ballot. This development, combined with the rise of other "third parties," reflects the changing UK politics landscape, where a dominant two-party system is giving way to a more unpredictable and uncertain environment, potentially leading to a hung parliament and domestic economic uncertainty.

site_title: Indonesian executions spark international anger
summary: Indonesia executed seven foreign drug convicts, including two Australians, one Brazilian, and four Nigerians, on April 29, 2015, sparking international anger. Australia withdrew its ambassador, Brazil expressed "deep regret" and France vowed a diplomatic battle to save a citizen still on death row. Indonesia defended the executions as a crucial front in its "war" on drugs, despite international pleas for clemency. The European Union and United Nations also condemned the executions, calling for a moratorium on further killings.

site_title: AA Reit posts 16.3% rise in DPU for Q4
summary: AA Reit reported a 16.3% year-on-year increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.92 Singapore cents for Q4 FY2015, driven by a full quarter of contribution from Phase Three of 20 Gul Way. Gross revenue rose 2.1% to S$30.09 million, while net property income climbed 5.5% to S$20.31 million. The Reit maintained high occupancy of 95.8% and is cautious on the outlook for FY2016 due to a challenging business environment.

images.alt_text: The fourth quarter result was boosted by a full quarter's rental contribution from Phase Three of 20 Gul Way, and renewal of leases representing 15,646.7 sq m at a weighted average rental increase of 6.8 per cent on renewals," said Koh Wee Lih, chief executive of the Reit's manager. "Additionally, we maintained high occupancy of 95.8 per cent.

site_title: Walmart to open 115 new stores across China
summary: Walmart plans to expand its presence in China by opening 115 new stores by 2017, aiming to become an integral part of China's economy. The retailer seeks to counter slowing growth by focusing on the online grocery market and improving food safety. The new stores will be opened in cities such as Shanghai and Shenzhen, creating over 30,000 jobs. This expansion comes as global grocery firms face challenges in China, where sales have declined in recent years.

site_title: Iran harassed a US-flagged cargo ship last week: US
summary: The US military reported that Iran's Revolutionary Guards harassed a US-flagged cargo ship, the Maersk Kensington, on April 24, following it for 15-20 minutes in actions deemed aggressive. The incident occurred days before Iran seized control of another cargo vessel, the Maersk Tigris, in the Strait of Hormuz. The US Navy monitored the situation, but no military action was taken. Iran claims the Tigris was seized due to a commercial dispute with Denmark's Maersk group. The US is urging Iran to respect international shipping rules and protocols.

images.alt_text: Iran's Revolutionary Guards "harassed" a US-flagged commercial ship last week in the Gulf, days before seizing control of another cargo vessel in the Strait of Hormuz, the Pentagon said Wednesday.

site_title: AXA banks on customer-centric motto to grow its business
summary: France's largest insurer, AXA, is shifting its business towards data analytics and online operations as part of its customer-centric vision. The company has allocated €950 million (S$1.37 billion) for investments in this area since 2013 and has established a data innovation lab in Paris and a laboratory in Silicon Valley. AXA aims to leverage its position as a composite and multi-channel insurer to differentiate itself and drive growth, particularly in Asia, where it employs over 56,000 agents and 12,000 non-sales staff. The company's ambition is to provide seamless online interactions with customers, allowing them to manage their portfolios and make claims online.

site_title: Mexico City facing office glut after oil dives
summary: Mexico City's financial district, Capital Reforma, is facing an office glut due to the decline in oil prices, which has undermined the economy. At least 10 skyscrapers are under construction, expanding total office space by 40% in the next three years. However, the new buildings are approaching completion as demand for office space falters. Investors, including real estate investment trusts, are concerned about higher vacancies and lower returns, with Fibra Uno, Mexico's biggest Reit, facing significant losses. The district's vacancy rate is expected to rise to 18% by 2017, putting pressure on developers to lower rents.

site_title: Pacific Century headed for delisting?
summary: Pacific Century Regional Developments (PCRD), a Singapore-listed company, is nearing the delisting threshold after months of share buybacks. The company's free float has dropped to 13% due to vehicles controlled by executive chairman Richard Li holding 85.7% of its shares. PCRD recently received shareholders' approval for another share buyback, which could trigger a suspension from trading if it falls below 10%. Speculation is high about a possible privatisation, with some analysts suggesting it may be a restructuring or reorganisation of the company's parent group.

site_title: Aero engine exhibition thrills over 4,800 local students
summary: A Rolls-Royce Trent 1000 engine, used in Boeing's 787 Dreamliner, was exhibited in Singapore, attracting over 4,800 students from 19 schools and institutions. The engine, which traveled overnight to new locations, was displayed as part of the Generation Aerospace project to expose young people to the aerospace industry. The event aimed to build human capital in Singapore's aerospace industry, which contributes 20% to the country's GDP. Students gained hands-on experience and insights from employee volunteers, with one student describing the exhibition as an "invaluable learning experience."

site_title: Under corporate governance code, external auditors required to address shareholders' queries
summary: Singapore's corporate governance code requires external auditors to address shareholders' queries at general meetings. The code states that auditors should be present to address queries about the audit and report. Shareholders can ask questions about the audit, but it is the chairman's role to facilitate the discussion. External auditors are protected from defamation when commenting on their work, but may be reluctant to answer questions due to fear of offending the client. Shareholders should direct questions to the chairman, who should provide an opportunity for auditors to respond.

site_title: S'pore to study possible uses for land under viaducts: SLA
summary: The Singapore Land Authority (SLA) is holding a public consultation to explore the possible uses for land under viaducts. The consultation, from April 29 to May 20, aims to optimize land resources in Singapore. The SLA plans to install basic amenities such as water and electricity to facilitate the use of these 3,000-6,000 sq m spaces, which have been unused for years. The initiative follows the success of the futsal facility under the Thomson flyover, which has proven popular with football enthusiasts.

site_title: US auto safety regulator likely to take action on Jeep, Takata recalls soon
summary: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) is expected to take action within two weeks to accelerate product recalls for Jeep sport utility vehicles and exploding Takata Corp airbags. NHTSA Administrator Mark Rosekind vowed to be as aggressive as possible to minimize dangers posed by the deadly defects. The agency will present a plan of options in each case early next month and is working to accelerate recalls to reduce safety risks.

site_title: Taiwan set to leap past fellow Asian tigers for 4th straight quarter
summary: Taiwan is expected to report its fourth consecutive quarter of economic growth, with a forecast of 3.5% growth in the first quarter, surpassing fellow Asian tigers South Korea and Singapore. This growth is driven by a shift to a more consumer-oriented economy, fueled by the success of companies like HTC and TSMC, which supply Apple's iPhones. The economy's performance is also boosted by a strong labour market and tourism industry, but faces challenges such as deflation and currency gains making exports less competitive.

site_title: OCBC's 360 account ties bonus interest to investment products
summary: OCBC Bank will offer a maximum 3.25% annual interest rate on up to S$60,000 in its 360 accounts, tied to investment products, starting May 1. Customers must credit their salary into the account to earn 1.2% interest, and buying eligible financial products will earn an additional 1% interest. The bank also cut bonus interest for bill payments and credit card spending by half. This move aims to lock customers in and encourages savings and investment, as Singaporeans are not saving and investing enough for retirement.

site_title: German dual-study system aims for skills mastery
summary: Germany's dual-study system, which combines academic studies with on-the-job training, has gained international attention for its effectiveness in producing skilled workers. The program, which has been in place since the 1970s, has seen a significant increase in popularity, with 1,505 courses available in 2014 and 95,000 students enrolled. Companies pay to train students, and graduates often go on to work at their sponsor companies, contributing to the country's Mittelstand (small and medium-sized enterprises) sector, which accounts for over half of Germany's total economic output.

site_title: Headwinds on two fronts
summary: A US Federal Reserve interest rate hike is expected in September, with some predicting it could happen earlier. This may lead to losses in fixed income and equity portfolios. Greece's potential exit from the eurozone is also a concern, with a panellist warning of a 50% devaluation of the Drachma and a meltdown in the economy. Investors are advised to watch the Fed's balance sheet, as a reduction could exacerbate market damage. The global economy faces headwinds from these developments, which may impact markets over the next 18 months.

site_title: Tyson pledges to stop using human antibiotics to raise chickens in US
summary: Tyson Foods, the US's largest chicken producer, has pledged to stop using human antibiotics to raise chickens in its US operations, with a September 2017 deadline. The company will also develop plans to eliminate antibiotic use in its turkeys, cows, and pigs. This move comes as the meat industry takes steps to address the growing public health issue of antibiotic-resistant superbugs, which cause thousands of illnesses and deaths in the US each year. The decision is seen as a "tipping point" for the chicken industry, but critics argue that the change may be too little, too late.

site_title: Blockbuster cancer treatments give US drugmakers a boost
summary: US drugmakers Pfizer, Merck, and Bristol-Myers Squibb reported strong earnings in the first quarter, driven by sales of new cancer medications. Analysts expect each company to have multi-billion-dollar blockbuster treatments by 2018. The treatments, which include immunotherapies, have price tags of up to $150,000 per year, sparking criticism from lawmakers and patient advocates about rising healthcare costs. Despite competition, the companies say their goal is to make these treatments accessible and reduce costs over time by improving patient outcomes.

site_title: ECB raises amount of emergency funds available to Greek banks
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) increased the emergency liquidity available to Greek banks by 1.4 billion euros to 76.9 billion euros, citing the ongoing bailout talks as a reason for the limited increase. The move is part of the ECB's efforts to support the Greek economy amidst a potential slowdown in bailout talks. ECB officials have proposed increasing discounts on securities used as collateral, and the Governing Council may discuss the issue in May. The ECB's support for Greek banks "can't continue indefinitely," with officials emphasizing the need for fundamental reforms.

site_title: Future plans for Mr Lee's Oxley home to respect its historical value: URA, NHB
summary: The Singapore government will not allow the redevelopment of Mr Lee Kuan Yew's Oxley Road home in a way that diminishes its historical significance. The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) and National Heritage Board (NHB) will consider Mr Lee's wishes regarding the property, which he wanted demolished after his daughter moves out. If demolition is deemed necessary, the government will prevent the site from being redeveloped in a way that diminishes its historical value, with plans to maintain the area as a low-rise residential precinct.

site_title: Abe sells trade deal to US Congress with war condolences
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe urged US Congress to support the Trans-Pacific Partnership, a 12-nation trade deal aimed at promoting democracy and freedom in the region. Abe offered "eternal condolences" for American lives lost in World War II and expressed Japan's aim to contribute to peace. He also proposed changes to Japan's pacifist post-war constitution to support US military forces. The deal, excluding China, aims to create a fair and dynamic economic market, but critics remain skeptical, particularly over Japan's wartime record.

site_title: Market sags into mid-week slowdown
summary: The Singapore stock market experienced a mid-week slowdown, with the Straits Times Index (STI) retreating 0.2% or 7.94 points to 3,487.15. Investors awaited the end of the Federal Reserve policy meeting, which may lead to interest rate hikes. Reits declined, with industrial landlord A-Reit falling 4.7%. Notable losers included QT Vascular, which dropped 16.7%, while Pacific Century Regional Developments jumped 9.9% to its highest level since 2002.

site_title: Singapore taps German model to deepen technical skills
summary: Singapore has launched a dual-studies programme with German companies to deepen technical skills and attract leading German firms to set up in Singapore. The "Poly goes UAS" programme sends local polytechnic graduates to Germany for a degree and in-depth work experience, with eight students sponsored by four German firms. The programme aims to strengthen Singapore's engineering talent and increase the presence of German Mittelstand companies in the city-state. The Economic Development Board expects the programme to create opportunities for Singaporeans interested in engineering careers and ultimately attract more German companies to set up regional headquarters in Singapore.

site_title: China's CMBC buys into HK securities firm Quam
summary: China's CMBC, the country's biggest private lender, is in talks to invest up to US$970 million for a controlling stake in Hong Kong-based securities firm Quam Ltd. CMBC would own up to 90.4% of Quam's enlarged share capital if the deal is completed. The proposed deal comes amid a frenzy of activity in China's and Hong Kong's securities industry, driven by a booming margin finance business and expected consolidation. Quam's shares soared 67% on the day trading resumed after a halt. A formal agreement between CMBC and Quam is required for the deal to proceed.

site_title: No takers for Binjai GCB put up for auction by bank
summary: A highly anticipated auction of a rare mortgagee sale of a Good Class Bungalow along Binjai Rise in Singapore did not result in a sale. Despite an opening price of S$19.5 million, no bids were received, with potential buyers opting for private negotiations instead. In contrast, two other properties were sold at the auction: a freehold intermediate terrace house at S$2.25 million and an apartment on the 15th floor of Golden Mile Complex for S$1.4 million.

site_title: Get executives, entrepreneurs to help steer global economy
summary: The Japanese government has nominated Yukitoshi Funo, a former Toyota executive, to join its central bank, marking a departure from the traditional practice of appointing only economists and academics. This move aims to bring industry expertise to monetary policy decisions, which are often made by unelected theoreticians. The article argues that tapping entrepreneurs and executives could provide valuable insights into the real world and help steer the global economy. Several high-profile business leaders, such as Bill Gates and Richard Branson, are suggested as potential candidates to serve at central banks.

site_title: Corporate governance in Muddied Waters
summary: Muddy Waters Research and Iceberg Research, two whistle-blowing firms, are targeting companies with alleged dubious business practices and lapses in corporate governance. Their success rate has been mixed, but their reports often prompt stock price drops and regulatory inquiries. Companies are being forced to respond to the charges, and some have even taken legal action against the whistle-blowers. The trend may mark a turning point in global corporate governance, with smaller companies potentially vulnerable to attacks. To prepare, companies should assess their business, accounting, and governance practices, and engage in good corporate governance to avoid potential attacks.

site_title: India offers more clarity and certainty for foreign investors
summary: India's Finance Minister Arun Jaitley presented the country's federal budget for 2015/16, aiming to accelerate growth, enhance investment, and improve the quality of life for citizens. The budget provided clarity and certainty for foreign investors, including those in Singapore, with several key announcements. The General Anti-Avoidance Rule (GAAR) has been deferred until April 1, 2017, and investments made before March 31, 2017, will be "grandfathered". Non-applicability of Minimum Alternate Tax (MAT) was also clarified, excluding capital gains earned by foreign institutional investors (FIIs). Additionally, indirect transfer taxation and taxation of offshore funds were clarified, providing greater certainty for foreign investors.

site_title: Australia faces ratings downgrade: analysts
summary: Australia risks losing its top credit rating from Standard & Poor's (S&P) for the first time in over two decades due to plunging commodity prices, weaker economic growth, and government difficulties in passing legislation. Goldman Sachs estimates a further A$55 billion hole in the government finances, leading to a potential downgrade. S&P has rated Australia AAA since 2003, and a downgrade could weigh on the nation's currency and lead to increased borrowing costs.

site_title: Oil firm Rex's losses deepen to US$8.15m in Q1
summary: Rex International Holding reported a net loss of US$8.15 million for the first quarter ended March 31, 2015, compared to a net loss of US$2.54 million in the year-ago period. Foreign exchange losses, higher administrative expenses, and losses from jointly controlled entities contributed to the increased losses. Despite a cautious outlook on the oil price slump, the group sees opportunities to take advantage of lower costs for seismic surveys and oil drilling services.

site_title: Boat Quay to get S$5m facelift from early 2016
summary: A S$5 million facelift is set to transform Boat Quay's riverfront promenade in Singapore, starting early 2016. The project, funded by the URA, aims to improve the outdoor dining experience by installing retractable canopies, timber decking, and enhancing landscaping. The makeover will also include new open spaces with public seating and slots for menu boards. Eighty percent of landlords and business owners support the plan, with some expecting a short-term loss in business but anticipating long-term benefits.

site_title: Delisting from SGX not on the agenda so far: Ying Li
summary: Chongqing commercial developer Ying Li International Real Estate has no intentions of delisting from the Singapore Exchange (SGX), despite its shares trading at depressed valuations. Executive Chairman Fang Ming attributes the issue to market problems, not management problems, and is working with state-owned enterprise China Everbright to strengthen fundamentals. The company has a joint project with China Everbright in Beijing and aims to improve market valuations through improved fundamentals, rather than speculation.

site_title: X30 Challenge Singapore prize pool tops S$150,000
summary: The X30 Challenge Singapore has secured a prize pool of over S$150,000 for its upcoming event, the largest in international karting history. Title sponsor Optima Werkz and race sponsor AutoInc EuroSports contributed S$20,000 in cash prizes, while Swiss luxury watchmaker deLaCour Geneve sponsored four limited-edition watches valued at S$28,800 each. The event will feature over 60 drivers from around the world competing in four rounds, with the winner crowned champion at the end of the season.

images.alt_text: deLaCour Geneve will sponsor four watches, each valued at S$28,800, for Saturday's race-karting series

site_title: Economy stalls in Q1, GDP grows at 0.2% rate
summary: US economic growth slowed sharply in Q1, expanding at a 0.2% annual rate, due to harsh weather, low energy prices, and a strong US dollar. Consumer spending, accounting for two-thirds of economic activity, slowed to a 1.9% rate, while business investment and construction were also impacted. Despite the weak GDP figures, economists believe the economy is not in a true recession and growth may pick up in the coming months. The Federal Reserve is expected to acknowledge the slowdown as temporary, with interest rate hikes potentially pushed to September.

site_title: The truth about inflation
summary: Inflation has shifted from deflationary concerns to modestly higher inflation in developed economies, driven by rising domestic labor costs and tighter labor markets. This shift has implications for investors, who may face unexpected damage to their standard of living due to their misunderstanding of inflation. Key concerns include the limited impact of inflation on debt burdens, the role of domestic labor costs, and the existence of inflation inequality, which can lead to varying inflation rates for different groups in society.

site_title: Kraft Foods Q1 profit falls 16% to US$429m
summary: Kraft Foods Group Inc reported a 16% decline in Q1 profit to US$429m, exceeding analyst estimates despite missing revenue expectations. The company attributed the drop to reduced advertising spending and overhead. Revenue fell slightly to US$4.35 billion, and shares fell 16 cents to US$85.72 in after-hours trading. The decline is attributed to sluggish demand for meals and desserts as consumers shift to healthier options. Kraft's cheese business and beverage sales, however, saw increases, driven by price hikes and partnerships.

images.alt_text: Heinz will combine with Kraft to create the third-largest North American food company, the companies said in late March.

site_title: Barclays sets aside further £800m for forex probe
summary: Barclays sets aside an additional £800 million to cover potential settlements for alleged foreign exchange manipulation, bringing the total to £2.05 billion. The bank reported a statutory pretax profit of £1.3 billion, down 26% from the previous year, and underlying pretax profit of £1.8 billion. The investment bank's profits rose 37% to £675 million, while core business profits rose 14% to £2.1 billion. The bank's efforts to settle past misconduct issues continue to impact its profitability, with shares down 1.6% after the results.

site_title: Japan begins unlocking casino market worth US$40b a year
summary: Japan has taken a crucial step towards legalizing casino gambling, with a group of lawmakers submitting a bill to Parliament. The move is expected to boost the economy, with estimated annual revenue of up to $40 billion by 2025, making Japan the second-largest gambling hub in the world. However, there are still hurdles to overcome, including parliamentary debate on the ethics of casino resorts and the need for coalition partner support. Critics argue that casinos could lead to gambling addiction and other vices, but proponents believe that proper regulation can bring economic benefits and create jobs.

site_title: Starhill Global Reit's DPU up marginally in Q5
summary: Starhill Global Reit reported a distribution per unit (DPU) of 1.26 Singapore cents for its fifth quarter, a 1.6% increase from the previous year. Gross revenue fell 2.7% to S$47.9 million, mainly due to lower contributions from China and the Australian dollar's depreciation against the Singapore dollar. Despite this, Singapore properties, which account for a third of its portfolio, performed well, with a 3.6% increase in net property income. The Reit's units ended two Singapore cents lower at S$0.865 on the stock market.

site_title: Chinaoil buys record amount of Mideast crude
summary: China National United Oil Co, the trading unit of China's biggest energy company, bought a record 24 million barrels of Middle East crude oil in April, surpassing the previous high in October. This purchase comes as global crude prices have fallen 44% amid a supply glut. China's refineries are processing oil at a record pace, and Beijing is expected to make more capacity available for emergency stockpiles. The purchase may be driven by demand or stockpiling, as Saudi Arabia resists cutting output, leading to increasing global demand.

site_title: Talent in a cup of coffee for young local artists
summary: The OWL Coffee Art Design contest, organized by OWL International in collaboration with The Little Arts Academy and 10 Square, has selected 15-year-old Muhammad Mustaghfir as the winner. His artwork, "Good Old Coffee," will be featured on limited-edition promotional packs of OWL White Coffee Tarik range, available in Singapore from July. The contest aims to give budding artists a platform for exposure, with a portion of the sale proceeds going to the Sing50 Fund, supporting the local music scene.

site_title: Govt to take lead in forming sectoral tripartite committees
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam announced that the government will lead in setting up sectoral tripartite committees to deepen the government-union-business partnership in identifying skills needed for workers to be future-ready. These committees, to be co-owned and co-driven by sectoral unions, employers, and government agencies, will focus on developing sectoral manpower plans under the SkillsFuture program. The goal is to make SkillsFuture relevant to the specialized needs of employers and workers in each industry, particularly for small and medium-sized enterprises.

site_title: Lufthansa shareholder meeting overshadowed by Germanwings crash
summary: Lufthansa's CEO Carsten Spohr addressed shareholders after the Germanwings crash, offering arbitration on collective wage agreements to end striking pilots' walkouts. The airline will close ranks and prioritize normal operations. Spohr reiterated that earnings will exceed 1.5 billion euros, despite the strike costs of 232 million euros last year. He also announced plans to modernize the fleet and cut unit costs. The company aims to return to normal operations and end the strikes, which have crippled the airline for months, with a dividend payment target of 32-81 cents per share.

site_title: Rubber set for bull run in China as exporters curb supply
summary: China's rubber prices rose to an eight-month high, poised to enter a bull market, as shrinking inventories signal tightening supplies. Rubber futures advanced 2.7% on the Shanghai Futures Exchange to 14,580 yuan (S$3,105) a tonne. Top exporters, including Thailand, are curbing shipments to bolster prices. Inventories have slumped to an 18-month low, and raw-material levels at Chinese tyre makers are at a low. Prices may reach 16,000 yuan, boosting costs for users and farmers in producer countries.

site_title: Twitter shares dip on pre-emptive report
summary: A financial analytics firm, Selerity, tweeted Twitter's disappointing earnings report nearly an hour before the scheduled Wall Street announcement, causing Twitter shares to plummet 18% in a day. Selerity's technology detected an updated link on Twitter's investor relations page and accessed the information, releasing it publicly. Twitter's revenue grew 74% in the quarter but fell short of forecasts due to a new advertising model. The incident highlights the speed at which information can spread on the internet and the potential impact on companies involved.

site_title: BOT unexpectedly cuts rate after growth forecast reduction
summary: The Bank of Thailand unexpectedly cut its benchmark interest rate for a second straight meeting, lowering it to 1.5% to combat weak economic growth. The rate cut aims to bolster consumer and business confidence, weaken the baht, and support exports. The central bank also lowered its 2015 economic growth forecast to 3.7% from 3.9%. The move followed a reduction in the 2015 export growth forecast to 0.2% from 1.4%.

site_title: Bush pilots offer US$16,000 outback adventures as Australian mines close
summary: Australian mining companies are shifting from fly-in-fly-out workers to tourism, with companies like Alliance Aviation Services Ltd offering US$16,000 outback adventures. As the commodities boom collapses, businesses are adapting to survive, with airlines tapping demand from tourists to visit sites like the Great Barrier Reef and Uluru. Tourism revenue has risen 8.5% to A$14.29 billion, and international tourist arrivals have increased 8.2%. The shift is driven by retiring baby-boomers seeking to explore Australia and the impact of faster economic growth abroad.

site_title: Trailing Netflix and Amazon, Hulu seeks first original hit
summary: Hulu, a video-streaming service owned by 21st Century Fox, Walt Disney Co, and Comcast Corp, is seeking its first original hit show to define its brand and compete with Netflix and Amazon. With $750 million in funding from its co-owners, Hulu is investing in original content, including Stephen King's "11/22/63" and family drama "The Way." Hulu's head of content, Craig Erwich, believes that original programming is key to success, citing the success of Netflix's original series and Amazon's "Transparent."

site_title: No compromise required
summary: Malaysian businessman Francis Yeoh, managing director of YTL Group of Companies, has committed to pursuing sustainability goals without compromise. Unlike many companies, Yeoh is not pressured by short-term shareholders to balance profitability with sustainability efforts. With his family owning over 50% of the stock, Yeoh can focus on long-term sustainability goals. He emphasizes that governments must also play a role in legislating sustainability and warns of dire consequences for the planet if actions are not taken. Yeoh believes sustainability is common sense and a moral imperative.

site_title: MAS fines insider trader S$9.6m
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) fined Lim Oon Cheng and his niece, Lim Huey Yih, a total of S$11.837 million for insider trading and false trading. They made profits of about S$3.81 million and S$896,340 respectively. The insider trading occurred between May 15 and 22, 2009, when Mr. Lim purchased shares in Singapore Petroleum Company (SPC) and Keppel Corporation (KCL) using non-public information about a PetroChina International acquisition. Mr. Lim also entered an order to sell shares in SPC, creating a misleading market appearance.

site_title: Detroit Three relying on US truck sales once more for global profits
summary: Detroit automakers, including Ford, General Motors, and Chrysler, are relying on US truck sales to cover losses overseas, a reversal of their pre-financial crisis strategy. This trend is evident in Ford's first-quarter results, where truck sales contribute significantly to profits. The reliance on fuel-efficient models has decreased, and the industry is once again focusing on high-demand, less fuel-efficient models. This shift may pose challenges for the industry's environmental and sustainability goals.

images.alt_text: Central to Ford's profit forecast is continued success for the launch of the aluminium-body F-150 pickup, which is still chugging towards full speed.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Parkway Life Reit reported Q1 FY15 distribution per unit (DPU) in line with estimates, with a 0.7% year-over-year growth in recurring income. The company's capital-recycling initiative improved the portfolio, justifying a premium over peers. Wilmar International Ltd (WIL) held its AGM, highlighting Africa as a key growth area with potential returns exceeding 20% in the medium to long term. However, near-term business outlook remains mixed due to lower commodity prices.

site_title: Currency wars defused amid yuan's Asia rally
summary: China has helped its Asian neighbors avoid a global currency war by resisting weakening the yuan, which has reduced pressure on regional export rivals to keep their products competitive. BlackRock forecasts Asian currencies will outperform peers in other emerging markets, and foreign-exchange traders have taken notice, with the Bloomberg JPMorgan Asia Dollar Index strengthening 2.3% from its lowest point in 18 months. China's currency is expected to end the year at 6.20 a dollar, with analysts predicting stability in the yuan will benefit countries with high export exposure to China.

site_title: Earnings, executions weigh on Indon stocks
summary: Indonesian stocks plummeted 2.6% on April 29, 2015, due to falling corporate earnings and concerns over Australia's execution of foreign nationals. The Jakarta Composite Index fell 4.3% before recovering, while the rupiah gained 0.3%. The executions have damaged investor confidence, with foreign funds selling $131.7 million worth of Indonesian stocks. Indonesia's GDP growth is expected to be 5.2-5.7% in 2015, despite slower growth in China and weaker government spending.

site_title: Far East H-Trust posts 17.7% drop in Q1 DPS
summary: Far East Hospitality Trust (H-Trust) reported a 17.7% drop in distribution per stapled security (DPS) to 1.07 Singapore cents for the first quarter ended March 31, 2015, due to softening travel demand and smaller corporate budgets. Net property income fell 11.3% and finance costs rose 19.4%. Despite this, the trust's financial position remained stable, with 60% of its debt portfolio secured at fixed interest rates. The hospitality industry is expected to be impacted by the fall in international visitor arrivals and the strong Singapore dollar.

site_title: Earn-and-Learn headstart for grads eyeing food-manufacturing careers
summary: Singapore's SkillsFuture Earn and Learn programme provides a headstart for fresh polytechnic graduates seeking careers in food manufacturing.
