The 20 graduates, supported by major food manufacturers, attend classroom lessons and on-the-job training, earning an advanced diploma in applied food science. The programme aims to strengthen the local talent pipeline and provide industry-relevant training, with a minimum starting salary of S$1,900 and potential for promotions to senior roles. The initiative is part of Singapore's SkillsFuture programme, which aims to develop professionals for various sectors.

site_title: Wang Jianlin's more than a developer
summary: Wang Jianlin, China's richest person, is a multifaceted tycoon with significant global influence. He controls thousands of movie screens worldwide, has invested billions in real estate projects across four continents, and is building skyscrapers in London and Chicago. Wang is also shopping for a Hollywood studio, further solidifying his position as a key player in advancing Beijing's interests abroad.

images.alt_text: He tends to present himself as the pragmatic face of big business in China, delivering a soothing message of opportunity to foreign audiences anxious about the country's rise.

site_title: Ascendas India Trust DPU for Q4 up 7%
summary: Ascendas India Trust reported a 7% year-on-year rise in distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.30 Singapore cents for Q4 2015, driven by stronger net property income and a favorable exchange rate. Net property income rose 9% to S$20.6 million in Singapore dollars, while in Indian rupees, it rose 3% to 948 million rupees. The trust's DPU grew 7% to 4.86 cents for the full year, lifted by an 8% rise in net property income.

site_title: Samsung misses net estimates, loses ground to Apple
summary: Samsung Electronics Co reported a 40% decline in net income to 4.52 trillion won (S$5.6 billion) for the first quarter of 2015, missing analyst estimates. The company lost ground to Apple in smartphone sales, with its mobile-phone unit operating profit slumping to 2.74 trillion won. However, Samsung's new high-end smartphones, including the Galaxy S6 and S6 Edge, received positive reviews and strong demand, prompting the company to accelerate production of curved screens. Samsung's semiconductor business saw a 49% increase in profit, and the company is also winning orders for the main processors in the next iPhone.

images.alt_text: Samsung will sell 46 million units of the S6 models this year, with the more-expensive curved model comprising half of shipments, according to estimates from Kevin Lee of Korea Investment & Securities Co.

site_title: Goldman sees gains from US stock buybacks
summary: Goldman Sachs predicts US companies will return over $1 trillion to investors this year through stock buybacks and dividend boosts. Over 80% of S&P 500 companies will exit a blackout period for repurchases next week, with Allstate, Apple, and Northrop Grumman likely to participate. Buybacks are expected to jump 18% and dividends to rise 7%, potentially fueling an extended market rally. However, some strategists caution that high valuations and a strong dollar may limit corporate cash usage.

site_title: ECB policies take effect as loans to private sector start to grow
summary: The European Central Bank's (ECB) monetary policies are showing signs of success as loans to the private sector in the euro area started growing again in March, increasing by 0.1% compared to the same month in 2014. This growth is attributed to the ECB's recent measures, including a massive bond-buying program, which have pumped liquidity into the system. The eurozone money supply grew 4.6% in March, faster than the 4% recorded in February, indicating a trend towards economic growth. Experts believe that the recovery is becoming more durable.

site_title: Microsoft to allow Android apps on Windows phones: sources
summary: Microsoft is set to allow Android apps on Windows phones later this year, marking a significant shift for the company. The move comes as Microsoft struggles to attract users and faces stiff competition from Android and Apple. The announcement is expected at Microsoft's developer conference in San Francisco. This change would allow Windows phones to access a wider range of apps, potentially improving their appeal to users.

site_title: Another new accelerator looking to groom S-E Asian tech startups
summary: A new accelerator, muru-D, backed by Telstra, was launched in Singapore to groom South-east Asian tech startups. The six-month program aims to support 10 startups in various sectors, offering S$40,000 in seed funding and access to mentors, investors, and experts. This is the fifth accelerator to debut in Singapore this month, with some experts questioning the feasibility of too many accelerators in the city-state.

images.alt_text: Muru-D, with the backing of Telstra, will offer a six-month accelerator programme

site_title: Strong interest likely for Toa Payoh housing site
summary: The Housing & Development Board (HDB) has released two 99-year-leasehold residential sites for sale, with high interest expected for the Toa Payoh site due to limited new supply. However, the Dundee Road site may see cautious bidding due to unsold inventory in the area. Consultants predict 15-25 bids for the Toa Payoh site, with top bids ranging from S$311-332 million or S$680-S$725 per square foot per plot ratio. In contrast, the Dundee Road site may attract 3-10 bids, with top bids around S$700-S$851 psf ppr.

site_title: US dollar down ahead of Fed policy decision
summary: The US dollar softened in Asia ahead of the Federal Reserve's policy decision, with traders expecting a delay in interest rate hikes following slowing US economic growth. The dollar fell to 118.83 yen and US$1.0964, while the euro edged down to US$1.0981. Analysts now expect a rate hike in September at the earliest, rather than June, citing soft consumer confidence data and a slowdown in overseas economies.

site_title: Money not enough, say US millionaires in survey
summary: Millionaires in the US, with a net worth of over $1 million, experience stress and anxiety despite their wealth. According to a UBS report, half of those with $1-5 million fear losing their lifestyle due to a major setback, while 63% of millionaire parents feel the same. The survey of 2,215 investors found that millennials are more insecure about their wealth, constantly checking their peers' lifestyles and feeling pressure to "keep up with the Joneses." Many feel stuck on a treadmill, striving for more wealth to live a luxurious lifestyle, despite having worked hard to earn their millions.

site_title: Pimco hires Bernanke as senior advisor; says he hopes to help with macro view
summary: Former Federal Reserve Chairman Ben Bernanke is joining bond giant Pimco as a senior advisor, bolstering the firm's star power following the departure of co-founder Bill Gross. Bernanke, who worked at the Fed from 2006-2014, will attend quarterly meetings and provide macroeconomic insights to help Pimco's investment strategies. He has also joined hedge fund Citadel as a consultant, but will restrict his advisory roles to just the two firms. Bernanke's appointment comes as investors continue to pull money from some Pimco funds, but the firm's flagship fund has recently improved its performance.

site_title: iPad app cited as American's flight delays stretch to second day
summary: American Airlines flights were delayed on Wednesday due to a software fault on iPads used by pilots for navigation charts, affecting about 40 flights. The issue, caused by a third-party application, required pilots to access Wi-Fi to fix, leading to some planes returning to terminal gates. The problem is isolated and not affecting all pilots. This is the second day of flight delays, with the issue first affecting operations overnight Tuesday. Pilots use iPads as part of their electronic flight bag, replacing paper-based materials.

site_title: Singapore billionaire Lim said to hire LVMH private equity's Teo
summary: Singapore billionaire Lim hired Christina Teo, former managing director at L Capital Asia's private-equity arm, as CEO of his investment unit Catpital Pte. Teo will source overseas investments and increase value at Lim's portfolio companies, focusing on industries such as sports, automobiles, healthcare, and hospitality. Teo left L Capital Asia in March to pursue alternative career options. Lim owns stakes in Valencia soccer team, McLaren Automotive, Rowsley Ltd, and Soverus Group, and has made significant investments in the past, including a 420 million euro acquisition of Valencia Club de Futbol last year.

site_title: Starhill Global Reit posts 1.26 cents DPU for Q5
summary: Starhill Global Reit posted a 1.26 Singapore cents DPU for its Q5, a 1.6% increase from the previous year. Gross revenue fell 2.7% to S$47.9 million, mainly due to lower contributions from China and Japan divestments. Net property income dipped 0.6% to S$38.9 million. The decline was attributed to a contraction of the high-end and luxury retail segment in Chengdu, China.

site_title: Gold snaps two-day rally before Fed rate statement
summary: Gold prices fell 0.6% to $1,205 an ounce after a two-day rally, snapping a rally sparked by soft US economic data and lowered expectations for a June Federal Reserve rate hike. The dollar hit two-month lows, making gold cheaper for holders of other currencies, but traders remain cautious about the long-term prospects of gold due to eventual US economic improvement and interest rate hikes.

site_title: Google launches security feature for Chrome web browser
summary: Google has launched a free extension for its Chrome web browser, called Password Alert, to protect Google accounts against online attackers. The extension warns users before entering account information on "phishing" pages, designed to steal passwords and personal info. Millions of phishing emails and websites are sent daily, with nearly 2% of Gmail messages intended to steal passwords. The new feature, which took three years to create, is an addition to Google's security measures, including safe browsing and verification tools.

site_title: Jackspeed's net profit grows four-fold to S$2.3m
summary: Jackspeed Corporation reported a four-fold increase in net profit to S$2.3 million for its full year ended Feb 28, 2015, with revenue rising 17.8% to S$40.1 million. Earnings per share rose to 0.92 Singapore cents. The company attributed the improvement to contributions from the accessories and automotive segments, with plans to develop existing markets, manage costs, and explore business opportunities.

site_title: Lufthansa says Germanwings crash scarred it forever
summary: Lufthansa's CEO, Carsten Spohr, stated that the Germanwings crash has permanently scarred the airline's parent company, leaving emotional scars that will remain forever. The March 24 crash, which killed all 150 people on board, was an apparent deliberate act by the co-pilot. The incident has had a lasting impact on Lufthansa, which held a minute's silence at its annual meeting to honor the victims.

site_title: Latest earnings
summary: US President Trump's 50% copper import tariff covers refined metal, impacting global markets. Oil prices rose over 2% as investors weigh market outlook and tariffs. US stocks edged down from records amid tariff threats, with stocks in Europe also declining due to bank and healthcare sector concerns. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall in H2 and operating loss similar to H1. London's Heathrow airport plans to increase fees for a £10 billion upgrade.

site_title: US crude stocks build less than expected as Cushing draws: EIA
summary: US crude stocks rose 1.9 million barrels in the last week, less than the expected 2.3 million barrels, according to the Energy Information Administration. Crude inventories at the Cushing, Oklahoma, delivery hub fell by 514,000 barrels, marking the first decline since November 28. The decrease at Cushing was a positive sign for the US oil market, but overall crude stocks remain elevated.

site_title: Oil steady near US$57 as US supplies seen exacerbating glut
summary: Oil prices remain steady near US$57 a barrel as US crude stockpiles are forecast to increase further, exacerbating a global supply glut. The US economy grew at a 0.2% annualized rate in the first quarter, and investors await a policy statement from the Federal Reserve. Despite efforts by OPEC to cut output, the group remains resistant to reducing production, and speculators are abandoning hedges at the fastest pace ever. Oil prices have advanced 20% in April, the biggest monthly gain since May 2009, but analysts warn of risks in the second quarter.

site_title: US: Stocks fall on weak 1Q growth
summary: US stocks fell on Wednesday as the economy registered a 0.2% growth in the first quarter, below the expected 1.0% growth. The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 61.03 points, the S&P 500 fell 6.25 points, and the Nasdaq Composite Index shed 17.73 points. Analysts attribute the weak data to cold winter weather and the West Coast port strike, suggesting the US Federal Reserve will keep interest rates on pause.

site_title: HSBC plans to cut 260 jobs at its Swiss private banking unit
summary: HSBC plans to cut 260 jobs at its Swiss private banking unit, with approximately 80% of the reductions in back office functions. The cuts are expected to occur over two years, with redundancies possibly beginning in the second quarter of 2015. The move is not directly related to recent media coverage, including investigations into money laundering and tax evasion. The job cuts are part of a larger effort to improve information technology and offices, with a US$200 million investment.

images.alt_text: HSBC Holdings Plc may cut as many as 260 jobs at its Swiss private bank after investing US$200 million to improve information technology and offices.

site_title: German price rises should help eurozone emerge from deflation
summary: German annual inflation accelerated to 0.3% in April, surpassing expectations, and remained above zero for the second consecutive month. This indicates the eurozone is moving out of deflation. The moderate inflation rate suggests the eurozone has likely emerged from deflation, with inflation rates expected to rise further in the coming months. However, German inflation remains below the European Central Bank's target of just below 2%.

site_title: US economy stalls in Q1 as weather, lower energy prices bite
summary: The US economy experienced a sharp slowdown in Q1, with GDP expanding at a 0.2% annual rate, the weakest reading in a year. Harsh weather and low energy prices negatively impacted consumer spending and energy companies' spending. A strong dollar and labor dispute at West Coast ports also contributed to the slowdown. Despite this, there are signs of activity picking up. The Commerce Department reported a big step down from the fourth quarter's 2.2% pace.

site_title: Contracts for US home sales at highest level since June 2013
summary: US home sales contracts reached their highest level since June 2013 in March, according to the National Association of Realtors. The pending home sales index rose 1.1% last month, exceeding economists' forecasts of a 1% gain. This increase puts contract signings at their highest level since 2013, indicating a positive sign for the US housing market as it emerges from a soft patch.

site_title: Taiwan to launch stock trading link with Singapore
summary: Taiwan's stock exchange has opened an office in Singapore to prepare for a share trading link-up with the island's trading partner. The cross-border trading, the first of its kind in Taiwan, is set to start in July. Under the scheme, brokers from both sides will be able to place orders for stocks, cutting costs for local and Singaporean investors. The plan aims to attract foreign investment and follows a similar link-up between Hong Kong and Shanghai bourses.

site_title: College Board hit by SAT cheating scandals in Asia
summary: The College Board, which administers the SAT college entrance exam, has faced SAT cheating scandals in Asia, particularly in Hong Kong and Singapore. Thousands of students were given the same exam administered in June 2014, with copies of the exam freely circulating on the web, giving Asian students an advantage in US university applications. The College Board has been plagued by test leaks and security breaches in Asia, prompting tens of thousands of test score delays and raising questions about the exam's integrity.

images.alt_text: As students around the world cram for this Saturday's SAT college entrance exam, many in Asia are poring over old tests in hopes that the College Board will again reuse a test that has leaked ahead of time.

site_title: Eurozone morale slips in April, but deflation threat eases
summary: Eurozone economic confidence slipped 0.2 points to 103.7 in April, despite improved business morale and rising consumer inflation expectations. The European Central Bank's quantitative easing program appears to be having the desired effect, with consumer inflation expectations climbing for a third straight month. However, the recovery remains fragile, with uncertainty surrounding Greece and divergent economic morale in Germany and France. Economists predict sustainable growth in the eurozone, with 1.4% economic growth in 2015 and 1.6% in 2016.

site_title: IPS Securex in US$55 million deal to supply technology products
summary: IPS Securex has signed a US$54.75 million deal with a dealer to supply PepperBall Technologies non-lethal countermeasure technology products to a government body in South-east Asia for a two-year period starting from Q3 2015. IPS is the authorized distributor for PepperBall products in several South-east Asian countries. The deal is expected to not significantly impact IPS's earnings per share and net asset value per share for FY15.

site_title: Broadway Industrial Group's net profit surges in Q1
summary: Broadway Industrial Group reported a net profit of S$1.1 million in Q1, more than five times its earnings from the same period last year. Revenue increased by 10.1% to S$168.2 million due to higher revenue from its components division, particularly its entry into the mobile segment. The company attributes its significant turnaround to management's focus on operational efficiency and productivity.

site_title: Singapore Wrap Wednesday
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has made it easier for retail investors to access a wider range of investment funds, including exchange-traded funds (ETFs), by reclassifying funds that make limited use of derivatives as Excluded Investment Products (EIPs). The MAS has also imposed civil penalties on Lim Oon Cheng and his niece for insider trading. Meanwhile, Telstra has launched a startup accelerator in Singapore, and the riverfront promenade at Boat Quay will undergo a $5 million facelift next year. Singapore share prices closed lower ahead of the Federal Reserve policy meeting.

site_title: Money not enough, say millionaires: UBS
summary: Millionaires face stress and anxiety despite accumulating wealth, with half of those with $1-5 million fearing a major setback would impact their lifestyle. 63% of millionaire parents working full-time feel the same, while young millionaires are the most anxious, constantly comparing themselves to peers and feeling pressure to keep up with their spending. Despite working hard to earn their wealth, many feel stuck, striving for more to achieve a better lifestyle, and worry about losing it all.

site_title: China simplifying rules for foreign direct investment
summary: China is simplifying rules for foreign direct investment, reducing bureaucracy to spur private investment. The State Administration of Foreign Exchange will no longer require registration or verification of foreign currency brought into the country. Foreign direct investors will also not need to file papers before moving foreign exchange out of China for overseas investment. Meanwhile, oversight of banks will be increased to ensure compliance with existing laws, as China opens its capital account and promotes international use of the yuan. This move aims to cut red-tape and promote market forces in China's second-largest economy.

site_title: Low oil prices hit Kim Heng's Q1 revenue, earnings
summary: Kim Heng Offshore & Marine reported a 72% drop in profit to S$1.1 million for its Q1 2015, due to lower revenue from its offshore rig services and supply chain management segment. The decline was attributed to low oil prices, which reduced demand for maintenance and related goods and services. The company expects its business to remain volatile and challenging in the next 12 months, but remains open to expansion activities and potential merger and acquisition opportunities.

site_title: Construction of Airbus-SIA training centre underway
summary: Construction of the Airbus-SIA training centre in Singapore has begun, with a completion date slated for the first quarter of 2026. The 9,250 square meter facility will offer type rating and recurrent training courses for Airbus aircraft types, featuring eight full flight simulators. The centre, a joint venture between Airbus and Singapore Airlines, aims to train over 10,000 people annually and will be the fourth Airbus flight training centre worldwide. Airbus holds a 55% stake, while SIA holds 45%. The centre will enhance Singapore's position as a leading aviation hub in the Asia-Pacific region.

site_title: Eurozone loans to private sector growing again: ECB
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) reported that loans to the private sector in the euro area have started growing again, increasing by 0.1% in March compared to the same month in 2014. This growth suggests that the ECB's monetary policy is beginning to work, with the overall eurozone money supply growing 4.6% in March. The ECB's measures, including a massive bond-buying program, are now having a positive impact on the economy, providing a barometer for future inflation.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index fell 12.13 points to close at 1,842.93, with 1.59 billion lots valued at RM1.89 billion traded. Gainers outnumbered losers 410-407. The market decline follows a broader trend in the Asia-Pacific region, with US and European stocks also experiencing downward pressure due to ongoing trade tensions and tariff concerns.

site_title: Singapore: Shares close lower ahead of Fed meeting outcome
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index closed 0.2% lower on Wednesday, weighed down by a drop in UOB and real estate investment trusts like Ascendas Reit, which fell 4.7%. Investors awaited the outcome of the Federal Reserve policy meeting, with about 1.49 billion shares changing hands, favoring losers over gainers 268 to 184.

site_title: RBS and Paribas say sell gilts, buy US debt as UK vote looms
summary: UK government bonds, known as gilts, are expected to weaken as anxiety builds before the May 7 general election. Strategists at Royal Bank of Scotland and Paribas predict the yield difference between UK and US debt will narrow, with some forecasting the spread to shrink to 15 basis points. This comes after nonresidents sold a net £13.7 billion of gilts in January and February, and gilts underperformed US and euro-region debt over the past month. The uncertainty surrounding the election outcome, which could lead to a minority government or weak coalition, is driving the shift in market sentiment.

site_title: Switzerland to return to Taiwan ex-leader's slush fund
summary: Switzerland will return $6.74 million to Taiwan from a slush fund used by former Taiwanese President Chen Shui-bian to stash bribes. The fund was linked to a high-profile financial merger and was frozen in Swiss bank accounts in Chen's son and daughter-in-law's names. Taiwan had requested the return of the money in 2013, which was initially contested in Swiss courts. The Swiss Supreme Court has now ruled in favor of Taiwan, and the funds will be returned soon. This is part of a larger effort by Switzerland to return $22 million in deposits held by Chen following his corruption conviction.

site_title: Lufthansa meet honours Germanwings dead with minute's silence
summary: Lufthansa held a minute's silence at its annual meeting to honor the 150 people who died in the Germanwings crash on March 24. CEO Carsten Spohr said the tragedy has changed the company and vowed to continue expanding flight safety structures. Lufthansa will support the families and friends of the victims and maintain its leading position in the area. The airline faces tough questions about its financial performance and strategy amid competition from European and budget airlines. The company's supervisory board chief, Wolfgang Mayrhuber, described the incident as a "terrible tragedy" that will leave scars forever.

site_title: Rex International's Q1 loss deepens to US$8.15m
summary: Rex International Holding reported a net loss of US$8.15 million for the first quarter of 2015, compared to a net loss of US$2.54 million in the same period last year. The company's revenue was US$2.07 million, with a loss per share of 0.64 cents. Despite a cautious outlook on the current oil price slump, Rex sees opportunities for lower costs in seismic surveys and oil drilling services. The company is on track to drill up to 10 wells in Norway, Oman, and Trinidad this year, using its proprietary virtual drilling technology with a 50% oil discovery success rate.

site_title: India brushes off concerns over gold import spike - for now
summary: India's central bank is reassessing concerns over a surge in gold imports, citing weak oil and commodity prices as a buffer. Despite a 125-tonne increase in March imports, officials believe the economy can handle the spike due to low oil prices and a large cushion. However, a sustained increase in imports above 100 tonnes per month after June could raise concerns. Industry players expect imports to rise 30% until June, driven by seasonal demand and lower gold prices.

site_title: Most countries woefully unprepared to fight resistant superbugs: WHO
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) has found that only 34 countries have national plans to combat antibiotic resistance, leaving many unprepared to tackle the growing threat of "superbug" infections. The WHO warns that antibiotic resistance poses a significant challenge to global health, with hundreds of thousands of deaths annually. Most countries lack effective monitoring systems, and non-prescription sales of antimicrobial drugs contribute to the problem. The WHO urges countries to develop comprehensive strategies to prevent the misuse of antibiotics and reduce the spread of antimicrobial resistance.

site_title: Weaker rupiah, higher competition hurt Jardine C&C's Q1 profit
summary: Jardine Cycle & Carriage reported an 18% drop in Q1 net profit to US$178 million, due to weaker rupiah, depressed commodity markets, and increased competition in the car sector. Revenue fell 14% to US$4.02 billion, with Astra International's car sales declining 21% to 137,000 units. The company cited economic slowdown and lack of new product launches as major factors, while a weaker rupiah reduced Astra's contribution. Jardine C&C's shares fell 22 cents to S$40.62 on the stock market.

site_title: Indonesia's finance minister says GDP to grow 5.2-5.7% this year
summary: Indonesia's finance minister predicts the country's GDP will grow 5.2-5.7% this year, down from 5.02% in 2014, due to slower growth in China and weaker government spending. The official target for growth this year is 5.7%. The slower growth in China is expected to have a negative impact on Indonesia's economy.

site_title: UK's Cameron vows to ban tax rises if re-elected
summary: British Prime Minister David Cameron has promised to ban major tax increases for the next five years if his party wins the May 7 election. He plans to introduce a "tax lock" to prevent increases in income tax, value-added tax, or national insurance contributions. This move comes as the UK economy has grown slower than expected, with a 0.3% increase in the first quarter of this year. Labour has criticized the move, calling it a "last-minute gimmick" as the economy is not strong and robust.

site_title: Tencent, Bank of Beijing launch US$1.6b online banking tie-up
summary: Tencent Holdings and Bank of Beijing have launched a US$1.6 billion online banking tie-up, with Bank of Beijing offering a 10 billion yuan credit line to support Tencent's WeBank service. The partnership aims to help Tencent compete in online finance with rival Alibaba, while also expanding the bank's Jingyitong initiative. The move comes as the Chinese government seeks to open the banking sector, which is dominated by state giants. The partnership is seen as a strategic move to deepen cooperation between the two companies and expand their online financial services.

site_title: SGX derivatives set new single-day volume record of 1.8 million contracts
summary: Singapore Exchange's (SGX) derivatives products reached a new single-day volume record of 1.8 million contracts on April 27, driven by strong trading in SGX FTSE China A50 Index Futures and India-related futures. This surpassed the previous record of 1.6 million set on January 27. Monthly volume also topped 8.3 million, up 19% from March, with a daily average volume of 435,721.

images.alt_text: The total volume of Singapore Exchange's (SGX) derivatives products jumped to a record 1.8 million on April 27, versus a previous record of 1.6 million set on January 27.

site_title: France increases defence budget post-attacks
summary: France's President Francois Hollande announced a 3.8 billion euro increase in the country's defense budget over four years to combat extremist threats following the Paris attacks. The move aims to ensure internal security and support military forces abroad. Emergency military patrols will be made permanent, with a 7,000-strong force dedicated to internal security. The increase represents a roughly 3% rise in the overall defense budget, reversing earlier plans for cuts and job losses.

site_title: HKEx held initial talks on possible Taiwan stock link: CEO
summary: Hong Kong's stock exchange, HKEx, held initial talks with Taiwan about a possible stock market link, which would allow investors to directly cross-trade shares. The talks were announced by HKEx Chairman Chow Chung Kong, who declined to give further details. The proposed link could give Hong Kong investors access to Taiwan's US$912 billion market and Taiwan investors to Hong Kong's US$4 trillion market. HKEx needs to consult Taiwanese authorities before proceeding, and the scheme is considered a 'future possibility' by HKEx CEO Charles Li.

site_title: Indonesia: Stocks plunge after executions
summary: Indonesian stocks plummeted 2.35% in afternoon trade, marking the largest loss since August 2013, due to disappointing corporate earnings and concerns over the execution of seven foreigners by firing squad. Lower first-quarter profits and fears of investor sentiment being affected contributed to the heavy losses. The executions, including two Australians, also weighed on sentiment, with Australia recalling its ambassador and warning bilateral ties had suffered. Analysts say the executions were "not foreign investor friendly".

site_title: China ICBC Q1 profit up 1.4%, slowest Q1 growth in over 8 years
summary: China's Industrial and Commercial Bank of China (ICBC) reported a 1.4% net profit rise in Q1 2015, its slowest growth in over 8 years, with a profit of 74.3 billion yuan. This result aligns with analyst estimates. ICBC's non-performing loan ratio increased to 1.29% from 1.13% at the end of December. The bank's Q1 growth marks a slowdown in China's economic performance.

site_title: Nepal earthquake: Tensions rise in Nepal after "weak" response to deadly quake
summary: A devastating earthquake in Nepal four days ago has claimed over 5,000 lives, with the death toll expected to reach 10,000. The government is facing criticism for its response, with protesters demanding increased aid distribution and improved relief efforts. Many survivors are stranded in remote villages, and rescue teams are struggling to reach affected areas due to landslides and collapsed hillsides. Foreign aid is pouring in, but tensions are rising between foreigners and locals desperate for relief.

site_title: ECB raises emergency funding cap for Greek banks to 76.9b euros: source
summary: The European Central Bank raised the emergency funding cap for Greek banks to 76.9 billion euros, a 1.4 billion euro increase, to pressure Athens into striking a deal with creditors over economic reforms required to unlock remaining bailout aid. This move follows previous increments and leaves an unused liquidity buffer of approximately 3 billion euros.

site_title: Ascendas India Trust posts 7% rise in Q4 DPU
summary: Ascendas India Trust reported a 7% year-on-year rise in distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.30 Singapore cents for the fourth quarter ended March 31, 2015. Net property income in Singapore dollar terms rose 9% to S$20.6 million, driven by stronger property income and a favourable exchange rate. The trust's CEO, Sanjeev Dasgupta, attributed the growth to development and acquisition strategies, a stable Indian rupee, and secured acquisition targets. The trust manages a portfolio of 8.07 million sq ft with 324 tenants.

site_title: Top Global back in the black in Q1
summary: Top Global, a Singaporean real estate group, reported a net profit of S$2.45 million for Q1 2015, reversing a net loss of S$677,000 from the previous year. Revenue increased six-fold to S$32.15 million, driven by sales of development properties and contributions from its Indonesian subsidiary. Despite market challenges, the company plans to continue marketing its developments in Singapore and leveraging its land banks in Indonesia.

site_title: UK consumer confidence falls as election nears: YouGov
summary: UK consumer confidence fell to 113.1 in April, the first time since December, according to a survey by YouGov. The dip in confidence coincides with the national election and follows official data showing economic growth slowed sharply in the first three months of the year. Despite inflation being at zero, consumers still feel the recovery is fragile, with many not feeling the benefits in their wallets. The survey suggests the government's confidence boost is at the wrong time, with the Conservative Party trailing in opinion polls.

site_title: China: Stocks up as investor optimism offsets bank weakness
summary: China's stock market rose 0.7% to 4,774.33 points, driven by gains in resource stocks and start-up companies. Despite banking shares falling 0.8% due to weak bank results, investors remain optimistic about the market's prospects. A survey by Franklin Templeton Investment found a positive shift in Chinese investor sentiment, with equities and fixed income seen as the best short- and long-term investment opportunities. China's government has launched reforms and infrastructure projects, which may support the market's rise.

site_title: Serial System's Q1 net profit up 45%, continues to explore M&As
summary: Serial System Ltd reported a 45% increase in Q1 net profit to US$3.06 million, driven by a 23% sales rise to US$261.76 million. The company attributed this growth to improved turnover in most markets, except Japan, which saw a 43% decline due to increased competition. Serial plans to pursue organic growth through product line expansion and distribution network development, and will also explore mergers and acquisitions to add long-term value to shareholders.

site_title: Europe: Shares edge up after results on Wednesday
summary: European shares rose early Wednesday, driven by strong results from UK retailer Next, Swedish bank Handelsbanken, and Dutch company DSM. The FTSEurofirst 300 index climbed 0.3% to 1,322.89, despite a 1.5% drop the previous day. The gains were largely attributed to mining and healthcare stocks, which saw significant increases. Investors are also closely watching US-EU trade talks, which may impact market sentiment.

images.alt_text: European shares edged up early on Wednesday, helped by better-than-expected results from UK clothing retailer Next, Swedish bank Handelsbanken and Dutch nutritional supplements DSM, among others.

site_title: Wife shields Greece's Varoufakis from anarchist attack at restaurant
summary: Greek Finance Minister Yanis Varoufakis and his wife Danae were attacked by a group of self-styled anarchists at a restaurant in Athens on Tuesday. The couple was shielding Varoufakis when the group threw glass objects at them, but his wife blocked the attack. The incident occurred in the Exarchia district, a site of frequent left-wing protests.

images.alt_text: A group of self-styled anarchists threw glass objects at Greek Finance Minister Yanis Varoufakis and his wife Danae at an Athens restaurant late on Tuesday, but she hugged him to shield him from the attack, the finance ministry said.

site_title: Australia: Shares suffer biggest drop in five months, partly due to strong currency
summary: Australian shares plummeted 2% on Tuesday, marking their worst performance of the year, due to a strong currency and stop-loss selling. The S&P/ASX 200 index fell 109.9 points to 5,838.6, its largest decline since December. Financials and resources shares led the sell-off, with the index now set for its second straight monthly fall. Analysts expect the market to recover if the Reserve Bank of Australia keeps interest rates steady.

site_title: Nepal earthquake: Death toll rises to 5,006: home ministry
summary: Nepal's death toll from the 7.9 magnitude earthquake has risen to 5,006, according to a home ministry official. The number increased by 300 from earlier Wednesday. Nepal's Prime Minister Sushil Koirala predicted the toll could reach 10,000.

site_title: Talent retention, commoditisation emerge as major trends in auditing
summary: Singapore's audit sector faces trends of talent retention and commoditization, similar to global concerns. To alleviate fee pressures, audit firms are encouraged to demonstrate audit value and improve communication with audit committees. Regulatory bodies, such as the Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority (ACRA), monitor audit talent and quality indicators, and are exploring initiatives to enhance transparency and assess audit quality. ACRA aims to raise the quality of audit through new initiatives, including improved communication between firms and audit committees.

site_title: Redevelopment of Mr Lee Kuan Yew's home will not diminish historical significance: URA, NHB
summary: The Singapore Government will not allow redevelopment of the site of late Mr. Lee Kuan Yew's home to diminish its historical significance. The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) and National Heritage Board (NHB) stated this in a joint statement, considering Mr. Lee's wishes regarding the future plans for the house at 38, Oxley Road. This decision aims to preserve the site's historical importance and respect the former Prime Minister's wishes.

site_title: China says will hunt down serial bribers
summary: Chinese authorities vow to hunt down individuals and organizations involved in serial bribery, particularly cases causing public anger or accidents. As part of a new campaign, the country's top prosecutor will focus on punishing "enormous, long-term and serial" bribery, with increased expropriations and harsher penalties. This effort aims to address the country's deep-rooted graft and "mass incidents" triggered by corruption, with President Xi Jinping's campaign against graft continuing since his inauguration two years ago.

site_title: China gives Luxembourg 50b yuan RQFII quota
summary: China has allocated 50 billion yuan (S$10.7 billion) to Luxembourg under the Renminbi Qualified Foreign Institutional Investor (RQFII) scheme, allowing qualified investors to invest in China's capital markets. This is the first time China has given such a large quota to Luxembourg. The RQFII scheme was launched in 2011 and allows financial institutions to use offshore yuan to buy securities in mainland China. The move is expected to boost investment in China's capital markets and deepen economic ties between China and Luxembourg.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks lose 0.15% by close
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended 0.15% lower, mirroring a regional sell-off due to weak US data. The Hang Seng Index closed at 28,400.34, while the Shanghai Composite Index rose marginally. The Shenzhen Composite Index jumped 2.10%. The decline in Hong Kong stocks follows a broader market trend, with investors awaiting the conclusion of the Federal Reserve meeting.

site_title: UK house price growth hits 10-month high in April: Nationwide
summary: The UK housing market experienced a 10-month high in April, with house prices rising 1.0% according to Nationwide. This marks the fastest monthly growth since June last year, beating economists' forecasts of a 0.1% increase. On an annual basis, house prices rose 5.2%, the first increase in seven months and surpassing expectations of a 4.1% rise.

site_title: Thailand surprises with rate cut as risk to growth rises
summary: Thailand's central bank unexpectedly cut its key interest rate for a second consecutive meeting, lowering the one-day repurchase rate to 1.50% to revive the country's struggling economy. The Bank of Thailand cited weaker-than-expected economic growth and a risk of falling consumer prices. The move comes as the military-led government faces criticism over its economic and political performance, with a recent poll showing massive unhappiness with its leadership. The rate cut was seen as a sign of desperation and strong disagreement with forecasts, and the baht extended losses to its weakest since March 23.

site_title: Ukraine 2015 inflation may be around 40%: World Bank
summary: Ukraine's inflation is forecast to reach around 40% in 2015, according to the World Bank, exceeding Ukraine's central bank's 30% prediction. The economy is expected to contract 7.5% this year, with inflation falling after 2015 but not returning to single-digit levels until 2017 or 2018.

site_title: Lufthansa offers pilots wider mediation on pay issues
summary: Lufthansa is offering pilots wider mediation on pay issues, extending a gesture of goodwill after 15 strikes since last April. The airline's CEO, Carsten Spohr, said the company is willing to discuss all outstanding wage issues, but not its low-cost expansion plans. The pilots' union, Vereinigung Cockpit, will review the offer before commenting. The move aims to resolve a long-running dispute that has cost the company over 200 million euros in lost operating profit. Lufthansa aims to report adjusted earnings of over 1.5 billion euros this year.

images.alt_text: Lufthansa said it will offer pilots mediation on a wide range of outstanding pay issues, extending an olive branch to their union in a long-running dispute over pay and low-cost expansion that has resulted in dozens of strikes.

site_title: Telstra launches startup accelerator in Singapore; 10 startups to be recruited from region
summary: Telstra-backed startup accelerator muru-D launches in Singapore, recruiting 10 tech startups from South-east Asia for a six-month accelerator program starting in August. Successful startups will receive S$40,000 in seed capital, mentorship, and introductions to investors. The program aims to accelerate technology innovation in the region, with Singapore offering a favorable business environment and access to a large population. The 10 selected startups will be announced in August after a pan-Asian roadshow.

site_title: Boat Quay to get S$5m facelift next year
summary: Singapore's Boat Quay to receive a S$5 million facelift next year, with revamped outdoor dining areas and new open spaces. The project, funded by the Urban Redevelopment Authority, aims to improve the riverfront's ambiance and consistency. Construction will occur in five phases over eight weeks each, starting in the first quarter of next year.

site_title: Barclays takes another US$1.2b hit to cover past problems
summary: Barclays reported a statutory pretax profit of 1.3 billion pounds, down 26% from last year due to increased provisions for foreign exchange issues, totaling 800 million pounds. The bank's underlying pretax profit was 1.85 billion pounds, up 9% from last year. This marks a significant hit to the bank's profits, following a 1.25 billion pound provision last year. The move aims to cover past conduct issues and fines related to foreign exchange manipulation.

site_title: Nepal earthquake: Avalanche-hit Nepal trekkers fight to get on rescue flights
summary: Avalanche hits Langtang village in Nepal, stranding hundreds of trekkers, mostly from Israel, after a 7.8 magnitude earthquake. Despite initial fears of over 250 missing, no confirmed deaths or serious injuries were reported. Stranded trekkers fought for food and rescue spots, with tensions easing when it became clear there would be enough flights to bring everyone to safety. Over 100 people were airlifted out on Wednesday morning, with more to follow, and Israeli helicopters were rescuing their own nationals first.

images.alt_text: Trekkers stranded by an avalanche in Nepal, many of them from Israel, fought for food and for places on rescue helicopters after being denied shelter by locals in the aftermath of an earthquake that killed more than 5,000 people.

site_title: Two residential sites launched for sale under GLS programme
summary: The Housing & Development Board launched two residential sites for sale under the 1H2015 Government Land Sales Programme. The sites, located at Lorong 6 Toa Payoh/Lorong 4 Toa Payoh and Dundee Road, yield approximately 1,180 residential units. The tender closing dates for the sites are June 18 and June 23, respectively.

site_title: Saudi King Salman appoints Prince Mohammed bin Nayef as new crown prince
summary: Saudi King Salman appoints Prince Mohammed bin Nayef as new crown prince, replacing his half brother. Mohammed bin Nayef, the kingdom's Deputy Crown Prince, will be the new heir apparent. Prince Mohammed bin Salman, the king's son, is appointed as deputy crown prince. Other key appointments include Adel al-Jubeir as foreign minister and Adel Fakieh as economy minister. The changes follow the king's ascension to the throne in January, following the death of King Abdullah bin Abdulaziz.

site_title: Saudi king names Al-Falih Aramco chairman, replacing Al-Naimi
summary: Saudi Arabia's King Salman appointed Khalid A Al-Falih as chairman of Saudi Arabian Oil, replacing Oil Minister Ali Al-Naimi. Al-Falih, who previously served as Aramco's president and CEO, was also named health minister. This move does not preclude him from holding other ministerial positions, including petroleum, in the future. Al-Falih has been a key figure in Saudi Arabia's stance on global crude markets, stating that the country won't single-handedly balance markets even if prices fall, and will continue to resist calls to trim output.

site_title: MAS imposes civil penalties on duo for insider trading
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has imposed civil penalties on Lim Oon Cheng and his niece, Lim Huey Yih, for insider trading. The duo agreed to pay S$9.597 million and S$2.241 million, respectively, for their roles in the 2009 transactions involving Singapore Petroleum Company and Keppel Corporation. They made profits of approximately S$3.81 million and S$896,340 from their insider trading activities. Mr. Lim also admitted to false trading, including a failed order to sell shares at an intra-day high price.

images.alt_text: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has imposed civil penalties on Lim Oon Cheng and his niece, Lim Huey Yih, for insider trading.

site_title: Gold holds near 3-week high; all eyes on Fed
summary: Gold prices held steady near a three-week high at $1,210 an ounce, boosted by soft US economic data and lowered expectations for a Federal Reserve rate hike in June. The metal gained nearly 3% in the last two sessions, following a string of data hinting at slowing US economic momentum.

site_title: Singapore, Korea tie up to train medical technologies talent
summary: Singapore and Dongguk University in Korea have signed a three-year "SSB-Korea Innovation Partnership" to develop talent in medical technologies innovation. The partnership aims to gain insights into medtech ecosystems in both countries and train 15 Korean students in Singapore's biodesign methodology. In return, Singapore's SSB Fellows will attend clinical immersion sessions in Korea to identify gaps in clinical needs and develop medical technologies for the country. The partnership also includes a faculty exchange to advance content taught at the SSB Innovation Class.

site_title: Seoul: Won rises for 4th day; shares down
summary: The South Korean won rose for the fourth consecutive day, reaching a six-month high against the dollar due to the US Federal Reserve's potential interest rate hike. The won closed at 1,068.6 per dollar, up 0.1% on the onshore market. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) slipped 0.2% to 2,142.63 points, its fourth consecutive loss, despite LG Electronics' 0.3% gain after announcing its first-quarter earnings.

site_title: Goldman Sachs sees Australia's AAA rating at risk of downgrade
summary: Goldman Sachs warns that Australia's AAA credit rating from Standard & Poor's is at risk of downgrade due to plummeting commodity prices, weaker economic growth, and government difficulties in passing legislation. The analysts predict a further deterioration of the nation's finances, potentially leading to a negative outlook on the AAA sovereign rating within coming months. This could weigh on the nation's currency and lead to a downgrade of the country's banks.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open flat
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened marginally higher on Wednesday, awaiting the Federal Reserve's policy meeting for guidance on interest rate hikes. The Hang Seng Index rose 10.35 points to 28,453.10, while the Shanghai Composite Index fell 0.67% to 4,446.12. The Shenzhen Composite Index also edged down 0.27% to 2,202.60. Investors are watching the Fed's meeting for cues on interest rate changes, which could impact global markets.

site_title: SGX expects more ETFs to be converted to EIPs after MAS widens definition
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has broadened the definition of Excluded Investment Products (EIPs) for collective investment schemes, allowing up to 20 ETFs to be accessible to retail investors without enhanced safeguards. Several ETFs are expected to convert to EIP status, offering retail investors a simple and low-cost method of diversification. The move aims to promote ETFs as investment products, with the Singapore Exchange (SGX) waiving ETF clearing fees for retail and institutional investors until December 2015.

site_title: Alibaba freezes hiring as Ma says company needs to be efficient
summary: Alibaba Group Holding, Asia's largest Internet company, has frozen all hiring due to rapid expansion. Billionaire Jack Ma stated that the current 30,000 workers are sufficient to maintain operations. The hiring freeze applies to companies controlled by Alibaba and will only be lifted when an existing employee quits. Ma aims to achieve 50% of sales outside of China by 2019 and connect with 10 million small businesses abroad. The company is investing in emerging markets, including Russia, Brazil, and India, to sustain exports.

site_title: Singapore: ST Index edges down 0.16 per cent at opening
summary: Singapore shares opened lower on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) down 5.69 points, or 0.16%, to 3,489.40. Despite this, some 122.1 million shares worth S$89.1 million changed hands, with gainers outnumbering losers 96 to 77. Top gainers included Jardine C&C, City Developments, and Ho Bee Land, whose first-quarter results showed a 180% surge in net profit to S$11.56 million.

site_title: Singapore to study possible uses for land under viaducts: SLA
summary: The Singapore Land Authority (SLA) is conducting a public consultation to explore the possible uses for land under viaducts, from April 29 to May 20, 2015. SLA aims to optimize land resources and facilitate the use of these unused spaces, which are typically between 3,000 to 6,000 square meters in size. Basic amenities like water and electricity will be installed to support various uses, building on SLA's existing management of 13,500 hectares of State land and 5,000 State buildings.

site_title: Thai finance ministry trims 2015 GDP growth forecast to 3.7%
summary: Thailand's finance ministry has trimmed its 2015 GDP growth forecast to 3.7% from 3.9% due to weak exports, with exports expected to grow only 0.2% this year. The economy may have grown 3.2% in the first quarter, and the military's inability to revive the economy after a coup last May has contributed to the downgraded forecast. This marks the weakest pace since 2011.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's stock market opened lower on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 1.05 points to 1854.01. The market saw a slight gain in volume, with 41.9 million lots worth RM14.4 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 92 to 64.

site_title: Asia: Stocks, dollar retreat ahead of Fed meeting
summary: Asian markets declined, with Shanghai suffering a 1.40% loss, as investors await the Federal Reserve's interest rate decision. The dollar retreated ahead of the Fed meeting, while the euro rose as Greece's government and creditors discussed a potential bailout reform deal. The US consumer confidence index fell in March, fueling speculation the Fed will wait to increase rates. The Dow and S&P 500 rose, but the Nasdaq eased, and oil prices fell slightly ahead of the US supply report.

site_title: Chinese demand for Apple's big-screen phones fuel sales growth
summary: Apple's large-screen iPhones are driving sales growth in China, with the company reporting a 71% increase in sales to $16.8 billion in the first quarter. The new iPhone 6 and 6 Plus models, which offer bigger screens, are particularly popular, taking market share from Samsung and local competitor Huawei. China is now Apple's second-largest market, accounting for 29% of global sales, up from 21% last year, and analysts predict it could become a key revenue source by 2017.

site_title: Wal-Mart to build 115 new stores in China by 2017
summary: US retailer Wal-Mart Stores Inc plans to build 115 new stores in China by 2017 and upgrade 50 stores this year, investing over 370 million yuan. The company aims to increase investment across its diverse business operations in China, following a shift to focus on the faster-growing online grocery market. This move is part of Wal-Mart's strategy to stave off slower growth in China, where it has been closing under-performing stores.

site_title: China to impose deeper cuts on subsidies of new-energy vehicles
summary: China plans to cut subsidies on new-energy vehicles by 40% from 2016 levels, with the reduction taking effect in 2019. This move aims to encourage automakers to develop more competitively priced products, forcing them to speed up product development and make electric cars and hybrids affordable without government support. The previous planned reduction was 20%, with another 10% cut in 2017. The move follows China's gradual lowering of subsidies to encourage the growth of the new-energy vehicle market.

site_title: Oil dips as oversupply outweighs Saudi royal reshuffle
summary: Oil prices dropped as oversupply outweighed Saudi Arabia's royal reshuffle, with King Salman appointing his nephew as crown prince and son as deputy crown prince. Benchmark Brent crude futures fell 10 cents to $64.54 per barrel, while US WTI crude fell 17 cents to $56.89. Analysts expect price volatility to remain high, citing rapid supply growth and high inventory levels. The move, which also saw the replacement of several senior ministers, had little impact on oil prices, which have been influenced more by fundamental factors.

site_title: News industry turning mobile: study
summary: The US news industry is shifting to mobile, with 39 of the top 50 digital news websites having more mobile traffic than desktop computers in early 2015. Despite this, digital news revenues remain limited, with mobile ad revenues largely controlled by just five firms. Print circulation and advertising revenues continue to decline, with daily and Sunday circulation falling 3% and advertising revenue dropping 4% in 2014. However, some digital news entities, such as Vice News and Vox Media, have seen significant growth, and the industry is expected to continue evolving with an increasing number of digital news entries and technological advancements.

images.alt_text: The news industry is struggling with a shift to mobile, getting scant revenues as more readers turn to smartphones and tablets for information, a research report showed Wednesday.

site_title: We thought our pay would be higher, Wall Streeters say in poll
summary: A Bloomberg Markets Global Poll found that 48% of Wall Street financial professionals earn less or much less than they expected, while 14% exceed expectations. The poll also revealed concerns that tighter regulations may lead to a shrinking Wall Street, with many believing banks are too big to fail. The respondents have little faith in regulators preventing the next financial meltdown.

site_title: China: Stocks fall for worst two-day loss in two months on profit
summary: China's stocks plummeted for a two-day loss, the worst in two months, due to concerns over slowing economic growth and declining earnings. The Shanghai Composite Index fell 1.5% to 4,408.90, led by declines in Anhui Conch Cement Co and Yanzhou Coal Mining Co. Analysts predict profits will climb 28% in the next 12 months, but investor confidence may sour if earnings don't improve. A Bloomberg survey found that a quarter of global investors see Chinese markets as offering the worst opportunities, with nearly three in five depicting the Chinese economy as deteriorating.

site_title: Indonesia's central bank sees economic growth well below Jokowi's 2019 target
summary: Indonesia's central bank predicts the economy will grow 6% in 2016, below President Joko Widodo's 7.7-8.3% target. The bank forecasts 6.5% growth in 2019, significantly lower than the president's goal. Analysts attribute the discrepancy to Indonesia's slow bureaucracy, supply bottlenecks, and limited infrastructure. The central bank expects a modest 5% growth in the first quarter of 2015, with a downside risk due to weak foreign investment.

site_title: Taiwan leaps past S'pore and other Asian Tigers as economy upgrades with iPhone
summary: Taiwan is expected to report 3.5% first-quarter economic growth, surpassing fellow Asian tigers Singapore and South Korea, driven by consumer spending and iPhone sales. The country's modern economy is shifting from export-driven growth to a more domestic demand-driven economy, with corporate profits boosted by Apple's product life cycle. Taiwan's economy faces challenges, including deflation and currency gains making exports less competitive, but its steady expansion is drawing global investment, with the central bank holding its policy rate and the local currency expected to remain resilient.

site_title: Hot stock: QT Vascular loses 5.5 cents in early morning trading after litigation update
summary: QT Vascular shares dropped 5.5 Singapore cents, or 20.37%, to 21.5 cents, after an update on ongoing litigation cases. The healthcare firm warned that it cannot predict the outcome of the litigation, which includes patent infringement claims and breach of fiduciary duties. The claims, initiated by AngioScore Inc, could potentially affect the company's business and financial position. QT Vascular's shares were the fourth most heavily traded by volume with 12.98 million shares changing hands.

site_title: China will reduce import tariffs on some consumer goods by end of June
summary: China plans to reduce import tariffs on some consumer goods by the end of June to satisfy rising consumer demand. The specific goods benefiting from reduced tariffs were not specified. This move aims to boost domestic consumption and counterbalance the economic slowdown.

site_title: China chokes as tobacco profits a tough habit to quit
summary: China struggles to curb its massive tobacco problem, with 52.9% of men smoking and 2% of women addicted. The industry generates 911 billion yuan (S$194 billion) in taxes and profits annually, but the country faces a heavy social burden as over a million people die from tobacco-related illnesses each year. Experts recommend raising cigarette prices to reduce consumption, but concerns about the impact on the poor and lack of awareness hinder progress, with Beijing's efforts to curb smoking facing an uncertain future.

images.alt_text: In the tobacco-producing heartland of China - the world's largest cigarette market - smoking is commonplace at work, in taxis and even in hospitals.

site_title: Japan: Markets closed on Wednesday
summary: Japan's financial markets are closed on Wednesday for a public holiday. Meanwhile, global stock markets experienced a mixed day, with European stocks down due to bank and healthcare sector drag, while US stocks edged down from record highs amid tariff threats. In Asia, traders remained optimistic despite Trump's new threats, with Singapore stocks notching a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Parkway Life Reit posts 14 per cent rise in DPU for Q1
summary: Parkway Life Reit reported a 14% year-on-year increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to 3.21 Singapore cents for Q1 2015, driven by a 14% rise in distributable income to S$19.46 million. Gross revenue rose 0.7% to S$24.77 million, with net property income increasing 0.8%. The company attributed its strong performance to the growing demand for private healthcare services in Asia, driven by an ageing population.

site_title: Nepal earthquake: Victims still stranded, PM says toll could be 10,000
summary: A devastating earthquake in Nepal on Saturday, April 25, 2015, killed over 4,600 people and injured 9,240. The death toll is expected to rise to 10,000, according to Prime Minister Sushil Koirala. Rescue efforts are hindered by remote locations, damaged infrastructure, and a lack of aid. International aid has begun arriving, but disbursement has been slow due to aftershocks and logistical challenges. The United Nations estimates 8 million people were affected, with 1.4 million in need of food.

site_title: Twitter cuts revenue forecast, shares slump
summary: Twitter Inc. reported a quarterly revenue shortfall, cutting its 2015 revenue forecast to $2.17-$2.27 billion, down from $2.3-$2.35 billion. The company's new direct response ads failed to meet expectations, leading to a 24% slump in shares. Revenue rose to $436 million, below analyst estimates, and net loss widened to $162.4 million. Despite a 18% increase in monthly active users, Twitter expects improvement in the second half of 2015.

site_title: Easier access to a wider range of investment funds, ETFs: MAS
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has made it easier for retail investors to access a wider range of investment funds, including exchange-traded funds (ETFs), by reclassifying certain funds that make limited use of derivatives as Excluded Investment Products (EIPs). This change allows investors to invest in EIP-ETFs in a similar way to SGX-listed shares, with the potential to increase the number of available EIP-ETFs to around 20, accounting for over 80% of assets under management by ETFs listed on SGX.

site_title: Paul McCartney returns to Tokyo, surprises fans with Beatles hit
summary: Paul McCartney, 72, returned to Tokyo's Nippon Budokan arena, 49 years after the Beatles' memorable performances, and surprised fans with a live performance of the Beatles' "Another Girl." The veteran musician also performed Beatles hits and his own songs, addressing the crowd in Japanese. McCartney last performed in Japan in 2013 and will wrap up his current tour in July in Chicago. The event marked a special reunion for the singer and his fans, who were thrilled to experience the rare live performance of "Another Girl."

site_title: AIMS AMP Capital Industrial Reit posts DPU of 2.92 cents for Q4 FY15
summary: AIMS AMP Capital Industrial Reit posted a 16.3% year-on-year increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.92 Singapore cents for Q4 FY15, driven by higher rental rates and recoveries for new and renewal leases. Distribution to unitholders rose 17.8% to S$18.37 million, while gross revenue climbed 2.1% to S$30.09 million and net property income increased 5.5% to S$20.31 million.

site_title: Far East H-Trust reports 17.7% drop in DPS for Q1 to 1.07 Singapore cents
summary: FAR East Hospitality Trust (H-Trust) reported a 17.7% drop in distribution per stapled security (DPS) to 1.07 Singapore cents for Q1 2015, due to weaker travel demand. Income available for distribution fell 16.9% and gross revenue decreased 10.8% year-over-year. Occupancy rates dropped 1-2% across hotels and serviced residences, while average daily rates fell 9-10%. However, revenue from excluded commercial premises rose 2.5%. The CEO attributed the decline to a sluggish economic environment and strong Singapore dollar.

site_title: Wynn Resorts cuts dividend 67% as betting in Macau tumbles
summary: Wynn Resorts cut its dividend by 67% due to a sharp drop in betting in Macau, where the company does about two-thirds of its business. The company's profit excluding some items fell to 70 cents a share, missing analysts' estimates. Revenue in Macau fell 38% to $705.4 million, with the company citing a crackdown on corruption led by President Xi Jinping as a contributing factor. The stock fell 11% in extended trading.

images.alt_text: Wynn Resorts, the casino company founded by Steve Wynn, posted first-quarter earnings that missed analysts' estimates after a sharp drop in betting in Macau. The company cut its dividend by two-thirds and the stock fell.

site_title: Total sees deal targets still too expensive after crude crash
summary: Total's Chief Financial Officer Patrick de La Chevardiere stated that prospective takeover targets remain too expensive after crude prices collapsed, despite a rebound in oil prices to $65 a barrel. The executive expressed concerns that share prices haven't adjusted to the new oil price environment, echoing comments from Total CEO Patrick Pouyanne. Pouyanne previously said that the opportunities for acquisitions will come if oil prices remain low over a longer period, and Total plans to move into Iran when sanctions are lifted.

site_title: QT Vascular updates on litigation cases
summary: QT Vascular has warned that litigation cases against it and two subsidiaries may impact its business. AngioScore Inc, co-founded by CEO Eitan Konstantino, has filed patent infringement and state law claims against QT Vascular and its subsidiaries, alleging breach of fiduciary duties. QT Vascular believes it has meritorious defenses, but cannot predict the outcome of the litigation, which may reduce the value of its products and affect its business. The patent claim is scheduled for trial in September, and the state law claims trial court has requested a post-trial briefing.

site_title: Ho Bee's Q1 net profit surges 181.6%
summary: Ho Bee Land's net profit surged 181.6% to S$11.56 million in Q1 2015, driven by a 80.7% increase in group revenue. Rental income from office buildings, particularly The Metropolis in Singapore and 1 St Martin's Le Grand in London, contributed to the growth. Net gearing decreased to 0.34 times, while no dividend was declared for the quarter. The company's shares slipped 1.3% to S$2.30.

site_title: Nepal earthquake: Nobody knows just how bad things are beyond capital
summary: A devastating earthquake struck Nepal on Saturday, leaving widespread destruction in its wake, particularly in the capital city of Kathmandu. Rescuers are desperately searching for survivors, including Sumit Balang's brother Amit, whose location is unknown. The search effort is ongoing, with Sumit expressing concern that if Amit is still alive, he may not survive without immediate help. The full extent of the damage remains unknown, with the city's infrastructure severely impacted.

images.alt_text: Down a side street in Kathmandu, Sumit Balang watched a bulldozer rummage through bricks, concrete chunks and other pieces of a four-story apartment building left in ruins after an earthquake on Saturday.

site_title: Samsung Electronics says Q1 operating profit down 29.6% year on year
summary: Samsung Electronics reported a 29.6% year-over-year decline in Q1 operating profit, reaching 6 trillion won (S$7.4 billion). This fell short of the company's earnings guidance of 5.9 trillion won. However, strong chip sales offset a decline in the mobile division, which saw a 57.3% year-over-year drop to 2.74 trillion won. The company's new mid-range products in major markets contributed to a quarter-over-quarter increase in the mobile division.

site_title: Europe tops US as favorite place to invest in Bloomberg poll
summary: In a Bloomberg poll of financial professionals, Europe surpassed the US as the top destination for investment for the first time since 2009, with 35% of respondents choosing the euro zone. Despite concerns over Greece's debt and potential euro zone exit, many investors believe the region's economy is improving, with 75% saying it will do so over the next 12 months. The poll also found that the US Treasury debt market is a bubble, with 25% of respondents saying it is already one. The dollar is seen as the best asset to go long, with 25% of respondents choosing it.

site_title: China is set to lose title of 'world's factory' to Southeast Asia
summary: China is poised to lose its title as the "world's factory" to Southeast Asia, driven by cheap labor and strategic locations in Myanmar, Cambodia, and Laos. By 2030, Southeast Asia is expected to support an emerging middle class with high consumption rates, leading to increased intra-regional trade and foreign direct investment. The Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean) aims to establish a free trade area by 2015, facilitating movement of goods, services, capital, and labor, and is projected to lift intra-regional trade to $1 trillion by 2025.

images.alt_text: The cheap, young labour and strategic location of Myanmar, Cambodia and Laos are set to draw increasing numbers of manufacturers to Southeast Asia, which will eventually displace China for the title of "world's factory."

site_title: Apple's blockbuster quarter eases doubts about growth
summary: Apple's second quarter earnings exceeded Wall Street's expectations, easing doubts about the company's growth prospects. The company sold 61.2 million iPhones, beating estimates, and shares rose to a record high before slipping 0.5% down. Analysts raised their price targets, predicting a 50% jump in shares by the end of the year, and estimated 13% five-year EPS growth rate. This suggests potential for further growth, driven by the adoption of iPhone 6 and 6 Plus models, and the switch of Android users to iPhones.

site_title: Opec officials said to plan technical talks with non-Opec in May
summary: Opec officials plan technical talks with non-Opec countries in May to discuss the global market, ahead of the organization's ministerial meeting in June. Experts from Russia, Mexico, and Oman will meet with Opec representatives to discuss production cuts, following the failure of a previous attempt to reach a joint accord. Venezuela has urged Opec to cut output to revive prices, which have lost 40% since November. The chances of a joint production cut are limited, according to Commerzbank, with the May conference convening advisers rather than ministers.

site_title: Finnish PM tenders resignation after election loss
summary: Finnish Prime Minister Alexander Stubb resigned after his party's election loss, with President Sauli Niinisto accepting his resignation and tasking incoming Prime Minister Juha Sipila with forming a new government. Sipila, leader of the Centre Party, aims to announce coalition partners within a week and have a government in place in about a month. His coalition is expected to consist of at least three parties, with speculation that the Centre Party, Finns Party, and National Coalition Party will form a coalition together.

site_title: Oil market climbs on Iran reports
summary: Oil prices rose on Tuesday, reversing earlier losses, after reports of Iran taking control of a US vessel in the Strait of Hormuz, but failed to hold gains. The US military scrambled a naval destroyer in response, and Iranian forces eventually boarded the cargo ship, which was sailing through the strait. The incident heightened tensions in the region and may be seen as a political statement by Iran. Oil prices rose 16 cents to $64.99 a barrel for Brent North Sea crude, and 2 cents to $57.02 a barrel for West Texas Intermediate.

site_title: UK's Cameron pledges not to increase taxes in life of next parliament
summary: British Prime Minister David Cameron has pledged not to increase taxes during the lifetime of the next parliament if his Conservative Party wins the May 7 general elections. The pledge includes guarantees on income tax, VAT, and national insurance, with plans to increase the tax-free personal allowance to £12,500 by 2020 and the 40p tax threshold to £50,000 by 2020. This comes as opinion polls show the Conservatives are neck and neck with the opposition Labour Party, with Labour accusing the Tories of making "billions of pounds of promises without saying where the money is coming from."

site_title: Obama, Abe revitalise ties as China 'flexes muscles'
summary: US President Barack Obama welcomed Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe to the White House, reaffirming their 70-year alliance amid China's growing influence. The two leaders pledged to counter China's territorial claims and military expansion, with Obama calling China "flexing its muscles." A deal was signed allowing Japan to defend the US, including the disputed Senkaku Islands, marking a more assertive role for Japan. The US and Japan also agreed to push forward with a Trans-Pacific trade deal, excluding China.

site_title: Europe: Shares slide as Atlas Copco and Commerzbank fall
summary: European stock markets declined on Tuesday, with the FTSEurofirst 300 index falling 1.5% to 1,618.26 points. Atlas Copco, Commerzbank, and UPM-Kymmene were the biggest losers, with declines of 9%, 5.7%, and 10%, respectively. Weak US consumer confidence data and Iran's interception of a cargo vessel added to market jitters. The FTSEurofirst remains up 18% since the start of 2015, but traders expressed caution ahead of the Federal Reserve's policy meeting and concerns about Greece's debt problems.

site_title: Google offers US$164 million to ease strife with EU publishers
summary: Google is investing $164 million over three years to support European online journalism projects, aiming to ease tensions with publishers who have lodged antitrust complaints. Eight European publishers, including the Financial Times and Les Echos, will participate in the grants. The move comes after Google shut down Google News in Spain due to a law requiring payment from publishers. Google's head of strategic partnerships in Europe, Carlo D'Asaro Biondo, acknowledged the company's mistakes and emphasized that publishers are in control of their content. The investment aims to improve Google's relationship with the news industry.

site_title: Currency wars defused by China as yuan rally spreads across Asia
summary: China's currency policy has helped to calm regional export rivals, reducing pressure to weaken exchange rates and sparking a rally in Asian currencies. The yuan has strengthened 1.1% in Shanghai, while Taiwan's dollar has climbed 2.7% and Singapore's currency advanced 3%. Analysts predict Asian currencies will outperform peers in other emerging markets, and interest rate cuts and reduced reserve requirements will bolster economic growth. China's efforts to include the yuan in the International Monetary Fund's Special Drawing Rights basket may also contribute to its reserve-currency status.

site_title: Qatar opens US$1b environmental gas project
summary: Qatar has launched the world's largest environmental project, the US$1 billion Jetty Boil-Off Gas Recovery Project (JBOG), which captures wasted gas and reduces CO2 emissions by 1.6 million tonnes annually. The project, operational since October, recovers 29 million cubic feet of gas per year, equivalent to powering 175,000 cars or 300,000 homes. It aims to reduce flaring at the Ras Laffan port by 90% and is driven by environmental concerns, not economic factors, according to Qatargas chairman Saad Sherida al-Kaabi.

site_title: Japan's spending woes persist as retail sales fall at fastest pace in 17 years
summary: Japan's retail sales declined 9.7% in March from the same month last year, the fastest annual pace in 17 years, as consumer spending struggled to recover after a sales-tax increase. This drop, worse than forecasted, may lead the Bank of Japan to hold off on expanding stimulus. The persistent spending woes are a concern for the BOJ, which hopes rising wages and lower oil prices will boost household spending later this year.

site_title: British economic growth slows sharply before election
summary: Britain's economy grew 0.3% in the first quarter of 2015, slower than expected, according to official data released just nine days before a general election. This marks the second consecutive quarter of slowing growth, which is a blow to the government. The Office for National Statistics reported a 0.6% growth in the final quarter of 2014, and the slower first quarter growth is a concern for voters. The data could impact the election's outcome as it raises questions about the government's economic management.

site_title: Adelson says ex-Sands China chief almost destroyed company
summary: Sheldon Adelson, founder of Las Vegas Sands Corp, testified that Steven Jacobs, former CEO of Sands China, almost destroyed the company with his "outrageous" and "illegal" actions, including collecting compromising information on Macau government officials. Adelson claimed Jacobs tried to sabotage the company by unilaterally cutting out junket operators and compiling a file of "outrageous" actions to blackmail his employer. Jacobs alleges he was fired due to clashes over demands, including a $300 million payment for Chinese officials. The court is determining whether Jacobs can sue Sands China and Adelson in Nevada.

images.alt_text: Sheldon Adelson, the billionaire founder and chairman of Las Vegas Sands Corp, said the man he fired almost five years ago as the head of his casinos in Macau was a "very strange man" who almost destroyed the company.

site_title: US: Stocks end higher but Twitter, Apple stifle gains
summary: US stocks ended higher, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average up 72.17 points, but Apple's 1.6% decline and Twitter's 18.2% drop in revenue held back gains.
