Despite strong results from Merck, Microsoft, and Intel, Twitter's early earnings release and Apple's disappointing China-driven results limited the market's advance. The Nasdaq Composite fell 0.10%, while the S&P 500 rose 0.28%.

site_title: Britain's recovery slows sharply in pre-election setback for government
summary: Britain's economy grew 0.3% in the first quarter of 2015, the slowest quarterly rate since 2012, dealing a setback to Prime Minister David Cameron ahead of the upcoming election. Economists say the weakness is likely a blip, but the data puts the Conservatives on the back foot, with Labour seizing on the data to challenge the government's claim to be trustworthy guardians of the economy. The growth rate is half that of the previous quarter and below forecast, causing a brief weakening of the pound and British government bond prices.

site_title: Air Canada impresses analysts but investors still keep away
summary: Air Canada has impressed analysts with its turnaround plan, which includes cost-cutting measures and fuel-efficient jets, but investors remain cautious. The airline's stock boasts the highest rating among North American airlines, with analysts projecting a 48% rally in the next 12 months. However, investors are hesitant to buy into the company due to its history of bankruptcy and high operating costs, with the airline still ranking as the second-least-efficient in North America. Air Canada's CEO, Calin Rovinescu, aims to cut operating expenses by 15% through 2018, but investors are looking for the next leg of growth.

site_title: GoPro buys virtual reality firm Kolor
summary: GoPro acquired Kolor, a French-based virtual reality firm, for undisclosed terms. Kolor specializes in "spherical media" technology, enabling video and images to be displayed on a globe-like device. The deal aims to combine GoPro's camera technology with Kolor's software to deliver immersive viewing experiences and virtual reality solutions. Kolor employees will join GoPro and maintain operations in France. The acquisition is seen as a step towards transforming entertainment, education, and other industries through virtual reality.

site_title: Alitalia CEO wants 5-star airline with flair backed by Etihad
summary: Alitalia CEO Silvano Cassano aims to revamp the struggling Italian airline with a 5-star experience, backed by Etihad Airways, which owns 49% of the company. Cassano plans to drop unprofitable short-haul routes, upgrade technology, and enhance customer services. He believes a strong international partner will help revive the 68-year-old carrier, which has suffered decades of losses and declining customer numbers. Cassano's turnaround plan focuses on intercontinental flights and premium services, with the goal of transforming Alitalia into a competitive and profitable airline.

images.alt_text: When Silvano Cassano was offered a chance last year to go back to running a company after working as a consultant, he told himself, "if it's in Italy, no thanks."

site_title: LKY: Singapore's anti-corruption visionary
summary: Singapore's former Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew played a crucial role in fighting corruption, implementing a "zero tolerance" approach to graft and establishing the Corrupt Practices Investigation Bureau (CPIB). His vision has led to Singapore's reputation as a corruption-free country, with recent statistics showing stable and under control levels of corruption. The CPIB plans to review the Prevention of Corruption Act, boost its manpower, and establish a one-stop reporting center. Lee's principles, including vigilance, thorough investigations, and public opinion, remain foundational to modern compliance programs, applicable to both public and private sectors.

site_title: Global Infrastructure Facility team to be based in Singapore
summary: A team for the Global Infrastructure Facility (GIF) will be based in Singapore to grow the pipeline of infrastructure projects. The GIF combines efforts of multilateral development banks, private sector, and governments to collaborate on complex infrastructure projects. The move aims to increase the number of projects facilitated by the GIF, but the article does not provide further details on the team or its goals.

site_title: Pimco's multi-pronged solutions
summary: Pimco, a mutual fund giant, aims to grow its business in the Asia Pacific at a double-digit clip over the next five to seven years, driven by client demand for "alpha" returns above the markets. The company has around $1.6 trillion in assets under management, with $68 billion in liquid alternative assets and $30 billion in alternatives such as hedge funds and private equity. Pimco sees opportunities in Asia's "great growth dynamics" and is focusing on creating locally-oriented strategies for both local and global investors.

site_title: Q&M buys over TP Dental for S$28.6m
summary: Q&M Dental Group has acquired TP Dental for S$28.6 million, expanding its presence in the high-end dental market in Singapore. The acquisition, valued at S$28.6 million, includes the purchase of 100% of TP Dental Surgeons, a dental centre in Orchard Road with 25 dentists. The deal is part of Q&M's plan to grow its market share and provide more services to patients, with the goal of becoming a larger player in the fragmented Singaporean dental market.

site_title: Sinopec No. 2 caught in graft probe as China crackdown widens
summary: China Petrochemical Corp, also known as Sinopec No. 2, has had General Manager Wang Tianpu, the company's No. 2 official, caught in a graft probe. Wang is suspected of violating state law and Communist Party discipline. This is part of China's widening anti-corruption efforts led by President Xi Jinping, targeting state-owned enterprises. Wang has resigned from his position and the company has stated it supports the government's decision, focusing on maintaining business stability.

images.alt_text: China Petrochemical Corp has had another executive swept up in what seems to be a relentless and widening array of corruption investigations at state-owned enterprises ordered by President Xi Jinping.

site_title: Use of air conditioning set to soar worldwide
summary: Researchers warn that the use of air conditioning worldwide is expected to rise dramatically by the end of the century, leading to a significant increase in electricity demand and greenhouse gas emissions. Refrigerators and air conditioners release hydrofluorocarbons (HFCs), which are thousands of times more potent than carbon dioxide, exacerbating global warming. The study highlights the urgent need for alternative cooling technologies to mitigate the environmental impact of air conditioning.

site_title: Indonesia executes foreign drug convicts, defying global anger
summary: Indonesia executed seven foreign drug convicts, including two Australians, Andrew Chan and Myuran Sukumaran, by firing squad despite international condemnation. The executions were carried out on the island of Nusakambangan, with a Filipina, Mary Jane Veloso, being spared at the last minute after a suspect turned herself in. The move sparked widespread anger in Australia, with the government and opposition politicians condemning the executions as a display of "abuse of State power and regressive thinking".

site_title: CPF Board recovers S$378.2m in arrears for 288,000 employees
summary: The CPF Board in Singapore has recovered S$378.2 million in CPF arrears from 288,000 employees, including 2,000 employers who underpaid or did not pay contributions. This is the highest recovery in 2014, with 46 convictions for non-payment and underpayment, and 223 for late payment. The board attributes the success to its WorkRight campaign, which raised awareness of workers' CPF rights, resulting in a 50% reduction in non-compliant employers.

site_title: Harvard Business School grads to mentor students from 5 schools
summary: Harvard Business School (HBS) has launched a mentorship program for students from five post-secondary institutions in Singapore, including polytechnics and universities. The program, set to begin at the end of the year, pairs 30 HBS graduates with six students each for a six-month period. The mentors will guide students on various topics such as business ethics and entrepreneurship. Education Minister Heng Swee Keat praised the program as a meaningful way to give back to the community, highlighting the value of mentoring over financial assistance.

site_title: Coca-Cola faces renewed pressure over executive pay
summary: Coca-Cola faces renewed pressure over executive pay from proxy advisory firms ahead of a shareholder meeting. Institutional Shareholder Services recommends investors cast advisory votes against top leaders' pay, including chairman Muhtar Kent's $25.2 million in 2014. Despite changes to its equity plan, ISS questions whether the changes will lead to concrete performance improvement. Two large pension funds, California State Teachers' Retirement System and Canada Pension Plan Investment Board, have already voted against the pay. The outcome of the shareholder vote may lead to more criticism, following last year's investor revolt over executive pay.

images.alt_text: Coca-Cola Co faces renewed pressure over its executive pay from large proxy advisory firms ahead of a shareholder meeting on Wednesday and at least two major pension funds disclosed they voted against the company's compensation.

site_title: Thailand faces weak Q1 after exports fall in March
summary: Thailand's exports fell 4.45% in March, marking the third consecutive decline and suggesting a quarterly contraction in Q1. The decline, attributed to slow global growth and a strong baht, raises concerns about the country's economic growth, with economists forecasting a 0.3% contraction. The government aims for 4% growth this year, but the central bank's latest estimate of 3.8% may be missed. A fresh poll shows massive dissatisfaction with the junta's economic performance, with 92% of respondents seeing no improvement from the economic downturn.

site_title: S'pore's hedge fund industry must evolve to prosper
summary: Singapore's hedge fund industry faces challenges to prosper, including differentiation and increased competition. Institutional investors are injecting US$90-$110 billion into hedge funds in 2015, driving the launch of new funds. To attract capital, funds must demonstrate operational excellence, including real-time reporting, robust risk management, and cost efficiency. The industry is also seeing consolidation, with funds seeking to simplify systems and reduce costs. Additionally, there is an increase in capital inflow into Asian funds, driven by institutional investors and private wealth, and a trend of hedge funds converting into family offices to cater to high net worth individuals.

site_title: Dollar sinks ahead of Fed policy decision
summary: The US dollar declined ahead of the Federal Reserve's policy decision, with the euro rising to $1.0981 from $1.0889. Consumer confidence plummeted to 95.2 in April, fueling speculation that the Fed will wait until September to hike interest rates, rather than in June as previously signaled. Traders await the FOMC statement for clues on interest rates, expecting a 1.0% growth rate for the first quarter. The dollar's decline is attributed to investors positioning for less optimism, with some analysts predicting a longer timeframe before rate hikes.

site_title: Japan sees clean energy edging out nuclear by 2030
summary: Japan's draft report proposes that by 2030, clean energy sources such as solar and hydro will generate 24% of the nation's electricity, surpassing nuclear power plants which are expected to supply 22%. The report marks a diminished role for nuclear power in Japan, which has been opposed by the public since the Fukushima disaster in 2011. Despite nuclear being estimated to be the cheapest source, the report suggests that clean energy will become the primary source of electricity, with gas and coal providing a significant portion of the remaining energy.

site_title: Projected small rise in petrol prices to add to M'sia's cost woes
summary: Malaysia is set to experience a projected 2.6% to 5 sen increase in petrol prices this Friday, adding to the country's rising cost woes. The price increase, based on global oil prices, comes as the country's new 6% goods and services tax (GST) takes effect. The government's managed-float mechanism to fix pump prices is being tested, with economists predicting a potential shift away from blanket fuel subsidies. The increase is expected to test the government's resolve to maintain the mechanism, which could save RM11 billion this year.

site_title: Shipping's environmental record under attack
summary: The shipping industry is under fire from environmental group Transport & Environment (T&E) over its environmental record. T&E claims that new ships built in 2013 are on average 10% less fuel-efficient than those built in 1990, contradicting the International Maritime Organization's (IMO) Energy Efficiency Design Index (EEDI) standards. The International Chamber of Shipping (ICS) disputes T&E's claims, citing selective use of data and ignoring improvements in fuel efficiency. CE Delft, the consultancy behind T&E's report, acknowledges limitations in its methodology and does not make recommendations for shipowners. The IMO is set to discuss EEDI standards in May, with T&E pushing for more stringent measures.

site_title: Resale condo prices edge up 0.2% in March, flash estimates show
summary: Singapore's resale condo prices rose 0.2% in March, according to the National University of Singapore (NUS) index's flash estimates. However, analysts say this small increase does not signal a recovery, citing abundant supply and prudent buyer behavior. Small units, which were in high demand from 2010-2012, saw prices ease 0.4% due to market oversupply. The rate of decline in prices appears to be slowing, but its sustainability is unclear, with further price cuts possible in developer projects.

site_title: China insurance deposit scheme launches on Friday
summary: China is set to launch an insurance deposit scheme for banks on Friday, providing coverage of up to 500,000 yuan per deposit holder. The scheme aims to promote market-driven lending and reduce financial contagion risks, as part of China's broader financial reform program. Analysts expect the move to allow banks to raise deposit rates, increasing competition and benefiting households and private firms. The scheme has been years in the making, with full interest rate liberalization expected within the next year, and is seen as a step towards leveling the playing field for smaller, private sector banks.

site_title: Cordlife's 'belle of the ball' in bid for China Cord Blood
summary: Singapore-listed Cordlife Group may be a target in the takeover bid for US-listed China Cord Blood Corp after its substantial shareholder Golden Meditech received a non-binding cash offer for US$6.40 per share. Golden Meditech, which owns 42% of CCBC, is also the largest shareholder of Cordlife. The offer for CCBC ends weeks of speculation about a possible privatization bid, and Cordlife's stock price may see increased interest due to its substantial stake in CCBC.

site_title: US dollar inches up ahead of Fed policy meeting
summary: The US dollar edged up against the yen ahead of the Federal Reserve policy meeting, with investors reducing expectations of a June interest rate hike. The euro slipped, while the eurozone's single currency lost some gains after Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras expressed confidence in a potential deal by early May. The Fed's policy setting committee began a two-day meeting, with traders seeking clues on its interest rate timetable.

site_title: Sembcorp Marine stock slides further
summary: Sembcorp Marine's stock fell 7 cents to S$2.94 on Tuesday after the group announced worse-than-expected earnings for January through March, citing concerns over a lack of new orders and heightened exposure to troubled Brazilian rig owner Sete Brasil. Analysts estimated that about S$4.5 billion of Sembcorp Marine's S$10.6 billion net order book is related to Sete Brasil, and warned that orders could be cancelled due to customers' weaker balance sheets. Only two analysts rated the stock a buy, with a target price of S$2.77.

site_title: Junk bonds are a good buy - if you can get your hands on them
summary: Investors can earn significant profits by buying newly issued junk bonds and selling them for a profit, but the obstacle is often securing a spot in the primary sale. Recently, companies such as Valeant Pharmaceuticals and Dollar Tree have seen their bonds increase in value, with Valeant's bonds rising by $345.5 million and Dollar Tree's by $180 million. The early mover advantage is a significant factor, with the largest investment firms often securing the best deals.

site_title: South Korean ferry captain gets life term
summary: A South Korean appeals court has sentenced the captain of the ferry that capsized in 2014, killing over 300 people, to life in prison for murder. Captain Lee Jun-seok was convicted of "murder through willful negligence" for abandoning the ship and passengers without taking required steps to help them. The court reversed a lower-court ruling that acquitted him of murder charges, citing lack of evidence. The verdict marked a victory for prosecutors and victims' families, who had protested the initial ruling.

site_title: A manpower-lean economy driven by productivity: Chuan-Jin
summary: Outgoing Manpower Minister Tan Chuan-Jin emphasizes the need for Singapore's economy to grow with fewer workers and higher productivity. He notes the country's labor market will remain tight due to a slowing local workforce growth and the government will maintain a sustainable foreign workforce. Tan urges workers, employers, and the government to collaborate to achieve a manpower-lean economy driven by innovation, skills, and productivity, creating good jobs and sustaining wage growth.

site_title: Companies providing expertise in addition to donations for Nepal
summary: Companies are providing expertise and donations to aid Nepal's relief efforts following the 7.8-magnitude earthquake. Local firms HSL Constructor and DHL have sent disaster-response teams and supplies, while airlines such as Korean Air and Singapore Airlines are delivering aid. The Singapore Red Cross has raised funds and dispatched teams, and insurance provider Tokio Marine Life will match staff donations. Online platforms like Facebook and Line are also contributing, with Facebook matching donations up to $2 million. The death toll has surpassed 4,400, with thousands left injured and without shelter.

images.alt_text: The team sent by HSL Constructor under the Corporate Citizen Foundation's banner teaching Nepalese how to use the water filtration system brought in from Singapore. The supplies they brought also included body bags and stretchers (in the foreground).

site_title: Nobel Design's founder voted out of board
summary: Bert Choong, founder and largest shareholder of Nobel Design Holdings, was voted out of the company's board at the firm's annual general meeting. Shareholders raised queries about the company's dividend yields and accounting practices, with some questioning the declared dividend yield and the accuracy of the company's financial statements. Despite the controversy, the other eight resolutions were passed, and the company's management assured shareholders that the lawsuit with several directors is a "personal" matter.

site_title: Deutsche Bank dilutes radical revamp after ECB stress test
summary: Deutsche Bank has abandoned its plan to become a pure investment bank and corporate lender after a stress test by the European Central Bank deemed the model unresilient to a severe financial crisis. The bank instead will sell its Postbank retail arm, cut investment bank assets, and invest more in equities trading and wealth management. This less ambitious plan aims to boost returns while addressing concerns about funding and cost of capital. The decision comes after trade unions and politicians expressed opposition to the original plan, which would have involved stripping off the retail arm and merging it with Deutsche's own retail brand.

site_title: Australia to recall ambassador over Indonesia executions: PM
summary: Australia has recalled its ambassador to Indonesia following the executions of two Australian citizens, Myuran Sukumaran and Andrew Chan, for drug offenses. Prime Minister Tony Abbott described the relationship with Jakarta as "suffered" and said the executions were "both cruel and unnecessary." This move is unprecedented for Australia, which has never recalled an ambassador over a drug execution before. The recall will allow for consultations to be held, and Abbott expressed hope that the relationship will be restored for the benefit of both countries.

images.alt_text: Australia on Wednesday took the unprecedented step of recalling its ambassador to Indonesia after two of its citizens, Myuran Sukumaran and Andrew Chan, were executed for drugs offences.

site_title: PM's articulation of priority areas will keep smart nation journey focused
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong has outlined three priority areas for the country's Smart Nation initiative: helping older citizens "age in place," improving mobility and transportation, and creating a safe and secure data marketplace. The initiatives aim to enhance quality of life for residents while ensuring cybersecurity and unlocking innovation opportunities. The Smart Nation journey has no clear end point, and the PM's articulation provides a clear roadmap for regulators and officials to follow, despite the disruptive nature of emerging technologies.

site_title: Petrobras write-down may boost US class action lawsuit
summary: Petrobras' US$17 billion write-down may bolster a US class action lawsuit alleging US$98 billion of artificially inflated assets since 2010. The lawsuit, filed by large investors, claims Petrobras inflated project costs to benefit suppliers and contractors. The company's write-down may provide fresh evidence supporting the investors' allegations, with the lawyer leading the case stating it is "highly relevant." Petrobras has moved to dismiss the case, arguing investors are targeting the wrong parties, but experts say the write-down bolsters the case, particularly for bondholders.

site_title: 'Early bird' clause prohibited: SIC
summary: The Securities Industry Council (SIC) has clarified that an "early bird" clause, previously suggested as a possible component of a two-tier offer, is prohibited in the Singapore Code on Takeovers and Mergers. This clause, which guarantees a higher price to shareholders who accept a lower price within a specified time frame, is deemed unfair to other shareholders and is prohibited in Singapore, the US, the UK, and Australia. The SIC stated that such clauses are contrary to the principle of equal treatment of all shareholders in a takeover.

site_title: G-3 recovery will lift S'pore growth, but China slowdown will temper it
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) expects Singapore's economy to grow 2-4% in 2015, supported by a firmer recovery in the G-3 countries (US, Japan, and eurozone) but tempered by China's slowdown. China's economy is forecast to grow 6.9% in 2015, down from 7.4% in 2014, due to property market weakness and consolidation within heavy industries. Singapore's external-oriented sectors will benefit from the G-3 recovery, while domestic-oriented industries will be supported by firm demand and a temporary reprieve from foreign worker levy hikes.

site_title: StarHub to upgrade network with SDN
summary: StarHub, a Singaporean telco, announced plans to upgrade its network using software-defined networking (SDN) technology. The move aims to enhance network capabilities and respond to customer needs amid growing data-traffic. SDN promises to improve efficiency by allowing system administrators to provision network connections using software, rather than manual configuration. The upgrade is expected to reduce time to market and lower network management costs, while providing effective network management and competitiveness. StarHub has partnered with Huawei and Cisco to design and implement the SDN architecture.

site_title: Japan's Capital Medica eyeing S-E Asia hospitals
summary: Capital Medica Co, a Japanese operator of care facilities, is seeking to acquire hospitals in South-east Asia to attract patients for heart bypasses and other surgical procedures, capitalizing on Japan's lower costs and weaker yen. The global medical tourism market is worth up to $55 billion and is growing at 25% annually. Capital Medica plans to list one of its subsidiaries on the Tokyo Stock Exchange's Mothers market next year to improve visibility and utilize IPO proceeds for business development.

site_title: Fall in US crude output expected to accelerate
summary: US crude oil production is expected to accelerate its decline as investment cuts and falling rig counts continue, contrary to a V-shaped recovery. The US shale oil boom has led to record-high production, but a drop in prices and reduced investment have reduced output. The industry needs to add 200 rigs to stabilize output, but this is unlikely to happen this year. Saudi Arabia appears ready to allow current market conditions to continue, with prices at an over-tight market, and may discuss a multilateral deal to cut production with other countries.

site_title: MCC makes defensive bid for Tampines Ave 10 site
summary: MCC Land, a China developer, made a top bid of S$227.78 million for a 99-year private residential site in Tampines Avenue 10, Singapore. The site attracted 12 bids, with an average bid price of S$390 psf ppr. MCC Land's bid was slightly bullish, considering its need to protect pricing power for its nearby Santorini condo. Market watchers expect the project to be priced around S$1,000 psf, with a break-even cost of S$920 to S$950 psf.

site_title: Apple's quarterly profit up 33% from iPhone sales
summary: Apple reported a 33% increase in quarterly profit to $13.6 billion, driven by strong iPhone sales, particularly in China, where revenue rose 71%. The company sold 61 million iPhones in the first quarter, a 40% jump from the same period last year. Apple also launched its Apple Watch, which received an "overwhelmingly positive" response from customers. The company increased its share-buyback program by $50 billion and boosted its dividend by 11%.

site_title: Funds buy more S'pore stocks overall
summary: Global mutual funds bought more Singapore stocks than they sold in the three months to April 22, with S$1.36 billion worth of net buys compared to S$1.09 billion of net sells. The most actively traded buy was SingTel, while the most actively traded sell was Keppel Land. In the industrials segment, excluding transportation, net sells of S$154.6 million outweighed net buys of S$25.2 million, with Singapore Technologies Engineering being the top sell and China Everbright Water the top buy.

site_title: Wage growth slowing despite tight labour market
summary: Singapore's wage growth moderated to 1.6% in 2014, largely due to a rise in part-time workers, lower-paying jobs, and sluggish economic conditions. The labour market remains tight, with unemployment rates at 1.9% and 2.6% for overall and resident workers, respectively. Wage growth is expected to pick up in 2015, but is unlikely to exceed the 10-year historical average of 3.7%. However, if economic conditions improve and the unemployment rate falls, wage growth could rise more sharply in 2016.

site_title: StanChart misses estimates in last results under CEO Sands
summary: Standard Chartered reported a 22% decline in first-quarter profit to US$1.5 billion, missing analyst estimates. The bank's pre-tax profit fell across all divisions, with commercial banking income down 17% and private banking income down 4%. Loan impairment increased 80% to US$476 million. CEO Peter Sands' final results, which include a focus on cost-cutting and improving governance, have led to a 0.7% decline in shares. The bank is under pressure to move to Asia due to rising UK taxes on banks.

site_title: British voters need real information to judge politicians
summary: The UK general election on May 7, 2015, will have a significant impact on the country's direction. Neither the Labour Party nor the Conservative Party has a majority, so a coalition government is likely. The Scottish National Party (SNP) is a major player, demanding further breakaway from the UK and potentially wiping out Labour in Scotland. The SNP's policies include scrapping the nuclear deterrent, reversing austerity measures, and increasing public expenditure. A coalition between the Conservatives and the SNP may be necessary to secure a majority, but the SNP has threatened to cooperate with Labour instead.

site_title: Democrats' stance on trade angers Obama
summary: President Barack Obama expressed frustration with Democrats' criticism of his trade policies during a White House Correspondents' Dinner appearance. He attacked MSNBC, whose progressive hosts have been critical of his trade agenda, saying his presidency has been about helping working families. Obama criticized Democrats, including Senators Elizabeth Warren and Harry Reid, for misrepresenting information about the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) and alleged currency manipulation. He also defended his administration's efforts to secure worker rights in foreign countries and proposed trade agreements, which he said would not harm American workers.

site_title: Woodside trims US$ bets amid uncertainty over Fed policy
summary: Woodside Holdings Investment Management has trimmed its US dollar bets to 75% due to uncertainty over the Federal Reserve's interest rate hike timeline. The company cut its dollar holdings amid dovish comments from Fed officials and a 1.8% slump in the dollar index in April. Woodside still expects the dollar to strengthen in the medium term and plans to re-accumulate its dollar position if the rally resumes. This move comes as traders have been setting back bets on US interest rate hikes following unorthodox policy decisions from central bankers.

site_title: Greeks may be asked to vote on bailout deal: Tsipras
summary: Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras hinted that voters may be asked to decide on a bailout deal that could exceed his campaign pledge to end austerity. Tsipras said his mandate is to negotiate an accord with creditors, but if the deal "exceeds that mandate," Greeks "will have to decide, obviously not through elections." The country is struggling to amass cash to pay pensions and state employees' wages, and a potential default would mark a failure for Europe, according to Tsipras.

site_title: More hotels in US embrace sustainability
summary: Hotels in the US are embracing sustainability, with 6.4 million guests participating in the "Make a Green Choice" program since 2009. Guests can opt out of daily housekeeping, earning loyalty points or a $5 voucher. Hotels are also implementing eco-friendly practices, such as energy-efficient lighting and water conservation, and partnering with organizations to support conservation efforts. Guests are increasingly important in driving these efforts, with 79% of travelers valuing environmentally minded practices.

images.alt_text: Mr Parrella (left) inspecting a beehive on the rooftop of the Fairmont Washington DC. The hotel uses its own honey in recipes and cocktails.

site_title: London-based Mazi Mas seeks to help migrant women in other cities
summary: Mazi Mas, a London-based social enterprise, aims to expand its migrant support services globally. Founded by Nikandre Kopcke, the organization offers training and experience in the food industry to help migrant women. Kopcke discussed plans to set up the organization in Berlin, citing its relevance in addressing migration's impact on urban environments. Mazi Mas's expansion efforts focus on local engagement and adapting to each city's unique challenges, aiming to create a global network of support for migrant women.

site_title: Tax tiffs cast a cloud over foreign companies in India
summary: Foreign companies operating in India face significant tax-related challenges, with disputes totaling around $10 billion. Tax spats have forced companies like Nokia to suspend operations, and a byzantine tax code has created uncertainty. Despite Prime Minister Narendra Modi's efforts to simplify tax procedures and reduce the corporate tax rate to 25%, tax enforcement powers remain with state governments, creating a challenge to his "Make in India" initiative. The disputes have deterred foreign investment, with the benchmark S&P BSE Sensex index dropping about one percent this year.

images.alt_text: Mr Jaitley plans to lower the corporate tax rate to 25 per cent from 30 per cent over the next four years.

site_title: Jho Low's luxury portfolio includes S$43m S'pore penthouse
summary: Malaysian tycoon Jho Low, linked to the 1MDB controversy, purchased two luxury apartments in Singapore's TwentyOne Angullia Park for S$54 million in 2013. The properties, a triplex penthouse and a condominium, were bought through a shell company and cost S$42.9 million and S$11.5 million, respectively. The purchases are part of Low's extensive luxury portfolio, which includes properties in New York, Beverly Hills, and Hong Kong.

site_title: Celanese building VAE emulsions unit at S'pore plant
summary: Celanese Corporation has begun construction of a vinyl acetate ethylene (VAE) emulsions production unit at its Singapore plant, expected to start production by mid-2016. This unit will support the South-east Asian market and other Asia-Pacific countries, including India, Australia, and New Zealand. The new facility will integrate with raw material supplies and broaden Celanese's network to better serve customers in high-end applications such as architectural coatings, building and construction, carpets, and paper industries.

site_title: Cheers to a better brew
summary: Heineken, a leading brewer, has made sustainability a priority with its "Brewing a Better World" initiative. Launched in 2014, the program aims to embed sustainability within the organization, creating real value for all stakeholders and achieving business objectives. The company focuses on four key areas: protecting water resources, reducing CO2 emissions, sourcing sustainably, and advocating responsible consumption. Heineken has achieved notable successes, such as reducing water consumption by 25% and implementing water protection plans in water-scarce areas. The company's efforts have also promoted responsible drinking and community engagement, with initiatives like installing "biopori" holes to alleviate flooding and donating bamboo seeds to halt erosion.

images.alt_text: Partygoers at ZoukOut 2013 saw a sunrise powered by themselves - the more they danced, the brighter the Heineken ''sun'' and therefore, the more spectacular the sunrise
''We have made it a business priority to inspire and engage our employees to build a business that is designed to succeed for the future.'' - Roland Pirmez, president, Heineken Asia-Pacific

site_title: WBL break-up sparks questions at OCBC AGM
summary: OCBC CEO Samuel Tsien stated the bank is not in a hurry to sell its 20% stake in UE, despite the company's recent break-up with WBL. OCBC owns 25% of WBL, and the bank initially acquired UE to protect its shareholders' interests. The bank is instead focusing on providing a broader range of services to lock in depositors. Shareholders raised questions about the bank's board composition and the "musical chairs" of fund movement, with some calling for more female directors.

site_title: US studying coal mining firms' cleanup programme for shortfalls
summary: The US government is examining whether coal companies that use a self-bonding program to avoid full cleanup costs can still qualify for the exemption. The program allows financially qualified companies to leave part of their potential cleanup costs uninsured. Industry experts say many US coal companies would struggle to pay for full coverage and lifting the exemption could push them closer to bankruptcies. The four largest coal producers using the program, including Peabody Energy and Arch Coal, may face significant cleanup liabilities if pushed to bankruptcy.

site_title: Earthquake rebuilding cost will exceed US$10b: Nepal minister
summary: Nepal's devastating 7.8 magnitude earthquake has resulted in an estimated death toll of over 5,200 with the possibility of exceeding 6,000. The cost to rebuild the country is expected to exceed US$10 billion, equivalent to about half of Nepal's US$20 billion economy. Heavy rains in Kathmandu have hindered rescue efforts, and residents are becoming restless due to the lack of food, water, medicine, and power. The government is struggling to provide adequate relief and has appealed to the international community for support, with Prime Minister Sushil Koirala estimating the death toll could reach 10,000.

site_title: Innovation and smart money rule at startup festival
summary: Minister Vivian Balakrishnan unveiled two initiatives at InnovFest unBound 2015 in Singapore to support entrepreneurs, particularly in the ageing population sector. Modern Ageing, a four-month accelerator scheme, aims to create businesses for ageing, while NEAT IP connects companies to NUS technologies at no upfront cost. Additionally, smart money is flowing into Singapore, with equity crowdfunding platform Capbridge set for a soft launch in May. Local startups DocDoc and 2C2P also secured funding from Hong Leong Financial Group and Sparklabs Global Ventures, respectively.

site_title: Investment in Indonesia picks up to quarterly record in fillip for Joko
summary: Foreign direct investment in Indonesia rose 16.9% to a quarterly record of 124.6 trillion rupiah in the first quarter of 2015, driven by a weaker rupiah and government reforms. President Joko Widodo's administration aims to boost growth by cutting red tape, building infrastructure, and attracting investment. Despite recent rule changes making it harder to do business, investment remains strong, with a goal of 7% GDP growth by 2019. Major investors include Coca-Cola, Singapore, Japan, and South Korea, with a total investment target of 519.5 trillion rupiah for 2015.

site_title: Mother's Day art for special needs children
summary: Mother's Day art workshop for special needs children was organized by United Overseas Bank (UOB) in collaboration with established artists Chua Say Hua and Hong Sek Chern. The workshop, part of UOB's art programme, allowed 12 children from the Association for Persons with Special Needs (APSN) Katong School to learn contemporary Chinese ink painting techniques. The event aimed to inspire young artists to express their love and gratitude to their mothers creatively. This was the first of six art events UOB will organize for 100 children this year, designed in collaboration with past UOB Painting of the Year competition winners.

site_title: Asean meetings a chance to deepen ties with Europe
summary: Asean and the European Union (EU) are strengthening ties through recent meetings in Kuala Lumpur and Langkawi. The EU, the world's largest economy, is shifting focus to Asia, where Asean countries are playing a key role in the region's rise. The Asean-EU relationship is crucial for both regions, with Asean's 10 countries and EU's 28 countries seeking to deepen cooperation in trade, politics, and other areas. This partnership is essential for Asia's growing influence and the EU's economic interests.

site_title: PBOC's role in focus as local government debt grows
summary: China's local-government debt has surged to 16 trillion yuan, a 47% jump from 2013, prompting the People's Bank of China (PBOC) to consider unconventional policies to avoid a credit crunch. The central bank's options include broad monetary easing and targeted measures, such as buying local government bonds. Local governments plan to sell 1.7 trillion yuan in municipal bonds this year, and the PBOC may adopt policies similar to the US Federal Reserve's mortgage securities purchases to shore up the market. This move aims to ease the pressure on local government debt repayment and support the municipal bond market.

site_title: Honda forecasts flat profit this year
summary: Honda forecasts a flat profit of 525 billion yen (S$5.84 billion) for the fiscal year ending March 2016, missing analyst estimates, due to weaker overseas currencies eroding earnings. The company's president Takanobu Ito will step down in June after quality problems led to its biggest vehicle recalls in decades. Honda predicts higher selling expenses will erode full-year operating profit by 90 billion yen, and faces lingering concerns over recall costs and its reputation. The company expects its US sales to recover in the latter half of the business year with new model launches.

site_title: A special sunrise
summary: Heineken, in partnership with APB Singapore, created a unique sunrise experience at the 2015 ZoukOut festival on Sentosa island. The "Heineken sun" was a 10-metre wide balloon with an adjustable light source that intensified as more partygoers danced on a custom-made reactive dance floor. Over 400,000 dance steps were collected, resulting in the festival's first-ever sunrise at 6:30am. The initiative aimed to encourage responsible drinking by providing water and promoting pacing among partygoers.

site_title: UOI posts lower Q1 profit, higher EPS
summary: United Overseas Insurance (UOI) reported a 20.8% drop in Q1 net profit to S$9.36 million, driven by a 4.5% decline in gross premiums written. However, underwriting profit rose 21.5% to S$6.88 million. Net asset value per share grew to S$5.15, and annualised EPS increased to 59.74 cents. The company cited challenges in a mature market and unpredictable global factors as reasons for the decline. Despite this, UOI's counter rose six Singapore cents to S$5.06.

site_title: Falls in Keppel, Jardine drag STI below 3,500
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) fell 20.76 points to 3,495.09 due to declines in Keppel Corp and Jardine stable. Despite a surge in Hong Kong, local market performance remained unchanged. The STI has been influenced by caution ahead of the US Federal Open Market Committee meeting. Macquarie Equities Research expects DBS to show good earnings momentum with double-digit EPS growth in 2015.

site_title: The future of further education
summary: Singapore's university education landscape has dramatically evolved over the past 50 years, increasing from 3% in 1965 to 40% by 2020, with about 30% of primary school students now eligible to attend local universities. The presidents of Singapore's six universities discuss the challenges of recruiting top students and faculty, and their hopes for the future, including increased international collaboration and innovation.

site_title: Critical shortage of cybercrime specialists: Experts
summary: Experts warn of a critical global shortage of cybercrime specialists, with fewer than 1,000 qualified individuals needed to address the issue. The shortage is exacerbated by the growing complexity of cyber attacks, which require effective intelligence and skilled personnel. To address this, Saudi Arabia plans to establish a National Cybersecurity Centre, which will focus on capacity building and knowledge sharing. The centre aims to develop a national framework for cybersecurity and address the shortage of skilled professionals, with a target of over 30,000 specialists needed worldwide.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary:
Here's a 100-word summary of the article:

Stock market analysts have released their views on three companies: First Reit, Sembcorp Marine, and Hutchison Port Holdings Trust. First Reit is recommended to "accumulate" with a target price of S$1.55, driven by its expansion plan for private hospitals in Indonesia. Sembcorp Marine's Q1 net profit fell 14% year-on-year, prompting a "sell" rating with a target price of S$2.57. Hutchison Port Holdings Trust maintained a "hold" rating with a target price of US$0.65, citing a 15% cut in dividends due to capital expenditure plans. Analysts also expressed concerns over market outlook and tariffs.

site_title: JV to turn excavated clay into reclamation material
summary: Singapore construction company Logistics Holdings is collaborating with Taiwan's China Steel Corporation to develop a method to convert excavated clay into usable land reclamation material. The partnership, through Logistics' subsidiary New Soil Technologies, aims to create a sustainable solution for reclamation projects. The non-binding memorandum of understanding (MOU) was signed, marking the beginning of this innovative project.

site_title: Oxley Holdings sets up unit in Myanmar
summary: Oxley Holdings has established a subsidiary, Oxley Consultancy & Management Company, in Myanmar with a US$50,000 capital. The company, required by Myanmar law to have at least two shareholders, has 49,999 shares held by Oxley Yangon Company, a wholly-owned subsidiary, and one share held by Ching Chiat Kwong, the executive chairman and CEO. The incorporation is in line with the group's expansion plans.

site_title: Russia's economy has overcome peak of difficulties: Putin
summary: Russia's economy has overcome its peak of difficulties and is no longer at risk of collapse, President Vladimir Putin said. The economy has strengthened and its stability is impossible to destroy, with the ruble gaining 18% against the dollar this year. Despite a recession forecasted for this year, the economy may return to growth in the fourth quarter, driven by a more stable real sector. Sanctions continue to weigh on the economy, but the improved outlook is already affecting the ruble's exchange rate.

site_title: Japan expects clean energy to edge out nuclear power
summary: Japan anticipates that by 2030, clean energy sources such as solar and hydro will generate slightly more electricity than nuclear power plants, accounting for 24% of the nation's electricity. Nuclear power is expected to provide 22% of Japan's electricity, down from nearly a third before the Fukushima disaster in 2011. The shift towards clean energy is driven by the need for nuclear power to be phased out following the disaster, which triggered strong public opposition and led to increased electricity prices.

site_title: Private investments in Malaysia's ETP rise at 11% in 2014
summary: Malaysia's private investments in its Economic Transformation Programme (ETP) rose 11% in 2014 to RM146.1 billion, exceeding the country's goal of achieving high-income nation status by 2020. The country's total investments grew to RM228 billion, with public investment falling to RM81.9 billion. Malaysia's economy grew at 6.0% in 2014, driven by construction and manufacturing gains, but analysts warn that weaker global oil prices may impact the country's income in the months ahead.

site_title: China's anti-graft drive targets art
summary: China's ruling Communist Party has launched an anti-corruption drive targeting art and literary prizes, aiming to curb officials' use of awards to gain influence. The culture ministry plans to cancel or streamline over 60% of awards, and criticism will be strengthened. The move comes as part of President Xi Jinping's efforts to crack down on corruption nationwide, following warnings from the party's internal commission to stop officials from using art and calligraphy associations for personal gain. The crackdown aims to ensure "legitimate benefits" in the arts.

site_title: Apple adds yet another title: Largest dividend payer in S&P
summary: Apple has become the largest dividend payer in the Standard & Poor's 500 Index, with a 10.6% increase in its dividend to $2.08 per share, amounting to $12.1 billion annually. This surpasses Exxon Mobil Corp, the previous title holder, and reflects the company's success in generating cash through its products. Apple's capital return program now totals $200 billion, including $140 billion in buybacks, with the company generating $9.9 billion in additional payouts this year.

site_title: Oil falls as US crude stockpiles set for another high
summary: Oil prices fell on Tuesday as US crude stockpiles are expected to rise for the 16th straight week, withdrawing from a 4 1/2-month high. Brent crude futures dropped 43 cents to $64.40 a barrel, while US June crude fell 40 cents to $56.59 a barrel. Analysts expect lower US production and stock draws, but Saudi Arabia's oil minister says demand in Asia will grow, and the country will meet it. Barclays raised its oil price forecast due to conflict in Yemen and Syria, and unplanned production outages.

site_title: US consumer confidence unexpectedly declines to four-month low
summary: US consumer confidence unexpectedly fell to a four-month low in April, dropping to 95.2 from 101.4 in March, according to the Conference Board. The decline was driven by a decrease in respondents' views of the labor market and income expectations, signaling consumers will remain cautious about spending. This setback may indicate slow demand after a stronger dollar, winter weather, and labor disputes weighed on the economy in the first quarter.

site_title: US: Stocks open mixed
summary: US stocks opened mixed on Tuesday, April 28, 2015, after a retreat from all-time highs. The Standard & Poor's 500 Index fell 0.1% to 2,106.18, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average added 3.04 points. Gains were offset by weaker-than-forecast results from Whirlpool Corp and Coach Inc, which fell 6.4% and 7% respectively. In contrast, Merck & Co rose 5% after boosting its annual profit forecast.

site_title: Update: PBOC has no plans to buy local govt debt
summary: China's central bank has no plans to use quantitative easing by buying local government bonds, according to People's Bank of China chief economist Ma Jun. The PBOC has sufficient monetary policy tools to sustain reasonable growth in liquidity and money supply. Ma stated that there's no need to directly buy newly-issued local government bonds to expand the monetary base, and a plan to swap high-interest local government debt for government bonds would not tighten liquidity conditions. The central bank will pursue prudent monetary policy this year.

site_title: SEC probes Bank of America over customer funds: source
summary: Bank of America is being investigated by the Securities and Exchange Commission over potential rule violations and misrepresentation related to customer account safeguarding. The probe focuses on a three-year period (2012-2015) involving large, complex trades and loans intended to save on funding costs. The SEC is examining whether Bank of America broke customer-protection rules and misled regulators about its actions, which were halted in mid-2012.

site_title: Nepal earthquake: Aid begins to reach desperate quake-hit Nepal villagers
summary: A devastating 7.8-magnitude earthquake struck Nepal on Saturday, killing nearly 4,500 people and injuring 8,000. Aid has begun to reach remote areas, with international assistance pouring in from countries such as the US, China, and India. The UN estimates 8 million people have been affected, and the nation's economy is expected to take a hit. A state of emergency has been declared, and the government is struggling to cope with the scale of the disaster, including food and water shortages.

site_title: Immigrants slow population decline in Germany: stats office
summary: Germany's population is expected to shrink more slowly than initially predicted due to high levels of immigration, according to the country's statistics office. The population, which hit 81.1 million in 2014, is projected to decline to between 67.6 and 73.1 million by 2060, with immigration levels determining the final outcome. The rising number of immigrants has sparked heated debate, but the government and industry argue that they are necessary to counter the demographic squeeze caused by an aging population. A significant decline in working-age people is also forecast.

site_title: Ford profit misses expectations
summary: Ford Motor Co reported a profit less than expected in the first quarter, with net income falling 7% to $924 million, or 23 cents a share. The company maintained its full-year forecast but highlighted worsening business conditions in South America. Revenue fell 5.6% to $33.9 billion, matching analyst expectations. Ford attributed a two-cent profit shortfall to a higher-than-expected tax rate. The company's North American operating margin is expected to rise to 8.5-9.5%, despite a 6.7% operating profit margin in North America.

site_title: Indonesia: Stocks pare losses after biggest decline
summary: Indonesian stocks erased losses after the benchmark index's biggest decline since 2013, closing 0.1% lower at 5,242.16. The Jakarta Composite Index plummeted 3.5% on Monday following a 80% drop in palm oil producer PT Astra Agro Lestari's profit. Global funds have been net sellers of Indonesian stocks, selling $140 million worth of equities on Tuesday. The index is now up 0.3% for the year, lagging behind an 11% gain by the MSCI Emerging Markets Index.

site_title: Singapore Wrap Tuesday
summary: Singapore's economy growth is expected to be supported by a stronger recovery in the G3 countries, but offset by China's slowdown. The Monetary Authority of Singapore reported a recovery of S$378.2 million in CPF arrears from underpayments and late payments. Two new programs for entrepreneurs and startups were also unveiled. In market news, the Straits Times Index fell 20.76 points to 3,495.09 due to falls in Keppel Corp and Jardine stable.

images.alt_text: Singapore's CPF Board (CPFB) has recovered about S$378.2 million in CPF arrears from underpayments, nonpayment and late payment of contributions by employers.

site_title: Deutsche Bank co-CEO in dock on false testimony charges
summary: Deutsche Bank co-CEO Juergen Fitschen and four others are on trial for allegedly giving false testimony in a lawsuit with defunct media group Kirch. The defendants, who have denied wrongdoing, face prison sentences of 1-10 years if convicted. A guilty verdict would harm Deutsche Bank's image, which is already struggling with several legal challenges, including a record $2.5 billion fine for rigging Libor interest rates. The trial, set to conclude by September, could result in fines of up to 1 million euros for the bank if it is found to have participated in the deception.

site_title: Pfizer cuts full-year forecast on stronger dollar
summary: Pfizer reported a slight rise in first-quarter profit but lowered its full-year forecast due to a stronger dollar. The company cited a hit to foreign sales, particularly from the dollar's gains against the euro. It cut its full-year sales estimate to $44.0-$46.0 billion, down from $44.5-$46.5 billion. Adjusted earnings per share were estimated at $1.95-$2.05, five cents less than previously estimated.

site_title: Malaysia: Stocks end the day lower
summary: Malaysian shares closed lower on Tuesday, with the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index slipping 4.52 points to 1,855.06. Trading volume reached 2.17 billion lots valued at RM2.15 billion, with losers outnumbering gainers 762 to 183.

site_title: China said to consider PBOC lending tool to help local debt
summary: China's central bank is considering expanding a new lending tool, the Pledged Supplementary Lending (PSL) program, to support local-government bonds and bolster demand for municipal debt. The program, which has already channeled 1 trillion yuan, aims to bring transparency to borrowing by provinces and cities. The move is part of China's efforts to develop a municipal debt market and avoid a credit crunch, as the country's economy slows. The PBOC's support is part of its targeted monetary easing to add liquidity while avoiding a lending binge.

site_title: UOI posts 20.8% drop in Q1 net profit
summary: United Overseas Insurance (UOI) posted a 20.8% drop in Q1 net profit to S$9.36 million, despite a 21.5% increase in underwriting profit to S$6.88 million. Gross premiums written declined 4.5% to S$29.3 million, while net earned premiums rose 1% to S$11.9 million. The company attributed the decline to a mature market and unpredictable factors affecting profitability.

site_title: EU to impose anti-dumping duties on electrical steel imports
summary: The European Union will impose anti-dumping duties on imports of grain-oriented electrical steel (GOES) from five countries, including Russia, Japan, China, the US, and Korea, starting May 14. The duties range from 21.6% to 35.9% and aim to protect the EU steel industry from dumped imports, which have damaged EU industry by driving prices below production costs. Eurofer, the European steel producers association, lodged the complaint in 2014, citing 47% market share of dumped imports in 2012, mostly from Japan and Russia.

site_title: Malaysia's flagship economic programme sees rise in investments
summary: Malaysia's Economic Transformation Programme (ETP) saw a 11% rise in private investments in 2014, reaching 146.1 billion ringgit (US$41.11 billion). The country is halfway to achieving high-income nation status by 2020. Total investments grew to 228 billion ringgit, with public investment falling to 36% of total investment. The programme aims to generate US$444 billion in investments and raise annual per-capita income to US$15,000 by 2020. Despite a 6.0% economic growth in 2014, analysts warn that weaker global oil prices may impact Malaysia's income in the months ahead.

site_title: Nepal earthquake: 60 Singaporeans and PRs flying out of Kathmandu on C-130
summary: About 60 Singaporeans and permanent residents are leaving Kathmandu on a C-130 for Singapore, with two flights scheduled. The departures follow the devastating Nepal earthquake.

site_title: Singapore: Keppel, Jardine drag index lower
summary: The Straits Times Index in Singapore declined 20.76 points to 3,495.09, weighed down by falls in Keppel Corp and the Jardine stable. Hong Kong's market, influenced by caution ahead of the US Federal Open Markets Committee meeting, saw a surge but ultimately lost gains. DBS reported a net profit of S$1.13 billion, exceeding market estimates, with Nomura maintaining a Buy rating and price target of S$24.30.

site_title: Twitter's chief delivers on updated features, but right mix is elusive
summary: Twitter's CEO Dick Costolo has begun implementing new features to improve the user experience after a tumultuous 2014. The company has introduced a revamped home page, automatic tweet recaps, and live video feeds through the Periscope app. However, users like Edgar Cahn, an 80-year-old law professor, struggle to understand the platform's complexities, such as retweeting and following. Twitter's new management team aims to build a product that provides unique value to users without requiring an initial investment, similar to YouTube's public content model.

images.alt_text: Mr Costolo seems satisfied that he now has the right team in place to achieve his audacious goal of reaching the largest daily audience in the world.

site_title: RBS says Ulster Bank CEO Brown to become boss of Williams & Glyn
summary: Royal Bank of Scotland (RBS) has appointed Jim Brown, current CEO of its Irish business, to replace John Maltby as CEO of Williams & Glyn, a UK "challenger" bank. Brown will oversee the business, which comprises 314 branches, focusing on lending to small businesses. RBS plans to list Williams & Glyn on the London Stock Exchange in the second half of 2016, following a European regulator's order to sell the business as part of its bailout. Maltby will resume his previous role as advisor to investors.

site_title: Saudi Arabia affirms oil strategy as market seen as 'excellent'
summary: Saudi Arabia reaffirmed its oil strategy, stating it will continue to pump oil to meet demand and maintain market stability. The country's deputy oil minister, Prince Abdulaziz, said Saudi Arabia will supply any demand for its oil to keep customers happy and maintain stability in prices, supply, and demand. This comes as the oil market is considered "excellent" by the kingdom, despite a global glut. Saudi Arabia plans to increase shale gas production by 2025 to meet its goal of reducing crude consumption by 1.5 million barrels per day by 2030.

site_title: Agricultural Bank of China profit up 1.3%
summary: Agricultural Bank of China Ltd reported a 1.3% increase in quarterly profit to 54.1 billion yuan, driven by a 6% rise in net interest income as loans increased 4.9%. Bad loan provisions rose 51% to 20 billion yuan. The lender's shares have climbed 40% in the past year, outpacing the Hang Seng Index. The bank's results come as China's economy cools, with the government deregulating the finance industry and intensifying competition for funds.

site_title: Latest earnings
summary: US President Trump's 50% copper import tariff is set to cover refined metal. Oil prices rose over 2% as investors weigh market outlook, tariffs, and sanctions. In the US, stocks edged down from records amid tariff threats. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times. Creative Technology warned of potential H2 revenue below target and similar operating loss to H1. London's Heathrow plans to increase fees for a £10 billion upgrade.

site_title: Ho Bee Land Q1 net profit surges 181%
summary: Ho Bee Land's Q1 net profit surged 181.6% to S$11.56 million, driven by a 81.5% increase in group revenue to S$31 million, largely due to rental income from office buildings in Singapore and London.

site_title: India confident on inflation even with sub-par monsoon
summary: India's junior finance minister Jayant Sinha expressed confidence in managing potential inflationary pressures despite forecasted sub-par monsoon rains this summer. The monsoon's impact on food prices and inflation is a concern, but Sinha believes the country can manage the situation. Meanwhile, India's merchandise exports shrank for the fourth month in March due to the appreciation of the rupee and a collapse in the euro's value, particularly affecting exports to Europe. Sinha advises exporters to focus on innovation to boost global competitiveness.

site_title: Amazon.com launches new marketplace for US businesses
summary: Amazon.com launched its new marketplace, Amazon Business, on April 28, 2015, to connect individual US businesses with suppliers, offering exclusive pricing, discounts, and tax exemption. The platform aims to tap into the US$8.2 trillion business-to-business (B2B) market, which is expected to grow at a 7.7% CAGR over the next five years. With the launch, Amazon Business will provide free two-day shipping for orders over $49, as well as an Amazon guarantee for product delivery.

site_title: Japan lawmakers submit casino legalisation bill
summary: Japan's pro-casino lawmakers submitted a bill to parliament to legalize casino gambling, aiming to generate US$40 billion annually and boost economic growth. The bill, submitted by the ruling Liberal Democratic Party and other parties, is expected to be discussed before the current parliamentary session ends in July or August. Prime Minister Shinzo Abe sees the industry as key to Japan's economic growth. The lawmakers hope the bill will pass before the session ends, but a specific timeline has not been set.

site_title: Daimler closes gap with BMW, Audi as profit jumps
summary: Daimler's Mercedes-Benz division reported record sales and a 41% jump in adjusted earnings before interest and tax (Ebit) to 2.93 billion euros. The company beat forecasts and narrowed its profitability gap with rivals BMW and Audi. Daimler's flagship C-Class saloon and SUVs drove the growth, with deliveries up 18% year-over-year to 459,708 models. The company expects significant growth in deliveries, revenue, and EBIT this year, with CEO Dieter Zetsche citing a successful growth strategy and product offensives.

site_title: JTC launches two confirmed list sites at Woodlands, Tuas
summary: JTC Corporation has launched two confirmed list sites for industrial development in Woodlands and Tuas, and one reserve list site in Tampines. The confirmed sites have a 20-year tenure and maximum permissible gross plot ratios of 2.0 and 1.4, respectively. The sites are part of the government's industrial land sales programme for the first half of 2015, with tenders closing on June 23. The reserve list site will be put up for application if a suitable offer is received or market interest is sufficient.

site_title: Tampines Avenue 10 site attracts 12 bids
summary: Tampines Avenue 10, a 99-year private residential site, drew 12 bids for its development. The top bid of S$227.78 million (S$483 psf ppr) was from MCC Land, followed by Allgreen Properties at S$212.89 million (S$451 psf ppr). The lowest bid was S$127.39 million (S$270 psf ppr) from Edition Land. The site's sale price is expected to generate significant revenue for the winning bidder.

site_title: Growing output, strong refining contain Total Q1 drop
summary: French oil major Total reported a 22% drop in first-quarter net profit to US$2.60 billion, despite lower crude prices, due to strong refining margins and growing oil and gas production. The company's production rose 10% to 2.40 million barrels of oil equivalent per day, with new start-ups in Nigeria, Norway, and the British North Sea expected to boost output this year. Total aims for an 8% increase in production and maintains its proposed dividend unchanged.

site_title: Malaysia's CIMB expects Indonesian operations to improve from Q2
summary: Malaysia's CIMB Group Holdings Bhd expects its Indonesian operations to improve from the second quarter due to lower loss provisioning. The company's Indonesian unit, Bank CIMB Niaga Tbk PT, plans to raise US$313 million via a 30-year zero-coupon bond and establish a new 6 billion ringgit conventional and Islamic bond programme. CIMB Chairman Nazir Razak expects significant improvement in performance from the second half of 2015, driven by reduced provisions and lower operating expenses.

site_title: 1MDB Malaysia needs to improve disclosure on 1MDB's debt, CIMB says
summary: Malaysia's 1Malaysia Development Bhd needs to disclose more information about its debts to reassure investors, according to CIMB Group Holdings Bhd's chairman Nazir Razak. The state-owned investment company amassed 41.9 billion ringgit in borrowings as of March 2014, missing a loan repayment in November. The government has ordered an audit and will enforce the law if wrongdoing is uncovered, contributing to the ringgit's 8.2% decline against the US dollar. CIMB's concerns have unsettled Malaysian financial markets, highlighting the need for transparency on 1MDB's debt.

site_title: Qatar expanding gas production with US$1b recovery plant
summary: Qatar is expanding its gas production with the US$1 billion Jetty Boil-Off Gas Recovery Project, which recovers 29 billion cubic feet of gas annually from over 500 ships. The plant, a joint venture of Qatar Petroleum and major energy companies, has the capacity to produce 100 million cubic feet of natural gas daily, equivalent to 600,000 tons of LNG. This recovered gas will power 300,000 homes and is being sent to Qatar's LNG production plants, increasing output to 77 million tons last year.

site_title: South Korea antitrust body investigating Oracle for software bundling
summary: South Korea's antitrust body is investigating US database services provider Oracle Corp for allegedly bundling its new software offerings into maintenance services contracts with customers. The investigation, expected to be concluded in June or July, aims to determine if the practice limits fair market competition. Oracle has not commented on the matter. This move follows a trend of tech companies facing antitrust scrutiny globally for their business practices.

site_title: Currency hedge catch-22 confounds Indonesia as rupiah swings
summary: Indonesia's rupiah is Asia's most volatile currency, with a one-month onshore implied yield of 13.05% in April, making it expensive to hedge against exchange-rate losses. State-owned companies are reluctant to hedge due to the high cost, which could hurt the economy. Less than 30% of companies' new foreign-currency debt is hedged, and companies like Pertamina and PT Aneka Tambang are considering hedging, but are deterred by the cost. Bank Indonesia is considering relaxing rules on structured products to offer a less expensive hedging option, but this may take time to resolve.

site_title: Nepal earthquake: Rebuilding cost to exceed US$10b
summary: Nepal's earthquake, the country's most devastating in eight decades, has resulted in a death toll exceeding 4,300 and could climb beyond 6,000. The estimated cost to rebuild will exceed US$10 billion, equivalent to half of Nepal's US$20 billion economy. The government is struggling to rescue trapped survivors, citing a lack of adequate equipment. Finance Minister Ram S. Mahat appealed for international help in the reconstruction efforts, which will take years to complete.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end flat on Tuesday
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended flat on Tuesday, rising 9.16 points to 28,442.75, despite losses on Wall Street and a decline in Shanghai. The Shanghai Composite Index fell 1.13%, while the Shenzhen Composite Index dropped 2.76%. Dealers await the outcome of a key US Federal Reserve policy meeting.

site_title: Nepal earthquake: Toll could reach 10,000, govt on "war footing"
summary: Nepal's death toll from a 7.9 magnitude earthquake could reach 10,000, Prime Minister Sushil Koirala said, as the government orders intensified rescue efforts and appeals for foreign aid. The latest death toll stands at 4,349, with over 7,000 injured and many left homeless due to destroyed homes and aftershocks. Koirala has issued orders to improve relief coordination and will address the nation later. The government needs tents, medicine, and other supplies, with many people sleeping outdoors due to the disaster.

site_title: Sri Lanka raises US$81.25m through development bonds
summary: Sri Lanka raised US$81.25 million through two- and three-year dollar-denominated development bonds, with the two-year bonds selling at 6-month Libor plus 360 basis points and the three-year bonds at 6-month Libor plus 377.20 basis points. The government received bids worth US$45 million for the two-year bonds and US$63.25 million for the three-year bonds, exceeding the initial offer of US$25 million each. The successful bond sale is seen as a step towards raising funds for the country's development projects.

site_title: BlackRock said to debut euro bonds as low costs lure US sales
summary: BlackRock, the world's largest money manager, has debuted its first euro-denominated bonds, priced at 85 basis points above benchmark rates. The move comes as European Central Bank measures stimulate the economy, lowering the cost of issuing bonds in the euro currency to historic lows. This has attracted buyers such as Coca-Cola and Berkshire Hathaway, luring them with low yields of 0.85% and 0.91% respectively.

site_title: Panasonic says annual profit soared 49% to US$1.5b
summary: Panasonic's annual profit surged 49% to $1.5 billion, driven by strong results from its auto parts unit and lower costs from restructuring. Revenue edged down 0.3% to $7.7 trillion. The company expects a 180 billion yen net profit for the current fiscal year. Panasonic's shift to focus on lesser-known businesses has helped boost its bottom line, making it a standout among rivals Sony and Sharp, which continue to struggle.

site_title: Templeton fund ends reign in Asia as top picks falter
summary: Templeton's Asian Growth fund, led by Mark Mobius, has ended its six-year reign as the top equity fund in Asia after suffering its second consecutive quarter of investor withdrawals. The fund shrank to $11.8 billion, trailing the $12.2 billion First State Asia Pacific Leaders fund, due to underperformance and substantial allocations in energy and Thai equities. Despite Mobius' bullish view on Thailand, the fund's returns fell short of the MSCI All Country Asia ex-Japan index.

site_title: Europe: Stocks fall at open on Tuesday
summary: Europe's leading stock markets fell on Tuesday, with London's FTSE 100 down 0.43%, Frankfurt's DAX 30 down 0.03%, and Paris' CAC 40 down 0.23%. The decline was attributed to bank and healthcare sectors. The US-EU trade talks are also in focus, amid concerns over tariffs.

site_title: Job ad volumes for legal and compliance positions in Singapore up 30% in Q1
summary: Job ad volumes for legal and compliance positions in Singapore increased 30% in Q1 2015, according to the Robert Walters Asia Job Index. IT and accounting jobs also saw significant growth, with a 18% rise. However, product and logistics operations saw a 14% drop in job ads due to higher operating costs. The overall annual growth in job adverts for Singapore in Q1 2015 was 0.4%. Companies prioritize hiring Singaporean professionals, focusing on talent development and retention to attract top talent.

images.alt_text: The legal and compliance sector saw the biggest rise in job advertising volumes in Singapore in Q1 2015, increasing 30 per cent year on year, according to the Robert Walters Asia Job Index.

site_title: Daiwa quarterly profit rises on brokerage commissions, trading
summary: Daiwa Securities Group Inc reported a 16% increase in quarterly profit to 38.5 billion yen, beating analyst estimates, driven by rising brokerage commissions and trading income. The company attributes the growth to shifting savings towards investments, boosting commissions, and plans to expand overseas to mitigate potential decline in Japan's retail business due to demographic changes.

site_title: China "extremely concerned" by Asean statement on disputed sea
summary: China's foreign ministry expressed "extreme concern" over an Asean statement warning of land reclamation and navigational freedom in the disputed South China Sea. The Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean) criticized China's reclamation work, citing erosion of trust and potential security risks. China claims 90% of the South China Sea and asserts its right to build on islands, but Asean leaders warned of the threat to stability. China has exercised restraint, saying it will resolve the dispute through direct talks, but tensions remain.

site_title: French consumer confidence at highest in five years
summary: French consumer confidence reached its highest level in five years in April, rising to 94, its highest since January 2010. Despite concerns about unemployment, which rose to 10% and has been a nagging issue, households are more willing to make significant purchases and are slightly more upbeat about their finances. This reading is in line with expectations and comes as President Francois Hollande has vowed to not seek re-election unless unemployment falls.

site_title: Google teams up with European media to boost online journalism
summary: Google is launching a 150 million euro Digital News Initiative to support innovative online journalism in partnership with eight European publications, including The Guardian and Les Echos. The initiative aims to promote quality journalism through technology and innovation, with a focus on product development, training, and research. Google will invest US$160 million in the project to increase revenue, traffic, and audience engagement. The partners will set up a working group to drive these goals, with the goal of supporting quality journalism in Europe.

images.alt_text: Google will on Tuesday launch a 150 million euro programme to support innovative online journalism in partnership with eight European publications.

site_title: UK recovery slows sharply in pre-election blow for Cameron
summary: Britain's economy slowed to 0.3% growth in the first quarter of 2015, down from 0.6% in the previous quarter, according to the Office for National Statistics. This is the slowest growth since 2012, raising concerns about a potential recession. The decline in growth is a setback for Prime Minister David Cameron, who is seeking re-election next week. The UK's economic recovery appears to be slowing, contradicting Cameron's campaign promise of a strong economy.

site_title: Woodside Holdings cuts dollar bets, citing volatile policies
summary: Woodside Holdings, a Singapore-based family office, has cut its dollar bets to 75% from 80% due to uncertainty over the Federal Reserve's interest rate hike. The company's chief investment officer, David Fergusson, cited the Fed's dovish comments and unexpected policy changes in other countries as reasons for the reduction. Despite this, Fergusson expects the dollar to strengthen over the medium term and still holds a higher percentage of its assets in dollars than at the start of last year.

site_title: Oil prices down in Asian trade on Tuesday
summary: Oil prices in Asia fell on Tuesday after Saudi Arabia's Deputy Oil Minister, Prince Abdulaziz bin Salman, stated that the country has no intention of cutting production to alleviate a global supply glut. US benchmark West Texas Intermediate fell 73 cents to $56.26 and Brent eased 68 cents to $64.15. Saudi Arabia, the world's top crude exporter, has maintained its production levels and is focusing on maintaining its market share through price cuts. This move puts pressure on oil prices, which have shed about half their value since last June due to a global supply glut.

site_title: Asean leaders concerned over South China Sea land reclamations
summary: Southeast Asian leaders expressed "serious concerns" about China's land reclamation in the disputed South China Sea, citing erosion of trust and potential undermining of regional security and stability. The Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean) issued a statement, without naming China, after a summit in Kuala Lumpur. The move comes amid China's claims to nearly all of the South China Sea and artificial island creation. The statement reflects a consensus among Asean member states, including the Philippines and Vietnam, which have been critical of China's actions.

site_title: China: Stocks ease off seven-year highs, but banks firm
summary: China stocks ended lower on Tuesday, easing off a seven-year high, as ChiNext slumped 3% amid concerns over valuations. Despite this, banking stocks gained amid speculation of new policy tools by the central bank. The People's Bank of China may consider buying lenders' assets to improve banks' asset quality. The CSI300 index fell 1.4% and the Shanghai Composite Index lost 1.1%. PetroChina shares dropped 2.2% after dismissing merger rumors, while China COSCO and Merchants Energy Shipping Co jumped 10% on consolidation expectations.

site_title: GIF team to be based in Singapore to develop project pipeline
summary: A Global Infrastructure Facility (GIF) team will be based in Singapore to develop project pipelines, complementing the country's infrastructure hub strategy. The GIF, launched last year, aims to raise long-term financing for infrastructure projects in emerging markets, with Asia requiring US$1 trillion in investments annually between 2010 and 2020.
