The Singapore office will oversee strategy, product development, and pipeline management, collaborating with the World Bank and other partners to generate projects and investment opportunities for Singapore companies. The GIF has raised over US$80 million in seed funding from its founding partners.

site_title: Costa Coffee owner ramps up expansion plans as CEO departs
summary: Whitbread's CEO, Andy Harrison, announced his departure by February 2016, as the company posted a 18.5% increase in underlying pretax profit to 488.1 million pounds. Whitbread raised its expansion targets for Premier Inn and Costa Coffee, aiming to have 85,000 Premier Inn UK rooms by 2020 and 2.5 billion pounds in sales for Costa by 2020. The company also increased its full-year dividend by 19.4%. Harrison will become chairman of Dunelm.

site_title: Texchem-Pack's losses narrow to RM1.68 million for Q1
summary: Texchem-Pack Holdings reported narrower losses of RM1.68 million (S$627 million) for the first quarter of 2015, compared to RM3.96 million in the same period last year. Revenue rose 13% to RM47.52 million, driven by higher sales in data storage, consumer electronics, and medical/life sciences segments. Loss per share decreased to 1.21 Malaysian sen, down from 2.86 Malaysian sen in the previous year. Administrative expenses increased 9% due to higher payroll costs.

site_title: Australia: Shares fall as investors cash in on recent rally
summary: Australian shares fell 0.6% to 5948.5, reversing a recent rally, as investors cashed in on gains. The benchmark hit a seven-year closing high of 5982.7 on Monday. New Zealand's benchmark NZX 50 index edged up 0.1%. The decline was attributed to investors booking profits after a recent winning streak in the iron ore market.

site_title: China's slowdown puts Asian central banks in a bind as Fed looms
summary: China's slowing economy is putting pressure on Asian central banks to lower interest rates further, amid a looming US Federal Reserve rate increase. China's growth in the first quarter slowed to its weakest since 2009, prompting the People's Bank of China to cut rates and free up cash for lending. Central banks across Asia, including Australia, South Korea, Indonesia, and Japan, are expected to consider further rate cuts to stimulate growth. The International Monetary Fund forecasts Asia's growth to remain at 5.6% this year, with signs of economic improvement emerging in countries such as South Korea and Thailand.

site_title: China Telecom Q1 net profit falls 9% after tax reform
summary: China Telecom's first-quarter net profit fell 9% to 5.05 billion yuan due to the introduction of China's new value-added tax, replacing a flat rate tax. Revenue declined 2.1% to 81.45 billion yuan, but subscriber numbers rose 3.2 million to 189 million.

site_title: Singapore's growth supported by G3 recovery, offset by China slowdown: MAS
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) expects Singapore's economy to post moderate growth of 2-4% in 2015, supported by a firmer recovery in the G3 countries (US, Japan, and eurozone), but offset by China's slowdown, which is forecast to grow 6.9% in 2015. The MAS attributes the growth to a broad-based boost to external-oriented sectors, but notes that uncertainties include a slowdown in China, corporate realignments in the IT industry, and continued weakness in oil-related transport engineering sectors.

site_title: China MOF warns of slowing revenue, urges local govts to speed bond issuance
summary: China's Ministry of Finance has warned of slowing tax revenue growth and urged local governments to speed up bond issuance to address provincial budget concerns. The warning comes as land sales revenue drops sharply and banks are reluctant to purchase new debt at offered yields. Local governments are urged to issue bonds "rationally" and complete the work urgently, amid signs of faltering plans to tap the local government bond market to make up for lost tax revenue. This move signals official concern over provincial budgets at a critical time for the economy and planned fiscal reforms.

site_title: Prices of completed apartments and condos up 0.2% in March: NUS index
summary: Singapore's completed non-landed private homes and condos experienced a 0.2% price increase in March, according to the NUS flash estimate. The sub-index for Central Region rose 0.1%, while Non-Central Region prices increased 0.3%. However, small apartment and condo units in the Islandwide category saw a 0.4% decline. The revised February index values showed a 0.2% overall price drop, less than the initially estimated 0.3% decrease.

site_title: Fair, stable oil prices to benefit everyone: Saudi oil minister
summary: Saudi Arabia's Oil Minister Ali al-Naimi stated that fair and stable oil prices will benefit both producers and consumers, allowing for steady global supply and demand growth. The 50% drop in global oil prices since June last year has helped growing Asian economies but posed challenges for oil producers. Naimi emphasized the need for stable prices, citing China's 2008 intervention to calm markets when oil prices spiked. Saudi Arabia remains committed to meeting Asia's oil demand and maintaining its position as the world's largest crude exporter.

site_title: Gold clings on near US$1,200 ahead of Fed meeting
summary: Gold prices rose to near US$1,200 ahead of the Federal Reserve's policy meeting, driven by a weaker dollar, short-covering, and expectations of no rate hike in June. Spot gold remained steady at US$1,200.90 per ounce. A soft dollar boosted gold, seen as a safe haven, while options-related buying and declining expectations of a rate hike supported prices. If the Fed holds rates near rock-bottom levels, gold prices could be supported, but higher rates could dent demand.

images.alt_text: Gold clung to sharp overnight gains on Tuesday, bolstered by a weaker dollar and short-covering on rising expectations the Federal Reserve would not hint at a June rate increase at its policy meeting this week.

site_title: StanChart Q1 profits fall 22% as bad debts jump from year ago
summary: Standard Chartered reported a 22% drop in Q1 profits to $1.5 billion, largely due to a 80% increase in bad loan losses to $476 million. The bank attributed this to challenging trading conditions. Despite this, the bank remains on track to achieve its capital and cost targets for the year. CEO Peter Sands stated that underlying business volumes are strong, and the bank is taking steps to de-risk and build capital. Standard Chartered expects to reach a core capital ratio of 11-12% by the end of the year.

images.alt_text: Asia-focused bank Standard Chartered said profits in the first three months of this year fell 22 per cent from a year ago as losses from bad loans jumped 80 per cent and trading conditions remained challenging.

site_title: Indonesia says FDI commitments rise 14% y-o-y in Q1
summary: Indonesia saw a 14% year-on-year increase in foreign direct investment (FDI) commitments in the first quarter of 2015, reaching 82.1 trillion rupiah (S$8.4 billion). The Investment Coordinating Board attributed this growth to the mining, food, and utilities industries. The figure is an encouraging sign for President Joko Widodo, who aims to boost economic growth to over 7% by 2019. This growth is expected to be driven mainly by attracting offshore investment.

site_title: Tsipras presses for early Greek debt deal but flags referendum
summary: Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras expressed confidence in an early deal with international creditors, despite sidelining his finance minister over demands deemed unacceptable by his government. Talks with EU and IMF lenders have stalled over reforms, including pension cuts and labor market liberalization. Athens is weeks away from running out of cash, and Tsipras warned that he would consider a referendum if lenders' demands were not met.

site_title: Japan says two in cockpit after Alps crash
summary: Japan has announced that all domestic airlines must have at least two people in the cockpit at all times, following the Germanwings crash. A flight attendant or an off-duty pilot will be required to accompany the remaining pilot when one leaves the cockpit. The rule will be implemented within a week, with the Transport Ministry overseeing the change. This measure aims to improve safety and follows similar regulations introduced by other countries.

site_title: StarHub to upgrade networks using software-defined networking technology
summary: StarHub, a Singaporean telecommunications company, plans to upgrade its core and access networks using software-defined networking (SDN) technology to better handle growing data traffic. The move aims to enhance network operational capabilities, support corporate customers' business needs, and contribute to Singapore's Smart Nation initiatives. SDN technology allows for rapid and flexible network provisioning, enabling customized solutions for corporate customers. The upgrade is part of StarHub's strategy to accelerate growth and improve efficiency, with the goal of becoming its second-largest revenue contributor in the near future.

site_title: Japan expects clean energy to edge out nuclear power
summary: Japan expects clean energy to surpass nuclear power by 2030, with solar and hydro generating 24% of the nation's electricity, compared to nuclear's 22%. The draft report proposes a diminished role for nuclear, which accounted for 29% in 2010, following the Fukushima disaster. Gas will supply 27%, coal and oil 26% and 3%, respectively. The shift is attributed to the public's opposition to nuclear power and rising electricity prices, with clean energy sources becoming increasingly cost-competitive.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close 0.38% higher
summary: Tokyo stocks closed 0.38% higher on Tuesday, driven by a surge in Fanuc, a factory robotics giant. The Nikkei 225 index rose 75.63 points to 20,058.95, while the Topix index increased 0.52% to 1,627.43. Investors await earnings reports from major Japanese firms and a US Federal Reserve policy meeting.

site_title: AVJennings enters into JV to develop land in Australia's Victoria
summary: AVJennings, a UK-based property developer, has entered into a joint venture with AustralianSuper to develop a 1.4 million square metre plot of land in Wollert, Victoria, Australia. The project, expected to start in May 2016, will deliver over 2,000 lots and form an integral part of AVJennings' Victorian business. AustralianSuper, Australia's largest superannuation fund, is investing in the project.

site_title: Nepal earthquake: Rescuers battle to reach victims
summary: A 7.8-magnitude earthquake struck Nepal, killing at least 4,310 people and injuring 7,953. The impoverished country's leader, Prime Minister Sushil Koirala, said relief workers struggled to reach remote communities due to lack of equipment and rescue experts. Aid efforts are ongoing, with the US pledging $10 million in relief. The earthquake also triggered an avalanche on Mount Everest, killing at least 18 people. Many Nepalis fled the capital, Kathmandu, in search of supplies, with long queues forming at petrol stations and supermarkets.

site_title: Asia: Stocks mostly higher, weak yen boosts Tokyo
summary: Asian markets rose on Tuesday, with Tokyo boosted by a weaker yen, while European stocks declined due to bank and healthcare concerns. Despite losses on Wall Street, Japan's Nikkei and Shanghai rose 0.63% and 0.18%, respectively. The euro managed to hold its value despite ongoing Greek bailout talks. The US Federal Reserve's policy meeting is expected to provide insight into interest rate hikes, while the Bank of Japan is also set to meet. Oil prices fell in Asia, and gold prices rose.

site_title: Worst Asian default forgiven as Indonesia billionaire sells debt
summary: Indonesia's billionaire Eka Tjipta Widjaja's family has successfully returned to the dollar bond market, with companies backed by the family receiving orders for two bond issues at yields below Asian junk-rated peers. Developer PT Bumi Serpong Damai raised $225 million and Golden Agri-Resources Ltd issued $125 million in notes. The move comes 14 years after the family's Sinarmas empire defaulted on a $14 billion debt by its Asia Pulp & Paper business, and amid a dollar-debt restructuring. Investors are showing faith in the family's credit, with the combined market value of 12 family-controlled companies holding steady at about $15 billion.

site_title: Thailand braces for poor Q1 after weak export performance
summary: Thailand's exports fell 4.45% in March, marking a third consecutive decline, and are expected to post a quarterly contraction of 0.3% in Q1, according to the Commerce Ministry. The poor performance is attributed to slow global growth and a strong baht, as well as weak domestic demand and large infrastructure projects. The Bank of Thailand is likely to keep the benchmark interest rate unchanged at 1.75% after a surprise cut last month, as recent data suggests a need for stability.

site_title: China probes doctor over US$18m bribes, 100 houses
summary: China's top prosecutor is investigating senior doctor Wang Tianchao in Yunnan province for taking over US$18 million in bribes, including cash, real estate, and parking spots. Wang, head of No. 1 People's Hospital, allegedly used his position to seek bribes related to construction projects and medical procurement. He received 35 million yuan (S$7.5 million) in cash, 100 properties worth around US$13 million, and coveted car parking spaces. The investigation aims to hold Wang accountable for his alleged corruption.

site_title: South Korea's Park 'regrets' bribery scandal
summary: South Korean President Park Geun-Hye expressed regret over a bribery scandal that implicated her closest aides, forcing Prime Minister Lee Wan-Koo to resign. The scandal, triggered by the suicide of a former construction company head, implicated eight people, including Park's chiefs of staff. Park promised a sweeping review of corruption in her country, following a decline in her approval ratings. This is not her first scandal, as bribery has been a fixture of South Korean politics for decades, with two former presidents serving prison terms for taking bribes.

site_title: Yahoo unveils new online video series
summary: US internet giant Yahoo has unveiled 18 new online video series, including 14 featured in digital magazines, to attract a larger audience and advertisers. The series will focus on beauty, show business, finance, music, and comedy, with deals to broadcast music festivals and events. CEO Marissa Mayer is trying to transform Yahoo into a growth-oriented company, with encouraging revenue growth of 8% in the latest quarter. The move aims to compete with search market leader Google and attract a younger market segment.

site_title: Two new programmes for Singapore entrepreneurs and startups unveiled
summary: Singapore unveiled two new programmes to support entrepreneurs and startups, Modern Ageing and NEAT IP. Modern Ageing, a four-month programme, focuses on creating businesses for an ageing population, while NEAT IP connects startups to technologies to enhance business and productivity. The programmes are co-organised by NUS Enterprise and ACCESS Health International, and supported by Duke NUS and the Ministry of Health. The initiatives aim to address Singapore's ageing population and support the country's Smart Nation ambitions. The programmes are expected to commence in August and offer seed funding, incubation support, and access to technologies and partners.

site_title: Australia: Shares retreat as key 6,000 mark remains out of reach
summary: Australian shares retreated from the key 6,000-point psychological barrier, falling 15.2 points or 0.3% to 5,967.0, as investors cashed in profits after a recent winning streak. Iron ore prices rose, but concerns about a short-lived rebound kept resource stocks under pressure. Health stocks, led by CSL and ResMed, were the biggest drag, while energy stocks and banks were mixed.

site_title: Q&M to buy TP Dental for S$28.6 million
summary: Q&M Dental is set to acquire TP Dental Surgeons for S$28.6 million, with S$18 million paid in cash and the remaining S$10.6 million issued as shares. The acquisition is a result of agreements with five doctors and is seen as a strategic move to expand Q&M's services. TP Dental, founded in 1973, has consistently delivered excellent results with post-tax net profits of S$1.9 million in FY2013. Q&M's CEO Ng Chin Siau stated that TP Dental is a "perfect fit" with a strong management team.

site_title: Singapore: STI follows Wall Street's decline to slip 0.15% at opening
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.15% to 3,510.69 at opening, following Monday's decline on Wall Street. Top gainers included DBS, Great Eastern, and IHH. 135.1 million shares worth S$131.2 million changed hands, with gainers outnumbering losers 103 to 96.

site_title: SGX issues 'trade with caution' note on Yanlord shares
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has issued a "trade with caution" note on Yanlord Land Group shares due to a near 23% rise in its share price between April 23 and 27. Yanlord was unaware of any reasons for the significant jump, and the SGX will investigate possible transgressions and work with regulatory agencies to maintain a fair market.

site_title: CAAS awards contract on air traffic management to UK's NATS
summary: CAAS has awarded a contract to UK-based air traffic management firm NATS to enhance air traffic navigation services at Changi Airport. NATS won four out of five work packages in a bidding process and will expand its Singapore office. The contract, which started in March 2015, will run through 2017 and aims to support the airport's expansion plans, including the incorporation of a third runway. The deal is part of CAAS's efforts to improve air traffic management capabilities in anticipation of future growth.

site_title: Hong Kong stocks down 0.13% at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell 0.13% in early trading on Tuesday, with the Hang Seng Index dropping 35.92 points to 28,397.67. This decline was attributed to profit-taking, following a sell-off on Wall Street. In mainland China, the Shanghai Composite Index was flat, while the Shenzhen Composite Index rose 0.12%.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks rise from 15-yr highs, TW$ jumps again
summary: Taiwan's stocks rose 0.2% on Tuesday, reaching a 15-year high, with the TAIEX index extending a 0.6% gain from the previous session. TSMC and Cathay Financial led the gains. The Taiwan dollar jumped 1.141% to TW$30.509 to the US dollar. This follows Monday's milestone at the 10,000-point level not seen since 2000.

site_title: Greek PM sees EU-IMF loan deal by early May
summary: Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras expressed confidence that tough negotiations with EU-IMF creditors will reach a deal by early May, aiming to secure 7.2 billion euros in remaining bailout money. Tsipras said his government would consider privatisations, such as the management of the port of Piraeus, as concessions if a deal is reached. He also defended his Finance Minister Yanis Varoufakis, calling him an "important asset" to the government, and stated that the negotiations would not require a referendum if a deal is reached within his mandate.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 1.2 points to 1858.38. Losers outnumbered gainers 152 to 149, and volume reached 237 million lots worth RM87.3 million.

site_title: BP's deepwater oil hunt off Australia evokes Gulf disaster fears
summary: BP's deepwater oil exploration project in the Great Australian Bight is sparking concerns over environmental risks, with critics citing the company's lack of full emergency-response plans and the potential for a disaster similar to the 2010 Gulf of Mexico oil spill. The project, which aims to drill 400 km west of Port Lincoln, has been met with scrutiny from environmentalists, who warn of the risks to 18 threatened species and the remote, hostile environment. BP asserts it has the technological capability to safely explore the area, but the company's plans must be reviewed by Australian regulators.

site_title: White & Case's Qualifying Foreign Law Practice licence extended till April 2019
summary: White & Case, a US-headquartered law firm, has had its Qualifying Foreign Law Practice (QFLP) licence extended by Singapore for four years until April 2019. This licence allows foreign law firms to practise certain areas of Singapore law. The firm, which has 38 offices across 26 countries, is pleased with the extension and sees it as an opportunity to build on its past success in the region. The licence extension is a significant development for White & Case's presence in Singapore, where the firm has had a meaningful presence for over 30 years.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open 0.49% higher
summary: Tokyo stocks opened 0.49% higher on Tuesday, led by a surge in Fanuc. The Nikkei 225 index rose to 20,080.34 points. A weaker yen is seen as positive for Japanese exporters, lifting hopes for bumper earnings from Panasonic and Honda. Investors await the outcome of the Federal Reserve policy meeting and the release of major Japanese firms' full-year earnings.

site_title: Time Warner Cable open to merger talks with Charter
summary: Time Warner Cable is open to merger talks with Charter Communications following a failed US$45 billion bid by Comcast. The two companies are in friendly negotiations, contrasting their previous acrimonious exchanges. Charter views Time Warner Cable's stock as more valuable given its recent 33% stock increase, and is open to deals with other companies. Analysts debate whether Charter will pursue a friendly deal or try to secure TWC for less. Liberty Media Corp's John Malone had previously stated his intention to pursue Time Warner Cable if the Comcast deal fell through.

images.alt_text: Time Warner Cable Inc is open to merger discussions with Charter Communications Inc following a failed US$45 billion bid by Comcast Corp, according to people familiar with the matter.

site_title: JPMorgan's head of commodities risk leaves for Citi
summary: JPMorgan Chase & Co's global head of commodities risk in London, Kiru Rajasingam, has left the company to join Citigroup. Rajasingam, who joined JPMorgan in 2007, is set to start an unidentified oil trading role at Citi later this year.

site_title: Sydney home prices surging at 5 times wages fuel bubble woes
summary: Sydney home prices have surged more than five times faster than wages in the past two years, fueling concerns of a housing bubble. Home prices have risen 40% from their 2012 trough to a record high, while wages growth has slowed to the lowest on record. Regulators have called for banks to strengthen lending standards, and Moody's has warned of potential values to drop. The Reserve Bank of Australia is expected to cut interest rates, but economists predict a moderation or correction in house prices versus wages may not occur until interest rates rise.

site_title: As UK election looms, Ireland fears 'Brexit'
summary: The Irish government is urging Britain to remain in the European Union as the UK prepares for a potential referendum on EU membership. Irish Foreign Minister Charlie Flanagan warns that "Brexit" would be a significant blow to the EU and Ireland's economy, which is still recovering from a painful crisis. The Irish government has launched a study on the possible impact of a Brexit and is urging Britain to keep its EU membership intact. The UK's Prime Minister David Cameron has promised a referendum on EU membership by 2017 if he is re-elected.

site_title: Singapore's CPF Board recovers about S$378.2 million in CPF arrears
summary: Singapore's CPF Board has recovered S$378.2 million in CPF arrears from underpayments, nonpayment, and late payments by employers. This affects over 288,000 employees, with S$14 million recovered from 2,000 employers and S$364.2 million from 4,300 late-paying employers. The recovery is attributed to the WorkRight campaign, which has seen a 50% reduction in non-compliant employers since its launch three years ago. Employers who failed to pay or underpay CPF contributions can face fines of up to S$10,000 and/or imprisonment.

images.alt_text: Singapore's CPF Board (CPFB) has recovered about S$378.2 million in CPF arrears from underpayments, nonpayment and late payment of contributions by employers.

site_title: Bank of Korea's Lee says weak yen, China economy hurting exports
summary: Bank of Korea Governor Lee Ju Yeol stated that the weak yen and China's sluggish economy are negatively affecting South Korea's export performance. Economic momentum in the second quarter will be crucial for the economy's future growth. Despite a weak domestic recovery, recent positive signs suggest the economy may be on the path to improvement.

site_title: Chinese stocks in Hong Kong fall after Petrochina profits slump
summary: Chinese stocks in Hong Kong fell for the first time in three days after PetroChina Co. reported a 82% slump in profits in the first quarter. PetroChina's decline led to a 4% drop in the company's stock price, while China Petroleum & Chemical Corp. fell 2.8%. The Hang Seng China Enterprises Index lost 0.3%, while the Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.6%. Despite the decline, other companies like Gree Electric Appliances Inc. saw a 10% surge in mainland trading due to a jump in new income and bonus shares.

site_title: Cordlife Group-linked China Cord Blood Corp gets acquisition proposal
summary: Cordlife Group has announced that China Cord Blood Corp (CCBC) has received a proposal letter from Golden Meditech seeking to acquire CCBC for US$6.40 per share, including senior convertible notes. Cordlife Group, which holds a 9.13% stake in CCBC, has not entered into an agreement with Golden Meditech and has "no certainty" that a transaction will occur. The acquisition proposal is expected to be financed with available cash, debt, and equity capital.

site_title: Chinese rail firm signs US$5.5 bln worth of deals in Africa
summary: China Railway Construction Corp Ltd (CRCC) has signed two deals worth US$5.5 billion in Africa, with a US$3.5 billion intercity railway line in Nigeria and a US$1.93 billion residential construction project in Zimbabwe. These deals are part of China's "going global" strategy to make its railway firms more competitive globally. The deals are seen as a milestone for CRCC's expansion into Africa, with Beijing pushing to increase its influence in the region. The moves are also part of a planned merger of China's top two train-makers, set to create a US$26 billion behemoth.

site_title: Samsung Heavy says no plan to seek merger with Samsung Engineering again
summary: Samsung Heavy Industries Co denied plans to merge with Samsung Engineering Co again, citing shareholder opposition that led to a failed US$2.5 billion takeover attempt in November. The proposed merger was part of the Samsung Group's efforts to simplify its shareholding structure for succession control. The group's patriarch, Lee Kun-hee, is set to step down, and his children are expected to take over.

site_title: Police attacked, stores ransacked in Baltimore riots
summary: Rioters in Baltimore attacked police and looted stores after the funeral of Freddie Gray, a 25-year-old African American man who died in police custody. At least 15 police officers were injured, and 27 people were arrested. The National Guard was deployed, and a city-wide curfew was imposed. The unrest was sparked by a cryptic message on social media and follows a string of high-profile confrontations between African Americans and police. President Barack Obama was briefed on the situation, and a civil rights probe has been launched by the US Justice Department.

site_title: Gold posts biggest advance in three months as Fed drives whipsaw
summary: Gold prices surged 2.4% to $1,203.20 an ounce, its largest gain in three months, as investors await the Federal Reserve's interest rate decision, driving increased volatility. The US economy's slow growth has led traders to expect a delay in rate hikes, boosting gold's appeal as a hedge against inflation. Silver also rose, with a 4.8% gain, and other precious metals, including platinum and palladium, followed suit.

site_title: Greece PM rules out default, cites wages and pensions as priority
summary: Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras has ruled out defaulting on debt, citing paying wages and pensions as his government's top priority. Greece faces a payment of 700 million euros to the IMF on May 12 and has a deal with creditors by May 9 to ease liquidity conditions. Tsipras emphasized that paying pensions and wages is his government's obligation to society, saying "our priority is to pay wages and pensions."

site_title: French jobless number hits new record in March
summary: France's unemployment rate reached a new record of 3.51 million in March, a 0.4% increase from February, with young people particularly affected. The Labour Ministry attributed the slight increase to the government's job creation efforts, citing the smallest increase in jobless workers since 2011. However, the INSEE statistics office forecasts a 20-year record high of 10.2% unemployment rate this year, citing insufficient economic growth to drive down unemployment.

site_title: Europe stocks gain amid Greece optimism as Hsbc, Volkswagen rise
summary: Europe's Stoxx Europe 600 Index rose 1% to 412.42, driven by a Greek stock rally amid optimism over a possible bailout deal. Greece limited Finance Minister Yanis Varoufakis' role in talks, while Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras is willing to suspend minimum-wage plans to reform proposals. HSBC Holdings rose 3.1%, while Volkswagen AG surged 5.3% after its chairman resigned. Other notable gains included Cap Gemini SA, Mediaset SpA, and Swedish Orphan Biovitrum AB.

site_title: Worst Asian default forgiven as Indonesia billionaire sells debt
summary: Indonesia billionaire Eka Tjipta Widjaja's family company, Sinarmas, has issued two bond issues worth US$225 million and S$125 million, respectively, at yields below average for Asian junk-rated peers. The move comes 14 years after the company's Asia Pulp & Paper business defaulted on US$14 billion in debt, marking Asia's worst corporate default. Investors are showing faith in the company's credit, with the combined market value of 12 family-controlled companies remaining steady at about US$15 billion over the past year.

site_title: First Sponsor turns in Q1 FY15 profit, acquires two hotels in Amsterdam
summary: First Sponsor, a Mainboard-listed property group, reported a net profit of S$10.73 million in Q1 FY15, up from a loss of S$9.18 million a year ago. Revenue surged 70.5% to S$12.65 million, driven by higher property financing revenue. The company also announced the acquisition of two hotels in Amsterdam for S$78.8 million, with an expected net rental yield of 7.2%. This follows a 25-year master lease arrangement starting last year.

site_title: Yahoo unveils 18 new series in push to expand digital video
summary: Yahoo! Inc unveiled 18 new series in a digital video push, bringing its total to 55 series. The new content includes original programming, live broadcasts, and magazine videos on subjects like cars and food. CEO Marissa Mayer is relying on video to drive a turnaround at the struggling Web portal, with revenue increasing 58% in the first quarter. The move aims to compete with rivals like Google and Facebook, and is seen as a key part of Yahoo's efforts to revamp its offerings and attract marketers and consumers.

site_title: Apple is rushing to increase watch supply, finance chief says
summary: Apple is struggling to meet demand for its new watch, with Chief Financial Officer Luca Maestri stating the company is working hard to catch up on supply. Despite a strong customer response, initial shipments pushed past the official release date of April 24, with some customers not receiving their devices until June. Apple expects to ship around 547,000 watches by June 11 and is optimistic about its sales, with estimates suggesting up to 14 million units could be sold in the fiscal year. The company's retail stores initially did not carry the watch, instead directing customers to online purchases.

site_title: UK growth slowdown to put economy back in election spotlight
summary: The UK economy is expected to show a slowdown in the first quarter of 2015, with quarterly growth forecast to ease to 0.5%, down from 0.6% in the previous quarter. This is the slowest pace in over a year, potentially hurting Prime Minister David Cameron's re-election bid. Economists predict a sharper slowdown, possibly as low as 0.3%. The data is set to be released on Tuesday, adding to concerns about the economy's recovery.

site_title: Teva Pharma said to take acquisition bid directly to Mylan holders
summary: Teva Pharmaceutical Industries Ltd is meeting with key Mylan shareholders to win their support for its US$40.1 billion takeover offer, despite Mylan's initial rejection. Mylan Chairman Robert Coury said the offer "grossly undervalues" the company and would expose it to a "problematic culture" and management with a "poor record." Teva may consider a hostile bid if negotiations don't progress, and has reiterated its offer of US$82 a share in cash and stock. Mylan's board rejected the initial offer, seeking a valuation of at least US$100 a share.

site_title: Japan March retail sales fall 9.7% year on year; misses consensus
summary: Japan's retail sales plummeted 9.7% in March from the same period last year, missing economists' forecasts of a 7.3% drop. This decline was largely attributed to a surge in sales before a consumption-tax increase. On a seasonally adjusted basis, sales fell 1.9% from the previous month. The data suggests a slowdown in Japan's economy, which may put pressure on policymakers.

images.alt_text: Japanese retail sales fell 9.7 per cent in March compared with the same month last year, when sales had surged the most in 17 years ahead of a consumption-tax increase, government data showed on Tuesday.

site_title: Oil prices turn mixed
summary: Oil prices have turned mixed, with Brent North Sea crude falling 10 cents to $65.18 a barrel and US benchmark West Texas Intermediate rising 29 cents to $57.44 a barrel. The price fluctuations are attributed to fighting in Yemen, which has fueled concerns about a supply disruption in the Middle East. Analysts expect prices to remain volatile due to high supply levels and ongoing geopolitical tensions, particularly in Yemen.

site_title: Deutsche bank strategy fails to convince as actions unclear
summary: Deutsche Bank's new five-year plan to cut costs by selling Postbank and shrinking its securities business has failed to impress investors, with the stock falling 4.6% in Frankfurt trading. The bank aims to achieve 3.5 billion euros in annual cost savings, but analysts question how it will achieve this target, citing a lack of specific actions and concerns about rising legal costs. Deutsche Bank's profitability target has also been scrapped, and the bank plans to reduce leverage by 150 billion euros by 2018, while spending 2.5 billion euros on digital projects.

site_title: YuuZoo expects to earn S$33.4 million profits from sale of franchisee licences
summary: YuuZoo expects to earn S$33.4 million in profits from the sale of franchisee licences, based on a valuation by a "big four" audit firm. The company has signed new franchise agreements covering 59 countries and commits to 5.7 million new users within a year and 40 million users within three years. Revenues and profits from the sale will be included in YuuZoo's accounts once the franchisees start operations.

site_title: Britain's Conservatives take one point lead ahead of election: YouGov poll
summary: Britain's Conservatives have taken a one percentage point lead over the Labour Party ahead of the election, according to a YouGov opinion poll. The Conservatives now hold 35% of the vote, while Labour is at 34%. The poll, released on Monday, marks a slight shift from the previous day's result. The two main parties have been neck-and-neck in opinion polls since the start of the year, with neither expected to secure an overall majority in the 650-seat Parliament.

site_title: Nepal earthquake: Google, Facebook join Red Cross to find thousands missing
summary: Google and Facebook have joined the Red Cross in Nepal to locate thousands of people missing after the earthquake. A Facebook "Safety Check" feature helped reunite a couple, Caroline Siebald and Charles Gertler, with their families after they managed to send a message to her mother in the US. Similar efforts have been made by people around the world, including migrant workers and IT professionals, using social media to look for missing relatives and share news of survival in Nepal.

site_title: Google sets up marketplace to buy patents
summary: Google has established an online marketplace for buying patents, allowing patent owners to sell their intellectual property to the company. The "Patent Purchase Promotion" aims to simplify the process, removing friction from the patent market and reducing the risk of patent trolls. Patent holders can submit their patents for review through a portal from May 8 to May 22, with Google evaluating and making offers by June 26. Deals are expected to be completed by late August, with the platform initially limiting to US patents and holders with a US tax identification number.

site_title: Philippines' February imports at 13-month high
summary: The Philippines saw a 11.2% increase in February imports, the highest since January 2014, driven by a 42.4% rise in electronics imports. Mineral fuels, however, declined 18.7% from last year. The country's trade deficit in the first two months of the year was US$1.68 billion, down from US$2.1 billion in 2014. The Philippine central bank expects a narrower trade deficit this year, leading to bigger balance of payments and current account surpluses, with estimates of US$1 billion and US$6.8 billion, respectively.

site_title: Vision & leadership
summary: The Singapore Business Awards recognized several companies and leaders for their transformative strategies in the current global economic environment. The winners include Straits Trading Company's chairman Chew Gek Khim, who led the company's transformation from a low-yielding asset-based business to an investment holding company, and Mapletree Investments' CEO Hiew Yoon Khong, who integrated the roles of a developer, investor, and capital allocator to drive growth. Other award winners include Affin Hwang Capital's Maimoonah Hussain, Sheng Siong's Lim Hock Chee, and Tecity Group's Chew Gek Khim, who were recognized for their leadership and vision in driving organizational change and growth.

site_title: No early end to ECB quantitative easing: economists
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is unlikely to end its quantitative easing (QE) program early, with over two-thirds of economists surveyed predicting it will stop in September 2016 as planned. Most respondents expect the program to be tapered, but not before the end of the year. Economists predict the euro area's economic recovery will continue, with inflation rates and unemployment rates expected to improve, but some question the ECB's willingness to remain aggressive in its monetary policy.

site_title: China's checks on solar quality could spur more consolidation
summary: China's National Energy Administration is conducting inspections to crack down on defects in solar panels, aiming to improve quality and efficiency. The inspections will target equipment and projects, potentially leading to consolidation among manufacturers. A cut in preferential power prices for solar projects is also expected, as the government seeks to balance incentives with quality standards. The crackdown may accelerate solar installations, with the government aiming to approve 17.8 gigawatts of PV plants this year and reach 100 gigawatts by 2020.

site_title: US union membership sinking, except for managers: study
summary: US union membership has declined over the past 15 years, except for management occupations, where numbers rose from 438,000 to 562,000. Union membership sank to 14.6 million people, or 11% of the workforce, from a peak of 35% in the 1950s. The decline is attributed to weakening unions, with economists blaming income disparity. Despite this, 48% of Americans still support unions, with 62% backing workers' right to unionize in industries like manufacturing and fast-food service.

site_title: US: Stocks snap record-setting rally
summary: US stocks closed at record highs on Monday, snapping a three-day rally, after investors awaited Apple's earnings results and a Federal Reserve policy meeting. The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 42.17 points, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index fell 0.41% and 0.63%, respectively. Apple rose 1.8% ahead of its earnings report, while biotech shares slid after Mylan rejected a hostile takeover bid.

site_title: Euro racks up third straight gain against dollar
summary: The euro gained its third consecutive gain against the dollar, reaching $1.0889, amid expectations that the US Federal Reserve will not raise interest rates before July. This follows the Fed's previous decision to delay a June rate hike, citing slower first-quarter growth and the need for further economic data. Analysts believe the Fed will study the economy's improvement before making a decision. The euro's gain was driven by the Fed's cautious stance, while the yen weakened ahead of a Japanese central bank meeting.

images.alt_text: The euro scored its third straight gain against the dollar on Monday amid rising expectations that the US Federal Reserve will not raise interest rates before July.

site_title: Forward-looking internal audit in step with business changes
summary: Internal audit functions must evolve to address the most relevant risks in today's rapidly changing business landscape. According to PwC's Global 2015 State of Internal Audit Profession study, only 11% of chief audit executives (CAEs) characterize their internal audit functions as providing value-added services, while 60% of CAEs and 45% of stakeholders expect internal audit to take on a more proactive role. To achieve this, internal audit functions must focus on the right risks, develop talent with relevant skills and business acumen, align with enterprise risk management (ERM) and other lines of defense, and leverage data analytics throughout the audit life cycle.

site_title: Greece clips Varoufakis' wings as it reorganises bailout-negotiating team
summary: Greece has reorganized its bailout-negotiating team, limiting Finance Minister Yanis Varoufakis' role, after three months of talks with creditors failed to secure aid. Deputy Foreign Minister Euclid Tsakalotos will now oversee day-to-day negotiations with creditors, while Varoufakis will focus on supervising political talks. The move comes as Greece struggles to meet its debt payments and amid criticism of Varoufakis from euro-area finance ministers. The Greek government remains committed to its anti-austerity stance, but a reshuffle may help streamline negotiations and boost credibility.

site_title: Air conditioning use poised to spike worldwide: study
summary: A study published in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences warns that air conditioning use worldwide is poised to spike by the end of the century, leading to significant increases in electricity consumption and greenhouse gas emissions. Researchers predict that nearly 70% of households will have air conditioning by the end of the century, with the US, India, and other nations experiencing the largest increases. This could result in $3+ billion in increased annual electricity expenditures and a 23+ million ton annual increase in carbon dioxide emissions.

images.alt_text: The use of air conditioning may rise dramatically by the end of the century, requiring far more electricity and sending pollutants into the atmosphere at unprecedented rates, researchers warned Monday.

site_title: No need for strong stimulus, says PBOC economist
summary: China's chief economist, Ma Jun, says the country's employment situation is good and progress has been made in structural adjustments, making strong stimulus unnecessary despite downward economic pressure. The People's Bank of China (PBOC) recently lowered interest rates and reserve requirements to prevent a sharp slowdown. Ma stated that the central bank has "a lot of tools" to adjust monetary policy if needed, but there is no need for strong stimulus at present.

site_title: Why digital banks in financial services are gaining ground
summary: A growing wave of digital startups in financial services is gaining ground, targeting dissatisfied bank customers with low-cost structures and innovative offerings. These firms aim to siphon off banks' profitable lines of business, such as foreign exchange fees and card-not-present fees. To stay competitive, traditional banks must invest in digital reinvention, adopting a stringent approach to funding, governance, and talent management. By thinking like venture capitalists, running multiple innovation models, and fostering a culture that encourages innovation, banks can succeed in the digital landscape.

site_title: RHB takes CIMB sukuk deal crown months after megabank bid stalls
summary: RHB Capital surpassed CIMB Group Holdings as Malaysia's top sukuk arranger, managing 20 Islamic bond offerings valued at 3.9 billion ringgit in 2015, compared to CIMB's 23 transactions valued at 3.8 billion ringgit. The shift comes three months after a proposed megabank deal between RHB, CIMB, and Malaysia Building Society was scrapped due to unfavourable economic conditions. Competition is intensifying in the Malaysian sukuk market, which has seen a 11% decline in sales to 22.7 billion ringgit this year.

site_title: Apple profit soars on iPhone, China sales
summary: Apple reported a 33% increase in quarterly profit to $13.6 billion, driven by strong iPhone sales, including 61 million units in the first quarter. Revenue rose 27% to $58.01 billion, with China sales contributing 71% growth. The company also announced a $50 billion share buyback program and a 52 cents per share dividend increase, aiming to boost shareholder value. Apple's shares rose 1.5% after the announcement, with the company's market capitalization reaching over $770 billion.

site_title: Fed expected to remain patient on rate hike
summary: The US Federal Reserve is expected to remain patient on rate hikes amid a US growth slowdown and concerns over the Greek crisis. The Fed's decision comes after signs of easing economic conditions, including a strong dollar and low inflation. Analysts suggest the Fed may delay its first rate hike, now expected in June, until September, citing uncertainty over the impact of the oil price plunge on inflation. The Fed's stance will be influenced by inflation data and its desire to show the economy has momentum.

site_title: Using technology, training to transform healthcare delivery
summary: Singapore's government is implementing technology and training to transform healthcare delivery, addressing the country's spiraling healthcare costs and aging population. Since 2009, investments in medical technology and digital health have increased, with a focus on hospital workflow, health mobility, and health analytics. This has led to improvements in customer satisfaction, with the healthcare sector's fourth-quarter 2014 score helping lift overall customer satisfaction levels. Polyclinics have seen significant improvements, with SingHealth and National Healthcare Group Polyclinics implementing measures to reduce wait times and enhance patient experience.

site_title: Facebook launches video calling in Messenger app
summary: Facebook has introduced free video calling in its Messenger app, transforming its mobile messaging service into a full-featured platform. The feature is available for Messenger's 600 million users, competing with other video calling services like Skype, FaceTime, and Hangouts. This move aims to expand Messenger's reach and features, mirroring its social network's capabilities.

images.alt_text: Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg introduces a new messenger platform at the F8 summit in San Francisco, California, on March 25, 2015. Facebook Inc introduced free video calling in its Messenger phone app on Monday as the company seeks to transform its mobile messaging service into a full-featured platform with the same reach as its 1.4 billion user social network.

site_title: In historic sea-change, US, Japan revise defense ties
summary: The US and Japan unveiled new defense cooperation guidelines, expanding Japan's global role amid concerns over China's rising influence. The revised rules allow Japan to come to the aid of US forces in a third country and deploy minesweeper ships in the Middle East. US Secretary of State John Kerry and Defense Secretary Ashton Carter, along with Japanese counterparts, announced the new rules after talks in New York.

site_title: The sky's the limit
summary: Sky Creation, a space-solutions provider, aims to differentiate itself by adding value to its clients. The company, led by CEO Sky Tan, has expanded its services to include carpentry, manufacturing, and a boutique selling lighting and accessories. Tan emphasizes the importance of quality control, ensuring that materials meet high standards. To achieve this, Sky Creation has taken control of its supply chain and invested in servers to optimize productivity. The company is also exploring new ways to educate customers, such as its "Musée" interior design materials library in Singapore and a similar space in Johor, Malaysia.

images.alt_text: Dr Sky Tan, chief executive of Sky Creation, is adamant that the company add value for its clients. His company lays claim to being the first in the business to open a "library" of materials samples and catalogues for its clients, so they can learn and make better design decisions for their properties in consultation with designers.

site_title: Google opts for fashion mojo
summary: Google has launched a fashion trend report service, leveraging its search data to identify popular and emerging trends. The company will issue reports twice a year, distinguishing between sustained growth trends, seasonal growth trends, and fads. Google's fashion team has begun working with major retailers, including Calvin Klein, to incorporate real-time search data into fashion planning and forecasting. The service aims to provide clients with data on what will be in vogue next, helping them stay ahead of the fashion curve.

site_title: Make music, make better companies
summary: A professional orchestra, the Metropolitan Festival Orchestra, has developed a unique corporate training program, "Sounds of Leadership," led by conductor Ian Woodward. This program teaches corporate managers the finer points of leadership and communication by immersing them in the music-making process of the orchestra. Participants learn through live interaction, including conducting the orchestra, to gain a fresh understanding of their leadership roles. The program has received positive feedback from corporate leaders, with one calling it "one of the most memorable learning experiences."

site_title: Private equity versus the strategic acquirer
summary: Private equity firms have gained an advantage in M&A activity, surpassing strategic buyers in terms of financial discipline, flexibility, and focus. PE firms' fundraising challenges impose financial discipline, while their ability to conduct rigorous financial analysis and network of advisers enables them to identify potential targets swiftly. Strategic buyers, on the other hand, have the benefit of intimate industry knowledge but may face limitations in target selection and due diligence. PE firms' leverage and ability to structure and negotiate deals give them an edge in valuation, financing, and transaction execution.

site_title: Otto Marine's shares tumble over creditor's winding-up application
summary: Otto Marine's shares plummeted 9.5% to a two-week low after the company announced an unnamed creditor was attempting to wind it up over $1.6 million in debt. However, the company paid the debt in full, and the creditor withdrew the application. Analysts expressed concerns that the creditor's actions may raise operational issues, despite the matter being resolved.

site_title: Big Data: Risks and possibilities
summary: Big Data presents opportunities for businesses to gain a competitive edge, but it also comes with significant risks. The growth of Big Data is fueled by new technologies and tools, allowing for real-time processing and analysis of vast amounts of data. However, this also raises concerns over privacy and data protection, with the risk of data theft through cybercrime and potential identification of individuals through cross-referencing of multiple data sets. To mitigate these risks, businesses must invest in scalable data quality tools and practices, and ensure they have robust processes for managing the quality of their data.

site_title: France's 'economic patriotism' laws expected to have limited effect
summary: France's "economic patriotism" laws, aimed at protecting domestic industry, are expected to have limited effect in preventing foreign takeovers. The laws, including double-voting rights for state and long-term shareholders, were introduced to encourage foreign investors to take over French blue-chip firms. However, data shows that foreign bidders have already secured $104 billion in merger and acquisition deals in 2014, with the state not always benefiting. The laws may block an all-out bidder, but their impact is debatable, and other countries, like the US, have similar measures in place.

site_title: HPH Trust raising tariffs by up to 10%
summary: Hutchison Port Holdings Trust (HPH Trust) is raising its port tariffs by up to 10% to prepare for mega container ships. The trust posted a 48.9% drop in first-quarter net profit to HK$285.8 million. Revenue for the quarter increased 0.1% to HK$2.95 billion. The move aims to free up space for larger vessels by adding more berths in Shenzhen port.

site_title: Takata airbags linked to 105 injuries, 6 deaths
summary: Takata airbags linked to 105 injuries and 6 deaths, according to the US Senate Commerce Department. The company recently provided updated information, citing 40 additional alleged incidents of rupturing airbags, including one death. About 20 million vehicles worldwide have been recalled to fix the problem. The cause of the defective airbags remains unknown, and lawmakers are calling for the production of safe replacement inflators. Honda and other manufacturers are taking steps to ensure the safety of replacement inflators, but independent validation is needed.

site_title: Gender diversity in Asia-Pacific: Too little of a good thing
summary: A study by Korn Ferry found that the Asia-Pacific region's female representation on corporate boards is still under-represented, with a regional average of 9.4% in 2012-2013. Only 24 boards out of 1,000 had four or more female directors, and women held only 3% of chair positions. Countries like Australia and New Zealand have shown improvement, while others like South Korea and Indonesia have seen a decline. To achieve a balanced representation, companies, governments, and organizations must work together to promote female candidates and increase transparency in the board selection process.

site_title: Deutsche Bank pledges overhaul to boost earnings, cut risk
summary: Deutsche Bank is undergoing a major overhaul to boost earnings and cut risk, with plans to sell 200 billion euros in investment bank assets and exit 10% of its countries of operation. The bank will also close 200 branches and sell its Postbank retail division by 2016, resulting in annual cost savings of 3.5 billion euros. The restructuring aims to improve leverage ratio and dividend payout ratio, with investments in India and China, and will cost 3.7 billion euros. The plan is part of a larger effort to address the bank's costly universal banking model and meet investor expectations.

site_title: Territorial spats can derail region: PM Lee
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong urged Asean to address rising tensions in the South China Sea and terrorism, citing threats to regional economic growth. China's land reclamation activities in the disputed sea lane have raised concerns, and Lee emphasized the need for a code of conduct to prevent incidents. Asean must work with China to maintain peace, stability, and freedom of navigation and overflight in the South China Sea. Lee also called for closer cooperation in the fight against terrorism and extremism.

site_title: Sustained shipping recovery an 'illusion': Hamburg Sued chief
summary: Hamburg Sued, Germany's second-largest maritime carrier, believes container shipping won't experience a sustainable recovery due to overcapacity in the market. CEO Ottmar Gast stated that shippers should boost capacity to achieve economies of scale and cut costs to survive. Despite this, the company expects to boost transport volume by 20% this year through new business acquisitions and investments. Hamburg Sued's transport volumes rose 2.3% last year, while sales fell 1.3% due to lower freight rates.

site_title: Aztech Q1 profit down on one-off costs
summary: Aztech Group's first quarter profit dropped 27.5% to S$1.22 million due to one-off start-up costs, including the setup of a central kitchen and launch of a new outlet. Revenue remained flat at S$85.59 million, with growth in its electronics division offset by lower revenue from material supply and marine divisions. The group expects "elevated headwinds" in the next year due to foreign exchange volatility and low inflation, but sees potential for increased demand in LED lighting products.

site_title: Healthy competition behind banks' improved performances
summary: Singapore's banking sector achieved a record level of customer satisfaction in 2014, with the Customer Satisfaction Index of Singapore (CSISG) score rising 4.1% to 72.2 points. This marks the highest score in the index's eight-year history. The improvement is attributed to healthy competition among banks, which has led to innovative offerings and better services, such as mobile banking and innovative products. The top-ranked bank, DBS, saw a significant 5.4% jump in its score to 75.8, while other banks like OCBC and Citibank Singapore also reported improvements in customer satisfaction.

site_title: BHP fighting A$522m tax bill on Singapore marketing hub
summary: BHP Billiton is contesting A$522 million in Australian tax bills on its Singapore marketing operations up to 2010, citing minimal tax payments since 2006. The global miner released figures in response to an Australian Senate panel's investigation into corporate tax avoidance. BHP claims to have paid almost no tax in Singapore during this period, prompting the tax bill. The dispute is part of a broader investigation into tax avoidance practices by major corporations.

site_title: Singapore seeks to attract more foreign system schools
summary: Singapore is launching a Request-For-Interest (RFI) exercise to attract more foreign system schools, offering 30-year leases for sites zoned for education. The move aims to enhance quality of education and attract international companies to the country. Existing and new schools can apply, with evaluations based on proposal quality, track record, and financial ability. The government aims to provide sufficient high-quality international school places, following previous RFI exercises that have awarded sites to schools such as Stamford American International School and Global Indian International School.

site_title: New orders drying up for Sembcorp Marine
summary: Sembcorp Marine, a rigbuilder, posted a 13.6% decline in Q1 net profit to S$105.9 million due to weak new orders and lower revenue from rigbuilding and repair. The company has zero rig orders for the year and only a S$56 million floating storage and offloading contract. Despite a S$10.9 million foreign exchange loss, its net order book stands at S$10.6 billion, with deliveries until 2019. The company faces a challenging market environment and may slow down construction for its projects with Sete Brasil.

site_title: HSBC shares soar in London, HK on report it may spin off UK consumer bank
summary: HSBC shares surged 4.6% in London and 2.7% in Hong Kong after a report suggested the lender may spin off its UK consumer bank, worth £20 billion, as it considers relocating from the UK to reduce a bank levy. The bank's chairman, Douglas Flint, said it would review its domicile, citing the UK's high bank levy. Analysts believe Hong Kong is the most likely destination, with a potential transfer costing HSBC no more than $1.5 billion.

site_title: Is a public float off the table?
summary: Mapletree Investments, a Singapore-based real estate capital management firm, has abandoned its plan to go public with an initial public offering (IPO). Despite initial reports in 2008, the company has decided not to pursue a listing, citing compliance with listing standards. The decision was made between the company and its shareholders.

site_title: PSA venture begins operations at Saudi port
summary: Saudi Global Ports (SGP), a joint-venture between the Public Investment Fund and PSA International, began commercial operations at the King Abdul Aziz Port in Dammam, Saudi Arabia. On April 23, SGP handled its first commercial vessel, M/V Niara, with 1,011 twenty-foot equivalent units (TEUs). The terminal has a capacity of 1.8 million TEUs per annum and features 16 meters of water depth and six quay cranes. The partnership aims to contribute to the development of the Kingdom's economy, with both companies expressing their commitment to the project.

site_title: Adopting customer-centric tweaks to get ahead
summary: Life insurers in Singapore have improved customer satisfaction levels by adopting needs-based services, resulting in a 11.4% year-on-year increase in the Customer Satisfaction Index of Singapore (CSISG) to 73.6 points. AIA Singapore, Great Eastern Life, and Prudential Singapore led the sub-sector with the highest scores, with AIA achieving a score of 75.2. Insurers have implemented technology to improve information flow, simplified claims processes, and developed holistic financial planners to deliver better customer service, leading to higher satisfaction levels and increased competitiveness in the industry.

site_title: Delivering the best for the client
summary: The Singapore Management University's Institute of Service Excellence (ISES) roundtable discussed the 2014 findings of the Customer Satisfaction Index of Singapore (CSISG), which showed a slight increase to 71.1 points. Key sectors contributing to the rise were finance and insurance, and healthcare. Experts emphasized the importance of developing a startup mindset, creating a business ecosystem for disruptive growth, and delivering high-quality customer service. However, low productivity and a "trading mentality" remain challenges, and experts called for new valuation metrics and a focus on financial and social inclusion to drive future growth.

site_title: Tainted oil from the US makes its way to Asia
summary: Chevron Corp has shipped 1 million barrels of contaminated California oil to Asia, bound for two tankers, after the oil sat in tanks outside San Francisco for three years. The tainted oil, which costs $46 a barrel, was valued at $97 a barrel before contamination. The shipment is rare, as most crude is barred from leaving US borders, and the export is seen as a result of "circumstance" rather than economic necessity. The oil's value has dropped by $50 million since it was flushed from a pipeline in 2012, and its ultimate destination remains unknown.

site_title: SilkAir inks S$2m MOU to boost travel into Singapore
summary: SilkAir has signed a S$2 million MOU with GTA to boost travel to Singapore. Despite a 3.1% drop in visitor arrivals last year, the airline aims to improve awareness and address misconceptions about Singapore's affordability. The partnership will span a year and focus on marketing efforts to attract more tourists. This comes as SilkAir seeks to increase inbound traffic from its 48 destinations into Singapore.

site_title: Asean: The next horizon
summary: Asean, a regional grouping of Southeast Asian nations, has immense potential despite challenges and uneven progress among member countries. The region is expected to replace China as the world's manufacturing hub and become the fifth largest economy by the end of the decade. Integration through a single market and production base is crucial, but addressing infrastructure needs, harmonizing business conditions, and promoting financial integration are significant challenges. Singapore, a key player in the region, will need to adapt to changing economic conditions and competition from neighboring Mekong economies. Strong domestic leadership and business support are essential for accelerating regional integration.

images.alt_text: Singapore will face greater competition from the Mekong economies as they move up the manufacturing value chain. It will need to carve out new niches to maintain its competitiveness.
Singapore will face greater competition from the Mekong economies as they move up the manufacturing value chain. It will need to carve out new niches to maintain its competitiveness.

site_title: Spotify lives out its vision of building a 'new music economy'
summary: Spotify is said to have achieved its vision of building a 'new music economy'. This shift comes after the music industry was disrupted by digital file-sharing platforms and piracy. The company's legitimate, payable song downloads, as seen with iTunes, initially dampened the appeal of full albums. However, Spotify's success may have paved the way for a new era in music consumption, allowing artists to monetize their work directly through streaming services. This marks a significant shift in the music industry, with Spotify's vision of a 'new music economy' potentially changing the way music is consumed and monetized.

images.alt_text: Ms Kaur, Spotify's managing director for Asia, said the company has paid out some US$2 billion in royalties to the music industry.

site_title: Survivor 2015: the GOP reality game show
summary: The article discusses the requirements to run for the US presidency, including being a born US citizen, at least 35 years old, and living in the US for 14 years. It pokes fun at the idea that these requirements are the only barriers to running for president, implying that ambition and optimism can be sufficient. The article also humorously highlights the challenges of overcoming perceived shortcomings, such as lack of experience and supporters.

site_title: Oil bears routed by spring thaw in prices
summary: Speculators rapidly reduced their bearish bets on oil prices, cutting short positions by 32% in a week, according to US Commodity Futures Trading Commission data. This surge in net-long positions marked the highest since July. The move was driven by renewed Saudi strikes on Yemen and slowing US output. Oil prices rose over 2% amid investor uncertainty about market outlook, tariffs, and sanctions.

site_title: CSISG 2014 scorecard
summary: The article appears to be a collection of news summaries from various sources, but none of them are directly related to the "CSISG 2014 scorecard" mentioned in the title. However, no content is provided for the scorecard.

site_title: Danish households repaying home loans at record pace
summary: Danes repaid home loans at a record pace of 3.87% last year, with borrowers shifting to fixed-rate mortgages due to record low interest rates and higher fees on riskier loans. The development has helped banks meet demands to cut risks, with the industry emerging stronger than it was five years ago. Low interest rates, which have been in place since Denmark cut its key rate to minus 0.75%, have driven borrowers to fixed-rate mortgages, now available as low as 2% for 30 years.

site_title: Miners may invest US$5b in Argentina with new president, new rules
summary: Argentina's new president may ease capital restrictions, potentially attracting US$5 billion in investments from major miners such as Goldcorp, Glencore, and Yamana Gold. These companies are considering investments in the country if the new government is more receptive to the industry. Industry officials and provincial representatives have expressed optimism about the prospect of new investments, citing the potential for increased economic growth and job creation.

site_title: Finding the way forward when growth stalls
summary: Management teams face a debate over using company cash for share buybacks or growth investments. While buybacks boost earnings and stock prices, they fail to stimulate growth. Investing in innovation is crucial for job creation and GDP growth. Companies that fail to grow will eventually shrink or die, destroying jobs and value. This failure to invest has negative implications for both individual companies and the economy.

site_title: Singtel, UOB help keep STI in the black
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 2.85 points to 3,515.85 on Monday, driven by strong gains in Singtel and UOB, with Singtel rising S$0.07 to S$4.44 and UOB S$0.35 to an all-time high of S$25.05. Other notable movers included Noble Group, Golden Agri-Resources, and ThaiBev, with the latter being the most intraday swinging STI stock. Market turnover was 1.8 billion units worth S$1.3 billion, with Nomura reporting a neutral global equity sentiment measure.

site_title: White House takes cybersecurity pitch to Silicon Valley
summary: Defense Secretary Ash Carter toured Silicon Valley to announce a new military strategy for computer conflict, urging software engineers to consider a tour of service to fend off hackers. He acknowledged the need to rebuild trust with Silicon Valley, whose companies have rolled out encryption technologies to defeat surveillance. Carter's appeal was part of a campaign to undo the damage of Edward Snowden's revelations, which showed a difference in view between the government's actions and public perception. Many computer security professionals expressed skepticism about a technical compromise that would enable the government to decode emails and track web activities.

images.alt_text: "I think that people and companies need to be convinced that everything we do in the cyber domain is lawful and appropriate and necessary," says Mr Carter.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary:

GuocoLeisure maintained an "add" rating with a target price of S$1.18, despite ceasing management of 19 Thistle Hotels, citing potential catalysts such as expanding hotel earnings and a bounce in oil prices.

site_title: Drawing out a simpler future
summary: Singapore-based startup Crayon Data aims to simplify enterprises' choices for customers by leveraging big data and machine learning. The company's "SimplerChoices" engine combines data from review sites, social media, and internal enterprise data to provide personalized product recommendations. With clients such as major banks and telcos in Singapore and global expansion plans, Crayon Data seeks to hit the one-billion-customers mark by 2018 and become a globally relevant software company.

site_title: Bacteria scare sparks recalls by ice-cream makers
summary: At least five ice-cream companies, including Blue Bell Creameries, have recalled products due to listeria contamination. The recalls follow DNA testing and genome sequencing, which have allowed health officials to link illnesses to tainted ice-cream since 2010. The companies are reviewing procedures to ensure no other outbreak occurs. Listeria mainly affects older people, pregnant women, and those with weakened immune systems, and can only be killed by cooking or pasteurizing. Industry leaders are taking steps to improve food safety protocols, and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention is expanding the use of DNA sequencing to other bacteria.

site_title: Peer pressure works, at Sheng Siong
summary: Sheng Siong, a Singaporean supermarket chain, has adopted an unconventional performance evaluation system where weak performers face social pressure to shape up or quit, rather than facing a performance evaluation. Employees receive a fixed bonus regardless of their performance, and those who struggle are encouraged to leave. The company's CEO, Lim Hock Chee, believes that money is earned through individual efforts and that employees must grow and learn to increase their salary. Despite doing away with performance evaluations, the company has seen significant growth, with a 22.3% increase in net profit last year and a 5.6% year-on-year increase in revenue.

site_title: Considered measures to ensure donations benefit many
summary: The Tan Chin Tuan Foundation (TCTF) has shifted its focus from solely providing basic necessities to rehabilitation, physiotherapy, and equipment, maximizing the impact of its donations. The non-profit organization channels 67% of its donations towards education and 20% towards community service. By requiring beneficiaries to submit a plan for their donations, TCTF evaluates the effectiveness of its giving and makes considered decisions. The foundation's efforts have helped more than 200 beneficiaries in Singapore and Malaysia, as well as charities in the Asean region.

site_title: Big mergers likely to reduce China SOEs to 40: report
summary: China is planning to cut the number of its central government-owned conglomerates to 40 through massive mergers, as part of a broader plan to overhaul the country's underperforming state sector. The consolidation will primarily take place in commercial sectors, especially in competitive industries, to avoid cut-throat competition. The move aims to increase resources on large enterprises and reduce losses, following President Xi Jinping's push to raise the performance of China's state sector.

site_title: Market players expect T+2 to be global norm
summary: Singapore's proposed T+2 settlement period, expected to align with global norms within 10 years, has sparked debate. A survey by Omgeo found 82% of respondents support T+2 cycles, while 32% expect all markets to shift to this cycle immediately. The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has been considering the proposal, which could reduce credit risk and improve capital efficiency, but the Society of Remisiers has expressed concerns about limiting contra activity. The SGX has assured that contra trading will not be excluded.

site_title: Landmark ruling on performance bonds in building contracts
summary: The Singapore Court of Appeal has ruled that a clause in a building contract limiting the grounds for an injunction against a call for an unconditional performance bond is enforceable. The ruling, in a case involving developer Asplenium Land and contractor CKR Contract Services, upholds the clause's validity despite CKR's claims of unconscionability. The decision allows property developers to make it harder for contractors to seek an injunction against calls for unconditional performance bonds, a move seen as significant for the construction industry in Singapore.

images.alt_text: Property developers can now make it harder for contractors to seek an injunction against calls for unconditional performance bonds used in building works contracts following a landmark ruling by the Court of Appeal.

site_title: Airbus A380 suffers from lack of orders
summary: The Airbus A380, a double-decker aircraft, is struggling to win new orders after two years of no deals, sparking concerns of its future. Despite its initial success, the plane has failed to meet projections, with only 317 orders secured since 2000. Airbus is re-evaluating its marketing strategy, focusing on its efficiency and mass transportation capabilities, rather than luxury features. The company aims to persuade existing and prospective buyers to adopt denser configurations and increase standard seat capacity to 544.

images.alt_text: Since 2000, the A380 has won just 317 orders, less than a third of the 1,200 Airbus projected in its first 20 years.

site_title: The complaining customer - a potentially happy one
summary: Singapore's national customer satisfaction in the ISES survey reached an all-time high in 2014, despite a rise in complaints rates. The Customer Satisfaction Index of Singapore (CSISG) scored 71.1 points, the highest since its inception in 2007. Only two sectors, finance and insurance, and healthcare, saw increased customer satisfaction. The seeming incongruency can be attributed to the fact that the number of complaining customers has not kept pace with the rise in customer satisfaction, indicating that customers who complain are not necessarily unhappy with their overall experience.

site_title: Affin Hwang sets sights on new heights
summary: Malaysia's Affin Hwang Capital aims to become the top player in investment banking, asset management, and equity sales within its five core units in five years, with a target of doubling its revenue. Led by CEO Maimoonah Hussain, the company seeks to adapt to changing market dynamics, focusing on online brokerage and institutional investments. With a significant acquisition last year and an alliance with Daiwa Securities Group, Affin Hwang aims to differentiate itself from competitors and capitalize on growth opportunities, particularly in the Asian market.

site_title: World's steelmakers fear flood of exports from huge China mills
summary: China's steelmakers, despite domestic industry overcapacity, are benefiting from plunging iron ore prices, leading to a surge in record exports. The country boosted exports by 50% last year to a record 94 million tonnes, with many large mills posting better earnings in 2014. This has raised concerns among rival producers worldwide, including the EU and India, which are imposing anti-dumping duties. China aims to cut overcapacity by 40% and increase the market share of its top 10 mills to 60% by 2025, but small mills face higher environmental costs and tightened credit conditions.

site_title: It's all about the data, and how to mine it
summary: General Electric unveiled plans for computer-connected LED streetlights to collect and analyze performance data for lower costs and better safety. This move is part of a larger trend in the technology world to make everything more efficient. The goal is to create a global efficiency centered on machine-led prediction, but it raises questions about whether this will benefit the many or just the few.

site_title: Why Americans should take notice of UK election
summary: The article discusses the relevance of the 1997 UK general election to US presidential campaigns. An interview with a correspondent from the London Evening Standard in Iowa revealed that many Americans were unaware of the UK prime minister at the time. However, one voter noted that the US would be a valuable ally in case of an extraterrestrial invasion, highlighting the perceived importance of US foreign policy in British eyes.
