site_title: 5,000 small firms back Britain's Conservatives ahead of elections
summary: Leaders of 5,000 small firms in the UK have signed a letter endorsing the Conservative Party ahead of the general election, citing the party's commitment to low taxes as a key factor in creating 1,000 jobs a day since 2010. The businesses praised the Tories as "genuinely committed to making sure Britain is open for business." Labour responded by saying the Tories have "let down Britain's small businesses" and promised to lower the tax burden on small firms if elected. The endorsement comes just 10 days before the May 7 election.

images.alt_text: Leaders of 5,000 small companies have signed a letter endorsing the Conservative Party, saying they would like Prime Minister David Cameron (left) and Finance Minister George Osborne (right) to have the chance to finish what they have started, the Telegraph reported.

site_title: US airlines post record profits in first quarter amid lower fuel prices
summary: US airlines reported record profits in the first quarter, driven by lower fuel prices and strong demand for domestic air travel. Despite the traditionally weak first quarter, carriers such as Delta Air Lines lifted shares on an upbeat outlook for travel demand. The industry's consolidation efforts also contributed to the record earnings, as airlines kept planes full. The financial performance was a significant departure from the weak first quarter, highlighting the benefits of lower fuel prices and increased demand.

site_title: Goodyear to build US$500m tyre factory in central Mexico
summary: Goodyear to build a US$500 million tyre factory in central Mexico, producing six million tyres a year for the Americas. The plant, set to begin production in mid-2017, will employ around 1,000 people and break ground in June. This investment follows major announcements from Toyota and Ford, highlighting Mexico's attractiveness to auto sector companies due to its proximity to the US market, cheap labor, and free trade agreements.

site_title: India's SMEs still to gain from new government
summary: India's small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) are growing impatient with the government's failure to deliver on promised reforms and policies a year into Prime Minister Narendra Modi's premiership. Despite the economy outpacing China, SMEs are still struggling to benefit from Modi's business-friendly initiatives. The lack of progress is causing frustration among India's SMEs, which are a significant contributor to the country's economic growth.

site_title: Artimedia to make splash in Israel with exclusive tie-up with Walla!
summary: Singapore-listed Artivision Technologies' video advertising subsidiary, Artimedia, has partnered Israeli Internet company Walla! Communications for a three-year, exclusive contract. The deal makes Artimedia the largest premium video ad network in Israel, serving over 2.5 million monthly unique users. As part of the contract, Walla! will integrate Artimedia's video ad platform, providing at least 10 million video views per month for ads. Artimedia will pay Walla! a minimum annual cash payment, and its patented video ad technology is expected to bring significant value to Israeli advertisers.

site_title: Lang Lang, Tracy Huang join Sing50 concert
summary: The Sing50 concert, a mega-concert in Singapore, will feature a star-studded lineup of local musicians, including Tracy Huang, Stephanie Sun, JJ Lin, Lang Lang, and Apl.de.ap from The Black Eyed Peas. The concert, organized by The Business Times and The Straits Times, will draw 45,000 people and showcase Singapore's best-loved songs from the past five decades in all four languages. Lang Lang will also perform with 50 pianists in a specially commissioned medley, which will be donated to schools after the concert.

site_title: Apple iPhone sales in China seen surpassing US for first time
summary: Apple's iPhone sales in China are projected to surpass US sales for the first time, driven by strong demand during the New Year celebrations. The company is expected to report a 20% increase in earnings, with 58.1 million iPhones sold worldwide, and a 33% rise in iPhone unit sales in the US. China's growing middle class and increasing smartphone penetration have contributed to the surge in sales, with analysts predicting that iPhone sales in China will continue to outpace those in the US in the coming quarters.

site_title: Big China steel thrives, stoking export fears
summary: China's steel industry is thriving, with big mills posting better earnings in 2014 due to plunging iron ore prices. China's exports of alloy steel rose by 50% to a record 94 million tonnes, and the industry is expected to continue to expand, despite concerns from rival producers. The European Union and India have imposed anti-dumping duties on Chinese steel imports, while China aims to cut the number of steel mills by 40% by 2017. The country's plan to have three to five giant steel players by 2025 has investors backing it, but small mills are struggling due to higher environmental costs and tighter credit conditions.

site_title: The mass exodus at China's top state banks
summary: China's top state banks are experiencing a mass exodus of bankers due to pay cuts and reduced perks as part of Beijing's anti-graft efforts. Senior-level bankers have seen pay cuts of up to 50%, while mid-level bankers have seen salaries decrease by 10-20%. Many are fleeing to newer finance firms such as leasing companies, trusts, and online platforms, which offer higher salaries, longer holidays, and fewer travel restrictions. This trend could make it difficult for state lenders to hire and retain talent, giving newer firms an advantage.

images.alt_text: At Shanghai Pudong Development Bank Co Ltd, a broad 10-20 per cent pay cut at headquarters this year triggered a rush for the exit.

site_title: Flights disrupted as Chile's Calbuco volcano spews more ash
summary: Chile's Calbuco volcano erupted, spewing ash and lava, forcing 6,500 people to evacuate and disrupting flights in southern Chile and beyond. Ash clouds reached Buenos Aires 2,000km away, cancelling flights to and from the US and Europe. A state of emergency has been in place since Wednesday, with authorities emptying a 20km radius around the volcano. Domestic flights operated normally in Santiago, but international flights were cancelled. The government is considering emergency payments for farmers affected by the disaster.

site_title: Like shale oil, solar power is shaking up global energy
summary: Japan is turning to solar power as an alternative to oil-fired power plants, following the Fukushima nuclear disaster. Solar power has become cost-competitive in most major economies, with costs falling 80% in the last decade. Japan is expected to become the last G-7 economy where solar energy is economically viable, freeing it from government subsidies. This shift marks a significant change in Japan's energy landscape, with solar energy poised to become profitable as early as this quarter.

site_title: DBS first-quarter profit rises 3% as interest income increases
summary: DBS Group Holding, Southeast Asia's largest lender, reported a 3% increase in first-quarter profit to S$1.27 billion, driven by a 14% rise in net interest income. The increase was attributed to rising domestic interest rates, allowing the bank to impose greater charges on borrowers. DBS also booked a one-time gain of S$136 million from selling a Hong Kong property investment. Analysts expect the rising interest-rate environment to benefit lenders, with impacts becoming more prominent from the second quarter.

site_title: Greece debt talks to resume after Tsipras, Merkel call
summary: Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras and German Chancellor Angela Merkel agreed to establish stable communication to speed up negotiations on a 7.2 billion euro bailout deal. The talks will resume on Monday after a meeting with Eurogroup chief Jeroen Dijsselbloem. Greek Finance Minister Yanis Varoufakis expressed a willingness to convince creditors of Greece's commitment to reforms, while Merkel emphasized Greece's place in the eurozone. A survey shows 70% of Greeks support an agreement with creditors, as the country seeks to avoid default and potential exit from the euro.

site_title: Indonesia faces int'l resistance to imminent executions
summary: Indonesia is set to execute 10 convicted drug smugglers by firing squad as early as Tuesday, sparking an international backlash. Australia and France have issued last-minute appeals for clemency for two Australian citizens, Andrew Chan and Myuran Sukumaran, while other countries, including Brazil and the Netherlands, have recalled their ambassadors after Indonesia executed their citizens in January. The UN Secretary-General has stated that the death penalty should only be used for the most serious crimes, and Indonesia's President Joko Widodo has rejected all appeals for clemency.

site_title: Prevention of future financial collapse difficult
summary: Regulators in the US and UK are facing criticism for being too late to prevent a potential future global financial collapse, according to a recent case involving a single day trader. Navinder Singh Sarao, a 36-year-old UK resident, is accused of causing the 2010 "flash crash" that wiped off $1 trillion in global stock value. This incident highlights concerns about the risks of quantitative easing and ultra-low interest rates, which have been implemented by central banks, including the US Federal Reserve, European Central Bank, and Bank of England.

site_title: Slow going on Asean-China code of conduct on South China Sea dispute: Shanmugam
summary: ASEAN and China are making slow progress in developing a code of conduct to ease tensions in the South China Sea, despite efforts to calm the territorial dispute. Singapore's Foreign Minister K Shanmugam expressed concern that the issue is being overemphasized, emphasizing the importance of economic, security, and political ties between China and ASEAN countries. ASEAN is on track to become a common market by year-end, with a focus on efficiency and effectiveness, and discussions are underway to reduce unnecessary meetings and potentially merge leaders' meetings.

site_title: Carmageddon
summary: Singapore has established a centre to advance sustainable aviation in Asia-Pacific. The country also launched initiatives to boost employment rates among graduates and support tariff-hit businesses. Deputy Prime Minister Gan will visit the US for trade talks, with a new grant of up to SGD 100,000 available for affected businesses. Additionally, a study suggests Singapore has the potential to become a global hub for advanced chip packaging, while the Workforce Singapore and Singapore Business Federation offer training and career guidance for workers to future-proof their careers.

site_title: BOJ signals concern over surge in Japanese banks' overseas lending
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) has expressed concern over a surge in Japanese banks' overseas lending, citing potential funding risks. This comes as Japanese banks have aggressively expanded their operations in Asia and beyond, with overseas lending doubling to around $600 billion between 2010 and 2015. The BOJ warns that this strategy may lead to funding squeezes and currency mismatches, particularly among regional banks. The central bank's Financial System Report highlights the need to monitor international operations and overseas exposure to ensure the stability of the Japanese financial sector.

site_title: Trading the Asian markets
summary: The Asian markets have seen increased interest and growth, driven by emerging Asia's higher growth expectations and the expansion of advanced economies. The US Federal Reserve's interest rate timeline has been pushed back to the second half of the year, bolstering loose monetary conditions. Mainland China and Hong Kong shares have rallied, with the FTSE China A50 Index soaring past 13,000 and the Hang Seng Index reaching 28,000. Structured products have emerged as a means for retail traders to gain access to emerging Asian markets, offering customizable risk-reward profiles and features such as margin trading and diversification.

site_title: Alibaba, China Telecom tie up to sell inexpensive smartphones
summary: Alibaba Group Holding Ltd and state-owned China Telecom Corp Ltd have partnered to sell inexpensive smartphones, dubbed "Tianyi Taobao Shopping Handsets", in smaller cities and rural areas. The phones come pre-installed with either Alibaba's Taobao app or YunOS mobile operating system, offering buyers 4 months of free 2G data service. This partnership aims to boost mobile commerce and promote Alibaba's mobile operating system in China's cut-throat handset market, where shipments have declined. The move follows Alibaba's expansion of its e-commerce base and mobile operating system.

site_title: Volkswagen chairman quits in power struggle with CEO
summary: Volkswagen chairman Ferdinand Piech resigned as chairman after losing a five-to-one vote of the steering committee in a power struggle with CEO Martin Winterkorn. Piech had previously clashed with other executives, including his hand-picked successor, but was isolated in the vote. The decision came amid efforts to boost profitability and address underperformance in the US market. Piech's resignation was seen as a necessary step to restore trust and cooperation among Volkswagen's leadership.

site_title: Oil hits 2015 peak as Saudis resume strikes on Yemen
summary: Oil prices surged to a four-month high of $65.80 per barrel as Saudi-led airstrikes in Yemen stoked supply tensions in the Middle East, with Brent oil prices hitting a 2015 peak. The renewed bombing campaign in Yemen raised concerns of potential disruption in oil shipping across the region. Meanwhile, gold prices fell as investors eyed receding worries over the Greek crisis, with the metal sliding to $1,183 an ounce.

site_title: Nepal earthquake: IMF ready to send team to assess needs
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) is ready to send a team to Nepal to assess the country's financial needs following the 7.9-magnitude earthquake that killed over 2,400 people and devastated Kathmandu. The team will help the government evaluate the macroeconomic situation and determine any financing needs. The IMF is coordinating with the World Bank and Asian Development Bank to evaluate the impact of the quake. Overwhelmed doctors are moving hundreds of patients onto the streets due to aftershocks, while victims face worsening weather conditions and the risk of disease spreading due to damaged sewage and water systems.

site_title: Cuts to pay and perks trigger flight from China's state banks
summary: China's state banks are experiencing a brain drain as senior bankers quit due to pay cuts and reduced perks. Beijing's austerity measures, aimed at an anti-graft drive, have led to salary reductions of up to 50% for senior-level bankers. Many are moving to alternative financial firms, making it challenging for state lenders to hire and retain talent. This trend could give newer lending institutions a competitive edge, according to headhunters and bankers.

images.alt_text: Bankers at China's top state lenders are quitting in increasing numbers because of cuts to their pay and perks, and moving to a new breed of financial firms such as leasing companies, trusts and online platforms, bankers and headhunters say.

site_title: Shapewear maker Spanx tries to loosen up its image
summary: Spanx, a popular shapewear brand, is rebranding itself to appeal to a new generation of women who prioritize comfort and real beauty over the pursuit of a perfect figure. The company has introduced a new line of products with a less constricting fit and is promoting a message of self-acceptance and empowerment. As the conversation around women's bodies evolves, Spanx is navigating a challenging image turnaround, competing with the growing popularity of athleisure apparel and plus-size clothing.

site_title: Revitalising growth in emerging markets
summary: Emerging markets have experienced a slowdown in growth, prompting investors to consider new setups. To tackle this challenge, cities are establishing smart region master plans to promote connectivity, productivity, and growth. India and Indonesia are investing in smart cities, which are expected to present opportunities worth $1.5 trillion over the next five years. Businesses can lead the charge by adopting innovative solutions, building a culture that encourages innovation, and establishing open ecosystems that facilitate partnerships with vendors. However, each emerging market has unique capabilities and needs, and businesses must adapt to these differences to succeed.

site_title: Taking heart
summary: A rebate scheme in Singapore's NTUC FairPrice has saved over 46.5 million plastic bags and given out more than S$2.3 million in rebates since its launch in 2007. The Straits Times School Pocket Money Fund and self-help organizations received a S$1 million donation from Tang Holdings Group. Meanwhile, the Sailors' Society is expanding its support to seafarers' mental health and well-being through its Wellness at Sea initiative. Singapore aims to ink a carbon credits transfer agreement with its first Asean country by end-2025.

site_title: Emerging economies seen as a drag on global growth: report
summary: The Washington-based Institute of International Finance (IIF) reports that emerging economies are being seen as a drag on global growth, with China's slowdown impacting Asia and other emerging economies in the region. Global growth has slowed to 2% in the first quarter of 2015, with the US experiencing temporary factors and oil exporters struggling. However, the IIF forecasts that momentum will increase in the second half of 2015 and 2016, with annual growth rising to 3.3%. Emerging markets are expected to benefit from solid growth outcomes in mature economies and monetary policy easing, but risks remain tilted to the downside.

site_title: KL-Singapore rail link may miss 2020 deadline by two years
summary: A high-speed rail link between Kuala Lumpur and Singapore may miss its 2020 deadline by two years, potentially pushing the completion date to 2022. The project, estimated to cost nearly RM40 billion, has many "big moving parts" that need to be ironed out, making the original deadline ambitious. The Malaysian Cabinet has approved the project, and MyHSR Corp Sdn Bhd has been established to undertake the project, with Malaysia and Singapore agreeing to share the costs. The project's timeline and details, including design, financing, and governance, are still being finalized.

site_title: Aftershocks cause more terror as Nepal quake toll tops 2,400
summary: A 6.7-magnitude aftershock hit Nepal, causing more terror and triggering fresh avalanches at Everest base camp, as the country's hospitals struggled to cope with the aftermath of a 2,400-deathquake. Terrified residents, many forced to camp out in Kathmandu, were jolted by the aftershock, which compounded the disaster that struck the impoverished nation over 80 years ago. Rescuers were still digging through rubble in the devastated capital as the death toll continued to rise.

site_title: British parties stand by revered NHS principles despite funding gap
summary: British parties stand by the revered NHS principles despite a significant funding gap. The National Health Service (NHS) has been a cornerstone of the UK's healthcare system, but its future is uncertain due to a substantial funding shortage. Despite this, major parties in the UK have reaffirmed their commitment to the NHS, prioritizing its principles over financial concerns. This stance could potentially influence the outcome of the national elections, with the NHS being a key issue in the campaign.

site_title: Solar batteries may soon light up US homes
summary: Tesla is set to unveil a new, noiseless, and easy-to-install home battery, which could revolutionize the way Americans generate and store energy. The battery, priced between $10,000 and $15,000, would allow homeowners to store solar power for nighttime use, reducing their reliance on the national grid. With its simplicity, low maintenance, and 20-year lease options, Tesla aims to make home batteries more accessible to mainstream Americans, who could save on their power bills and even sell excess energy back to the grid.

site_title: Camaraderie key to CBRE's success
summary: CBRE's Singapore office has quintupled its revenue over the past decade due to growth of regional services hubbed in the city. The company attributes its success to "camaraderie and teamwork" among staff, with many long-serving employees. Pauline Goh, head of the Singapore office, highlights the importance of staff retention and repeat business, which she believes contributes to the firm's success. CBRE has expanded its services, including capital markets and capital advisory, and has invested in new business lines to bring in top talent. Despite challenges, Goh emphasizes the need to balance profit and investment in growth.

site_title: Engaging stakeholders
summary: Companies can improve interaction with shareholders at annual general meetings (AGMs) by implementing a two-way communication channel beyond the AGM agenda, such as a shareholder blog or a regular "CEO's question time" via Skype. This approach encourages long-term engagement, transparency, and education, rather than just providing standard FAQs. Companies should also consider hosting investor relation events, perception audits, and using digital and social media channels to engage with shareholders. Effective engagement fosters a culture of openness and transparency, builds trust, and promotes alignment of interests between companies and institutional investors.

site_title: Whither the lead independent director?
summary: A lead independent director (Lead ID) is a corporate governance role introduced in Singapore in 2005, but only about half of the required 537 listed firms have appointed one. The role involves being available to shareholders, resolving issues, and providing feedback to the chairman. Unlike the UK's equivalent Senior ID, the Lead ID's responsibilities are not clearly defined. Some directors, such as Ong Kian Min and Lim Chee Onn, believe the Lead ID should be a senior ID and possess sound judgement to find a balance in a neutral manner. Despite the lack of clarity, 54.4% of required firms have appointed a Lead ID, and some directors argue the role is essential during periods of stress.

site_title: Blue-chip companies and SMEs to compete for new CSR award
summary: Singapore is launching the inaugural Singapore Apex CSR Awards to recognize companies with the highest level of corporate social responsibility (CSR) excellence. The awards, co-presented by the Singapore Compact for CSR, the Singapore Business Federation, and The Business Times, have attracted entries from blue-chip and mid-sized companies across various sectors. The awards aim to showcase companies with successful and sustainable business models, with a focus on environmental stewardship and social responsibility. The first awards will be given out annually, with two categories: small and mid-sized companies, and large companies.

site_title: Plots in Argentina's Napa up for sale to investors
summary: Argentine wine country, particularly the Uco Valley, is attracting foreign investment with plots of land going for US$60,000 an acre. Wineries such as Jose Manuel Ortega's and Michael Evans' Vines of Mendoza LLC are selling off land to investors, citing the potential for increased land prices and wine values after the October presidential election. The region's Malbec wine production has gained popularity, and investors are drawn to the area's high-altitude grapes and lower costs compared to Napa Valley.

images.alt_text: The terraced vineyards (pictured) across the steep slopes in the wine-growing region of Lavaux, Switzerland.

site_title: Buying falls, selling among directors still at low
summary: Buybacks and sales among directors on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) fell in the fourth week of April, with 10 companies repurchasing shares worth S$5.4 million and 2 companies selling shares worth S$4.6 million. Pacific Century Regional Developments Limited and Nordic Group Limited resumed buying shares, with Pacific Century purchasing 387,000 shares at 36.5 cents each. Nordic Group's CEO Dorcas Teo purchased 530,000 shares, boosting her stake to 30.53%. The buyback activity fell for the second consecutive week, while selling activity remained low.

site_title: Central Asian art takes centre stage
summary: Central Asian artists showcased their works at the New Silk Roads: Painting Beyond Borders exhibition at the Ion Art Gallery in Singapore until Monday. The exhibition featured five modern and contemporary artists from Kazakhstan, Turkmenistan, and Uzbekistan, focusing on the theme of the Silk Road. The artists include Fayzulla Akhmadaliev, Murat Hojakuliyev, and Kadirov Gafur Kolbovich, among others. The works are priced from S$1,690 to S$62,000. This is the first time Central Asian artists have been brought together for a group exhibition in Singapore, highlighting the region's growing presence in the art world.

site_title: Oil glut is a strain on West Texas storage tanks
summary: A glut in West Texas storage tanks is putting downward pressure on oil prices. The Permian Basin, a major oil-producing region, is experiencing high inventories due to production outpacing takeaway capacity. Pipeline disruptions in May will divert oil to Cushing, Oklahoma, adding to already high supplies and potentially lowering crude prices. The Permian's stockpiles have hit records in the last four weeks, with over 20 million barrels stored. Investors are watching for declines in weekly inventory data to signal demand is rising or production is tapering off.

site_title: Songs of our lives
summary: The Sing50 committee has curated a list of over 100 iconic songs for a concert, with about 50 songs to be performed on August 7. The list includes a mix of English and Chinese songs from various decades, showcasing the evolution of music in Singapore. The event aims to celebrate the country's musical heritage.

site_title: Berlian Laju sets out binding terms for it restructuring
summary: PT Berlian Laju Tanker, an Indonesian chemical tanker operator, has set out binding terms for its restructuring. The agreement involves transferring 27 vessels out of 39 to a newly formed entity, with lenders under a mandated facility agreement. Berlian will call a shareholders' meeting to seek approval for the restructuring, which has been ongoing since 2012. Trading in shares remains suspended.

site_title: Luxury-housing boom in London fizzles out
summary: London's luxury-housing market is slowing down, with price gains in top neighborhoods like Kensington & Chelsea trailing other UK cities. The city's best areas saw minimal growth, while Newham in east London experienced the highest increase, 14.2%. Central London home prices rose 11.8% in the past year, but are expected to slow due to uncertainty around the national election and high prices. In contrast, other UK cities like Glasgow and Manchester saw significant price increases, with values rising 7.6% and 6.8% respectively.

images.alt_text: Home values in the Kensington & Chelsea borough rose the least in the city in the 12 months through March.

site_title: Russian hackers read Obama's unclassified emails last year: NYT
summary: Russian hackers breached the White House's unclassified computer system last year, accessing President Barack Obama's emails. Although no classified information was compromised, officials acknowledged that sensitive information, such as diplomatic emails and personnel moves, was retrieved. The breach was "far more intrusive and worrisome" than previously acknowledged, with senior White House officials aware of the depth of the intrusion for months. The president's email account itself was not hacked, but the content of his communications was accessed by the hackers.

site_title: Whoever wins election, Britain faces more austerity medicine
summary: Britain's general election on May 7 will likely result in more austerity measures, regardless of the winning party. Conservative Prime Minister David Cameron, who took power in 2010, has positioned himself as an economic saviour. The UK economy has already shrunk for the second month, adding to the uncertainty.

site_title: UBI not ruling out tie-up with Monte dei Paschi: CEO
summary: UBI, Italy's fifth-largest bank, does not rule out a potential tie-up with troubled Monte dei Paschi di Siena, but will not be forced into an unwanted deal. UBI CEO Victor Massiah stated that creating value for shareholders is the priority, and while a 50% chance of a tie-up with Monte dei Paschi exists, UBI is open to other options. The bank is expected to play a prominent role in a wave of deals spurred by government reforms, which aim to convert cooperative banks into joint-stock companies within 18 months.

site_title: US dollar falls for 2 weeks in a row
summary: The US dollar dropped for a second consecutive week, falling 0.4% against major peers, as weak economic data raised concerns about a potential interest rate hike this year. The Bloomberg Dollar Spot Index slid to 1,180.61, while net bullish bets on the dollar's strength dwindled to the lowest level since October. The Federal Reserve will decide on monetary policy on April 29, amidst a report showing first-quarter economic growth slowed, with the US GDP expanding at a 1% annual rate.

images.alt_text: The dollar dropped for a second week as data on the world's largest economy persistently trailed forecasts, raising questions about whether the Federal Reserve will have scope to raise interest rates this year.

site_title: Deutsche Bank Q1 profit falls by half as legal charges bite
summary: Deutsche Bank's Q1 profit dropped by half to 559 million euros, largely due to hefty legal charges and litigation expenses. Revenue rose 24% to 10.4 billion euros, driven by an increase in client trading activity, but investment banking pre-tax contribution fell by more than half. The bank prepares to unveil a strategic overhaul, including the sale of its Postbank retail chain, amid a tumultuous period for its co-CEOs, who face regulatory fines and trials.

site_title: Protesters call for independent inquiry into Sewol ferry disaster
summary: Thousands of protesters in Seoul called for an independent inquiry into the 2014 Sewol ferry disaster, which claimed 304 lives, mostly teenagers. The protesters, including families of the victims, chanted slogans accusing President Park Geun Hye of obstructing the investigation. Despite the government's announcement to raise the sunken ferry to the surface, the relatives demanded a fully independent inquiry with no government interference. The protesters dispersed peacefully after a brief candlelit vigil, marking the third consecutive day of demonstrations.

site_title: Five years on, MBS shuns status quo
summary: Marina Bay Sands (MBS) celebrates its 5-year soft opening, marking a significant milestone under the leadership of CEO George Tanasijevich, who drives the integrated resort to stay ahead of the competition. With a focus on continuous improvement and innovation, MBS has introduced new features, including a revamped hotel room design and a new restaurant at the SkyPark observation deck. The resort prioritizes local procurement, awarding 9 out of 10 contracts to Singapore-based companies in 2013 and 2014. Tanasijevich's vision for MBS is to "never settle" and continuously strive for excellence, with plans to expand into Japan and South Korea in the future.

site_title: Otto Marine's creditor seeks to wind up firm over S$1.57 million debt
summary: Otto Marine's creditor has filed an application with the Singapore High Court to wind up the marine company over a debt of about S$1.57 million. The company has stated it is not disputing the debt and is in negotiations to reach a settlement. A separate winding-up application against its subsidiary, Go Offshore Asia, has been withdrawn after the subsidiary paid the debt of US$118,000.

site_title: China law curbs tobacco ads in land of smokers
summary: China's parliament has passed a revised Advertisement Law that restricts tobacco advertising in public, banning ads in mass media, public places, and outdoors. The law aims to curb smoking, affecting over 1 billion smokers and second-hand smokers in the country. The new regulations also prohibit tobacco products from being advertised alongside other products, limit outdoor smoking, and increase punishments for false advertising. The move is part of China's efforts to combat the health crisis of smoking, with cigarette prices and taxes being considered in the future.

site_title: Cuts to pay and perks trigger flight from China's state banks
summary: China's state banks are experiencing a flight of talent as pay cuts and reduced perks trigger departures to newer financial firms. Senior bankers are leaving for better-paying jobs, with some earning up to double what they did at state banks. The pay cuts, part of Beijing's anti-graft drive, have made it difficult for state lenders to hire and retain talent, while newer firms are offering more attractive salaries, longer holidays, and fewer travel restrictions. This trend is expected to continue, potentially disrupting the flow of talent in China's banking sector.

site_title: Pepsi dropping sweetener aspartame from diet cola drinks
summary: PepsiCo announced it will discontinue the use of aspartame in its US diet cola drinks, including Diet Pepsi, starting in August. The company will replace aspartame with a blend of sucralose and acesulfame potassium, responding to customer demand. The move comes after reports showed diet cola sales were in decline last year. PepsiCo cited evolving consumer demand as the reason for the change.

site_title: Privatised Dell looking to capture greater market share in Asia-Pacific
summary: Dell, a computer major, completed its first full fiscal year as a private company, achieving 4% year-on-year revenue growth and a 38% rise in operating income. The company's senior VP and CFO, Tom Sweet, expressed confidence in its market share in the Asia-Pacific region. Dell's strong financial performance indicates its ability to compete in the market.

site_title: Starbucks payment system outage in US, Canada resolved
summary: Starbucks' payment system outage in the US and Canada was resolved, affecting several Evolution Fresh and Teavana stores. The outage occurred due to a failure during a daily system refresh and caused some stores to close early. Despite the issue, sales at Starbucks shops in the Americas region were up 7% in the second quarter. The company apologized to customers for the inconvenience and stated that all stores should reopen as usual on Saturday.

site_title: Blue chips likely to be in limelight this week
summary: The Singapore stock market, particularly blue chips, are expected to be in the spotlight this week. A recent rally has provided relief for retail brokers, but it appears to be losing steam, with declining turnover and low volatility. The Straits Times Index (STI) is expected to trade in a narrow range, lacking direction. As the market waits for upcoming GDP data, traders are bracing for potential changes in market trends.

site_title: Nepal steps up rescue efforts as quake toll jumps to at least 2,400
summary: A 7.9-magnitude earthquake struck Nepal, killing at least 2,400 people and injuring 4,700, mostly in the capital city of Kathmandu. The quake also triggered a deadly avalanche on Mount Everest, with dozens critically injured. Rescue efforts are ongoing, with Nepal urging nations to send aid and bracing for the death toll to rise. The government has set up shelters and plans to re-open roads, while international aid groups are preparing to provide assistance.

site_title: Alibaba, China Telecom tie up to sell phones
summary: Alibaba Group Holding Ltd and China Telecom Corp Ltd have partnered to sell inexpensive smartphones in smaller cities and rural areas, aiming to boost mobile commerce. The "Tianyi Taobao Shopping Handsets" will come pre-installed with either Alibaba's Taobao app or YunOS mobile operating system, offering free 2G data service for four months. This partnership seeks to deepen Alibaba's e-commerce base in less developed regions and promote YunOS in a shrinking handset market, where mobile shopping is on the rise, with 265 million monthly active users.

site_title: Software developers try on Apple watch, see more apps coming
summary: Software developers who tried on Apple Watch for the first time predicted a rush of new apps, particularly in health, messaging, and social media. The watch's capabilities, such as automatic wrist detection and microphone functionality, allowed developers to create new apps. As a result, 3,061 total apps supporting Apple Watch were counted, including 310 games, 248 productivity apps, and 213 lifestyle and health/fitness apps. Notable apps from major companies like Uber, ESPN, Twitter, and Instagram were available, while Facebook and Snapchat were absent, with a Google spokesperson stating only time would tell if Google would create an app.

site_title: Fighting shape
summary: Titleist Performance Institute co-founder Dave Phillips suggests that men need to look more closely at women to hit the ball longer. Despite size advantages, men generally don't hit the ball as far as female pros. Phillips emphasizes the importance of technique and practice in improving golf swing speed.

site_title: US regulator says 'flash crash' manipulation hard to detect
summary: US regulator Richard Ketchum stated that detecting "flash crash" manipulation is challenging due to spoofing techniques, which are typically carried out through multiple firms and accounts. Ketchum said spoofing is "very low" but still prevalent, and regulators should be concerned. He also expressed hesitation in questioning other regulators without understanding the facts. Regulatory measures implemented after the flash crash would make it less likely for manipulative practices to trigger a similar disruption.

site_title: Barclays must face US fraud lawsuit tied to 'dark pool' probe
summary: US District Judge Shira Scheindlin allowed a lawsuit against Barclays Plc to proceed, accusing the British bank of defrauding shareholders about its private "dark pool" trading platform, Barclays LX. The lawsuit, filed by investors, alleges Barclays misrepresented the safety of LX and understated its activity to high-speed traders. The judge found that the investors' claims "adequately alleges Barclays' past scandals" and that the bank's misrepresentations could be imputed to the company. The lawsuit seeks class-action status on behalf of investors from 2011 to 2014.

site_title: Australia fears worst for drug traffickers in Indonesia
summary: Australia is fearing the worst for two drug traffickers, Myuran Sukumaran and Andrew Chan, who are set to be executed in Indonesia. The pair, ringleaders of the "Bali Nine" heroin trafficking gang, have exhausted their legal appeals. Foreign Minister Julie Bishop has made a last-ditch appeal to Indonesian President Joko Widodo to spare their lives, but admitted she fears the worst due to the 72-hour notice requirement for executions. The executions are set to take place on a high-security prison island in Indonesia, with family members reportedly rushing to Indonesia for what could be their final goodbyes.

site_title: Goodyear to build US$500 million tire factory in Mexico
summary: Goodyear to build a US$500 million tire factory in central Mexico, producing six million tires a year for the Americas. The plant, set to begin production in mid-2017, will employ around 1,000 people and supply tires to customers in Mexico, Latin America, and North America. The investment is the third major auto sector announcement in Mexico since last week, following Toyota's US$1 billion investment and Ford's US$2.5 billion project. Mexico's proximity to the US market, cheap labor, and free trade agreements have made it an attractive destination for investors.

site_title: China: This time it's different
summary: China's financial services sector is undergoing significant reforms, with the stock market surging and international capital flows increasing. Mainland Chinese mutual funds now have assets under management exceeding $1.1 trillion, and the Shanghai Composite Index has risen 70% in six months. The Chinese government is using the Hong Kong market to boost international capital and facilitate the restructuring of existing bank debt, a key part of its 21st-century financial service industry plan. The authorities aim to reduce the risk of a volatile market driven by day traders and margin lending, while promoting long-term investing institutions and foreign investment. This could lead to a recapitalization of Chinese banks and an influx of international capital, presenting an opportunity for the financial sector to grow.

images.alt_text: It is significant that at the end of March the Chinese announced that henceforth mainland Chinese fund management companies would be able to invest in Hong Kong equities via the through train, but without needing to be approved for QDII, the quota system that previously governed outward investment.

site_title: Could've thought of that!
summary: Philippou, a filmmaker, raised £3,049 on Kickstarter for her horror movie "Crazy Golf," exceeding her goal of £2,000. The film features a female underdog main character and aims to evoke both laughter and disgust. Philippou credits this project as one of her early breakthroughs.

site_title: Juicy, tasty spread - duck in
summary: Two Chinese restaurants, Four Seasons and Sum Yi Tai, offer comforting familiarity in Singapore. Four Seasons, a London-based chain, serves decent but not exceptional roast duck, with its sauce being a highlight. The restaurant's decor is 1980s-inspired but lacks a carefully crafted aesthetic. Sum Yi Tai, with a groovy take on 1980s Hong Kong, offers steady and dependable food, including a daily soup and a refreshing lemongrass jelly dessert. Both restaurants have a "down-to-earth" feel, but may not aim high in terms of quality or creativity.

Sum Yi Tai's signature roast duck aand XO carrot cake. The restaurant, a groovy take on 1980s Hong Kong with its soundtrack of Cantonese ballads and a stylised bar concept, lags behind its original

One should not miss Four Seasons' soya sauce chicken (above) which is better than the duck. A typical Hong Kong minced green onion and ginger dip gives it a lift.

site_title: The curious case of the missing workforce
summary: US policymakers are concerned about the missing workforce, with an estimated 8.1 million people dropping out of the labor force since 2007. Bringing half of these workers back into the labor force could lift GDP by 1.5%. Federal Reserve Governor Jerome Powell is optimistic that job prospects for those who've dropped out are improving, which could lead to lower interest rates. However, some economists argue that the decline in workforce participation is structural, driven by reduced demand for labor, rather than cyclical. The participation rate has been little changed since 2013, with some numbers being made up by aging of the US population.

site_title: Tried & tested, play it
summary: Jordan Spieth dominated The Masters Tournament 2015, securing a green jacket on the first day and holding onto it throughout the week.

site_title: Stress relief
summary: Ben Hogan once shared his experience of feeling nervous during tournaments, highlighting the common phenomenon of stress and nervousness. The article appears to be unrelated to the provided news articles, which cover various topics such as a new food review, economic agreements, jobless claims, and China's economic initiatives.

site_title: Dollar weakens as US data disappoints
summary: The US dollar weakened on Friday as economic data disappointed, helping the euro gain ground. The Federal Reserve's planned interest rate increase is now data-dependent, with weaker-than-expected durable goods orders and manufacturing surveys. The Greek bailout talks stalled, with Eurozone finance ministers ending a meeting without a breakthrough. The softer US dollar provided support to global markets, but concerns over Greece's economic stability and the Federal Reserve's policy remain.

site_title: Basically, this is the bullying, baying Internet that we've become
summary: The term "Basic Bitch" and its male counterpart "Basic Bro" have emerged as internet slang to mock individuals who conform to mainstream trends, often associated with Taylor Swift fans. However, this label carries an ugly undercurrent of contempt and public shaming, which can be arbitrary and pointless. The article argues that the internet has amplified existing base behavior, making it difficult to distinguish between real life and online interactions, and has created a culture of intolerance for anything that is too visible.

site_title: Higher wages, better career progression for landscape workers
summary: Singapore's landscape maintenance workers will receive higher wages and better skills training under a new progressive wage model, effective June 2016. The model stipulates a minimum wage of S$1,300 for full-time workers, increasing to S$2,100 for supervisors. The goal is to uplift the sector's image and attract and retain manpower, addressing issues like a shortage of local workers and low productivity.

site_title: Rise of US$ not hurting US as feared: UBS
summary: A senior economist at UBS, Paul Donovan, states that the strength of the US dollar will not harm US economic growth, contrary to common fears. US exporters have gained market share in Europe and Japan, while European and Japanese exporters have lost market share in the US. Japanese exporters have not passed on changes in the dollar-yen exchange rate to their products' prices, instead choosing profit over market share. This shift is seen as a significant change in global trade dynamics, with US consumer demand expected to continue growing.

site_title: Asian central banks likely to ease further
summary: Emerging Asian central banks are expected to cut interest rates again, with the People's Bank of China (PBOC) likely to loosen policy most in the region. However, economists polled by Reuters are doubtful that these moves will significantly boost growth or inflation, with median estimates for growth and inflation downgraded from previous surveys. The PBOC may cut interest rates by end-June, while the Reserve Bank of India is expected to do so before its June meeting. Despite efforts to stimulate the economy, growth and inflation are expected to remain stagnant.

site_title: Japan ready for bigger security role: Abe
summary: Japan is poised to take on a bigger security role under Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's visit to the US, where he will stress Japan's readiness to contribute to global security. Abe's speech to Congress on April 29 will coincide with the unveiling of updated US-Japan defense cooperation guidelines, which reflect the largest change in Japanese security policy in decades. The guidelines aim to expand Japan's roles and missions worldwide, amid concerns that the US may not always be available to defend Japan in a crisis, particularly with China's growing influence.

site_title: US says new EU plan for GMO imports is no solution
summary: The US has criticized the European Union's new plan to allow member states to block genetically modified imports, calling it "hard to square" with EU aspirations for a seamless internal market. The US assistant trade representative expressed hope that the EU will move forward with a plan that respects decades-old trade rules. The proposal, part of the transatlantic free-trade pact, was met with skepticism by the US, highlighting ongoing tensions between the two regions over trade and regulatory issues.

site_title: Lloyds wins as banks pay Britons incentives to switch
summary: Lloyds Banking Group's Halifax unit gained the most customers in the third quarter, with 53,624 new accounts opened, while Royal Bank of Scotland and Barclays lost the most UK checking accounts, 31,377 and 31,331 respectively. The Competition and Markets Authority's probe into British banks' market practices led to financial incentives, resulting in more customers switching banks. Halifax's £125 opening incentive was a major factor, attracting low-quality deposits. The data show a 7% increase in customers switching checking accounts in the past year, with 1.14 million consumers changing accounts between March 31 and September 30.

site_title: Deutsche Bank to sell Postbank
summary: Deutsche Bank announced plans to sell its Postbank subsidiary as part of a strategy to improve profitability. The sale, which will deconsolidate Postbank, aims to achieve greater efficiency and a more robust control environment. Postbank, with around 14 million customers, posted a net profit of 278 million euros last year. The sale is part of a new strategy to be unveiled Monday, following increased financial sector regulation and low interest rate environment challenges. The bank will issue its first quarter results on Sunday ahead of schedule.

images.alt_text: Germany's biggest lender Deutsche Bank announced on Friday it was seeking to sell its Postbank subsidiary as part of a revamp to improve profitability.

site_title: Transferring and sustaining the family wealth
summary: The article highlights the importance of strategic planning for inter-generational wealth transfer among Asian families, particularly in China. Research shows that family corporations owned by ethnic Chinese in Asia decline by 60% in value after a family patriarch departs. This decline is often accompanied by family feuds and asset dissipation. To avoid such outcomes, families need to build constructive relationships, define ownership and management roles, and establish a clear decision-making process. Creating a trust or family office can also help preserve business legacy and promote harmony, ultimately ensuring the continuation of family wealth.

site_title: No long queues at Apple Watch launch as buyers go online
summary: The Apple Watch launched globally on April 24, 2015, with a small queue in Tokyo, contrary to expectations. The device will not be sold at Apple stores, but rather at upscale boutiques and department stores, with buyers able to order online. About 50 people lined up in Tokyo, while others waited outside mobile carrier SoftBank Corp. Apple aims to ship at least 20 million watches this year, with estimates varying widely among analysts.

site_title: New PepsiCo push for cost cuts as strong US$ hits sales
summary: PepsiCo Inc. is aiming to achieve US$1 billion in cost savings this year amid a strong US dollar negatively impacting overseas sales. The company plans to return US$8.5 billion to US$9 billion to shareholders. Despite the challenges, PepsiCo remains committed to its cost-cutting goals, demonstrating its resilience in the face of global economic pressures.

site_title: Europe pushes Greece in bogged down debt talks
summary: European finance ministers urged Greece to speed up bailout talks to avoid a default and a messy exit from the eurozone, failing to reach a breakthrough on unlocking 7.2 billion euros in bailout cash. The Eurogroup's Jeroen Dijsselbloem described the talks as "very critical," with a 200 million euro IMF payment due on May 1. The lack of progress has raised concerns about Greece's economic stability and its future in the eurozone, with the threat of a messy exit still hanging in the balance.

site_title: As electronica booms, DJs seek voice beyond machines
summary: Electronic music artists are seeking to redefine the genre by emphasizing the human element beyond machine-driven beats. DJs such as Richie Hawtin and Francois Kevorkian argue that discovering a unique voice and sound in the studio is crucial to success. The industry's growth, worth $6.2 billion, is attributed to low overhead costs for DJs, but they caution that expensive equipment is not key to success. Artists like Squarepusher are pushing the limits of electronic music by experimenting with new sounds and technology, seeking a live feel and individuality.

images.alt_text: Electronic music has enjoyed soaring growth in recent years, but to detractors the genre consists of little beyond crowd-pleasing DJs clicking play on their computers.

site_title: From tactical genius to managerial flop
summary: Liverpool manager Brendan Rodgers is under fire after failing to meet his pre-season targets. He will become the first Liverpool manager to miss a trophy in their first three years in charge since the 1950s. Rodgers took the job in 2012 but has failed to win any major trophies, including the Champions League and the Premier League. His season is set to end a month from now, and he is likely running out of time, luck, and excuses to turn things around.

site_title: Push on DBS, UOB helps STI avert a bigger loss
summary: The Straits Times Index fell 12 points to 3,513 last week, but gained 10.25 points on Friday due to a push from banks DBS and UOB. Despite a firm Wall Street and all-time high for Nasdaq, interest was low, with volume in penny stocks declining throughout the week. Market turnover on Friday was 1.9 billion units worth S$1.3 billion, with a unit average of S$0.68.

site_title: No more aid till full reform deal, eurozone ministers tell Greece
summary: Eurozone finance ministers have warned Greece that no more aid will be provided until a complete economic reform plan is agreed upon. A remaining 7.2 billion euros in frozen bailout funds will no longer be available after June, and creditors will not discuss longer-term funding and debt relief until a full interim agreement is concluded. Greece's creditors, including the European Central Bank, are under pressure to accelerate negotiations, with a crucial payment to the IMF due on May 11.

site_title: Historic week for US stocks as Nasdaq breaks 15-year record
summary: The Nasdaq broke its 15-year record, closing at 5,056.06 on April 24, 2015, after a 3.25% gain. This milestone marks a significant recovery from the 2000 dot-com crash, with real earnings and reasonable price measures supporting the market. The Nasdaq's record-breaking performance is a historic week for US stocks, indicating investors may not need to fear a repeat of the crash.

site_title: Comcast set to drop mega-merger with TWC: report
summary: US cable giant Comcast is reportedly ending its $45 billion mega-merger with Time Warner Cable due to opposition from antitrust regulators. The deal, which would have boosted Comcast's dominance in the US market, was opposed by consumer groups and regulators citing concerns over market power and conflict of interest. A formal announcement ending the deal is expected to be made on Friday, following meetings with regulators and industry leaders.

site_title: Sembcorp to develop gas-fired power plant in Myanmar
summary: Sembcorp Industries has received a notice of award to develop and operate a 225-megawatt gas-fired power plant in central Myanmar, worth US$300 million. The project, set to be completed in 2017, will supply power to the Myanmar Electric Power Enterprise under a 22-year power purchase agreement. Sembcorp will hold an 80% stake in the project, marking the company's entry into Myanmar's power market, which is expected to see a 13% annual growth rate in electricity demand over the next 15 years.

site_title: NTU tie-up puts out electric taxi for the tropics
summary: The Nanyang Technological University (NTU) in Singapore has unveiled EVA, the world's first electric taxi designed for the tropics. EVA can travel 200km on a single 15-minute charge, features overhead air-conditioning and an infotainment system, and is optimised for Singapore's climate and driving patterns. The vehicle is part of a collaboration between NTU and Germany's Technische Universität München, and its development is expected to benefit Singapore through technology transfer and the creation of electro-mobility specialists. TUM Create plans to commercialise EVA and integrate it into public transport systems globally, with the goal of making electric taxis more cost-effective and energy-efficient.

images.alt_text: COOL CAB: EVA, designed in a collaboration between NTU and Germany's Technische Universität München, is said to be able to go some 200km on a single 15-minute charge, and features overhead air-conditioning, seat cooling and an infotainment system controlled by the passenger's mobile devices

site_title: Starbucks' Q2 sales beat estimates
summary: Starbucks' Q2 sales exceeded estimates, rising 18% to $4.56 billion, driven by its mobile app and expanded menu. Revenue growth was fueled by its food business and strong mobile ordering service. Globally, sales at stores open at least 13 months increased 7%, surpassing analyst estimates. The company reiterated its full-year forecast for 16-18% revenue growth and plans to open 1,650 new cafes this fiscal year, including 850 in China and Asia-Pacific.

HomesToLife Pop-Up at Katong showcases a variety of furniture and home decor items from local and international brands. Meanwhile, an exhibition at the National Design Centre in Singapore showcases works by Barcelona's leading designers, offering unique and handmade items for sale.

site_title: GE Q1 profit falls 5% in absence of one-off gain
summary: Great Eastern Holdings reported a 5% decline in Q1 net profit to S$220.5 million due to a one-off gain in the prior year period. Excluding the gain, profit grew 9% year-over-year. Gross premiums rose 1% to S$1.88 billion, while operating profit from insurance business increased 5% to S$150.7 million. New business embedded value remained stable at S$85.2 million.

site_title: S$15m pledged to extend programmes for seafarers
summary: Singapore has pledged S$15 million to extend the Certificate of Competency (COC) programmes for seafarers for another three years. The programmes, which provide training for deck officers and marine engineers, were announced by parliamentary secretary Muhammad Faishal Ibrahim at a graduation ceremony. The extension aims to support the maritime industry and ensure a skilled workforce.

site_title: Looming supply, interest rates concerns weigh on private home prices in Q1
summary: Singapore's private home prices and rents declined 1% and 1.7% in the first quarter, respectively, amid concerns over looming supply and interest rates. The decline reinforces views that the downcycle will persist, with prices expected to soften by 5-8% in 2015. Developers offered discounts to lure buyers back into the market, and rents fell across all segments. The vacancy rate of completed private residential units eased to 7.2%, but a looming supply glut is expected to exert further downward pressure on prices.

site_title: Ascott Reit eyes portfolio size of S$6b by 2017
summary: Ascott Reit aims to expand its portfolio size to S$6 billion by 2017 through accretive acquisitions in key gateway cities. The trust-manager, ARTML, plans to consider opportunities from its sponsor, The Ascott Limited, and third parties. Ascott Reit reported a 1% rise in distribution per unit to 1.76 Singapore cents for the first quarter, with revenue and gross profit increasing 12% and 10% respectively. The trust plans to divest properties with limited growth potential and refurbish existing assets to optimize returns.

site_title: Soilbuild Construction posts 15% rise in Q1 profit
summary: Soilbuild Construction Group reported a 15% year-on-year increase in net profit to S$4.43 million for the first quarter ended March 31, 2015, despite a 19% decline in revenue to S$70.42 million. Gross profit rose 16% to S$7.32 million, and earnings per share increased to 0.67 Singapore cents. The company remains focused on core capabilities and cost efficiency, with a stable order book of S$763.9 million.

site_title: World Happiness Report puts Swiss and Icelanders at the top
summary: Switzerland is the happiest country in the world, followed by Iceland, Denmark, Norway, and Canada, according to the 2015 World Happiness Report. The report, which analyzed 158 countries, found that real GDP per capita, healthy life expectancy, and social support were key factors in determining happiness. The United States ranks 15th, while Afghanistan and Syria are among the 10 least happy countries. The report emphasizes the importance of fairness, honesty, and good health in maintaining happiness, and its findings are expected to influence government policy.

site_title: Goods of Desire quits Singapore
summary: Goods of Desire, a Hong Kong-based homeware and lifestyle retailer, has announced its withdrawal from Singapore after a three-year stint. The decision was cited as sluggish retail sales and a shift to online shopping, with the brand citing rising rents, costs, and competition. The store will close on April 26, with existing staff redeployed to other Far East Organization business units. Goods of Desire has maintained a strong loyal following in Hong Kong, where it operates six stores, and is now exploring opportunities in Taiwan, where it has recently opened its first store.

site_title: March factory output cues slight Q1 growth upgrade
summary: Singapore's manufacturing sector showed a slight improvement in March, with factory output rising 1.2% year on year, beating expectations. This may lead to a revision of the first quarter GDP growth to 2.2%, up from the initial estimate of 2.1%. However, manufacturers still face uncertainties due to economic uncertainty in export markets and a tight labor market. Key industries, such as electronics and pharmaceuticals, experienced contraction, with electronics output falling 5.2% year on year. Despite this, economists expect a "modest recovery" for the electronics cluster in the coming months.

site_title: GM's US$900m Q1 profit misses analysts' forecast; shares slip 3.3%
summary: General Motors (GM) reported a Q1 profit of $900 million, missing analysts' estimates of $1.04 billion. Adjusted earnings per share tripled to 86 cents, surpassing last year's 29 cents. Struggles in Russia and Brazil impacted US light truck sales, contributing to the underperformance. GM's shares fell 3.3% following the announcement.

site_title: Rickmers keeps Q1 DPU steady
summary: Rickmers Maritime, a container ship owner, has maintained its distributions per unit (DPU) at 0.6 US cent for the first quarter, despite a 29% decline in net profit to US$7 million. The trust tapped into its cash reserves to cover the shortfall, using a portion of its US$55 million cash balance. Despite weak charter revenue, the trust's fleet was 98.8% utilized in Q1, and charter rates are expected to continue their gradual recovery.

site_title: Retail, office rents headed for divergent paths
summary: Office rents in Singapore are expected to rise 5-6% this year, with vacancy rates hitting around 3% by year-end, according to experts. Retail rents, however, are expected to decrease by up to 5% due to a cautious retailing climate. The island-wide office vacancy rate remained flat at 10.2% in Q1, while retail space supply increased by 22,000 sq m. Experts attribute the divergent trends to healthy leasing demand for new office buildings and a decline in retail transaction volume.

site_title: Abercrombie's hot sales staff policy is over
summary: Abercrombie & Fitch Co. has scrapped its hiring rule requiring employees to be attractive and have a "sense of style." The policy change, effective Friday, marks the end of a legacy under former CEO Mike Jeffries. The move comes as the retailer seeks to diversify its workforce and distance itself from its former focus on physical appearance.

site_title: UEL's S$225m bond sale eight times subscribed
summary: United Envirotech Ltd (UEL) successfully sold its S$225 million bond, with orders exceeding S$1.8 billion, attracting strong demand from institutional and private bank investors. The bond sale follows Citic Ltd, China's largest conglomerate, acquiring a 55% stake in UEL.

site_title: China's second-hand car market revs up
summary: China's second-hand car market is growing, with 6.05 million vehicles sold in 2014, a 16.3% increase from the previous year. Despite cultural preferences for new items, foreign manufacturers are investing in the market, with companies like Peugeot, Ford, Nissan, Audi, and Volvo setting up certification centers to resell their used vehicles. The market's maturity is attributed to restrictions on new vehicle registrations, which are gradually changing attitudes towards used cars. The growth of the used car market is also driven by the sluggish economy, with prices for even one-year-old vehicles 25% lower than new.

site_title: Nobody knows for sure whether Grexit will lead to a contagion or not
summary: Greece's potential exit from the eurozone, known as Grexit, has sparked concerns about a potential contagion effect on other eurozone countries. However, so far, borrowing costs for Portugal, Spain, and Italy have remained relatively stable, and the region's banks have reduced their exposure to Greece. The IMF and European Central Bank have also downplayed the risk of a financial disaster. Despite this, investors remain uncertain about the outcome, with some predicting a 30% chance of Grexit and others expecting the eurozone to remain intact.

site_title: Nasdaq sets new record 15 years after dot-com crash
summary: The Nasdaq exchange broke its 15-year-old record on April 23, 2015, closing at 5,056.06, surpassing the 5,048.62 mark set in 2000. The final-hour sell-off prevented the S&P 500 from surpassing its previous record high. The Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 20.42 points, while the S&P added 4.97 points. Leading Nasdaq names rose, including Apple, Google, and Biogen, but Facebook fell 2.6% due to a 20% decline in first-quarter net income.

site_title: Winner Sonata
summary: The Hyundai Sonata, the seventh generation of Hyundai's mid-sized sedan, boasts a luxurious interior with a boxier styling, standard daytime running lights, and headlamp washers. The vehicle features a generous wheelbase, ventilated front seats, and leather upholstery. Although it lacks performance, the Sonata makes up for it with great value, offering features normally found in luxury models. It also boasts a quiet, comfortable, and spacious ride. The Hyundai Sonata is priced at S$149,999, offering a cost-effective alternative to Japanese mid-sized sedans.

site_title: Asean 'may be the next factory of the world'
summary: ANZ Banking Group predicts Asean won't become a fully integrated common market by the end of this year, but it will still become Asia's third engine of growth, replacing China as the world's factory. Singapore is tipped to play a key role as the financial hub and banker in Asean's growth. The report projects intra-Asean trade to exceed $1 trillion by 2025 and extra-Asean trade with G-4 economies to reach $3.7 trillion. Asean is expected to emerge as the world's fifth-largest economy by the end of the decade.

site_title: Zeti: No rate cut barring 'fundamental' slowdown
summary: Malaysia's central bank governor Zeti Akhtar Aziz has signaled no need for an interest rate cut unless there's a "fundamental" economic slowdown. With above 5% growth and inflation near the slowest since 2009, the Bank Negara Malaysia has held borrowing costs steady for four straight meetings. Aziz attributes Malaysia's diversified economy, with 80% of its economy not linked to oil and gas, as a reason for maintaining rates. The central bank will hold its key rate for the rest of the year.

site_title: Brokers' take

site_title: Insights into wine at BT Luxe Night
summary: Wine specialist Lim Hwee Peng shared his expertise with 100 senior executives at the BT Luxe Night in Singapore, emphasizing the importance of approaching wine with an open mind and minimal information. He recommended letting the wine "talk" for itself, rather than relying on preconceived notions or labels. This approach allows individuals to truly appreciate the nuances of wine and develop their own understanding.

site_title: UIC's Q1 net profit up 39% on property sales, SingLand privatisation

site_title: Stabilising HDB resale flat prices may draw buyers back to market
summary: The Housing & Development Board (HDB) reported a 1% quarter-on-quarter drop in its resale flat price index for the first quarter of 2025, the smallest decline since 2013. site_title: Changi Airport offers aeronautical fee cuts
summary: Changi Airport in Singapore has announced further reductions and rebates on aeronautical fees, including lower passenger service charges and extended landing and parking fee rebates. site_title: The (new) art of war: Fighting disruption
summary: Industry incumbents can fight digital disruption using seven strategies: Block, Milk, Invest, Disrupt, Retreat, Redefine, and Exit. The Block strategy involves inhibiting the disruptor through patent claims, regulatory hurdles, and legal barriers. The Milk strategy extracts value from vulnerable businesses while preparing for disruption. The Invest strategy involves investing in the disruptor, while Disrupt involves launching a competing product or service. Retreat focuses on a niche segment, Redefine builds a new business model, and Exit involves exiting the business entirely. These strategies are often used in combination and can be effective in preserving market share and value, but may come with significant challenges and uncertainties.

site_title: TIH invests US$0.5m in Salim Group-linked entity via convertible loan notes

site_title: Surplus in China's zinc market as demand wanes
summary: China's zinc market is facing a surplus in the second quarter due to steady domestic production and imports, while demand weakens amid a slowing domestic economy. Environmental requirements are also expected to trim zinc demand, particularly for semi-finished and finished zinc products. Despite this, demand is expected to rise moderately in the second half as liquidity and infrastructure projects boost orders. China's zinc production rose 15% in the first quarter, and imports reached a seven-month high in March.

summary: China has unveiled free-trade zones in three provinces, including Guangdong, Fujian, and Tianjin, to boost yuan-denominated trade and financing. The trust remains optimistic on China's retail sales prospects, citing the government's commitment to boosting domestic consumption. The trust's shares closed up 10 cents at S$1.75.

site_title: Volvo to make new generation of small cars in Belgium and China: CEO
summary: Volvo Cars, a Swedish automaker, plans to produce a new generation of small cars in collaboration with Chinese parent Zhejiang Geely Holding Group. The production will take place in Volvo's Belgian factory and potentially in China, with three existing plants considered. Volvo aims to use the Compact Modular Architecture (CMA) platform developed with Geely. The company's first CMA-based car is likely to be a redesigned V40 hatchback, while a small SUV is also in consideration.

site_title: Soilbuild Construction posts 15% rise in Q1 profit
summary: Soilbuild Construction Group reported a 15% year-on-year increase in net profit to S$4.43 million for Q1 2015, despite a 19% decline in revenue to S$70.42 million. Gross profit rose 16% to S$7.32 million, driven by a 22% decrease in cost of sales. Earnings per share increased to 0.67 Singapore cent from 0.58 Singapore cent a year ago.

site_title: Apple aims to ship more than 20 million smartwatches in 2015: sources
summary: Apple aims to ship at least 20 million Apple Watches in 2015, exceeding analyst forecasts of 10-26 million units. Supply chain sources estimate 2 million watches per month in the current quarter, with some predicting a production plan of 26 million watches for the year. Despite low initial sales compared to the iPhone, analysts believe Apple won't give up on the smartwatch, considering it a long-term strategy.

site_title: China Minzhong Food's Q3 profit down 19%
summary: China Minzhong Food's Q3 net profit fell 19% to 108 million yuan, down from 133.3 million yuan in the same period last year, due to decreased sales from processed and cultivation business segments. Revenue dropped 29.6% to 485.8 million yuan. The company expects challenges in cultivation and processed business segments due to labor shortages and rising costs, but sees growth opportunities in China's domestic market.

site_title: Samsung hints at new smartwatch on Apple Watch launch day
summary: Samsung has hinted at a new smartwatch, the Gear, on the same day Apple's long-awaited wearable devices launched. The South Korean tech giant's official blog post revealed images of the smartwatch with a round face and partnered with Baidu, Yelp, and CNN. A wearable software development kit will be released for third-party developers. Despite launching six smartwatches since 2013, Samsung's sales have been modest, with estimates suggesting 1 million units shipped globally last year. No release date was announced for the new Gear smartwatch.

site_title: Quick takes: What 5.5% drop in Singapore's March manufacturing output means for growth outlook
summary: Singapore's manufacturing output dropped 5.5% in March from a year ago, a sharper decline than February's 3.3% drop but better than the 5.9% expected by economists. This follows a better-than-expected report on non-oil domestic exports for the month. Economists are cautiously optimistic about the economy's growth outlook, with Citi and Bank of America Merrill Lynch expressing a more positive view than initially expected.

site_title: Noble Group's head of grain and oilseeds departs
summary: Noble Group's head of grain and oilseeds, Paul Marland, has left the company amid integration with China's COFCO Corp. Marland had run Noble's grain and oilseeds operations since 2012, following a US$1.5 billion deal between COFCO and Noble in April last year. The combined entity, Noble Agri, is expected to be listed with COFCO's assets within 3-5 years. Sources suggest Marland's departure was due to concerns over his future in the merged company, potentially leading to staff cuts and trading operations being reshuffled.

site_title: Basically, this is the bullying, baying Internet that we've become
summary: The article discusses the phenomenon of "Basic Bitch" and "Basic Bro" labels used to mock individuals for conforming to mainstream trends. The term has an ugly undercurrent, as it can be used to belittle someone's intrinsic worth and is often employed in public shaming. The author argues that this kind of derision is a dated concept, reminiscent of past labels like "square" and "beige." The internet has amplified this behavior, making it difficult to distinguish between genuine criticism and online bullying. The author fears that this trend of intolerance and judgmental behavior will continue until it's normalized, and the internet becomes an indistinguishable part of everyday life.

site_title: Singapore: Friday's push on banks helps cut STI's weekly loss
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 12 points to 3,513, but gained 10.25 points on Friday due to a large push from DBS and UOB. The banks are set to report first-quarter figures next week. Despite a reasonably firm Wall Street and all-time high for Nasdaq, the STI was not significantly impacted. Volume in penny stocks declined, with the unit average rising to S$0.70, as brokers attributed this to local proprietary desks and lack of external fund inflows.

site_title: United Envirotech's S$225m bond sale eight times subscribed
summary: United Envirotech Ltd issued S$225 million bonds, eight times subscribed with orders over S$1.8 billion, attracting strong interest from institutional and private bank investors. The three-year bonds were priced at 4.70% and will be used for refinancing, investments, and acquisitions. The bond sale saw banks taking 9%, fund managers 22%, and private banks/retail 69%. The strong demand is attributed to the company's enhanced shareholding, including a 55% stake held by Citic Environment.

site_title: Hwa Hong Q1 profit plunges 50.2%
summary: Hwa Hong Corporation's Q1 profit dropped 50.2% to S$1.21 million, primarily due to a 53.2% decline in rental segment profit and a 21.5% decrease in investment segment profit. Revenue remained steady at S$5.78 million. Earnings per share decreased to 0.19 cents, and net asset value per share fell to 32.04 cents. No dividends were declared for the quarter. The company's stock closed down half a cent at S$0.34.

site_title: German business morale hits highest level since June
summary: German business morale reached its highest level in almost a year in April, according to a survey by Ifo. The business climate index climbed to 108.6, surpassing the Reuters consensus forecast of 108.4. This marks the first time since June 2014 that the index has reached such a high level, indicating a strong start to the second quarter for Europe's largest economy.

site_title: Sembcorp clinches power-purchase deal for gas-fired power plant in Myanmar
summary: Sembcorp Industries has secured a $300 million deal to develop and operate a 225-megawatt gas-fired power plant in central Myanmar. The plant, set to be completed in 2017, will supply power to Myanmar's MEPE under a 22-year power-purchase agreement, with Sembcorp holding an 80% stake. This marks Sembcorp's entry into Myanmar's power market, allowing the company to expand its global business and grow its overseas utilities contribution.

site_title: Indian banks set for cost increases on new loan provisioning rules
summary: Indian banks are set for cost increases due to new loan provisioning rules, which require them to make bigger provisions for restructured debt. The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) has ended a period of "forbearance" and increased provisioning requirements from 5% to 15%. This could lead to higher lending costs, reduced profits, and a decrease in the recovery chances of troubled borrowers. The stricter norms may also affect state-controlled banks, which have a higher percentage of poor quality loans and are under-provisioned.

site_title: Apple thwarts geeks, investors probing smartwatch components
summary: Apple has successfully thwarted attempts to disassemble its new smartwatch by encasing its chips in a tough resin and using rare screws. Gadget repair firm iFixit, which had traveled from the US to Australia to examine the watch, found it difficult to access the electronics due to the resin casing and tri-wing screws. Apple appears to be promoting its brand by not revealing the origins of its components, complicating detailed analysis. The move is seen as a protectionist measure to safeguard its suppliers and maintain a competitive advantage in the wearable technology market.

site_title: Singapore among top 25 happy countries: World Happiness Report 2015
summary: Singapore ranks 24th among the top 25 happiest countries globally, according to the World Happiness Report 2015. The report, by the Sustainable Development Solutions Network, assesses factors such as GDP per capita, social support, life expectancy, and perceptions of corruption.
