Switzerland tops the list, followed by Iceland and Denmark. The report aims to guide policymaking with its happiness measurements.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close 0.84% higher to breach 28,000
summary: Hong Kong shares rose 0.84% to breach the 28,000-point barrier, the first time in seven years, driven by a record-breaking lead from Wall Street and expectations of China introducing more stimulus measures. The Hang Seng Index closed at 28,060.98, while the Shanghai Composite Index fell 0.49% in mainland China.

site_title: ExxonMobil AP chairman joins IE Singapore board, YCH chief is new deputy chairman
summary: The Ministry of Trade and Industry announced several board appointments for IE Singapore, effective May 1. Robert Yap, executive chairman of YCH Group, was appointed as the new deputy chairman, while Olivia Lum was re-appointed as an existing member. Gan Seow Kee, executive chairman of ExxonMobil Asia Pacific, was also appointed to the board.

site_title: Cnooc first-quarter sales drop on lower realised crude price
summary: Cnooc Ltd, China's largest offshore oil and gas explorer, reported a 40% decline in first-quarter oil and gas sales due to lower crude prices, reaching 35.5 billion yuan (S$7.7 billion). The average realised oil price fell 49% to US$53.40 a barrel, while output rose 9.4% to 118.3 million barrels of oil equivalent. Despite the decline, Cnooc exceeded expectations with a 6.6% increase in profit in its full-year result, attributed to effective cost control.

site_title: HSBC to launch immediate review on moving HQ away from UK: Sky News
summary: HSBC is launching an immediate review to consider moving its headquarters from the UK. The decision comes after a report by Sky News citing sources. Shares in the London-listed lender rose 2.1% after the news. The bank was not immediately available to comment on the review.

site_title: China says to increase policy support for cooling economy
summary: China plans to increase policy support to bolster its cooling economy, as its growth rate slowed to a six-year low of 7% in the first quarter. The government will accelerate the construction of big projects and may cut interest rates to meet its 7% growth target. Despite concerns, China's unemployment rate remains stable, and the country created 3.24 million new jobs in the first three months of the year. Policymakers acknowledge the economy faces headwinds but are confident in their ability to stabilize growth.

site_title: China: Stocks down on IPO concerns; ChiNext follows Nasdaq to record high
summary: China stocks fell 0.8-0.5% on Friday, weighed down by financial heavyweights, after the securities regulator accelerated IPO approvals to cool the market. However, Shenzhen's ChiNext closed at a record high. The CSI300 index rose 2.3% for the week, while the Shanghai Composite gained 2.5%. Despite concerns of over-heating, analysts say the bull run isn't over, with regulators seeking a long and steady market.

site_title: China targets gambling hub of Macau in crackdown on graft
summary: China has launched a crackdown on corruption in Macau, the world's largest gambling hub, with seven people, including government officials, being investigated for accepting bribes. This marks a significant shift from last year, when no high-profile officials were questioned. The investigation is part of China's broader efforts to combat graft, led by President Xi Jinping, and comes as Macau's gambling revenues plummet due to fears of being caught up in graft investigations.

site_title: Australia: Shares rise on broad-based rally; up 1% for the week
summary: Australian shares rose 1.5% on Friday, their best performance in five weeks, driven by gains in crude oil and iron ore prices. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 5,933.3, up 88.5 points. This follows a poor run for the market, which was affected by discouraging economic news from China and weak global commodity prices.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks end at 15-year high, boosted by record gain in Nasdaq
summary: Taiwan's main stock index, the TAIEX, reached a 15-year high of 9,913.28, up 1.18% from its previous close. The rally followed a record gain in the Nasdaq overnight. The financial subindex and semiconductor subindex also rose, while the electronics subindex gained 1.7%. The Taiwan dollar strengthened against the US dollar, closing at T$30.934. The gains come ahead of US-EU trade talks and amid ongoing tariff threats.

site_title: Europe: Stocks climb at open on Friday
summary: Europe's main stock markets rose at the start of trading on Friday, with London's FTSE 100 up 0.26% and Frankfurt's DAX 30 up 0.51%. Paris's CAC 40 gained 0.46%. The gains were driven by mining and healthcare shares. The focus shifted to US-EU trade talks, which have been a concern for investors. Despite this, the US stock markets edged closer to record highs, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh levels.

images.alt_text: European stock markets rose at the start of trading on Monday, with London's benchmark FTSE 100 index gaining 0.43 per cent to 6,579.08 points.

site_title: China Eastern Airlines plans US$2.4 bln private share sale to fund global push
summary: China Eastern Airlines plans to raise up to $2.42 billion through a private share sale to fund the expansion of its fleet, with the funds used to purchase 23 aircraft and pay for bank loans. The airline's scheduled purchases include A321 jets from Airbus and B737-800 and B777-300ER planes from Boeing. This move comes as Chinese carriers seek to tap into the booming local stock market to fuel growth, with rival Hainan Airlines also planning a $3.86 billion private share sale. The funds will support the airline's international expansion plans.

site_title: Ringgit gains for a fifth week as oil rebound eases revenue woes
summary: Malaysia's ringgit rose for a fifth week, reaching a two-month high, as Brent crude rebounded, easing concerns about government revenue. The currency has swung from Asia's worst-performing currency to the best since March, with a 3.3% gain since March 31. Bank Negara Malaysia Governor Zeti Akhtar Aziz ruled out interest rate cuts, citing accommodative borrowing costs. The nation's economy is expected to grow 4.5-5.5% this year, according to Zeti, despite inflation accelerating to 0.9% in March.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close down 0.83% after three-day rally
summary: Tokyo stocks closed down 0.83% on Friday, ending a three-day winning streak, despite a record close on the Nasdaq. The Nikkei 225 lost 167.61 points to 20,020.04 and the Topix index eased 0.37% to 1,618.84. This marks the first decline in the benchmark index since April 15. The rally was attributed to the recent record highs on the Nasdaq, but investors were cautious ahead of US-EU trade talks.

site_title: China to expand pilot freeing capital account convertibility: sources
summary: China plans to expand a trial allowing companies to freely move yuan and other foreign currencies in and out of the country to three more free-trade zones by the end of the year. This move is a crucial step in liberalizing China's capital account and turning the yuan into a convertible currency. The experiment, currently only in Shanghai, aims to pave the way for the yuan to be traded freely worldwide.

site_title: NTU-linked electric taxi unveiled
summary: NTU-linked electric taxi, EVA, was unveiled in Singapore, marking the world's first electric taxi for tropical megacities. EVA can travel 200km on a single 15-minute charge, producing zero local emissions, and is 150kg lighter than average taxis due to its lightweight carbon-fibre composites. TUM CREATE, a collaboration between NTU and Germany's Technische Universität München, is in talks to commercialize EVA and bring it to big cities worldwide, citing decreasing costs for electric vehicles and charging infrastructure. This represents a disruption to the traditional taxi industry and automobile sector.

site_title: Greece offers concessions in talks with creditors
summary: Greece offered concessions to international creditors, including pension system reforms and partial privatization of public assets, in exchange for new funding. Greek Finance Minister Yanis Varoufakis agreed to these conditions in a blog post, stating that current disagreements with partners are not unbridgeable. This move comes as Athens quickly runs out of money, and euro zone finance ministers meet in Riga to assess progress on a comprehensive package of reforms. The concessions aim to address creditor demands and unlock new funding for Greece.

site_title: Asia's taste for chocolates to ice cream seen rising on incomes
summary: Asia's growing middle class is driving up demand for chocolates and ice cream, with cocoa futures expected to rise 8% annually for the next 10 years. Despite a decline in processing in Europe and North America, Asia's increased grinding capacity has reduced demand for beans, hurting processor margins. The region's growing demand is expected to lead long-term growth in cocoa and chocolate consumption, with emerging economies becoming increasingly middle-class and seeking better quality chocolates.

site_title: Singapore's manufacturing sector shrinks by smaller-than-expected 5.5% y-o-y in March
summary: Singapore's manufacturing sector contracted 5.5% year-over-year in March, a smaller-than-expected decline. Despite a 13.9% drop in pharmaceutical output, the biomedical manufacturing cluster still saw an 8.5% contraction. Electronics and transport engineering sectors drove the decline, with electronics output falling 5.2% and transport engineering output declining 15.6% year-over-year. Overall, industrial output rose 1.2% month-over-month, beating market forecasts.

site_title: South Korea finance minister says growth seen above 1% in Q2 q-o-q
summary: South Korea's finance minister, Choi Kyung-hwan, stated that the country's economy is expected to experience sequential growth above 1% in Q2, despite no signs of a firm recovery. The March quarter's economy expanded 0.8% seasonally adjusted, with much of the first quarter growth influenced by a weak period in the October-December quarter of last year.

site_title: Oil at US$65 seen freeing 500,000 barrels from shale fracklog
summary: US oil drillers are expected to tap a pent-up supply of oil locked in shale wells once oil prices reach $65 a barrel, adding 500,000 barrels per day to the market by the end of 2016. The "fracklog" of idled wells has ballooned to 4,731, with 1,540 waiting to be completed in the Permian Basin. As prices rebound from a six-year low, drillers are expected to start working through their backlog, potentially slowing the recovery and capping prices.

site_title: Oil prices edge back from 2015-highs
summary: Oil prices edged back from 2015-highs on Friday, with Brent crude at $64.54 a barrel and US crude at $57.42 a barrel. Renewed air strikes in Yemen and a weakening dollar supported prices, which have surged about $10 a barrel over the last month. The rise in prices has created a disconnect between oil producers and Wall Street, with some predicting a quicker recovery in oil prices. Producers are bracing for oil to remain at around $60 a barrel for the next five years.

site_title: Progressive wage model launched for Singapore's landscape industry
summary: Singapore launches a progressive wage model for its landscape industry, benefiting 3,000 workers with higher wages, improved skills training, and clearer career progression. The model sets a basic minimum wage of S$1,300, replacing the previous median basic wage of S$1,000. The requirement will apply to companies in the Landscape Company Register by June 2016, aiming to attract and retain manpower in the industry.

site_title: Seoul: Shares fall after posting a 4-year high; won firms
summary: South Korean shares fell 0.6% to a near four-year high, erasing early gains, as investors took profits. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) reached 2,189.54 points, its highest intraday level since July 2011. The won also rose 0.3% to 1,079.4 per dollar, marking a fourth consecutive week of gains. The decline followed a week of strong gains, with KOSPI up 0.8% and the won climbing 0.4% this week.

site_title: MAS strengthens regulations against money laundering, terrorism financing
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has issued revised anti-money laundering (AML) and countering the financing of terrorism (CFT) notices, strengthening regulations against these activities. Key changes include a more comprehensive enterprise-wide risk assessment to complement individual customer risk assessments.

images.alt_text: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has issued on Friday revised Notices to financial institutions on anti-money laundering (AML) and countering the financing of terrorism (CFT).

site_title: Talk of China Dim Sum bond market's death is greatly exaggerated
summary: China's Dim Sum bond market, which has long been a key platform for Chinese firms to raise debt in Hong Kong, is not expected to diminish as some analysts suggest. Instead, it will likely remain a niche market alongside the larger onshore market. The Dim Sum market's issuance has fallen 64% this year due to rising offshore yuan interbank rates, but analysts believe it will continue to attract issuers, particularly non-Chinese companies. Global investors will prefer the onshore market due to its greater variety and financial transparency, but Dim Sum bonds will still be attractive for their liquidity premium.

site_title: Google search mobile switch a revolution for some
summary: Google has modified its search algorithm to favor mobile-friendly sites, a move dubbed "mobilegeddon" by US media, as the company seeks to upstage Apple in the mobile search market. The change affects over half of internet searches worldwide, driven by smartphone penetration in developing countries. Experts predict a significant impact, but some websites have reported little change, while others have seen no initial impact, with some warning of a 60-80% loss in turnover if rankings drop. Google argues the change benefits users, but risks losing users and revenue if search results are not adapted.

site_title: Saudi Arabia's solution to global oil glut: Pump ever more crude
summary: Saudi Arabia plans to pump near-record levels of crude oil, exceeding 10.3 million barrels a day, to counter the global surplus and undermine rival producers. The move, which has been criticized by fellow OPEC members, aims to increase domestic demand and reduce reliance on exports. Analysts predict the kingdom will continue to ramp up production, potentially reaching 11 million barrels a day, as domestic consumption rises in the summer months and new refineries require supplies.

site_title: Q&M plans to spin off China dental manufacturing business
summary: Q&M Dental Group plans to spin off its China manufacturing subsidiary, Q&M Aidite International, through a listing on a reputable stock exchange. Aidite produces zirconium oxide blocks for CAD/CAM machines used in tooth restorations. The spin-off aims to provide another source of funding for growth and give investors an independent assessment of the manufacturing business. Q&M acquired Aidite for 74.5 million yuan in 2014. The listing's success depends on preparatory work, regulatory approvals, market conditions, and directors' decisions.

site_title: JPMorgan names Li as China equity research head in new role
summary: JPMorgan Chase & Co. has appointed Karen Li as the head of China equity research in a newly created role. Li, who joined the investment bank in 2005, will report to James Sullivan, chief of equity research for Asia ex-Japan. This move comes as the Shanghai Composite Index has surged 114% in the past 12 months, with JPMorgan expanding its analysis of mainland and Hong Kong-traded Chinese companies. The bank expects to see increased investment opportunities in China over the next 5-10 years.

site_title: Asia: Stocks mostly up after record on Wall St
summary: Asian stocks rose on Friday, following a record-breaking day on Wall Street where the Nasdaq reached a 15-year high. Hong Kong, Sydney, and Taipei led gains, while Tokyo and Shanghai declined. Investors tracked US market movements, with oil prices edging down after a rally fueled by Yemen unrest concerns. The euro ticked higher ahead of a eurozone meeting to discuss Greece's debt crisis, which may impact the meeting's outcome.

site_title: Office rents rise, retail rents fall in Q1: URA
summary: Office rents rose 0.6% in Q1, after a 1.7% increase in Q4, while retail rents fell 0.3% after a 0.5% increase in Q4. The total office space supply increased by 22,000 sq m, with 880,000 sq m in pipeline, while retail space supply was 723,000 sq m. The island-wide vacancy rate for office space remained unchanged at 10.2%.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Q&M, Ascendas Reit, Great Eastern
summary: Q&M Dental Group plans to spin off its China manufacturing subsidiary, Q&M Aidite International, through a listing on a reputable stock exchange. Ascendas Reit reported a distribution per unit (DPU) of 3.71 Singapore cents for its fourth quarter, up 4.5% from a year ago. Great Eastern reported a net profit of S$220.5 million for its first quarter, down 5% from the previous year due to the absence of a one-off gain.

site_title: Prices, rents of private home prices continue to slip in Q1: URA
summary: Private home prices in Singapore slipped 1% in Q1, marking the sixth consecutive quarter of decline, according to URA data. Prices fell 0.4% in Core Central Region, 1.7% in Rest of Central Region, and 1.1% in Outside Central Region. Landed properties also declined 0.9%. Rents of private homes dropped 1.7% across all segments, with a decline seen in all regions.

site_title: If China is seeing capital outflow now, what happens in crisis?
summary: China is experiencing capital outflows, despite its strong economic growth and rising stock market. The outflow is attributed to a property bust, squeezed corporate profits, and the end of a currency upswing, as well as President Xi Jinping's anti-corruption campaign. The government is playing down the risk, but experts warn of a potential confidence crisis if the macro story deteriorates further or the stock exchange collapses. China has measures in place to counter the outflows, including foreign exchange reserves and potential interventions to shore up the yuan.

site_title: Broker's take: Citi downgrades Mapletree Commercial Trust to 'neutral'
summary: Citi Research has downgraded Mapletree Commercial Trust to "neutral" due to flattening tenant sales and concerns with the office market. The target price was raised from S$1.43 to S$1.63. The trust's shares fell 1.5 cents to S$1.59. This downgrade comes after the release of an April 23 report.

images.alt_text: Citi Research has downgraded Mapletree Commercial Trust, which owns Vivocity mall along with some office properties, to "neutral", though it raised its target price from S$1.43 to S$1.63.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Friday, rising 5.06 points to 1852.99, with 143 gainers outnumbering 58 losers. The market saw 87.6 million lots traded worth RM36.6 million.

site_title: Asia must boost infrastructure investment
summary: Bank of Japan deputy governor Hiroshi Nakaso emphasizes the need for Asia to boost infrastructure investment to sustain high economic growth. He notes that insufficient infrastructure in some Asian economies hinders industrial advancement. This is in line with Nakaso's expertise on global financial markets, having navigated the 2008 financial crisis. The call for increased infrastructure investment comes as Asia faces various economic challenges, including the impact of US tariffs on the garment industry and slowing GDP growth in China.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks rise on Nasdaq, may extend 7-1/2-yr gains
summary: Taiwan's main TAIEX index rose 1.6% to 9,951.29, extending its 7-1/2-year gains. The index closed at a 7-1/2-year high on Thursday, with a target of the 10,000-mark looming if it surpasses 9,912. This follows an overnight rally in the Nasdaq, where stocks rose to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty and split Fed views.

site_title: Documents show flash crash trader's frenetic business dealings
summary: US court documents show that Navinder Singh Sarao, a 36-year-old British trader, contributed to the 2010 Wall Street flash crash, wiping out $1 trillion from US stock markets in minutes. Sarao allegedly used an automated program to "spoof" markets, generating large sell orders, then canceling them and buying the contracts at lower prices, reaping a $40 million profit. The trader maintained frenetic relationships with brokers, banks, and software firms, and his rapid-fire trading activity mirrored his business dealings. Sarao has been charged in US civil and criminal complaints and faces extradition to the US for trial.

site_title: Low-key launch as Apple Watch finally goes on sale
summary: Apple Watch launched globally on April 24, 2015, with a low-key launch, with only a handful of upscale boutiques and department stores selling the gadget. Around 50 people lined up in Tokyo, but no excitement was seen at Apple stores. The watch will be sold online instead of in-store, preventing typical fan lines. Apple has not released sales numbers, but Wall Street estimates vary widely, with some predicting 20 million watches sold. The company is working to fill orders quickly based on available supply and order priority.

images.alt_text: The Apple Watch launched globally on Friday with a small queue of Japanese tech-addicts lining up in Tokyo for Apple Inc's first wearable gadget, but there was no sign of the excitement usually attached to the company's product rollouts.

site_title: Ascott Residence Trust posts 1% rise in Q1 DPU; OCBC keeps 'buy' call
summary: Ascott Residence Trust reported a 1% rise in distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.76 cents for Q1 2015, driven by revenue growth of 12% to S$90 million and gross profit growth of 10% to S$43.1 million. However, revenue per available unit declined 8% due to weaker performance in Singapore and Vietnam. Analysts maintain a "buy" call on the trust, with OCBC Investment Research revising its fair value estimate downwards due to missed expectations. The trust aims to grow from S$4.1 billion to S$6 billion by 2017 through accretive acquisitions and capital recycling.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks up 0.54% at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened 0.54% higher on Friday, following a strong lead from Wall Street, where the Nasdaq reached a record high. The Hang Seng Index gained 150.69 points to 27,978.39. In contrast, mainland China's Shanghai Composite Index fell 1.76% and the Shenzhen Composite Index lost 1.52%.

site_title: China says unemployment rate at 4.05% at end Q1
summary: China's urban unemployment rate decreased to 4.05% at the end of March, down from 4.1% at the end of 2014, according to the labor ministry. The government aims to create at least 10 million new jobs in 2015 while keeping the rate below 4.5%. This follows a slight decrease from 4.1% in the previous year, indicating a steady improvement in employment.

site_title: US power grid's US$2 trillion push needs European efficiency
summary: The US power grid requires a $2 trillion upgrade by 2030 to blend renewable energy and fortify against extreme weather, with efficiency playing a key role in keeping costs down. Despite higher electricity rates, European countries like France, Italy, and Germany enjoy lower monthly bills due to smart technology, smaller homes, and more efficient appliances. The US ranks 13th in energy efficiency among major economies, with the government and industry taking steps towards efficiency through smart thermostats, air conditioning, and grid upgrades.

site_title: Singapore: Stocks open higher on Asia, US
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index opened 2.82 points higher at 3,505.57 points, driven by US gains and a positive Asian open. Gainers outnumbered losers 108 to 43, with top stocks including DBS, Global Logistic Properties, and Singtel. This marks a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: Singapore cuts aeronautical fees at Changi Airport
summary: Singapore Changi Airport Group announced several reductions and rebates to aeronautical fees, effective May 1, 2015. Passenger service charge for transfer and transit passengers will be reduced to S$3, and a 50% landing fee rebate for long-haul flights will be extended to March 31, 2017. Landing fees for large aircraft will be cut by up to 5%, and existing rebates for airlines will be extended until March 31, 2017. The measures aim to strengthen Changi Airport's attractiveness as a long-haul transfer hub and support the cargo sector.

site_title: Apple wins patent appeal in China
summary: Apple has won a patent appeal in China, with the Beijing Higher People's Court upholding the company's appeal and ordering a Chinese agency to reverse its decision. The agency had previously ruled that Apple's "Siri" voice recognition system infringed on a Chinese patent. The decision allows Apple to continue offering Siri, and the company can now enjoy the conveniences brought by the technology without infringing on other patents. The ruling comes ahead of the launch of the Apple Watch in China, a key market for the company.

images.alt_text: Apple has won an appeal in China over patent rights to voice recognition software such as the iPhone's "Siri", with a court overruling an earlier decision that had gone against the US technology giant.

site_title: Comcast said planning to drop offer for Time Warner Cable
summary: Comcast is planning to drop its proposed $45.2 billion takeover of Time Warner Cable after US regulators, including the Federal Communications Commission (FCC), expressed opposition to the deal. The FCC staff and Justice Department are leaning against the transaction, citing concerns it may not benefit consumers. The decision may be made as early as Friday, after Comcast makes a final decision on its plans. The FCC's opposition could effectively kill the deal by dragging out the approval process beyond the companies' time frame for completion.

site_title: Global Logistic Properties tie-up to sell asset to Japan Reit for 7.2b yen
summary: Global Logistic Properties (GLP) is selling its 392,000 sq ft property in Greater Osaka, Japan to GLP J-Reit for 7.2 billion yen (S$81 million). The sale creates a 38% development value creation margin for the joint venture within 14 months. GLP J-Reit is a Tokyo-listed real estate investment trust focused on logistics properties in Japan, and GLP owns 15% of the trust.

site_title: Worldwide coal market is adjusting as China's appetite slows
summary: China's coal consumption continues to rise, but at a slower rate, leaving global producers with excess supply. Chinese imports have dropped 33% from last year, and prices are at multiyear lows due to a strong dollar. The International Energy Agency forecasts 2.1% annual growth in global coal demand through 2019, down from 3.3% in the first three years of the decade. China's coal demand is expected to decline 18% this year, and the country is still in the early stages of utilizing coal, according to Peabody Energy CEO Greg Boyce.

site_title: Singapore HDB resale price index slips 1% in Q1 from Q4
summary: Singapore's HDB resale price index decreased 1% in Q1 from Q4, marking the seventh consecutive drop. Resale transactions fell 10.8% to 4,135 cases, while the number of approved subletting applications rose 0.2% to 10,385 cases. HDB also offered 3,995 flats for sale under the February BTO exercise and will offer 4,040 new flats in the upcoming May BTO exercise.

site_title: China to increase frequency of monetary policy adjustments: planner
summary: China plans to increase the frequency of monetary policy adjustments due to stable inflation, according to Li Pumin, General Secretary of the National Reform and Development Commission. The country will also accelerate large infrastructure projects, with Deputy Head of the NDRC's investment department, Luo Guosan, stating that projects will be expedited. This move aims to boost economic growth and address potential slowdowns.

site_title: Dutch expert fired after showing MH17 victim photos
summary: A Dutch expert, George Maat, has been fired after showing photographs of MH17 victims at a public lecture, deemed "completely inappropriate and in bad taste" by the Justice Minister. Maat, an anthropologist at Leiden University, was suspended while further action was considered. The lecture, intended for medical students, showed body parts and discussed identification processes, causing distress to victims' relatives. The incident has sparked criticism, with the deputy head of the MH17 Air Disaster Association calling the display "shameful and very shocking".

site_title: China boosts pace of IPOs, adding to supply as prices surge
summary: China's securities regulator is increasing the pace of initial public offerings, allowing more companies to tap into a booming market. The China Securities Regulatory Commission will review and approve two batches of IPO applications each month, up from one previously. Since the start of the year, all but one of over 140 IPOs has surged by the maximum 44% allowed on their first trading day. This surge in new listings is expected to meet the demand, with the Shanghai Composite Index reaching a seven-year high.

site_title: Starbucks' sales exceed estimates after customer traffic grows
summary: Starbucks reported second-quarter sales exceeding estimates, with revenue gaining 18% to $4.56 billion. The growth was attributed to the company's mobile app and expanded menu, drawing more customers to stores. Earnings per share matched analysts' estimates. The company plans to test delivery services in Seattle and New York, further expanding its digital services. Following the results, Starbucks' shares rose in extended trading.

images.alt_text: Starbucks Corp, the world's biggest coffee- shop operator, posted second-quarter sales that topped analysts' estimates after its mobile app and an expanded menu helped draw more customers to stores.

site_title: Freeport considers energy spinoff two years after diversifying
summary: Freeport McMoRan Inc is considering spinning off its energy assets, two years after acquiring them for $9 billion, due to lower commodity prices and a need to finance development plans. The company may hold an initial public offering for a minority stake in the oil and gas business, aiming to optimize funding and highlight the standalone value of its energy assets. This move comes as the company faces a first loss since the global financial crisis and cuts its forecast for copper output.

images.alt_text: Freeport McMoRan Copper & Gold's open-pit mine at its Grasberg complex. Freeport McMoRan Inc is considering spinning off energy assets two years after agreeing to acquire them for US$9 billion as it tries to finance development plans amid lower commodity prices.

site_title: Hershey's China growth target in peril as sales tumble
summary: Hershey Co Inc's China sales nearly halved in the first quarter, falling to US$185 million compared to US$333 million in 2014, due to a slowdown in discretionary spending. The company stuck to its annual sales target of US$450 million, but analysts say it's difficult to meet. China's economic growth slowdown to 7% in the first quarter and consumers holding back on spending during the Chinese New Year period contributed to the decline.

site_title: Marina Bay Sands still a resilient business, says Las Vegas Sands chairman
summary: Las Vegas Sands chairman Sheldon Adelson expressed confidence in Marina Bay Sands' resilience, beating analyst expectations with adjusted property Ebitda of US$415 million, down 4.6% from a year ago. The casino earned a record in mass win per day, and its strong financial results confirm it as a world-class integrated resort destination, despite a decline in Chinese visitors due to China's anti-corruption crackdown. Occupancy and revenue per available room fell, but the business remains a key reference site for emerging jurisdictions.

images.alt_text: Singapore's Marina Bay Sands continues to be a resilient business that beat analyst expectations and hit new winnings records, said Las Vegas Sands chairman Sheldon Adelson.

site_title: Finding a new balance
summary: Oil prices are expected to stabilize at US$60-80 per barrel by the end of the year, according to industry veterans, following a dramatic 60% plunge over the past year. The US shale boom has led to oversupply, but a potential cutback in supply due to unprofitability is expected to limit gains. Benchmark Brent crude oil is currently trading at around US$62 a barrel, while US crude is valued at around US$56 a barrel. Political instability in the Middle East has also contributed to higher prices.

site_title: A groovy kind of love
summary: Pooja Nansi's poetry collection "Love Is An Empty Barstool" has gained popularity among young people for its intense and confessional poems about love and heartbreak. Published in 2013, the book features poems that capture the writer's raw emotions and urges, often feeling "hell-bent on creating their own mythology." Nansi's writing is characterized by a sharp, combative intelligence, and her lack of ambivalence or opacity, making her stand out as a voice for the ardour and anguish of love.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: Switzerland, Scandinavia top global 'happy' index
summary: Switzerland tops the global 'happy' index, followed by Iceland, Denmark, Norway, and Canada, according to the 2015 World Happiness Report. The report, published by the United Nations, identifies variables such as real GDP per capita, healthy life expectancy, and social support as key determinants of happiness. The US trails in 15th place, while Afghanistan and war-torn Syria are among the 10 least happy countries. The report emphasizes the importance of fairness, honesty, and good health in maintaining happiness, and highlights examples of countries that have successfully maintained happiness despite economic crises and natural disasters.

site_title: Starbucks sees bigger hit from foreign exchange this year
summary: Starbucks expects a 2 percentage point hit from foreign exchange on earnings and revenue this year, up from its previous forecast of 1 percentage point. Despite this, the company stands by its fiscal 2015 revenue growth forecast of 16-18% and full-year earnings per share of $1.55-$1.57. Strength across its businesses is expected to offset the impact, with Chief Financial Officer Scott Maw citing this as a positive factor.

site_title: Google shares rise after online ad sales drive revenue higher
summary: Google's quarterly revenue rose 12% to $17.26 billion, beating analyst expectations, despite a hit from the strong dollar. Ad sales, driven by a 13% increase in ads and a 7% decline in ad prices, accounted for the majority of the growth. The company's shares rose 3.5% after-hours, and net income rose to $3.59 billion, or $5.20 per share. Despite missing forecasts, investors expressed relief, with some analysts attributing the positive reaction to a "degree of relief rally."

images.alt_text: Google Inc reported higher quarterly revenue and profit as rising online ad volume offset a hit from the strong dollar, sending the Internet company's shares higher in after-hours trading.

site_title: Great Eastern Q1 net profit down 5% to S$220.5m due to lack of one-off gain
summary: Great Eastern reported a 5% decrease in Q1 net profit to S$220.5m, excluding a one-off gain from the sale of a joint venture stake. Gross premiums collected rose 1% to S$1.88 billion. The group sold 85 million shares in New China Life Insurance for HK$4.3 billion (S$763 million), with proceeds used for portfolio reallocation.

site_title: Wrong calls for Singapore dollar's drop abandoned as rally holds
summary: Singapore's currency, the Singapore dollar, has surged to its biggest monthly gain versus the US dollar since January 2012, reaching record highs against the euro and Malaysia's ringgit. Foreign-exchange strategists have revised their forecasts, with Credit Suisse and Goldman Sachs raising their estimates, citing the Monetary Authority of Singapore's decision to refrain from adding stimulus in April. The currency's rally is attributed to the MAS's surprise move, which was seen as an end to its easing cycle. Analysts now expect the currency to appreciate to S$1.40 by year-end, a two-cent increase from previous forecasts.

site_title: China Aviation Oil Q1 profit down 27%
summary: China Aviation Oil's first quarter 2015 net profit fell 27% to US$14.36 million due to lower oil prices and thinner trading volumes. Revenues nearly halved to US$2.08 billion and total supply and trading volume for jet fuel and other oil products dropped 13.02%. The company expects the oil trading environment to remain challenging amid uncertainties in oil supply and demand.

site_title: Zeti signals no need for Malaysian rate cut in near future
summary: Malaysian central bank Governor Zeti Akhtar Aziz signaled no need for interest-rate cuts in the near future, citing steady economic growth and low inflation. The economy has above-5% growth and inflation near its slowest since 2009, with about 80% of the economy not linked to oil and gas. Zeti also stated that the ringgit's weakness won't prompt a rate cut, as the central bank looks at risks to inflation and growth. The next interest-rate decision is on May 7, and the central bank is expected to hold its key rate for the rest of the year.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open 0.22% lower
summary: Tokyo stocks opened 0.22% lower on Friday, despite three days of gains that pushed the Nikkei index to a 15-year high. The Nikkei 225 index fell 45.18 points to 20,142.47 at the start, influenced by a lower opening.

site_title: US removes prominent Myanmar businessman from sanctions list
summary: The US removed Win Aung, a prominent Myanmar businessman, from its sanctions list despite doubts over the country's reforms. Win Aung, a former head of Myanmar's chamber of commerce, was removed from the Specially Designated Nationals and Blocked Persons list due to actions taken by the sanctioned individuals or enterprises. The decision came despite allegations that Win Aung had exported timber to China from protected areas due to his military ties. The US sanctions architecture remains in place, and changes will depend on Myanmar's continued reforms and resolving disputes with ethnic groups.

site_title: US: Stocks shrug off mixed earnings and data, Nasdaq tops record
summary: US stocks rose, with the Nasdaq Composite reaching a 15-year high, despite mixed earnings and disappointing manufacturing data. The Nasdaq climbed 0.4% to close at a record, while the S&P 500 rose 0.2%. Oil rose to a four-month high. Gains from Microsoft and eBay pushed the Nasdaq past its record. The market is giving large companies a "free pass" and assuming an acceleration in earnings, according to analysts.

site_title: McDonald's to reveal comeback plan on May 4
summary: McDonald's CEO Steve Easterbrook is set to reveal a turnaround plan on May 4, aiming to improve performance and deliver enduring growth. The plan includes shutting underperforming 350 restaurants worldwide, selling a new premium sirloin burger, and boosting pay at company-owned restaurants. The move comes after the company posted a sixth straight quarter of decreasing US sales, with profit missing analyst estimates and net income tumbling 33%. Easterbrook is also taking steps to improve McDonald's image by reducing antibiotic use in chicken and curbing antibiotic resistance.

site_title: Commodity markets feel liquidity crunch as banks exit trading
summary: Commodity markets are experiencing a liquidity crunch due to banks' exit from trading and stricter capital requirements. Major trading houses claim that the reduction in risk capital and increased regulation has led to dramatic price moves. Liquidity is concentrated at the front of the curve, while the back end is scarce, leaving market participants hesitant to hedge large volumes. This has led to wider trading spreads, decreased options liquidity, and less open interest, posing risks of violent changes in prices.

site_title: Fed concerned about ability of asset managers to repay in a crisis
summary: The Federal Reserve is concerned about the ability of asset managers to repay in a crisis, particularly in a scenario where investors panic and demand cash, exposing the market to liquidity risks. The Fed's worries stem from the decline in liquidity in the bond market due to bank regulations and a surge in asset management inflows. Fed officials, including Stanley Fischer and William Dudley, have warned about the risks of a "taper tantrum" and the potential for a spike in borrowing costs that could hurt economic growth.

site_title: DBS Group committed to 'first wife': CEO
summary: DBS Group CEO Piyush Gupta has assured shareholders that the bank is committed to POSB Bank, the "first wife" of the group, despite some shareholders' concerns about its future. Gupta responded to questions about POSB's relevance and the bank's focus on DBS Bank. He stated that the chairman and he are committed to POSB and that the bank will continue to provide banking services under the POSB brand.

site_title: KKR beats quarterly profit estimates on boots, fotolia sales
summary: KKR & Co reported a 5.1% decrease in economic net income to $526 million, or 62 cents a share, in Q1 2025, beating analyst estimates of 52 cents. The firm's private equity holdings appreciated 5.1% and sales of assets, including Fotolia and Big Heart Pet Brands, drove a 16% increase in distributable earnings. KKR's energy-related holdings declined in value, and the firm marked down loans and collateralized loan obligations. The results were driven by higher revenues, primarily performance fees related to private equity marks.

images.alt_text: KKR & Co's first-quarter profit beat expectations, driven by sales of private equity holdings, even as earnings decreased after the firm marked down energy-related holdings and its loans portfolio.

site_title: Merkel: must prevent Greece running out of cash before deal
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel urged Greece to prevent running out of money before reaching a cash-for-reform deal with international creditors. Merkel met with Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras, noting significant progress in negotiations, but differences remain over labor market, pension system, and taxation reforms. Euro zone finance ministers will review progress on Friday, amid concerns Greece's financial position is deteriorating, with a primary budget surplus target of 1.2-1.5% of GDP. A deal is crucial to unlock frozen bailout funds and prevent investors from fearing a default, potentially forcing Greece out of the eurozone.

site_title: Peabody explores asset sales to shore up balance sheet
summary: Peabody Energy Corp, the largest US coal producer, is exploring asset sales in Australia and the US to strengthen its balance sheet amid a depressed coal market. The company considers selling non-core reserves, land holdings, and stakes in active operations, including a 3 billion-ton coal reserve and 500,000 acres of land. Peabody also explores the possibility of placing US coal operations in a master-limited partnership to increase shareholder value. The company reduced its US thermal coal output forecast to 180-190 million tons and reported a widened net loss of 39 cents per share.

site_title: Google launches phone service, but only on Nexus phones for now
summary: Google has launched Project Fi, a phone service available only on Nexus 6 phones, competing with Verizon, AT&T, and other wireless service providers. The service blends traditional wireless technology with wireless Internet service, offering a seamless transition between Wi-Fi and cell networks. Project Fi will cost $20/month for basic voice and text service, with data plans starting at $10/GB. Google is using Sprint and T-Mobile networks, limiting its competitive threat to traditional carriers, but analysts see the service as a bid to reimagine phone calls and expand Google's mobile presence.

site_title: EU must dismantle Fortress Europe, liberalise its immigration policy
summary: The European Union's immigration policy has been criticized for treating migrants as criminals, leading to a significant number of deaths in the Mediterranean. The EU's "Fortress Europe" approach, which includes militarizing border controls, criminalizing migration, and outsourcing controls, has resulted in thousands of migrant deaths. The EU's 10-point plan, proposed on Monday, includes military action against smuggling networks, but critics argue that it will only exacerbate the problem. To address the issue, the EU should dismantle "Fortress Europe," liberalize its immigration policy, and open up legal routes for migrants, rather than treating them as criminals.

site_title: MPA signs S$2.4b deal for first phase of Tuas Terminal
summary: The Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore (MPA) has signed a S$2.42 billion deal with a joint venture between Dredging International Asia Pacific and Daelim Industrial to develop the first phase of the Tuas Terminal. The project includes reclaiming 294 hectares of land, which will increase the terminal's capacity to handle up to 65 million containers per year, nearly twice Singapore's current container throughput volume. The project is expected to be completed by December 2020, with the MPA also announcing an expansion of its research and green technology initiatives.

site_title: Goldman to buy Pac Life unit to add US$18 billion of assets
summary: Goldman Sachs Group Inc. agreed to buy Pacific Global Advisors, a unit of Pacific Life Insurance Co., to bolster its asset-management operation. The unit has US$18 billion in assets under supervision and is expected to be completed in the middle of this year. This acquisition marks Goldman's sixth since 2011, increasing assets under management to over US$1 trillion. The deal is expected to drive 10%+ revenue growth for the business.

site_title: SE-Asia heading in right direction: Credit Suisse
summary: Credit Suisse predicts South-east Asia will continue growing despite the volatile economic environment, driven by foreign investment, trade agreements, and a youthful workforce. The region has averaged 6% annual growth from 2010-2014, thanks to smart decisions by leaders and favorable foreign investment. Trade and investment agreements, such as the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank and China's US$40 billion Silk Route Fund, will support progress. The growth of China's middle class and social networking companies will also energize long-term growth in the region.

images.alt_text: South-east Asia can build on its recent record of robust economic growth averaging 6 per cent annually from 2010-2014, says Mr Varvel (above)

site_title: Garuda plans strategic growth; to boost capacity on S'pore route
summary: Garuda Indonesia plans to boost capacity on its Singapore route by 20% by October, with six Airbus A330s operating 10 daily flights between Jakarta and Singapore. The airline aims to carry 25 million passengers this year, up 12% from last year, and will see its fleet grow to 145 planes by December. Garuda is restructuring its network and cutting costs to turn itself around, with Citilink, its budget carrier arm, expected to turn a profit this year. The airline is also strengthening its position in the domestic market and planning to launch international routes.

images.alt_text: Mr Wibowo says this year Garuda will grow about 12 per cent in capacity. It aims to carry 25 million passengers, up from 21.5 million last year.

site_title: Japan lifts age limit for plane captains to 67
summary: Japan has raised the age limit for plane captains to 67, aiming to ease a pilot shortage while ensuring safety. Currently, pilots must retire at 65, but those aged 64 or less will be allowed to continue flying until their 68th birthday. The move is expected to make Japanese airline pilots among the oldest in the world, addressing a shortage that has led to cancelled flights and is expected to worsen in the 2030s due to retirement. The industry faces a lack of skilled pilots and high training costs, with experts noting that older pilots do not pose a safety risk if properly trained.

site_title: You thought Amazon's cloud was big? Alibaba's is huge
summary: Amazon's cloud computing business, Amazon Web Services (AWS), has surpassed Alibaba's Aliyun in the global market, with 28% of the worldwide market share, followed by Microsoft with 10%. Alibaba, however, is rapidly expanding its cloud services globally, with over 1.4 million customers and a growing international presence. The company aims to achieve a global deployment of its cloud, making it self-contained, and has partnered with Intel to develop custom chips and ARM-based processors to reduce electricity bills. As AWS faces increasing competition from Alibaba, a battle is looming in both China and abroad.

images.alt_text: After keeping the world waiting for nine years, Amazon finally broke out earnings for its Amazon Web Services today.

site_title: Inflation down for a fifth month; no deflation feared
summary: Singapore's consumer prices fell 0.3% in March for the fifth consecutive month, the lowest rate since 2009. Economists expect the inflation rate to reach its trough in the third quarter of 2015 and remain negative throughout the year, but not triggering deflation concerns. Housing and transport costs declined, while food inflation rose at a slower pace. The Monetary Authority of Singapore and Ministry of Trade and Industry project headline inflation to average -0.5 to 0.5% and core inflation to range from 0.5 to 1.5% this year.

site_title: April factory activity growth slows to three-month low
summary: US factory activity growth slowed to a three-month low in April, with the manufacturing sector's Purchasing Managers' Index falling to 54.2 from 55.7 in March. Employment growth also weakened, while new-home purchases dropped 11.4% to a four-month low, exceeding forecasts. The housing market's progress is being hindered by a limited supply of available homes and tight lending standards, with income growth needed to support further growth.

site_title: UK homebuilders look strong as both parties pledge more housing
summary: UK homebuilders appear strong as both the Conservative and Labour parties pledge support for housing ahead of the May 7 election. Valuations for the industry are at their cheapest in four years, and analysts have upgraded construction firms due to expected boosts in house building. Despite a cooling housing market, property-related companies are among the most loved by analysts, with ratings averaging 4.17 on a scale of five. The Bloomberg UK Homebuilder Index has outperformed the nation's equity benchmark this year, with companies like Persimmon and Taylor Wimpey advancing over 11% in 2015.

site_title: Barclays needs faster cuts at investment bank: analysts
summary: Barclays' investment bank needs to speed up cuts to meet profitability targets, according to Citigroup analysts. The bank must reduce costs faster than revenue, requiring "faster downsizing" and a greater focus on shrinking low-yielding assets. Barclays aims for a 12% return on equity by 2016, but analysts fear this may be "behind schedule" unless the investment bank is fixed. The bank has pledged to cut 7,000 jobs since CEO Antony Jenkins took over in 2012, but further cuts are needed to meet the target.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Mapletree Commercial Trust (MCT) reported Q4 FY15 revenue of S$71 million, a 3.5% year-on-year increase, driven by Vivocity and higher office portfolio rents. Distribution per unit grew 8.5% to eight Singapore cents. Analysts at OCBC Investment Research and DBS Group Research maintain "hold" ratings, citing a strong key asset, Vivocity, and resilient office portfolio. Golden Agri-Resources' target price was raised to S$0.53, with analysts at RHB Research maintaining a "buy" call, citing a bottomed cycle and potential for 20% upside.

site_title: A change from her usual offering
summary: Acclaimed indie singer-songwriter Rachael Yamagata will return to Singapore in May for a concert at the Esplanade Concert Hall, showcasing her new album. The album, which explores universal themes of inner challenges and finding peace of mind, marks a departure from her usual romantic relationship-focused music. Yamagata, who has been self-managing her music career for over four years, successfully crowdfunded her album and plans to donate 5% of the funds raised to charity. The concert will feature a full band and is part of her international tour.

site_title: Management reshuffle seen at GuocoLand
summary: GuocoLand, a Singapore-based property developer, is undergoing a management reshuffle following subdued sales of its massive private condominium project, Sims Urban Oasis. Several high-level departures have occurred, including managing director of GuocoLand China, Vito Koh, and executive director PY Wong, who handled projects. At least three employees, including marketing head Sharon Ng, left the company on short notice this week. The moves come amid a wave of resignations last year and amid efforts to boost sales of Sims Urban Oasis, which has sold only 20% of its units.

site_title: As Beijing steps up, it is also jostling for leadership
summary: US pressure on China to assume global responsibilities has finally borne fruit, with Chinese President Xi Jinping embracing the concept of being a "responsible stakeholder" in the international system. In a series of statements, Xi has indicated China's willingness to take on greater responsibilities, but with a twist, warning against countries attempting to dominate regional security affairs and infringing on others' rights. This shift has left little room for the US in Asia, with China now taking on a more prominent role in regional and global affairs.

site_title: HSBC volunteers 'pull' together for charity
summary: HSBC volunteers participated in the "Tarik for Charity" event, raising a total of S$84,000 for two charities. The event involved a relay match of pulled tea, with every 10 milliliters of tea raised supporting a primary school beneficiary. The funds will be donated to the Straits Times School Pocket Money Fund and the Business Times Budding Artists Fund. This event is part of HSBC's corporate responsibility efforts, which include community service and environmental projects. The bank has also donated S$300,000 to six charities and matched the funds, totaling S$600,000.

site_title: A noisily entertaining package
summary: Avengers: Age of Ultron, the latest Marvel blockbuster, is a noisily entertaining package with an impressive array of superheroes and effects-driven action. Writer-director Joss Whedon takes a "more-is-more" approach, loading up on action and action sequences, meeting minimum expectations but potentially surpassing its predecessor in box office numbers. The film features an all-star ensemble, with screen time spread equally among the lead members, and is notable for its sheer scale and ambition, despite not quite matching the impact of the original Avengers.

site_title: A tribute to the vintners we've lost
summary: The wine world has lost several notable vintners, including Thierry Manoncourt of Château Figeac, Laurence Faller of Domaine Weinbach, Baroness Philippine Rothschild of Château Mouton Rothschild, and Anne-Claude Leflaive of Domaine Leflaive. Tributes from fellow vintners and industry figures highlight their dedication to their craft and commitment to excellence, despite commercial and financial pressures. The losses come as a shock to the wine world, with many remembering their passion, charm, and contributions to the industry.

site_title: A-Reit's Q4 DPU up 4.5% at 3.71 S'pore cents
summary: A-Reit posted a 4.7% increase in distributable income for its fiscal fourth quarter, driven by recent acquisitions and improved occupancy rates. Net property income improved by 4.3% to S$117.2 million, resulting in a 4.5% increase in distribution per unit to 3.71 Singapore cents. For the full fiscal year, A-Reit's amount available for distribution increased by 2.7% to S$351.1 million, with a 2.5% increase in full-year distribution per unit to 14.6 Singapore cents.

site_title: Mapletree aims to double AUM: CEO
summary: Mapletree Investments aims to double its assets under management (AUM) to $40-50 billion by 2019, with a focus on sustainable returns. The company, led by CEO Hiew Yoon Khong, is diversifying beyond Asia to the US and Europe, driven by concerns that Asian markets are at a "bubbling stage." Mapletree is leveraging partnerships with companies like Oakwood Worldwide to access new markets and opportunities, with a target of 10-15% average return on invested equity.

site_title: Deutsche Bank fined record US$2.5b to settle Libor fixing probes
summary: Deutsche Bank has been fined a record US$2.5 billion to settle investigations into manipulating the Libor benchmark interest rate. The bank must also fire seven employees, including six in London and one in Frankfurt, for their role in the scandal. The US Department of Financial Services, the US Commodity Futures Trading Commission, and the Justice Department have all fined the bank, with the largest penalty coming from the DFS at US$600 million. The settlement comes as the bank reviews options to boost returns amid ongoing investigations into other dealings.

site_title: Facebook reports big user shift to mobile
summary: Facebook reports strong financial results, with advertising revenue rising 46% to $3.32 billion in the first quarter, driven by a shift to mobile devices. The company's net income fell to $512 million, but its profit was up 28% from last year. Facebook's focus on quality over quantity has led to a 285% increase in average ad price, despite a 62% decline in ad views. The company's co-founder and CEO Mark Zuckerberg emphasized the importance of quality over quantity, saying "The primary goal is to increase the quality. That's our strategy for growing the business."

site_title: S$18m hongbaos for DBS staff are from managers' bonus pool
summary: DBS Group Holdings awarded S$18 million in hongbaos to 18,000 employees, totaling S$1,000 each, from its senior managers' bonus pool. The gesture, announced to celebrate SG50 and reaching S$50 billion in market capitalization, was met with mixed reactions from the public. The bonus did not increase the bank's costs, according to Chairman Peter Seah, and was seen as a way to boost employee morale and "bonding".

site_title: The lost art of turn-of-the-century travel
summary: A new coffee table book, "The Romance Of The Grand Tour: 100 Years of Travel in South East Asia," explores luxury travel in South-east Asia in the early 1900s. Written by Kennie Ting, the book features 12 cities, including Rangoon, Georgetown, and Bangkok, with images and archival materials showcasing colonial hotels, vintage transportation, and daily life in these thriving cities. Ting, a sociologist and cultural heritage professional, highlights the joint heritage of these cities, which were connected through trade and travel, and how their colonial architecture and infrastructure still exist today.

site_title: Broad market weakens despite STI gain
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 6.51 points to 3,502.75, despite a broad market with 195 gains and 277 falls. Interest in penny stocks continued to wane, with unit turnover falling from 3.4 billion to 1.6 billion. Noble Group's counter shed S$0.02 to S$0.86, while Singtel rose S$0.02 to S$4.35. Analysts maintained neutral to hold ratings on several stocks, citing concerns over the offshore marine sector and Greece's mounting problems.

site_title: Messy politics trumps economics at KL investors' conference
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Najib Razak's keynote speech at the Invest Malaysia 2015 conference was overshadowed by the country's ongoing political turmoil. Najib addressed the audience's interest in the political situation, stating he wasn't feeling lonely in speaking the truth, and expressed confidence in the stability and growth of the country under his government. However, critics point to allegations of mismanagement and breach of trust involving the 1MDB development company, and the government's handling of the economy, which is projected to grow 4.5-5.5% despite crumbling oil prices and a new consumption tax.

site_title: Nokia targets major tech firms in sale of maps unit: sources
summary: Nokia is selling its HERE maps unit, a money-losing business, to major tech firms like Apple, Alibaba, and Amazon for over $4.3 billion. The company aims to focus on mobile-network equipment and services. The mapping assets, which Nokia bought for $8.1 billion in 2008, are now worth around $2 billion. Several companies, including Google, Sirius, and private equity firms, are interested in acquiring the unit to improve their navigational software.

site_title: Relax, airlines are turning to mood lighting on planes
summary: Airlines are incorporating mood lighting on planes, utilizing new LED technologies to create various ambiance settings. This feature allows designers to adjust cabin lighting to suit different stages of flight, such as energizing or relaxing passengers. Airlines like Virgin Atlantic and Finnair are experimenting with different colors and gradual light transitions to minimize jet lag. The LED lights are expected to last 10-20 times longer than traditional lights, offering a new level of customization for in-flight experiences.

site_title: Asean's business community cautiously optimistic about AEC
summary: Asean's business community is cautiously optimistic about the Asean Economic Community (AEC) despite challenges ahead, with few expecting significant changes before the end of the decade. Executives in six Asean countries, including Indonesia, Malaysia, Singapore, Thailand, the Philippines, and Vietnam, view intra-Asean trade as a difficult process, but see the AEC as a step in the right direction. CEOs are more optimistic than staff, predicting growth for their offices in 2015, but concerns about talent shortages, cheap oil, and the rise of the US dollar remain. The AEC is expected to benefit larger, pan-Asean companies, while smaller domestic companies are less likely to benefit.

site_title: City Buzz
summary: No relevant articles were found in the provided content.

site_title: As drillers hunker down, Wall St sees oil bounce
summary: Oil industry CEOs predict oil prices will remain depressed for at least five years, with some expecting prices to stay below $60 a barrel. This outlook contradicts the financial community's expectation of a quicker recovery, with investors buying energy equities and planning private equity acquisitions. The disconnect between industry executives and investors has significant implications for future oil prices, as the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries has abandoned efforts to manage the market with output cuts, leaving energy companies to reduce drilling and curb supply.

site_title: More foreign workers axed last year than in 2013
summary: In 2014, Singapore saw a 40% increase in foreign worker layoffs, with 5,690 workers let go, surpassing the 4,050 in 2013. Meanwhile, resident workers, including Singaporeans and Permanent Residents, saw a 2% decline in layoffs, from 7,520 in 2013 to 7,240. Business restructuring and productivity drives accounted for nearly 60% of total redundancies, with professionals and managers, or PMETs, making up more than half of those laid off. Most laid-off PMETs quickly found new jobs, with 68% re-entering employment within 12 months.

site_title: NZ$ sinks on central banker's comments
summary: The New Zealand dollar (NZ$) fell 1.5% to US$0.7552 after Reserve Bank of New Zealand assistant governor John McDermott suggested that lower interest rates might be warranted due to weakening demand and lower price risks. This move follows a slowdown in China and weakening global demand for New Zealand's commodities. The kiwi's decline also follows a similar slide in the Australian dollar.

site_title: Sheng Siong posts 12% rise in Q1 net profit
summary: Sheng Siong Group, a Singaporean supermarket operator, reported a 12.2% increase in net profit to S$14.06 million for Q1 2015, driven by higher revenue and improved gross margin. Revenue rose 4.8% to S$198.4 million, with comparable same-store sales growth contributing to the increase. The company attributed the improvement to a reduction in input costs and expects the industry to remain competitive despite upward pressure on manpower costs. Two new stores are set to open in May 2015, expanding the group's retail area by 2%.

site_title: China-Pakistan corridor could be a game changer if conditions are met
summary: China has pledged to invest $46 billion in Pakistan's infrastructure projects through the China-Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC), a mega-project envisioned to link northwest China to south Pakistan. The project could bring substantial benefits to both countries, including easier access to ports, infrastructure development, and economic growth. However, it faces challenges such as security concerns, corruption, and regional disparities. For the project to be successful, Pakistan's government must address these challenges and gain buy-in from provincial governments.

site_title: Higher commercial rents boost Mapletree Greater China trust
summary: Mapletree Greater China Commercial Trust (MGCCT) reported a 9.8% increase in available distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.742 cents in the fourth quarter, driven by a 19.6% jump in net property income to S$62.3 million. The trust's Festival Walk mall saw retail sales grow despite Hong Kong's retail market weakness, while its Gateway Plaza office building in Beijing benefited from a 30% increase in rental. The trust's portfolio value rose to S$5.3 billion, with DPU up 10.4% for the full year to 6.543 cents.

site_title: American Apparel sued over CEO ouster
summary: American Apparel Inc sued its former CEO Dov Charney over his ouster, with shareholders claiming CEO John Luttrell orchestrated the firing to set the stage for a sale. The shareholders, who have ties to Charney, allege Luttrell approached Charney about selling the company but refused, leading to Charney's firing. American Apparel denies the claims, calling them "completely baseless". Charney has tried to return to the company but was unsuccessful.

site_title: Showcasing Singapore's design talents
summary: A pop-up shop called Born & Raised has opened at Tangs department store in Singapore, featuring over 25 local talents and showcasing a range of products including fashion, art, home goods, and accessories. The shop, which runs until August 31, aims to promote local designers and artists, with items exclusive to the store. Founded by Watson Lee, the shop is part of a larger initiative to support local creatives and promote sustainability. Established and lesser-known designers are featured, with some items available only at the shop.

site_title: Higher prices help put fizz back into Coca-Cola
summary: Coca-Cola Co, the world's largest beverage company, reported its first quarterly sales gain in two years, driven by higher drink prices that offset sluggish demand. The company posted a 48-cent-per-share profit, exceeding analyst estimates of 42 cents. This marks a significant turnaround for the company, which had previously experienced declining sales. The sales increase is attributed to higher prices, which helped boost profits.

site_title: Fears rise over hidden debt of China developers
summary: China's property developers are increasingly using joint ventures to hide debt, raising concerns among investors and credit rating agencies. The practice allows developers to keep off-balance sheet debt details unless they hold a controlling interest, making it difficult to assess credit risk. Notable examples include Kaisa Group, whose debt more than doubled to $10.4 billion in six months, and Cheung Kong Property Holdings Ltd, which reported $16.8 billion in adjusted borrowings. This lack of transparency is exacerbating China's slowing economic growth and prompting investors to reevaluate their exposure to the sector.

site_title: Swiss left helpless in currency wars as franc keeps surging
summary: Switzerland's currency, the franc, continues to surge despite efforts by the Swiss National Bank (SNB) to control its value. The franc has gained the most among its G-10 peers this year, driven by the European Central Bank's stimulus program. Consumer prices are falling, and Swiss stocks are lagging behind European counterparts. The SNB has intervened in currency markets, cut interest rates, and implemented negative rates, but the franc's value remains strong. Experts expect the franc to reach parity with the euro later this year, and the SNB may refrain from cutting rates too much due to concerns about the financial-services industry.

site_title: SGX aims to double market cap of firms in 3-5 years
summary: SGX aims to double the market value of its listed companies over the next 3-5 years through increased listings from China, India, and other locations. The bourse, seeking to compete with Asian peers, has already seen a significant increase in market value, with 287 overseas companies valued at $587 billion as of 2023. To achieve this goal, SGX is relaxing IPO rules, allowing mainland companies to list without incorporating overseas, and courting mining and energy companies. The bourse's president, Muthukrishnan Ramaswami, believes closer ties with China and increased listings will drive growth.

site_title: Rolls-Royce appoints acclaimed technology executive as CEO
summary: Rolls-Royce appoints Warren East as its new CEO, replacing John Rishton, who will retire in July. East, former head of ARM Holdings, aims to restore the company's fortunes after a year of declining profit and job cuts. The move follows a significant overhaul of the company's strategy. East's appointment is seen as a key step in reviving Rolls-Royce's business.

images.alt_text: Mr East takes over in the midst of a restructuring programme, with 2,600 jobs being cut from a global total of about 55,000 at the firm.

site_title: China's April PMI declines amid deflation worries
summary: China's factory activity contracted at its fastest pace in a year in April, with the HSBC/Markit Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) falling to 49.2. The decline in employment moderated, while export orders rose for the first time in three months. New orders declined to a one-year low, and input and output prices accelerated, signaling intensifying deflationary pressures. The weak PMI adds to signs that China's economy is decelerating rapidly, with economists expecting growth to cool further to 7% in 2015.

site_title: Euro-region output growth slows awaiting QE effect
summary: Euro-area manufacturing and services growth slowed in April to 53.5, below the 54 forecast by economists, as the European Central Bank's bond purchases take time to revive a fragile recovery. The Purchasing Managers Index (PMI) fell from 54 in March, indicating a slowdown in expansion. Despite the decline, the reading remains above the 50-point mark, suggesting the economy is still expanding, but at a slower pace.

images.alt_text: Euro-area services activity dropped to 53.7 from 54.2 in March, while a similar index for the manufacturing industry fell to 51.9 from 52.2, London-based Markit Economics said on Thursday.

site_title: ANZ revives talks to sell 39% stake in Panin: sources
summary: ANZ Banking Group Ltd has resumed talks to sell its 39% stake in PT Bank Pan Indonesia after discussions stalled for over a year. The sale may attract interest from Japan's Mizuho Financial Group Inc and other bidders. The Gunawan family, which controls Jakarta-based Bank Panin, may be more receptive to another investor buying the holding. ANZ is seeking to sell the stake due to regulations requiring banks to subtract the value of overseas minority investments from Tier-1 capital.

site_title: Taking a less obvious route - and a few risks
summary: Writer-director Dan Fogelman's "Danny Collins" is a dramedy about a fading rock star who discovers a letter from John Lennon that he never received, inspiring him to reevaluate his life and career. The film stars Al Pacino as the aging star, who must confront his past and reconnect with his music and himself. While uneven, the movie takes a few risks and offers some bittersweet moments, making it a somewhat entertaining and memorable cinematic distraction.

site_title: Industrial space prices, rentals in Q1 edge up despite bigger supply
summary: Industrial space prices and rentals in Singapore edged up 0.7% and 0.4% respectively in Q1 2015, despite a 0.2% dip in occupancy rates. Year-on-year, prices rose 0.5% and rents fell 2.0%. The increase is attributed to a traditional lull period due to Chinese New Year festivities and the lingering effect of the Total Debt Servicing Ratio (TDSR) requirement. However, a significant supply surge is expected to exert downward pressure on occupancy rates, with prices and rents likely to ease in the coming years.

site_title: OCBC sees Myanmar as catalyst for growth
summary: OCBC, a Singaporean bank, has opened its first branch in Myanmar, aiming to double its revenue from the regional business of its SME and mid-cap clients within three years. The bank expects significant reforms in the domestic financial sector to spur growth, with foreign banks expected to collaborate on reforms and eventually work with domestic businesses. OCBC's expansion into Myanmar is seen as a catalyst for growth in the region, particularly for Asean, and the bank will offer services such as cash management, trade finance, and working capital financing to foreign companies and joint ventures.

site_title: Going places
summary: Singaporean arts professionals who were trained or cut their teeth in Singapore are making their mark abroad in various positions of responsibility in the global arts industry. Notable examples include Meiyin Wang, director of the Public Theater's Devised Theatre Initiative and co-director of the Under the Radar Festival, and Khairuddin Hori, deputy director of Palais de Tokyo in France. Others, such as Low Kee Hong and Qinyi Lim, have secured roles in Hong Kong and London. The growth of the arts industry in Singapore has led to increased opportunities for Singaporean artists and administrators to work abroad, with international institutions recognizing their expertise and experience.

site_title: Accelerator that looks out for edutech startups launched
summary: The Lithan EdTech Accelerator, launched in Singapore, aims to turn traditional educators into "edu-preneurs" by developing technology-driven products and tools to enhance learning and pedagogy. Backed by Lithan Hall Academy and Red Dot Ventures, the accelerator offers two phases: a six-week bootcamp for 30 startups and a 100-day programme for 10 selected startups. The initiative seeks to capitalize on Singapore's ripe conditions for edtech adoption, citing rising mobile penetration, a mobile-first approach, and increasing per capita expenditure on education.

images.alt_text: Singapore startups in education technology (edtech) now have an accelerator to offer them advice and resources to help them on their way.

site_title: 1MDB funds disappeared, Mahathir says, demands PM resign
summary: Malaysian former Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad has launched a scathing attack on current Prime Minister Najib Razak, demanding he account for the disappearance of billions of dollars borrowed by state fund 1MDB or resign. Mahathir claims nearly RM42 billion of 1MDB's funds are unaccounted for, and he argues that governments can lose money through bad investments, but being unable to account for large sums is different. Najib has ordered an audit of 1MDB's accounts, but Mahathir's comments have weakened the prime minister's position within the ruling coalition.

site_title: Suntec Reit's Q1 DPU steady at 2.23 Singapore cents
summary: Suntec Reit reported steady Q1 distributable income (DPU) of 2.23 Singapore cents, a 10.1% increase from the year-ago period. Gross revenue rose 12.9% to S$74.5 million, and net property income increased 17.3% to S$51.4 million, driven by the completion of Suntec City Phase 2. The office portfolio achieved 99.6% committed occupancy, and the retail portfolio reached 93.5% occupancy. The company's debt-to-asset ratio was 34.8% as of March 2015.

site_title: Singapore Wrap Thursday
summary: OCBC has opened its first branch in Myanmar and expects to double its revenue from its SME and mid-cap clients within three years. DBS Chairman Peter Seah revealed that the S$18 million hongbao given to employees came from senior managers' bonus pool. The Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore (MPA) has invested S$2.42 billion in the first phase of the Tuas Terminal. Despite a quiet session, the Straits Times Index (STI) rose 6.51 points, but the overall market was weak, recording 195 rises versus 277 falls.

site_title: German banks lead in foreign loans to Greeks: BIS data
summary: German banks lead in foreign loans to Greeks, with $13.3 billion, followed by US and British lenders, and Dutch, French, and Italian banks. Most foreign banks cut their exposure to Greece after 2012 debt restructuring. Athens is struggling to secure bailout funds, and if it fails, foreign banks could lose money, potentially leading to capital controls or a eurozone exit.

site_title: FCOT's Q2 distributable income up 17%
summary: Frasers Commercial Trust (FCOT) reported a 17% increase in distribution income for its fiscal second quarter, driven by higher net property income from Singapore business parks. Net property income rose 14% to S$24.7 million, largely due to higher occupancy rates and rental rates. The company expects vacancy rates for business parks to fall due to limited new speculative supply in 2015. However, an Australian office tower's lower occupancy rate and weakening Australian dollar reduced the increase. FCOT's units closed unchanged at S$1.545.

site_title: Petrobras posts biggest-ever loss
summary: Brazil's state-run oil company Petrobras reported its largest-ever loss of 21.6 billion reais due to a 50.8-billion-real write-down related to a massive corruption scandal. The company's new CEO, Aldemir Bendine, promised a return to normality and transparency. Petrobras has downgraded its financial situation, cutting investment in offshore oil discoveries and facing debt downgrades by major ratings agencies. The scandal has affected dozens of construction and engineering firms, bankrupting at least five and throwing thousands out of work.

site_title: Changi offers partners cost savings in drive to grow hub
summary: Changi Airport has announced cost-saving initiatives to encourage airlines to use the airport as a hub, aiming to save S$180 million over two years.
