However, hotels using Booking.com's service will still be barred from charging cheaper prices on their own website, except for customers with loyalty cards. The changes, known as "parity clauses," take effect on July 1.

site_title: Abe meets Xi, says ties have improved
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe met Chinese President Xi Jinping for the second time in less than six months, marking an improvement in ties despite Japan's past aggression. The 29-minute meeting came after Abe's speech in Jakarta, which barely mentioned remorse over World War II, and a day after sending an offering to a Tokyo war shrine seen as a symbol of militarism. Ties have improved since their last meeting in November, with trade and tourism increasing, and both sides agreeing to maintain high-level dialogue to prevent the situation from worsening.

site_title: Scorpio East building on Tai Seng Avenue put up for sale
summary: A seven-storey industrial building, Scorpio East, on Tai Seng Avenue in Singapore, has been put up for sale by expression of interest with an indicative price of S$30 million. The building, situated on a 27,000 square feet site with a 51-year lease, offers approximately 68,000 square feet of total gross floor area.

images.alt_text: Scorpio East, currently used for media production and office operations, has a 38-seat theatre, exhibition area and a production studio.

site_title: Big Mac test exposes drawbacks of the job market in distributing wealth
summary: The job market's inability to distribute wealth effectively has been exposed by a 15-year study on McDonald's wages. Real wages measured by Big Mac prices declined worldwide, including in the US, between 2000 and 2007, during a period of steady economic growth. This suggests that capitalism's primary institution for wealth distribution is not working properly, raising questions about the role of public assistance. Experts argue that the job market's decline is due to factors such as globalization, technological advancements, and stagnant education levels, requiring new mechanisms to distribute income.

site_title: The smell of trouble in US perfume industry
summary: The US perfume industry has seen a decline in sales, with mass fragrances dropping by half since 2000 to approximately $600 million in 2014. In contrast, premium fragrances have seen a 16% increase in sales to a record-high $5.2 billion. The industry's decline is attributed to the rise of scented products in everyday items, making fragrances seem less special and commoditized. Companies like Verizon and United Airlines are trademarking unique fragrances to differentiate themselves, while Coty has shifted focus to prestige and celebrity fragrances to counter declining mass fragrance sales.

images.alt_text: While sales of premium fragrances in the US hit a record US$5.2 billion last year, sales of mass fragrances, or non-designer scents, have dropped by half since 2000 to about US$600 million last year.

site_title: Creative's Q3 loss widens
summary: Creative Technology reported a net loss of US$11.7 million for Q3 2015, widening by more than a third from S$8.8 million a year ago. Revenue slumped 9% year-over-year to US$22.7 million due to uncertain market conditions. Despite lower sales, selling expenses remained steady, while gross margin improved to 29%. The group expects no significant change in challenging market conditions and reports an operating loss. Loss per share worsened to US$0.17, and net asset value per share decreased to US$1.50.

site_title: Car-pooling startup seeks profits from life in Japan's slow traffic lanes
summary: Notteco, a car-pooling startup in Japan, aims to reduce traffic jams by matching drivers with long-distance travelers. Founder Kohei Miwa, a former banker, plans to raise 100 million yen initially from individuals and later approach companies for more funding. The platform targets 30,000 users in a year and 100,000 after two years, with plans to charge a handling fee when it reaches 50,000 members. Notteco estimates the car-pooling market in Japan to be worth 12 billion yen, with potential to double or triple.

site_title: SGX looks again to draw from China well
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) is increasing its focus on China as a key source of growth, expanding its team in Beijing and Shanghai. The exchange reported a 16.4% increase in Q3 profit to S$88.2 million, driven by growth in its derivatives market. Revenue rose 20.4% to S$199.3 million. SGX aims to tap China's growing market, including through listings, capital raising, and derivatives trading, with former head of listings Lawrence Wong leading its China business.

site_title: Foodbank use reaches one million as UK parties spar over poverty
summary: The UK's foodbank usage has reached a record 1 million people over the past 12 months, according to The Trussell Trust. This marks a 10-year high and a 10% increase from the previous year. Labour leader Ed Miliband has criticized the Conservative-led coalition, saying their policies have led to a decline in living standards. Prime Minister David Cameron has defended his government's decision to allow job centres to advertise foodbanks, citing a 3% referral rate from job centres.

site_title: Big China shift from luxury to consumer goods
summary: China's consumer market is shifting from luxury goods to mainstream items, with demand for authentic American products growing online. Chinese shoppers are looking for reliability and brand authenticity in everyday goods, driving sales of US brands on digital marketplaces owned by Alibaba Group and JD.com. Cross-border purchases by Chinese web shoppers grew from $2 billion in 2010 to $20 billion in 2014, and are expected to double in size in five years. US retailers are capitalizing on this trend, with thousands of American brands appearing on digital marketplaces and Alibaba's Alipay payment service being used on US websites.

site_title: BHP Billiton delays output boost as iron ore prices fall
summary: BHP Billiton, the world's third-largest iron ore miner, has delayed plans to boost its iron ore output to 290 million tonnes a year due to a 60% drop in prices over the past year. The company cited a plunge in iron ore prices as the reason for the delay, which affects around 20 million tonnes of iron ore. Analysts say the delay is a symbolic posturing position, but it also signals the bottom of the iron ore market. BHP had expected to reach the production target by June 2017, but has revised its 2015 full-year production guidance to 250 million tonnes.

site_title: Rents of single-family homes in US to rise 5.7% this year
summary: US single-family home landlords plan to raise rents by 5.7% this year, shifting focus from buying properties to boosting profits. The move comes after corporate landlords built a new real estate asset class on the rubble of the housing crash. Large buyers have amassed 528,000 single-family rental homes since 2011, with a focus now on optimizing revenue. CEOs of several public landlords, including American Homes 4 Rent, plan to raise rents in markets such as Phoenix, where rental vacancy rates have dropped.

site_title: Existing home sales hit 18-month high
summary: Existing home sales in the US reached an 18-month high in March, with 5.19 million annualized sales, a 6.1% increase from the previous month. Job growth, cheap borrowing costs, and better weather are driving the surge, with prices rising 7.8% from March 2014. The median home price reached $212,100, and inventory of unsold homes increased 5.3% to 2 million. The housing market is recovering, but concerns remain about rising prices and limited supply.

site_title: A stately house full of history and tragedy
summary: A stately house, Tekigaiso, once home to Japan's pre-war prime minister Fumimaro Konoe, is set to be opened to the public during special events. Built in 1927, the one-storey wooden mansion was purchased by Konoe in 1937 and played a significant role in Japan's lead-up to World War II, hosting important cabinet meetings and negotiations. The property has undergone significant changes since the war, with the garden sold off and the house altered to a more Western style. The "lord's room," where Konoe took his own life in 1945, will be opened to the public, offering a glimpse into Japan's turbulent past.

site_title: Globalisation has brought Asia, Africa closer
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong emphasized the growing connection between Asia and Africa at the Asia-Africa Summit in Jakarta. He noted that globalization has brought the two regions closer together, with Asian countries recognizing Africa's vibrant development centers. Despite this, Lee stressed that Singapore still doesn't know enough about Africa and urged greater cooperation between the two regions. The summit aims to strengthen South-South cooperation to promote world peace and prosperity, tackling common challenges such as terrorism and climate change.

site_title: Flawless 100-carat diamond sells for US$22.1m
summary: A flawless 100-carat, D colour emerald-cut diamond was sold for US$22.1 million at a Sotheby's auction in New York. The diamond, mined by De Beers in southern Africa, was purchased by an anonymous buyer via a telephone bid, exceeding its pre-sale estimate of US$19 million to US$25 million. The sale marked a significant achievement for the auction house and highlighted the allure of rare and high-quality diamonds.

site_title: Luxe HK home prices still rising
summary: Hong Kong's luxury home market continues to rise, with sales of homes worth more than HK$12 million jumping in the first quarter to their highest since 2012. The market surge is driven by mainland China investors seeking quick profits, despite the city's efforts to curb speculative demand. Analysts expect luxury home sales to reach a record HK$240 billion this year, fueled by a new supply of luxury units and the city's booming stock market. This trend may stoke discontent among those priced out of the market, prompting calls for new measures to control prices.

site_title: Google probe in EU props up stocks of Russian competitor
summary: A European Union antitrust probe into Google has boosted Russian search engine Yandex's stocks, despite the company still facing significant challenges. Yandex's market capitalization rose to $6.54 billion after the probe, driven by hopes that it could win more screen space and advertising revenue. The company's earnings are expected to fall 29.6% in the first quarter, but revenue is seen up 11.9%. A deal with Mozilla to make Yandex the default search engine in Turkey may also boost growth prospects.

site_title: Latin America uses commodities crisis to reshape economy
summary: Latin America is using the commodities crisis as an opportunity to reshape its economy. The region's finance ministers, such as Colombia's Mauricio Cardenas and Peru's Alonso Segura Vasi, believe that the crisis will lead to diversification and growth. Key strategies include allowing exchange rate flexibility, investing in infrastructure, and human capital. The World Bank and IMF note that some countries, like Brazil, are taking proactive steps to address the crisis, while others, such as Argentina, are struggling with inflation and negative growth. Overall, the crisis presents a chance for Latin America to adopt new policies and build for the future.

site_title: Yahoo Q1 revenue misses analysts' forecasts
summary: Yahoo's first-quarter revenue fell 4% to $1.04 billion, missing analyst estimates, as sales from new channels, partners, and content deals failed to attract users and advertisers. The decline is attributed to the company's struggles to compete with younger rivals like Google, Facebook, and Twitter. Despite a 58% increase in revenue from emerging businesses, including mobile and video ads, the company's overall sales declined, and profit before costs was 15 cents a share. Yahoo's CEO, Marissa Mayer, has been focusing on the mobile business and exclusive content deals, but the company's growth remains stagnant.

images.alt_text: Yahoo said revenue from its emerging businesses which include mobile, video ads, native ads and its Tumblr blogging platform - expanded in the quarter.

site_title: 124-year-old cooking club that's still going strong
summary: The Thursday Afternoon Cooking Club in Wichita, Kansas, has been continuously operating for 124 years, making it the oldest continuously operating club devoted to cooking and domestic science. Founded in 1891, the club's members have shared recipes and cooking ideas, reflecting middle-class American culinary trends. Despite the rise of modern cooking methods, the club has maintained its traditional approach, with members following strict rules and prioritizing gracious entertaining and culinary exploration. The club's history and traditions have been preserved, with older women becoming honorary members and a meat-and-cheese tray delivered to the family of a deceased member.

site_title: Crude prices won't dip below US$50, says world's top trader
summary: Vitol Group, the world's largest independent oil trader, expects crude prices to remain above US$50 a barrel for sustained periods, as producers need this level to invest in new supplies. CEO Ian Taylor stated that prices will trade from US$50 to US$70 a barrel in the second half of this year, driven by slowing US production growth and strong demand. This prediction contradicts the collapse in oil prices last year, as OPEC maintained its output, and follows Taylor's previous prediction of a price rise by the end of the year.

site_title: Enhanced connectivity trials in Jurong Lake District to be launched in Q3
summary: Singapore to launch HetNet trials in Jurong Lake District in Q3, a heterogeneous network trial aimed at providing seamless connectivity to the internet. The trials, part of the Smart Nation initiative, will be carried out by Singtel, StarHub, M1, and MyRepublic, and are expected to bring immediate and long-term benefits to citizens, including better mobile and wireless connectivity in congested areas. The trials will also facilitate the development of solutions to meet industry challenges, such as increasing data demands.

site_title: Blue chips, penny stocks ease amid low volume
summary: The Straits Times Index fell 12.37 points to 3,496.24 on Wednesday, dragged down by expectations of weakness on Wall Street and European markets. Retail brokers reported a sudden loss of upward momentum in Hong Kong and Wall Street, leading to decreased interest among clients. The penny segment also showed signs of fatigue, with business done amounting to 1.8 billion units worth S$1.2 billion. Key stocks fell, including Keppel, Singtel, and Jardine Strategic.

site_title: Greek cash can last into June; no deal with EU imminent
summary: Greece can meet its payment obligations until June, eurozone officials and Greek officials said, playing down fears of an imminent default. The country's economy has shrunk by 25% and unemployment has soared, but it has received two international bailouts worth $347 billion since 2010. Greece will not present a new list of economic reforms required to unlock further EU funds, but aims to have a 2.5 billion euro cash buffer by the end of May. Eurozone officials say progress in negotiations with Athens is slow, but a deal is possible, with Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras set to meet German Chancellor Angela Merkel in Brussels.

site_title: HK skyscrapers ask world's highest office rents
summary: Hong Kong's skyscrapers have the highest office rents globally, with costs reaching $251 per square foot, 66% more than in New York, where rents rose 20% to $150 per square foot. The number of skyscrapers over 1,000 feet high has increased to 79 worldwide, with 40% in China. Companies are willing to pay premium rents to retain staff, while investors seek to buy properties for $1 billion or more. Despite this, other international cities like New York and London are eroding Hong Kong's lead in skyscraper rents.

site_title: Japan posts trade surplus after 3 years of deficits
summary: Japan logged a trade surplus in March for the first time in nearly three years, with exports rising 8.5% and imports falling 14.5%. The surplus of 229 billion yen was the first since June 2012, driven by increased exports to the US and moderate growth in Europe. Analysts say the data suggests Japan's economy is steadily recovering and may turn a corner, with the Nikkei 225 stock index reaching a 15-year high.

images.alt_text: The trade balance in March was a 229 billion yen surplus, the first such surplus since June 2012, reflecting an increase in exports amid a global economic recovery, particularly in the US.

site_title: A study in enterprise risk management
summary: Lee Kuan Yew's governance of Singapore was compared to effective enterprise risk management (ERM) due to his emphasis on delivering results and managing uncertainty. ERM involves identifying, assessing, responding to, controlling, and monitoring risks to create value. Singapore's 1995 ERM framework, developed by an Australian-New Zealand joint effort, was influenced by concepts and techniques discussed in Lee's book "From Third World to First." The leadership team applied ERM principles, including event identification, risk assessment, and monitoring, to achieve strategic goals and operational objectives.

site_title: JPMorgan boosts yuan's weight, lowers US#x27;s in currency indexes
summary: JPMorgan Chase & Co. has increased the yuan's weighting in its foreign-exchange indexes, reflecting China's growing share in global trade. This is the first time in 15 years the yuan has seen a boost, as the US dollar's weight has decreased. China's share in global trade has tripled over the last decade, and the yuan is being made more suitable for international trade and finance. Despite progress, the yuan remains excluded from the International Monetary Fund's reserves and faces challenges in the US market, where only 10% of US firms use the currency.

site_title: Indonesia wants foreign investments to develop infrastructure: PM Lee
summary: Indonesian Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong met with President Joko Widodo, discussing the country's need for foreign investments in infrastructure development. Indonesia aims to attract more foreign investors, including those from Singapore, to build critical infrastructure such as ports, roads, and telecommunications.

site_title: Boeing profit soars, confirms 2015 forecasts
summary: Boeing reported a 38% increase in first-quarter net profit to $1.34 billion, surpassing Wall Street's expectations. The company reaffirmed its 2015 forecasts, with revenue and adjusted earnings per share expected to be between $94.5-96.5 billion and $8.20-8.40, respectively. Boeing's Commercial Airplanes segment saw revenue rise 21% to $15.4 billion, driven by 14% increase in deliveries to 184 jetliners. The company also raised dividends by 25% and plans to repurchase $9.5 billion shares over the next two to three years.

site_title: Aussie inflation benign in Q1, no bar to rate cut
summary: Australian consumer prices rose 0.2% in Q1, the slowest pace in almost three years, due to a sharp decline in petrol prices. However, rising education and healthcare expenses kept core inflation slightly above forecasts at 2.3%. Despite this, the Reserve Bank of Australia may consider cutting interest rates due to low inflation and economic slack, with a 45% chance of a rate cut in May.

site_title: Speed trader arrested in UK over role in 2010 US 'flash crash'
summary: A 36-year-old UK trader, Navinder Singh Sarao, has been arrested and charged with wire fraud, commodities fraud, and manipulation over his alleged role in the 2010 US "flash crash," which wiped out nearly $1 trillion in market capitalization. Sarao used automated programs to generate large sell orders, causing prices to drop, and then bought the contracts at the lower prices to benefit from the market's recovery. The US Department of Justice and the Commodity Futures Trading Commission have filed charges against him, citing his manipulation as a contributing factor to the flash crash.

site_title: CCT to start reaping distributable income from CapitaGreen only next year
summary: CapitaCommercial Trust (CCT) is set to start generating distributable income from its 40% owned CapitaGreen office development next year, despite the property being 76.4% leased. The trust posted a 3.9% increase in first-quarter distributable income (DPU) to 2.12 Singapore cents, driven by positive rent reversions and higher occupancies at its fully-owned properties. CCT targets full occupancy at CapitaGreen by the end of the year, with committed tenants from the insurance, banking, and financial services sectors.

site_title: Smog-hit China aims for environmental stimulus
summary: China aims to stimulate its economy through targeted environmental financing initiatives in smog-hit Hebei province. After Premier Li Keqiang's support, 18 banks agreed to lend over $135 billion for technological renovation and industrial transformation. The move aims to boost growth in industries like emissions controls and water treatment, while also improving the environment. The decision comes as China's economy slows and heavily leveraged banks restrict lending to polluting industries, with economic growth in Hebei slipping to 6.5% last year, one of the lowest rates in the country.

site_title: Blackstone CEO sees 'excess' in Chinese stock market
summary: Blackstone CEO Steve Schwarzman warns of "excess" in the Chinese stock market due to retail investors borrowing heavily to invest, despite slowing economic growth. The Shanghai Composite Index reached a seven-year high, with Schwarzman citing a lack of returns from bank deposits and real estate investments. He sees opportunities in technology-driven industries and shopping centers benefiting from China's growing middle class. The Chinese government is likely to take steps to prevent the market from overheating, with gradual currency convertibility expected.

site_title: Europe: Shares are little changed while Greek lenders rebound
summary: European stocks halted a two-day gain as disappointing earnings releases from Kering SA and Tesco Plc weighed on the market. Greece's benchmark ASE Index rose 2.1% after Greek lenders rebounded from a record low, with banks gaining 13% after gaining more emergency funding. The Stoxx Europe 600 Index slipped less than 0.1% to 408.97, falling short of its record high. Analysts say more good news is needed to boost earnings momentum.

site_title: Coffee spill led to plunge of Serbian president's plane: report
summary: Serbian President Tomislav Nikolic's plane nearly plunged into the Adriatic Sea after a co-pilot accidentally activated an emergency switch due to spilling coffee in the cockpit. The incident occurred at 33,000 feet, causing a brief shutdown of the third engine and a 1-minute drop in altitude. The plane's captain regained control, and it returned to Belgrade. The co-pilot was suspended for endangering flight safety, and the aircraft will undergo further checks. The incident led to the president postponing his meeting with Pope Francis and prompted consideration of switching to commercial flights.

site_title: Ascendas China Business Parks Fund 4 launched
summary: Ascendas China Business Parks Fund 4 (ACBPF 4) was launched with a final closing of S$333 million to invest in premium business park assets in Shanghai, Suzhou, and Xi'an. The portfolio includes completed properties and one development project in these cities, driven by China's growing e-commerce, R&D, and IT industries. Ascendas holds a 23% stake in the fund, with other co-investors including bpfBouw Asia, ImmoFinRE Group, and Singapore Press Holdings. This is the latest addition to Ascendas' ACBPF series, which aims to provide exposure to China's fast-growing business space segment.

site_title: India seeks to calm investor jitters, stands firm on back taxes
summary: India's finance ministry officials sought to calm investor jitters over tax demands, promising a favorable environment for foreign investors. The government has faced uncertainty over its plans to claim retrospective payments, which could increase overall tax on gains to 20%. Finance Minister Arun Jaitley exempted foreign investors from the Minimum Alternative Tax (MAT) on past gains, but left room for US$6 billion in tax demands. Officials assured investors that they would back a stable tax policy and address tax disputes, but some investors remain uncertain due to the government's handling of the issue.

site_title: Germanwings crash inquiry will re-stage doomed jet's flightpath
summary: Germanwings investigators will re-stage the doomed jet's flightpath to help understand the March 24 crash in the French Alps, which killed all 150 people on board. The re-enactment, led by Deutsche Lufthansa AG, will provide further insight into the tragedy. Data from flight recorders and a computer at co-pilot Andreas Lubitz's home support the theory that he deliberately crashed the plane after researching suicide methods and cockpit-door mechanics. The re-staging will help investigators better understand the events leading up to the crash and shed light on remaining open questions.

site_title: Latest earnings
summary: US President Trump announced a 50% copper import tariff, covering refined metal. This follows recent tariffs on Canada and other metals. Global markets reacted, with oil prices rising 2% amid concerns over market outlook and trade tensions. The US stock market edged down from record highs, with investors weighing Trump's tariff threats. In other news, NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times, while Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss. London's Heathrow airport plans to increase fees for a £10 billion upgrade.

site_title: VW eyes budget car cooperation with Great Wall: Manager Magazin
summary: Volkswagen is considering a budget car cooperation with China's Great Wall, according to Manager Magazin. Volkswagen's China chief, Jochem Heizmann, mentioned developing budget SUVs and MPVs to keep up with market shifts. One possible option discussed is Volkswagen taking a stake in Great Wall. Analyst Max Warburton stated that Volkswagen struggles to produce low-cost cars, unlike Great Wall. Retail sales of SUVs in China have surged, and Volkswagen is seeking a solution to stay competitive in the emerging market.

site_title: Tech, you're IT
summary: Tech stocks remain unpopular among investors, despite strong performance. A low-profile property trust is exploring a data centre venture. US weekly jobless claims fell unexpectedly, while China urges Southeast Asian countries to support openness amid US tariffs. Chinese property shares surged on unverified reports of a potential meeting to revive the sector. Reliance Jio, led by Ambani, has delayed its India IPO beyond this year. China introduced new measures to aid employment amidst trade tensions.

site_title: Citigroup must face South Korean bank's lawsuit over failed CDO
summary: A US appeals court revived a lawsuit filed by South Korea's Woori Bank against Citigroup, accusing the bank of defrauding it into buying risky mortgage securities. Woori had invested $25 million in a 2007 CDO, which defaulted in December 2007, but did not sue until 2012, citing a three-year statute of limitations. The 2nd US Circuit Court of Appeals ruled that Woori had "practical and specific awareness" of its claims by 2011, allowing it to sue within the statute of limitations. The case will proceed to further proceedings.

site_title: New Chinese FTZ to help deepen economic ties with Taiwan: Xinhua
summary: China has opened three new free trade zones (FTZs) to deepen economic ties with Taiwan, Hong Kong, and Macau. The FTZs in Fujian, Guangdong, and Tianjin will follow the Shanghai FTZ model, introducing looser rules for currency conversions and foreign direct investment. Chinese Premier Li Keqiang visited the Fujian FTZ, while Vice Premier Wang Yang discussed the integration of Hong Kong and Macau. The move aims to strengthen economic cooperation and integration with neighboring regions.

site_title: Atmospherics, substance, and US strategic partnerships
summary: US President Barack Obama and Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi have strengthened their strategic partnership, aimed at sustaining peace, prosperity, and stability in South Asia and the Indian Ocean region. The partnership is driven by personal chemistry between leaders, with Obama and Modi endorsing a new Delhi Declaration of Friendship and articulating principles to advance mutual prosperity and economic cooperation. However, concerns arise over India's "strategic autonomy" and its relationship with Russia and China, potentially hindering the development of a true strategic partnership with the US.

site_title: Cheaper oil encourages top traders to drive up volumes
summary: Some of the world's largest oil trading houses anticipate increased volumes in 2015 due to cheaper oil prices. With oil prices dropping from US$115 million to US$60 million, trading volumes become more financially viable. However, this increase in trading volumes may lead to unused banking lines and strained relationships between traders and banks, as they prefer maintaining active credit lines.

site_title: Euro steadies, A$ up on inflation data
summary: The euro recovered slightly against the dollar on Wednesday, up 0.3% at US$1.0770, amid subdued market activity. Meanwhile, the Australian dollar rose over 1% to US$0.7794 after inflation data showed core inflation of 0.6% in the first quarter, reducing the likelihood of an interest rate cut in May. Sterling gained around 0.5% against a basket of peers after Bank of England minutes emphasized hopes for a further improvement in the UK economy.

site_title: RBA chief talks down A$, questions benefits of rate cuts
summary: Australian Reserve Bank Governor Glenn Stevens downplays the nation's currency, stating the Aussie will "very likely fall further yet" and questioning the benefits of further rate cuts. Stevens' comments come as the economy sputters, with the currency stuck above major export prices, affecting competitiveness and income from abroad. The RBA has maintained a cash rate of 2.25%, above peers' near or below-zero rates, and Stevens has nominated 75 US cents as a preferable currency level.

images.alt_text: Mr Stevens had said that he would "be a bit surprised actually" if the currency doesn't decline from current levels.

site_title: Oil prices lifted by US production decline
summary: US oil production declined by 18,000 barrels per day last week, resulting in a 0.19% drop. Oil prices rose due to this decline, with Brent crude increasing 66 cents to $62.74 a barrel and US crude rising 20 cents to $56.81 a barrel. A rise in gasoline stocks and instability in Yemen also contributed to the price increase. Analysts expect the market to continue awaiting further production declines, potentially leading to a new bull market in the sector.

site_title: Peugeot, IBM agree to expanded "connected car" partnership deal
summary: PSA Peugeot Citroën and IBM have agreed on a seven-year partnership to develop connected car services beyond navigation and infotainment. The deal aims to create services within vehicles, for drivers and passengers, and back-end applications for preventive car maintenance and traffic management. Financial terms were not disclosed, building on their initial partnership announced a year ago. The companies plan to develop new services, including preventive car maintenance and traffic management functions.

site_title: Tech stocks still not investors' darlings
summary: Singapore's tech ecosystem is still in its growth stage, with listed tech companies not yet reaching the valuation of global giants like Apple. Despite this, investors focus on metrics like PE ratios rather than profitability. Recent investments in AI and digital innovation hubs, such as the NIE-Amazon Web Services edtech research hub and Lazada's creator commerce program, indicate growing interest in the sector. However, the country's tech industry still lags behind its global peers, with many major players yet to emerge.

site_title: Owning a home is a faraway dream for young Londoners
summary: Young Londoners struggle to own homes due to rising prices and a lack of new construction, with the average house costing over 10 times average earnings. To buy a home, Londoners must earn over £100,000, more than three times the average salary. This has led to a generation of "Generation Rent" being priced out of the market, with many forced to rent and spend over 50% of their income on housing. Experts warn that this is a systemic failure that could have significant implications for the UK's politics and society.

site_title: Singapore Wrap Wednesday
summary: Singapore's stocks fell 12.37 points to 3,496.24 on Wednesday, as blue chips weakened due to US market expectations. The COE premium for big cars rose, while motorcycles' premium reached a record high. Meanwhile, Ascendas launched a S$333m fund to invest in China business parks, and IDA will launch HetNet trials in Jurong Lake District in Q3.

site_title: US existing home sales hit 18-month high; prices rise
summary: US existing home sales reached an 18-month high in March, with a 6.1% increase to 5.19 million units, the highest level since September 2013. The improvement in inventories suggests strength in the housing market ahead of the spring selling season. The data indicates the economy is regaining momentum after a slow start in the first quarter, but the Federal Reserve may not raise interest rates in June due to insufficient growth.

site_title: Cache Logistics Trust's Q1 DPU up 0.3% to 2.146 cents
summary: Cache Logistics Trust reported a 0.3% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.146 Singapore cents for its Q1 2015, driven by build-in rental escalation and contribution from Australian properties. Gross revenue rose 1.6% to S$21 million, while net property income increased 0.6% to S$19.7 million. The trust will pay its distribution on May 27 and close its books on April 30.

site_title: US crude oil inventories rise as refiners pare record runs: EIA
summary: US crude oil inventories rose 5.3 million barrels last week, exceeding expectations, as refineries cut output from a seasonal record high. Gasoline stocks fell 2.1 million barrels, while distillate inventories rose 395,000 barrels. Refinery crude runs fell by 230,000 barrels per day, and US crude imports increased by 617,000 barrels per day. The data led to a rally in US oil prices, turning positive on the day.

site_title: EU markets watchdog to look deeper into digital currency investments
summary: The European Union's markets watchdog, ESMA, is examining trading investments based on digital currency systems like bitcoin, as it is unclear whether ownership is legally enforceable. ESMA is looking into the use of blockchain technology to issue and trade securities, which bypass regulated stock exchanges. The watchdog is seeking information on investment schemes, derivatives, and assets traded using blockchain, as it considers the potential for virtual currency-based assets to enter the financial mainstream. ESMA has no immediate plans to take regulatory action.

site_title: Changi City Point boosts Frasers Centrepoint Trust's Q2 results
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Trust reported a 2.9% increase in distribution per unit to 2.963 Singapore cents for its Q2 2015 results, driven by the addition of Changi City Point to its portfolio in June 2014. Gross revenue rose 15.9% to S$47.5 million.

site_title: Xi and Abe agree to work for better ties: Jiji
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe and Chinese President Xi Jinping agreed to work on improving ties between the two countries, promoting "mutually beneficial strategic ties" to contribute to regional stability and prosperity. This follows a meeting on the sidelines of an Asia-Africa summit in Indonesia, where tensions have flared over wartime history and territorial rows. The cautious rapprochement began when Abe and Xi met in Beijing last year. The agreement aims to ease historical tensions and promote cooperation between Asia's two biggest economies.

site_title: US: Wall St slips on mixed bag of earnings
summary: US stocks slipped in choppy trading on Wednesday, with Boeing and Chipotle falling due to disappointing earnings reports. Despite this, McDonald's and Coca-Cola rose, while Visa and MasterCard gained after China's decision to open its market for foreign bank card transactions. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 0.17%, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also declined. Analysts predict more buybacks and mergers in the second half of the earnings season as CEOs try to boost stock prices.

site_title: IDA's HetNet trials in Jurong Lake District to kick off in Q3
summary: The Infocomm Development Authority of Singapore (IDA) will launch HetNet trials in the Jurong Lake District in Q3 2015, as part of Singapore's Smart Nation initiative. HetNet enables seamless switching between various wireless networks for optimal spectrum use. IDA will collaborate with Sentosa Development Corporation and three telcos to co-innovate and prototype technologies, with Sentosa providing real-business challenges to address. This trial aims to create market-validated products for commercialization, improving efficiency and guest experience on Sentosa island.

site_title: ECB has not decided on raising haircut on Greek bank collateral: source
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) has not made a decision to raise the discount applied to Greek bank collateral, according to a source. The ECB has discussed possible scenarios, including reducing the value of such collateral, but no decision has been reached. ECB President Mario Draghi stated that haircuts on Greek sovereign debt were mentioned but not discussed during a recent news conference. The decision on potential haircuts will be made by the ECB's Governing Council.

site_title: Oil prices dip below US$62 on US stock build
summary: Oil prices dropped below US$62 a barrel on April 22, 2015, after the US Energy Information Administration reported a higher-than-expected 5.5 million barrel build in US crude oil inventories. Brent oil fell 31 cents to US$61.77 a barrel, while US crude declined 54 cents to US$56.07 a barrel. The decrease was attributed to the US stock build, which outweighed the expected drawdown.

site_title: StanChart hires former UK surveillance chief to combat cybercrime
summary: Standard Chartered has appointed Iain Lobban, former head of Britain's GCHQ, to its financial crime committee to strengthen cyber defences. Lobban's two-year renewable term aims to combat financial crime and improve conduct and compliance capabilities. The appointment follows a US$667 million fine in 2012 for violations related to US sanctions on Iran and other countries. Lobban's expertise in cybersecurity will help the bank combat rising cyber threats from sophisticated criminals targeting banks and client data.

site_title: Asean Economic Community launch will see rise in trade flows, but also more problems: OCBC chief
summary: The launch of the Asean Economic Community is expected to increase trade flows between 10 Asean member states, but also brings more problems such as money laundering and fraud. OCBC Bank CEO Samuel Tsien warned that these challenges require "prudent monitoring and vigilance" from regulatory authorities and banks. The shift to Asia will also increase the need for access to trade credit, particularly for small and medium enterprises, which are crucial for economic expansion. Tsien emphasized the importance of knowing customers and their customers to prevent criminal irregularities.

site_title: Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi opens branch in Myanmar, to finance learning centre
summary: The Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi UFJ (BTMU) has opened a branch in Yangon, Myanmar, and will fund the development of a learning centre at the Myanmar Institute of Banking. The centre, set to be ready by mid-2015, will provide computer-literacy and language training to staff of member banks. BTMU CEO Go Watanabe sees this as a mutually beneficial partnership to raise workforce competency in the financial sector, supporting Myanmar's economic growth. The move marks the bank's first foreign branch in Yangon, aiming to promote long-term prosperity between Myanmar and Japan.

site_title: Investing in a deflationary world
summary: The world is experiencing a rare phase of disinflation, with year-on-year price declines in the US and globally, mainly due to sharp falls in oil prices. This is expected to support growth worldwide, with the US economy projected to achieve a 3% growth rate this year, the strongest since 2005. Europe and China are also expected to see economic acceleration, with the US dollar likely to appreciate due to monetary policy divergence. Developed market equities, particularly in Europe and Japan, and select Asian markets, are preferred investments, but investors should be cautious of increased volatility and use leverage judiciously.

images.alt_text: Deflation fears have been increasing globally since last year, notably in Europe and Japan, and increasingly in China.

site_title: India's richest state needs over US$200b to house its poorest
summary: Maharashtra, India's wealthiest state, requires over $200 billion in fresh investment by 2022 to address its chronic affordable housing shortage. The state needs 5 million new homes in urban areas and 10 million new homes overall by 2022 to end the shortage. The shortage is exacerbated by a growing urban population, with Mumbai's population expected to double by 2050. The issue has been highlighted by nationalist groups, with the Shiv Sena party appealing to the working class for affordable housing. The shortage is a major challenge for the state's politicians, with the government needing to redevelop overcrowded cities and build new ones to accommodate growing city dwellers.

images.alt_text: Maharahstra, India's wealthiest and most urbanised state, needs more than US$200 billion in fresh investment by 2022 if it is to solve a chronic shortage of affordable housing in its fast-growing cities, a report by consultants KPMG found.

site_title: Taiwan says Singapore bourse equity-trade link to start in July
summary: Taiwan plans to launch a cross-border stock trading platform with Singapore on July 1, allowing Taiwanese investors to trade on the Singapore Exchange. This move aims to increase global investment in Taiwan's equity market. The link follows the success of Shanghai-Hong Kong cross-border trading, which has boosted prices in Asia. Taiwan's 150 largest stocks will be eligible, and the program is seen as a step towards internationalizing the country's security market.

site_title: Coca-Cola reports revenue growth for first time in nine quarters
summary: Coca-Cola Co. reported its first revenue growth in nine quarters, driven by a 6% rise in revenue from North America. Net operating revenue rose 1.3% to US$10.71 billion, while net income fell to US$1.56 billion. The company's shares rose 2.3% to US$41.70 in premarket trade.

images.alt_text: Coca-Cola Co reported a rise in revenue for the first time in nine quarters, helped by a 6 per cent rise in revenue from North America, its biggest market.

site_title: BOJ report shows Japan banks slashing JGB holdings, take on more risk
summary: Japanese banks have cut their Japanese government bond (JGB) holdings by 34 trillion yen as the Bank of Japan's stimulus program has led to a significant increase in their balance sheet. The banks have also increased domestic and overseas lending and investments, spending nearly double the amount they cut in JGB holdings. This shift indicates that the banks are taking on more risk as the central bank's aggressive bond buying continues.

site_title: MPA to work with World Maritime University to train global maritime leaders
summary: The Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore (MPA) has signed a memorandum of understanding with the World Maritime University to develop leadership training programs for the global maritime industry. The partnership aims to enhance the local maritime workforce and address a shortage of skilled workers. MPA Academy will also exchange faculty members with the university. This move is part of the MPA's efforts to remain "pro-business" and retain top maritime firms in Singapore. The partnership is expected to benefit the local maritime industry and enhance its competitiveness globally.

site_title: DBS, Westpac cut fee for withdrawal of foreign currency from their ATMs
summary: DBS and Westpac have removed the fee for foreign customers to withdraw cash from their partner banks' ATMs in Australia, a move expected to save customers around A$3.5 million annually. The transactions will be subject to a 3% foreign transaction fee. The partnership aims to benefit Singaporean customers planning to travel to Australia, one of the most sought-after travel destinations in the region.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower
summary: Malaysia's stock market ended lower on Wednesday, with the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index slipping 8.03 points to close at 1,854.77. The market saw 2.74 billion lots traded, valued at RM2.12 billion, with 293 gainers and 564 losers.

site_title: Germany raises 2015 growth forecast to 1.8% on consumer spending
summary: Germany's government has raised its 2015 growth forecast to 1.8% due to increased consumer spending. The Economy Ministry cited a strong labor market with rising wages and increasing employment as the main drivers. Growth is expected to maintain its 1.8% pace in 2016 as corporate investments pick up. Economy Minister Sigmar Gabriel stated that private consumption will support the country's growth, but the government will focus on improving medium-term growth prospects through investments in education, research, and infrastructure.

site_title: Mapletree Commercial Trust's Q4 DPU rises 2.4%
summary: Mapletree Commercial Trust reported a 2.4% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to 2 cents for its Q4 2015, surpassing last year's 1.953 cents. Gross revenue rose 3.5% to S$71 million, driven by positive contributions from all its properties.

site_title: Bank of England unanimous on rates, more upbeat on eurozone
summary: The Bank of England's Monetary Policy Committee unanimously voted to keep interest rates at a record-low 0.5% in April, citing a stronger-than-expected recovery in the eurozone and a good chance of US economic growth rebounding. The central bank also expressed more concern about upside risks to British inflation, which it aims to reach 2% in the coming months. Despite a record-low inflation rate in February, policymakers believe strong economic growth could lead to higher prices and wages.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close up 0.30%
summary: Hong Kong shares closed 0.30% higher on Wednesday, following a surge in Shanghai, as investors await further economy-boosting measures by China. The benchmark Hang Seng Index rose 83.36 points to 27,933.85. Mainland China's Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indices also increased, with Shanghai rising 2.44% and Shenzhen gaining 2.74%. The gains extended Hong Kong's recent rally, driven by hopes for economic stimulus.

site_title: Property writedown drags Tesco to worst ever loss
summary: Tesco, Britain's largest retailer, reported its worst annual loss in 96-year history, a statutory pretax loss of 6.38 billion pounds, due to a 4.7 billion pound writedown of its store value, an accounting scandal, and declining sales. Trading profit was 1.4 billion pounds, less than half of the previous year's 3.3 billion pounds. The company's net debt and pension deficit were 8.5 billion pounds and 3.9 billion pounds, respectively. New boss Dave Lewis faces significant work to mend the firm's finances.

site_title: Big-car COE premium rises; commercial vehicles' slumps
summary: The Certificate of Entitlement (COE) premium for big cars rose, with Category B cars increasing from S$78,001 to S$78,001, while motorcycles' premium reached a record high. In contrast, commercial vehicles' COE premium dropped 17% to S$67,601. The price changes reflect shifting market dynamics and regulatory adjustments.

site_title: SGX posts 16.4% rise in Q3 profit; revenue jumps 20.4%
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) reported a 16.4% increase in net profit to S$88.2 million for its third quarter ended March 31, 2015, driven by a 20.4% rise in operating revenue to S$199.3 million. Excluding Energy Market Company (EMC) revenue, all businesses recorded higher revenues compared to the previous year. This was after SGX completed the acquisition of EMC on October 1, 2014, making it a wholly owned subsidiary.

site_title: China: Stocks rise to fresh 7-year high on bullish state media commentary
summary: Chinese stocks reached a 7-year high, rising 2.6% and 2.5% in the CSI300 and Shanghai Composite Index, respectively. State media commentary described the current bull market as having "just begun" and denied a bubble, citing China's grand development strategy and economic reforms. The surge in share prices reflects China's growth potential, and investors are seeking more confidence from regulators. Despite a recent crackdown on margin financing, the latest commentary provided more support, with some analysts predicting a "craziest time" for the ChiNext start-up board.

site_title: Volvo says it has hired CEO of rival Scania
summary: Volvo has hired Martin Lundstedt, CEO of rival Scania, to take over its operations in October. This move comes as the company reported a 4.25 billion crowns ($660 million) profit increase in the first quarter, thanks to strong sales and efficiency gains. Volvo's stock performance is not mentioned in the provided article.

site_title: China's Huawei says expects carrier services revenue to reach US$11.4b in 2015
summary: Huawei expects its carrier services revenue to reach $11.4 billion in 2015, a 9% increase from the previous year. The company aims to build its presence in the service sector for global carriers, with services accounting for 33% of its carrier business in 2014. This growth positions Huawei to compete with Ericsson for the top spot in the global market for communications towers and other infrastructure.

site_title: Europe: Stocks rise at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets rose at the start of trading on Wednesday, with the FTSE 100 index up 0.34% to 7,086.78 points. Frankfurt's DAX 30 and Paris's CAC 40 indices also gained 0.38% and 0.35% respectively. The increases were driven by mining and healthcare stocks, while US-EU trade talks are in focus.

images.alt_text: Europe's main stock markets climbed at the start of trading on Wednesday, with London's benchmark FTSE 100 index up 0.34 per cent at 7,086.78 points.

site_title: South Korean bonds rise as slowing economy boosts rate-cut bets
summary: South Korea's government bonds rose as investors speculated the country's slowing economy would prompt the central bank to cut interest rates. The country's GDP likely increased 2.3% in the first quarter, the slowest pace in two years. The yield on 2% bonds due December 2017 dropped to 1.70% as investors bet on another rate cut. The Bank of Korea reviews benchmark borrowing costs on May 15, with some analysts forecasting a rate cut to 1.5% before the end of the year.

site_title: Singapore: Blue chips weaken, penny interest continues to dwindle
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 12.37 points to 3,496.24 on April 22, 2015, due to expectations of weakness ahead on Wall Street. The penny segment showed signs of fatigue, with prices weakening in low volume. Retail brokers reported decreased interest among clients, likely due to the loss of upward momentum in the STI and Hong Kong markets. The STI's unit average price was S$0.67, with a total market advance-decline score of 200/287, excluding warrants.

site_title: Uniqlo adds shoes to lineup in Japan, some overseas markets
summary: Uniqlo, a Japanese casual-wear chain, has expanded its product lineup to include shoes at all its Japanese stores, as well as in China, South Korea, and the US, with plans for France in June. The brand aims to gauge demand before considering further international rollouts. This move is part of Fast Retailing's goal to become the world's top apparel retailer by 2020, surpassing competitors Inditex, H&M, and Gap Inc. The Japan shoe lineup includes 5 color variations priced at 2,990 yen (S$34).

site_title: ECB to fund Greek banks as long as they stay solvent
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) will continue to provide liquidity to Greece's banks as long as they remain solvent and have sufficient collateral. ECB Executive Board Member Benoit Coeure stated this in an interview with a Greek newspaper, ruling out capital controls and speculation about Greece leaving the euro. The ECB's decision to return profits from Greek bonds will depend on Greece's successful conclusion of its bailout review.

site_title: Ascendas launches S$333m fund to invest in China business parks
summary: Ascendas has launched the S$333 million Ascendas China Business Parks Fund 4 to invest in Shanghai, Suzhou, and Xi'an business parks. The fund will acquire completed properties and a development project, including the Ascendas Lotus Business Park in Shanghai, Ascendas-Xinsu portfolio in Suzhou, and the Ascendas Innovation Towers development project in Xi'an.

site_title: ANA to take up to 19.9% stake in bankrupt budget carrier Skymark
summary: ANA Holdings Inc has agreed to acquire a stake of up to 19.9% in bankrupt budget carrier Skymark Airlines Inc, gaining access to highly coveted landing slots. The deal allows ANA to strengthen its lead over rival Japan Airlines Co. Skymark's bankruptcy was triggered by its ambitious expansion program, including plans to fly Airbus A380s, which left the airline unable to keep up with payments. Japanese private equity firm Integral Corp will hold just over 50% of the airline. ANA's stake is kept below 20% to avoid losing landing rights at Tokyo's Haneda airport.

site_title: Drone with radiation sign lands on roof of Japan PM Abe's office: media
summary: A drone carrying a small camera, water bottle, and flare, marked with a radioactive sign, was found on the rooftop of Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's office on April 22, 2015. The incident occurred while Abe was in Indonesia attending an Asia-Africa summit. The significance of the drone was not immediately clear, and no official comment was made by Abe's office. This incident follows a similar incident in the US where a drone crashed in the White House grounds, raising concerns about regulatory guidelines.

site_title: China vice-finance minister to be new stats chief: govt sources
summary: China will appoint Vice-Finance Minister Wang Baoan as the country's statistics chief, succeeding Ma Jiantang, who has taken up a new job at the Chinese Academy of Governance. Wang's appointment could be announced soon, with no further details provided. Ma, who headed the National Bureau of Statistics from 2008, remains a member of the central bank's monetary policy committee. This change may bring new pressures on policymakers as China's GDP growth is expected to slow.

site_title: Malaysia March inflation picks up to 0.9% y-o-y
summary: Malaysia's consumer price index in March rose to 0.9% y-o-y due to increased prices of alcohol and tobacco products. The inflation rate matched the median forecast of 0.9% in a Reuters poll. This marks the end of a two-year period of deflation in Malaysia.

site_title: Rolls-Royce's CEO Rishton to retire, Warren East to succeed
summary: Rolls-Royce Holdings announced the retirement of CEO John Rishton in July, who will be succeeded by Warren East, the former ARM CEO. East has been a non-executive director since 2014 and oversaw ARM's growth into a leading chip developer. Rishton will step down on July 2 to seek a change in lifestyle. East's appointment follows a difficult period for the company under Rishton's leadership.

site_title: China to open bank card clearing businesses to foreign firms
summary: China will allow foreign firms to apply for licenses to establish bank card clearing businesses starting from June 1, following a WTO ruling that found China discriminated against US card firms in 2012. This move potentially opens the door for Visa and Mastercard to challenge UnionPay's near-monopoly in the domestic market. The decision aims to increase competition and openness in China's financial sector, as the country seeks to promote economic growth and global trade.

site_title: Australia: Shares close lower on May rate cut doubts
summary: Australian shares fell 0.6% on Wednesday, led by a decline in the financial sector, despite inflation data showing consumer prices rose at the slowest pace in almost three years. The Reserve Bank of Australia has room to ease monetary policy, but the data did not increase pressure for an imminent interest rate cut. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 5,837.5, while New Zealand's share market also fell, closing at its lowest in nearly two months.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei closes above 20,000 for first time in 15 years
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index closed at 20,133.90, surpassing 20,000 for the first time in 15 years. The index rose 1.13% driven by hopes for strong Japanese corporate earnings, despite a weak lead from Wall Street. This marks a significant milestone for the Japanese market, which had not seen a closing above 20,000 since April 2000.

site_title: Philippine banks outclass South-east Asian peers in valuations
summary: The Philippines' top five banks have seen their median price-to-earnings (PE) ratio rise to 14.53, the highest since June 2013, driven by foreign investor funds and a bullish economic outlook. The banks are expected to swing to a combined profit increase of 9.5% this year, up from a 1.5% contraction in 2014. Investors are focusing on consumer loans, mortgages, and corporate lending as the economy is supported by strong domestic demand and public infrastructure projects. However, Asian banks may increase competition in the sector as they plan to expand lending operations in the Philippines.

site_title: Australia property sector needs money laundering safeguards: report
summary: Australia's booming property market has been identified as a high-risk destination for money laundering, particularly from the Asia-Pacific region, according to a report by the intergovernmental Financial Action Task Force. Real estate agents, lawyers, and accountants are considered high-risk sectors, with current regulations failing to require them to report suspicious transactions. The report recommends that Australia widen its efforts to combat money laundering, including requiring these professionals to report suspicious activities. The move comes as Australia has been a popular destination for Chinese foreign buyers, with nearly A$6 billion in real estate purchases made in 2013.

site_title: Seoul: Shares nearly flat on profit-taking; won firms
summary: South Korean shares ended nearly flat on Wednesday, erasing early gains, after touching a near 4-year high. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) closed at 2,144.79, down 0.9 points. Foreign investors bought a record 711 billion won of shares, and the won rose 0.4% against the dollar. The gains were largely due to profit-taking after the KOSPI's intraday high of 2,161.23, its highest level since August 2011.

site_title: South Korea says reaches deal with US to revise nuclear energy pact
summary: South Korea and the US reached a deal to revise an agreement limiting South Korea's ability to enrich uranium and reprocess spent fuel for nuclear power generation. The foreign ministry in Seoul announced the agreement without providing further details. South Korea, which generates one-third of its power from nuclear energy, has pushed for greater freedom to manage its nuclear fuel.

site_title: Noble Group barred from Platts' oil pricing process: sources
summary: Commodity trader Noble Group has been barred from participating in some oil pricing processes by Platts, a reporting agency, due to allegations of inflating asset values through aggressive accounting. Noble has denied the accusations and is still trading in derivatives markets. The company has faced increased scrutiny this year and its shares have fallen by as much as one-third. Platts temporarily barred Noble from its market-on-close process, a decision that may not significantly impact its trading activities.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks rise; Asus leads computers higher
summary: Taiwan's stocks rose 0.78% on Wednesday, led by computer makers, including AsusTek Computer Inc, which gained 3.13%. The electronics subindex was up 1%, with semiconductors and electrical components also rising. The Taiwan dollar strengthened to T$31.091 to the US dollar. The gains followed a strong performance in regional bourses, with the main TAIEX index closing up 74.79 points to 9,608.77.

site_title: Indonesia calls for new financial global architecture
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo called for a new global financial order that is open to emerging economic powers, leaving "obsolete ideas" of Bretton Woods institutions behind. The speech marked the 60th anniversary of a conference that united developing countries against colonialism. Widodo's remarks came amid thawing relations between China and Japan, with bilateral talks in Jakarta. Indonesia is one of nearly 60 countries supporting the China-backed Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank, which challenges Western-dominated institutions. Widodo emphasized the need for change in the global economic order, citing shifting world realities and the dominance of a certain group of countries.

site_title: South Korea announces plan to raise sunken Sewol ferry
summary: South Korea has announced plans to raise the sunken Sewol ferry, one year after it sank with over 300 lives lost. The salvage operation, expected to begin in September, will be a technical challenge due to the vessel's depth and estimated cost between $90 million and $140 million. The operation will be carried out by a selected company and aims to recover the bodies of the missing. The decision meets a key demand of the victims' families, who have vowed to continue protests for a fully independent inquiry into the sinking.

images.alt_text: The South Korean government announced Wednesday it would raise the wreck of the Sewol ferry, one year after it sank with the loss of more than 300 lives, most of them schoolchildren.

site_title: Google to unveil wireless service as soon as Wednesday, WSJ says
summary: Google plans to unveil its wireless service as early as Wednesday, reportedly allowing customers to pay only for data used each month. The service will run on Sprint and T-Mobile networks, initially available on Google's Nexus 6 phones. This move could help Google promote its Android operating system and serve users with targeted advertisements. Google's investment in mobile software and services follows a trend of increasing internet access through wireless devices, with Android dominating the smartphone market.

site_title: BOJ to keep policy steady on April 30 unless big CPI forecast cut: sources
summary: The Bank of Japan is expected to maintain its monetary policy steady on April 30 unless a significant cut in its core consumer inflation forecast is made. The central bank is anticipated to slightly downgrade its inflation forecast for the current fiscal year to 1.0% due to the impact of last year's recession and soft consumer spending. However, it is likely to project inflation to reach 2% in the following two years, indicating that the economy can meet its 2% inflation target without additional stimulus.

images.alt_text: The Bank of Japan is expected to hold off on expanding monetary stimulus next week even though the bank is likely to slightly reduce its inflation forecast for this fiscal year, said sources familiar with its thinking.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 2.68 points to 1,860.12. Volume reached 125.2 million lots worth RM42.1 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 105 to 78.

site_title: Japan says PM Abe will meet China's Xi in Indonesia
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe will meet Chinese President Xi Jinping at an Asia-Africa summit in Indonesia, a sign of a potential thaw in relations between the Asian rivals. The meeting, which was confirmed by a Japanese government official, comes after a cautious rapprochement began when the two leaders met in Beijing last year. Abe's speech in Jakarta is expected to be watched for hints about whether he wants to dilute past apologies over World War II, a move that could sit poorly with China.

site_title: Sony raises full-year profit view on strength in sensors, video games
summary: Sony raised its full-year profit view to 68 billion yen (S$766 million), citing strong sales of camera sensors and video games. This surpasses its previous estimate of 20 billion yen and the average forecast of 50.3 billion yen among analysts. The company's operating profit for the year ended March 31 was 26.5 billion yen, a significant improvement from its recent losses. This positive outlook is a result of Sony's diversification efforts and increased sales in key areas.

images.alt_text: Japanese consumer electronics maker Sony Corp on Wednesday raised its earnings estimates for the fiscal year that ended in March, citing higher-than-expected sales of camera sensors and videogames.

site_title: Most Asian markets up, Tokyo at 15-year high
summary: Asian markets rose on Wednesday, with Tokyo hitting a 15-year high after Japan recorded its first trade surplus in three years. The Nikkei broke through the 20,000-point barrier as the yen weakened against the dollar. Other markets, such as Hong Kong and Shanghai, also gained, while Seoul added 0.72% and Sydney slipped 0.58%. The euro slipped due to concerns over Greece's bailout negotiations, while US stocks fell despite a positive lead from Asia.

site_title: Oil prices drop as Middle East tension ease
summary: Oil prices declined as Middle East tensions eased after Saudi Arabia ended its military campaign in Yemen. Brent crude fell 28 cents to $61.82 a barrel and US crude fell 38 cents to $56.22 a barrel. Industry data showed a larger-than-expected build in US oil inventories, but traders expect prices to recover due to strengthening demand, particularly in India and Europe. Prices are unlikely to plummet to this year's lows, with some predicting one more dip in the second quarter.

site_title: Singapore: Stocks open lower despite gains in Asian stocks
summary: The Singapore Straits Times Index (STI) opened 4.73 points lower, 0.13% down, at 3,503.88. Despite this, 90 gainers outnumbered 55 losers. Noble Group topped trading value, up half a cent to S$0.875, after promising more transparency in its Q1 2015 results. Other top five stocks included ST Engineering, SPH, Sembcorp Industries, and Singtel.

site_title: Japan March exports rise 8.5% y-o-y: MOF
summary: Japan's exports rose 8.5% in March from a year ago, exceeding expectations, driven by overseas demand. The trade balance turned into a surplus of $1.9 billion, the first since June 2012. Imports fell 14.5% in the same period, mainly due to lower oil prices. The stronger-than-expected data suggests the Japanese economy is gaining momentum.

site_title: Indonesia's Pertamina Q1 net profit US$28m vs its target of US$427m
summary: Indonesia's state oil and gas company PT Pertamina reported a first-quarter net profit of $28 million, significantly below its target of $427 million. Revenue fell short of its target of $12.31 billion, with $10.67 billion reported. CEO Dwi Soetjipto attributed the poor performance to various factors, including fluctuations in global oil prices and increased competition. The results have raised concerns about Pertamina's financial health and its ability to meet its targets.

images.alt_text: First quarter net profit at Indonesia's state oil and gas company PT Pertamina came in at US$28 million, far below its target of US$427 million, CEO Dwi Soetjipto said in a parliamentary hearing on Wednesday.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks down 0.10% at open
summary: Hong Kong shares dropped 0.10% in the opening minutes of trade on Wednesday, with the Hang Seng Index easing 29.17 points to 27,821.32. This follows a surge in the previous session. In contrast, mainland China's Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.56% to 4,317.67. The decline in Hong Kong was attributed to investors cashing in, while the Shanghai Composite Index gain was likely due to market optimism.

site_title: China to promote yuan by relaxing investment scheme rules: sources
summary: China plans to relax rules for the Qualified Foreign Institutional Investor (QFII) programme, allowing foreign asset managers and banks to move capital in and out of China daily, enhancing the yuan's global standing and supporting its inclusion in the IMF's reserve currencies. This move could strengthen the yuan and support Beijing's push to increase its global influence.

site_title: Australian core consumer prices matched estimates last quarter
summary: Australia's core consumer prices rose 0.6% in the latest quarter, matching forecasts, leaving room for the Reserve Bank of Australia to reduce interest rates. The trimmed mean gauge of core prices is "stickier" than expected, with the annual rate close to the central bank's target range. Governor Glenn Stevens has kept the benchmark cash rate unchanged for two months, aiming to reinvigorate domestic industries and transition the economy away from slower mining investment.

site_title: China stocks rise to seven-year high as drugmakers advance
summary: China's benchmark index rose 0.5% to a seven-year high, driven by gains from drugmakers and technology companies. The Shanghai Composite Index reached 4,312.81, with Jiangsu Hengrui Medicine and Wangsu Science & Technology Co. advancing 3% and 6.6%, respectively. Meanwhile, a state-owned company, Baoding Tianwei Group, defaulted on a bond, but investors view this as a maturation of the Chinese economy, which is slowing down. The government's easing of monetary policies and opening up to market forces are seen as supporting the economy.

site_title: In North Korea, solar panel boom gives power to the people
summary: In North Korea, a solar panel boom is empowering citizens to generate their own electricity, despite the country's notorious power shortages. Household solar panels are increasingly being installed, particularly in Pyongyang, with prices dropping due to domestic production. The surge in demand reflects rising incomes and the need for electronic goods, with 2.5 million mobile phone users driving the market. While private solar panels are not illegal, some local authorities may demand bribes for permission to install them, and electricity supply remains prioritized for factories and areas of political importance.

site_title: Golden Agri's S$125m three-year notes priced at 5.5% a year
summary: Golden Agri-Resources priced its S$125 million, three-year senior unsecured fixed rate notes at 5.5% per annum, as part of a US$1.5 billion multicurrency medium term note programme. The company plans to use the net proceeds for general corporate purposes and working capital needs, including debt repayment. The notes are managed by Credit Suisse, MUFJ, and OCBC Bank, with the company maintaining its stock price at S$0.435 following the announcement.

site_title: Super storm lashes Australian east coast for third day
summary: A cyclonic storm has lashed Australia's east coast for a third day, causing millions of dollars in damage and killing three people. The storm has washed away houses, cut power to over 200,000 homes, and stranded a cruise ship off the coast. Gale force winds of up to 100 km/h and heavy rain have caused widespread disruption, with many commuters stranded in flooded areas. The Insurance Council of Australia has received over 7,500 insurance claims, with damage costs expected to rise.

site_title: Deutsche Bank credit risk rises as review fuels funding concerns
summary: Deutsche Bank's credit risk is rising due to concerns over funding and a potential sale of its retail business to focus on investment banking. Bondholders demand a higher yield premium, up 83 basis points, due to fears of volatile returns and increased reliance on wholesale funding. The bank's review, led by Co-CEOs Anshu Jain and Juergen Fitschen, aims to boost returns and capital levels, but investors worry that bondholders' interests will be neglected. This could lead to increased risk for creditors and potentially harm bondholders.

site_title: LNG takes off in gas-rich Mideast as conflict thwarts pipelines
summary: Liquefied natural gas (LNG) is increasingly being used in the Middle East and North Africa due to pipeline sabotage and the desire for diversity of supply. Despite being cheaper than pipelines, LNG is becoming more attractive as countries like Morocco and Jordan seek alternative sources to meet growing electricity demands. The region is expected to spend $120 billion on gas-fired power plants by 2035, with LNG deliveries set to double in 2015. Major energy producers and resource-poor countries are turning to global markets for energy, driven by lower LNG prices and the difficulty of getting regional gas.

site_title: Cambridge Industrial Trust Q1 DPU at 1.225 cents, down 2.1%
summary: Cambridge Industrial Trust reported a Q1 DPU of 1.225 Singapore cents, down 2.1% from the same period last year. Revenue increased 16.7% to S$27.5 million, while net property income rose 11.9% to S$21.2 million. The annualised distribution yield is 6.9% based on its closing price of S$0.715. Net asset value per unit decreased to S$0.68 from S$0.681 at end-2014.

site_title: Tokyo's Nikkei index bounces back over 20,000 at open
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei index surged 0.71% to 20,050.03, surpassing the 20,000 mark for the first time in nearly 15 years, driven by a weaker yen that boosts exporter shares. The yen's decline makes Japanese exports more competitive abroad and inflates repatriated profits. Japan posted its first trade surplus in nearly three years in March, while global monetary easing has also boosted investor sentiment.

site_title: Smog-hit China aims for environmental stimulus as growth wanes
summary: China's Hebei province aims to boost its economy and tackle environmental issues through targeted financing initiatives. 18 banks agreed to lend over $135 billion to revitalize local industry and improve the environment. The move follows a 100 basis point cut in bank reserve requirements to stimulate lending, as China's economy struggles with slowing growth. The financing package is expected to benefit firms involved in emissions controls and water treatment, but economists remain skeptical about the impact on private cleantech firms.

site_title: World's biggest oil trader sees US$50 floor for crude prices
summary: Vitol Group, the world's largest independent oil trader, predicts US$50 is a floor price for crude oil, as producers need this level to invest in new supply. CEO Ian Taylor says prices won't drop below US$50 for sustained periods, and expect prices to trade between US$50 and US$70 a barrel in the second half of 2025. The company attributes the recent price slump to "overreaction" and believes prices will rise as US production growth slows and demand looks good for the year.

site_title: Self-driving cars hold key to future highway: Google exec
summary: Google executive Ray Kurzweil predicts that self-driving cars will revolutionize the automobile industry, reducing traffic fatalities and transforming the industry. Kurzweil believes the technology is not far away and that autonomous vehicles will save millions of lives. Despite the need for more reliable and safe technology, Kurzweil notes that Google will not introduce self-driving cars into the market until they are ready. The rapid decline in computing power and advances in artificial intelligence will make autonomous driving a reality, with the potential for increased efficiency and reduced costs.

site_title: ConocoPhillips weighs sale of North sea assets in Norway
summary: ConocoPhillips is considering the sale of its North Sea assets in Norway, potentially worth up to $1 billion. The company, the largest independent producer of oil and natural gas, may sell stakes in the Aasta Hansteen, Alvheim, and Grane fields, which are operated by others. This move follows other oil majors' willingness to buy assets on the cheap due to low oil prices, with companies like Royal Dutch Shell and Anadarko Petroleum Corp also exploring sales. ConocoPhillips has not commented on the sale, citing that it does not discuss ongoing business development or commercial activities.

site_title: Fewer US rigs may not cut shale oil output: Exxon CEO
summary: Exxon CEO Rex Tillerson stated that a decline in US oil rigs may not lead to a long-term decrease in shale oil output due to rising productivity. Despite the US oil rig count falling by half over the past year, output is expected to rise, with the US Energy Information Agency forecasting 9.18 million barrels per day at year's end. Analysts believe the market will adjust to the reduced spending and determine the real cost of producing shale oil, leading to potential output increases in 2016.

site_title: Japan court rejects request to halt restart of Kyushu Electric's Sendai reactors
summary: A Japanese court has rejected a lawsuit to halt the restart of Kyushu Electric Power's Sendai nuclear station, allowing the plant to potentially begin operations as early as June. The decision comes four years after the Fukushima disaster, with the government pushing to restart Japan's idled nuclear industry. Despite concerns over safety, the court dismissed the lawsuit, clearing another hurdle for the restart of the Sendai station.

images.alt_text: A Japanese court rejected a lawsuit to halt the restart of Kyushu Electric Power's Sendai nuclear station, plaintiffs said on Wednesday, brushing aside the concerns of local residents worried about the safety of the plant.

site_title: Yahoo's profit, revenue miss estimates; weighs options for Japan stake
summary: Yahoo Inc. missed Wall Street's revenue and profit forecasts, with display advertising revenue rising 2.3% to $463.7 million but search revenue increasing 19.5% to $531.7 million, partly due to higher traffic acquisition costs. Net income fell to $21.2 million, or 2 cents per share, from $311.6 million a year earlier. The company has hired advisers to determine the "most promising opportunities" for its stake in Yahoo Japan, which has been urged by investors to cash in, following the planned spin-off of its Alibaba Group stake.

images.alt_text: Yahoo Inc missed Wall Street's revenue and profit forecasts as slight growth in its online advertising businesses was outweighed by higher payments to partners and websites which send readers to Yahoo.

site_title: UN urges Europe to put asylum at centre of migrant debate
