summary: The UN High Commissioner for Refugees urged European leaders to prioritize the protection of migrants in the Mediterranean crisis, amid 900 deaths this weekend. The UNHCR welcomed an EU action plan, but emphasized the need for asylum component and protection of people. The plan includes reinforcing naval patrols, destroying smuggling vessels, and measures for migrants arriving in Europe. The UNHCR proposed increasing search and rescue operations, resettlement, and humanitarian channels. The plan is seen as a "first step" in a long process, with EU leaders to discuss and clarify commitments at a summit on Thursday.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Noble, CapitaCommercial Trust, Cambridge Industrial Trust
summary: Noble Group has promised greater transparency in its quarterly results, following concerns raised after its annual general meeting. Office Reit CapitaCommercial Trust reported a 3.9% increase in distribution per unit to 2.12 Singapore cents for Q1. In contrast, industrial Reit Cambridge Industrial Trust saw a 2.1% decline in distribution per unit to 1.225 Singapore cents for the same period. These announcements may impact trading of these stocks.

site_title: Singapore consumer confidence rises slightly: survey
summary: Singapore consumers have become slightly more confident, with the ANZ-Roy Morgan Singapore Consumer Confidence survey index reaching 125.7 points in April, up 1.2 points from March. 29% of respondents said their families are financially better off, while 49% expect good financial times over the next 12 months.

images.alt_text: SINGAPORE consumers have become slightly more confident, according to the ANZ-Roy Morgan Singapore Consumer Confidence survey.

site_title: Britain's highest court to hear Malaysia massacre case
summary: Britain's highest court will hear a case arguing for a public inquiry into the 1948 "Batang Kali massacre" in which 24 Malaysian villagers were killed by British troops. Relatives of the victims claim the men were deliberately executed, not insurgents trying to escape. The case seeks to establish Britain's duty to investigate historical human rights abuses, including during the Northern Irish conflict. Lawyers argue that the European Convention on Human Rights requires an independent inquiry, despite critics arguing that military operations have different norms.

site_title: Sembcorp Marine unit bags S$56m contract to convert tanker
summary: Sembcorp Marine's subsidiary Sembawang Shipyard secured a S$56 million contract to convert a shuttle tanker into a floating storage and offloading ship for Teekay. The ship is expected to arrive in June 2015 and complete in 11 months, with operations in the Norwegian North Sea under a charter contract with Statoil. The contract boost is expected to contribute to Sembcorp Marine's shares, which closed at S$3.10, up two cents.

site_title: BP said to seek bids for US$2 billion in US pipeline operations
summary: BP is seeking buyers for up to $2 billion in US pipeline operations, including four pipelines and a gas plant along the Gulf of Mexico, and 15 storage terminals in the Midwest and East Coast. The assets, which are relatively easy to sell due to their fee-based business models, will help fund drilling activities. This move follows similar efforts by Chevron and Royal Dutch Shell to sell non-drilling infrastructure.

site_title: CapitaCommercial Trust Q1 DPU at 2.12 cents, up 3.9%; CapitaGreen 76% leased
summary: CapitaCommercial Trust reported a 3.9% increase in first-quarter DPU to 2.12 cents, with revenue up 6.5% to S$68.2 million. Net property income rose 6.4%. The Reit's office building CapitaGreen secured 76.4% of its net lettable area with leases, targeting full occupancy by end-2015. The distribution yield is an annualized 5%.

site_title: Indonesia long-term growth target is very ambitious: Djalil
summary: Indonesia's economy minister, Sofyan Djalil, has pushed back a target of achieving 7% growth by 2017, calling it "very ambitious." The country aims for 5.7% growth this year, but faces challenges such as a persistent current-account deficit and a struggling rupiah. Djalil cited infrastructure spending and attracting foreign investment as key to beating the 5.4% growth forecast by Bank Indonesia. The government aims to increase tax collection to 16% of GDP, but faces skepticism from economists, including Credit Suisse, which has widened its forecast for the budget deficit to 2.4% of GDP.

site_title: Noble promises more transparency again after AGM leaves some shareholders disconcerted
summary: NOBLE Group promised more transparency after its annual general meeting (AGM) left some shareholders disconcerted. The company will increase disclosures in its first quarter 2015 results, including net fair value gains/losses by region and product. Noble will also update segmental disclosures to reflect its ongoing businesses after the 2014 Noble Agri transaction. The company aims to balance increased transparency with commercial sensitivity, following concerns raised by shareholders at the AGM. Noble's valuation of its Yancoal associate was also elaborated upon, with a value in use calculation used at a discount rate of 9%.

site_title: Banks' first-quarter trading revenue prompts cautious optimism
summary: Banks' first-quarter trading revenue showed signs of recovery, with FICC revenue almost doubling to $17.1 billion, a modest 5.9% increase from the same period last year. Analysts are cautiously optimistic, citing increased volatility and support from European Central Bank quantitative easing. The top 10 global banks saw FICC revenue rise year on year only once since 2009, and some analysts believe the investment banking earnings cycle is at a turning point. Revenue from other banking activities, such as equities and advisory services, also showed signs of improvement.

site_title: Sinopec Group sells US$4.8 billion of bonds after euro-debt issue
summary: Sinopec Group, China's largest oil refiner, sold $4.8 billion of bonds in three parts, including $2.5 billion of 2.5% five-year notes and $1.5 billion of investment-grade euro-denominated debt. The bonds were issued to refinance existing debt and for overseas business, with yields 1.25 percentage points higher than US Treasuries. Despite lower oil prices weakening credit metrics, Sinopec's diversified business and access to liquidity are expected to preserve its finances, according to Moody's Investors Service.

site_title: Fuelling a rise to the top
summary: BP has solidified its position as the largest bunker supplier in Singapore, leveraging the country's vibrant maritime ecosystem. The company's commitment to quality, safety, and customer satisfaction has earned it the Bunker Award at the Singapore International Maritime Awards. BP's global reputation and rigorous approach to safety have given customers confidence to call at Singapore's port, and the company has played a key role in developing the country's bunker market. As the shipping industry recovers, BP plans to grow its global bunker network to capture rising demand for marine fuel.

site_title: Knight Frank Singapore stays independent despite new shareholder
summary: Knight Frank Singapore remains fully independent after Aspial Corporation, a property developer and jeweller, becomes a new investor with a 10% stake. Chairman stated that a licence agreement from Knight Frank UK ensures the firm's independence. The company will still compete for projects, despite the new investor.

site_title: US authorities impose stricter screening for airport, airline workers
summary: The Transportation Security Administration (TSA) has imposed stricter regulations for airport and airline workers in response to two incidents involving smuggling of guns. A Delta Air Lines baggage handler allegedly used his security clearance to smuggle guns, and a Federal Aviation Administration employee was found to have used a badge to access a secure area and then flew with a gun in his carry-on. The new rules include random screening of all airport and airline workers, regardless of their status, and require airports to reduce access points to secure areas and subject workers to random screenings.

site_title: Germany signals eased investment rules for financial companies
summary: Germany's Finance Minister Wolfgang Schaeuble announced plans to ease investment rules for financial companies, including insurers, to invest in infrastructure projects. The government will grant "more regulatory leeway" to pools of capital that increase their capital base, allowing them to invest in real assets such as public infrastructure. This move aims to boost investment in Germany and stimulate economic growth in the euro area, where institutions have identified the country as having a "significant weakness" in private and public investment.

images.alt_text: Finance Minister Wolfgang Schaeuble signaled that Germany's government will make it easier for insurers and other financial companies to make "safe and profitable" investments, including in infrastructure projects.

site_title: US stocks sag; Teva bid for Mylan boosts pharma shares
summary: US stocks declined Tuesday, with the Dow and S&P 500 falling 0.47% and 0.15%, respectively. However, the Nasdaq Composite rose 0.39% due to a $40.1 billion cash-and-stock bid by Teva for generic drug maker Mylan, boosting Mylan shares 8.9%. Other pharma stocks, such as Merck and Novartis, also gained. The strong dollar negatively impacted global firms, including DuPont and Harley-Davidson, which cut their full-year outlooks.

site_title: Google to help search for Scotland's Loch Ness monster
summary: Google has launched a Street View series of underwater and surface images of Loch Ness, allowing users to search for the mythical monster from anywhere in the world. The project features images of Urquhart Castle, Fort Augustus Abbey, and the lake from the monster's perspective. The launch coincides with the publication of the famous "Surgeon's Photograph," which helped popularize the legend. The Scottish tourism body, VisitScotland, hailed the project as "hugely exciting" and hopes it will inspire people to visit the area.

site_title: IBM needs software unit to stop shrinking to reach profit target
summary: IBM's full-year operating profit forecast of $15.75-$16.50 per share hinges on its software business, which needs to stop shrinking. The software division saw 8% sales decline in the first quarter, with pretax income gaining only 1%. To reach the high end of the forecast, software sales must increase by double-digit growth in the final three months of the year, a challenging task given current performance.

site_title: Full speed ahead
summary: The Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore (MPA) is investing in port infrastructure and sustainable shipping practices to support the nation's growing maritime sector. The MPA is expanding Pasir Panjang Terminal and planning for future development at Tuas Terminal. Additionally, the MPA's Maritime Singapore Green Initiative aims to encourage environmentally-friendly shipping practices. The authority is also focusing on workforce development with a recent injection of S$65 million into the Maritime Cluster Fund-Manpower Development programme.

images.alt_text: The Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore (MPA) lists some of the key initiatives ahead for nation's maritime sector.

site_title: Building a solid base in S'pore
summary: Jardine Shipping Services (JSS) plans to leverage Singapore's position as a maritime hub to grow its business beyond the region. The shipping agency has a staff strength of over 150 and handles over 400 vessels annually, ranging from tankers to cruise liners. JSS aims to expand its commercial base in Singapore, capitalizing on the city-state's role as an International Maritime Centre. The company has received the Maritime Service Provider Award for exceptional performance and is pursuing marketing efforts to promote the Port of Singapore to small and medium-size shipowners.

site_title: Mercuria CEO mulls energy-asset deals with private-equity firms
summary: Mercuria Energy Group, a fourth-largest independent oil trader, is considering acquiring oil and gas production assets from private-equity firms due to weak crude prices. CEO Marco Dunand plans to spend up to $1 billion on majority or minority stakes in projects in the US, Argentina, and Nigeria. This move aims to secure long-term supplies and benefit from lower prices squeezing producers. Despite struggling to find US sellers, Dunand sees opportunities in Argentina's shale gas and Nigeria's post-election changes. Mercuria has resumed plans to sell a 20% stake in its company.

site_title: Charting a new course forward
summary: Mitsui OSK Lines (MOL), a Japanese shipping company, has a history dating back to 1884 with the founding of Osaka Shosen Kaisha (OSK). The company merged with Mitsui Steamship Co. in 1964 and now has nearly 900 vessels in its fleet. MOL has announced plans to order six container ships, set to be launched in 2017, and introduced the MOL Chart, a guide for the company's core values of Challenge, Honesty, Accountability, Reliability, and Teamwork. The chart aims to enhance corporate value and promote safety and employee ownership.

site_title: Teva makes US$40.1 billion unsolicited takeover bid for Mylan
summary: Teva Pharmaceutical Industries made a US$40.1 billion unsolicited takeover bid for Mylan, offering US$82 per share in cash and stock. The bid values Mylan at 23% above its closing price on April 16. The deal would create a generics powerhouse and re-establish Teva as the industry giant, but faces antitrust hurdles. Mylan has publicly rebuked Teva and set up a mechanism under Dutch securities law to block the takeover. The deal is contingent on Mylan ending its pursuit of Perrigo, which rejected Mylan's US$28.9 billion bid.

images.alt_text: Teva Pharmaceutical Industries made an unsolicited offer to buy Mylan for about US$40.1 billion, in the drug industry's largest takeover attempt this year.

site_title: Yum profit tops estimates as China sales fall less than forecast
summary: Yum! Brands, the parent company of KFC and Taco Bell, reported a first-quarter profit of 80 US cents per share, beating analyst estimates. China sales, which had previously declined 16% in the fourth quarter, fell 12% in the first quarter, better than predicted. The company's efforts to revamp its Chinese business, including new menu items and improved food safety, appear to be paying off. Shares rose in extended trading, climbing 11% for the year to date.

site_title: Facebook shifts News Feed, gives priority to friends
summary: Facebook is reconfiguring its News Feed to prioritize content from "friends you care about," aiming to reduce reliance on referral traffic. The changes will display more content directly from friends, such as photos and status updates, and reduce commentary on posts. To make room, commentary on news stories and other posts will be pushed down or removed. Facebook is also relaxing its rule on multiple posts from the same source, allowing users to see more content. The changes aim to improve the user experience, particularly for those with limited content availability.

images.alt_text: Facebook said Tuesday it was reconfiguring its News Feed, in a move aimed at giving people more information about what is happening to "the friends you care about."

site_title: Europe: Shares get earnings lift, Greece lags
summary: European shares rose 0.5% on Tuesday, driven by strong company earnings updates, with Publicis, Sky, and ARM Holdings seeing significant gains. The European market is heading for its best earnings season in four years, outperforming US counterparts due to the weak euro and ECB's bond-buying stimulus. However, the Greek stock market fell 3.3% as concerns over its banking sector mounted, with a Bloomberg report suggesting the ECB may increase the haircut on security offered to Greek banks.

site_title: REC inks solar power purchase deal with Stolthaven Singapore
summary: REC, a global solar energy solutions provider, has signed a 25-year power purchase agreement (PPA) with Stolthaven Singapore, a bulk-liquid transportation and storage company. The deal involves a 187 kWp rooftop solar installation, which will provide cost-effective access to environmentally friendly power for the company. REC will bear the installation and maintenance costs, and the agreement is expected to be completed by the third quarter of this year. This is the first-of-its-kind PPA contract for the industry in Singapore.

site_title: Mutual funds buy more S'pore stocks
summary: Global mutual funds purchased more Singapore stocks than they sold in the three months to April 15, with net buys of S$918.1 million and net sells of S$738 million. In the segment of stocks with less than S$1 billion market capitalisation, mutual funds had net buys of S$53.1 million and net sells of S$46.7 million. Rex International Holding was the top buy, while Parkson Retail Asia was the top sell. The data, provided by ShareInvestor and Ipreo, offers insight into mutual fund transactions and their market focus.

site_title: Top China trainmaker eyes UK rail line contracts
summary: China's top trainmaker, CSR Corp, plans to bid for contracts on Britain's £50 billion High Speed 2 rail line, including rolling stock and services. The company aims to build and maintain 360 kmph trains and could also build the track and manage the network. This move is part of China's strategy to turn home-grown expertise into export revenue, targeting both developed and emerging markets. CSR faces competition from European rivals such as Alstom SA and Siemens AG, with the first phase of HS2 set to begin in 2017.

site_title: Straits Trading sets up unit to trade real estate securities
summary: Straits Trading has established SRE Capital, a unit focused on real estate investment and management. The new subsidiary will start with a dividend-paying fund investing in Reits and other real estate securities in the Asia-Pacific, with an initial seed capital of $130 million. SRE Capital aims to yield 8-10% returns and manage risks through capital rotation and hedging strategies. The fund is managed by Stephen Ray Finch, who expects the region to be fairly valued, and will focus on larger Reit markets in Japan and Singapore.

site_title: A global conversation for the maritime sector
summary: Singapore Maritime Week 2015, held from April 21 to 24, brings together industry leaders and stakeholders to discuss key trends and challenges in the maritime sector. The event, now in its 10th anniversary, features 30 events covering topics such as shipping, offshore, and maritime security. With around 54,000 participants, the event aims to promote thought leadership, networking, and collaboration among maritime professionals. The week celebrates Singapore's position as an international maritime centre and showcases its growth in the sector, which has developed an ecosystem of various maritime businesses and services.

site_title: A century-old relationship
summary: Mitsui OSK Lines, a Japanese shipping company, has maintained a century-old relationship with Singapore, with its Singapore arm, Mitsui OSK Bulk Shipping (Asia Oceania), operating over 150 vessels in the country each month. The company credits Singapore's strategic position and business-friendly environment for its success, with plans to continue using the city-state as a launchpad for regional expansion. Mitsui OSK Lines has won several awards for its contributions to Singapore's development as an international maritime centre, and its CEO notes that the company's commitment to safe operations and innovation will help it navigate industry challenges.

site_title: Saudi oil production near record high in April, says minister
summary: Saudi Arabia is producing near record levels of crude oil in April, with Minister Ali Al-Naimi stating the country is pumping around 10 million barrels per day. This move could potentially snuff out a recent rebound in oil prices, particularly with economic growth in China slowing down. Despite concerns, Al-Naimi is confident that demand will continue to grow, and Saudi Arabia is committed to supplying its customers with what they need. Oil prices have risen around 17% this month, but Morgan Stanley warns that Saudi production may be more important than US output in driving the market.

site_title: Investors should be careful about warning signs of rising financial risk
summary: Global investors should be cautious of warning signs of rising financial risk, including intensifying risks in the global financial system, huge bubbles in risky assets, and increasing worry about the stability of the global economy. The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has issued its second warning in six months about these risks, citing volatility in exchange rates and concerns about overvaluation in equity and bond markets. Investors are advised to be aware of the limitations of central bank action and the warning signs surrounding equity markets.

site_title: A pioneer unafraid of rough seas
summary: Shipping veteran Y C Chang, 96, has been honored for his contributions to Singapore's maritime sector. Chang founded Pacific International Lines (PIL) in 1967 and built it into the largest private shipping line in South-east Asia. He played a key role in developing Singapore's maritime sector, helping to alleviate unemployment and contributing to the country's growth through his company's logistics, shipping fund, and container manufacturing. Chang's humility, hard work, and loyalty have earned him the International Maritime Centre Award, with his son, Teo Siong Seng, describing him as a "pioneer unafraid of rough seas."

images.alt_text: "Our ships would get searched all the time, and our people were roughly handled. But my father said that no matter what, we have to continue to service the port (of Aqaba in Jordan). He was thinking of the friendships he had built up there with the customers." - Teo Siong Seng on his father YC Chang's (above) perseverance during the Iraq-Kuwait war

"Our ships would get searched all the time, and our people were roughly handled. But my father said that no matter what, we have to continue to service the port (of Aqaba in Jordan). He was thinking of the friendships he had built up there with the customers." - Teo Siong Seng (above) on his father YC Chang's perseverance during the Iraq-Kuwait war

site_title: Global business, local talent
summary: Oldendorff Carriers, a German-based shipping company, has grown its operations in Singapore from 19 employees to over 130 in eight years. The company, which has been in the bulk carrier business since 1921, manages its own fleet and offers ship management and consultancy services to third parties. It handles around 300 million tons of cargo annually and operates approximately 500 vessels worldwide, calling at over 14,000 ports in 125 countries.

images.alt_text: From far left: Thomas Antony (operations director - Capesize), Venise Wong (trainee), Xiaoyi Shan (operations manager), Miley Lin (operations manager), Michael Dos Santos (senior operations manager - trainer) and Johnny Ang (trainee).

(From left) Xiaoyi Shan, who has completed Oldendorff's training programme and become an operations manager; Alice Klever, Learning and Development HR manager; and Mark Joubert, operations director - Handymax and Handysize.

site_title: US, Japan fail to seal trade accord before Abe's trip to Washington
summary: US and Japanese officials failed to reach an agreement on a trade accord in Tokyo, hindering Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's hopes of arriving in Washington with a pact in hand. The talks, which concluded around 4am, were stalled over differences on auto and rice imports. This setback makes it less likely that the two nations will secure a deal on the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) this year, a broader Asia-Pacific agreement involving 10 other nations.

site_title: James Murdoch may soon ascend at Fox
summary: Saudi Prince Alwaleed bin Talal, a Murdoch family ally, says James Murdoch is ready to take a larger role at 21st Century Fox, citing his ability to grasp the digital world and understand the media landscape. Prince Alwaleed's endorsement may lead to James Murdoch taking over as co-CEO alongside Chase Carey, potentially as early as the end of this year, according to a person familiar with the family's thinking. However, the change has not been formalized and may be subject to delay.

site_title: Higher rentals, occupancies boost Mapletree Industrial's Q4 DPU
summary: Mapletree Industrial Trust reported a 5.6% increase in distribution per unit to 2.65 Singapore cents for its Q4 2015. Gross revenue rose 5.6% to S$79.4 million, driven by higher rental rates and occupancies. Net property income increased 8.4% to S$57.8 million, while net asset value per unit rose 8% to S$1.32. The Reit expects a mixed outlook for the industrial property market in 2015, with rents easing for multi-user developments and strengthening for business parks and higher specification buildings.

site_title: Jump-starts for Spintronics and S'pore-based startups
summary: Singapore's tech ecosystem has received significant funding boosts. The Singapore Spintronics Consortium has secured S$5 million in funding from the National Research Foundation to develop spintronics technology. Meanwhile, Singapore-based startup TradeGecko has raised US$6.5 million in Series A funding to support growth, expanding to over 200 employees and establishing new offices in the US, Australia, and Hong Kong.

site_title: Hubble is revolutionising the way we look at space
summary: Hubble, the pioneering telescope, marks its 25th year in space, revolutionizing modern astronomy and offering glimpses of distant galaxies. Astronomer Jennifer Wiseman praises Hubble's impact on human understanding of the universe, stating it has "changed the way humans look at the universe and our place in it."

site_title: Vietnam to raise ceiling on foreign holdings in banks
summary: Vietnam's Prime Minister Nguyen Tan Dung announced plans to lift the 30% foreign ownership cap in local banks, allowing foreigners to buy stakes above this limit. This move aims to attract more foreign investors and rebuild the financial sector, which has been affected by bad debt and real estate issues. The change is part of Vietnam's broader liberalization program, including state sector privatization and increased foreign investment. The move is expected to expand the market and help Vietnamese banks gain more control and access to financial investors.

site_title: US, Chinese investors buy Cirque du Soleil
summary: US private equity firm TPG and Chinese investor Fosun have acquired Cirque du Soleil for an undisclosed sum, with TPG holding 60% and Fosun 20%. The deal values Cirque du Soleil at $1.5 billion. Founder Guy Laliberte retains a small stake and will continue providing strategic and creative input. The Quebec government also acquired a 10% stake in exchange for assurances the company's head office and creative team remain in Canada. The acquisition aims to expand Cirque du Soleil's presence in Asia and license intellectual property to third parties.

site_title: US war of ideas to have long-term impact
summary: The US is experiencing a transformation in its approach to global affairs, with the GOP emerging as pro-free trade and pro-military intervention, while Democrats are shifting towards protectionism and isolationism. This shift is reflected in the current congressional debate over President Obama's trade policies, including the proposed Trans-Pacific Partnership. While the White House hopes for bipartisan support, centrist Democrats are increasingly opposed to free trade, and the party is moving to the left. This shift has significant implications for US global policies in the coming years, potentially limiting the ability of Republican and Democratic presidents to promote new trade initiatives.

site_title: Unit of Chengdu-based HAITE opens aviation training centre here
summary: HAITE Aviation Training Singapore, a subsidiary of Sichuan Haite High-Tech Co, has launched a S$95.3 million aviation-training centre in Changi Business Park. The facility, which will train pilots and aviation-related crew, is expected to attract up to S$55 million in direct and indirect revenues each year over the next five years. The centre will deliver nearly 50,000 hours of training annually and plans to expand to house seven bays, partnering with Baltic Aviation Academy to offer courses to commercial airlines in South-east Asia.

site_title: US dollar ticks up despite rate hike uncertainty
summary: The US dollar rose to 119.44 yen on Tuesday, despite a Federal Reserve official's comments casting doubt on a mid-year interest rate hike. The euro slipped to $1.0734, while the euro strengthened to 128.20 yen. The dollar's gain was attributed to uncertainty surrounding the interest rate hike, while Greece's bailout woes held back the euro.

site_title: The mystery of China's gold stash may soon be solved
summary: China is believed to have tripled its gold stash to 3,510 tonnes, potentially to diversify its US$3.7 trillion in foreign-exchange reserves. This move may challenge US dominance in global trade and finance. China's push to promote the yuan as a viable competitor to the US dollar could be supported by the addition of gold and other assets to its central bank reserves. A larger gold holding could boost market sentiment and provide support for prices, currently languishing.

images.alt_text: The People's Bank of China may have tripled holdings of bullion since it last updated them in April 2009, to 3,510 tonnes, says Bloomberg Intelligence.

site_title: China overhauling IPO process: report
summary: China is set to overhaul its IPO process, adopting a "registration system" where the market decides who gets to list, when, and for how much. This shift will eliminate the need for official approval, allowing companies to register with stock exchanges to float shares. The change aims to address corruption and share price volatility, and will require companies to show profit and earnings sustainability, as well as clean criminal records. The move is also seen as a step towards creating an "international board" for foreign companies.

site_title: StanChart not selling stake in Indonesia's Bank Permata
summary: Standard Chartered has stated it has no intention to sell its 45% stake in Indonesia's Bank Permata Tbk, according to CEO for Asean Lim Cheng Teck. This comes as the lender has been reviewing its Asian banking assets amid plans to boost capital. StanChart had previously shut its global equities business in January, sparking speculation about the sale of stakes in Asian banks.

site_title: Emerging markets to outperform: Mobius
summary: Emerging markets are expected to outperform developed markets this year, according to Mark Mobius, executive chairman of Templeton Emerging Markets Group. EM has returned 8% so far this year, compared to the World Index's 4.06% and S&P 500's 2.6%. Mobius attributes the recovery to lower government debt, increased foreign reserves, and rating agency upgrades. Templeton Asset Management's private equity investments in EM are also expected to perform well, with a double-digit internal rate of return (IRR) forecasted for its latest fund.

site_title: China's Finance Minister hits out at US 'negative list'
summary: China's Finance Minister Lou Jiwei criticized the US proposal for a Bilateral Investment Treaty (BIT) due to the lack of specific definitions in the "negative list," which outlines prohibitions on foreign investment. The US list includes prohibitions on key infrastructure, technology, and national security investment. China's Vice-Finance Minister Zhu Guangyao expects China and the US to exchange "negative list" offers in the next month, with substantial progress expected in September during a meeting between Chinese President Xi Jinping and US President Barack Obama.

site_title: STATS ChipPAC pares loss to US$2.1m in Q1
summary: STATS ChipPAC, a semiconductor packaging and test services company, reported a net loss of US$2.1 million in its Q1, down 86.7% from US$15.8 million last year, on revenue of US$371 million, a 1.5% increase. The company attributed the revenue growth to emerging market handsets and new high-performance smartphones. Gross margin and operating margin were 10.5% and 2.1%, respectively. The company also reduced debt to US$1.19 billion and increased cash reserves to US$197.1 million.

site_title: A journey of growth
summary: Swire Pacific Offshore Operations (SPO) has grown its fleet to nearly 100 vessels since establishing its presence in Singapore four decades ago. The Singapore-headquartered group provides marine services to the offshore oil and gas and renewables industries. SPO has expanded its services to include salvage, seismic survey, and subsea support, and has received several awards for its contributions to the maritime sector. Despite the current downturn in the industry due to low oil prices, SPO remains committed to delivering safe and high-quality services, and has no plans to reduce its investment in personnel training and development.

images.alt_text: SPO has helped develop industry-leading training programmes in Singapore and in 2007, it established a centre here that serves as the global training hub for its seafarers. The bulk of the training delivered at the centre focuses on safety, operational excellence and reliability.

SPO has helped develop industry-leading training programmes in Singapore and in 2007, it established a centre here that serves as the global training hub (above) for its seafarers. The bulk of the training delivered at the centre focuses on safety, operational excellence and reliability.

site_title: Short sellers of US stocks hit hard by resilient market
summary: Short sellers of US stocks have been hit hard by the resilient market, with major indices less than 2% from all-time highs. Despite concerns over slow growth and potential debt defaults, the US stock market has performed well, with most sectors benefiting from ultra-low interest rates. Dedicated short funds have been particularly affected, with Credit Suisse's short-biased index down 4.4% and market-neutral index off 1.6% by the end of March. Long-short equity funds have shifted towards long bets, pulling back on unprofitable short positions, while Tesla Motors remains a favourite of shorts, with some stocks rebounding aggressively.

site_title: One tanker attacked in S-E Asia every 2 weeks: piracy watchdog
summary: Pirates in South-east Asia are attacking one small coastal oil tanker every two weeks, with 38 incidents reported in the first quarter of 2015, a 70% increase from the global total of 54. The attacks, mainly targeting fuel cargoes, have resulted in 140 seafarers being taken hostage and 13 crew members being assaulted. Indonesian waters remain the most piracy-prone, with 21 attacks. The International Maritime Bureau warns that attacks could increase further if the problem is not addressed, emphasizing the need for a robust and coordinated regional response.

site_title: Tech companies set to net US$320b
summary: US technology companies, particularly those on the Nasdaq 100 Index, are expected to generate $320 billion in profits this year, a significant increase from the industry's peak in the Internet craze. Despite concerns over valuation, investors remain optimistic, with 80% of tech companies reporting profits exceeding analysts' estimates. The Nasdaq 100 is within 8% of retaking its record high set in 2000, with 13 years of steady growth since the dotcom collapse. Companies like Microsoft, Facebook, and Google are expected to drive this growth, with analysts forecasting strong earnings and sales expansion.

site_title: Building on a green heritage
summary: Philips, a Dutch technology giant, has been prioritizing sustainability since its inception. The company aims to improve the lives of three billion people by 2025 through innovative products and services. Philips is focusing on energy-efficient solutions, material use, and healthier lifestyle solutions. The company has set a goal to reduce its own carbon emissions by 40% by 2015 and has invested €463 million in green product development. Philips is also offering a zero-capital-expenditure scheme to help customers reduce energy consumption, with a focus on creating a "circular economy" that decouples economic growth from natural resources.

site_title: A long history of client-focused solutions
summary: ING Investment Management International rebranded to NN Investment Partners on April 7, 2015, as part of NN Group NV. The asset manager manages approximately 186 billion euros in assets globally, employing over 1,100 staff across 16 countries. NN Investment Partners has a deep heritage dating back to 1845, with a focus on client-focused asset management and responsible investing.

site_title: Home prices in Australian mining towns slump
summary: Australian mining towns are experiencing a housing market downturn due to the decline of the mining boom. Home prices in coal-rich regions, such as Blackwater and Port Hedland, have plummeted by 57% and 23% respectively, with median prices now under $200,000. The slowdown is attributed to China's shift from heavy industry to household consumption, causing steel prices to drop and leading to job cuts at coal mines. This has resulted in a surge in unsold properties, with some towns facing over 16 years to clear their property overhang.

site_title: Clearing the fog hanging over the Chinese property market
summary: Beijing has taken measures to prevent the Chinese property market from imploding, following recent sector weakness and the default of Kaisa, a mid-sized Shenzhen-based developer. The company's financial woes are linked to China's two-year anti-corruption drive, with allegations that Kaisa is being probed for ties to a corrupt local official. Despite concerns of a property bubble, the government has shown no intention of allowing the sector to collapse. The government's actions suggest that it will continue to support the market, ensuring its stability and preventing a potential economic crisis.

site_title: Indian Hotels sees profit in two years
summary: Indian Hotels Co, owner of the Pierre hotel, expects to turn profitable in two years by selling assets and reducing debt. The company plans to sell its stake in Orient-Express Hotels and pare down its overseas assets. CEO Rakesh Sarna aims to build a financial foundation slowly, avoiding reckless decisions that could harm the company's long-term prospects. The company has posted annual losses for four out of the past five years and has dropped 13% in shares since January due to concerns about its debt and asset mix.

site_title: China close to first bond default by state-owned firm
summary: China's Baoding Tianwei Group Co, a state-owned power-transformer maker, is at risk of defaulting on a 5.7% bond due on Tuesday. The company cited "big uncertainty" about making interest payments, sparking concerns about the country's onshore bond market. This would be the first default by a state-owned firm in the domestic market, following previous defaults by privately owned companies. The move has raised questions about China's efforts to open up the economy to market forces and reduce government control.

site_title: Top Pulitzer award goes to small Carolina paper
summary: The Post and Courier of Charleston, South Carolina, won the Pulitzer Prize for public service for its series "Till Death Do Us Part," which exposed the high number of deaths resulting from domestic abuse in the state. The series, which began with a 1925 Pulitzer win, was the first to go to a small newspaper in five years. The award was announced on April 20, 2015.

site_title: Global cooperation, or the lack of it
summary: Singapore Maritime Week 2015 highlighted the challenges of global cooperation in maritime regulations. International Chamber of Shipping chairman Masamichi Morooka criticized the US and EU for adopting regulations at variance with global maritime conventions, particularly the Ballast Water Management Convention. He warned that this could lead to an "impossible dilemma" for ships, and urged cooperation to avoid conflicting regulations. In contrast, a Port Authorities Roundtable and a memorandum of understanding between the Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore and the Port of Rotterdam Authority demonstrated collaboration and cooperation in the industry.

site_title: Binjai Rise GCB site put up for auction by lender
summary: A 17,035-square-foot freehold site at 15 Binjai Rise in Singapore is set to be auctioned off by a Hong Kong-based bank on April 29. The indicative price is S$20 million, or S$1,174 per square foot, with potential costs to complete the redevelopment ranging from S$1 million to S$6 million. This marks the first GCB site to be put up for auction in at least five years, but industry experts believe it is unlikely to spark a trend of mortgagee sales of GCBs.

site_title: ECB said to be studying curbs on Greek bank aid
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is studying measures to reduce emergency funding for Greek banks amid growing resistance to further aid. Staff have proposed increasing discounts on securities used as collateral, known as "haircuts," which could lead to reduced funding for Greek lenders. The ECB aims to rein in emergency funding, with a two-thirds majority required to restrict or veto assistance. The bank's patience with Greece is growing, and policymakers are seeking reforms in exchange for aid to keep the country in the eurozone.

site_title: Swiss hotel schools keep their edge
summary: Swiss hotel schools have maintained their reputation for excellence despite high fees. For over a century, these institutions have attracted students from around the world. The learning experience for students is immersive, with real-life scenarios and interactions with instructors and peers. This hands-on approach allows students to develop the skills needed to succeed in the hospitality industry. The unique environment helps to set these schools apart from others, ensuring their continued popularity among aspiring hotel professionals.

site_title: Greece battens down the hatches as potential default and Grexit loom
summary: Greece is facing a high-stakes financial crisis, with the potential for default and exit from the eurozone. The country has tapped into its cash reserves to pay civil service salaries and pensions, and has made plans to nationalize the banking sector and introduce a parallel currency. European finance ministers are set to meet on Friday, and the IMF has warned that a Greek exit from the eurozone could have significant economic fallout for Europe, with estimates suggesting a contraction in eurozone GDP of at least 1.5%. The Greek government's failure to agree new loans with creditors may increase the likelihood of Grexit, which could have far-reaching implications for the eurozone.

site_title: Penny play shows signs of flagging
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) rebounded 5.36 points to 3,508.61 after Monday's 21-point sell-off, driven by gains in the Jardine stable. However, the penny-stock run appears to be losing steam, with a mild decline in trading volume and a slight increase in the average stock price to S$0.65. Analysts attribute the loss of momentum to proprietary desk traders, who typically "hit and run" on their trades. Despite this, some stocks, such as CapitaLand, showed gains, with Nomura upgrading its target price to S$4.49.

site_title: Analysts see Kaisa's bond default as isolated event
summary: Kaisa Group Holdings Ltd, a Hong Kong-listed developer, defaulted on interest payments of US$52 million on its 2017 and 2018 bonds. Analysts consider this an isolated event and unlikely to trigger an immediate crisis, citing Kaisa's specific issues and the sector's increasing transparency through offshore bond funding. While Moody's Investors Service and Standard & Poor's warn of increased refinancing risk, others view the downturn as cyclical. China's property sector continues to face challenges, including weakening growth and declining home prices, but analysts do not foresee a systemic crisis.

site_title: Omni-channel strategies for Singapore retailers
summary: Singapore retailers must adapt to e-commerce and mobile payments to engage modern-day consumers. As of 2014, retail e-commerce hit S$3.6 billion, with 50% of traffic coming from mobile phones. The Economic Development Board (EDB) aims to drive e-commerce among Singapore companies, while omni-channel retailing integrates physical and digital platforms for a flexible shopping experience. Retailers should consider strategies such as cross-border e-commerce, social media presence, and mobile app optimization to reach new consumers and capitalize on the growing e-commerce market.

site_title: Google adds 'mobile friendliness' to its search criteria
summary: Google has added "mobile friendliness" to its search criteria, downgrading websites that don't meet its norms, starting a months-long warning period. Websites with shortcomings like hard-to-click links or lopsided sites will see their rankings tumble. Google's mobile search results account for half of its traffic, and the company is shifting to mobile devices as the dominant portal for internet use. The change has significant implications for businesses, with many at risk of losing rankings, and is seen as a wake-up call to adapt to changing user behavior.

site_title: AirAsia X to compensate passengers after quitting Adelaide
summary: AirAsia X has agreed to compensate passengers who were inconvenienced by its decision to quit direct flights to Adelaide, Australia. The airline has reimbursed travellers who were forced to cancel, rebook on other airlines, or make their own way to other Australian cities. The decision to quit Adelaide was made in January, following a "significant number" of complaints from authorities.

site_title: China to create more jobs as economy slows
summary: China's cabinet has pledged to implement proactive employment policies amid slowing economic growth, with annual growth hitting a six-year low of 7% in the first quarter. The government aims to support companies by offering tax breaks and help rural migrant workers start new businesses. Capital outflows quickened to a two-year high, with China's central bank and commercial banks selling a net 156.5 billion yuan worth of foreign currency in March. The move follows data showing China's foreign currency reserves fell by US$110 billion in the first quarter to US$3.73 trillion.

site_title: OOIL chairman: Merger with NOL unlikely
summary: OOIL chairman Tung Chee-chen stated that a merger with NOL is unlikely due to the complexity of integrating two large companies. Instead, he expects more mergers and acquisitions among smaller firms seeking economies of scale. The two companies, which are part of the G6 shipping alliance, have already collaborated on asset sharing, reducing the need for a merger. If OOIL were to merge, it would likely target other G6 alliance members rather than firms outside the alliance.

site_title: More trade to realise full Asia-Africa potential: Joko
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo called for improved cooperation and policies to unlock the full potential of Asia-Africa trade, citing the regions' high population and GDP but low trade figures. The two regions have seen a 100-fold increase in trade over the last quarter century, but only 26% of Asian exports and 3% of African exports reach each other's markets. To address this, Indonesia is setting up a new Asian-African Business Council, aiming to facilitate trade and investment between the two regions.

site_title: The incredible, enduring power of Moore's Law
summary: Gordon Moore predicted in 1965 that the number of electronic components on integrated circuits would double every year for a decade. This forecast, known as Moore's Law, has held true, with the number of components increasing exponentially since then. By 1975, the number was expected to reach 65,000, a prediction that has driven the rapid advancement of computing power. Moore's Law has been a driving force behind technological innovation, demonstrating the unpredictable nature of technological progress and the need for adaptability in the face of unforeseen changes.

site_title: Perennial, IJM plan 'iconic' Penang project
summary: Perennial Real Estate Holdings and IJM Land Bhd have partnered for a RM3 billion (S$1.12 billion) project in Penang, Malaysia. The 50-50 joint venture will develop a 1.4-million-square-foot waterfront site into a large-scale integrated mixed-use development, featuring retail, entertainment, and residential components. The project, positioned as Penang's first mega integrated waterfront icon, is expected to be completed in phases starting 2018 and will boost the state's tourism and economic standing.

site_title: Fed mulls further curbs on officials crossing over to Wall St
summary: The Federal Reserve is considering tougher measures to restrict bank examiners from leaving to take jobs at firms they have overseen. Currently, only the top two staff assigned to a bank are barred from joining a firm they examined for one year after leaving the central bank system. The proposed change aims to prevent "regulatory capture" and address criticism that the Fed is too deferential to large banks. The move could have a significant impact on the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, which oversees Wall Street firms.

site_title: SIAS joins Protiviti-SAC Coso Academy as strategic partner
summary: The Securities Investors Association (Singapore) has joined the Protiviti-SAC Coso Academy as its strategic partner. The academy, launched last year, aims to equip company directors and executives with better understanding of Coso frameworks, promoting sound corporate governance practices in Singapore. The partnership will support investor education programs and showcase the effectiveness of Coso Frameworks to the business community. This collaboration will raise awareness of the Coso Frameworks among investors and enhance corporate governance in Singapore.

site_title: 'Business as normal' in world economy as Greek default nears
summary: The World Bank and IMF spring meetings in Washington showed little concern about potential economic disturbances, including a possible Greek default, US interest rate hikes, and a slowdown in the Chinese economy. Greek finance minister Yanis Varoufakis failed to make an impact, unlike previous years, and the issue of a default was not discussed in the International Monetary and Financial Committee. Despite this, there are indications of turning points, including six key issues investors should focus on. The meetings suggest a sense of complacency among central bankers and finance ministers.

site_title: Shaky outlook dampens German investor sentiment
summary: German investor confidence unexpectedly fell to 53.3 in April, the first decline in six months, due to the uncertainty from Greece's debt crisis. This drop was lower than economists' forecast of a rise to 55.3. The ZEW Center for European Economic Research's index aims to predict economic developments six months in advance, indicating potential concerns for Europe's largest economy.

site_title: Technology to spawn the next black swan: BlackRock CEO
summary: BlackRock CEO Larry Fink warns that technology's inability to create jobs fast enough will lead to global instability, particularly in developing countries. He cites the impact of automation on sectors like manufacturing and agriculture, which are critical to growing middle classes. Fink also notes that regulators and governments are not yet aware of the technology's impact on economies, and that the US has a competitive edge in education, which will help it adapt to technological changes.

site_title: Bond market's 'dumb money' looks smart in US$350b shift
summary: The US bond market, particularly Treasuries, has seen a significant shift of $350 billion in recent months, with many market participants attributing this move to "dumb money" or retail investors. Despite concerns about low yields, high interest rates, and expensive prices, this shift has left many institutional investors wondering why they are missing out. The trend suggests that retail investors are driving the market, and experts predict that this trend will continue, potentially altering the dynamics of the bond market and safe-haven assets.

site_title: SAP operating profit in Q1 up 15% to 1.06b euros
summary: SAP reported a 15% rise in operating profit to 1.06 billion euros in Q1, driven by a cheap euro and solid business in European markets. Revenue rose 22% to 4.5 billion euros, beating analyst expectations. However, operating margin fell to 23.5% due to increased investments in cloud-based software, which requires higher initial costs. This contrasts with IBM's 12th consecutive quarter of revenue decline as it sheds unprofitable businesses to focus on cloud computing.

site_title: Russia's economy shrank by 2% in Q1, says PM Medvedev
summary: Russia's economy shrank by 2% in Q1 due to sanctions pressure and low oil prices, according to PM Dmitry Medvedev. This would be the first quarterly contraction since 2009. The government warned lawmakers that the situation could worsen further, with a predicted 4% economy shrinkage in 2015 if oil prices remain around $50 per barrel. The crisis has led to a decline in social welfare, growing unemployment, and bankruptcies, forcing the government to dip into reserves and consider raising retirement age.

site_title: Noble unit investing in 3 Indonesian companies
summary: Commodity trader Noble Group is investing in three Indonesian companies, PT Sriwijaya Inti Daya (SID), PT Sriwijaya Multi Terminal (SMT), and PT Karimata Baru Terminal (KBT), to form a fuel storage and distribution network in Sumatra and Java regions. Noble will hold a 51% stake in SID and 49% stakes in SMT and KBT, with a total investment of US$7.5 million. The move aims to meet demand from the palm oil, power, and mining industries, following Noble's efforts to improve profitability and transparency after facing recent accounting scrutiny.

site_title: More small-car owners renewing their COEs
summary: The number of Singaporeans revalidating their Certificate of Entitlement (COE) for their ageing small cars surged in March, with 285 Category A cars and 118 Category B cars opting for a 5-year extension instead of a 10-year renewal. This comes as owners of smaller and cheaper cars struggle to afford the 40% cash downpayment required for a new car, with the 5-year COE option costing significantly less. However, owners must consider higher road taxes and limited insurance coverage for cars over 10 years old.

site_title: TPP will create a quarter of a million US jobs: business group
summary: The Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) is expected to create nearly a quarter of a million US jobs due to increased foreign investment, according to a business group. The deal would boost US employment by 68,000 direct jobs and 165,000 indirect and induced jobs from foreign spending. California, Texas, and New York are likely to see the biggest employment boosts. However, Democrats and consumer groups have raised concerns that trade pacts can lead to job losses, citing previous agreements such as NAFTA.

site_title: US Fed plays down liftoff timing for hike in interest rates
summary: The US Federal Reserve has signaled that it will maintain an accommodative monetary policy for a long time, prioritizing the pace of interest rate hikes over the exact timing. Chair Janet Yellen and her colleagues have ruled out a rate increase at the next meeting, but have left the door open for a move in June or later. The Fed aims to avoid premature tightening, which could cause economic growth to falter, and instead plans a gradual pace of tightening, with the funds rate expected to reach 1.875% by the end of 2016 and 3.125% by the end of 2017.

site_title: CapitaMall Trust's Q1 DPU rises 4.3%
summary: CapitaMall Trust reported a 4.3% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) for its first quarter, reaching 2.68 Singapore cents, driven by strong tenant sales and a 4.2% growth in distributable income to S$92.9 million. Occupancy rate decreased to 97.2% due to a drop in Clarke Quay. The trust's gross revenue and net property income also increased, while average cost of debt and aggregate leverage remained stable. The trust will continue to focus on sustaining DPU growth and exploring new opportunities.

site_title: HP says to sell photo sharing service Snapfish
summary: HP will sell its photo sharing service Snapfish to digital imaging company District Photo for undisclosed financial terms. HP acquired Snapfish for over $300 million in 2005 and made it part of its printing and personal systems group. The sale follows HP's plan to separate its computer and printer businesses from its corporate hardware and services operations this year. The deal marks the end of HP's ownership of Snapfish, which was first launched in 2005.

site_title: US: Earnings beats lift Wall St at open
summary: US stocks opened higher on Tuesday, lifting Wall Street, as companies beat lowered earnings expectations, easing fears of a disappointing quarter. The Dow Jones rose 0.35%, the S&P 500 gained 0.43%, and the Nasdaq Composite added 0.65%. This marked a positive start to the week, following recent record highs.

site_title: Continental sees 700,000 barrel a day decline in US oil output
summary: US oil output may decline by as much as 700,000 barrels per day over the next year due to cost-cutting measures by producers, including Continental Resources Inc. CEO Harold Hamm stated that daily crude output from the three largest US basins has begun to decline. This decline will lead to higher oil prices, and it may take about six months for producers to ramp up drilling in response. The price "roller coaster" for oil and fuels is expected to continue.

site_title: Flawless 100-carat diamond could fetch US$25m at NY auction
summary: A 100-carat, flawless emerald-cut diamond is set to be auctioned off in New York, potentially selling for up to $25 million. The diamond, mined by De Beers in southern Africa, is one of only five of similar quality and size to ever be sold at auction. The diamond, graded as D color, is considered "the definition of perfection" by Gary Schuler, head of Sotheby's jewelry department in New York. The auction is expected to draw significant attention and interest from collectors and investors.

site_title: Huawei CEO says Chinese cybersecurity rules could backfire
summary: Huawei CEO Eric Xu has expressed concerns that China's cybersecurity rules, aimed at promoting domestic technology, could backfire by limiting opportunities for foreign technology firms and hindering innovation. Xu stated that China's information security can only be ensured by keeping its market open to the best technology products, regardless of their origin. He warned that domestic-only solutions could lead to inferior security measures, echoing concerns raised by US business lobbies and the White House.

site_title: Latest earnings
summary: US President Trump's 50% copper import tariff is expected to cover refined metal. Oil prices rose over 2% due to market uncertainty and ongoing tariffs. In the US, stocks edged down from records amid Trump's tariff threats. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times. Creative Technology warned of potential H2 revenue below target, with similar operating losses to H1. London's Heathrow airport is considering higher fees for its £10 billion upgrade.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: US President Trump has imposed a 50% tariff on copper imports, covering refined metal. Oil prices rose over 2% as investors weigh market outlook, tariffs, and sanctions. The US stock market edged down from records amid tariff threats. In Singapore, NTT DC Reit's public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed. Creative Technology warned of potential H2 revenue below target, with similar operating losses as in H1. London's Heathrow airport plans to increase fees for a £10 billion upgrade.

site_title: Google lobbying spending reached new high in early 2015
summary: Google spent a record US$5.5 million on lobbying in the first quarter of 2015, surpassing its 2014 spending of US$16.8 million. The company ranked ninth in total lobbying spending that year, behind the US Chamber of Commerce and the National Association of Realtors. Google's increased lobbying activity comes amid charges from the European Union that the company demoted rivals in search results. The disclosure highlights Google's growing influence in Washington, D.C.

site_title: Oil unlikely to hit new 2015 lows: traders
summary: Commodities traders expect oil prices to weaken again, but are unlikely to hit new 2015 lows, citing strengthening demand. Brent crude oil, which dropped 60% to around $45 a barrel in January, may dip briefly but has likely seen its 2015 lows.

site_title: Lower oil prices seen cooling Abu Dhabi's resurgent property sector
summary: Abu Dhabi's residential property sector is expected to stabilize in 2015 due to lower oil prices, which have weakened sentiment and slowed government spending. The sector experienced a price boom from 2013-14, with housing prices rising 24% in 2014. However, the rental market has been sluggish, with rents rising only 2% in the first quarter of this year. Experts predict mid-cycle stability, with single-digit growth in 2015, and a shortage of affordable housing. Developers have responded by launching new projects targeting moderate-income households.

site_title: Singapore Wrap Tuesday
summary: BlackRock CEO Larry Fink expects a US interest rate hike in September, despite a rising dollar impacting US growth. China-based Haite Group launched a S$95.3 million aviation training center in Singapore. REC secured a solar power purchase agreement in Singapore. Toyo-Thai aims to raise US$300 million from its subsidiary's IPO in Singapore. The penny-stock rally at Singapore Exchange appears to be flagging.

site_title: Moving HQ to Singapore makes sense for StanChart: Aberdeen
summary: Standard Chartered has a strong business case to move its headquarters from London to Singapore, saving millions in taxes, according to Aberdeen Asset Management. The bank's main franchise is in Singapore, Hong Kong, and Africa, making a move logical. HSBC, a comparable bank, faces a combined $2 billion UK bank tax bill this year. Aberdeen remains bullish on StanChart, citing its strong franchise in long-term growth markets at a reasonable value. However, the move would not be easy, requiring a thorough analysis and re-doing everything.

site_title: Hewlett-Packard teams with FireEye, Mandiant on cybersecurity
summary: Hewlett-Packard (HP) has teamed up with cybersecurity firms FireEye and Mandiant to offer comprehensive security services, including assessments and incident response, to a broader market. The partnership brings together HP's 5,000 security consultants with FireEye's threat detection technology and Mandiant's investigators, enabling smaller companies to access advanced security capabilities. The deal aims to help clients proactively improve their defense before a breach, rather than reacting after an incident.

site_title: BlackBerry to buy WatchDox to bolster data security
summary: BlackBerry Ltd is acquiring WatchDox, a US tech company that secures files, to bolster its data security credentials. The terms of the deal were not disclosed. WatchDox's software, used by major agencies and studios, allows clients to control file access and administrators to lock or remove compromised files. The acquisition aims to enhance BlackBerry's security offerings and provide clients with full visibility and control over their files.

site_title: India won't yield to foreign investors' demand for tax waiver: finance ministry source
summary: India's finance ministry has confirmed it will not yield to foreign investors' demands for a tax waiver on capital gains from previous years. Despite Finance Minister Arun Jaitley's exemption for capital gains made from April 1, 2015, the Indian tax department plans to levy tax on previous years' gains, prompting US and European investor groups to protest. The government has stated it will not withdraw tax notices issued to foreign investors, citing no intention to yield to their demands.

summary: The article discusses annual affairs in the corporate calendar, focusing on the Annual General Meeting (AGM) in Singapore. The AGM is a significant event in the corporate calendar, and its timing and placement vary by company. However, no specific information or events related to an AGM is mentioned in the provided article.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 14.14 points to close at 1,862.80, with 3.04 billion lots valued at RM2.47 billion traded. The market saw 536 gains and 359 losses.

site_title: Latest earnings
summary: US President Trump announced a 50% tariff on refined copper imports, covering a wide range of products. Global markets reacted with oil prices rising over 2% amid concerns about market outlook, tariffs, and sanctions. European stocks fell, with banks and healthcare companies being particularly affected, as investors weigh US-EU tariff tensions. The US stock market also edged down from records, despite no official tariffs announced, sparking concerns about ongoing trade threats.

site_title: China vows to step up public scrutiny of SOEs' financial performance
summary: China's government vows to increase public scrutiny of state-owned enterprises (SOEs) by requiring them to release major financial indicators and performance metrics. This move aims to fight corruption and improve transparency, following recent investigations into corruption cases involving top officials. The State Council also calls for greater transparency in areas such as pollution, air quality, and government purchases. These reforms are part of a nationwide campaign to overhaul the country's inefficient state sector, with the aim of increasing accountability and reducing corruption.

site_title: Grand Banks Yachts' luxury-boat order book at six-year high
summary: Grand Banks Yachts, a luxury yacht builder, has seen its order book reach a six-year high of S$31.6 million, driven by increased demand from the US. The company, which acquired Palm Beach Motor Yacht in 2014, has received five new orders from customers in the US, Australia, and New Zealand, with luxury boats typically costing between S$1 million and S$4 million. The US accounts for about 75% of the company's order book, and Grand Banks Yachts has managed to reverse a S$5.2 million loss in the preceding year, posting a full-year net profit of S$1.03 million.

site_title: Oil prices retreat as high supply weighs
summary: Oil prices retreated on Tuesday as high crude supplies weighed, despite China's stimulus measures boosting energy demand. Brent crude fell 65 cents to $62.80 a barrel, while US benchmark West Texas Intermediate dipped 23 cents to $56.15 a barrel. Analysts expect US oil production to rise, easing global oversupply, despite reports of a possible rebound in production. The Chinese central bank cut interest rates and reserve requirements to boost the economy, but dealers remain concerned about surging US production.

site_title: CIMB Bank and Wirecard embark on merchant acquisition business
summary: CIMB Bank has partnered with Wirecard to offer a range of electronic payment solutions to merchants in Singapore, including a merchant business account and credit facility, eCommerce support, and risk management services. The partnership aims to sign on over 1,000 retailers in Singapore, with services available in just one week. This collaboration allows CIMB Bank to expand its payment offerings beyond its internal infrastructure, leveraging Wirecard's technological expertise.

images.alt_text: BUSINESSES will soon be able to enjoy a complete host of electronic payment solutions, following the partnership agreement between CIMB Bank and Wirecard.

site_title: China sees first state-owned firm default on bond
summary: China's state-owned power company Baoding Tianwei Baobian Electric Co Ltd has defaulted on a bond payment, marking the first time a state-owned firm has done so. The default, made on a 5-year, 1.5 billion yuan bond, occurred despite a warning from the company on April 16 that it might miss the payment. The move adds to evidence that Beijing is slowly withdrawing its sovereign guarantee of low-quality bonds, with analysts warning that the default could "destroy the ironclad guarantee reputation of central government-owned issuers."

site_title: Norwegian Air launches Las Vegas, Caribbean flights
summary: Norwegian Air Shuttle, Europe's third-largest low-cost carrier, will launch new long-haul flights from Scandinavia and London to Las Vegas, Puerto Rico, and the US Virgin Islands later this year. The airline has rapidly expanded into the long-haul business, including the competitive London to New York route. This expansion aims to capitalize on growing demand for budget travel to the US.

site_title: STATS ChipPAC cuts Q1 loss by 86.7% to US$2.1m
summary: STATS ChipPAC reported a net loss of US$2.1 million in the first quarter, a 86.7% decrease from the same period last year. Revenue increased 1.5% to US$371 million, while net income was US$3.5 million. The company attributed the decline to seasonal weakness in personal computer and consumer end markets. However, the wireless communication market showed strength in emerging markets and new smartphone product ramps.

site_title: Think-tank downwardly revises 2015 Greek growth forecast to 1%
summary: Greece's IOBE think-tank revised its 2015 growth forecast to 1% due to rising uncertainty from prolonged negotiations with EU and IMF lenders. This is down from the previous forecast of 2.3% in January. The government also forecasts a 1.4% growth rate for the year. The prolonged negotiations have pushed political uncertainty to its peak, according to IOBE.

site_title: Seoul: Won falls on Greek anxiety, shares edge down
summary: The South Korean won fell 0.4% against the dollar, snapping a three-day winning streak, amid concerns over a Greek debt default. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) also edged down 0.1%, breaking a seven-day winning streak. The decline occurred as the dollar rose broadly due to Greek anxiety.

site_title: Yahoo, Microsoft add termination clause in search deal: filing
summary: Yahoo Inc and Microsoft Corp have added a termination clause to their 10-year search partnership agreement, allowing either company to end the deal on or after October 1, 2015. The clause was added to the terms of the agreement, which was crafted by former Microsoft CEO Steve Ballmer and former Yahoo CEO Carol Bartz. The partnership, signed on February 23, 2015, initially allowed for amendments or terminations five years after its commencement.

site_title: HKMA sells HK$7.75b to keep Hong Kong dollar within its trading band
summary: The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) sold HK$7.75 billion in Hong Kong dollars to maintain the currency within its trading band, which is pegged at 7.8 to the US dollar. The latest intervention lifts the aggregate balance to HK$292.313 billion by April 23. This is the fourth time the HKMA has intervened in the market in the past fortnight, following a similar sale on April 15. The move aims to keep the Hong Kong dollar within its trading range of 7.75 to 7.85.

site_title: Australia: Shares gain on belated China enthusiasm, commodity rebound
summary: Australian shares rose 0.7% on Tuesday, ending a two-day losing streak, as investors responded positively to China's bank lending boost and a rebound in iron ore prices. Newly released Reserve Bank of Australia meeting notes also fueled optimism about potential rate cuts. The S&P/ASX 200 index gained 39.2 points to 5872.3.

site_title: China: Stocks post strong gains despite warning against "irrational exuberance"
summary: China's stock market surged 2.2% and 1.8% on the CSI300 and Shanghai Composite Index, respectively, despite a warning from Xinhua News Agency against "irrational exuberance." Trading on the Shanghai Stock Exchange surpassed 1 trillion yuan for the first time, making it the world's biggest bourse in terms of turnover. Brokerage shares led the market, with investors betting on industry growth from surging trading.

images.alt_text: China stocks jumped on Tuesday as bullish investors piled into small-cap stocks, betting on further gains despite stretched valuations and a warning from official Xinhua News Agency against "irrational exuberance."

site_title: Toyo-Thai aims for US$300m IPO of subsidiary in Singapore bourse
summary: Toyo-Thai Corp, a Thai construction firm, plans to raise approximately US$300 million through the listing of its subsidiary Toyo Thai Power Holdings PTE Ltd on Singapore's stock exchange by the end of 2016. The funds will be used to finance its US$2.8 billion coal-fired power plant project in Myanmar, which includes a 1,280 megawatt power plant. The company signed an agreement with Myanmar's government earlier this month to build and operate the power plant.

site_title: Thai Q1 economy likely contracted quarter-on-quarter: central bank
summary: Thailand's economy likely contracted in the first quarter, according to the central bank, with a high chance of negative on-quarter GDP. However, growth is expected to return in the second quarter due to improved exports and government investment. The economy has remained weak despite the army's seizure of power last May, and official first-quarter GDP data is due on May 18.

site_title: German investor sentiment slips unexpectedly in April: ZEW
summary: German investor sentiment decreased by 1.5 points to 53.3 points in April, marking the first decline in six months, according to the ZEW economic institute. Weakened global growth negatively impacted confidence, despite a stable labor market and increasing wages boosting consumption. The sub-index measuring financial market players' view of the current economic situation jumped to 70.2 points, its highest level since July 2011. The decline in investor sentiment contrasts with ZEW president Clemens Fuest's statement that the German economy is in good shape.

site_title: Europe: Stocks firm at open
summary: Europe's stock markets rose on Tuesday, with the FTSE 100 up 0.08%, the CAC 40 in Paris gaining 0.34%, and Frankfurt's DAX 30 winning 0.87%. The rebound follows China's stimulus measures, which eased concerns over Greece.

images.alt_text: Europe's stock markets climbed in opening trade on Tuesday, with London's benchmark FTSE 100 index up 0.08 per cent at 7,058.40 points.

site_title: One tanker attacked in SE Asia every two weeks: piracy watchdog
summary: Southeast Asia remains the world's piracy hotspot, with 38 pirate attacks recorded in the first quarter of 2015, a 70% increase from the global total. The International Maritime Bureau reported one attack every two weeks, with Indonesian waters being the most piracy-prone, seeing 21 attacks. Most attacks involved armed gangs targeting small coastal tankers to steal fuel, resulting in 140 seafarers being taken hostage and 13 crew members being assaulted or injured. The bureau warns that attacks could increase further if the problem is not addressed.

site_title: Japan PM Abe: aims to improve ties with China
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe aims to improve ties with China, citing a mutually beneficial strategic relationship. This comes amid recent tensions over Japan's wartime history, territorial disputes, and differing security policies. Abe expressed readiness to meet Chinese President Xi Jinping, signaling a potential shift in Japan-China relations. However, the challenges to improving ties remain, with bitter memories of Japan's past and China's military assertiveness still present.

images.alt_text: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe said ahead of his trip to a leaders' summit in Jakarta that he aims to improve ties with China, and reiterated that he is ready to meet Chinese President Xi Jinping.

site_title: Indonesia will not re-introduce gasoline subsidies: energy minister
summary: Indonesia's energy minister, Sudirman Said, stated that the country will not reintroduce gasoline subsidies despite rising international oil prices. The subsidies were scrapped by President Joko Widodo at the start of the year, freeing up $20 billion in state spending. The removal of subsidies was part of Widodo's campaign to reduce reliance on oil and gas. The government has instead shifted the burden to Pertamina, the state-owned oil company, which lost $72.5 million in the first two months of the year.

site_title: Mapletree Industrial Trust's Q4 DPU up 5.6% after higher rentals, occupancies
summary: Mapletree Industrial Trust reported a 5.6% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.65 Singapore cents for its Q4 2015, driven by higher rental rates and occupancies in its high-tech buildings. Gross revenue rose 5.6% to S$79.4 million. The trust's acquisition of 2A Changi North Street 2 and a build-to-suit project contributed to the revenue growth.

site_title: Sembcorp joint venture to develop industrial park in Vietnam
summary: Sembcorp Industries' joint venture, Vietnam Singapore Industrial Park and Township Development Joint Stock Company (VSIP JSC), has signed an agreement to buy an industrial park in northern Vietnam's Cam Dien-Luong Dien Industrial Park for 110 hectares of industrial land. VSIP JSC has received an investment licence and will undertake the project, with a total investment of US$11 million. The acquisition will not impact Sembcorp's earnings per share and net asset per share materially for the financial year ending Dec 31, 2015.

site_title: China to approve new foreign fund managers for QDLP scheme
summary: China has approved five foreign fund managers, including UBS Global Asset Management and Deutsche Asset & Wealth Management, to enter the QDLP scheme, a pilot program aimed at opening China to the US$2 trillion-plus global hedge fund industry. The firms, which will receive US$100 million foreign exchange quotas, are expected to start operations by June. This move represents the Chinese government's latest effort to lift restrictions on its currency and expand the use of its US$3.73 trillion foreign reserves.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close up 1.40% on US gains, weak yen
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 1.40% on Tuesday, driven by US gains and a weaker yen, with the Nikkei 225 index reaching 19,909.09. Sony and Panasonic saw gains as exporters benefited from the weaker yen. The Topix index also rose 1.66%, with the Topix index finishing at 1,608.88.

site_title: China's finance minister hits at US "negative list": Xinhua
summary: China's Finance Minister Lou Jiwei criticized the US "negative list" proposal for a Bilateral Investment Treaty, stating it increases uncertainty for Chinese investors and makes them feel uncomfortable due to lack of specific definitions. Lou expressed concerns during a meeting in Washington DC.
