She also expressed confidence in the country's resilience to potential volatility from the US Federal Reserve's interest rate hike, citing a stable banking sector and fiscal consolidation efforts.

site_title: Greece requires public sector entities to transfer cash balances to central bank
summary: Greece has issued a legislative act requiring public sector entities to transfer idle cash reserves to the central bank as part of efforts to address a cash squeeze. The move aims to alleviate funding needs, which have become extreme under Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras. The regulation excludes pension funds and some state-owned firms, while excluding cash reserves needed for immediate payment needs. The cash-strapped country must repay the International Monetary Fund almost 1 billion euros next month, and Greece wants to honor its debt obligations.

site_title: BMW cutting production, prices in China to meet 'new normal'
summary: BMW cuts production and prices in China to address softening luxury demand. The company has reduced prices on some models and will scale back manufacturing to prevent unsold cars. BMW's China chief, Karsten Engel, notes that the company is adjusting to a "trend downwards" in the market. Foreign automakers, including Ford and Volkswagen, have also cut prices by up to 10% in recent weeks. The move is seen as a sign of the new normal in the Chinese auto market, where austerity and anti-corruption measures are impacting demand for luxury products.

site_title: US: Stocks jump on China stimulus
summary: US stocks rose Monday, driven by China's latest stimulus measure, which offset concerns about a Greek debt default. The Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 160.25 points (0.90%), the S&P 500 rose 13.72 (0.66%), and the Nasdaq Composite Index advanced 26.70 (0.54%). China's central bank cut reserve funds by 1% point, boosting lending. US stocks had fallen on Friday due to Greek default worries, but rebounded after the Chinese announcement.

site_title: Sino Construction completes building micro power plant in South Korea
summary: Sino Construction has completed its first micro power plant, "Korea MPP One," in South Korea. The company is part of a multi-year program to roll out several micro power plants, with a second location in Pohang pending approval. The successful project is expected to boost the company's cash flow, allowing it to divest underperforming assets and focus on profitability. Profits from the project will be used to expand the program, increase asset ownership, and establish a long-term dividend program. The power plant is awaiting final inspection and certification.

site_title: Singapore: STI falls 0.6% after slump at Wall Street
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) in Singapore fell 0.6% to 3,503.25 after the US market slump on Friday. China's surprise 100-basis-point cut in bank reserve requirements to boost liquidity also contributed to the decline. The local bourse saw 343 losers and 151 gainers, with turnover at 2.6 billion shares worth S$1.15 billion.

site_title: French police end Germanwings debris recovery in Alps
summary: French military police have completed the recovery of debris from the Germanwings plane crash site in the Alps, nearly a month after the March 24 crash that killed 150 people. The Airbus A320 was flying from Barcelona to Duesseldorf when it crashed, with co-pilot Andreas Lubitz believed to have deliberately crashed the plane after locking the pilot out of the cockpit. The incident raised concerns about pilots' mental health, prompting industry doctors to urge more extensive medical checks. Clean-up operations are now set to start, with pulverised fragments stored in a hangar near the site.

site_title: Tan Boon Khai to succeed Vincent Hoong as CEO of Singapore Land Authority
summary: Tan Boon Khai will succeed Vincent Hoong as CEO of the Singapore Land Authority (SLA) on May 1, 2015. Hoong, who served as SLA CEO from 2009 to 2015, was appointed as the registrar of the Supreme Court. Tan, 41, joins SLA from CapitaLand, where he was head of group procurement. During his tenure, Hoong championed reforms, including the Electronic Payment Instruction System and the launch of the OneMap in 2010. The Law Ministry thanked Hoong for his years of service and contributions to SLA.

images.alt_text: Tan Boon Khai will succeed Vincent Hoong as chief executive officer of the Singapore Land Authority (SLA) with effect from May 1, 2015, the Law Ministry said in a statement on Monday.

site_title: Singapore Wrap Monday
summary: Singapore stocks fell 0.6% on Monday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) dropping 21.94 points to 3,503.25. Iceberg Research criticized Noble Group's lack of transparency at its annual general meeting. Inflation expectations in Singapore reached a 3.5-year low of 3.05%. Manulife launched a new financial advisory firm and GCCP Resources launched its IPO on the Singapore Exchange.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher
summary: Malaysia's stock market ended higher on Monday, with the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 2.8 points to close at 1,848.66. Trading volume reached 3.13 billion lots, valued at RM2.14 billion, with 346 gainers and 485 losers.

site_title: Malaysian limestone producer GCCP launches IPO on Catalist
summary: GCCP Resources, a Malaysian limestone producer, has launched an initial public offering (IPO) on the SGX Catalist board. The IPO consists of 122 million new shares at 23 Singapore cents each, raising approximately S$28.1 million. The company plans to use the funds to build a calcium carbonate crushing plant and powder production plant at one of its quarries in Ipoh, Malaysia. Trading of its shares is expected to commence on April 30, 2015.

site_title: Indonesia's Widodo to investors: if you have a problem, call me
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo urged investors to invest in the country, promising "incredible profits" and assuring they can reach him if problems arise. Widodo acknowledged Indonesia's economic challenges, comparing them to the country's reliance on oil exports in the 1970s. He aims to raise growth to 5.7% this year and 7% average growth in his five-year term, shifting the economy from consumption to production and investment. Widodo told cabinet ministers to be honest about challenges, encouraging investors to "come and invest in Indonesia" and contact him if issues arise.

site_title: Malaysia March inflation seen picking up to 0.9% year-on-year
summary: Malaysia's annual inflation rate in March is expected to reach 0.9%, driven by slightly higher petrol prices following the removal of fuel subsidies in December. Despite this, economists anticipate minimal inflation increase due to lower oil prices and a global disinflationary environment. The 6% goods and services tax introduced in April is also expected to have a cushioning effect on price pressures. This marks a 5-year low inflation rate, seen in February.

site_title: Groupon to sell 46% stake in Ticket Monster for US$360m
summary: Groupon Inc. will sell a 46% stake in its South Korean e-commerce business, Ticket Monster, to a partnership formed by KKR and Anchor Equity Partners for US$360 million. Groupon will retain a 54% stake in Ticket Monster after the deal closes. Additionally, Groupon approved a new US$300 million share repurchase program.

images.alt_text: Groupon Inc said it would sell a 46 per cent stake in Ticket Monster, its South Korean e-commerce business, to a partnership formed by KKR and Hong Kong-based Anchor Equity Partners for US$360 million.

site_title: KSH wins S$33.2m contract to build sports centre at NUS
summary: KSH Holdings secured a S$33.2 million contract to build a three-storey University Sports Centre Building at the National University of Singapore (NUS). Construction is expected to start this month and be completed by May 2017. The new sports centre will replace the current facility, offering a larger and more sophisticated range of sports facilities. The contract win is expected to contribute positively to KSH's performance from FY2016 to FY2018, lifting its order book to S$420 million.

site_title: Obama must read up history if he wants Iran deal
summary: US President Barack Obama's Iran deal faces criticism from lawmakers, who compare his approach to British Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain's appeasement of Nazi Germany in the 1930s. The Senate Foreign Relations Committee approved a bill allowing Congress to review the final deal, which would require the administration to send the text to Congress and obtain approval before lifting sanctions. Critics argue that the deal could lead to nuclear proliferation and regional conflict, and that Obama's grand plan may fail if he doesn't consult with Congress.

images.alt_text: Last week's solid bipartisan vote in the Senate Foreign Relations Committee is a clear reflection of the growing uneasiness on Capitol Hill over Mr Obama's approach towards Iran and his foreign policy agenda.

site_title: Sabana Reit posts lower DPU for first quarter
summary: Sabana Reit posted a lower distribution per unit (DPU) of 1.78 Singapore cents for its first quarter, a 5.3% drop from the previous year. The decline was partly due to a larger unit base. Gross revenue rose 3.2% to S$25.4 million, while net property income increased 1.1% to S$18.6 million. The company's overall occupancy remained at 90.6%. CEO Kevin Xayaraj attributed the performance to a higher occupancy rate weighing down the company's overall performance.

site_title: Chinese tourists' luxury spending soars: Global Blue
summary: Chinese tourists spent a record amount on luxury goods in March, with spending soaring 122% from the previous month, driven by shopping sprees in Europe due to the weak euro. This brings the first quarter increase to 67%, with luxury items often costing 50% less in European capitals than in major Chinese cities. The trend has led to parallel trading, with 20-40% of luxury sales in mainland China now being resold at home, raising concerns about product authenticity.

site_title: Cheung Woh Technologies posts S$3.3m profit for Q4
summary: Cheung Woh Technologies reported a net profit of S$3.3 million for its fourth quarter, rebounding from a S$646,000 loss in the same period last year. Revenue more than doubled to S$27 million, driven by higher sales in the HDD components segment. Full-year net profit grew 12 times to S$12.6 million, while earnings per share increased from 0.35 to 4.18 cents. The company's shares closed at S$0.225, down half cent, after the results were released.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks sink 2.02%
summary: Hong Kong shares fell 2.02% on Monday, driven by China's clampdown on margin trading, despite a recent economic stimulus measure. The benchmark Hang Seng Index dropped 558.19 points to 27,094.93. Mainland China's Shanghai Composite Index fell 1.64%. The decline overshadowed the 2.5 percentage point cut in reserve requirements announced by China's central bank.

site_title: Mapletree Logistics Trust's Q4 DPU dips on higher borrowing costs
summary: Mapletree Logistics Trust reported a 2.1% drop in distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.85 Singapore cents for its Q4 2015, due to higher borrowing costs from incremental borrowings. Gross revenue rose 5.7% to S$84.7 million, while net property income increased 2.9% to S$70.3 million. Portfolio occupancy ended the year at 96.7%, down from 98.3% the previous year, mainly impacted by conversions of properties from single-user to multi-tenanted buildings.

site_title: Indonesia's chief economic minister comfortable with rupiah at current level
summary: Indonesia's chief economic minister, Sofyan Djalil, expressed comfort with the country's rupiah currency at its current level of 12,872 rupiah per dollar. The currency hit its lowest level in 17 years last month due to US interest rate expectations. Djalil stated 12,800 rupiah is a more comfortable level, but the government did not set a specific target. The central bank kept its benchmark interest rate unchanged, consistent with efforts to contain inflation and the current account deficit.

site_title: Chinese car market growth to halve this year: Germany's VDA
summary: German automotive association VDA expects China's passenger car market growth to halve this year, dropping to 6% from 12.7% in 2014. Despite this slowdown, foreign automakers continue to invest in new plants. German carmakers increased their market share to 23% in the first two months of the year. VDA President Matthias Wissmann noted that demand for cars remains unmet, especially in medium-sized cities and western China, with 52 cars per 1,000 inhabitants. He believes the emerging middle class will continue to drive demand for individual mobility.

images.alt_text: German automotive association VDA expects Chinese passenger car market growth to drop to as low as 6 per cent this year from 12.7 per cent in 2014, it said on Monday.

site_title: Turnover explosion at Shanghai stock exchange has too many zeros for software
summary: The Shanghai Stock Exchange recorded a historic 1 trillion yuan (S$217.3 billion) in trading turnover, surpassing the New York Stock Exchange. However, the surge in volumes exceeded the exchange's software capabilities, causing data to not be properly displayed. The Shanghai Stock Exchange attributed the issue to a software configuration problem, stating that trading and price quotes for individual stocks remained unaffected. The exchange plans to replace its software to resolve the issue, which is a result of China's stock market nearly doubling over the past six months.

site_title: AirAsia plans US$300m IPO for Indonesian arm in 2016: CEO
summary: AirAsia plans to raise approximately US$300 million through an initial public offering (IPO) for its Indonesian affiliate in the first half of 2016. The airline aims to sell a 30% stake in the Indonesian carrier, with CEO Tony Fernandes stating the move as part of the company's expansion plans.

site_title: HSBC chairman signals bank may shift headquarters from London
summary: HSBC chairman Douglas Flint stated that the bank may shift its headquarters from London once the regulatory environment becomes clearer. This comes as the UK government increased the levy on banks' balance sheets for an eighth time this year, affecting HSBC the most due to its significant assets in the UK. The bank has faced calls to relocate due to the high cost of being in London, with Standard Chartered also being urged to move to Asia.

site_title: Starhill Global Reit to buy Myer Centre Adelaide for A$288m
summary: Starhill Global Reit has agreed to buy the Myer Centre Adelaide in Adelaide, South Australia for A$288 million (S$302.4 million) in cash. The acquisition, expected to be completed by June 30, 2015, will add 6.6% yield and 2.8% distribution per unit (DPU) accretion. Funding will come from internal working capital and debt, increasing the Reit's gearing to 35.3% from 28.6%.

site_title: China: Stocks fall as short-selling fears offset impact from big reserve cut
summary: China's stocks fell 1.6% on Monday as fears of a regulatory crackdown offset the central bank's move to boost the economy by cutting banks' reserve requirements by a record 1 trillion yuan. The cut, aimed at freeing up funds to shore up the economy, was expected to lead to increased stock market activity. However, traders feared a selloff and market correction, with some predicting a 10% swing in the market. The CSI300 index fell to 4,521.92, and the Shanghai Composite Index lost 1.6% to 4,217.08 points.

site_title: Japan government leaves economic assessment unchanged in April
summary: Japan's government maintained its economic assessment unchanged in April, citing a moderate recovery trend driven by improving corporate activity. Factory output, consumer spending, capital expenditure, and exports remain stable, with a weak yen boosting corporate profits. However, real wages continue to fall, and inflation has ground to a halt due to lower oil prices. The Bank of Japan is under pressure to cut its inflation forecast, which could lead to further monetary easing. The central bank's review of forecasts is set for April 30, amid speculation of potential easing measures.

site_title: MOU signed to help Chengdu firms raise capital on SGX
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) and the Chengdu Municipal Finance Affairs Office signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) to facilitate capital-raising by Chengdu-based firms on SGX. Under the agreement, Chengdu FAO will encourage and assist companies to list on SGX via IPOs, bonds, and Reits, while SGX will help companies gain familiarity with international capital-market practices and products. This partnership aims to increase the number of Chengdu enterprises listing on SGX.

site_title: Morgan Stanley profit jumps 60% on higher trading revenue
summary: Morgan Stanley reported a 60% rise in quarterly profit to $2.31 billion, driven by higher revenue from trading bonds and equities. The bank's net income applicable to common shareholders rose to $1.18 per share, exceeding analyst expectations. Excluding items, Morgan Stanley earned $1.14 per share. The profit jump is attributed to increased trading activity, which contributed to a significant increase in the bank's earnings.

images.alt_text: Wall Street investment bank Morgan Stanley reported a 60 per cent rise in quarterly profit, boosted by higher revenue from trading bonds and equities.

site_title: Manulife Singapore launches new financial advisory firm
summary: Manulife Singapore has launched its new financial advisory firm, Manulife Financial Advisers, with 250 employees. The firm, majority-owned by Manulife Singapore, aims to contribute 50% of sales, complementing its existing financial advisers channel. The move strengthens Manulife's distribution network amid increasing competition in the insurance sector.

site_title: Central banks prepare to flood FX markets with euros
summary: Central banks are expected to reduce their euro-denominated foreign exchange reserves by a significant amount, potentially up to $104 billion annually, due to the rapidly depreciating euro and negative yields on eurozone government bonds. This shift is driven by concerns over negative yields and the European Central Bank's massive bond-buying program, which has flooded the market with euros. As a result, the euro's share of global reserves is expected to fall to 20% or lower, with a potential reduction of $240-$480 billion in euro assets over the coming quarters.

site_title: GCCP launches IPO; CEO not selling his shares
summary: GCCP Resources, a Malaysian crushed limestone producer, launched its initial public offering (IPO) on the Singapore Exchange's Catalist board. CEO Alex Loo, who owns 53.8% of the company, has committed to a moratorium on his holdings for up to three years due to stable demand for limestone. Loo cited the product's extensive applications and relatively stable price over the years as reasons for his decision.

site_title: China to launch three new free-trade zones
summary: China is launching three new free-trade zones in Guangdong, Tianjin, and Fujian, expanding on its initial Shanghai FTZ. The zones will cover around 120 square kilometers each and aim to promote economic integration with neighboring regions. The Guangdong zone focuses on Hong Kong integration, while the Fujian zone targets Taiwan and the "21st century maritime silk road" initiative. The Tianjin zone aims to integrate the city with nearby Beijing and Hebei province. The zones are subject to a "negative list" restricting foreign investment in 122 business areas.

site_title: Thai PTT power unit aims to raise US$340m from IPO in May
summary: Thai PTT Power's unit, Global Power Synergy Co, plans to raise approximately $456.5 million from an initial public offering (IPO) in May, with shares expected to trade starting May 18. The offer period is May 7-12 and prices will be discounted to an estimated fair value of 30-35 baht per share.

site_title: Gold holds above US$1,200 on softer dollar; Asian demand eyed
summary: Gold prices held steady above $1,200 an ounce on Monday due to a softer US dollar, but investors remain cautious due to uncertainty over a potential interest rate hike by the US Federal Reserve. Physical demand remains subdued, with no significant uptick in Asian markets, particularly in China and India. The Fed's policy meeting later this month will provide stronger clues about the timing of a rate hike, which could impact gold demand.

site_title: Adidas to use marine plastic waste in products from 2016
summary: Adidas partners with Parley for the Oceans to develop materials made from marine plastic waste for its products, starting from 2016. The company also plans to phase out plastic bags at its 2,900 stores. This move is part of the growing trend of big fashion brands highlighting their environmental credentials amidst pressure from groups like Greenpeace.

site_title: Trading interest in SGX's India-related futures surges in Q1
summary: SGX's India-related products saw significant trading interest in Q1, with the SGX Nifty Index Futures experiencing a 30% increase in volume compared to the same period last year. Record daily trading volumes were achieved, with 216,215 contracts traded in March, a 15% month-on-month increase. The surge in trading activity was attributed to improving economic forecasts in India and tighter futures bid-ask spreads averaging less than 0.5 NDF pips. This resulted in a record US$1 billion in notional turnover on April 8, coinciding with Moody's revised India's sovereign rating outlook to "positive".

site_title: Hot stock: Noble inches up in morning trading
summary: Noble Group, a commodity trader, gained 0.565% in morning trading on Monday. The company's CEO, Yusuf Alireza, and executive director, William Randall, received 4.29 million and 2.21 million shares, respectively, after the group's AGM on Friday. Noble's share price is still down 26% since allegations of accounting practices were made by Iceberg Research. The company has refuted the allegations and initiated legal proceedings.

site_title: Vietnam's banks see rates down, less bad debt in 2015: central bank
summary: Vietnam's banks expect improved business in 2015, with easing interest rates and reduced bad debt, according to the State Bank of Vietnam. The sector is projected to post annual credit growth of nearly 17% and deposits will grow nearly 15% this year. Most banks expect bad debt to decline below 3% by the end of 2015, down from 3.25% in December 2014. Interest rates are also expected to ease, with over half of banks anticipating a decrease of 0.6-1.1 percentage points in the second half of 2015.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei pares early losses to close flat
summary: Tokyo's benchmark Nikkei 225 index closed 0.09% lower at 19,634.49 following a decline on Wall Street, driven by concerns over Greece's eurozone future. The broader Topix index fell 0.38% to 1,582.68. The losses were partly offset by a tumble in US stocks, which saw a record close despite tariff concerns.

site_title: Indonesia to push for free trade pacts with South Korea, EEA
summary: Indonesia aims to boost exports by aggressively pursuing free trade agreements with South Korea, the European Economic Area (EEA) countries, and other nations. The country's exports contracted 9.75% in March, its sixth consecutive decline. Deputy Coordinating Minister Rizal Affandi Lukman said Indonesia will accelerate talks on free trade agreements, including a comprehensive economic partnership with Australia and joint study groups with the European Union, Chile, and Russia. The government has yet to decide on the US-led Trans-Pacific Partnership.

site_title: Seoul: Shares rise for 7th straight day, won also firms
summary: South Korean shares rose for the seventh consecutive day, with the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) increasing 0.2% to 2,146.71 points. The won also gained 0.4% to 1,079.2 per dollar, its highest level since January 28. The gains were driven by Beijing's decision to boost Chinese banks' lending power to support South Korea's largest trading partner, Greece's economy. The positive sentiment came despite uncertainty over Greece's debt future.

site_title: Spring Singapore, Intel collaborate to support Internet-of-Things and Wearable initiatives
summary: SPRING Singapore and Intel Singapore have partnered to support startups and SMEs in developing IoT and wearable products and services. The initiative, managed under Spring's Partnerships for Capability Transformation programme, aims to establish a well-connected ecosystem of Singapore companies using Intel technology. Currently, nine local startups are part of the initiative, with Intel's country manager citing scalability hurdles as a major challenge in the rapidly growing IoT market. The partnership aims to accelerate the development of products and solutions in the IoT and wearable segments.

site_title: Iceberg hits out at Noble after AGM
summary: An anonymous outfit Iceberg Research criticized Noble Group's founder and chairman Richard Elman for avoiding shareholders' questions about the company's accounting practices at its annual general meeting (AGM). Elman claimed the matter was finished and Noble would challenge Iceberg's claims in a public court. Iceberg countered that Elman showed his true colors by not being transparent, and that Noble's legal action against them was a distraction. Iceberg believes Noble will fail in its legal action and that the AGM could have been an opportunity for transparency.

site_title: AirAsia plans share sale of Indonesia subsidiary early next year
summary: AirAsia plans to sell shares of its Indonesia subsidiary early next year, following the crash of one of its planes in December that killed 162 people. The airline aims to capitalize on Asia-Pacific's rapid growth in air travel, with projected annual growth of 5% for the next two decades. AirAsia expects to be profitable this year despite oil price fluctuations, and will also launch a Japan venture early next year. The IPO will follow a planned share sale for AirAsia's Philippine business.

site_title: Australia, NZ shares slip as China proves no help
summary: Australian shares dropped 0.7% on Monday, falling 44.7 points to 5,833.1, as China's stimulus efforts failed to reverse the decline following a late finish on Wall Street. New Zealand's benchmark NZX 50 index also fell 0.6% to 5,824.27. The decline marks a 2.4% drop in the last week, retreating from the key psychological level of 6,000.

site_title: Australian professionals fill hole dug by mining slowdown
summary: Australia's cooling mining sector has led to a significant employment gap, but professionals in the housing sector are filling the gap. The professional, scientific, and technical services sector created 99,000 new positions in the year to February, more than twice the number lost to mining. The sector now employs a record 987,800 people, with architects, engineers, and lawyers driving the growth. Housing construction activity is expected to hit a fresh high in 2015, with annual housing starts expected to top out at 210,000 dwellings.

site_title: UOB finances gas engines for new power plant in Yangon
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) has financed Royal GK's gas engines for a new power plant in Yangon, Myanmar. Royal GK was commissioned by the Myanmar Central Power Co (MCPC) to build the plant, which will provide electricity under an agreement with the Ministry of Electric Power. The MCPC will own and operate the plant. This deal highlights UOB's involvement in Myanmar's energy sector, providing financing for the country's growing power needs.

images.alt_text: United Overseas Bank (UOB) has announced a financing agreement with Singapore-based Royal GK to provide electricity to Myanmar.

site_title: Talks with Greece have gained momentum but still long way from target
summary: Global lenders' negotiations with Greece have gained momentum but remain far from reaching the target, according to the IMF's European head, Poul Thomsen. Greece's talks with its euro zone partners and the IMF over economic reforms required to unlock remaining bailout funds have shown some impetus, but a lot more is needed to reach an agreement in time. The Greek government's finances are expected to last until June, and a deal could lead to more aid from the IMF and euro zone governments if Athens agrees to reforms to make its finances sustainable and competitive.

site_title: China steps up economy help with reduced bank reserve ratios
summary: China's central bank cut the reserve-requirement ratio by 1 percentage point to 18.5%, its second reduction this year, in an effort to boost lending and stimulate the economy. The move, aimed at easing monetary policy, is part of China's efforts to address its slowest economic growth in six years and mitigate job losses. The cut is expected to allow banks to boost lending by about $194 billion, and is seen as a step towards more monetary easing, following similar moves by the European Central Bank and Bank of Japan.

site_title: China's biggest auto show opens amid growth slowdown
summary: China's biggest auto show opened in Shanghai, with global car makers showcasing hundreds of vehicles despite a slowdown in sales growth. China's economy expanded 7.4% last year, the slowest in nearly a quarter of a century, with vehicle sales reaching 23.49 million. However, annual sales growth halved to 6.9% from 13.9% in 2013. SUVs are a bright spot in the market, expected to be the biggest in the world by 2018. Luxury cars have been impacted by the economic slowdown and government crackdown on corruption, while electric vehicles face challenges due to reliability and charging infrastructure issues.

images.alt_text: Global car makers showed off hundreds of vehicles in China's commercial hub Shanghai on Monday, as the world's biggest auto market continues to attract despite a sharp deceleration in sales growth.

site_title: Shale as world's swing producer signals 'jagged' oil future
summary: US shale oil has been designated as the world's new "swing producer" due to Opec's ceding control for the first time since the 1980s. Despite significant cuts in spending and rig idling, US production took five months to start declining. Analysts expect a slower and more difficult recovery compared to Saudi Arabia, with US oil supply lacking a single, centralized entity to control output. The US response will be "messy, jagged, and not happening overnight," according to experts.

site_title: Oil prices rise in Asian trade
summary: Oil prices rose in Asia, fueled by unrest in the Middle East and hopes of a global supply glut easing due to declining US production. US benchmark West Texas Intermediate gained 78 cents to $56.52, while Brent crude for June gained 77 cents to $64.22. Conflicts in Yemen, a drop in US oil rig activity, and weak US inventory data contributed to the price increases. Analysts see a slowdown in US production as a sign of a production slowdown that could alleviate global oversupply and push prices up.

site_title: Malaysia shares open higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 0.85 points to 1,846.71 on Monday, driven by higher trading volumes. The index opened higher despite a slight loss in volume, with 131 losers outnumbering 100 gainers.

site_title: Zeti defends Malaysia fiscal direction, says ringgit undervalued
summary: Malaysia's central bank Governor Zeti Akhtar Aziz defended the country's fiscal direction, stating the ringgit is undervalued despite a weakening growth outlook. The banking sector is "very solid" and fiscal deficit has narrowed, Zeti said. She cited accommodative interest rates and a narrowing deficit as reasons to maintain borrowing costs. However, Zeti noted slower external demand and a domestic consumption pullback due to a new tax as risks affecting Malaysia's outlook, amid a 9.8% ringgit drop in the past six months.

site_title: Hong Kong stocks flat at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened flat on Monday, easing 7.26 points to 27,645.86, as China's decision to reduce bank reserve requirements was offset by a mainland crackdown on margin trading. The Shanghai Composite Index fell 0.44%, and the Shenzhen Composite Index dropped 0.72%.

site_title: China: Stocks open mixed Monday
summary: China's stocks opened mixed on Monday, with the Shanghai Composite Index up 0.33% to 4,301.35, while the Shenzhen Component Index fell 0.11% to 14,132.83. The ChiNext Index, tracking growth enterprises, declined 1.58 points to 2,462.41. The mixed performance follows a global trend, with European stocks down due to bank and healthcare drag, and US stocks near records despite tariff threats.

site_title: Keppel Corp's non-executive and independent director to retire
summary: Keppel Corp's non-executive and independent director Tony Chew will retire from the group's board of directors on May 1. Chew, who has been chairman of the nominating committee since 2009, will be succeeded by Tan Puay Chiang. Chew's 13-year contributions to the company were recognized by Chairman Lee Boon Yang, who praised Chew's leadership and commitment to the group's interest. Chew's departure comes after a period of smooth leadership transition under his oversight.

site_title: Asia: Markets mostly down as Greece fears return
summary: Asian markets declined Monday as fears over Greece's return to the eurozone crisis weighed on investor sentiment. Despite China's announcement of additional monetary easing measures, including a cut in reserve requirements, Hong Kong and Shanghai fell, with Seoul and Sydney also losing ground. European stocks plummeted on Friday, with Germany's DAX 30 index tumbling 2.58%, and the euro edged down to US$1.0795. The Dow sank 1.54% on Wall Street, while US benchmark oil prices rose 58 cents to US$56.32.

site_title: Gold holds weekly loss as US inflation counters China stimulus
summary: Gold prices held a weekly loss as US inflation data countered expectations of increased demand, despite a 0.3% weekly decline. China's reserve-requirement ratio cut, the largest since 2008, boosted gold prices in Shanghai. US core inflation rose in March, and Federal Reserve officials debate interest rate boosts. Geopolitical uncertainty and US President Obama's call on Greece to resolve the standoff also affected gold prices, which generally offer returns only through price gains.

site_title: Singapore's inflation expectations at lowest levels in 3.5 years: SMU survey
summary: Singapore's inflation expectations have reached a 3.5-year low of 3.05% according to a survey by the Singapore Management University. The survey, which polled consumers in March, was influenced by global factors such as weak oil prices and exchange rate fluctuations due to US rate hike fears. This marks a significant drop from previous months, indicating a decrease in concerns about inflation.

site_title: Swiss franc antics threaten banks' grip on currency trading
summary: Banks are facing pressure to relinquish their control over the US$5.3-trillion-a-day currency market after the Swiss National Bank's decision to abandon its price cap on the franc. Dealers, including Bank of America, Barclays, and Goldman Sachs, have approached customers to renegotiate trades, but third-party platforms and exchanges are making a push to attract clients. These platforms offer standardized rules and fewer conflicts of interest, and some, like the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, have even proposed central-limit order books to match customers according to price.

site_title: China paper blames poor upbringings for top-level graft
summary: China's top newspaper, the People's Daily, attributes corruption cases to poor family upbringings, suggesting officials should learn from heroic figures from the early days of Communist rule. The commentary cites examples of former officials Zhou Yongkang and Ling Jihua, who were caught in graft scandals, and notes that their families' unhealthy upbringings contributed to the corruption. The newspaper emphasizes the importance of a person's upbringing in shaping their morals, referencing the example of Chen Yun, a senior figure who raised children with strict requirements and led by example.

site_title: Tsunami warning after 6.8 magnitude quake hits Okinawa: NHK
summary: A 6.8 magnitude earthquake struck far-southern Japan, triggering a tsunami warning for the Okinawa island chain. A one-meter tsunami wave is forecasted to hit several islands, with no visible damage reported in the Taiwan capital. The earthquake, centered on Yonaguni, caused buildings to sway in Taipei but no damage was visible. The warning is in effect for several islands, with authorities advising residents to take necessary precautions.

site_title: Singapore: STI opens lower on weaker Wall St close, eyes China's new bank requirements
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 4.23 points to 3,520.96, amid global market uncertainty, following China's bank reserve requirement cuts. US and European markets closed lower on Friday, with Greece debt issues unresolved. Top losers included Sembcorp and DBS, with 258 million shares changing hands worth S$112.2 million.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open 0.77% lower
summary: Tokyo stocks fell 0.77% on Monday, opening at 19,501.00, due to a firmer yen and sharp drops in New York shares last week on Greek default worries. The dollar remained weak, pressuring Japanese exporters. Greece was urged to deliver a fiscal and debt plan to official lenders amid escalating worries over a looming default. The euro held steady, while US stocks tumbled on Friday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average slumping 1.54%. Both sides are seeking a deal before eurozone finance ministers meet on April 24.

site_title: Rolls-Royce wins US$9.2b order from Emirates for A380 engines
summary: Rolls-Royce won a $9.2 billion order from Emirates to supply engines for 50 A380 aircraft, the largest order in its history. This deal comes after a torrid year of profit warnings and will help secure jobs. The aircraft are expected to enter service in 2016, and the selection could raise hopes that Rolls-Royce will win more orders from Emirates. The deal also includes a long-term "Totalcare" package for service and maintenance.

site_title: South Korea producer prices in March fall at fastest pace since mid-2009
summary: South Korea's producer prices in March fell 3.7% in annual terms, the fastest pace since mid-2009, driven by cheap global oil. Manufactured goods, particularly coal and oil products, plummeted 32.7% and 6.1% respectively, contributing to the decline. This marks the eighth consecutive month of price drops.

site_title: Rakuten takes stake in Chinese online discount provider Fanli
summary: Rakuten Inc, a Japanese online retailer, has acquired a stake of less than 10% in Chinese online discount provider Fanli Inc, expanding its presence in overseas markets. This move is part of Rakuten's strategy to transform itself into a one-stop-site for a global audience, similar to Amazon.com Inc. The investment comes after Rakuten's recent acquisitions of US eBook company OverDrive Inc and free messaging application Viber.

site_title: GM's China venture to spend US$16 billion by 2020 to win sales
summary: General Motors' joint venture with SAIC Motor in China plans to spend US$16 billion by 2020 to increase market share. The venture aims to achieve a 10% market share in five years, with plans to introduce over 10 new-energy models and sell 1 million units of Chevrolet and Buick brands. This expansion comes despite slower passenger-vehicle sales in China, with CEO Mary Barra citing the country's significant growth potential.

site_title: New Zealand posts slowest annual inflation in more than 15 years
summary: New Zealand's inflation rate slowed to 0.1% in the first quarter, the lowest in over 15 years, according to Statistics New Zealand. This supports expectations that the Reserve Bank of New Zealand may cut interest rates later this year. The central bank had signaled no rate hike until early 2017, and some traders now predict a rate cut by December. The New Zealand dollar fell after the report, which also showed a 0.3% decline in prices from the fourth quarter, the first consecutive decline since 1999.

site_title: Thin-film solar technology under scrutiny as China's Hanergy soars
summary: Chinese billionaire Li Hejun's Hanergy Holdings has seen its value surge six-fold to $37 billion, driven in part by Beijing's efforts to promote solar energy. However, industry experts say Hanergy's thin-film solar panels are not efficient or cheap enough to compete with conventional panels, with conversion rates up to 15% compared to 17-18% for traditional units. Despite this, Li remains confident that Hanergy has mastered the technology, predicting a global energy revolution and a market growth to $1.29 trillion in three years.

site_title: Japan manufacturers' mood slides on global uncertainty: Reuters Tankan
summary: Japan's manufacturers' confidence slid to 12 in April, the first time in three months, due to sluggish demand at home and abroad. The service sector, however, showed an improvement, with a sentiment index of 25, its highest since last June. Companies cited weak demand and high import costs as concerns, while the Bank of Japan's policy board is set to meet on April 30 to issue new forecasts that may lead to a potential cut in its price projections. A sustained manufacturing weakness could hamper the economy's recovery.

site_title: Fury as 700 feared dead in 'avoidable' Med shipwreck
summary: At least 700 people are feared dead after an overcrowded boat capsized off Libya, with only 28 survivors. The incident, considered the deadliest in the Mediterranean, occurred on a 20-meter fishing boat carrying approximately 700 migrants. Italian authorities are calling for an emergency EU summit, while Pope Francis urges leaders to act decisively to stop such tragedies. The disaster is the latest in a series of mass drownings of migrants attempting to reach Europe, with the UN High Commissioner for Refugees urging the EU to restore a robust rescue-at-sea operation.

site_title: Quick take: China cuts reserve ratio by 100bps, injects US$200b of new liquidity
summary: China's central bank cut the reserve requirement ratio (RRR) by 100 basis points, injecting US$200 billion of new liquidity into the system. This move aims to boost growth and support credit growth, with analysts predicting a 1.2 trillion yuan injection. Economists expect more easing to be needed to contain disinflation, with potential policy rate cuts in Q2 and 2H2015. The RRR cut is the largest since November 2008, and is seen as a response to weak data releases and concerns over the growth slowdown.

site_title: Markets could be caught unready if BOJ succeeds on inflation: Kuroda
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda warned that financial markets may be caught off guard if the central bank achieves its 2% inflation target in 2016 and interest rates rise as a result. Kuroda said the BOJ's expansionary monetary policy has been working to crack deflation, but there's a gap between market expectations and the central bank's confidence in hitting its target. Kuroda expects interest rates to gradually increase, which could surprise Japanese markets, but added that the BOJ doesn't think it's necessary to adjust policy at this stage.

site_title: London's financial vacancies up 19% in March, survey shows
summary: London's financial services industry saw a 19% increase in job vacancies in March, reaching 9,135, as firms hired to manage compliance and governance demands. The surge follows probes by UK and global regulators into benchmark interest rates, currency markets, and money laundering. Professionals with change management and corporate governance skills are in high demand, commanding a salary premium. The growth is expected to continue through Q2 2015, making it a favorable environment for job seekers.

site_title: Utilities see solar panels as threat to power lines and bottom line
summary: Hawaii's utilities are struggling to adapt to the growing popularity of home solar panels, which now account for 12% of the state's homes. The Hawaiian Electric Company, the state's largest utility, has been blocking solar installations due to concerns about the strain on its infrastructure. However, state energy officials have ordered the utility to begin installations, and thousands of applications have been approved in recent weeks. The issue has sparked a battle between utilities and solar companies, with some utilities trying to reduce incentives or add fees to stem the rise of solar.

site_title: IMF meetings end with Greece unresolved, deflation fears eased
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) concluded its April 17-19 meetings without a resolution on Greece's debt crisis, with European peers pushing for austerity measures. However, deflation fears appear to be diminishing, with the IMF's David Lipton stating the risk has decreased. The US dollar's rise is causing currency volatility, and central banks are preparing for potential interest rate hikes. The Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank, a proposed Chinese-led multilateral fund, was also a topic of discussion. Despite a lack of progress on Greece, the IMF meetings marked a shift in focus towards other global economic issues.

site_title: Prologis agrees to acquire KTR portfolio for US$5.9 billion
summary: Prologis agrees to acquire KTR Capital Partners' portfolio for $5.9 billion, expanding its presence in key US markets such as Southern California, New Jersey, and Chicago. The acquisition will add to Prologis' forecasted annual core funds from operations by $0.14 per share. KTR owns approximately 70 million square feet of real estate in 25 markets, with a focus on California, New Jersey, and Chicago. The deal is part of a growing trend in US industrial real estate, with prices rising 17% in the past year and within 2% of their 2007 peak.

site_title: Asking prices for homes in England hit new high: Rightmove
summary: Asking prices for homes in England hit a new record of £286,133 in April, up 1.6% from the previous month, according to Rightmove. The increase was driven by a shortage of homes on the market, with newly marketed properties down 4% from last year. Visits to Rightmove's website rose by 20% to an all-time high. The record price growth comes ahead of the UK's national election and may influence policy on housing.

images.alt_text: Asking prices for homes on sale in England and Wales hit an all-time in the month to early April, pushed up by a fall in the number of properties on the market, property website Rightmove said on Monday.

site_title: Big iron holds firm as price outlook nears Rio's fantasy land
summary: Iron ore prices have plummeted to a decade low of $47.08, despite forecasts being slashed, as major producers Rio Tinto and BHP Billiton boost output. The swift price drop has caught the industry off guard, with analysts warning that the strategy of increasing production may be "dumb." Credit downgrades and China's steel output notching its worst first quarter in two decades loom, with prices potentially falling below $30 a ton, forcing producers to shut mines. The industry faces a "breaking point" if prices continue to decline.

site_title: Lui opens new maritime heritage exhibit at 10th Singapore Maritime Week
summary: Transport Minister Lui Tuck Yew opened the 10th Singapore Maritime Week at the Marina Bay Sands, highlighting the growing role of Singapore as a maritime hub. The week features 30 events, including a maritime technology conference and the Singapore International Maritime Awards, attracting 54,000 attendees. A new maritime heritage exhibition was also launched, tracing Singapore's evolution into a global maritime centre. The event aims to engage the public and promote collaboration among maritime leaders to address industry challenges.

site_title: Indonesia's Lippo appoints banks for initial US$200m e-commerce funding
summary: Indonesia's Lippo Group has appointed Credit Suisse, Bank of America Merrill Lynch, and Rothschild to lead a US$200 million funding round for its e-commerce push. The funding will support the launch of online payment, chat, and other services early next year. Lippo aims to dominate Indonesia's e-commerce market, which is expected to receive an additional US$500 million in investment for a new online department store.

site_title: Anything goes
summary: Indie eatery Lollapalooza offers a free-style menu that changes daily, providing customers with an unpredictable dining experience. Located at 1A Keong Saik Road, the restaurant's menu is not fixed, allowing chefs to experiment with new dishes and flavors.

site_title: China-Pakistan to sign US$28 billion in projects during Xi visit
summary: China and Pakistan will sign agreements for US$28 billion in energy and infrastructure projects during President Xi Jinping's visit to Islamabad. The US$45 billion China-Pakistan Economic Corridor will connect China's western Xinjiang region to Pakistan's Gwadar port on the Arabian Sea, providing access to the Indian Ocean and improving transport networks and power supply in Pakistan. Chinese companies will invest US$22.5 billion in energy projects, while China will provide concessional loans for infrastructure projects. The agreements aim to deepen cooperation between the two nations beyond defense.

site_title: IKEA to invest up to 3b euros in shopping centres
summary: IKEA plans to invest up to 3 billion euros in new shopping centers over the next 5-7 years, mainly in China and Russia, where the retail sector is growing rapidly. The company aims to collect rent from retailers and increase customer traffic to its stores. Since forming IKEA Centres, the division has grown its property portfolio to 9-10 billion euros, with 58 out-of-town malls and retail parks in 13 European countries and China.

site_title: Airlines slash flights to Moscow in latest sign of Russia's growing isolation
summary: Airlines are slashing flights to Moscow, with easyJet reducing its London-Moscow service from two daily flights to one in each direction. This move follows a decline in demand due to Russia's growing isolation and economic recession. Other airlines, including Delta Air Lines, Cathay Pacific, and Air India, are also cutting back or suspending flights to Moscow. The reduced traffic mirrors the country's weakening economic clout, with fewer Russians vacationing abroad and fewer foreign business people and tourists visiting.

site_title: Foreign investors ready for direct access to Saudi bourse
summary: Saudi Arabia's $500 billion-plus bourse is set to open its doors to foreigners in June, making it one of the last major global bourses to allow direct investment. The move is expected to attract foreign investors, who are willing to accept the associated risks. This is the most anticipated economic reform in the region, rivaling Brazil and Russia's markets. The opening is seen as a significant step towards increasing foreign investment in Saudi Arabia.

site_title: Robust corporate earnings set to boost Nikkei, say analysts
summary: Japan's corporate earnings season is set to boost the Nikkei 225 index, with analysts predicting earnings above consensus forecasts. Stronger-than-expected results could dispel concerns of a "bubble" and send Tokyo stocks above the 20,000 level. Analysts attribute the growth to productivity and restructuring efforts, rather than the weaker yen. The predicted surge in corporate earnings could also boost consumption and investment in Japan, helping to drive economic growth.

site_title: Sale of US arms fuels the wars of Arab states
summary: US arms sales are fueling the wars of Arab states, particularly Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates, as they seek to counter Iran's influence in the region. The countries have stockpiled US military hardware, including F-15 fighter jets and Predator drones, and are expected to make large purchases of advanced weapons, including the F-35 fighter jet. This has raised concerns about the potential for an arms race and the escalation of sectarian conflicts in the Middle East. US defence firms are benefiting from the increased demand, but experts warn of the risks of these arms sales being misused.

site_title: Fee-driven scheme behind American Realty deals
summary: A class-action lawsuit accuses American Realty Capital Properties Inc. managers of manipulating cash-flow data to inflate stock for takeovers, generating over $900 million in managers' fees and bonuses. The scheme allegedly led to a $4 billion market value drop and $20 billion in assets added to the company. Ex-chairman Nicholas Schorsch and his controlled entities received hundreds of millions of dollars in fees, while investors lost money. The US Justice Department and Securities and Exchange Commission are also investigating the company's accounting errors and cover-ups.

site_title: Russian hackers' attempt to get sanctions data fails: FireEye
summary: Russian hackers linked to the Russian government attempted to infiltrate discussions on sanctions policy using previously unknown flaws in Microsoft's Windows and Adobe's Flash. The attack, attributed to Advanced Persistent Threat 28 (APT28), was detected by US cybersecurity firm FireEye on April 13 and halted before data extraction. APT28 used zero-day exploits, which are highly sought after by hackers, to try to infiltrate the computer systems of its victim. Adobe has created a fix for the vulnerability, while Microsoft is working on a patch, and the US State Department declined to comment on the attack.

site_title: Grace Fu heading to Jakarta for Asian-African ministerial meeting
summary: Singapore Cabinet Minister Grace Fu will lead a delegation to the Asian-African ministerial meeting in Jakarta on Monday, focusing on strengthening South-South cooperation and inter-regional dialogue. The meeting, hosted by Indonesia, aims to address regional issues and promote mutual benefit. Grace Fu will deliver a national statement and meet with ministers from Asian and African countries, while Indonesia's Foreign Minister Retno Marsudi chairs the event. The conference, commemorating Indonesia's 60th anniversary, will run until Friday and discuss topics such as security, Yemen, Syria, and the South China Sea territorial conflict.

site_title: S'pore still seen as major Asia Reit hub
summary: Singapore remains a major hub for real estate investment trusts (Reits) in Asia despite India and China developing frameworks for Reits. Both countries have large asset bases, but face tax and high interest rate hurdles that make it challenging for Reits to attract institutional investors and listings. India's Reit framework is still in the process of being shaped, while China lacks a draft of Reit legislation. Singapore's clear regulatory and tax frameworks give it an advantage, with its Reits offering a yield spread of 380 basis points over risk-free government bonds.

site_title: When pennies seem to be real market leaders
summary: The Singapore stock market has experienced a surge in interest in low-priced issues, known as penny stocks, following a year of low volume and reduced commissions. Retail clients are attracted to these stocks due to their potential for limited downside risk. This trend has brought relief to the dealing community, but it may also be driven by momentum and fear of missing out, rather than fundamental analysis. Meanwhile, global financial risks have increased, with the IMF warning of rising tensions and the Bank of America-Merrill Lynch survey showing that equity markets are overvalued.

site_title: China's Hanergy soars but doubts remain over its thin-film solar technology
summary: China's Hanergy Holdings, led by Li Hejun, has seen its value surge six-fold to US$37 billion, driven by the green energy potential of thin-film solar panels. However, doubts remain over the company's ability to translate laboratory research into commercially successful products. Hanergy Thin Film Power's Hong Kong-listed unit has surpassed its rivals, but the company's success is yet to be proven.

images.alt_text: Hanergy chief says the company is ready for a mass rollout of its products and that thin-film technology is already mature. But some experts say the firm's products are not efficient or cheap enough and are far from ready to take any major market share from conventional panels made with crystalline silicons.

site_title: Greenback suffers worst week in a month
summary: The US dollar experienced its worst week in a month, falling 1.6% against 10 major peers, according to the Bloomberg Dollar Spot Index. This decline was attributed to weaker-than-forecast economic data, including retail sales, industrial production, and jobless claims. The Federal Reserve's interest rate hike outlook has also been clouded, with some analysts predicting a delay in rate increases. The dollar's decline was further fueled by European Central Bank President Mario Draghi's comments, which suggested the region's recovery may not materialize this year.

site_title: Abuse of ADHD pills moves to include US offices
summary: US workers are misusing ADHD pills such as Adderall, Vyvanse, and Concerta to improve work performance, with many using the medications without a prescription or proper evaluation. Experts express concern over the risks of addiction, anxiety, and hallucinations, as well as the pressure in the workplace to join the trend. Misusers often obtain pills by feigning symptoms of ADHD or trading with colleagues. The number of stimulant misusers has risen sharply, with 2.6 million American adults receiving ADHD medication in 2012. Researchers caution that the medications may not improve learning or understanding, but rather attention and motivation.

site_title: Boards here and Down Under: Spot the differences
summary: Singapore and Australia, two nations celebrating 50 years of formal relations, share similarities in corporate governance practices despite differences in board dynamics. Australian boards are seen as risk-averse due to strict regulations and high standards of accountability, whereas Singaporean boards are more international in outlook and willing to venture into Asia. There are also differences in remuneration, board culture, and diversity, with Singapore having lower disclosure standards and a more optimistic outlook. Despite these differences, the two countries are expected to benefit from synergies in corporate governance practices, leading to significant strides in best practices.

images.alt_text: Australian boards face the "two strikes" rule where an entire company board can face re-election if at least 25 per cent of shareholders disagree with how much executives are being paid.

site_title: GM car owners to fight on for billions after bankruptcy ruling
summary: GM car owners will continue to seek $7.5 billion in compensation for the diminished value of recalled vehicles, despite a ruling that largely frees the company from liability for wrongdoing before its 2009 bankruptcy. The ruling, made by US bankruptcy judge Robert Gerber, limits GM's liability to claims related to actions taken after its bailout. Approximately 10 million drivers are eligible to sue, with estimated damages ranging from $750 per vehicle, based on price declines of $357 to $1,700.

site_title: Comcast, Time Warner Cable to meet US Justice Dept officials over merger: WSJ
summary: Comcast and Time Warner Cable are set to meet US Justice Department officials to discuss competition concerns raised by their planned $45 billion merger. The meeting aims to negotiate possible concessions addressing concerns that the combined company would have too much power in the Internet broadband market and unfair competitive leverage against TV channel owners. The Justice Department and Federal Communications Commission have raised concerns about the deal, with some staff attorneys nearing a recommendation to block the merger. A final decision would be made by senior officials.

site_title: Germany's 'smart factories' have some way to go
summary: Germany's industrial sector is lagging behind in adopting "Industrie 4.0" technologies, with only four out of 10 companies using digitization. Despite the potential for increased efficiency and quality, many firms are hesitant due to high investment costs and complexity. Experts warn that Germany risks falling behind international competitors, particularly China and the US, if it doesn't accelerate digitization. A new working group has been launched to address these issues and promote the adoption of smart factories.

site_title: Volkswagen CEO survives challenge from powerful chairman
summary: Volkswagen CEO Martin Winterkorn has survived a challenge from powerful chairman Ferdinand Piech, with senior supervisory board members backing Winterkorn and proposing extending his contract beyond 2016. The move came after Piech criticized Winterkorn in a magazine article, but analysts say Piech's defeat is not a guarantee. The power struggle has raised concerns about the carmaker's ability to boost profits and revamp its US business, which has struggled under Winterkorn's leadership.

site_title: Big turnout on store day shows rebirth of vinyl
summary: On Record Store Day, approximately 3,000 independent stores in nearly two dozen countries released new and reissued records, marking a resurgence in vinyl sales. The event, which began in 2007, has led to a 260% increase in US vinyl sales since 2009, with the US being the largest vinyl market. Reissues, such as a rare Elvis Presley single, have contributed to the growth, with some 200 new record stores opening in the US and Canada last year. Despite accounting for only 2% of the global recording industry, vinyl's aesthetic value and perceived sound quality have drawn audiophiles and fans.

site_title: Private equity-owned SunGard Data explores US$10b sale or IPO
summary: SunGard Data Systems, a financial technology company owned by private equity firms, is exploring a potential sale or initial public offering valued at up to $10 billion, including debt. The company has asked investment banks to prepare for interviews and plans to simultaneously consider both options. This comes after being approached by another company about a potential takeover. SunGard was acquired for $11.4 billion in 2005 and has struggled to boost its value for its owners to achieve a decent return.

site_title: US$27b Russian Arctic gas project on stream despite cold, sanctions
summary: The US$27 billion Yamal gas megaproject in Russia's Arctic region has started operations despite cold temperatures and international sanctions. The joint venture, led by Novatek, Total, and CNPC, aims to produce 16.5 million tonnes of liquefied natural gas per year, primarily for European and Asian markets. Funding issues have been exacerbated by sanctions, but the project's leaders remain optimistic, with Total CEO Patrick Pouyanne stating it will be completed by 2017 and serve as a "launchpad for growth" in Russia.

site_title: IMF nations point to exchange rate, geopolitical risks
summary: The International Monetary Fund's member nations warned of risks to the global economy from exchange rate shifts and geopolitical tensions. Moderate global growth was noted, with economies in developed countries strengthening while some emerging nations face weaker commodity prices and exports. The panel called for effective communication of policy normalization to reduce adverse impacts on other economies, and emphasized the need for easy monetary policies to maintain low inflation. The US is poised to hike interest rates, and the panel warned of financial and economic disruptions due to diverging monetary policies.

site_title: Check Point CEO kept on his toes amid cyber stock surge
summary: Check Point Software Technologies Ltd, the world's top firewall provider, is facing increased competition from younger rivals such as Palo Alto Networks. Despite its high operating margin and stable market share, CEO Gil Shwed is ramping up efforts to defend against younger competitors and market to new clients. The company has bought two cybersecurity startups and plans to hire hundreds of people worldwide to attract new customers, aiming for double-digit revenue growth by 2016. Analysts expect Check Point to maintain its operating margins above 50% despite increased investment.

site_title: Singapore builds up local expertise for commodity trading sector
summary: Singapore is building local expertise in its commodity trading sector, a crucial industry given the country's status as the world's busiest port by tonnage. Local talent supply, however, remains a challenge, with Singaporeans making up only about 60% of the industry's 14,000 workers. Efforts are underway to develop local expertise, addressing a shortage that could impact the country's economic competitiveness.

images.alt_text: Prof Ng (left), dean of NTU's College of Engineering, and Prof Ravi, dean of the Nanyang Business School. The two schools are jointly rolling out the International Trading Programme this year that aims to equip students with the unique skills to be successful in the trading industry.

site_title: Future shock for markets - cyber attacks, stricter laws
summary: A PwC survey of over 250 capital markets executives worldwide reveals three top scenarios for potential disruptions: a crippling global cyber attack, stricter laws restricting business profitability, and loss of market share to non-traditional players. The survey also identifies top challenges as increasing client profitability, adapting to new technologies, and attracting and retaining employees. Companies anticipate returns on equity to settle at 12-14%, down from 20% in 2006-7. Aggressive outsourcing and consolidation can save companies half of their current trade costs, but new financial technology companies will bring management and regulatory challenges.

site_title: IMF member nations point to exchange rate and geopolitical risks
summary: The International Monetary Fund's member nations have warned of risks to the global economy due to exchange rate shifts and geopolitical tensions. Global growth is considered "moderate" with uneven prospects. Developed economies have strengthened, while some emerging nations face weaker commodity prices and exports. Policymakers are under pressure as China's GDP growth is expected to slow, and the UK economy shrinks for the second month in a row.

images.alt_text: There has been little sign at the meetings of a renewed flare-up in the "currency wars" despite a surge in the value of the US dollar against the euro and yen.

site_title: Game-changing plan to create new specialities, jobs
summary: Singapore's SkillsFuture initiative may lead to game-changing shifts in various sectors of the economy. The development of comprehensive Sectoral Manpower Plans (SMPs) could result in the emergence of new skills and jobs. This push aims to maximize the potential of every citizen, regardless of their background. Successful implementation of SkillsFuture could have a significant impact on the economy, leading to a shift in various industries and creating new career opportunities.

site_title: All that glitters
summary: Gold prices are influenced by various factors, including economic and political uncertainty, the US dollar, and US interest rates. As a safe-haven asset, gold tends to rise during times of uncertainty, but its price is also affected by the strength of the US dollar. A weaker dollar boosts demand for gold, while a stronger dollar tends to decrease demand. US interest rates also have a negative impact on gold prices, as higher rates increase the opportunity cost of investing in gold. Emerging markets, particularly Asia, are expected to play a larger role in gold demand, driven by growing economies and increasing incomes. Central banks are also expected to continue buying gold, despite a strong US dollar, as they seek to diversify their portfolios and hedge against inflation.

site_title: Indonesia tin group says its members won't sell below US$17,000 a tonne
summary: Indonesia's tin smelters and exporter PT Timah have agreed to slash production and stop selling tin below $17,000 a tonne to stem a sell-off, following previous failed attempts to boost prices. The move comes as tin prices on the London Metal Exchange have dropped 12% this week, trading under $15,000. Indonesia, the world's largest tin exporter, is forecast to see a 8-14% drop in shipments this year, largely due to increased exports from Myanmar to China.

site_title: UK Conservatives and Labour tied in neck-and-neck race
summary: The UK election is neck and neck between Conservatives and Labour, with neither party having a clear lead. Sterling is down 14% against the US dollar, and the stock market is jittery due to uncertainty over a potential right-center coalition or a Labour-Liberal Democrat coalition. Promises from both parties are seen as untrustworthy, with experts warning of a left-wing government that could lead to higher taxes, entitlements, and state spending. The budget deficit has fallen, but the IMF predicts a deficit in 2018 regardless of the outcome, and some economists warn that the UK economy is a "ticking time bomb" waiting to explode.

images.alt_text: The Conservative party election bus (left) facing the Liberal Democrat bus before a day of campaigning in London last Wednesday. The IMF predicts that Britain will still be in deficit in 2018 if the Conservatives win.

site_title: Plumping up shrivelled market for France's famed prunes
summary: France's Agen prunes, a centuries-old delicacy, face a shrinking market share due to competition from Chilean growers. Local farmers have invested in modern methods, such as larger orchards and advanced technology, to boost production and earnings. The industry aims to increase its market share, targeting new markets like China and Europe, while reducing dependence on EU subsidies. The effort is a gamble, as farmers test whether French traditions can adapt to modern competition, with the goal of eventually reaching 500 hectares of cultivation.

site_title: Tapping a new common market
summary: Businesses are gearing up to tap opportunities from the Asean Economic Community (AEC) as it overhauls South-east Asia's investment and financial market landscape. Companies like ABN AMRO, Clifford Chance, and HSBC see the AEC as a gateway to a population of 640 million and a growing middle class, offering opportunities for investment and growth. To remain relevant, businesses are adapting to the new market landscape by innovating, collaborating, and leveraging local expertise. However, challenges such as cultural and language differences, regulatory barriers, and the need for consistent customer experience across the region remain.

site_title: Evergrande of China offers refund option to home buyers
summary: Evergrande Real Estate Group, a Chinese developer, is offering a refund option to home buyers nationwide, allowing them to get their money back without reason before home delivery. The policy, effective April 16, is seen as a sales strategy to attract more buyers, but may weaken the company's cash flow. Evergrande aims for a 14% increase in contract sales this year to 150 billion yuan, despite a slowing market and high debt levels. The move is also seen as a step towards making unconditional refund policies the "new normal" in the industry.

site_title: China in stimulus mode cuts bank reserve ratio again
summary: China has cut the reserve-requirement ratio for banks by 1 percentage point, the largest since 2008, to boost lending and stimulate the economy. The move, effective April 20, is expected to add 1.2 trillion yuan to the banking system and fuel the stock market. The cut is part of China's efforts to address slow economic growth, an outflow of capital, and inflation concerns, with policymakers aiming to offset these issues and stabilize the macro environment.

site_title: China says has room for easing
summary: China's central bank Governor Zhou Xiaochuan said the country has room to ease monetary policies, but will adjust carefully. China's economy expanded at its slowest pace since 2009 in the first quarter, with industrial production and inflation indicators also showing signs of slowing. Despite this, Zhou emphasized that China's economy remains within a "reasonable range" and employment growth remains stable. The People's Bank of China has already lowered interest rates and reserve requirements, and Zhou expressed caution about deflation risks, but did not rule out further easing if needed.

site_title: Cornell's chocolate milk fills refuelling gap
summary: Cornell University's athletic department has partnered with the college of agriculture and life sciences to provide athletes with a locally produced, 1% low-fat chocolate milk as a recovery beverage. The drink, called Big Red Refuel, contains 16 grams of protein and 230 calories per serving, and has been shown to be an effective way to replenish muscle glycogen and promote recovery after workouts. The partnership has resulted in improved recovery habits among athletes, with many reporting improved performance and reduced fatigue. The collaboration has also led to other universities forming similar relationships with their dairy programs.

site_title: The lady confronting Google is known for her tough resolve
summary: European Union's competition commissioner Margrethe Vestager filed formal antitrust charges against Google, alleging the search engine giant abused its market dominance by favoring its own comparison shopping service. If Google fails to refute the charges, it could face a fine of over $8.7 billion. Vestager, known for her toughness, has taken a narrower and more assertive approach to the case, which had been percolating in Brussels for over five years. Google has 10 weeks to respond, and Vestager is also investigating accusations of anticompetitive practices regarding Google's relationships with device manufacturers.

site_title: Japan, US ministers hail good start on trade talks
summary: Japanese Economy Minister Akira Amari and US Trade Representative Michael Froman said bilateral trade negotiations began on a positive note, with discussions on outstanding issues like farm and auto trade to continue on Monday. The talks could pave the way for a broader trans-Pacific trade deal, including access to each other's markets, a key hurdle to the long-delayed Trans-Pacific Partnership pact.

site_title: Getting to grips with forex markets
summary: The article discusses the complexities of the foreign exchange (forex) market, a relative game where traders play one currency against another. Understanding the risks, technical analysis, and fundamental factors are crucial for success. The forex market is influenced by global capital flows, central bank policy, and inflation expectations, making it a dynamic and subjective market. Key considerations include risk management, discipline, and understanding supply and demand. The current market backdrop features changing central bank policies and a potential for extreme volatility, making it an exciting but challenging market for traders.

site_title: UOB in deal to boost FDI, trade between Vietnam and Asean
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) and Vietnam's Foreign Investment Agency (FIA) signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) to boost foreign direct investments (FDI) and trade between Vietnam and Southeast Asia. This is the FIA's first MOU with a bank, marking a significant step in fostering economic ties between the two regions. The agreement was announced during a visit by Singapore's Trade and Industry Minister Lim Hng Kiang to Vietnam. The partnership aims to promote economic growth and development in the region.

site_title: No big changes in Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac fee structure
summary: The US regulator for Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac announced adjustments to mortgage guarantee fees, keeping costs largely the same for most borrowers. Borrowers with weaker credit will pay slightly lower fees, while most others will see prices remain the same. Certain riskier loans will become incrementally more expensive. The moves aim to balance easing credit with ensuring financial soundness, with fees remaining about twice 2009 levels.

site_title: Japan, US claim good start to TPP talks
summary: Japanese and US ministers reported a positive start to bilateral trade negotiations for a Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) deal. Japan's Economy Minister Akira Amari and US Trade Representative Michael Froman discussed remaining issues, such as farm and car trade, on the first day of negotiations. Japan is resisting US demands for increased access to its rice market and is seeking to reduce tariffs on US car imports. A breakthrough is hoped for before a bilateral summit on April 28, with President Barack Obama and Prime Minister Shinzo Abe expected to welcome progress.

site_title: A golden opportunity?
summary: A study by the World Gold Council suggests that gold can be a valuable asset in portfolios, with investors allocating between 2.5-11% of their investments to gold. Gold can be accessed through various methods, including futures contracts, gold-backed exchange-traded funds (ETFs), and investing in gold mining companies. These options offer diversification and can provide a defensive asset during times of rising debt and low interest rates.

site_title: SABIC Q1 net profit down 39%
summary: Saudi petrochemicals giant SABIC reported a 39% decline in net profits in Q1 2015, reaching 3.93 billion riyals (US$1.05 billion). The drop in oil prices from above $100 to around $56 per barrel has affected petrochemical prices, resulting in lower average sale prices and a fall in net income. SABIC's acting CEO attributed the decline to the cyclical nature of the industry, but expressed optimism about the long-term outlook and global presence of the company.

site_title: Indonesia govt, football association in standoff
summary: The Indonesian government and football association, PSSI, are in a standoff over the suspension of the domestic league. The sports ministry announced the suspension and plans to replace PSSI, citing the association's decision to halt the league. The move has sparked anger from FIFA, which could lead to further repercussions. The standoff is a result of a dispute between the government and PSSI over the direction of Indonesian football.

site_title: Investor sentiment about Brazil turning more positive
summary: Brazil's investor sentiment has turned more positive, with a recent selloff in financial markets seen as overdone. Inflation is expected to slow down, and the government's efforts to bring finances under control have gained traction. State-run oil company Petrobras is also expected to post financial statements, reducing the risk of a debt crisis. The real and Bovespa index have gained over 7% since March, while local-currency denominated debt has dropped. Investors are adjusting their portfolios to take advantage of declining inflation and interest rates, but economists still expect a recession and economic contraction this year.

site_title: Oil price soars, gold climbs while tin slumps
