summary: Oil prices surged, with Brent crude reaching $64.00 a barrel, as analysts predicted easing US shale oil production could curb the global supply glut. Gold prices also rose, driven by uncertainty over Greece's potential eurozone exit. Tin prices, however, slumped due to oversupply fears, while other metals like copper and aluminium rose. The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec) predicted US crude production would fall in the second half of the year, reducing the global oversupply.

site_title: Russia kept at junk rating with negative outlook by S&P
summary: Russia's foreign-currency credit rating was kept at junk rating (BB+) with a negative outlook by Standard & Poor's, due to policy makers' struggles to boost growth and the financial system's weakening due to sanctions and low oil prices. The rating was unchanged, placing Russia's rating on par with Bulgaria and Indonesia. Sanctions have locked out Russian corporate borrowers from international debt markets and weakened the ruble, which has lost half its value since last year.

site_title: China cuts bank reserve ratio requirement
summary: China's central bank cut the bank reserve ratio requirement by one percentage point, effective Monday, to boost lending. This move follows a similar cut in February and aims to "further enhance the ability of financial institutions to support restructuring." The cuts apply to various banks, including those providing agricultural and small-business loans. The move comes days after China reported its worst quarterly growth figure in six years, with GDP growth slowing to 7.0% in the first quarter.

site_title: Russian hackers use zero-days to try to get sanctions data
summary: Russian hackers linked to the government used previously unknown flaws in Microsoft's Windows and Adobe's Flash to try to infiltrate discussions on sanctions policy. The attack, detected by US cybersecurity firm FireEye, targeted an overseas agency and was halted before data was extracted. The hacking group, APT28, is known for advanced cyber-attacks and used zero-day exploits, which are weaknesses not previously detected. Adobe has created a fix for the vulnerability, while Microsoft is working on a patch. The attack was the latest in a series targeting the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and other governments.

site_title: Germanwings crash families could seek damages in the US
summary: Families of victims in the Germanwings crash are considering filing US court claims for damages if an agreement with parent airline Lufthansa cannot be reached. The crash killed all 150 people on board, with investigators blaming co-pilot Andreas Lubitz's deliberate actions. US courts typically award higher payouts for pain and suffering, and families are seeking 1 million euros (US$1.1 million) per victim. Compensation talks with Lufthansa are expected to start soon, but families may seek US court action if an agreement is not reached.

site_title: New CIMB CEO sets ambitious goals to be met by 2018
summary: Malaysia's second-largest lender CIMB has appointed Zafrul Abdul Aziz as its new CEO, replacing Nazir Razak. Aziz, 42, joined the firm in 2014 and became CEO in February 2015, with ambitious goals to be met by 2018. He stated that current realities render some historical cost structures irrelevant, indicating a shift in strategy for the bank.

images.alt_text: "Our Asian platform will be intact but we will have to operate it at the right cost structure in line with the difficult market environment." - Mr Zafrul (above)

site_title: China March home prices fall 6.1% y-o-y
summary: China's average new home prices fell 6.1% from a year earlier in March, marking the seventh consecutive month of decline. Prices dropped 3.7% in Beijing and 5% in Shanghai. The slowdown in property sales volumes was attributed to government support measures and developers focusing on clearing excess inventory. This marks the lowest rate of real estate investment growth since 2009.

site_title: Buying surges while sales remain low and buybacks fall
summary: In the third week of April, buying activity by directors surged with 37 purchases worth S$4.16 million, while sales remained low with only two firms disposing of S$0.23 million. In contrast, buyback activity declined with 12 companies repurchasing S$10 million. Notable trades included buybacks in BreadTalk Group and insider buys in Sarine Technologies.

site_title: Deutsche will sell Postbank but won't exit retail business, say sources
summary: Deutsche Bank plans to sell Postbank but maintain its own retail business, according to sources. The overhaul, set to be decided by management this week, involves deep cuts, including closing up to a third of its remaining German branches. Only two management board members support dumping all retail activities, while six favor selling Postbank. The bank's retail business will be significantly pared back, but not eliminated.

images.alt_text: Revamp will involve deep cuts, including closing up to a third of the group's remaining German branches

site_title: Terror arrests in Australia over planned Anzac Day attack
summary: Australian police arrested two 18-year-olds for allegedly planning an Islamic State-inspired terrorist attack using edged knives on an Anzac Day ceremony. Seven search warrants were executed in Melbourne, with a third man also arrested on weapons charges. The planned attack was reportedly inspired by the Islamic State group and targeted police officers, although authorities say no evidence suggests a beheading. The arrests come amid heightened security measures following a series of incidents and the country's deployment of troops to Iraq to combat the Islamic State group.

site_title: Warner Bros posts 'Batman v Superman' trailer early after leak
summary: Warner Bros. released a trailer for "Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice" three days early after a leaked version surfaced online. The clip features a voiceover about Superman and introduces Ben Affleck as Bruce Wayne/Batman. The leaked trailer included Portuguese subtitles and was recorded on a phone or handheld camera. Despite the early leak, Warner Bros. plans to screen the trailer at Imax Corp. theaters starting April 20. The movie is set to release on March 25, 2016.

site_title: Ford to spend US$2.5b on plants in Mexico, angering UAW
summary: Ford plans to invest US$2.5 billion in Mexico to build fuel-efficient engines and transmissions, creating 3,800 jobs. The move is expected to raise concerns among the United Auto Workers union, which may impact US labor talks with Ford, General Motors, and Fiat Chrysler Automobiles. Ford's investment is driven by Mexico's proximity to the US market and lower labor costs, complicating the UAW's efforts to raise worker pay and keep jobs in the US.

site_title: Volkswagen to develop budget SUVs, MPVs in China
summary: Volkswagen plans to develop budget SUVs and MPVs in China to keep up with the growing demand for these vehicles. The company's China chief executive, Jochem Heizmann, stated that the lack of affordable SUVs and MPVs contributed to Volkswagen's struggles in the first quarter of 2015. Retail sales of SUVs in China increased by over a third last year, and Volkswagen aims to address this issue with "concrete projects" and a product family. The company plans to boost manufacturing capacity and become more responsive to the market to stay competitive in China's growing passenger car market.

site_title: California gas pipeline explosion, fire injure up to 15 people
summary: A construction crew accidentally ruptured a 12-inch natural gas transmission line in Fresno, California, on Friday, sparking an explosion and fire that injured up to 15 people, including three critically. The pipeline was struck by a backhoe near state Highway 99, prompting the closure of the highway and an adjacent railroad line. Four of the injured were taken to a hospital with burns, and the cause of the accident is under investigation by the California Public Utilities Commission and the Pipeline and Hazardous Materials Safety Administration.

site_title: Investors prospect for gems at ShareInvestor roadshow
summary: Investors at the Malaysia Gems 2015 roadshow were advised to evaluate a business's key characteristics before investing. Clive Tan, director of 8 Investment, suggested considering factors such as industry competition, management, and cash position. He noted that industries with high competition, like aviation, may experience low profit margins, while niche markets with fewer players can maintain higher profit margins. The event also featured presentations from Malaysian companies, highlighting the country's projected 4.5% GDP growth despite economic headwinds.

site_title: Barring fears of Grexit and a bursting of China's equity bubble, stocks could rebound
summary: US stocks are expected to stabilize this week, barring further shocks from Greece, the US housing market, or the technology sector. Despite earnings season showing a decline of 2% overall, many companies have topped low expectations, with business booming in commercial real estate and corporate mergers. Analysts say the dollar's appreciation has already been "baked into the cake" of stock prices, and a rate hike by the Federal Reserve is expected. If the eurozone and Chinese stock markets can hold together, US stocks may recover lost ground.

images.alt_text: On the plus side for markets, business on Wall Street appears to be booming once more.

site_title: G20 discusses plans to sidestep US on IMF reforms
summary: The Group of 20 (G20) finance ministers and central bank governors met in Washington, discussing ways to raise emerging countries' voting rights at the IMF, sidestepping US opposition. The US can block reforms due to its controlling share of votes. The G20 agreed on an "ad hoc" interim plan, but it was dropped from the final communique. The US Treasury Secretary vowed to continue pressing Congress to approve the reforms, while Russia supported a "de-linking" proposal, which would temporarily suspend the US veto power.

site_title: G20 more upbeat on growth, but officials fret over Greece
summary: The G20 finance ministers and central bankers expressed a more optimistic outlook on global growth, citing improved prospects in rich nations, but warned of challenges from emerging markets, exchange rate volatility, and geopolitical tensions. Despite this, officials are concerned about Greece's inability to reach a deal with its lenders, which could impact Europe's recovery. The G20 emphasized the need for policymakers to carefully calibrate their actions to minimize negative spillovers and protect emerging markets from capital outflows.

site_title: Etsy IPO is test of corporate governance for B Corp firms
summary: Etsy, a certified Benefit Corporation (B Corp), made its debut on the Nasdaq stock market, becoming only the second for-profit company to go public with this certification. The online craft bazaar is part of a growing number of companies that adhere to social and environmental accountability guidelines. Etsy's IPO marks a test of corporate governance for B Corp firms, following over 1,000 companies with this certification.

site_title: Greece, creditors to hold more debt talks Saturday
summary: Greece and its international creditors will meet in Paris on Saturday to discuss the massive debt bailout program and reforms required for urgently needed funds. The talks, which have been elusive, come as Athens runs out of money to pay creditors, raising the risk of default and a chaotic exit from the single currency bloc. Greece wants the last $7.8 billion bailout funding, but has balked at tough reform conditions demanded by creditors. The Brussels group, comprising Greece, EU, ECB, IMF, and European Stability Mechanism, aims to discuss numbers and detailed tables to keep the process moving.

site_title: Petrobras says covers 2015 financial needs with loans, sale
summary: Brazil's state-run oil giant Petrobras approved 18.6 billion reais (US$6.12 billion) in credit and sale operations to meet its 2015 financial needs due to a widening corruption scandal. Nearly 70% of the new credit lines came from state-run lenders, as the company remains cut off from debt markets. Petrobras plans to sell US$13.7 billion worth of assets to shore up its finances, including a US$3 billion sale and leaseback of oil platforms with Standard Chartered PLC. The company will release its 2014 financial results after a board meeting on April 22.

site_title: Europe: Shares drop sharply; traders cite China regulation concerns
summary: European shares dropped sharply on Friday, with the FTSEurofirst 300 down 1.8% and the Frankfurt DAX down 2.6%. Traders cited weakness in Chinese futures markets and regulatory concerns, including a potential clampdown on margin trading, as drivers of the market volatility. Disappointing corporate reports and concerns over Greece's debt stand-off also contributed to the decline.

site_title: US: Stocks drop as Greece fears override bank results
summary: US stocks dropped 1.28% on Friday, falling 231.35 points to 17,826.30, despite large banks beating earnings expectations. Worries about high equity valuations and the Greek debt crisis overshadowed the positive bank results. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell for the second week in a row, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq also reaching fresh records despite concerns over US-EU trade tensions.

site_title: Google revolutionises search to help mobile users
summary: Google is changing its search algorithm to favor mobile-friendly websites, ranking them higher in search results for mobile device searches. The goal is to ensure users can easily find relevant and readable content on smaller screens. This change reflects the increasing use of mobile devices for online searches, with people seeking content that is easy to read and interact with on these devices.

images.alt_text: Google search on Tuesday will start factoring in how easy websites are to read on smartphones or tablet computers, underlining the changing way people surf the Internet.

site_title: G20 says volatile currencies pose risk after dollar surges
summary: The G20 group of finance chiefs warned that volatile currencies pose a risk to the global economy, citing the surge in the US dollar as a key concern. The dollar has risen 17% over the past year, leading to worries about capital controls and market instability. Emerging economies, particularly those tied to the dollar, are at risk of capital flight and economic challenges. The G20 advised these countries to adopt policies to smooth cash flows and recommended macroeconomic adjustments to manage volatile capital flows.

site_title: Samsung removes logo on smartphones in Japan
summary: Samsung has removed its corporate logo from its new smartphones sold in Japan, presenting them as "Docomo Galaxy" and "au Galaxy" instead. The move comes as the company struggles in the Japanese market, where Apple is dominant. Samsung rolled out its new phone in South Korea last week, aiming to reverse its fortunes. The reason for removing the logo is not provided by the company. This decision is seen as a strategic move to focus on partnerships with Japanese telecom service providers.

site_title: European power bourse Epex spot to swallow Anglo-Dutch APX
summary: European power bourse Epex Spot is set to acquire Anglo-Dutch rival APX group, creating a large pan-European trading operator. The deal, closing on May 4, will see EEX group, controlled by Deutsche Boerse, own 51% of the new Epex Spot. TenneT, Elia, and RTE will own the remaining 49%. The merger aims to harmonize trading systems, reduce costs, and increase liquidity, making the CWE power market more attractive.

site_title: Idea of Bursa-SGX merger 'far-fetched'
summary: Bursa Malaysia's CEO, Tajuddin Atan, dismisses the idea of a merger between Bursa and Singapore Exchange, citing the existing connectivity and familiarity between the two exchanges as a more realistic option. He notes that the current infrastructure facilitates cross-border trading, and brokers already have a significant presence in both countries. Atan also downplays the "Clob stigma" that may have deterred Singapore investors from buying Malaysian shares, suggesting that it is no longer a significant issue.

site_title: Grand Copthorne launches food waste recycling project
summary: The Grand Copthorne Waterfront Hotel in Singapore has partnered with the National Environment Agency to launch a food waste recycling pilot project. The hotel has installed a food waste digester, which converts waste into compost and nutrient-rich liquid for discharge into the sewage system, saving nearly S$3,000 a month on disposal charges and water usage. The project is part of Millennium & Copthorne's commitment to reduce, reuse, and recycle materials across its 120 hotels worldwide.

site_title: India takes "significant step" in HFC decision: US envoy
summary: India has agreed to phase down the use of potent greenhouse gas HFCs in appliances, a move considered a "significant step" towards global action on climate change. The decision, made after years of opposition, includes a 15-year transition period for developing countries. The amendment to the UN's Montreal Protocol aims to reduce HFC emissions, a highly potent form of greenhouse gas emissions, in refrigerators, air conditioners, and insulating foams. The US State Department's climate change envoy hailed the move as a crucial step towards global climate action.

site_title: Bank of China expanding presence in Singapore (Amended)
summary: The Bank of China is expanding its presence in Singapore with the opening of two new branches and 10 ATMs. The bank has also signed an agreement with the Singapore Exchange to strengthen the renminbi infrastructure and roll out yuan-denominated financial instruments. This includes commodities and derivatives contracts, and joint marketing efforts with SGX to offer firms access to growth opportunities in China and Singapore markets. The bank's Singapore unit has seen significant growth, with total assets reaching $38.3 billion and profit after tax increasing 72% to $237 million in 2014.

site_title: Oil falls from 2015 peaks, Brent jumps 9.6% on the week
summary: Oil prices fell from 2015 highs in choppy trading, but Brent crude rose 9.6% for its biggest weekly gain in over five years, driven by Middle East turmoil and lower US production. US crude also retreated from its 2015 high, with a 7.9% weekly gain. Yemen's conflict sparked the rally, and concerns about supply risks in the region, particularly Saudi Arabia, contributed to the price increase.

site_title: US piles pressure on Athens as Greek crisis roils markets
summary: The US is pressuring Greece to agree to key reforms in exchange for new EU financing, with the goal of preventing a default and keeping Greece in the eurozone. The US Treasury and President Barack Obama emphasized the need for Greece to implement comprehensive reforms, including tax collection and labor market reforms, to receive the additional $7.2 billion in bailout financing. However, Greek negotiators have balked at implementing austerity policies, and a deal must be reached by the April 24 Eurogroup meeting in Riga, Latvia, to avoid a potential default and market turmoil.

site_title: Pfizer wins first US trial over Zoloft birth-defect risk
summary: Pfizer has been cleared of liability in the first US trial over claims its antidepressant Zoloft causes birth defects in children born to women who take the drug while pregnant. The trial, which lasted a week, was brought by Kristyn Pesante, whose son was born with a rare congenital heart problem. Pesante sought damages, accusing Pfizer of downplaying Zoloft's risks to boost sales. The jury deliberated briefly and ultimately cleared Pfizer of liability, with no damages awarded.

site_title: Menu makeovers
summary: Four Singapore restaurants have introduced new menu makeovers. At Moosehead Kitchen-Bar, Australian chef Drew Wilson has taken over and created dishes with lighter flavors, such as seared watermelon and roasted cauliflower. Chef Wilson, who is new to Singapore, has been learning to shop for ingredients and balance flavors. At Jamie's Italian Singapore, Sardinian chef Alessandro Laconi has introduced new items, including Crispy Music Bread and Italian Nachos, following strict guidelines set by the restaurant chain. At Cook & Brew, Canadian chef Aaron Foster has introduced three separate menus, including a vegetable pierogi dish to educate customers about a new cuisine. At Akari Japanese Dining Bar, new head chef Hirotaka Murata is revamping the menu with an 11-course kaiseki menu priced at S$150++.

site_title: Grexit fears rise as IMF rebuffs payment delay
summary: Greek officials sought to downplay fears of a potential eurozone exit, after the IMF rejected suggestions that Athens would postpone loan repayments. Despite rising concerns, European officials and Greek Finance Minister Yanis Varoufakis insisted that Greece remains committed to the euro area. The April 24 deadline for a new financing deal looms, with Greece facing large debt repayments to the IMF and European Central Bank. The IMF managing director rejected payment delays, citing it has not occurred in 30 years.

site_title: Jakarta's commuters see no relief from traffic congestion
summary: Jakarta's traffic congestion is expected to persist for nearly a decade, with millions of commuters facing hours-long commutes daily. The city ranked top for traffic stops and starts, with an average driver stopping 33,240 times a year. A new mass rapid transit (MRT) system, set to open in 2018, is expected to provide some relief, but not until 2024 at the earliest. The government plans to build a light rail train and implement other initiatives to reduce traffic, but a solution to the city's congestion woes remains elusive.

site_title: Goldman, BOA sell US$7b of debt after posting profits
summary: Two major US banks, Goldman Sachs and Bank of America, have sold billions of dollars in debt to meet new capital rules following the financial crisis. Goldman Sachs sold $2 billion of perpetual preferred securities and Bank of America sold $5 billion in various debt offerings, including $2.5 billion of 10-year subordinated notes. The sales aim to boost reserves and improve leverage ratios for both banks. The move is seen as a cost-effective way for banks to meet regulatory requirements, with yields offering more than comparable government debt.

site_title: A two-tier market driven by penny stocks
summary: The Singapore stock market is experiencing a "two-tier" phenomenon, with penny stocks leading in terms of volume and percentage gains. This surge is attributed to proprietary traders capitalizing on a "feel-good" surge in sentiment triggered by massive gains in Hong Kong, following the launch of the Shanghai-Hong Kong Stock Connect. This has also sparked speculation about a potential link between the Singapore Exchange and China. Meanwhile, blue-chip stocks are experiencing reduced gains, with the Straits Times Index falling 6.42 points on Friday, reducing its weekly gain to 1.5%.

site_title: US warns export giants not to rely too much on US consumers
summary: The US Treasury Secretary, Jack Lew, warned that the global economy is relying too heavily on US consumers, urging other major exporters, including Germany and Japan, to boost domestic demand. Lew also called on China to revalue its yuan and Greece to commit fully to its bailout program. The US is concerned that this reliance on US demand could lead to an economic downturn. Lew emphasized the importance of holding to international commitments on exchange rate policies to avoid devaluing currencies.

site_title: Auditor raises issue on Blumont's ability to continue as a going concern
summary: Singapore - Blumont Group's independent auditor, Moore Stephens, has raised concerns about the company's ability to continue as a going concern due to a net loss of approximately S$66.2 million and a total comprehensive loss of approximately S$68.8 million for the 2014 financial year.

site_title: Samsung melds function and form in its S6s
summary: Samsung has revamped its Galaxy S series with the S6 and S6 Edge, featuring fast and wireless charging, longer battery life, and a sleeker interface. The new design prioritizes premium aesthetics and user experience, with a focus on intuitive and easy-to-understand features. The phones have dropped removable batteries and expandable storage, but offer advanced technologies such as a long-lasting battery and wireless charging. The S6 and S6 Edge are expected to be Samsung's best-selling phones to date, with analysts predicting strong demand and potentially record sales.

site_title: India March trade deficit highest in four months
summary: India's trade deficit in March was the highest in four months, reaching $11.79 billion, due to a decline in exports and a drop in global oil prices. Merchandise exports declined 1.2% to $310.5 billion, while imports fell 0.6% to $447.6 billion. Policymakers are concerned that weak foreign demand could hurt Prime Minister Narendra Modi's "Make in India" campaign, which aims to double exports to $900 billion over the next four years. Economists predict a sluggish export growth and a widening trade deficit, which could negatively impact India's GDP.

site_title: UK jobless claims fall to 40-year low, pay growth up
summary: UK jobless claims fell to a 40-year low of 772,400 in March, the lowest level since 1975, according to the Office for National Statistics. This marks the 29th consecutive month of decline. Pay growth also accelerated to 1.8% in basic pay, providing an electoral boost for Prime Minister David Cameron. The report comes ahead of the May 7 general election.

site_title: Chinese SUVs make inroads at home
summary: Chinese SUVs have gained significant ground in the domestic market, with eight Chinese brands ranking among the top 10 for the first time in two years. This growth is attributed to the increasing popularity of SUVs among Chinese drivers, who are opting for larger vehicles due to growing wealth and restricted single-car purchases in crowded cities. New entrants to the market, such as Great Wall and Changan, have built SUVs on sedan frames and priced them affordably, helping Chinese carmakers compete with foreign rivals. SUV sales are expected to continue growing, with IHS Automotive predicting a 21% increase this year.

site_title: EU's British finance chief woos London capital market leaders
summary: European Union's financial services chief, Jonathan Hill, recently addressed London's financial community, emphasizing the EU's plans to utilize London's strengths as a global trading center to boost economic growth. Hill praised London's ability to innovate and adapt to change. The EU aims to help markets raise more funds for the economy, highlighting London's key role in facilitating these efforts.

site_title: Challenging the status quo
summary: Fifteen Singaporean design studios are showcasing their works at the Triennale di Milano as part of the "Alchemists" exhibit, a nod to the 1970s Italian design movement Studio Alchimia. The showcase features a range of innovative designs, from interactive artefacts to furniture and textiles, that challenge the status quo and push the boundaries of design. The exhibit is curated by Stefano Casciani and Patrick Chia, and supported by grants from the DesignSingapore Council. The event aims to promote Singaporean designers globally and highlight the country's design talent.

site_title: The Connected life
summary: BMW's Connected Drive is an intelligent network technology that provides a seamless connection between the car and its environment. A built-in SIM card enables access to news, weather, real-time traffic information, and stock prices, as well as a suite of concierge services, including roadside assistance and emergency calls. The service is available on all BMWs sold in Singapore, with a 36-month free trial and optional renewal options. This comprehensive connectivity system aims to enhance the driving experience with convenience, safety, and infotainment features.

site_title: RBI said to oppose overseas settlement of debt
summary: The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) opposes the overseas settlement of India's sovereign debt, citing higher currency volatility as a concern. The RBI prefers foreign investors to engage local custodians or depositories instead of settling rupee bonds on Euroclear Bank SA or Clearstream Banking SA platforms. The government wants to make rupee debt eligible for these platforms to attract foreign investment and help fund India's current account deficit. RBI Governor Raghuram Rajan is in talks with institutions like Euroclear to settle trades in India while investors can work through a front elsewhere.

site_title: Schauble and Varoufakis: united by fear of failure
summary: German Finance Minister Wolfgang Schauble and Greek Finance Minister Yanis Varoufakis met in Washington, synchronizing their appearances at the World Bank and IMF spring meetings. Despite contrasting styles, both men expressed a common fear of failure and acknowledged the importance of saving the present, not endangering the future. Schauble emphasized the need for Greece to deliver on its commitments, while Varoufakis advocated for a compromise that makes economic sense and gives Greece a way forward, warning of the catastrophic consequences of failure. Both parties agree that failure would have global economic ramifications.

site_title: Singaporean demand for overseas properties continues to wane
summary: Singaporeans' demand for overseas properties has declined this year, with many investors waiting on the sidelines due to stricter regulations and cooling measures in popular markets such as London and Malaysia. The Monetary Authority of Singapore's survey showed a significant drop in overseas property purchases to S$1.07 billion in the first half of 2014, with properties in Britain, Malaysia, and Australia accounting for 76% of total transactions. Developers are cutting back on marketing exhibitions, while some are holding off on new projects, but overseas markets still see interest from buyers in other regions such as Hong Kong and the UAE.

site_title: Tat Hong expects Q4 loss
summary: Tat Hong Holdings, a Singapore-based crane operator, expects to report a loss for its fourth quarter ended March 31, 2015, due to sluggish Australian economy and weak performance of its Australian subsidiary. The company remains profitable for FY2015, despite the Q4 loss, and expects to disclose further details in its audited financial statements on May 29. This marks a 63% drop in net profit in the third quarter of 2014.

site_title: UEL's Multi-Fineline expects 25% rise in Q1 net sales
summary: UEL's subsidiary Multi-Fineline Electronix (MFLEX) expects Q1 net sales to be between US$145-150 million, a 25% increase from the prior year. Gross margin is anticipated to be above the company's guidance, driven by a favourable product mix and strong operational execution. The company's largest customer accounts for 65% of expected net sales, with newer customers contributing 30%. MFLEX's cash balance increased to US$155 million, and CEO Reza Meshgin expects strong second-quarter results.

site_title: Alibaba co-founder said to have bought penthouse at Le Nouvel Ardmore
summary: Alibaba co-founder Sun Tongyu is believed to have purchased a S$51 million penthouse at Le Nouvel Ardmore in Singapore. The 13,875 sq ft unit, spanning two levels, features five bedrooms and a private pool, and holds a record absolute price quantum for a penthouse in Singapore. Sun Tongyu, a Singapore permanent resident and former president of Taobao, is an investor in Singapore HealthTech Pte Ltd and has a history of investing in start-ups. The sale reflects the project's high-end market and S$3,676 per square foot price tag.

site_title: Insuring against market falls? Not worth it
summary: Schroders' head of structured fund management Thomas See says incorporating expensive insurance against market falls in low-rate environments is not justified due to negative returns. He uses a covered call strategy to offer 7-8% yields, selling call options on an equity income portfolio. This strategy trades away some upside for the call premium, but See believes the liquidity environment supports the fund. He notes that put options to insure against price plunges are not viable due to their high cost. This approach allows him to distribute high yields without incurring significant losses.

site_title: California farmers dig deeper as wells run dry
summary: California farmers are resorting to drilling 1,800 feet deep into the ground to access water as wells near Success Lake have run dry, leaving thousands without water. The state's agriculture industry, worth $43 billion, is under strain due to the fourth year of a record drought. Mandatory water rationing has been ordered by Governor Jerry Brown, and farmers are concerned about the long-term sustainability of groundwater resources. The situation is most severe in Tulare County, where 1,013 dry wells account for over half of those that have failed in the state since 2014.

site_title: China suspends bank technology rules
summary: China has suspended its bank technology rules, which were criticized as unfair regulatory pressure on foreign firms, until further notice. The decision comes after outcry from Washington and others. The rules, aimed at improving the security of banking technology, will be put on hold while the government solicits feedback from banks.

site_title: March NODX posts biggest monthly jump in over 3 years
summary: Singapore's NON-OIL domestic exports (NODX) surged 18.5% in March, the largest monthly increase in over 3 years, beating forecasts of a 1.1% dip. The strong electronics and non-electronics shipments, led by a 21.6% rise in pharmaceutical exports, reversed the 9.7% fall in February. The growth raised NODX levels to the highest since February 2012, but experts caution against being overly optimistic, citing a weak base for the electronics and pharmaceutical sectors, and potential slowdowns in PC-related exports and petrochemicals.

site_title: Tighter carbon emission scheme seen keeping car prices up
summary: A tightened carbon emissions-based vehicle scheme (CEVS) in Singapore is expected to keep car prices high despite a surge in Certificate of Entitlement (COE) supply. The new scheme, set to start July 1, 2015, will lower rebates for popular mass market models, but dealers predict COE premiums may not drop much due to continued demand from owners of ageing cars and a scramble to procure new cars before the deadline. COE premiums may remain high, with some dealers even anticipating prices to creep higher after July 1.

site_title: StarHub's CFO leaving for 'personal reasons'
summary: StarHub's CFO Nicholas Tan is resigning effective April 30 for "personal reasons". Tan joined the company in July 2013. The resignation was announced by StarHub on Friday, April 17, 2015.

site_title: Beijing will not use AIIB to fund Pakistan deal
summary: China will not use its Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB) or Silk Road fund to finance the US$46 billion Pakistan-China Economic Corridor, instead, both countries will jointly provide financing support. The project aims to connect Pakistan's Gwadar Port with China's Xinjiang region, bypassing the Straits of Malacca. Chinese Assistant Foreign Minister Liu Jianchao stated that financing details will be released during Chinese President Xi Jinping's upcoming visit to Pakistan, which is expected to focus on the corridor.

images.alt_text: BOOSTING CONNECTIVITY: The Pakistan-China Economic Corridor would shorten the route for China's energy imports, bypassing the Straits of Malacca between Malaysia and Indonesia.

site_title: Noble's AGM: Sound bites from Elman
summary: Noble Group's chairman, Elman, faced questions from shareholders during the AGM, including about the financial statement and Yancoal. Elman defended the company's actions, stating they adhere to rules and regulations. He also sidestepped questions about the company's annual report and independent directors, citing the need to stick to the meeting's agenda. The exchange was marked by tension, with Elman appearing defensive and dismissive of shareholder concerns.

site_title: New side of Bernanke: blogger provocateur
summary: Former Federal Reserve Chairman Ben Bernanke has launched a blog to share his thoughts on monetary policy, targeting those with an interest in inflation targeting, zero lower bounds, and term premiums. He has sparked online debates with former Treasury Secretary Larry Summers and criticized Germany's trade surplus. Bernanke has also offered advice on the Federal Open Market Committee's rate-setting and expressed concerns about the Fed's balance sheet size. The blog has gained attention, with Bernanke posting 10 times in its first 17 days, and he has been hired as an outside senior adviser by hedge fund Citadel.

images.alt_text: The bearded one went quiet after he left the Fed at the end of January 2014, but it turns out he was just gathering momentum for an upward surge, like a breaching killer whale.

site_title: Work staples
summary: A growing number of successful women, including fashion icons, wear a "work uniform" to the office, but many women feel pressure to constantly change their outfits. Experts say that wearing the same thing daily may be perceived as lazy or uncreative, but it can also be a deliberate statement of personal style. To rock a uniform, experts suggest keeping it simple yet scopeable, ignoring chatter and wearing what makes you feel best, and mixing it with vintage pieces. Ultimately, embracing a signature look can help women feel more confident and free to focus on their work.

site_title: Scoot away
summary: The Inokim electric scooter offers emission-free transportation and is designed to provide effortless mobility. It folds easily for convenient portability, allowing users to board buses or trains without having to walk. The scooter is a personal electric vehicle option that could be a solution for those looking to reduce their carbon footprint. With its portable design, it could make public transportation more accessible and convenient.

site_title: Changing of the guard
summary: Jordan Spieth, 21, wins his first Masters, breaking multiple records and becoming the second-youngest champion. He finished wire-to-wire, 18-under-par, and moved to No. 2 in the world rankings. Spieth's performance marked a new exciting era in the men's professional game, surpassing the potential of contenders like Rory McIlroy, Phil Mickelson, and Bubba Watson. Tiger Woods, a four-time Masters winner, finished 17th, and the rivalry between Woods and McIlroy may now be replaced by Spieth.

site_title: WikiLeaks publishes Sony documents, e-mails
summary: WikiLeaks has published over 200,000 internal Sony Pictures Entertainment documents and e-mails, making them searchable and accessible to journalists and competitors. The release comes after hackers tied to North Korea hacked Sony's computers last year, exposing executive and celebrity pay, and private e-mail exchanges. Sony has condemned the release, saying it will fight for employee safety and security, while the Motion Picture Association of America has also denounced WikiLeaks' actions.

site_title: Inflation firms as March cost of living rises
summary: US inflation firms as the cost of living rose 0.2% in March for a third month, driven by gains in rents, medical care, clothing, and used vehicles. The increase in the core consumer-price index reflects a strengthening labor market, potentially prompting companies to raise prices. Federal Reserve policymakers aim for inflation to reach 2% as they weigh interest rate hikes, with some expecting a rate increase in September.

site_title: Corporates needed in non-profit space
summary: The Centre for Non-Profit Leadership (CNPL) in Singapore emphasizes the importance of top-notch leadership in the non-profit sector, citing it as crucial as fundraising. CEO Yoon Wai Nam believes that strong leadership can make a significant difference in the sector's overall success. The CNPL aims to raise leadership capabilities in the non-profit space, highlighting the need for skilled leaders to drive the sector forward.

site_title: Europe's refiners to pay price for oil glut in US
summary: European refiners face declining margins in Q3 due to the US crude glut. Wood Mackenzie predicts a 42% drop in processing margins, primarily caused by US plants increasing exports of diesel and jet fuel, reducing the continent's domestic crude stockpile. This shift will lead to lower European prices, impacting refiners' profits.

site_title: Bloomberg terminals hit by global breakdown
summary: Bloomberg terminals experienced a global network problem, causing disruptions to users worldwide, including business and finance professionals in major financial centers. The outage began at around 9:50 PM on Friday, with some terminals restored by 9:45 AM GMT. The exact cause of the breakdown remains unknown, and Bloomberg technicians continue to work on resolving the issue. The outage led to a decrease in trading volumes in Europe and forced Britain to postpone an emission of Treasury Bills.

site_title: Heart surgery for those below 50
summary: Young adults under 50 with severe heart artery narrowing are considering heart surgery options, weighing risk of complications against long-term outcomes. CABG (coronary artery bypass graft surgery) carries a 8% risk of serious complications, while PCI (percutaneous coronary intervention) may have better survival rates but higher risk of heart attacks and repeat procedures. A study of 4,000 young adults found 1 in 8 died, 1 in 7 required re-surgery, and 1 in 3 experienced complications 15 years post-surgery. Vein grafts often degenerate over time, leading to complications and potentially requiring a second CABG.

site_title: E-cig use triples among US teens in 1 year
summary: US health authorities reported a significant increase in e-cigarette use among high school students, with 13.4% of students trying an e-cigarette in the past month, tripling from 4.5% in 2013. Hookah use also nearly doubled, from 5.2% to 9.4%. The CDC warns that nicotine exposure at a young age may cause lasting harm to brain development and promote addiction.

site_title: Bank shares trail market performance
summary: Singaporean bank shares have underperformed the market this year, with an average 1.36% increase from January 1 to April 16, compared to the 4.95% increase in the Straits Times Index. Analysts are positive about Q1 earnings results from DBS, OCBC, and UOB, despite the underperformance.

site_title: Chinese premier urges reluctant banks to support real economy
summary: Chinese Premier Li Keqiang urged banks to support the real economy, particularly small and medium-sized enterprises, as the government grows frustrated with commercial banks' reluctance to lend for productive investment. Despite record loan disbursements in March, credit has not yet flowed into key sectors, and banks prioritize high-risk, high-return loans over policy goals. The government aims to boost economic growth, but banks' profit-oriented approach and concerns over risk assessment hinder their willingness to lend to smaller private companies and the cash-starved farm sector.

site_title: Markets backed by liquidity: Schroders
summary: Global equities may achieve a 10-13% return in 2015, according to Schroders' Alex Tedder, driven by 7-10% earnings growth and 3% dividend yields. Liquidity and supportive government policies will support markets, despite high valuations in some markets. Emerging markets, particularly India, South Korea, and Hong Kong-listed China stocks, are seen as opportunities, while the US dollar's strength is a concern. Investors are also considering alternative assets, such as US high-yield bonds and energy-related stocks.

site_title: China's DJI drones flying high among US companies
summary: China's DJI Technology Co Ltd has established a strong lead in the US commercial market for its drones, with 61 out of 129 companies approved to use them, or 47%, according to federal records as of April 9. Nearly 400 other companies have applied to use DJI drones, more than half of the 695 businesses still awaiting approval. This significant lead is attributed to DJI's inexpensive, lightweight flying devices being used for various applications, including film shooting, mapping, and site inspections.

site_title: US companies using more of their credit lines to hire and expand
summary: US companies are tapping more of their credit lines to fund hiring and expansion, a promising sign for the economy. Commercial borrowers are using 2-3% more of their credit lines than a year ago, levels not seen since the 2009 financial crisis. This indicates companies are investing in growth, potentially boosting economic activity.

site_title: JPMorgan Asset Management tells investors how to attain yesterday's sterling yields today
summary: JPMorgan Asset Management managing director Olivia Mayell advises investors to increase risk in less liquid assets or sell growth for income to achieve yesterday's sterling yields. The firm's Global Income Fund now has 55% equity exposure, up from 20% in 2008, and 25% high-yield debt, down from 60%. Mayell suggests complementing high-yield debt with developed market equities to achieve similar income levels.

site_title: Oilfield services provider Schlumberger cuts more jobs
summary: Schlumberger, the world's largest oilfield services provider, cuts an additional 11,000 jobs, bringing the total to 20,000, or 15% of its workforce. The move follows a significant drop in crude prices and is expected to lead to further job cuts in the industry. Energy producers are estimated to cut spending by $114 billion this year, with analysts predicting another wave of job cuts. The company's CEO attributes the move to the abrupt drop in North American drilling, citing a recovery in US land drilling activity as uncertain.

site_title: US consumer sentiment rises in April
summary: US consumer sentiment rose to 95.9 in April, exceeding expectations of 94.0. The survey's subindex on business conditions increased to 108.2 and consumer expectations rose to 88.0, both up from March readings. The improvement in consumer sentiment is a positive sign for the US economy, but analysts note that it may be influenced by factors such as low interest rates and the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic. The data suggests a resilient consumer market, but further economic indicators will be closely watched for signs of a sustained recovery.

site_title: Jones the Grocer chalks up close to S$20m in liabilities
summary: Jones the Grocer's Singapore arm has accumulated nearly S$20 million in liabilities, with creditors likely to recover only a fraction of sale proceeds if a buyer is found. The Australian gourmet grocer's Singapore outlets are up for sale after the company was found insolvent and placed under judicial management. Creditors can expect to receive around 15% of sale proceeds, with some preferential creditors agreeing to share the proceeds with unsecured creditors. A majority of creditors voted in favor of a sale, which is seen as encouraging for potential buyers.

site_title: Apple Watch to boost 'glance journalism'
summary: The Apple Watch is expected to revolutionize the way news is consumed, with "glance journalism" becoming a key focus for news organizations. With millions of watches expected to be sold, news outlets are developing apps and content optimized for the tiny screen. Apps like The New York Times, Yahoo, CNN, and National Public Radio will provide bite-size news updates, microsummaries, and fantasy sports coverage. Experts predict that the Apple Watch will become an essential tool for journalists, enabling faster access to knowledge and allowing for a more personal and always-on news experience.

site_title: China sees policy divide as growth slows
summary: China's economic growth is projected to hit a quarter-century low, prompting policymakers to debate the best course of action. Some economists urge more stimulus to prevent a deeper downturn, while others advocate for structural reforms to promote sustainable growth. The government is concerned about debt defaults, unemployment, and social unrest, but also fears excessive stimulus could fuel asset bubbles. Think tanks and advisers are polarized, with some calling for deeper interest rate cuts, yuan depreciation, and tax reductions, while others recommend reforms to make the economy more efficient.

site_title: Opec should consider return to oil quotas: delegate
summary: OPEC delegate suggests re-introducing individual output quotas to prevent oversupply and stabilize prices if Iran increases oil exports following a nuclear deal. This proposal could spark a debate as national prestige and market share are at stake. OPEC has been pumping more than its target of 30 million barrels per day due to record Saudi Arabian output, higher Iraqi exports, and a partial return of Libyan crude.

site_title: Dicey margins prompt seat squeeze in airlines
summary: Airlines are reducing seat pitch to 28 inches, increasing the number of seats per row, and using slim-line designs to protect profit margins from falling ticket prices. This has raised health and safety concerns, with more air rage incidents and difficulties for crew to assist passengers in need of medical help. Industry experts have proposed solutions, such as extra emergency exits and in-seat amenities, but it remains unclear if passengers will accept the reduced comfort.

site_title: Wall Street banks pin hopes on mutual funds
summary: Wall Street banks, including Goldman Sachs, Morgan Stanley, JPMorgan Chase, and Wells Fargo, are relying on mutual funds to generate fees despite underperforming their benchmarks over the past 10 years. Most funds have struggled to outperform basic benchmarks, with only 12% of Goldman's funds beating their relative benchmarks over the past decade. The banks' focus on fees rather than returns makes it difficult to compete with low-cost fund managers like Vanguard, which has seen 80% of its actively managed funds outperform peers. The banks' efforts to improve performance have been met with skepticism.

site_title: Rallying businesses against trafficking
summary: Singapore businesses are being urged to combat human trafficking by preventing it from happening in the first place. The country's Prevention of Human Trafficking Act has been in effect since last year, and some companies, like Charoen Pokphand Foods, have taken steps to counter labor abuse in their supply chains. Experts believe that by enlisting the cooperation of businesses, they can persuade companies to take a firm stand against trafficking. By reviewing their practices, insisting on minimum labor standards, and making public their efforts, companies can create a climate in which they are taken as the norm and help to combat trafficking.

site_title: Coke to buy China multi-grain drinks maker for US$400m
summary: Coca-Cola Co has agreed to buy China Culiangwang Beverages Holdings Ltd's beverage business for $400.5 million, including debt, to gain a foothold in the fast-growing multi-grain drinks category. This marks Coke's first takeover in China since 2010, and the deal pays a premium to China Culiangwang's market value of $230 million. The sale is subject to Chinese antitrust approvals, and the company will continue to develop its consumer products business.

site_title: Fall in Swiss retail sales adds to deflation fears
summary: Swiss retail sales plummeted in February, sparking concerns over deflation. The Swiss National Bank's decision to abandon the franc's cap on the euro led to a sharp rise in the currency, eroding consumer spending power. Falling prices and the franc's surge have prompted consumers to hold onto their money, fueling deflation fears. This could lead to the SNB taking action, such as weakening the franc or cutting rates, to counter the economic impact.

site_title: Noble dodges accounting queries at AGM
summary: Noble Group's annual general meeting (AGM) was marked by founder and chairman Richard Elman dodging shareholders' queries on the group's accounting practices, despite recent allegations from Iceberg Research and Muddy Waters. Despite Noble refuting the allegations, the company's shares have plummeted 27% since February 15. Elman repeatedly steered the meeting's focus to financial statements and directors' reports, and refused to elaborate on Noble's valuation of its Yancoal stake. The meeting's resolutions were passed, but shareholders expressed concerns over transparency and the company's valuation methods.

site_title: US to propose higher royalty rates for drilling federal land
summary: The US government plans to propose higher royalty rates for oil and gas drilling on federal land, aiming to increase the federal government's share from 12.5% to 18.75%. This move aims to ensure taxpayers profit from the national energy renaissance while implementing new controls to protect federal land. The proposal will be open for comment through May and may include requirements for energy companies to hold more cash or insurance for depleted drill sites and increase drilling fees.

site_title: Alibaba inks deal with Shanghai GM to finance car purchases
summary: Alibaba Group Holding Ltd has partnered with Shanghai General Motors (GM) to offer online sales and financing for GM cars. The partnership, announced on April 17, 2015, will utilize Alibaba's big data analysis to serve ads to prospective car buyers and offer loans. The deal marks Alibaba's expansion into the automotive business, with over 50 car brands and 10,000 dealerships already partnering with the company in China.

site_title: Gasoline, shelter costs lift US consumer prices
summary: US consumer prices rose 0.2% in March for a second straight month, driven by increases in gasoline and shelter costs. This marks a reversal of the recent disinflationary trend, suggesting the Federal Reserve may start raising interest rates this year. Over the past 12 months, the Consumer Price Index slipped 0.1%. The broad-based price increases indicate the recent slowdown in inflation has run its course.

site_title: Haute or hot?
summary: Singapore's hawker food scene is evolving, with independent chefs drawing inspiration from traditional dishes to create new, innovative cuisine. Despite concerns that the scene may die out due to the lack of younger generations interested in preserving heritage foods, many chefs are finding success by adapting hawker classics to more upscale settings. Chefs like Willin Low, Damian D'Silva, and Han Li Guang are incorporating modern twists and high-quality ingredients into their dishes, while Jeremy Nguee and Zacharie Ong are experimenting with new flavors and presentation styles. The industry's emphasis on quality and innovation has led to a surge in demand for premium hawker-inspired cuisine, with some chefs charging higher prices for their dishes.

site_title: Sigma-Aldrich opens Asia-Pacific HQ and technical centre in Singapore
summary: Sigma-Aldrich, an American life science company, has opened its Asia-Pacific headquarters and cell culture technical centre in Singapore. The facility, located at Biopolis Research Park, aims to support customers in the region with local technical solutions. The centre will provide pre-clinical media manufacturing services and optimisation services for biopharmaceutical development and manufacturing. The opening marks a significant expansion of the company's presence in the region, with plans to open its first fully-owned distribution centre in South-east Asia later this year.

site_title: Italy to post modest GDP growth in Q1, says central bank
summary: Italy's central bank reported modest economic growth in the first quarter of 2015, with industrial production rising slightly and gross domestic product increasing slightly. The Bank of Italy expects this growth to continue, citing the European Central Bank's quantitative easing program, which is expected to raise Italian inflation by over 0.5 percentage points in 2015 and 2016. This marks a positive trend for Italy, which had experienced three years of recession prior to this growth.

site_title: US leading indicator points to slower growth
summary: A US leading economic indicator rose 0.2% in March, suggesting slower growth in the first quarter. The Conference Board's Leading Economic Index increased after a downwardly revised 0.1% rise in February. This aligns with views of slowing economic activity, indicating a possible slowdown in the US economy.

site_title: Malaysia's DRB-HICOM enters joint venture to sell Lotus cars in China
summary: Malaysia's DRB-HICOM has entered a joint venture with China's Goldstar Heavy Industrial to sell Lotus cars in China. The joint venture, Goldstar LOTUS Automobile, will produce and sell Lotus cars, engines, and parts in China, providing after-sales services. Proton Holdings and Lotus Group International Limited formed the joint venture, marking DRB-HICOM's expansion into the Chinese market. The partnership aims to increase Lotus' presence in China and provide a new revenue stream for the Malaysian company.

site_title: Microsoft unveils touch-friendly Office apps for Windows phones
summary: Microsoft has unveiled touch-friendly Office apps for Windows phones, allowing users to work on Word, PowerPoint, and Excel documents using touch commands and easily transferring files between devices. The apps, called Office Universal, are available for download now with full versions to be released by the end of the month. The apps are designed to adapt to different devices, including Windows Phone, tablets, and Apple's iPad and iPhone, and offer basic functions for free, with advanced editing features requiring a subscription to Office 365.

site_title: G20 warns of financial volatility risk as central banks diverge
summary: The G20 warned of financial volatility risk as central banks diverge in monetary policies. The group urged policymakers to carefully calibrate and communicate their actions to minimize negative spillovers. They expressed concerns over potential disruptions due to rising financial market volatility, uneven global growth, and geopolitical tensions. The nations pledged to pursue fiscal policies flexibly to support growth and reaffirmed their commitment to resisting trade protectionism, maintaining easy monetary policies, and resisting exchange rate volatility.

site_title: StarHub CFO Nicholas Tan leaving telco for 'personal reasons'
summary: StarHub announced the resignation of CFO Nicholas Tan, effective April 30, citing personal reasons. Tan joined the telco in 2013. CEO Tan Tong Hai will oversee financial matters until a new CFO is appointed.

site_title: China premier says to deepen interest rate reform: state radio
summary: China Premier Li Keqiang announced plans to deepen interest rate reforms, aiming to stimulate economic growth. He also stated the country will expand the use of its foreign exchange reserves to facilitate overseas investments. This move is seen as a response to China's slowing GDP growth, which is putting pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Volkswagen extends CEO's contract, ending leadership battle
summary: Volkswagen extends CEO Martin Winterkorn's contract, ending a leadership battle sparked by supervisory board chief Ferdinand Piech's comments that he was "distancing himself" from Winterkorn. Piech, a member of the Porsche dynasty and a key shareholder, had ignited speculation of a fierce battle for control. However, other shareholders have rallied behind Winterkorn, leaving Piech looking isolated. The decision aims to maintain stability and smooth running of the company.

site_title: Singapore Wrap Friday
summary: Singapore's Non-Oil Domestic Exports (NODX) jumped 18.5% in March, driven by growth in electronic and non-electronic exports. StarHub CFO Nicholas Tan is leaving the telco for personal reasons. Blumont Group's auditor raised concerns about the company's ability to continue as a going concern. Bank of China is expanding its presence in Singapore with new outlets and ATMs. The Singapore market is divided into two tiers, with blue chips and penny stocks.

images.alt_text: The call to grant directors the authority to allot and issue shares got a cool response from Noble Group's shareholders, even as all resolutions at its annual shareholders' meeting were passed on Friday, a regulatory filing showed.

site_title: Bigger risk of Finnish job cuts in Nokia-Alcatel deal: minister
summary: Finnish Finance Minister Antti Rinne warned that Nokia's takeover of Alcatel-Lucent could lead to more job cuts in Finland than in France, citing the country's lower labor costs. He stated that it's cheaper to let people go in Finland, with a lower cost of around zero if an employee works until the end of their notice period. This contrasts with France, where a middle-management employee with 15 years experience would cost around 50,000 euros to fire. The deal, valued at 15.6 billion euros, aims to preserve jobs in the long-term.

site_title: UK's Labour courts youth with pledge to end unpaid internships
summary: UK's Labour leader Ed Miliband has pledged to end unpaid internships lasting longer than four weeks, aiming to woo young voters ahead of the May 7 national election. The move comes as polls show Labour neck and neck with Prime Minister David Cameron's Conservatives. Miliband's promise is in response to the death of a 21-year-old intern in 2013, who worked at Bank of America Merrill Lynch. Labour says 31% of university graduates working as interns are unpaid, but critics argue this could harm work experience opportunities.

site_title: Airbus upbeat on jet market, still studying A380 upgrade
summary: Airbus predicts continued strength in the aircraft market, with deliveries of the A350 model expected to pick up, potentially recapturing the global crown from Boeing. The company may increase production of its most popular jets if the trend continues. Airbus will not abandon the A380 but will study the business case for the 'A380neo' upgrade requested by Emirates. The company expects more orders than deliveries in 2015 and has hedged against the weak euro, providing benefits to smaller parts suppliers.

images.alt_text: Airbus sees continued strength in the aircraft market and may increase production of its most popular jets above planned rates if the trend continues, the head of the European planemaker said on Friday.

site_title: Classic comeback
summary: Chef Sebastien Lepinoy has successfully revamped Les Amis, a Singaporean French restaurant, by cutting menu prices by 40% and introducing a new, more affordable pricing structure. The restaurant is now mostly fully booked, with a profit margin, and has regained its ranking at 13th place in the Asia Best50 Restaurants list. Lepinoy's focus is on classic, traditional French cuisine, which he believes is ripe for a comeback, and offers an extensive a la carte menu at great value. The restaurant's new pricing strategy aims to make fine dining more accessible and affordable for a broader audience.

images.alt_text: Sebastien Lepinoy.
VERY FRENCH: Lepinoy's clean traditional French cuisine includes highlights such as tete a veau, a headcheese made of ox tongue and calf's head.
FAVOURITES: Lepinoy's cold angel hair pasta with caviar and black truffle at Les Amis

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index ended lower on Friday, closing at 1,845.86 after a 2.08-point drop. The index saw 2.58 billion lots valued at RM2.28 billion traded, with 493 gains and 334 losses.

site_title: Oil market slides before weekend
summary: World oil prices dropped on Friday as investors locked in profits following a six-day rally, with Brent North Sea crude falling 38 cents to $63.60 per barrel and US benchmark West Texas Intermediate falling 42 cents to $56.68 per barrel. Analysts attributed the decline to a rise in OPEC's output in March, which added to downward pressure, despite a potential easing of US shale output. OPEC's production rose by 810,000 barrels per day in March, highlighting the global crude oversupply problem, which has led to a 50% collapse in prices between June and January.

site_title: Latest earnings
summary: US President Trump's 50% copper import tariff affects refined metal, causing oil prices to rise over 2%. Stock markets in Europe and the US are down, with a focus on US-EU tariffs. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer is 9.8 times oversubscribed. Creative Technology warns of potential revenue shortfall in H2, similar to H1 operating loss. London's Heathrow Airport plans to increase fees for a £10 billion upgrade.

site_title: Tat Hong issues Q4 profit warning
summary: Tat Hong, a crane operator, has issued a Q4 profit warning, stating it expects a loss due to weak performance in its Australian subsidiary. Despite this, the group remains profitable for FY2015, citing stable underlying performance. The company attributes the weak performance to a sluggish Australian economy and the non-realization of expected activity level recovery in the Australian construction sector. Tat Hong will disclose further details in its audited financial statements on May 29, 2015.

site_title: Blumont's independent auditor raises going concern issue
summary: Blumont Group's independent auditor, Moore Stephens, has raised concerns over the company's ability to continue as a going concern due to a net loss of S$66.2 million and a total comprehensive loss of S$68.8 million in the 2014 financial year. The company's current liabilities exceeded its current assets by S$16.5 million and S$32.9 million, respectively. However, the group has since embarked on various fund-raising activities to address these concerns.

site_title: 1,400 mourners join memorial for Germanwings crash victims
summary: A memorial service was held in Cologne, Germany, on April 17, 2015, for the 150 victims of the Germanwings plane crash in the French Alps on March 24, 2015. The service, attended by German Chancellor Angela Merkel and officials from France and Spain, featured a somber ecumenical service at the historic Cologne Cathedral. The crash, blamed on a depressed co-pilot, led to increased calls for more extensive medical checks for pilots and changes to airline safety protocols.

site_title: Bank of China expands Singapore footprint with new outlets, more ATMs (Amended)
summary: Bank of China (BOC) has expanded its presence in Singapore with the opening of two new branches in Jurong East and Woodlands, bringing the total number of branches to eight. The bank now has 10 standalone ATMs across various locations. BOC has also signed an agreement with the Singapore Exchange to roll out yuan-denominated products, including commodities and derivatives contracts, marking the bank's first Chinese settlement bank for its derivatives market. The bank's Singapore division has seen a 30% increase in total assets to S$38.3 billion by the end of 2014.

site_title: Bloomberg says terminals hit by global breakdown
summary: Bloomberg's technical department reported a "global network problem" affecting its terminals, causing screens to go black on Friday morning. The cause of the breakdown was not specified. The company's network teams are working to resolve the issue.

site_title: China allows fund managers to lend stocks for short-selling
summary: China has allowed fund managers to lend stocks for short-selling, increasing the supply of shares and encouraging mutual fund companies and securities firms to participate. This move aims to boost the slow-growing short-selling business, which has seen rapid growth in margin financing. The decision was made by the Securities Association of China in collaboration with the Shanghai and Shenzhen stock exchanges.

site_title: GE reports US$13.6b loss due to finance sale charges
summary: General Electric reported a US$13.6 billion loss in the first quarter due to finance sale charges from its plan to sell most of GE Capital. Despite lower profits from power and water, industrial profits rose 8.6% to US$3.6 billion. The company's shares dipped 0.1% in pre-market trade. CEO Jeff Immelt attributed the results to a volatile environment with growth opportunities in infrastructure, and stated that the GE Capital sale is a key step in the company's strategy to focus on its competitive advantages.

site_title: Nokia CEO says French jobs pledge is business as usual
summary: Nokia CEO Rajeev Suri defended the company's commitment to protect jobs in France after its planned takeover of Alcatel-Lucent. Nokia pledged not to cut French jobs for two years beyond Alcatel's plans. Suri stated the move is "business as usual" and makes sense given the strategic rationale. However, he acknowledged that job cuts would eventually occur, with a focus on countries other than Finland and France, where the companies have a larger presence.

site_title: Japan, US seek to seal free trade deal before summit
summary: Japan and the US are racing to finalize a bilateral trade deal ahead of a summit between Prime Minister Shinzo Abe and President Barack Obama later this month. The deal, seen as crucial for a broader Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) trade pact, aims to address gaps over the agricultural and auto sectors. Japan's Economics Minister Akira Amari said that progress in working-level talks could lead to formal ministerial talks, with a timeframe yet to be set. The deal is crucial for the US to move forward with the TPP negotiations, which also involve other major economies.

site_title: UK employment jumps, jobless rate lowest since July 2008
summary: The UK employment rate jumped to a record 73.4% in February, with 248,000 new jobs added, bringing the total to 31.049 million people in employment. The unemployment rate fell to 5.6%, its lowest level since July 2008. Total average weekly earnings rose 1.7% and excluding bonuses, pay increased 1.8%. Economists attribute the increase to new EU rules on bankers' pay. The government sees this as a success of its economic plan, while the opposition Labour Party argues that wages remain below pre-2010 levels.

site_title: Cathedral service to mourn victims from Germanwings crash
summary: Germany holds a memorial service at Cologne's historic cathedral to mourn the 150 victims of the Germanwings crash, which occurred on March 24, 2015, when a co-pilot deliberately steered the plane into a mountain. The service, attended by 1,500 guests, including German Chancellor Angela Merkel and relatives of the victims, aims to honor the deceased and address the mental health issues that contributed to the tragedy. The event follows calls for increased medical checks for pilots and changes in airline safety protocols.

site_title: Rolls-Royce wins US$9.2b engine order from Emirates for A380s
summary: Rolls-Royce has won a $9.2 billion order to supply engines for 50 A380 aircraft for Emirates airline, marking the first time the Gulf carrier has ordered Rolls-Royce engines. The deal comes after a difficult year for the company, and follows an earlier Reuters report. The order is for the A380 fleet, which is currently powered by Engine Alliance engines. The deal is seen as a boost for Rolls-Royce, and will likely have a positive impact on the company's financial performance.

site_title: The car tsunami
summary: The Singapore government will auction off 41% more COEs (certificates of entitlement) for new cars from May to July due to high vehicle supply. This is the largest increase in COE supply in a few years. The surge in COE supply is attributed to deregistration of old cars, which allows the government to add more COEs to the market. This trend is expected to continue, potentially leading to a "car tsunami" as older cars stay on the road for longer, and their COEs expire. The impact on COE premiums and the demand for new cars remains uncertain.

site_title: China says AIIB won't be used for US$46b Pakistan deal
summary: China does not plan to use the Asian Infrastructure Development Bank (AIIB) or Silk Road fund to finance the US$46 billion Pakistan-China Economic Corridor, instead opting for joint financing from both countries. The project, which aims to connect Pakistan's Gwadar port with China's Xinjiang region, will focus on economic development for Pakistan. Chinese Assistant Foreign Minister Liu Jianchao stated that the financing will be provided through various means, without specifying which institutions will be used.

site_title: China's Li urges banks to support real economy: sources
summary: Chinese Premier Li Keqiang urged state-owned banks to support the real economy during visits to the Industrial and Commercial Bank of China and China Development Bank. This move aims to boost economic growth, which is expected to slow. Li's comments come amid growing concerns about the country's economic stability. The visits were confirmed by ICBC, while CDB declined to comment.

site_title: Europe: Stocks stable at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets opened steady on Friday, with London's FTSE 100 index up 0.03% at 7,062.70 points. The CAC 40 in Paris dipped 0.19% and Frankfurt's DAX 30 shed 0.47% compared to Thursday's close. The stability follows a record peak for London on Wednesday and comes amid fresh worries over Greece.

site_title: China building runway in disputed South China Sea: reports
summary: China is building a 3,110-meter runway on reclaimed land in the disputed South China Sea, potentially raising tensions with Southeast Asian neighbors. The airstrip, part of China's Fiery Cross project, is under construction on a reef that was transformed into an island in 2014. The project has sparked concerns about China's territorial claims and military capabilities in the region. The US and several Southeast Asian countries have expressed concerns, with the US warning that the project could accommodate an airstrip. China claims nearly all of the South China Sea, leading to disputes with its neighbors.

site_title: Nestle posts higher-than-expected first quarter growth
summary: Nestle reported better-than-expected growth in the first quarter, with organic sales rising 4.4% despite a 4.5% decline in reported sales due to strong currency exchange rates. The company reaffirmed its full-year growth outlook of around 5% and aims to improve margins and underlying earnings per share. Nestle's chief Paul Bulcke attributed the growth to internal growth and pricing, and pledged to restore momentum in sluggish markets in Asia, Africa, and North America.

images.alt_text: The world's top packaged food maker Nestle on Friday posted better-than-expected growth in the first quarter despite currency exchange rates that hampered sales.

site_title: Indonesia mulls new higher-grade petrol to ease foreign dependence
summary: Indonesia's Pertamina is considering replacing its lower-grade gasoline with a cleaner RON90 "Pertalite" grade, aiming to ease the country's dependence on foreign supplies. The higher grade could help Pertamina pocket more revenue as it was previously sold at a loss. Energy Minister Sudirman Said stated that making Indonesia's energy cleaner is the best course of action, but no decision has been made on the replacement.

site_title: A very exclusive coffee kick on St Helena island
summary: St. Helena Island, a remote British territory in the South Atlantic, is home to some of the world's most expensive and exclusive coffee beans. The island's unique climate and genetic heritage have preserved the 300-year-old coffee plantations, but scarcity has become a problem due to neglect. The island's only coffee producer, Solomons, produces only 1-1.5 tonnes of organic beans per year, which are exported to England before roasting. The rare beans have fans in Europe and Asia, with prices ranging from $20.10 to $21, and the island's small-scale producers are hoping to scale up production with the introduction of weekly flights to the island.

site_title: Thai govt hopes to see a weaker baht: Deputy PM
summary: Thailand's Deputy Prime Minister Pridiyathorn Devakula stated that the government hopes to see a weaker baht, despite not intervening in the foreign exchange rate mechanism. The Bank of Thailand will monitor the baht's direction. The Thai economy is expected to expand by 4.0% in the second quarter, driven by possible recovery in exports.

site_title: Singapore: A two-tier market led by pennies
summary: Singapore's stock market is experiencing a two-tier effect, with penny stocks leading in volume and percentage gains, surpassing blue chips. This shift is attributed to proprietary traders capitalizing on a "feel-good" surge in sentiment after massive gains in Hong Kong. The market's momentum is also driven by the removal of a cap on clearing fees, allowing traders to operate freely. This trend contrasts with the previous year, when blue chips dominated daily volume.

site_title: Seoul: Won hits 2-week high; shares post best weekly gain in 11 months
summary: The South Korean won reached a two-week high against the dollar, closing at 1,083.7 per dollar, its highest level since April 6, due to foreign buying of domestic equities. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) gained 2.6% to post its sharpest weekly gain since May 16, as the dollar was broadly weakened after tepid US economic data.

site_title: Japan consumer confidence improves 4th straight month in March
summary: Japan's consumer confidence improved for a fourth consecutive month in March, according to a Cabinet Office survey, with the sentiment index reaching 41.7. This marks a slight increase from the revised 40.9 in February. The upgrade in consumer confidence suggests that the economy is picking up, according to the Cabinet Office.

site_title: China: Stocks post 7th week of gains as interest shifts to blue chips
summary: China's stocks reached a seven-year high, posting their seventh consecutive week of gains, as investor interest shifted to blue chip shares. The CSI300 index rose 1.8% and the Shanghai Composite Index gained 2.2% to fresh highs. New A-share accounts opened at a record 1.68 million last week, with over 6 million opened in the past month, significantly higher than Los Angeles' population. Analysts attribute the shift to money flowing into blue chips, driven by index futures.

site_title: Alibaba helps Sinopec with cloud computing, big data
summary: Alibaba Group Holding Ltd has partnered with Sinopec, Asia's largest oil refiner, to provide cloud computing services and big data analysis. The collaboration does not involve equity cooperation and aims to upgrade Sinopec's traditional petrochemical services. Alibaba's Aliyun cloud computing business will help Sinopec build cloud-based business systems and perform data analytics covering the entire petrochemical production chain. This partnership dovetails with government policy to encourage state-owned companies to utilize information technology and cloud computing for better resource management and environmental tracking.

site_title: Dollar heads for worst week in a month on weak US data run
