summary: The US dollar fell for a fourth consecutive day, nearing its one-week low, amid weak economic data, including lower-than-expected housing starts and modest factory activity. The dollar index is on track to fall 2% this week, its largest loss in a month. The euro, benefiting from the dollar's weakness, rose 2% for its best week in a month. Traders will watch US consumer inflation data and a meeting of Group of 20 finance ministers for further market insights.

site_title: Australia: Shares slip on weak mining, banks; NZ also soft
summary: Australian shares fell 1.2% on Friday, led by a decline in mining stocks due to weak iron ore prices. The S&P/ASX 200 index lost 69.6 points to end at 5,877.9, set for its second-largest weekly loss this year. New Zealand's benchmark NZX 50 index also eased 0.3% lower. The decline follows the index's inability to break a key psychological level of 6,000 points.

site_title: Thai PM hails progress, says he doesn't want to stay in power
summary: Thai Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-ocha hailed the progress of his military government, stating he doesn't want to stay in power. He defended his government's actions, including the overhaul of the constitution, and said foreign governments understand Thailand's situation, wanting quick elections. Prayuth emphasized his commitment to restoring democratic rule and maintaining peace, despite criticism from rights groups and the UN. The economy is in recovery, thanks to stimulus measures and investment procedures, according to the prime minister.

site_title: Indonesia central bank sees current account deficit at 1.6% of GDP in Q1
summary: Indonesia's central bank forecasts a current account deficit of 1.6% of GDP in Q1, narrowing from 2.81% in Q4 2014. The improvement is attributed to a larger-than-expected trade surplus of $2.43 billion, the largest in three years. Economic growth is expected at 5% in Q1, in line with the government's assumption.

site_title: SGX and Bank of China extend collaboration in RMB market
summary: SGX and Bank of China are extending their collaboration in the renminbi market, aiming to grow the yuan-denominated products and enhance clearing and settlement services. This is an extension of their 2013 memorandum of understanding, focusing on joint marketing and access to growth opportunities in China and Singapore markets. The partnership seeks to increase the use of the renminbi in international trade and finance.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai defy Asia slump on stimulus hopes
summary: Asian markets rallied on Friday, with Hong Kong and Shanghai extending gains on hopes for new stimulus measures from China. Shanghai rose 1.79% and Hong Kong added 0.62%, while Tokyo fell 0.80%. The US dollar lost ground after disappointing jobs and housing figures, while the euro held up despite worries over Greece. The yen advanced against the dollar, and oil prices fell after six consecutive days of gains. The rally is driven by expectations of Chinese easing measures and a link-up between Hong Kong and Shanghai exchanges.

site_title: Noble Group chairman says year has started off well for firm
summary: Noble Group chairman Richard Elman stated that the year has started off well for the commodities trader, despite criticism over its accounting policies. The company reported its first quarterly loss in three years due to asset write-downs in February. Elman, who owns about a fifth of the company's shares, expressed confidence in Noble's performance, rejecting the criticism about its accounting practices.

site_title: Asiana suspends Hiroshima flights for safety check
summary: Asiana Airlines suspended flights to Hiroshima, Japan, pending a safety review after a passenger jet hit a communications antenna while landing. The incident injured 27 people, but no one was killed. The airline will refund booked passengers and adjust routes until the end of April. An investigation is underway, with suggestions that a sudden down draft may have contributed to the crash. This incident echoes a 2013 Asiana flight that crashed in San Francisco, killing three people.

site_title: Philippine Airlines parent says back in black
summary: Philippine Airlines' parent firm, PAL Holdings, reported a net profit of 129.74 million pesos (US$2.93 million) in its fiscal year to December 31, marking the first time in three years the entity was profitable. The turnaround was attributed to increased gross revenue, nearly doubling to 101.50 billion pesos, following the lifting of aviation safety restrictions by the US. This allowed PAL to deploy new Boeing 777 jets for long-haul flights and resumed flights to New York. PAL Holdings had previously reported net losses in 2013 and 2014.

site_title: Australian energy firm AGL to shut all coal power stations by 2050
summary: AGL Energy Ltd, Australia's No.2 power retailer, announced it will not buy any more coal-fired power stations and will close all existing coal-fired power plants by 2050. The company cited a slowdown in Australia's coal exports to China, a key trading partner, as the reason for the move. AGL's CEO, Andy Vesey, stated that the transition to new generation technologies and careers will be an ongoing process. This decision comes as the global energy landscape shifts towards cleaner energy options, with Australia's coal industry facing significant challenges.

site_title: Broker's take: Singapore banks' Q1 to reflect high single-digit loan growth
summary: Singapore banks are expected to post "reasonable quarters" in the first three months of the year, driven by high single-digit loan growth, according to Nomura. The broker predicts core net interest income will show high single-digit loan growth and stable net interest margins. Trading- and capital market-related income may pose some surprise due to asset class volatility. DBS and OCBC are expected to outperform the market, while provisioning for OCBC's Wing Hang Bank acquisition may be higher than expected. Short-term interest rate impacts on earnings are unlikely in the first quarter.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Keppel Corp, Qian Hu, SATS, United Fiber
summary: Keppel Corp shifted focus to areas beyond drilling for its offshore business, reporting a 6.4% increase in first-quarter net profit to S$360.2 million. Qian Hu Corporation posted a 2.6% decrease in net profit to S$112,000 for the first quarter. SATS entered a joint venture agreement with BRF GmbH to process meat and manufacture branded food products. United Fiber System awaits an outcome in a takeover battle for Asia Resource Minerals, which could transform it into a major coal miner.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks fall 1.17% by close on strong yen
summary: Tokyo stocks fell 1.17% on Friday, led by a stronger yen, amid discouraging US data. The Nikkei 225 index dropped 232.89 points to 19,652.88, while the Topix index fell 0.67% to 1,588.69. Investors are now gearing up for the Japanese earnings season. The decline was attributed to a weaker yen, which took air out of the market, and US data that raised concerns about economic growth.

site_title: China suspends bank-technology rules that sparked worry
summary: China has suspended bank-technology rules that sparked international concern over unfair regulatory pressure on foreign firms. The rules, issued in December, aimed to improve banking technology security but were seen as too onerous for foreign companies. The suspension comes as US Secretary of Commerce Penny Pritzker visits China on a trade mission. The move is seen as a concession to foreign business groups, which had expressed concerns over the rules favoring domestic products and requiring sensitive intellectual property disclosure. China is also working on an anti-terrorism law that could limit foreign technology companies' opportunities.

site_title: Londoners flee steep house prices, head for provinces
summary: Thousands of Londoners are fleeing the city due to steep house prices, an overloaded transport system, and lack of space. Between 2012 and 2013, 60,000 people aged 30-39 left London, with many choosing cities like Birmingham, Bristol, and Manchester as alternatives. Birmingham's affordable housing, lower costs, and cultural attractions are drawing in new residents, including entrepreneurs and young professionals. The city's regeneration efforts, including new developments and infrastructure improvements, are contributing to its appeal.

site_title: World Bank should join China-led bank in syndicated loans: Japan
summary: US and Japan want the World Bank and Asian Development Bank to join a new Chinese-led development bank in syndicated loans, aiming to help the new lender establish strong standards. The move follows Washington and Tokyo's initial hesitation due to concerns over lending standards. Japanese Finance Minister Taro Aso agreed with US Treasury Secretary Jack Lew that syndicated loans involving the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB) would help it meet global standards on governance, debt, and environment. This collaboration aims to enhance the AIIB's standards and credibility.

site_title: Shareholders overwhelmingly vote in favour of adopting Noble's accounts
summary: Shareholders of Noble Group Ltd overwhelmingly voted in favor of adopting the company's financial statements for last year, with 99.92% of votes supporting the resolution. Noble's chairman, Richard Elman, rejected allegations of improper accounting made by Iceberg Research, calling them "inaccurate, unreliable, and misleading." This is Noble's first public response to the allegations.

site_title: STI down 0.09 point at opening, paring gains following weaker Wall Street
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.09 point to 3,531.52 at opening on Friday, paring gains from the week. The decline followed weaker Wall Street overnight. The top losers included the Singapore Exchange, which denied talks of a China stock connect. Trading volume was 159 million shares worth S$120 million, with gainers outnumbering losers 94 to 68.

site_title: Update: Shares of Noble gain ahead of AGM on Friday
summary: Noble Group shares rose 1.1% ahead of its annual shareholders' meeting on Friday, following criticism from research firm Iceberg Research and short seller Muddy Waters. Iceberg questioned Noble's valuation and wrote off $200 million from its Australian-listed mining firm Yancoal, which Noble holds a 13% stake in. Noble denied any link between the write-off and Iceberg's allegations. The company maintained that it has "clear controls in place" to ensure the accuracy of its valuations.

site_title: Nissan says to expand US regional recall for Takata air bags
summary: Nissan is expanding its US regional recall for Takata air bags in certain regions, adding about 45,000 Sentras from the 2004-2006 model years. The recall follows a March 21 accident in Louisiana that injured a woman from shrapnel. Since 2008, nearly 25 million vehicles have been recalled due to potentially deadly Takata-made air bag inflators. Nissan will replace passenger-side air bags of the affected Sentras.

site_title: Indonesia flight makes emergency landing after bomb threat
summary: An Indonesian Batik Air flight with 122 people on board made an emergency landing in Makassar, South Sulawesi, after a suspected bomb threat. No bomb was found on the plane. Authorities isolated the plane and airport operations were not affected. The incident is currently under investigation by the police.

site_title: China gains drive emerging stock rally; oil set for weekly surge
summary: Chinese stocks drove an advance in emerging-market equities, with indexes in Hong Kong and Shanghai reaching seven-year highs. The MSCI Emerging Markets Index rose 0.3% and the Hang Seng China Enterprises Index jumped 0.8%. US index futures lost 0.1% and oil was set for its best week since 2011, rallying over 8% this week. Demand from mainland Chinese investors fueled Hong Kong-traded shares, while a weak US dollar and oil prices also contributed to the surge.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks drop; TSMC down after bleak forecast
summary: Taiwan's stocks declined 0.77% on Friday, mainly due to a poor forecast by TSMC, the world's largest contract chip maker, which predicted a drop in revenue. The TSMC stock fell 2.72% and dragged down peers, while the electronics subindex declined 1.12%. The TAIEX index fell 74.65 points to 9582.22. This decline was attributed to TSMC's bleak forecast, which painted a relatively poor outlook for the semiconductor industry.

site_title: Baggage worker who got trapped in cargo hold banned by Alaska Airlines
summary: A contract baggage handler at Alaska Airlines was banned from future work after becoming trapped in the cargo hold of a jet on takeoff from Seattle. The incident occurred after the worker fell asleep in the cargo hold. The airline has stated that the worker's actions put the safety of others at risk. The baggage handler's identity was not disclosed, and the airline has taken steps to prevent similar incidents in the future.

site_title: All resolutions at Noble's AGM passed
summary: Noble Group's annual shareholders' meeting concluded with all resolutions passed, despite controversy surrounding the company. The resolution to grant directors share allotting authority received 60% of votes in favor, while most other resolutions were approved with nearly 100% support. The company has faced criticism from research firms, including Iceberg Research, which claims Noble's assets are inflated. Chairman Richard Elman rejected allegations as "inaccurate, unreliable and misleading." Shares rose 1.7% following the meeting.

images.alt_text: The call to grant directors the authority to allot and issue shares got a cool response from Noble Group's shareholders, even as all resolutions at its annual shareholders' meeting were passed on Friday, a regulatory filing showed.

site_title: With SUVs, Chinese carmakers at last unsettle foreign brands
summary: Chinese automakers are gaining ground in the global market, particularly in the SUV segment. In the first three months of 2015, eight Chinese SUVs ranked among the top-10, up from just one two years prior. Shifting focus to SUVs has helped local brands like BYD compete with foreign rivals, with the domestic SUV market experiencing rapid growth. This trend is attributed to the expanding market scope and momentum gained by indigenous brands.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks rise 0.25% at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.25% at open on April 17, 2015, extending recent gains amid hopes for China's fresh monetary easing measures to support its economy. The Hang Seng Index gained 68.53 points to 27,808.24, while the Shanghai Composite Index jumped 1.53% in mainland China.

site_title: China's first fund using Hong Kong link says H shares are cheap
summary: China's first mutual fund using Hong Kong's exchange link has stated that Hong Kong shares are cheap, despite recent surges to seven-year highs. The fund, managed by Linda Xie, favors low-valuation, big-capitalization H shares in internet, electronics, and consumer industries, expecting above-average returns. Valuations are 25% lower than mainland counterparts, and the fund will invest 45% of its assets in both yuan-denominated A shares and H shares. This move is seen as a boost to Hong Kong's stock market, with net inflows totaling 38 billion yuan since March 30.

site_title: Noble Group chairman Elman rejects improper accounting allegations
summary: Noble Group chairman Richard Elman has rejected allegations by Iceberg Research that the company inflated asset values by billions of dollars through aggressive accounting. Elman stated that nothing Noble has done violates rules and considers the matter "finished." Noble shares rose 1.7% after Elman's comments, erasing the previous day's fall, as the company remains focused on its business and is in a robust financial condition. Elman also linked Iceberg Research to an employee Noble fired in 2013 and has started legal action against him in Hong Kong.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's stock market opened higher on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 1.95 points to 1,849.89. The index saw 126 gainers for every 59 losers, with a total volume of 70.213 million lots worth RM28.33 million.

site_title: Emerging countries blast US for not backing IMF reform
summary: Emerging economies, part of the G-24 group, criticized the US for blocking reforms to the International Monetary Fund (IMF) for five years. The reforms, agreed in 2010, aim to increase IMF funding and voting power for emerging economies, particularly China and India. The US Congress has refused to ratify the deal, citing concerns about increased costs and the potential erosion of US dominance. IMF Managing Director Christine Lagarde urged the US to complete ratification, calling the delay a hindrance to the IMF's credibility and effectiveness.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open 0.38% lower
summary: Tokyo stocks opened 0.38% lower on Friday due to the yen strengthening against the dollar following disappointing US economic data. The Nikkei 225 index fell 75.37 points to 19,810.40. This move is seen as further evidence that the Federal Reserve may hold off raising interest rates.

site_title: Singapore NODX jumps 18.5% in March
summary: Singapore's NON-OIL domestic exports (NODX) jumped 18.5% year-over-year in March, driven by growth in electronic and non-electronic NODX. This follows a 9.7% fall in February. Month-over-month, NODX surged 23% seasonally adjusted. The top contributors to NODX's expansion were the EU, US, and Malaysia, except for Indonesia and Japan. This marks a reversal of the previous month's decline.

site_title: Etsy shares soar in stellar stock market debut
summary: Etsy's shares more than doubled in their initial public offering (IPO), reaching a value of over $3.5 billion, after pricing at $16. The online marketplace, known for its socially-conscious focus on handmade and vintage goods, raised $267 million. Despite concerns about its ability to make quick profits, Etsy plans to maintain its status as a certified B Corporation. The IPO marks the third B corporation to become publicly traded, highlighting a potential contradiction between social values and shareholder interests.

site_title: Oil sees sixth day of price gains
summary: Oil prices rose for the sixth consecutive day, with West Texas Intermediate advancing 32 cents to $56.71 a barrel and Brent North Sea crude rising 66 cents to $63.95 a barrel. The US Department of Energy reported a slight decline in crude production and a small rise in US crude inventories, fueling hopes that the global supply glut may be easing. Analysts predict US crude production will fall in the second half of the year, reducing global oversupply, and prices may rebound to the $65-70 range.

site_title: Brokers' take: Analysts fret over Keppel Corp's orderbook
summary: Keppel Corp's orderbook faces risk due to a weakening demand, with analysts expecting global jackup rig orders to halve year-on-year in 2015. The company's offshore business will shift focus beyond drilling as rig orders dry up, with net profit rising 6.4% to S$360.2 million. New order wins totalled S$500 million, but analysts downgraded assumptions due to deferred orders and potential distressed asset sales. Shares fell 4 Singapore cents to S$9.40.

images.alt_text: Keppel Corporation, which announced its results on Thursday, faces risk in a weakening orderbook, analysts said on Friday.

site_title: Airline seat squeeze raises health and safety concerns
summary: Airlines are increasing seat density to protect profit margins, resulting in reduced seat pitch as low as 28 inches. Industry watchers express concerns over health and safety, citing air rage incidents and difficulties for crew to assist passengers in need of medical help. Airlines are responding by adding technology and amenities, such as in-seat power and USB ports, to offset the reduced space. The trend is expected to continue, with Boeing and Airbus increasing the number of seats per row, despite health and safety debates.

site_title: Ex-IMF head Rato in preliminary corruption probe
summary: Former International Monetary Fund (IMF) head Rodrigo Rato had his home and office searched by Spanish authorities as part of a tax and money laundering investigation into his personal wealth. Rato cooperated with authorities, releasing documents relevant to the investigation, and expressed confidence in Spain's judicial system. The investigation is focused on allegations of money laundering, fraud, and asset stripping, and judicial officials will decide whether to name Rato as a suspect and open formal proceedings against him.

site_title: Russia says AIIB complement to BRICS bank, not replacement
summary: Russia's central bank governor Elvira Nabiullina stated that the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB) will complement the BRICS development bank, not replace it. Representatives from Brazil, Russia, India, China, and South Africa reached an agreement to launch the AIIB ahead of their leaders' summit in July. Russia has ratified the AIIB and plans to contribute $2 billion. India will appoint the president of the BRICS bank, while a Russian representative will chair the board of governors. The move aims to fund infrastructure projects in emerging economies.

site_title: Dollar falls as weak US data lowers rate hike outlook
summary: The US dollar fell against the euro due to weak US economic data, including a rise in initial jobless claims and a decrease in housing starts. The data raised concerns about a slowing US economy, which may lead to the Federal Reserve holding off on raising interest rates. This has sparked a shift in the debate from a possible June rate hike to whether September is too early. The euro rose to $1.0761, while Greece's debt crisis was also in focus after Standard & Poor's cut its credit rating.

site_title: Oil prices fall as Opec production soars
summary: Oil prices fell as Opec announced a surge in production in March, adding to a global glut. Opec's March output jumped 810,000 barrels per day to 30.79 million barrels per day, equivalent to a third of global supply. This led to a 15-cent drop in Brent crude futures to $63.83 per barrel and a 20-cent drop in US crude futures to $56.50 per barrel. The decline was attributed to a bearish market outlook and the impact of US tariffs on global demand.

images.alt_text: Oil prices fell in early trading on Friday, ending a run of rallies earlier in the week, after Opec said that its output surged in March, adding to a global glut.

site_title: China's DJI drones flying high among US companies
summary: China's DJI drones have taken a strong lead in the US commercial market, with 61 out of 129 companies using their products, accounting for 47% of the market. DJI's inexpensive and lightweight drones are being used for various purposes, including film production, site inspections, and real estate promotions. The company is expected to exceed $1 billion in sales this year and is in talks to raise new capital. DJI's market share is expected to continue to grow, with the US commercial drone market projected to reach $5.4 billion by 2023.

site_title: Prosecuting those responsible for MH17 crash key priority: Dutch minister
summary: The Dutch Justice Minister, Ard van der Steur, has stated that prosecuting those responsible for the MH17 crash is a key priority. The Boeing 777 was shot down in Ukraine in July 2014, killing 298 people, including 193 Dutch citizens. The Netherlands has led the investigation, with a preliminary report blaming structural damage caused by external objects. Dutch investigators have recovered more body parts from the crash site, and the remains of most victims have been identified. A final report is due in the summer, with prosecution of those responsible expected to be a central focus.

site_title: Twitter out to crack down on abusive tweets
summary: Twitter is overhauling its safety policy and increasing efforts to detect and limit abusive content, aiming to balance free speech with protection of users from mean, hateful, or menacing tweets. The company has tripled its protection team and expanded its definition of banned "abuse" to include indirect threats of violence. Twitter's new approach aims to curb revenge porn, anonymous accounts used to intimidate or silence people, and has improved response times to complaints, with a five-fold increase in speed. The changes follow similar updates from Facebook and Instagram.

site_title: Lagarde says she won't support Greece missing payment to IMF
summary: IMF Managing Director Christine Lagarde warned that she would not support Greece skipping a debt payment to the International Monetary Fund (IMF), citing that it would be the first time a country has delayed a payment in 30 years. Greece must pay the IMF approximately $1 billion next month, and missing the payment would put the country in a similar financial situation as Zimbabwe, Somalia, and Sudan. Despite this, Finance Minister Yanis Varoufakis denied asking the IMF about skipping a payment, and the European Commission expressed concerns about the lack of progress in resolving Greece's financial crisis.

site_title: Greece unveils modest cuts in government spending
summary: Greece's hard-left government has unveiled modest spending cuts to ministerial budgets in an effort to achieve around 300 million euros in total economies. The measures, including renting out public buildings and cracking down on black market fuel sales and healthcare abuse, aim to raise new revenues and reduce the country's huge debt and financing costs. The announcement comes as Greece struggles to agree with EU partners on a debt financing deal, with creditors demanding tough reforms and austerity policies in exchange for the last 7.2-billion euro bailout funding tranche.

site_title: EU says eager to 'finalise' probe into Google market abuse
summary: The European Union has formally charged Google with abusing its market dominance in search, potentially leading to mega fines of up to 10% of the company's $66 billion in global turnover. EU Competition Commissioner Margrethe Vestager said Google's preferential use of its shopping product in search could harm consumers and competitors, and the case may lead to further investigations into other Google tools. Google has 10 weeks to respond to the charges, and Vestager has vowed to keep the case separate from politics.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Private home sales in Singapore rebounded 55% in March 2015, driven by successful launches of large-scale projects like Kingsford Waterbay and Sims Urban Oasis. Year-to-date sales have dropped 24% to 1,367 units. Analysts expect April numbers to remain strong, citing successful property launches and selective investment demand amid cooling measures. Key picks include CapitaLand, Frasers Centrepoint, and UOL, with Hyflux, Biosensors International, and UOB Kay Hian maintaining buy recommendations.

site_title: Ntegrator's shares most traded
summary: Ntegrator's shares surged 18.52% on the Singapore Exchange, with over 121.4 million shares traded, after the company won a S$25.6 million contract for the Next Generation Nationwide Broadband Network in Singapore. The contract, for three years, involves the supply of services for the installation, operation, and maintenance of the network. Despite posting a net loss of S$4.95 million in FY2014, Ntegrator's core businesses remained profitable.

site_title: Europe: Shares retreat from multi-year highs, Casino and Pearson dip
summary: European stocks retreated from 14-year highs, led by a 4.6% drop in Casino's shares due to slower sales growth and a 4% decline in Pearson's shares following a report on a troubled educational technology project. The FTSEurofirst 300 index closed 0.9% lower, while Germany's DAX fell 1.9% due to a stronger euro. Despite concerns over Greece's loan repayments, Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras expressed optimism about reaching an agreement with foreign creditors by the end of April.

site_title: Courts ties up with 2 brands, launches new store concept
summary: Courts, a leading retailer in South-east Asia, has partnered with US-based Ace Hardware and Danish retail chain JYSK to launch new shop-in-shop concepts. The collaborations are expected to be operational by the first half of FY2015/16. Ace Hardware will offer tools and hardware products, while JYSK will sell furniture and accessories, both brands expanding Courts' offerings.

site_title: US: Stocks edge lower on mixed earnings, Greece worries
summary: US stocks closed lower on Thursday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 dipping 0.04% and 0.08% respectively, amid mixed earnings and concerns over Greece's finances. The Nasdaq Composite Index fell 0.06%. The Commerce Department reported a 2% increase in US home construction, while initial jobless claims rose to 294,000. Equities in Britain, France, and Germany fell sharply due to slow progress in bailout negotiations.

site_title: Eco World plans golf course, marina on Penang mainland
summary: Eco World Development Group plans a mixed-development marina and golf course on 470 acres of land in Batu Kawan, Penang mainland. The project aims to enhance investment, job opportunities, and affordable housing in the northern state. The development is part of the state's efforts to boost economic growth and establish itself as a major property player. The project's details and timeline have not been disclosed.

site_title: Palm oil buyers said to delay purchases to get duty-free cargoes from Malaysia
summary: Malaysia's decision to scrap its crude palm oil export tax in May may prompt India and China, the country's largest buyers, to delay purchases to secure cheaper cargoes. The move comes as Indonesia, the world's top palm oil producer, considers imposing additional levies to fund biodiesel subsidies and mandates. This shift in market dynamics could impact global palm oil prices, with buyers potentially opting for cheaper cargoes from Malaysia rather than Indonesia.

site_title: WikiLeaks dumps data from Sony hacking scandal
summary: WikiLeaks has released thousands of documents from the 2014 Sony hacking scandal, including 30,287 documents from Sony Pictures Entertainment and 173,132 emails. The leak, which was initially released in November 2014, shows that the company's CEO, Michael Lynton, dined with President Barack Obama and that employees raised money for Democratic politicians. The leak also reveals racially insensitive jokes about Obama that were exchanged between company executives. The release of the searchable data was condemned by Sony, which claimed that the leaked information was private and should not be made public.

site_title: Norway sovereign wealth fund looks deeper into Africa
summary: Norway's sovereign wealth fund is expanding its investments in Africa, particularly in Nigeria, Kenya, and parts of West Africa, in search of growth opportunities. The fund, which already has investments in South Africa, aims to capture the fastest growth in the global economy. With returns in developed markets eroded by monetary easing, the fund is seeking opportunities in emerging and frontier markets, with a focus on local investment advisers to guide its decisions.

site_title: 'Chewie, we're home': Star Wars trailer delights fans
summary: The Star Wars: The Force Awakens trailer premiered at the Star Wars Celebration convention in Anaheim, sending fans into a frenzy. The action-packed trailer features iconic characters Han Solo and Chewbacca, with Harrison Ford's voice as Solo saying "Chewie, we're home." Fans on Twitter adopted the hashtag #Chewiewerehome, and many expressed tears of joy after the trailer's finale. Director J.J. Abrams discussed the film's approach to realism, emphasizing the importance of authentic sets and locations. The movie is set to release on December 18, 2015.

site_title: Western carmakers to face Chinese competitors in Iran if sanctions lift
summary: European carmakers, including Peugeot and Renault, may re-enter Iran's car market if sanctions are lifted under a proposed nuclear pact. Chinese carmakers, such as Chery, Lifan, and Jianghuai, have already gained a significant share of the market, with Chinese vehicles becoming a common sight on Iranian roads. The Chinese companies have benefited from the sanctions, with their share of the Iranian market increasing from 1% in 2011 to 9% in 2016. If sanctions are lifted, Western carmakers may face increased competition from Chinese models, which are seen as more affordable, but also have a reputation for low quality in Iran.

site_title: Britain's opposition parties clash weeks from election
summary: Opposition parties in the UK, including the Conservative party led by David Cameron and the Labour party led by Ed Miliband, clashed in a televised debate three weeks before the election. The debate saw Miliband challenge Cameron to a one-on-one debate, while the leader of the Scottish National Party (SNP), Nicola Sturgeon, hinted at forming an alliance with Labour to take down the Tories. Miliband emerged as the winner of the debate, according to a poll of viewers. The election is expected to be the closest in decades, with both parties relying on support from smaller parties to form a majority.

images.alt_text: British Prime Minister David Cameron speaks at the launch of the Scottish conservative election manifesto in Glasgow on April 16, 2015. Prime Minister David Cameron's Conservative party and main rival, the Labour party of Ed Miliband, are neck-and-neck ahead of the vote and both may rely on support from smaller parties to form a majority.

site_title: Iraqi prime minister says committed to reforms to attract business
summary: Iraqi Prime Minister Haidar al-Abadi has committed to implementing reforms to attract foreign investment, citing a need to reduce bureaucracy and tackle corruption. The government aims to provide support to the private sector, with reforms including easing visa requirements, automating bureaucratic processes, and granting greater authority to local governments. Al-Abadi also touted the government's success in battling Islamic State insurgents, while seeking US aid and weapons to combat the group. The country faces a $25 billion budget deficit due to a drop in oil revenues.

images.alt_text: Iraq is committed to making difficult reforms to its bureaucracy and regulations for foreign companies in order to attract much-needed investment, Prime Minister Haidar al-Abadi said at a Washington forum on Thursday.

site_title: Unmissable, emotively accessible theatre
summary: Wild Rice's production of Public Enemy, a dramatized look at a Singaporean doctor's fight against the system, is a powerful and emotive theatrical experience. Based on Ibsen's An Enemy of the People, the play explores the complexities of governance and the cost of progress. The cast delivers strong performances, with Ivan Heng standing out as the doctor, Dr. Thomas Chee, who risks everything to expose the truth. The play raises important questions about individuality and the consequences of speaking out against the majority, and is now running until April 25 at Victoria Theatre.

site_title: India set to overtake China as biggest thermal coal importer
summary: India is poised to surpass China as the world's largest importer of thermal coal by 2017, according to Bloomberg Intelligence analysts. India's coal demand is expected to increase 42% to 1 billion tonnes by 2020, driven by a surge in new power generation plants. This growth will be fueled by a decline in coal supplies from Indonesia, the current largest exporter, and India's own increasing demand. The shift is expected to impact the global seaborne thermal coal market, with Indian imports potentially shaping the outlook for thermal coal prices.

site_title: AAF ups its game with new director
summary: The Affordable Art Fair (AAF) has appointed Alan Koh as its new director, aiming to bring art collecting to a wider audience. The fair will feature a personal art shopper program, a SG50 Feature Wall, and live art-making demonstrations. AAF has been successful in attracting first-time collectors and young artists, with 60% of buyers being new to the market. Despite criticism that the fair makes art less critical and exclusive, Koh advocates for buying only artworks loved, rather than as an investment. The fair's success has also led to the expansion of AAF to other cities, including Hong Kong and Seoul.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: Painting heritage is 'slow' art
summary: Artist Tung Yue Nang spent years perfecting his Peranakan series, a collection of paintings featuring intricately detailed porcelain and jewelry. He began the series in 1997, immersing himself in the culture and studying the craft of a Nonya lady sewing beads. The paintings, which include over 40 works, are now on exhibit at the Pan Pacific Hotel in Singapore until June 29. Tung's attention to detail and dedication to the craft have made his series iconic, with prices ranging from S$8,800 upwards for each piece.

site_title: Crowdlending provides new financing option for SMEs
summary: Crowdlending platforms, such as Capital Match and MoolahSense, are gaining popularity as alternative financing options for SMEs and startups in Singapore. These platforms allow individuals to lend directly to businesses in exchange for a fixed return, filling a gap in the banking ecosystem. Since their inception, MoolahSense has successfully funded three campaigns, raising S$550,000, while Capital Match has listed two campaigns, achieving their target amounts with interest rates ranging from 2.4% to 10%. Crowdlending provides businesses with easier access to funding and investors with a new instrument to make returns, but high interest rates require financial discipline from both parties.

site_title: A*Star inks partnerships to boost productivity and tech adoption in SMEs
summary: A*Star has partnered with Spring Singapore, Singapore Productivity Centre, and National Trades Union Congress (NTUC) Health to boost productivity and technology adoption among small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in Singapore. The partnerships aim to increase the adoption of A*Star's technological solutions, such as inventory tracking systems, among SMEs, with an average productivity gain of over 20%. The collaborations will provide SMEs with customized solutions, technical expertise, and funding to support their adoption of technology.

site_title: Lessons from the KepLand takeover
summary: Keppel Corp successfully completed its takeover of Keppel Land, with a two-tier offer structure that included a higher price for minority shareholders who accepted quickly. However, the offeror fell short of the compulsory acquisition threshold, resulting in all shareholders receiving the lower price. The deal highlights the importance of carefully reviewing offer terms to avoid missing out on the higher price, and future offerors may consider introducing an "early bird" clause to encourage early acceptance. The takeover also sheds light on the complexities of the settlement system, particularly the timing of share delivery and potential issues with short-selling into the buying-in market.

site_title: Jawbone finds no threat from smartwatches
summary: Jawbone has released new Up bands, including a water-resistant Up3 model, and teased a flagship Up4 model with biometric sensors and American Express contactless payment capabilities. Despite the pending arrival of the Apple Watch, Jawbone remains confident in its wearable computing trend, focusing on creating a platform that can sync to various applications and services. The company aims to differentiate itself by making its platform open to developers, which could lead to lucrative opportunities for revenue diversification.

site_title: Deep-pocketed Alibaba can thrive in India
summary: Alibaba, the world's largest e-retailer, is showing interest in India's fledgling e-commerce market. Founder Jack Ma has visited India twice and met Prime Minister Narendra Modi, expressing plans to invest in Indian entrepreneurs and improve the relationship between the two nations. Alibaba has already announced a 25% stake in Paytm and is reportedly close to striking a deal with Meru Cabs, a major cab aggregator in India. The company aims to partner with Indian e-retailers to expand its product range and improve customer experience, despite challenges such as inadequate logistics networks and consumer reluctance to use online payment gateways.

site_title: Keppel Corp posts 6.4% rise in Q1 earnings
summary: Keppel Corp reported a 6.4% rise in Q1 earnings, attributing the growth to reduced offshore rig construction costs and increased demand for other services. The company plans to shift its offshore business focus beyond drilling rigs as orders dwindle. Additionally, Keppel is considering delaying rig deliveries to major customer Sete Brasil until long-term financing is secured.

site_title: Ex-Fed chief Bernanke to advise US hedge fund firm
summary: Former Federal Reserve Chairman Ben Bernanke has signed on as a senior adviser to Citadel Investment Group, a $25 billion hedge fund. Bernanke will provide analysis on global economic and financial issues to Citadel's investment committees and meet with investors worldwide. He joins a growing trend of former Washington insiders transitioning to the financial industry, citing the need to offer guidance on navigating an uncertain economic environment. Bernanke's arrangement with Citadel is non-exclusive, allowing him to take on other consulting roles.

images.alt_text: Mr Bernanke will offer his analysis of global economic and financial issues to Citadel Investment Group.

site_title: AIIB is about unlocking wealth via a new Asia-Europe link
summary: The Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB) aims to unlock wealth by linking Asia with Europe via Central Asia, leveraging China's $4 trillion foreign exchange reserves. The institution's vision and mission, announced by Chinese President Xi Jinping, go beyond competing with existing banks like the Asian Development Bank and World Bank. Instead, the AIIB will focus on developing infrastructure and productive sectors in Asia, with a potential role in the Silk Road Fund, a $40 billion venture to secure private-sector participation in infrastructure projects. This approach complements existing institutions, rather than competing with them, and has the potential to create new wealth and employment in the region.

site_title: Tokio Marine investing in property funds of funds
summary: Tokio Marine Holdings Inc, a Japanese insurer, is investing in property funds of funds, focusing on overseas real estate investments. Unlike other Chinese peers, Tokio Marine is not directly buying trophy properties, but rather investing in funds that do. This strategy is a departure from its counterparts, which have been purchasing high-end properties in the US and Europe.

site_title: Deluge of China investors into HK stocks both boon and bane
summary: China's surge in investors into Hong Kong's stocks has boosted the market, but also poses risks to the city's economy and currency. Since November, Chinese investors have poured 68 billion yuan into Hong Kong-listed stocks, driving the market's capitalization to HK$28.6 trillion. However, volatility from these unfamiliar investors and potential sudden capital outflows could destabilize the economy and currency. Analysts warn that Hong Kong's economy is entering a bubble cycle, and the influx of cash may fuel inflation and property price increases.

site_title: Why S'pore property shares make sense
summary: Institutional investors are targeting Singapore property shares of developers that may be taken private due to government curbs on home sales and penalties for unsold units. Six developers have been bought out since 2010, with an average share-price premium of 26%. Companies like Keppel Corp, Wing Tai Holdings, and Ho Bee Land Ltd are potential candidates for delisting, with shares rallying since Keppel Corp's recent purchase of Keppel Land. Privatization could help major shareholders avoid penalties and regulations, which have distorted profit margins for some developers.

images.alt_text: Institutional investors are eyeing real estate developers that may be taken private

site_title: UniFiber pinning hope on Asia Resource takeover
summary: Singapore's United Fiber System (UniFiber) is nearing completion of its $1.88 billion reverse takeover (RTO) of Jakarta-listed PT Golden Energy Mines, controlled by Indonesia's Sinar Mas group. The move could transform UniFiber into a major coal miner. UniFiber has also signed a memorandum of understanding to acquire Asia Resource Minerals (ARMS), a London-listed Indonesian coal mine, pending the completion of its RTO. A takeover bid by ACE, backed by Sinar Mas, poses a challenge to ARMS' rescue plan led by European financier Nat Rothschild.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Women directorships make some headway among S'pore firms
summary: Women's representation on Singapore's listed company boards increased slightly in 2014, with 448 women holding directorships, a 10% rise from the previous year, but their share of directorships remained at 8.8%. The majority of the gain came from independent directors, with 39% of all women directors being independent. However, women's representation varied across industries, with media companies showing significant improvement, while retail businesses were more diverse. Despite the slight improvement, Singapore's national participation rate lags other major markets, with only 8.8% of directorships held by women.

images.alt_text: FEMALE representation on the boards of Singapore's listed companies grew slightly in 2014 but remained below levels at many other major markets, according to a new report by the Diversity Action Committee (DAC).

site_title: Sharp, banks near US$1.7b bailout deal: source
summary: Sharp Corp, a Japanese electronics company, is set to agree on a $1.7 billion bailout deal with its main banks, Mizuho Bank and Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi UFJ. The plan includes a debt-for-equity swap and a pledge to scale back its North American television operations, resulting in around 5,000 job cuts. Sharp's LCD operations, accounting for 30% of its sales, are likely to be split off to improve transparency and accountability. The deal is seen as insufficient by many investors, with analysts stating that it only addresses short-term issues and does not provide a strategy for future growth.

site_title: Smart home technologies for Ascott's serviced residences
summary: Ascott, a serviced residence arm of CapitaLand, partnered with Samsung Asia to develop Internet of Things (IoT) smart solutions for its properties. This makes Ascott the first global serviced residence company to adopt smart home technologies. The technologies will enable guests to control devices remotely, receive real-time insights on their preferences, and enhance productivity. The rollout is expected to begin by the first half of 2016, with plans to introduce the technologies in over 20 countries.

site_title: Rescuing record store day
summary: Record Store Day in Singapore will be relatively quiet this year due to the severe vinyl shortage plaguing the industry. Despite this, local record shop owners and acts are launching their own initiatives to keep the occasion alive. Vinylicious Records and Hear Records will offer exclusive releases, while Curated Records will host in-store events and a sale. The Singapore office of Universal Music will also release 20 titles. Despite the challenges, the event aims to promote local music and keep the record shop culture alive in the digital age.

images.alt_text: Riot !n Magenta (above) will be playing a mini set to mark the recent release of their acclaimed Voices EP at Hear Records; while I Am David Sparkle will host a listening party of their highly-anticipated new album, Art is Blood.
Hanging Up The Moon's new album Immaterial will be getting a special release on vinyl ahead of its global and CD launch next month to mark Record Store Day (RSD)
A selection of limited-edition releases that will be on sale at Vinylicious Records including Metallica's vintage No Life 'Till Leather demos reproduced on cassette tape
Two specially-designed event posters to celebrate RSD in Singapore
Two specially-designed event posters to celebrate RSD in Singapore

site_title: Delta to pare capacity on international routes
summary: Delta Air Lines plans to cut international seating capacity by 3% due to the strong US dollar and declining oil prices, affecting routes to Japan, Africa, India, and the Middle East. The reductions will take effect in the fourth quarter, impacting 30% of Delta's revenue. Despite a 20% reduction in international capacity, Delta expects to save $2 billion in fuel costs this year. The airline's first-quarter profit beat analyst estimates, with a record $372 million profit.

site_title: Toyota to build new factories in Mexico, China
summary: Toyota plans to build two new factories, one in Mexico and the other in China, ending its self-imposed expansion freeze. The Mexican plant, valued at $1 billion, will have an annual capacity of 200,000 cars and approximately 2,000 workers. The move increases Toyota's North American production capacity by the same number of vehicles. This expansion aims to put pressure on global rivals and solidify Toyota's position in the market.

site_title: SMRT jumps on telco ambitions
summary: SMRT Corporation's shares surged after the company expressed interest in expanding into the telecommunications business by partnering with OMGTEL, a contender for Singapore's fourth wireless telecommunications carrier licence. SMRT plans to invest up to S$34.5 million in OMGTEL. The company has entered into an exclusive agreement with OMGTEL to work on the bid, marking a significant move into the telco sector.

images.alt_text: Shares of SMRT Corporation surged on Thursday after the train operator suggested it may expand into the telecommunications business by partnering a contender for Singapore's fourth wireless telecommunications carrier licence.

site_title: China exporters expect tough times as costs rise, demand falters: poll
summary: China exporters expect a trade slowdown lasting at least six months due to rising production costs and weakening European demand, particularly hit by a weaker euro. According to a Reuters survey at the Canton Fair, more than half of China's exporters anticipate a slowdown. International buyers, especially Europeans, are ordering fewer goods and pushing for discounts. This trend may pose challenges for China's exporters and could impact the country's economic growth.

site_title: City Buzz
summary: Alternative gems in film and dining are highlighted in Singapore. The Society for Cult and Underground Movies (SCUM) presents a documentary screening of "Jodorowsky's Dune" about the failed sci-fi project in April, while the Singapore Chinese Film Festival (SCFF) returns with a lineup of 40 films, including the Singapore premieres of "North by Northeast" and "Black Coal, Thin Ice". Meanwhile, a Glenfarclas Whiskey Dinner is held at the Bar & Billard Room, featuring a four-course meal paired with premium Glenfarclas whiskies. The Crown Bakery & Café, a collaboration with Japanese bakery Signifiant Signifie, opens with healthy, artisanal breads and pastries.

site_title: A$ up against major peers on job gains
summary: Australia's dollar surged to its strongest three-day winning streak since 2013, gaining 1.3% to 77.82 US cents, after a government report showed employers added more than twice as many positions as forecast in March, driving down the unemployment rate. Traders reduced the odds of the Reserve Bank of Australia cutting interest rates next month to 62%, from 73% previously. The Aussie's gain was the largest against its 16 major peers since September 2013, as the Bloomberg Dollar Spot Index declined for a third-straight day.

site_title: Number of COEs headed for 41% surge from May
summary: The number of Certificate of Entitlement (COE) in Singapore is expected to surge by 41.1% from May, with a total of 19,912 COEs available. This follows an 18.3% increase in the current three-month period. COE premiums for Category A small cars are expected to ease, but Cat B and Cat C premiums are expected to rise. The increase in Cat C COEs is attributed to the low take-up rate for the Early Turnover Scheme, which allows diesel vehicle owners to pay the prevailing quota premium instead of bidding for a COE.

site_title: Actor a real-life hero both on and off-screen
summary: Actor Epy Quizon, known for his roles in local dramas, stood up for fellow Filipino workers on a film shoot in Malaysia, refusing to work until they were paid. He credits this experience for his real-life heroism and says it influenced his portrayal of a migrant restaurant owner in the film Unlucky Plaza. Quizon, who has over 100 films to his credit, credits his family, including his father Dolphy, and fatherhood for mellowing his personality and changing his outlook on life, becoming an ambassador for peace.

site_title: Netflix shares soar as global video streaming subscribers top 62m
summary: Netflix announced its video streaming service reached 62 million subscribers worldwide, surpassing forecasts. US subscribers rose 2.28 million and international accounts grew 2.6 million in the first quarter. The company's shares soared 12% to a record high, driven by strong US growth and original programming. Despite losses overseas due to the strong US dollar, Netflix remains a "subscriber growth momentum story," according to analysts.

site_title: Microsoft plays agitator in antitrust probe against Google
summary: Microsoft is playing a key role in an antitrust probe against Google in Europe, where regulators have accused the company of abusing its dominance. Microsoft has founded or funded several groups, including the Initiative for a Competitive Online Marketplace (ICOMP), which has waged a public relations campaign promoting grievances against Google. The investigation, which started in 2010, involves three companies that claimed Google manipulated its search results to favor its own shopping services. Microsoft and other American tech companies, including Yelp and TripAdvisor, are lining up against Google in Europe, with influential European powers also weighing in.

site_title: The weight of a heartbreak
summary: Actor Adrian Pang perfectly embodies the character John Au Yong, a 40-something libertine, in Huzir Sulaiman's award-winning monologue "The Weight Of Silk On Skin." Pang's performance brings depth to a character initially perceived as misogynistic, revealing a broken man haunted by his past love, ex-girlfriend Anna. The play's structural elegance and Pang's heart-wrenching performance make it a standout, deconstructing the character's persona and showcasing his vulnerability.

site_title: Woman on board
summary: A Singaporean firm is set to sign a carbon credits transfer agreement with its first ASEAN country by the end of 2025, as part of Singapore's efforts to reduce its carbon footprint. This move aims to increase the use of green finance and align with the country's goal of becoming a leader in environmental, social, and governance (ESG) practices. Additionally, Singapore is considering introducing legislation for carbon offsetting in the airline industry, while Temasek has invested S$46 billion in sustainability-aligned investments by the end of 2025. This move reflects the country's commitment to ESG practices.

site_title: Accor to run Keong Hong JV hotels
summary: Keong Hong Construction, a Singapore-based construction group, has appointed French hotel group Accor to run its first two hotel properties in the Maldives through a joint-venture company called Pristine Islands Investment. Keong Hong holds a 45% share in Pristine Islands Investment. This marks Keong Hong's entry into the Maldives hotel market, with plans to develop an airport in the country as well.

site_title: S'pore education is no child's play
summary: A new play, "Normal", by playwright Faith Ng, highlights the negative impact of Singapore's education system on the self-esteem of academically weak students. The play follows two troubled teens as they struggle to cope with the school system, despite the efforts of their teacher. The production, directed by Claire Wong, features strong performances from the teenage actresses and a supporting cast of educators. The play serves as a cautionary tale, urging Singapore to reevaluate its emphasis on test scores and prioritize every child's well-being. The play is sold out and will be restaged next year.

site_title: Eurozone growth, inflation outlook brighter: ECB survey
summary: The European Central Bank's (ECB) quarterly survey of professional forecasters indicates that eurozone growth and inflation are expected to improve, driven by the ECB's policy measures. Eurozone inflation is predicted to stand at 0.1% in 2015, 1.2% in 2016, and 1.6% in 2017, moving towards the ECB's target of 2%. The survey also sees an upward revision in economists' growth forecasts for 2015, 2016, and 2017, with real GDP growth expectations revised up to 1.4%, 1.7%, and 1.8% respectively.

site_title: Deepwater drilling will never be risk-free
summary: The Deepwater Horizon disaster, which occurred five years ago, remains a highly controversial issue in the oil industry. The massive spill resulted in 11 deaths, harmed thousands of marine animals, and affected large stretches of US coastline. Despite regulatory and safety measures, concerns about the risks of deepwater drilling continue. New studies have shown that the legacy of the disaster can have long-term effects on local ecosystems, and the industry's reliance on deepwater areas remains strong due to the growing demand for energy. The industry's resilience and ability to adapt to risks also contributes to its continued operation in these areas.

site_title: Amazon's grocery delivery cheapest in NYC: study
summary: Amazon's grocery delivery service is the cheapest in NYC, according to a study by Nomura Securities International. Amazon's service costs $20 less than its closest competitor on a 30-item order. The study suggests that Amazon may target supermarkets with its delivery service, similar to how it has entered the book and big-box chain markets. This move could further expand Amazon's presence in everyday life.

site_title: Motivating staff with values, not red tape
summary: A thought-provoking article suggests that the US Constitution is more effective in advancing the well-being of ordinary Americans than the Internal Revenue Code. The complexity of the tax code has hindered its functionality, limiting employees' problem-solving abilities. In contrast, high-performing companies design flexible operating models that adapt to changes, allowing employees to think critically and solve problems effectively. The article implies that a more adaptive and streamlined system, like the Constitution, is better suited for governing working life.

site_title: Staging Shakespeare's midlife crisis
summary: Director Braham Murray views Prospero in Shakespeare's The Tempest as a character experiencing a midlife crisis. Murray, who has directed the play once before during his own midlife crisis in his 40s, sees Prospero's actions as a desperate attempt to regain control and power after being stranded on an island. This interpretation highlights the themes of aging, power, and identity in the play, which was written as Shakespeare's final work.

site_title: ACE and NUS team up to deepen know-how on entrepreneurship
summary: Singapore's Action Community for Entrepreneurship (ACE) and the National University of Singapore (NUS) Business School are partnering for a two-year collaboration to deepen entrepreneurship knowledge, drive apprenticeship opportunities, and host master classes. The partnership aims to provide policymakers and the business community with fresh strategic insights into Singapore's innovation and enterprise ecosystem. NUS students will have more opportunities for field-service projects, practicums, and internships with startups, while ACE and NUS will jointly host master classes and conferences featuring industry leaders and academics.

site_title: US trade chief says fast-track would move trade deals forward
summary: US Trade Representative Michael Froman announced plans to get fast-track authority to move trade deals through Congress quickly, allowing the Obama administration to advance trade agreements. Treasury Secretary Jack Lew expressed support for provisions to counter currency manipulation, which would be a "powerful" signal to trading partners. This move aims to facilitate trade deal progress, although details of the new bill have not been released.

site_title: Dutch shift focus in MH17 crash to investigating culprits
summary: The Dutch government has shifted its focus from repatriation to investigating the culprits behind the downing of Malaysia Airlines Flight MH17, which killed all 298 people on board. With the identification of 296 victims, prosecutors are testing the theory that the plane was shot down by a surface-to-air BUK missile fired from pro-Russian forces in eastern Ukraine. The Netherlands, which has a significant number of victims, is leading the post-crash investigation, with foreign ministers from Malaysia, Ukraine, and Australia agreeing to push ahead with justice.

site_title: CSA has work cut out as Singapore already in cross hairs of cyber attackers
summary: A report by FireEye reveals that a China-linked hacking group, APT30, has been targeting Singapore, other ASEAN states, and India for at least 10 years, focusing on organizations with sensitive information on regional politics, economics, and military issues. The group's persistent attacks have evaded detection until recently, and their methods are similar to those of established technology businesses. The CSA, Singapore's cyber security agency, has been established to address this challenge, with a focus on developing a national cyber security strategy and policy, and building international partnerships to protect critical information infrastructure.

images.alt_text: "It's rare that we see a group with a distinct regional focus . . . There are many attack groups that target specific countries or businesses within the region."- Mr Boland

site_title: Dark offering that doesn't stoop to the low-brow
summary: Writer-director Ken Kwek's film "Unlucky Plaza" tackles dark themes in Singapore, including property scams, problem gambling, and loan sharking. The story follows Onassis Hernandez, a restaurateur, and Sky, a self-absorbed motivational speaker, as their worlds collide. Despite bold social commentary, the film is drawn out and has an overly convenient ending, preventing viewers from fully investing in the characters' fates. The movie is a welcome departure from the typical Singaporean film, focusing on mature and complex issues.

site_title: Manulife does away with cubicles
summary: Manulife, Canada's largest insurer, is renovating and expanding its offices in Toronto, Montreal, and Hong Kong to reduce its property bill by 25%. The insurer aims to eliminate cubicles and adopt flexible workspaces, allowing employees to work remotely. By 2017, a third of Canadian employees will have unassigned desks and tighter layouts. The move is part of a broader trend among financial firms to reduce office space and adopt more modern workspaces, with companies like Deloitte and Sony Corp also adopting similar strategies.

site_title: Malakoff sets tight price range for IPO: sources
summary: Malakoff Corporation Bhd, Malaysia's largest independent power firm, has set a tight bookbuilding range for its initial public offering (IPO), valuing the offering at RM2.74 billion, the largest in Malaysia in almost three years. The top end of the range has solid support from domestic cornerstone investors, according to sources. The IPO is expected to be a significant milestone for the company, marking the largest in Malaysia in over three years.

site_title: Debt is no longer a burden in zero-rate environment
summary: The developed world is shifting towards a long-term zero-interest-rate environment, with the eurozone already experiencing near-zero rates and Japan's environment becoming increasingly unique. This shift has significant implications for investors and debtors, as nominal interest rates become negligible and real returns can be positive in a low-inflation environment. The "extend and pretend" phenomenon, where debtors roll over maturing debt at low rates, allows them to continue carrying large debt burdens indefinitely, undermining the concept of a "debt overhang" and the Maastricht Treaty's debt limit.

site_title: Beige Book reveals rosy picture of US economy
summary: The US economy continues to grow, with most regions reporting moderate to slight growth, according to the Federal Reserve's Beige Book. Labour markets remain stable, with modest wage increases and rising prices. The strong dollar, falling oil prices, and harsh winter weather have had some impact, but overall conditions are improving. Car sales have climbed, and consumer spending on tourism and travel is rebounding. The housing market is improving, except in the New York district, and the Fed is set to debate its first interest rate hike since 2006 at its next meeting on April 28-29.

site_title: Aussie March job growth more than doubles forecast
summary: Australian employment surged in March, exceeding forecasts with a 37,700 job gain. This more than doubled the initial forecast of 15,000. February's job growth was also revised up to 41,900. The strong employment numbers led to a surge in the local dollar and a decrease in interest rate cut bets, indicating a positive economic outlook.

images.alt_text: Full-time employment was healthy and hours worked rose again, suggesting that the labour market was not as weak as generally assumed.

site_title: Qian Hu's Q1 earnings down 2.6% at S$112,000
summary: Qian Hu Corporation, a Singapore-based ornamental fish service provider, reported a net profit of S$112,000 for the first quarter of FY2015, down 2.6% from S$115,000 in the same period last year. Revenue increased 0.3% to S$20.8 million. The company's Q1 earnings were lower than expected, but revenue growth was seen as a positive sign.

site_title: Champagne can be an anytime drink!
summary: Champagne can be enjoyed beyond celebratory occasions. A tasting of Champagne Pol Roger's cuvees revealed that their Brut 2000 and Brut Vintage 2002 pair well with oysters and local shellfish. The 2003 Pinot Noir from New Zealand's Central Otago district is a substitute for pricey Burgundian Pinots, offering similar flavors at a lower price. This challenges the notion that champagne is only suitable for special occasions, making it a more accessible drink for regular consumption.

site_title: China suspends new bank-technology rules: WSJ
summary: China suspended new bank-technology rules, which were criticized by Washington as unfair pressure on foreign firms, according to the Wall Street Journal. The rules aimed to improve banking technology security and had triggered US protests over China's anti-terrorism law requiring foreign companies to hand over encryption keys. The suspension comes as China agrees to delay implementing the technology restrictions, and Reuters reported earlier that the country had agreed to delay the rules.

site_title: Malaysia sells US$1.5b Islamic bonds in first global offering since 2011
summary: Malaysia sold $1.5 billion in Islamic bonds, its first global offering since 2011, with 10-year bonds yielding 3.04% and 30-year bonds at 4.24%. The sale was met with strong demand, with orders exceeding $9 billion. The move aims to cut borrowing costs and stabilize the government's finances amid concerns over the state investment company 1MDB's rising debt. Despite Fitch Ratings warning of a sovereign downgrade risk, analysts say Malaysia's long-term fundamentals remain intact.

site_title: Starwood launches brand featuring independent hotels
summary: Starwood Hotels has launched its new Tribute Portfolio brand, featuring independent hotels. The brand aims to amass 100 hotels by 2020, with half in the Asia-Pacific region. Tribute hotels will focus on upper-scale properties, complementing Starwood's other brands. The brand will leverage Starwood's distribution channels, sales platforms, and loyalty program to appeal to hotel owners seeking independent spirit while benefiting from Starwood's resources. The first Tribute hotel, Royal Palm South Beach Miami, has opened in the US, with more to follow in the US and Asia-Pacific.

images.alt_text: The Tribute brand made its debut with the Royal Palm South Beach Miami (above), which opened this week.
Mr Sukumaran (above) said US and European hotels will also join the Tribute portfolio.

site_title: Europe: Stocks fall as Germany, Italy, Portugal lead declines
summary: European stocks fell 0.8% to a three-week low, with Germany, Italy, and Portugal leading declines. The Stoxx Europe 600 Index dropped, with chemical companies falling the most. Investors locked in profits, citing a risk-off day. Despite a 20% year-to-date rally, analysts say a pause is needed. The European Central Bank's quantitative easing remains in place, supporting the economic recovery.

site_title: Search area for MH370 to double if wreckage not found
summary: Malaysia's government ministers have agreed to double the search area for missing Malaysia Airlines Flight MH370 if wreckage is not found in the current target area. The Boeing 777 aircraft, carrying 239 passengers and crew, disappeared in March 2014 and is believed to have crashed in the Indian Ocean off Australia's west coast. The extended search, which could take up to a year, aims to locate the wreckage, with most passengers being Chinese. No trace has been found so far.

site_title: Microsoft and Yahoo amend search deal
summary: Microsoft and Yahoo amended their 2009 search deal, giving Yahoo more flexibility to enhance its search services. Microsoft will have exclusive rights to sell ads delivered by its Bing ads platform, while Yahoo will continue to sell ads on its Gemini platform. The partnership, crafted by former CEOs Steve Ballmer and Carol Bartz, was initially set for 10 years.

site_title: How retail investors can avoid short-sellers' targets
summary: Retail investors can avoid short-seller targets by recognizing common signs of fundamental problems in companies. These include unclear business models, inflated sales and profit numbers, poor operating cash flows, dependence on large and frequent acquisitions for growth, and non-verifiable assets. Diligent investors can save themselves grief by avoiding companies that exhibit these characteristics, even if they have high institutional ownership or glowing analyst forecasts. By scrutinizing cash flow statements and understanding a company's business model, investors can make more informed decisions and avoid potential short-seller targets.

site_title: Philly Fed factory activity rises in April
summary: The Philadelphia Federal Reserve Bank reported a business activity index of 7.5 in April, surpassing economists' expectations of 6.0 and marking the first expansion in the region's manufacturing since January. This rise indicates growth in eastern Pennsylvania, southern New Jersey, and Delaware. The index is seen as a leading indicator of US manufacturing health before the national Institute for Supply Management report.

images.alt_text: Factory activity in the US mid-Atlantic region accelerated in April, a survey showed on Thursday.

site_title: Gold rises as sluggish US data pressures dollar
summary: Gold rose for a second day, up 0.3% to $1,205.21 an ounce, as soft US housing and jobless reports weighed on the dollar, supporting speculation of a delayed interest rate hike from the Federal Reserve. This could boost interest in gold, a non-interest-paying asset. Analysts expect a September rate hike and a potential extension of trading in the near-$1,200 level before prices rise at year-end.

site_title: Handmade goods website company Etsy valued at US$3.88b in debut
summary: Etsy, an online marketplace for handmade goods and craft supplies, debuted with a valuation of US$3.88 billion, more than doubling its shares. The company's initial public offering raised US$267 million, valuing each share at US$34.48. Founded in 2005, Etsy offers a wide range of handmade and vintage items, with 29 million items listed on its website. Revenue rose 56% to US$195.6 million in the year ended December 31, despite a widening net loss.

site_title: Absorbing, slow-paced thriller
summary: A serial rapist wearing a surgical mask terrorizes women in a rural Chinese community, evading police. Village policeman and elderly pig breeder form an unlikely alliance to track the predator. The thriller, "North by Northeast," is a highlight of the Singapore Chinese Film Festival, showcasing the challenges of village life in post-Cultural Revolution China. Directed by Zhang Bingjian, the film is a smart and witty exploration of unease and suspense in a seemingly tranquil setting.

images.alt_text: The assailant easily eludes the mostly clueless local cop Li Zhanshan and his underlings but Cao Bing, who runs a pig breeding station, is made of stern stuff and her sleuthing abilities are more impressive than Li's.

The assailant easily eludes the mostly clueless local cop Li Zhanshan and his underlings but Cao Bing, who runs a pig breeding station, is made of stern stuff and her sleuthing abilities are more impressive than Li's.

site_title: EU bank supervisors focus on bonuses, cyber resilience, conduct
summary: European Union regulators will focus on enforcing the bloc's cap on bonuses, cyber resilience, and preventing misconduct in banks this year. The European Banking Authority (EBA) will assess banks' compliance with the bonus cap, which limits payouts to no more than a fixed salary or twice that amount with shareholder approval. The EBA also plans to review conduct risk, monitor corporate governance, and assess IT risks to prevent cybercrime and outages. New resolution colleges will be set up to scrutinize banks' crisis recovery plans, and regulators will have new powers to force lenders to make internal changes if plans are deemed unworkable.

site_title: IMF says 'excessive' currency depreciations should be avoided
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has warned that excessive currency depreciations to boost domestic economies could exacerbate global tensions over exchange rates. IMF Managing Director Christine Lagarde said such reliance could lead to winners and losers. The IMF has advised countries to avoid relying too heavily on exchange rate depreciations, citing the need for better global financial safety nets and coordination. The warning comes as the US dollar's sharp rise against the euro and yen has exposed some emerging economies. The IMF has called for a better system to help countries in turmoil, citing uneven access to financial safety nets.

site_title: SunPower, Apple to build solar projects in China
summary: SunPower Corp and Apple Inc announced plans to build two solar power projects in China's Sichuan province with a total capacity of 40 megawatts. The projects, expected to be completed in the fourth quarter of 2015, will provide up to 80 million kilowatt-hours of electricity per year. Apple and Sichuan Shengtian New Energy Development Co Ltd will jointly own the projects. The partnership is seen as a significant move to promote renewable energy in China.

site_title: STI takes a breather after 4 days of rises
summary: The Straits Times Index fell 8.34 points to 3,531.61 after four days of rises, with penny stocks dominating the market. Turnover was 2.6 billion units worth S$1.5 billion, with 266 rises and 203 falls. Rotational punting of penny stocks, driven by improved sentiment in Hong Kong, led to significant gains for stocks like Ntegrator and Healthway Medical. Meanwhile, blue chips like Singapore Exchange and Noble Group fell, and property stocks were mixed despite strong sales data. A Bank of America-Merrill Lynch survey found that 25% of global investors believe equity markets are overvalued.

site_title: Total to halt crude refining near Marseille, bets on biofuels
summary: Total, France's largest oil refiner, plans to halt crude refining at its La Mede site near Marseille by the end of 2016, investing 200 million euros in a biorefinery to meet growing demand for biofuels. The move aims to cut 180 jobs and make the site profitable. Total also plans to invest 400 million euros at its Donges refinery to capture low-sulphur fuel markets. The company aims to reduce its oil refining capacity by 20% by 2017, with other European refiners expected to follow.

site_title: SATS forms joint venture with global food company BRF
summary: SATS's Singapore Food Industries has entered into a joint venture with global food company BRF GmbH to set up a company in Singapore to process meat and manufacture branded food products. The joint venture, SATS BRF Food, will have an issued and paid-up share capital of S$48 million, with SFI holding 24.48 million shares and BRF GmbH holding 23.52 million shares. Under the agreement, SFI will transfer its food distribution business and 49% of the company's share capital to BRF GmbH for S$26 million.

site_title: Tanker lifts one million barrels of crude at Libya's Hariga port
summary: A tanker successfully lifted one million barrels of crude oil from Libya's Hariga port, marking a significant shipment after the terminal reopened following poor weather. Libya has managed to boost oil output to nearly 600,000 barrels per day despite militant attacks and factional fighting. However, the oil sector remains uncertain due to plans to sell oil via a new state firm bypassing the existing entity in Tripoli, raising concerns about the sector's future stability.

site_title: Brent crude oil hits 2015 high as US output slows
summary: Brent crude oil reached a 2015 high of over $63 per barrel, driven by evidence that US production is slowing, balancing the oversupplied market. US production has decreased for the second time in three weeks, while refinery runs are increasing, driving demand higher. Analysts expect US production to turn negative, supporting the price rally. However, the market remains oversupplied, and some analysts predict a sharp downturn could occur after a potential rise towards $70 per barrel.

site_title: Greek PM Tsipras confident of EU deal despite friction over major reforms
summary: Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras expressed confidence in reaching a deal with foreign creditors by the end of April, despite disagreements over major reforms such as pension and labor reform. Tsipras stated that several points of agreement have been found, particularly on tax collection and corruption, but four issues remain unresolved. European partners, including German Finance Minister Wolfgang Schaeuble, have expressed skepticism about a deal, citing Greece's risk of running out of cash and defaulting on debt payments.
