Tsipras remains optimistic, citing the need for "bridging differences" and "stability" rather than "unethical financial blackmail".

site_title: Seattle homeless newspaper vendors pioneer scan-to-pay Google app
summary: Seattle's homeless newspaper vendors will accept digital payments through a Google-developed app, allowing customers to scan a barcode with their phones to receive a $2.99 digital edition of the Real Change newspaper for $2. This initiative aims to help the paper survive in the digital age, where fewer people have access to cash and prefer to read news on mobile devices.

site_title: Indonesian parliament approves new police chief after graft scandal
summary: Indonesia's parliament approved President Joko Widodo's new police chief, Badrodin Haiti, after withdrawing his initial nominee, Budi Gunawan, due to a bribery scandal. Gunawan was implicated in a bribery scandal earlier this year, leading to public pressure on the president. Haiti passed a "fit-and-proper" test, where parliament members grilled him on tackling corruption and crime. The move has raised concerns about the president's ability to take on powerful vested interests, and anti-corruption activists warn that appointing Gunawan as deputy chief of police would jeopardize police reform efforts.

site_title: US: Wall St falls as investors eye earnings
summary: US stocks fell as investors awaited earnings reports, despite largely beating expectations. The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 0.17% to 18,082.48, while the S&P 500 lost 0.14% to 2,103.72 and the Nasdaq Composite fell 0.17% to 5,002.35. The market's slight decline was attributed to investors' cautious approach amid tariff threats and ongoing US-EU trade talks.

site_title: US jobless claims rise; continuing claims lowest since 2000
summary: US jobless claims rose 12,000 to 294,000 in the week ended April 11, exceeding economists' forecasts. Despite the increase, the four-week moving average of claims ticked up to 282,750, indicating a strengthening labor market. The number of people still receiving benefits after an initial week of aid fell to 2.27 million, the lowest reading since December 2000, suggesting more long-term unemployed are getting jobs.

site_title: European privacy watchdogs join forces to probe Facebook
summary: European data protection authorities from France, Belgium, Germany, the Netherlands, and Spain have joined forces to probe Facebook's privacy controls. The probe focuses on Facebook's privacy policy, data sharing between apps, and alleged breaches under European Union law. This move comes amid concerns over data protection and follows a class action suit filed by an Austrian law graduate against Facebook for alleged privacy breaches. The investigation aims to ensure Facebook complies with data protection laws and safeguards user privacy.

site_title: US housing starts rise below expectations; permits fall
summary: US housing starts rose 2.0% to 926,000 units in March, below expectations. Permits fell 12.4% to 1.13 million units, the largest drop since May. This decline may raise concerns about the economy's recovery from a soft first quarter. Single-family home starts increased, while multifamily starts declined. February's starts were revised up to 908,000 units.

site_title: Fink says US first-quarter growth will be 'disappointing'
summary: Laurence Fink, CEO of BlackRock, predicts a "very disappointing" first quarter of US economic growth, driven by lower oil prices and weak consumer spending. In contrast, Europe is expected to show higher GDP due to a strong dollar, quantitative easing, and a cleaner banking system. Fink attributes the US slowdown to consumers not spending their savings from lower gasoline prices, rather than weather-related factors.

site_title: BlackRock quarterly profit rises 8.7%
summary: BlackRock Inc, the world's largest money manager, reported an 8.7% rise in first-quarter profit, driven by positive flows into its exchange-traded funds. The company's income rose to $822 million, or $4.84 per share, from $756 million, or $4.40 per share, a year earlier. This boost was primarily due to increased investor confidence in the company's funds.

site_title: Opec sees higher demand for its oil as price drop hits rivals
summary: Opec reported higher demand for its oil this year, forecasting an average of 29.27 million barrels per day, up 80,000 bpd from its previous prediction. The increase is attributed to a price drop hurting rival producers, while non-Opec supply is expected to rise only 680,000 bpd, down from 850,000 bpd. Opec's production rose to 30.79 million bpd in March, filling the gap in excess supplies. The report suggests Opec's strategy of lowering prices is taking effect.

site_title: Citigroup profit jumps as legal, restructuring costs fall
summary: Citigroup reported a 16% jump in quarterly profit, driven by a 76% decline in legal and restructuring costs to $403 million. The bank's shares rose 2% to $54.33. Citi has been simplifying its structure by selling non-core businesses and cutting costs. CEO Mike Corbat aims to return more capital to shareholders, and the bank's return on assets was 1.05%, higher than its target. Adjusted net income rose to $4.82 billion, or $1.52 per share, exceeding analyst expectations.

images.alt_text: Citigroup Inc, the third biggest US bank by assets, reported a 16 per cent jump in quarterly profit as legal and restructuring costs plunged.

site_title: Singapore Wrap Thursday
summary: In Singapore, the number of COEs (Certificates of Entitlement) will increase by 41.1% starting next month. A report found female representation on Singapore's listed company boards rose to 8.8% in 2014. Consumers are encouraged to provide feedback on financial advisers under new assessment rules. A*Star partnered with organizations to boost productivity and tech adoption in SMEs. The Straits Times Index fell 8.34 points, while penny stocks remained a focus. Internationally, Vietnam reacted to the US Trump tariff announcement, and China's GDP growth is expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers.

site_title: IAG's British Airways quits European trade body over policy differences
summary: International Airlines Group (IAG) announced the withdrawal of its subsidiaries British Airways and Iberia from the Association of European Airlines due to policy disagreements over competition in the skies. IAG has long advocated for liberalizing aviation markets, contrasting with some rivals who oppose the entry of Gulf carriers, such as Emirates and Qatar Airways, which they claim benefit from unfair state aid. The decision reflects a shift in IAG's stance on key policy issues.

site_title: Putin sees return to growth in Russia in under 2 years
summary: President Vladimir Putin predicted Russia's economy could return to growth in under 2 years, despite global oil price falls and economic sanctions. He largely blames the West for Russia's economic problems. The central bank expects an economic contraction of 3.5-4% this year and 1-1.6% in 2016. Putin believes sanctions will not be lifted, calling them "purely political." His ratings in Russia have soared since annexing Crimea, but relations with the West are at their lowest point since the Cold War.

site_title: ECB survey of experts paints brighter eurozone outlook
summary: The European Central Bank's Survey of Professional Forecasters suggests a brighter outlook for the eurozone, with economists predicting inflation will remain near zero this year, but rise to 1.2% in 2016 and beyond. The low euro value and quantitative easing program are credited with this improvement. Economic growth forecasts for the next three years have also been upgraded, while unemployment is expected to show only modest improvement by 2017. ECB President Mario Draghi has pledged to continue the quantitative easing program until September 2016 or until inflation reaches the bank's target of near 2%.

site_title: China targets overseas fund transfers in graft fight
summary: China has launched a nationwide crackdown on offshore companies and underground banks that transfer ill-gotten assets abroad as part of its "Sky Net" initiative to combat graft. The campaign, led by the People's Bank of China, aims to sever transfer channels for corrupt assets and maintain state financial management order. The move follows the repatriation of 500 suspects and 3 billion yuan in assets last year, with over 150 "economic fugitives" believed to be in the US. China has given the US a priority list of suspected corrupt officials, but no extradition treaty exists between the two countries.

site_title: Indonesia's Pertamina may invest in overseas oil refinery for first time
summary: Indonesia's state-owned energy company Pertamina may invest in its first overseas oil refinery to meet the rising fuel needs of Southeast Asia's largest economy. The move comes amid unfavourable investment conditions at home and lower valuations of overseas assets due to tumbling oil prices. Pertamina's new CEO, Dwi Soetjipto, said the company may acquire a refinery overseas and dedicate its production to the state. The plan aims to re-balance Indonesia's fuel output and double domestic fuel production by 2023.

site_title: Scooting with the times
summary: Electric scooter enthusiasts in Singapore hope the Land Transport Authority (LTA) will relax regulations on public use of the environment-friendly vehicles. Despite current laws banning PMDs on LTA roads and pavements, an Active Mobility Unit is set to be established to review safety guidelines. Users, including professionals and tourists, praise the convenience, cost-effectiveness, and environmental benefits of electric scooters. They advocate for a re-evaluation of laws and a focus on educating scooter users, with some suggesting speed regulations and guidelines for safe usage. A conclusion is expected by the middle of the year.

site_title: US CEO pay rose 12% in 2014: Towers Watson
summary: US CEOs experienced a 12.1% pay raise in 2014, driven mainly by increases in pension benefits. Excluding pension value changes, total compensation would have increased 8.1%. This represents a significant jump from the 1.6% increase in 2013. The increase was largely due to lower interest rates and other factors that drove up pension values.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher
summary: Malaysian shares ended higher on Thursday, with the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 7.81 points to close at 1,847.94. A total of 2.7 billion lots valued at RM2.52 billion were traded, with 517 gainers and 340 losers.

site_title: Seeking an edge, short-sellers turn to behavioural analysis
summary: Short-sellers are increasingly using behavioural analysis to challenge companies' accounting methods, as seen in Muddy Waters' recent attack on Noble Group. The firm hired a behavioural analysis firm, QVerity, to assess Noble's executives' communication during an earnings call, identifying potential deceptive behaviour. This unorthodox method is being adopted by activist short-sellers, who claim it helps uncover accounting irregularities. While some experts are sceptical about the value of this analysis, others argue it's a necessary step in innovative investment research, pushing traditional paradigms forward.

site_title: Keppel Q1 earnings climb despite revenue drop
summary: Keppel Corp's Q1 earnings rose 6.4% to S$360.2 million, despite a 6.1% drop in revenue to S$2.81 billion. The decline in revenue was attributed to lower contributions from its infrastructure arm. The offshore and marine division saw its operating margin slip to 12% from 14.2% the previous year. Despite this, the company secured new orders worth S$500 million and is focusing on developing niche, non-drilling vessels.

site_title: Japan's large firms to raise monthly wages at fastest pace in 17 years
summary: Japan's large firms agreed to raise monthly wages by 2.6% this year, the largest gain since 1998, in a positive sign for consumer spending. The move aims to shift the economy from deflation and meet the Bank of Japan's 2% inflation target. Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's government has been encouraging private firms to raise wages since 2012, but results have been disappointing. The wage increase is essential for Abe's campaign to boost growth.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares end 0.44% higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.44% to 27,739.71 on Thursday, following a rally in Shanghai as China's weakest quarterly growth in six years fuels expectations of further stimulus measures. The Shanghai Composite Index jumped 2.71% to its highest since March 2008. The rally in Hong Kong was driven by a similar sentiment in mainland China.

site_title: Women's presence on Singapore boards edges up to 8.8% in 2014: report
summary: Singapore's female representation on listed company boards increased to 8.8% in 2014, with 448 directorships held by women, according to a report by the Diversity Action Committee. This represents a 10% rise from 2013, with most gains coming from independent directors. However, the national participation rate lags behind major markets such as Norway, the UK, and the US. Despite this, the finding is seen as encouraging, with the CEO of the Singapore Exchange saying it supports better governance and business performance with a more gender-diverse board.

site_title: China: Stocks hit fresh 7-year high despite unease over margin trading
summary: China's stocks reached a 7-year high, rising 3.0% and 2.7% in the CSI300 and Shanghai Composite Index, respectively. Despite concerns over margin trading risks, the market brushed off warnings from regulators to be "rational and calm". China's top securities regulator urged investors to be responsible for their decisions, cautioning against volatility. The surge in trading turnover is attributed to retail investors borrowing heavily to buy stocks, pushing the market up 30% this year.

site_title: European car sales shift up nearly 11% in March
summary: European car sales increased by 10.6% in March, their strongest gain in a year, reaching 1,604,107 units. This marks the 19th consecutive month of increasing vehicle registrations in Europe, with sales rising 8.6% in the first quarter of 2015. The strongest gains were seen in Spain (40.5% increase) and Italy (15.1% increase), with Volkswagen maintaining its market share lead in Europe.

site_title: ECB's commitment to QE squeezes German yields to near zero
summary: German 10-year yields fell to near zero after the European Central Bank reaffirmed its commitment to quantitative easing, a trillion euro asset purchase program. French yields also hit record lows, while other top-rated eurozone government bonds reached all-time troughs. Despite a large bond auction in France, analysts expect low net issuance in April due to central bank buying and redemptions. France is expected to join Germany, Austria, and the Netherlands in selling five-year bonds at negative yields, allowing countries to profit by borrowing.

site_title: Ringgit gains most since 2013 as Fed bets pared on factory data
summary: Malaysia's ringgit surged 1.4% to 3.6537 against the US dollar, its largest gain since September 2013, after disappointing US data led traders to pare rate-increase bets. The Empire Manufacturing Index's contraction in April reduced expectations for Federal Reserve monetary policy tightening. Brent crude prices rose for a sixth day, alleviating concerns over government finances in a net oil-exporting nation. Investors cut wagers on future rate hikes, with Citigroup targeting a 1,150 for MSCI's global equity index by mid-2026.

site_title: South Korean won hits 1-week high; shares rise for 5th straight day
summary: The South Korean won reached a one-week high against the dollar, closing at 1,088.9 won per dollar, after the dollar weakened following disappointing US output data. This marked the fifth consecutive day of gains for the won. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) rose 0.9% to its highest close since August 1, 2011.

site_title: Italy Feb global trade surplus rises vs year ago
summary: Italy posted a global trade surplus of 3.538 billion euros in February, up from 2.651 billion euros in the same month of 2014. Imports rose 1.0% year-on-year, while exports increased 3.7%. The trade surplus with the European Union was 691 million euros, down from 1.313 billion euros in 2014. Net of energy products, Italy's global trade surplus would have been 9.255 billion euros.

site_title: China's fiscal revenue growth slows in Q1
summary: China's fiscal revenue growth slowed to 3.9% in the first quarter, down from 8.6% in 2014, with total revenues reaching 3.64 trillion yuan. The slowdown was attributed to a decline in business tax receipts from the real estate sector and a drop in government revenue from selling state land. Meanwhile, fiscal expenditure rose 7.8% to 3.28 trillion yuan, lagging the average rise of 8.2% in 2014. The government has set a wider budget deficit for 2015 to support the slowing economy, which experienced its lowest growth rate in six years.

site_title: Japan's Sharp, banks near US$1.7b bailout deal: source
summary: Japan's Sharp Corp and its main banks, Mizuho Bank and Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi UFJ, are nearing a $1.7 billion rescue and restructuring plan, including a debt-for-equity swap and a promise to split off its loss-making smartphone display business. The company will scale back its North American TV operations and cut around 5,000 jobs, or 10% of its global workforce. Analysts say the plan is insufficient to resolve Sharp's basic problems, and the company's future growth strategy remains unclear.

images.alt_text: Japan's Sharp Corp and its main banks are set to agree on Thursday to a US$1.7 billion rescue and restructuring plan that will likely include a promise to split off its ailing smartphone display business, a person involved in the discussions said.

site_title: Singapore: Blue chips weaken but pennies remain the focus
summary: The Straits Times Index in Singapore fell 8.34 points to 3,531.61, after a 4-session rise of 80 points. Rotational punting of penny stocks continued, with new names entering the active list, driven by proprietary traders and retail clients seeking to capitalize on improved sentiment from Hong Kong's surge. Turnover reached S$1.5 billion, with 266 rises and 203 falls.

site_title: A*Star inks partnerships to boost productivity and tech adoption in SMEs
summary: A*Star, a Singaporean research agency, partnered with Spring Singapore, SPC, and NTUC Health to boost productivity and tech adoption in SMEs. The collaborations aim to customize and deploy technologies to various industries, including food, hotel, and retail sectors. A*Star will provide technical expertise and licensing, while Spring will offer funding support. The initiatives focus on increasing productivity and improving care quality for nursing home residents, with the goal of encouraging more SMEs to adopt technologies.

site_title: Australia says additional search area for MH370 may take up to a year to scour
summary: Australian government ministers have agreed to extend the search for missing Malaysia Airlines Flight MH370 by an additional 60,000 sq miles if the wreckage is not found in the current search area. The extended search, which could take up to a year, will cover a new area off Australia's west coast. This decision comes as the current search effort has yielded no signs of the plane, which disappeared in 2014. The extension will involve cooperation between Australian, Chinese, and Malaysian authorities in the search for the missing jet.

images.alt_text: Government ministers from Australia, China and Malaysia on Thursday said that they would extend the search for missing Malaysia Airlines Flight MH370 by an additional 60,000 sq miles if the wreckage is not found in the current search area.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei index closes flat
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei index closed flat on Thursday, ending at 19,885.77, after early losses were offset by late buying. The index reached 15-year highs last week but has since come off the mark. The broader Topix index also rose, up 0.67% to 1,599.42. The market's performance was influenced by concerns over US-EU trade tensions and tariffs.

site_title: Europe: Stocks slip at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets opened lower on Thursday, with London's FTSE 100 index down 0.16% to 7,085.08 points, Paris' CAC 40 losing 0.14% to 5,246.75 points, and Frankfurt's DAX 30 shedding 0.09% to 12,224.76 points. The declines were attributed to bank and healthcare stocks, with investors focusing on US-EU trade tensions. The losses followed a record peak the previous day.

site_title: Temasek's Ho Ching says she's 'well' following sabbatical announcement
summary: Temasek Holdings CEO Ho Ching, 62, announced a three-month sabbatical leave, citing a need to catch up on sleep and attend to personal matters. Despite her sabbatical, Ho will continue to oversee her board and specific stewardship duties. The move comes after a busy period, including her husband's recent surgery and the passing of Singapore's former Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew. Analysts say the timing is suitable for Ho to take a break, given the stable global market conditions and lack of major market upsetting events until May or June.

site_title: Asia FX sentiment improves further, bearish Sing dollar bets lowest in 6 months
summary: Asia's emerging currencies have seen improved sentiment over the past two weeks, with bearish bets on the Singapore dollar at its lowest in nearly six months. The Singapore central bank's decision to hold off further monetary easing and expectations of a delayed US interest rate hike have contributed to the improvement. Bullish bets on the Chinese yuan and Thai baht have also risen, while bearish bets on the Indonesian rupiah have fallen to a near five-month low. This sentiment shift is attributed to weak US economic data and expectations of a delayed interest rate hike.

site_title: Bernanke to advise hedge fund Citadel: NYT
summary: Former US Federal Reserve Chairman Ben Bernanke has agreed to become a senior adviser to hedge fund Citadel Investment Group, founded by billionaire Kenneth Griffin. Bernanke will advise on global economic and financial issues and meet investors. He chose Citadel due to its lack of Federal Reserve regulation, allowing him to avoid lobbying. Bernanke's role is non-exclusive, and he will receive an annual fee but not own a stake or receive a bonus based on performance.

site_title: China exporters expect more pain as economy sputters: survey
summary: China exporters expect a trade slowdown to last at least six months, with 24% citing continued decline and 33% expecting more than a year. Production costs are expected to rise 6.5% in 2015, while orders are forecast to increase just 3.1%. European buyers are pushing for discounts due to a weaker euro, and some Chinese manufacturers have agreed to slash prices by 8-10%. The survey, conducted at the Canton Fair, reflects China's economic struggles with a strengthening currency and rising labor costs, threatening the country's dominance as the world's largest exporter.

site_title: Thai economy to grow about 3% y/y in Q1: planning agency
summary: Thai economy is expected to grow around 3.0% in Q1, driven by lower energy prices and strong tourism. Exports are forecast to grow 3.5% this year, with the National Economic and Social Development Board maintaining a full-year GDP growth forecast of 3.5-4.5%. The government has asked the Bank of Thailand to monitor the baht to prevent it from becoming too strong.

site_title: China trade ministry says foreign investment not leaving country
summary: China's trade ministry stated that foreign investment is not leaving the country, despite the country's economic slowdown. Inbound foreign direct investment rose 11.3% to $34.88 billion in the first quarter, while outbound flows increased 29.6% to $25.79 billion. Only a minority of firms are adjusting to China's "new normal" for economic growth. This suggests that foreign investors remain optimistic about China's long-term prospects despite current economic challenges.

site_title: Australia: Shares rise 0.7% after 3 sessions of falls
summary: Australian shares rose 0.7% on Thursday, rebounding from three consecutive sessions of falls, driven by gains in financials, materials, and energy stocks. The S&P/ASX 200 index rose 39.08 points to 5,947.5, despite better-than-expected local jobs data, which reduced the likelihood of a rate cut in May. The index remains within a whisker of the 6,000-point psychological level, having fallen in three of the last five weeks.

site_title: 41% spike in May-July COE quota
summary: The Singapore government has announced a 41.1% increase in the May-July 2015 certificates of entitlement (COE) quota, with a total of 19,912 COEs to be issued. This includes a 44.6% rise in Category A small car COEs, a 28.5% increase in Category B cars, and a 54.4% jump in Category E open category COEs. Category C goods vehicles and buses will see the largest percentage increase of 99.5%, while Category D motorcycles will see a 14.6% rise. The increased COE quota aims to manage demand.

site_title: Qian Hu's Q1 profit down 2.6% to S$112,000
summary: Qian Hu Corporation, an integrated ornamental fish service provider, reported a net profit of S$112,000 for the first quarter of FY2015, down 2.6% from the previous year. Revenue increased 0.3% to S$20.8 million. The company's executive chairman and managing director, Kenny Yap, attributed the growth to steady core business expansion and innovation in filtration, fish nutrition, and genetic breeding of unique Dragon Fish.

site_title: Free, open Internet essential, US commerce secretary tells China
summary: US Commerce Secretary Penny Pritzker emphasized the importance of a free and open Internet in China, urging officials to create an environment that enables entrepreneurship rather than hinders it. Despite efforts to support start-ups, the Chinese government has faced criticism for inadequate intellectual property protection, limited access to capital, and internet censorship. Pritzker's comments came as part of a three-city trade mission focused on green industries, aiming to boost US-China business links despite ongoing issues.

site_title: South Korean president says sunken Sewol ferry will be raised
summary: South Korean President Park Geun-Hye has promised to raise the sunken Sewol ferry at the earliest possible date, following a key demand from the victims' relatives. The ferry sank on April 16, 2014, claiming 304 lives. Park made the announcement during a visit to the southern island of Jindo to mark the first anniversary of the disaster. The decision comes after months of pressure from families of the victims.

site_title: China Premier says China can't devalue yuan to aid exports
summary: Chinese Premier Li Keqiang stated that China cannot devalue its yuan to aid exports, contradicting the country's economic struggles. Despite a 7% annual growth rate in the first quarter, China's economy faces challenges, including a six-year low in growth. Li emphasized that China is not in deflation, unlike some global economies, and that devaluation is not a viable solution to boost exports. His comments come as China's economy faces pressure from policymakers and declining global commodity prices.

site_title: Australia's jobless rate falls to 6.1%
summary: Australia's unemployment rate has dropped to 6.1% in March, beating expectations of a 6.3% rate, according to data from the Australian Bureau of Statistics. This decrease is attributed to 37,664 new job positions created, with full-time roles increasing by 31,516 and part-time jobs rising by 6,148. The participation rate also strengthened to 64.8%. This better-than-expected reading may ease pressure on the central bank to further cut interest rates, providing a positive economic outlook for the country.

site_title: Your new coffee habit is way too efficient for a reeling market
summary: Single-serve coffee brewing machines popularized by Keurig Green Mountain have disrupted the US coffee market. Over 25% of Americans use these machines, leading to a shift away from traditional drip-brewing pots. The increased efficiency of single-serve machines has slowed demand growth for the US coffee market, valued at $52 billion. This has hurt sales, particularly as commodity prices have fallen. The shift towards single-serve machines is having a significant impact on the industry, altering the way coffee is consumed and potentially changing the market landscape.

site_title: Sembcorp Industries completes sale of unit for £104.5 million in cash
summary: Sembcorp Industries completed the sale of Sembcorp Bournemouth Water Investment to Pennon Group for £104.5 million, yielding a net gain of £25 million for the group. The sale was made through its UK subsidiary and will be accounted for in the financial year ending Dec 31, 2015.

images.alt_text: SEMBCORP Industries on Thursday said it has completed the sale of all of Sembcorp Bournemouth Water Investment that translated into cash proceeds of £104.5 million (S$214 million).

site_title: Hong Kong stocks dip 0.22% at open
summary: Hong Kong's stock market dipped 0.22% at open on Thursday, ending a nine-session winning streak that saw a 15% gain. The Hang Seng Index fell 61.53 points to 27,557.29. Mainland China's benchmark Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also fell, down 1.28% and 1.97% respectively.

site_title: Hot stock: SGX retreats, after refuting talk of trading link with China
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) retreated 16 cents, or 2%, to S$8.43 after refuting rumors of a potential trading link with China. The SGX clarified it is not in talks to establish a stock trading link similar to the Shanghai-Hong Kong Stock Connect, which has boosted Hong Kong's trading volumes. The exchange remains open to future collaborations.

site_title: Philippines' Bloomberry says plans US$1b casino deal in South Korea
summary: Bloomberry Resorts Corp plans to invest over $1 billion in an integrated casino complex in South Korea, in talks with a potential Korean partner. The gaming firm signed deals to buy an island and a casino operator last month, starting its overseas expansion program. This is part of Bloomberry's efforts to diversify its business beyond its US$1.2 billion integrated casino-resort Solaire in Manila.

images.alt_text: Bloomberry Resorts Corp plans to invest more than US$1 billion in an integrated casino complex in South Korea and is in talks with a potential Korean partner for the project, company chairman Enrique Razon said on Thursday.

site_title: PBOC easing seen by economists to cushion growth slowdown
summary: China's central bank is expected to ease monetary policies to support the economy, which expanded at its weakest pace since 2009 in the last quarter. The government will inject more cash into banks, cut interest rates, and reduce reserve requirements to stimulate growth. Policymakers have "room to act" to address deflation risks and prevent labor market instability, with economists forecasting further stimulus and targeted easing in the coming months.

site_title: Oil rises to 2015 high as data signals end of US supply surge
summary: Oil prices surged to a 2015 high as data showed a slowdown in the US shale boom, signaling an end to the largest supply glut since 1930. Crude supplies increased last week, but at a slower pace than expected, with output from shale formations like North Dakota's Bakken set to fall in May. West Texas Intermediate rose 5.8% to $56.39 a barrel, while Brent crude gained 3.2% to $60.32 a barrel. Refineries have boosted operations, processing a record amount of crude, and economists predict production will stabilize and decline faster than expected.

site_title: TPG, Fosun in the lead to acquire Cirque du Soleil: sources
summary: A consortium of TPG Capital and Fosun International is in final negotiations to acquire Cirque du Soleil, prevailing over a rival consortium led by CVC Capital Partners and Providence Equity. The deal, valued near $1.5 billion, would see Guy Laliberté retain a 10% stake and continue to play a significant role in the company. Cirque du Soleil, known for its acrobatic spectacles, has been exploring a strategic partner since last year. The acquisition is expected to help Cirque du Soleil expand in Asia through TPG's partnership with Fosun.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 1.99 points to 1842.12. A total of 239.7 million lots were traded, valued at RM106 million, with 221 gainers and 67 losers.

site_title: UBS said to begin review of Australia wealth-management business
summary: UBS is conducting a review of its Australian wealth-management business, which may lead to a potential sale. The review focuses on management structure and technology platform. This comes after UBS's global wealth-management division posted lower-than-expected earnings in the fourth quarter, amid pressure from negative interest rates. The review was sparked by CEO Sergio Ermotti's reorganization of Switzerland's largest bank to focus on high-end wealth management, a business facing significant challenges. The outcome of the review remains uncertain, with a sale being a possible outcome.

site_title: Hot stock: Sembcorp Industries gains on China expansion, completed divestment
summary: Sembcorp Industries' shares rose 1.9% to S$4.81 after the company announced the expansion of its renewable energy business in China through a 150-megawatt wind farm in Huanghua, Hebei Province. The company also completed the sale of its S$214 million stake in Sembcorp Bournemouth Water Investment, generating £104.5 million in cash proceeds.

site_title: Hot stock: SMRT surges 3% on bid to diversify into telco business
summary: SMRT Corporation's stock surged 3.37% to S$1.685 after the train operator expressed interest in expanding into the telecommunications business. SMRT may invest up to S$34.5 million in OMGTEL, which is bidding for a telco licence in Singapore. The company has entered into an agreement with OMGTEL to work exclusively on the bid. This move is seen as a bid to diversify SMRT's business and capitalize on the growing demand for telecommunications services in Singapore.

site_title: Broker's take: Singapore banks to post fatter margins for Q1
summary: Singapore banks are expected to post stronger margins in Q1 due to rising benchmark rates. Maybank Kim Eng predicts DBS will be the top pick, despite potential flat margins, while OCBC and UOB will report results on April 30. The brokerage notes benign asset quality and good liquidity, with only sporadic weakness expected. Rising interest rates and increased buffers for provisions in the fourth quarter are seen as mitigating factors. Overall, the report suggests a positive outlook for Singapore banks' Q1 results.

site_title: Gold extends advance as data signal Fed may delay rate increase
summary: Gold prices rebounded as US data showed uneven economic expansion, sparking speculation the Federal Reserve may delay interest rate hikes. Gold rose 0.4% to $1,207.70 an ounce, rebounding from a two-week low. The data, including industrial output and manufacturing indexes, suggested the Fed may push back the timing of raising interest rates for the first time since 2006, boosting gold's appeal.

site_title: Consumers urged to give feedback on financial advisers amid new assessment rules
summary: Consumers in Singapore are being urged to provide feedback on their financial advisers as part of a new assessment requirement. The Association of Banks, Life Insurance Association, and Association of Financial Advisers are implementing a new Balanced Scorecard framework to ensure financial advisers' pay is tied to performance indicators beyond sales. The move aims to improve disclosure of material information to clients and prevent variable income tied to unsuitable product recommendations. Consumers are expected to provide feedback on their recent purchases of investment or insurance products to help firms assess their performance.

site_title: Fed not fiddling with rate now, aims for mid-range later
summary: The Federal Reserve is not adjusting its key policy rate, but aims to lift it to the middle of the range after initial tightening, according to the New York Fed's market operations head, Simon Potter. The current fed funds rate is between 0% and 0.25%. Potter stated that when the Fed raises the target range, it should fall around the middle of that range, indicating a mid-range target for future rate hikes.

site_title: STI up 7.31 points at opening, extending this week's gains
summary: Singapore shares rose 7.31 points to 3,547.26 at opening, extending gains this week. The Straits Times Index reached multi-year highs earlier in the week. Banks and Sembcorp Industries were among the stocks in early morning trade. The sale of Sembcorp Bournemouth Water Investment generated £104.5 million in cash proceeds. Gainers outnumbered losers 154 to 45, with 173.9 million shares changing hands.

site_title: Iron ore industry, apart from Big 3, faces existential challenge: Goldman
summary: Goldman Sachs has cut its iron ore price forecasts through 2018, citing a peak in seaborne demand next year. The bank now estimates iron ore will average $52 a metric ton this year, down 18% from previous forecasts, and $44 next year. The industry faces an existential challenge, with the world's three biggest producers expanding while up to half of the rest may close. Seaborne demand is expected to peak in 2016, with Chinese steel consumption contracting until it reaches a sustainable rate. This could lead to reduced production volumes in the industry.

site_title: Singapore property gloom has silver lining for stock investors
summary: Singapore's property market is experiencing a downturn, with home sales at a six-year low due to government curbs on property prices. However, investors are taking advantage of the situation by eyeing developers that may be taken private by their parents to avoid penalties. Several developers, including Wing Tai, Ho Bee Land, and Wheelock Properties, are trading at undervalued prices, making privatization a potential opportunity. Analysts believe that the controlling shareholders of these companies may opt to take them private to avoid penalties and capitalize on future upside.

site_title: Japan tops China as biggest foreign holder of US bonds
summary: Japan surpassed China as the largest foreign holder of US bonds in February, with $1,224.4 billion in US government debt. China, excluding Hong Kong, held $1,223.7 billion. The US federal deficit fell to $483 billion in 2014, its lowest level in six years. Net foreign sales of long-term securities in February were $10.6 billion, significantly lower than $67.3 billion in January. The decline in US capital flows and reduced government borrowing indicate a shift in global economic dynamics.

site_title: Hot Stock: Vallianz, Ezra gain on contracts talks, deals
summary: Ezra Holdings and Vallianz Holdings saw gains on Thursday following news of new contracts. Ezra won US$55 million in new contracts through its subsea services division, with its stock rising 1.5 Singapore cents to 49 Singapore cents. Vallianz is in talks to secure more than US$100 million in contracts from its main customer, causing its shares to rise 0.3 Singapore cents to 7.8 Singapore cents before halting trading.

site_title: US fast-food workers plan rallies
summary: US fast-food workers are holding rallies in 230 cities on April 15, 2015, demanding higher pay ($15) and union rights. The "Fight for $15" campaign, backed by the Service Employees International Union, aims to pressure McDonald's and other chains to meet the demands. McDonald's had previously announced a wage hike for company-owned stores, but critics say the move was a public-relations stunt. The rallies mark the largest action yet for the movement, which began in 2012.

site_title: Ernst & Young settles NY lawsuit for $10m over Lehman auditing
summary: Ernst & Young has agreed to pay $10 million to settle a New York lawsuit alleging the accounting firm helped Lehman Brothers deceive investors before its 2008 collapse. The firm had previously earned $99 million from Lehman between 2001 and 2008, with nearly all of the $10 million settlement going to investors in Lehman securities. The settlement resolves a lawsuit claiming massive accounting fraud facilitated by Ernst & Young's auditing, with the New York Attorney General stating that such actions harm investors, the economy, and the country.

site_title: EU accuses Google of hurting consumers, competitors in Web search case
summary: The European Union has accused Google of distorting web search results to favor its own shopping service, potentially hurting consumers and competitors. The EU's Competition Commissioner, Margrethe Vestager, has sent a Statement of Objections to Google, giving the company 10 weeks to respond. This five-year investigation could lead to changes in the rules for business online and may also prompt an investigation into Google's Android mobile operating system, a key component of its online advertising strategy.

site_title: Airbus plans exceptional 10% buyback, new legal status
summary: Airbus Group plans to approve an exceptional 10% share buyback at its annual meeting on May 27, allowing the company to distribute divestment proceeds. This move will be in addition to an existing 10% share repurchase program, primarily linked to employee share schemes. The company also aims to adopt "European Company" status, renaming itself Airbus Group SE and maintaining its presence in Paris, Frankfurt, and Spain, reflecting its diversified operational presence across European countries.

site_title: China charge into HK stocks both boon and bane
summary: China's surge in investments in Hong Kong's stock market has boosted the city's economy and currency, but also poses new risks. Since November, Chinese investors have poured in $68 billion, mainly through the Shanghai-Hong Kong stock connect programme, driving up the market's capitalization to $28.6 trillion. However, analysts warn that this influx of cash could lead to a bubble, high property prices, and inflation, with sudden capital outflows potentially destabilizing the Hong Kong dollar peg.

images.alt_text: Surging investment from mainland China has jolted Hong Kong's stock market from the doldrums, but the volatility of such flows, driven by an unfamiliar breed of investor, presents new risks to the stability of the city's economy and currency.

site_title: Ramba Energy in arbitration over Indonesian project with former JV partner
summary: Ramba Energy has initiated arbitration proceedings in Singapore against its former joint venture partner Super Power Enterprises Group (SPE) over a disputed project in Lemang, Indonesia. SPE claims the Indonesian government's forfeiture of its 49% participating interest in the contract was unlawful, seeking damages and a determination that the forfeiture was unlawful. Ramba's unit, PT Hexindo Gemilang Jaya, holds an 80.4% stake in the project and will vigorously defend its rights against SPE's claims. The arbitration follows the signing of a new joint operating agreement in 2011, which transferred rights and liabilities to Eastwin Global Investments.

site_title: Ezra wins US$55 million in contracts
summary: EZRA Holdings has won US$55 million in new contracts through its subsea services division, providing project support, inspection, maintenance, and repair services to the oil-and-gas industry. Work has begun for several projects, with others slated for offshore execution from the third quarter of this year. The scope of work includes pipeline removal, buoy installation, and pre-FEED study. No details on the number of contracts awarded were disclosed.

site_title: Aussie April consumer sentiment slips: survey
summary: Australian consumer sentiment fell 3.2% in April, according to a survey of 1,200 people by the Melbourne Institute and Westpac Bank. The index reading of 96.2 was 3.5% lower than in April last year, amid concerns over the economic outlook ahead of the budget announcement. Despite this, respondents felt it was a good time to buy big-ticket household items, with the index climbing 5.9%. Westpac's chief economist Bill Evens warned that the consumer mood was fragile, predicting a second cut in interest rates by the Reserve Bank of Australia.

site_title: India and China: two radically different growth stories
summary: India's GDP growth is expected to outpace China's for the first time since 1999, with India's growth rate at 7.5% and China's at 6.8%, according to the IMF. However, the comparison between the two countries is misleading due to significant differences in their base GDPs and development stages. China needs to slow down its growth to address debt and investment issues, while India needs to grow faster to create jobs and improve living standards.

site_title: Philippine mall giant eyes China expansion
summary: SM Prime, a Philippine shopping mall giant, plans to invest $6.1 billion over the next two years, doubling its earnings from 2013. The company will allocate $449 million annually in China, focusing on the middle market, and aims to open at least four malls in the Philippines and a new mall in Tianjin, China this year. SM Prime, owned by the Philippines' richest man, posted a 13% increase in net profit in 2014, with a total of 69,000 condominium units built in the Philippines.

site_title: China FDI up 2.2% in March to US$12.4, outbound investment also rises
summary: China drew $12.4 billion in foreign direct investment (FDI) in March, up 2.2% from the same period last year, according to the Commerce Ministry. This marks an 11.3% rise in FDI for the first quarter, with outbound non-financial investment also increasing 0.4% to $8.39 billion. The data follows a disappointing series of economic readings, including a slump in exports and weaker-than-expected investment and industrial output.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SGX, Ezra, Vallianz, Sembcorp Industries, Keppel Land
summary: SGX and Ezra Holdings are stocks to watch on Thursday. SGX denied establishing a stock trading link with China, following a query from the Monetary Authority of Singapore. Ezra Holdings won $55 million worth of new contracts through its subsea services division. The article also mentions other stocks, including Vallianz, Sembcorp Industries, Keppel Land, and PSC, but does not provide detailed information about them.

site_title: S'pore ready for Sea Games: President Tan
summary: Singapore is ready to host the South East Asian (Sea) Games, which begin on June 5, with President Tony Tan expressing confidence in the country's preparations. The Sea Games will be held at the S$1.3-billion Sports Hub, which will stage 10 sports and the opening and closing ceremonies. The President has called on Singaporeans to rally behind Team Singapore, and the event has attracted new sponsors, including Singapore Airlines and JK Technology, with a total sponsorship amount exceeding S$60 million.

site_title: IMF warns of rising risks as dollar hits emerging markets
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) warns of rising risks to the global financial system due to a strong US dollar and weak commodity prices affecting emerging markets. The IMF states that rapid dollar appreciation, higher US interest rates, and geopolitical risks could pressure emerging-market currencies and asset markets. Foreign investors may reduce holdings of local-currency debt, creating debt rollover challenges and adding to turbulence. This could have significant implications for countries and firms that export commodities, potentially slowing the global recovery. The IMF urges caution and monitoring of these risks.

site_title: EU charges Google with market abuse, says it intends to probe Android
summary: The European Union has formally charged Google with abusing its dominant position as Europe's top search engine, potentially leading to a fine of over $6 billion. The EU also plans to investigate Google's Android operating system, which dominates the global mobile phone market, for anti-competitive behavior. The investigation aims to ensure companies operating in Europe don't artificially limit consumer choice or stifle innovation, according to EU Competition Commissioner Margrethe Vestager.

site_title: Fed may have to ramp up reverse repos to raise rates: EVP Potter
summary: The Federal Reserve may need to increase its use of reverse repos to raise interest rates when the time comes, as excess reserves in the banking system could make it harder to control the benchmark federal funds rate. The Fed is testing an overnight reverse repo facility, which involves borrowing cash from money-market mutual funds and returning it with interest, to put a floor under interest rates. Officials expect to begin raising rates later this year, but there are concerns that the current cap of $300 billion may not be sufficient to prevent rates from falling.

site_title: Small iron ore producers refuse to yield
summary: Australian small iron ore producers are resisting a market squeeze by big players, boosting output amid a price decline. Despite big producers like BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto flooding the market, smaller producers like Arrium Ltd are restarting mines and increasing shipments, aided by lower costs and state royalty relief. This has slowed the expected displacement of high-cost miners, according to a senior economist. As a result, iron ore prices have fallen to their lowest since 2005, with prices expected to remain downward pressured into 2016.

site_title: Saudi-backed group to control former Canadian Wheat Board
summary: A Saudi-backed company, Bunge and Saudi Agricultural & Livestock Investment Company (SALIC), agreed to buy a 50.1% stake in the former Canadian Wheat Board for C$250 million. The deal gives them access to Canadian grain exports. SALIC was established to secure Saudi Arabia's food supplies, and the transaction aligns with their vision, according to the CEO of the Bunge-SALIC joint venture, G3 Global Grain Group. The transaction is expected to close in July.

site_title: Forum Partners plans new fund to target China property
summary: Forum Partners, a global property investment firm, plans a new pan-Asian fund to target China's real estate market, which is expected to recover in the second half of 2015. The fund will take advantage of a trough in the market, with home prices in first-tier cities like Beijing and Shanghai expected to gain later this year. Forum has invested $130 million in China and manages about $4 billion of assets globally, with onshore funding costs for developers starting to drop. The firm's managing director expects 2015 to be a good year for the fund but notes that financing costs may decrease in 2016.

site_title: China's demand lag unsettles copper industry as Goldman sees rout
summary: China's copper demand has slowed, with Goldman Sachs predicting a US$5,200 per tonne price by the end of the year, down from its current price below US$6,000. The slowdown, attributed to China's shift towards a consumer-driven economy and measures to curb corruption and environmental damage, may lead to lower prices. Copper demand in China has peaked, with some analysts expecting a 10-12% growth rate to be "extremely unhealthy" for the market. The country's influence on global industrial metals is diminishing, with its market share declining.

site_title: Airline pain is fliers' gain as Brazilian slump weighs on fares
summary: Brazil's economic slump has led to a surge in airfare discounts, with travelers finding bargains on routes like Sao Paolo to Rio de Janeiro. The country's three biggest airlines - Azul, Gol, and Tam - are maintaining their fleets and offering discounts to keep planes full, despite facing losses. This approach threatens to extend losses at airlines with failed turnaround strategies, but executives are willing to take the risk to maintain market share and flying rights.

site_title: Why add tonnage in these bad times?
summary: The maritime industry is facing significant challenges, including waning confidence, falling oil prices, and geopolitical tension, amid uncertain global growth prospects. Shipowners expect a 2.3% growth in turnover this year, down from 6% last year, with offshore shipowners anticipating a 4.2% drop. Industry leaders are calling for the industry to adapt to changing market conditions and manage costs to ensure its long-term future. Companies are focusing on scrapping or selling older assets and raising equity to stay afloat, but some owners are ordering new tonnage despite low freight rates, posing a risk to the industry's future.

site_title: Condo rents fall in March on higher volume, says SRX
summary: Condo rental prices in Singapore fell 0.4% in March, with city centre and fringe areas seeing the largest decreases. Rents in the suburbs rose 0.8%. Year-on-year, condo rents dropped 6.3%, while HDB rentals remained flat in March, with a 0.1% increase. Rental volume improved, with 3,948 condo units rented in March, a 37.1% increase from February. Consultants expect condo rents to fall 6-8% in 2015 due to a record number of new home completions.

site_title: Heeton again seeks buyer for iLiv@Grange
summary: Heeton Holdings is seeking a buyer for its iLiv@Grange project in Singapore, a 16-storey building with a curvaceous facade, for S$110-120 million, or S$1,879-2,050 per square foot. The project, which received Temporary Occupation Permit in 2013, comprises one to three-bedroom apartments and two penthouses. Heeton has until October 2015 to sell all units, and analysts believe its breakeven cost could be around S$2,000-2,200 psf.

site_title: Alibaba injects pharmacy business into HK-listed affiliate
summary: Alibaba Group Holding is investing $2.5 billion in its Hong Kong-listed affiliate Alibaba Health Information Technology through a deal to buy 100% of its online pharmacy operations. The move aims to consolidate Alibaba's healthcare enterprise and capitalize on China's growing online health market, expected to reach $219 billion. The deal, subject to shareholder approval, will increase Alibaba's effective equity ownership to 53% and make Alibaba Health a consolidated subsidiary.

images.alt_text: Chinese e-commerce firm Alibaba Group Holding is injecting its online pharmacy operations into a Hong Kong-listed affiliate in a US$2.5 billion deal to consolidate its healthcare enterprise and ride a boom in online health-related business.

site_title: Europe's currency manipulation
summary: The European Union's currency manipulation, primarily due to the eurozone's current-account surplus, poses a significant barrier to the benefits of the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP) and the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP). The eurozone's surplus is largely driven by the European Central Bank's monetary expansion, which devalues the euro for struggling economies like Greece, Spain, and Italy. This creates internal imbalances, as the euro remains too strong for the southern countries and too weak for Germany, exacerbating economic distress and populist movements.

site_title: SGX dismisses talk of Shanghai-HK type link in response to MAS query
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) has denied rumors of establishing a Shanghai-Hong Kong type stock trading link, responding to a Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) query. The SGX stock surged 2.7% to a five-year high following market speculation, prompting questions about why the regulator was not notified. The company stated it remains open to future collaborations that benefit partners and shareholders, and will notify the market of any material developments. The SGX will report its fiscal third-quarter results on April 22.

site_title: Revised Companies Act delayed until early next year
summary: The Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority (Acra) in Singapore has delayed the full implementation of the revised Companies Act until early next year, following delays in its online business filing portal. The amendments, which include provisions for small companies and dual-class share structures, will be implemented in two phases, with 40% taking effect on July 1, 2015, and the remaining phase in the first quarter of 2016. The delays are attributed to the ongoing revamp of the BizFile portal.

site_title: Global financial risks intensifying and rotating, says IMF
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has warned of intensifying and rotating global financial risks, citing China as a place where risks are becoming most heightened. Volatility in major exchange rates has reached its peak since the financial crisis, and the IMF has identified divergent growth and monetary policies as key factors. The organization has urged regulators to monitor financial system risks and implement measures to address shadow banking, corporate debt restructuring, and foreign currency exposures. The IMF also warned of rising fiscal risks in advanced and emerging economies, particularly in countries with high public debt levels.

site_title: New ways to pay
summary: Innovations in payment methods are reshaping the way merchants and customers handle money, with options like PayPal, Apple Pay, and digital wallets emerging. The digitized world is moving away from cash and credit cards, with consumers potentially doing away with traditional payment methods.

site_title: China tourists continue to stay away from Malaysia
summary: China tourists continue to decline in Malaysia, with double-digit drops in arrivals over the past three months. This decline comes a year after the disappearance of Flight MH370, which had a significant impact on the country's tourism industry. The Chinese government's wariness of visiting Malaysia has led to a significant drop in arrivals, with the country's main airport operator reporting a decline in the China sector. The decline is expected to continue, with bilateral ties between Malaysia and China remaining strong despite the economic impact on the tourism industry.

site_title: WTO rules against US dolphin-safe labels
summary: The World Trade Organization (WTO) ruled against the US, siding with Mexico in a long-running dispute over dolphin-safe labels for canned tuna. The US rules, which disqualify Mexican tuna from bearing dolphin-safe labels, were found to be discriminatory and inconsistent with international trade laws. The WTO panel recommended that the US bring its measure into conformity with its obligations, potentially leading to retaliation against US exports. The decision could impact the US$680 million US market for imported canned tuna from Mexico.

site_title: How China manages its slowdown bears close watching
summary: China's economy grew at 7% in the first quarter, its slowest pace in six years, as the real estate and manufacturing sectors slowed. This growth rate was in line with economists' expectations and the 2015 target of "around 7%". The Chinese authorities face challenges in balancing monetary policy easing with concerns about debt levels and long-term economic reforms. Recent policy moves, including interest rate cuts and infrastructure spending, have not produced the desired impact, and the slowdown may lead to a sharper-than-expected downturn.

site_title: ST Index creeps up to 7-year high
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) reached a 7-year high, gaining 0.5% to 3,539.95 points, despite weak economic news from China. The index's performance was driven by local banks and Jardine stocks, but overall blue-chip turnover was low, making up less than 10% of total volume. The STI's gain was also overshadowed by a 17.8% drop in Sino Construction and a slide in SGX shares.

site_title: OECD to Tokyo: Get on with structural reforms
summary: The Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) has criticized Japan's progress on structural reforms, urging Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's government to speed up implementation of the "third arrow" of its policy package. The OECD forecasts Japan's economy will grow by 1% this year and 1.4% in 2016, but emphasizes the need for fundamental reforms to promote long-term fiscal sustainability and close the gap in living standards with leading OECD countries. The report highlights issues such as high government debt, limited labor market flexibility, and low productivity growth.

images.alt_text: OECD secretary-general Angel Gurría also urged the Abe administration to reduce the growing government debt.

site_title: Jones the Grocer's Singapore stores up for sale
summary: Jones the Grocer's Singapore stores are up for sale after the company was placed under judicial management. The move comes three months after the gourmet grocer assured that it was business as usual. Assets up for sale include two outlets, payroll, kitchen, and retail inventory, with bids closing on May 22. The decision to sell is attributed to board differences, with former CEO John Manos citing poorly managed operating expenses and overly aggressive growth plans as contributing factors. The sale may impact the brand's franchise value, but experts believe the Jones name still carries significant brand value.

site_title: Developers' March private home sales highest in five months
summary: Singapore developers sold a record 613 private homes in March 2015, a 57% increase from the previous month, driven by recent launches and strong demand. The sales figure marks a 28% year-on-year improvement and is the best result since October 2014. Analysts attribute the surge to attractive pricing and project draw, but warn that the momentum may be short-lived if pricing and project quality decline. The sales performance is expected to continue in April, with several new projects launching in the secondary market.

site_title: Vallianz in talks for more deals
summary: Vallianz Holdings, an offshore support vessel owner, is in talks to secure contracts worth over $100 million each from a Middle Eastern state oil company. The contracts are not disclosed, but the company believes they could be worth more than the initial estimate. This is part of Vallianz's efforts to secure more deals, with the company looking to capitalize on its main customer's needs. The exact outcome of these talks remains uncertain, but the potential contracts could significantly boost the company's revenue.

site_title: Nokia agrees to buy Alcatel-Lucent for 15.6b euros
summary: Nokia has agreed to buy Alcatel-Lucent for 15.6 billion euros in an all-stock deal, creating the world's largest supplier of equipment for mobile-phone networks. The deal will surpass Ericsson and Huawei in wireless-infrastructure revenue, according to IDC. Alcatel investors will receive 0.55 Nokia shares for each stock they own, valuing the deal at 4.12 euros per share.

site_title: 'Clear evidence' monetary policy is working: Draghi
summary: European Central Bank President Mario Draghi stated that monetary policy is effectively boosting inflation in the region, citing "clear evidence" of its success. The ECB's asset purchase programme is helping the economy recover, with gauges of activity and confidence pointing upwards. Draghi assured that the measures will continue until September 2016 or until a sustained adjustment in inflation is seen. The eurozone's economy has gained momentum since 2014, and inflation rates are expected to increase later this year.

site_title: The super-expensive SUV is here, and here to stay
summary: Rolls-Royce is developing a luxury SUV, "Project Cullinan", set to be sold by 2018 with a potential price tag of $400,000. The vehicle joins high-end SUVs like the Land Rover Range Rover SV Autobiography ($200,000) and Mercedes-Benz G65 AMG ($218,000), catering to ultra-high net worth individuals. Experts predict the trend will continue as luxury SUVs offer better profit margins and unique customization options, with many brands already planning similar models.

site_title: SICC targets productivity with launch of annual awards for SMEs
summary: The Singapore International Chamber of Commerce (SICC) has launched the "SICC Awards: Innovations in Productivity" to encourage mutually beneficial collaborations between large organisations and SMEs, aiming to boost productivity. The awards will have two categories: transformational collaboration and scalable collaboration, recognizing the most impactful and replicable partnerships. This initiative aims to foster a more productive and competitive business environment in Singapore.

site_title: World's most expensive bank still a strong buy
summary: HDFC Bank, India's largest lender by market value, remains a strong buy despite its high price-to-book ratio. The bank has reported annual profit growth of at least 20% since 1998, outpacing the world's 200 biggest lenders. Analysts predict further valuation growth, citing a 30-35% annual earnings growth rate over the next three years. HDFC's consistent profitability and limited exposure to heavily-indebted corporations make it an attractive option for foreign investors, who are willing to pay a record 20% premium to buy the bank's shares.

site_title: Stolen artifacts worth US$107m seized in New York
summary: Manhattan district attorney's office seized 2,622 artifacts worth $107.6 million from storage rooms linked to imprisoned art dealer Subhash Kapoor, accused of looting from India and the Near East. The items include bronze and stone statues of Hindu deities. Authorities aim to return the stolen objects to their countries of origin and prosecute Kapoor in the US. Kapoor, awaiting trial in India, denies wrongdoing, while three associates have cooperated with investigators. The case, Operation Hidden Idol, is being pursued with Indian officials across four continents.

site_title: Temasek CEO Ho Ching to take three-month sabbatical
summary: Temasek CEO Ho Ching will take a three-month sabbatical, starting immediately, with no relation to retirement plans. During her absence, President Lee Theng Kiat will cover her duties. Ho Ching, who has been CEO since 2004, plans to use the time to catch up on sleep and pursue personal interests. She will continue with her board duties and specific stewardship duties.

site_title: Scoot takes another spirited jab at US-based Spirit Airlines
summary: Scoot, a budget airline, has taken a lighthearted jab at US-based Spirit Airlines, pointing out similarities in branding, website, and advertisements. In a letter to Spirit's CEO Ben Baldanza, Scoot's chief Campbell Wilson noted that Spirit's recent branding and ads resemble Scoot's since 2012. The letter, accompanied by a cheeky video post, has garnered significant attention and views on Facebook. This is not the first time Scoot has taken a playful shot at Spirit, with the airline previously highlighting similarities in their marketing efforts.

site_title: China's Q1 property investment growth at lowest since 2009
summary: China's property investment growth in Q1 slowed to 8.5% as developers focused on clearing excess inventory, the lowest rate since 2009. This growth eased from 10.4% in the first two months of 2015, while property sales volume dropped 9.2% from the year-earlier period. The slowdown is expected to weigh on the economy, with economists predicting falling property investment will continue to impact GDP, which slowed to a six-year low of 7% in Q1.

images.alt_text: The Chinese government's easing monetary policies will be of limited help to property investment, says Nomura.

site_title: Stores of the future
summary: Stores of the future will combine digital and physical experiences, offering customers a seamless shopping experience on various devices and touch points. According to regional managing director Michele Ferrario of Zalora, this new approach will stimulate customers' senses, blurring the lines between physical and digital spaces. This shift is driven by the growing demand for e-commerce and the need for a more engaging shopping experience.

site_title: Iron ore crash puts pressure on Fortescue
summary: Fortescue Metals Group, Australia's fourth-largest iron ore miner, faces pressure due to a crash in the iron ore market. The company has a US$9 billion debt pile and must decide on a capital-raising option, including selling stakes in mines or infrastructure, or issuing new shares. A rights issue could be the quickest option, but it may dilute chairman Andrew Forrest's one-third stake. Fortescue updates its quarterly production and costs on Thursday, with investors watching to see if it is burning through its US$1.6 billion in cash.

site_title: KepLand posts 17.2% fall in Q1 profit
summary: Keppel Land reported a 17.2% year-on-year fall in Q1 profit to S$72.6 million, citing lower property sales and divestments of Equity Plaza and MBFC Tower 3. Revenue fell 2.3% to S$278.4 million, with earnings from overseas accounting for 36.8% of the group's net profit. The company remains focused on Asia, with Singapore and China as core markets, and is seeking opportunities in global cities with growth potential.

site_title: Digital transformation
summary: Retail banks face challenges from digital transformation, regulation, and changing customer expectations, risking survival if they fail to innovate. Technology, customer needs, and regulatory pressures are forcing banks to adapt and transform. Those that fail to innovate will be left behind, highlighting the need for banks to prioritize digital transformation and innovation to stay competitive.

site_title: Asiana plane smashes antenna in Japan runway accident
summary: An Asiana Airways plane crashed into a communications antenna while landing at Hiroshima airport in Japan on April 15, 2015, injuring 27 people. The Airbus A320, carrying 73 passengers and 8 crew, suffered significant damage but all on board evacuated safely. No fatalities were reported. The accident bears similarities to Asiana's 2013 fatal crash in San Francisco, and investigators are working to determine the cause of the incident.

site_title: A Labour-led government may be just what the UK needs
summary: A Labour-led government in the UK may be more stable than a Conservative-Liberal coalition, potentially preventing a referendum on British EU membership. Ed Miliband, leader of the opposition Labour Party, is defying expectations by trailing in the opinion polls despite the country's strong economic recovery. His focus on supporting poorer people may appeal to voters, while Prime Minister David Cameron's lack of a clear economic agenda has led to his party being stigmatised as the party of austerity. A Labour government could steer a more pro-European line, potentially stabilizing the UK's relationship with the EU.

site_title: Toyota plots comeback for Prius after ceding stardom to Tesla
summary: Toyota is revamping its Prius hybrid car, nearly seven years after its last major update, in an effort to regain its status as a leader in the green-car market. The new Prius will feature a lower center of gravity, improved ride and handling, and a more advanced fuel-economy system, thanks to Toyota's New Global Architecture (TNGA) design. The company aims to cut costs and improve the car's design, which has been criticized for being bland, with a goal of increasing sales and repositioning the Prius as a more mainstream model.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Soilbuild Reit reported Q1 2015 results with gross revenue up 10.5% and DPU 4.5% to 1.633 Singapore cents. Despite a 100% tenant retention rate, management expects this to decline due to macroeconomic headwinds. Analysts maintain buy ratings, with targets at S$0.93 for Soilbuild Reit and S$4.20 for Singapore Press Holdings. Keppel T&T's Q1 net profit was in line with expectations, with analysts tweaking earnings forecasts due to higher-than-expected data centre revenue.

site_title: SATS unveils e-Acceptance, training initiatives
summary: SATS Ltd is introducing an e-Acceptance initiative to digitise and speed up the process of lodging export cargo at Changi Airport, aiming to boost productivity and enhance its status as an air cargo hub. The company is also launching the SATS Coolport Academy, offering Iata-certified training in pharmaceutical handling, to develop the capabilities of the talent pool in Singapore and the region. The initiatives are part of SATS' strategy to capitalise on Asia's growing middle class and increase its competitiveness in the air cargo market.

site_title: Factory output edges higher in March
summary: US factory output edged higher in March, rising 0.1% after a 0.2% decline in February. The increase was driven by a rebound in car making, while other industries, such as utility and mining production, declined. A strong US dollar and cheap oil are hurting American manufacturing, but car sales remain a bright spot due to an improving job market and low interest rates. Total industrial production declined 0.6% in March, the largest drop since August 2012.

site_title: SMRT may invest in telco licence bidder OMGTEL
summary: SMRT Corporation may invest up to S$34.5 million in OMGTEL, a company bidding for Singapore's fourth wireless telecommunications carrier licence. The investment is contingent on OMG winning the licence, satisfactory due diligence, and execution of definitive agreements. OMGTEL was incorporated in October 2014 and has raised S$150 million from previous funding rounds. The move aims to work exclusively with OMGTEL on its telco licence bid.

site_title: Iran shaping up as a potential gas play
summary: Iran is poised to become a significant player in the global gas market, surpassing Russia as the largest holder of conventional gas reserves. Following a potential deal with six world powers, Iran plans to increase oil production and exports, potentially flooding the market with up to a million barrels. While this could lead to lower oil prices, it may not have a devastating impact if demand improves or OPEC abandons its market share strategy.

site_title: Beijing not walking its talk in South China Sea spats
summary: Beijing has failed to stop its reclamation of land in the South China Sea, despite US pressure. The US has accused China of using its size and muscle to bully smaller neighbors, and warned of "dangerous incidents" if the militarization continues. China has turned submerged reefs into artificial islands, capable of hosting military aircraft and vessels, sparking concerns among the Philippines and Vietnam. The US has called on Beijing to stop the reclamation, but China has shown no signs of backing down.

site_title: ECB says QE 'seems to be effective in supporting lending'
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) reported that its asset-buying program is effectively supporting lending in the euro area, with banks using the additional liquidity from asset sales to grant loans. The program, which aims to boost consumer prices and spur credit supply, has been expanding since last year. Despite some banks expecting profit declines due to tighter margins, the ECB believes the program is having a positive impact. The ECB's president, Mario Draghi, had predicted the plan would boost consumer prices and stimulate credit supply, with the goal of spending 60 billion euros a month until September 2016.

site_title: China Q1 GDP slows to 7 per cent, more easing expected
summary: China's economy grew 7% in the first quarter, the slowest quarterly growth in five years, putting pressure on Beijing to ease monetary policy further. This is in line with the government's forecast of annual GDP growth of 7%. The country faces challenges in its real estate sector, corporate debt levels, and inefficient industrial sector. Analysts expect more easing measures to be implemented to stimulate growth.

site_title: How did it all go wrong?
summary: Jones the Grocer, a Singapore-based food emporium, was sold to John Manos in 2005 after its founder, Lindsay Jones, left the business. Manos expanded the company to 18 stores across several territories, but growth targets were not met due to differing views between shareholders. Manos alleges that private equity company L Capital Asia's decision to appoint administrators was "oppressive conduct." Manos now holds a 37% stake and plans to focus on resolving issues before exploring future opportunities in the food and retail industry.

site_title: Protecting historic properties
summary: The National Trust for Historic Preservation has acquired the 1923 bungalow in Queens, New York, known as the Ferrigno House, for $849,000. The property comes with strict preservation easements, including restrictions on renovations, expansions, and additions, to ensure it remains true to its original character. The trust, which oversees properties like the Glass House and Mar-a-Lago, aims to conserve the home's vernacular architecture and prevent it from being replaced with a modern McMansion. The arrangement creates a windfall for the nonprofit and ensures the property's protection in perpetuity.

site_title: Alibaba pays the price for US IPO as Tencent stock soars on Shanghai-HK link
summary: Alibaba Group Holding Ltd missed out on a potential IPO in Hong Kong due to its desire for management control, resulting in the company missing billions of dollars from mainland Chinese investors. Meanwhile, Tencent Holdings Ltd surged 40% this year, adding $54 billion in market value, due to the exchange link with Shanghai enabling mainland Chinese to invest in the company. As a result, Tencent closed the gap in overall market value to Alibaba, which has seen its shares slump 18% in New York.

site_title: CNY gives shot in arm to February retail sales
summary: Singapore's retail sales rose 15.8% in February 2015, reaching S$3.4 billion, with food and beverages experiencing a 66.6% year-on-year increase. Department stores and supermarkets also saw significant gains, with 32.2% and 29% rises respectively. In contrast, petrol service stations and recreational goods reported declines, while sales of motor vehicles and minimarts fell 24.8% and 15.9% year on year. The strong sales performance was attributed to the Chinese New Year period, which fell in February this year.

site_title: Oil jumps after lower than expected US stock build
summary: Oil prices jumped over $1 after a lower-than-expected build of US crude oil stocks. Crude stocks rose 1.29 million barrels to 483.69 million barrels in the week to April 10, defying a forecast of a 4.1 million barrel rise. Front-month May Brent crude futures rose $1.35 to $59.78, while US crude futures gained $1.60 to $54.89. The US Energy Information Administration also reported a 15,000-barrel-per-day decline in North Dakota oil production in February.

site_title: India's tobacco giant tries short cigarettes as taxes hit demand
summary: India's tobacco giant ITC Ltd is cutting the size of its cigarette products to preserve margins as tax revenue from cigarettes declines. The company has shortened its discount Bristol brand cigarettes to 64 millimeters from 69 millimeters, lowering the tax without cutting the retail price. This move is in response to rising taxes, which have more than doubled in the past four years. As a result, smokers are favoring cheaper options such as chewing and leaf-wrapped tobacco.
