ITC's sales volume has slumped, and the company's stock has plummeted, the most in seven years, due to the proposed tax increase by Finance Minister Arun Jaitley.

site_title: BOE seen raising rates earlier if Labour-led govt wins
summary: The Bank of England may raise interest rates earlier than expected if a Labour-led government wins the UK election, according to economists at AXA Investment Managers and Blackrock Inc. Labour's fiscal austerity plans, which include spending cuts and tax increases, could lead to a quicker tightening of monetary policy and higher gilt yields. Economists forecast the BOE will keep rates unchanged until 2016, but a Labour-led government could prompt an earlier rate hike, potentially reducing the initial boost to GDP in the latter stages of the parliament.

site_title: Global fund managers worry but stay almost fully invested
summary: Global fund managers are almost fully invested despite being cautious about expensive bonds and equities, with cash reserves at 4.6%, historically above average. A survey by Bank of America Merrill Lynch found that 84% believe bond markets are overvalued, while 68% think the US stock market is overvalued. Despite this, 95% of assets remain in bonds and equities, with many predicting higher profits and a rate hike this year. Geopolitics is seen as the biggest tail risk, and investors are considering hedge funds that take both bull and bear positions.

site_title: London's Mayfair sees mansion glut
summary: London's luxury property market is experiencing a glut of multi-million-pound residences in Mayfair, with over 440 new homes approved in the enclave. This oversupply is fueled by uncertainty surrounding the UK's national election and tax increases, resulting in a 30% decline in home sales and a 10% increase in housing stock. Developers are competing for the world's richest buyers, with prices forecast to drop 3.6% in 2015. The area's luxury market is being eroded by neighboring districts, with prices falling to 40% of their original value due to the premium for new properties.

site_title: Euro falls broadly after ECB leaves rates unchanged
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) left interest rates unchanged at 0.05% and -0.20%, as expected, despite a recent economic pick-up. The euro fell 0.7% to $1.0585 and 0.5% lower against the yen, reaching a one-month low against the US dollar. Investors expect the ECB to reiterate its dovish policy bias, supporting a sell-on-rallies stance for the euro, with forecasts predicting it will ease to $0.95 by the end of 2015.

site_title: 10-year SGS rises back to its February level
summary: The 10-year Singapore Government Securities (SGS) has risen over 1% in the past two weeks, reaching a level not seen since February, with a yield falling more than 6% to 108.35 on April 14. This follows softer economic data and tracks the US Treasury. The price of the SGS was previously at 108.39 in February, before selling down to 104.10 in March. The move is seen as a reaction to the economic data and a shift away from corporate bonds to government securities.

images.alt_text: The benchmark three-month Sibor (Singapore interbank offered rate) eased again on Wednesday as speculators unwound the short bets on the Singapore dollar after Tuesday's move by the MAS to keep the SGD on a "modest and gradual" appreciating path

site_title: ECB's Draghi says eurozone economy to keep strengthening
summary: European Central Bank President Mario Draghi stated that the eurozone economy is expected to continue strengthening, with inflation rates expected to rise later in 2015 and 2016. The economy has gained momentum since the end of 2014, driven by monetary policy decisions, lower oil prices, and a lower euro exchange rate. Draghi noted that while inflation remains low, it is expected to increase in the coming years, with growth predicted at 1.5% in 2015 and 1.8% in 2017.

site_title: Huawei to double 2015 smartphone sales in East, Southern Africa
summary: Huawei plans to double smartphone sales in east and southern Africa to 4 million this year, as part of its expansion into international markets. The company's vice president, David Wang, stated that the market potential is huge, despite being a "virgin market." Huawei has partnered with the Zimbabwean government on a $200 million project to expand wireless coverage and has no plans to start manufacturing or make acquisitions in Africa. Most of Huawei's products are produced in China due to lower labor costs and a need for skilled workers.

site_title: EU charges Google with market abuse, to probe Android
summary: The European Union has formally charged Google with abusing its search engine dominance, specifically favoring its own comparison shopping product in search results. The EU has also launched a probe into Google's Android mobile operating system, alleging potential anti-competitive practices. If found guilty, Google could face a fine of up to 10% of its annual sales, currently estimated at $66 billion. The investigation aims to ensure the Android system remains open to all, and the EU Competition Commissioner has called on Google to discuss the issues amicably.

images.alt_text: The EU on Wednesday formally charged US Internet giant Google with abusing its search engine's dominance and launched a sensitive probe into its omnipresent Android mobile phone operating system.

site_title: Corporate stewardship: making the leap from theory to practice
summary: A corporate chairman admits to failing to resist pressure from institutional shareholders to increase debt and payout dividends, leading to exposure during the 2008 financial crisis. Short-termism is costly, reducing research and development spending and US growth. Stewardship is essential for building enduring companies that meet human needs, train, and create working communities. Effective stewardship requires a joint effort from management, boards, and owners to manage assets and hand them over in better condition. Practical steps to make stewardship work include applying the concepts of value and mandate.

images.alt_text: For boards of directors, the starting point of good stewardship is a clear mandate.

site_title: Hip online firm Etsy to make Wall Street debut
summary: Etsy, an online marketplace for artisan goods, is set to make its Wall Street debut, raising up to $307 million and valuing it at $1.78 billion. The company, known for its social values and commitment to sustainability, plans to maintain its status as a certified B Corporation. Despite potential criticism from investors over its focus on social responsibility, Etsy has reported a $1.93 billion in sales and a large number of active buyers and sellers, making it a "highly lucrative" business.

site_title: Google criticises EU charges
summary: Google has dismissed European Union charges of abusing its dominant position as Europe's top search engine, stating that allegations of harm to consumers and competitors are "wide of the mark." The company claims that users can now access information through multiple sources, reducing Google's role as a gatekeeper. Google's official blog post downplays the charges, emphasizing the company's efforts to provide users with various options for finding and accessing information.

site_title: Sembcorp gets nod for wind farm
summary: Sembcorp Industries has received approval for a 150-megawatt wind farm in Huanghua, Hebei Province, China, valued at 1.3 billion yuan. The project is expected to be completed by the second half of 2017. This follows the successful completion of a 48MW wind farm in the same region, which began supplying power in 2015. The projects are part of Sembcorp's expansion of its renewable energy business in China, with a total renewable energy capacity of 1,200MW.

site_title: US home builder sentiment rises to 2015 peak: NAHB
summary: US homebuilder sentiment has reached its highest level since 2015, according to the National Association of Home Builders. The NAHB/Wells Fargo Housing Market index rose to 56 in April, up from 52 in March, indicating that builders see favorable market conditions. This marks a reversal of a three-month decline and the highest level since 2015. The single-family home sales component and prospective buyer traffic also increased, suggesting optimism about the housing market's future.

site_title: Fed's Bullard says economic boom to send jobless rate to 4% range
summary: US Federal Reserve President James Bullard expects the economy to experience a boom, sending the unemployment rate into the 4% range. The US economy is expected to maintain 3% growth in the medium term, prompting Bullard to suggest interest rates should reflect this growth. He also hinted that the Fed may consider raising interest rates, citing the need for an appropriate rate path for the upcoming economic boom.

site_title: China's Huawei shows smartphone credentials with P8 launch
summary: Huawei unveiled its flagship P8 smartphone in London, featuring a 5.2-inch display, eight-core 64-bit processor, and a metal body. The device's technical specifications match those of Samsung Galaxy S6 and iPhone 6. Huawei, a major player in telecoms equipment, ranked fourth in global smartphone sales last year, shipping 68 million units. The company is challenging Samsung and Apple, particularly in their home market, with fellow Chinese companies Lenovo and Xiaomi also vying for market share.

site_title: Singapore: Shares touch fresh high
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.54% on Wednesday, reaching a fresh high of 3,539.95, driven by gains in Jardine stocks and banks. Most action was in penny stocks, with Sino Construction falling 17.8% despite 170.5 million shares traded. Total shares worth S$1.6 billion changed hands, with 277 gainers outnumbering 224 losers.

site_title: Schaeuble 'confident' Greece won't exit eurozone
summary: German Finance Minister Wolfgang Schaeuble expressed confidence that Greece won't exit the eurozone, despite market expectations. However, he noted that no agreement has been reached between Athens and EU negotiators on a new financial lifeline for Greece. The country's massive debt has raised concerns about a potential default, but Schaeuble believes the market has already priced in a Greek exit.

site_title: US industrial production falls in March
summary: US industrial production fell 0.6% in March, more than double the expected drop, due to lower utility output as winter weather faded. This decline was largely offset by a 0.1% gain in manufacturing. Capacity utilization fell to 78.4%, below the long-run average of 80.1%. The decline marked the fourth consecutive month of lower utilization.

images.alt_text: US industrial production fell sharply in March, pulled down by lower utility output as bad winter weather faded, the Federal Reserve said on Wednesday.

site_title: IMF warns of rising risks as strong dollar hits emerging markets
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) warns of rising risks to the global financial system due to the strong US dollar and weak commodity prices, affecting emerging markets. The strengthening greenback and lower oil prices boost the world recovery, but also put pressure on countries and firms that export crude and other commodities. The IMF cautions that rapid dollar appreciation, interest rate hikes, and geopolitical risks could exacerbate emerging-market currency and asset market volatility, potentially leading to debt rollover challenges and market instability.

site_title: US oil stockpile show smallest rise this year: EIA
summary: US crude oil stockpiles rose by 1.3 million barrels last week, the smallest increase this year, according to the Energy Information Administration. This was less than the expected 4.1 million barrels. Crude stocks at the Cushing, Oklahoma, delivery hub also rose, while gasoline stocks decreased and distillate inventories increased. The data suggests a slight slowdown in the US oil market.

site_title: Japan poised to overtake China as America's biggest creditor
summary: Japan is poised to overtake China as America's largest foreign creditor, with the Bank of Japan adding $7.7 billion to US government securities in January, narrowing the gap to $1 billion. This comes as China cut its investment in US government securities for the fifth month in a row. Japan's low interest rates and demand for US Treasuries, driven by foreign investors, will help suppress yields. The US Treasury is the safest security in the world, making it an attractive asset, especially with the Federal Reserve poised to raise interest rates.

site_title: SGX clarifies stock trading link rumour, in response to MAS query
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) has clarified that it is not currently setting up a stock trading link similar to the Shanghai-Hong Kong Stock Connect, despite a Monetary Authority of Singapore query. The company remains open to future collaborations benefiting partners and shareholders. The clarification follows news reports of SGX shares surging to a five-year high due to market speculation about the potential trading link.

site_title: Singapore Wrap Wednesday
summary: Temasek Holdings CEO Ho Ching is taking a three-month sabbatical. The Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority (Acra) will implement Companies Act amendments in two phases due to website revamp delays. Keppel Land's Q1 net profit fell 17.2% to S$72.6 million. Singapore shares rose 0.54% despite China's economic slowdown.

site_title: Segway bought by Xiaomi-backed China transporter startup Ninebot
summary: Segway Inc, the developer of two-wheeled electric people movers, has been acquired by Ninebot Inc, a China-based competitor backed by Xiaomi Corp. The deal, announced on April 1, includes all of Segway's assets and brings together industry-leading research, development, engineering, and manufacturing. Ninebot will use electric driving, mobile Internet, and man-machine interaction technologies for future products, while Segway holds over 400 patents related to the devices. The acquisition marks a significant shift in the company's future direction after a high price tag and restrictions on sales hindered individual consumer sales.

images.alt_text: Segway Inc, the developer of two-wheeled, electric-powered people movers, was acquired by China-based competitor Ninebot Inc.

site_title: Inflight entertainment exposes airliners to hackers: US report
summary: A US government report by the Government Accountability Office (GAO) warns that inflight entertainment systems on commercial airliners connected to the internet could be vulnerable to hacking, potentially compromising cockpit electronics. The FAA is starting to address this issue, but modern communications technologies increase the risk of unauthorized access. The report identifies inflight cybersecurity as a growing concern, highlighting the need for improved security measures to protect aircraft avionics systems.

site_title: Panasonic eyes doubling of airline Wi-Fi installation to meet demand
summary: Panasonic Avionics plans to double its Wi-Fi system installations from 488 per year to 1,000 to meet growing demand from airlines. The company has a 46% share of Wi-Fi systems installed since 2009 and aims to equip 12,000 narrow-body planes with the technology in the next 10 years. Panasonic is also expanding its avionics business through acquisitions, including the recent purchase of software consultancy Tactel. Suppliers are showcasing new hardware designs, such as a tilt-adjustable antenna and a flat-panel design with electromagnetic metamaterial technology, to improve satellite signal reception.

site_title: Keppel Land Q1 profit down 17.2%
summary: Keppel Land's Q1 net profit fell 17.2% to S$72.6 million due to lower revenue from its property trading segment. The decline was mainly attributed to the absence of revenue from The Lakefront Residences in Singapore and lower revenue from The Springdale in Shanghai. Revenue also dropped 2.3% to S$278.4 million.

site_title: Gold, silver price forecasts slashed as US rate rise looms
summary: Analysts have cut their forecasts for gold and silver prices, citing the prospect of higher US interest rates and resulting in lower prices. Gold is now expected to average $1,209 an ounce this year, down from $1,234, and $1,250 an ounce in 2016, down from $1,278. The expectation of a US rate hike is expected to boost the dollar, making gold less attractive and leading to lower prices. Analysts also note that current prices are not stimulating strong demand from physical gold markets in Asia.

site_title: Fed's Bullard repeats view of hiking 'now', cites asset bubble risk
summary: US Federal Reserve Bank President James Bullard says the Fed should raise interest rates "now" to prevent asset bubbles, citing a strong economy with a growth rate near 3% over the medium term. Bullard, a policy hawk, argues that monetary policy will remain accommodative even after rate hikes, and the Fed should start normalizing policy to set it appropriately for an improving economy over the next two years. This contradicts the Fed's current stance of keeping rates low for an extended period.

site_title: ECB's Draghi sees no problem in finding bonds to buy in QE programme
summary: European Central Bank President Mario Draghi stated that the ECB's 1 trillion euro government bond buying program, set to run until September 2016, will be fully implemented without concerns about available bonds. Draghi played down market speculation that the program might be scaled back due to signs of eurozone recovery, saying the focus will be on full policy measures, which are "flexible enough" to be adjusted if necessary.

site_title: German air controllers urge remote control of planes after crash
summary: The German air traffic control authority has urged the aviation industry to consider technology that would allow remote control of planes in emergency situations, following the Germanwings crash in March that killed 150 people. The system, which could be used to safely land a plane, is likely to take a decade to develop. The suggestion comes after a voice recording and flight data showed pilot Andreas Lubitz deliberately locked his captain out of the cockpit and steered the plane into a mountain. The technology could provide a safer alternative in emergency situations.

site_title: China's central bank asked lenders to check margin trading risk: memo
summary: China's central bank, the People's Bank of China (PBOC), has ordered commercial lenders to check for risks in their margin trading business, following a surge in the practice. The move aims to ensure transparency and control risks, amid concerns that margin trading is being used to fund other business activities. The PBOC has requested lenders to report risks and measures to handle them, following a tightening of controls on wealth management products (WMPs) last year.

site_title: SMRT may invest in telco licence bidder OMGTEL
summary: SMRT Corporation may invest up to S$34.5 million in OMGTEL, a company bidding for Singapore's fourth wireless telecommunications carrier licence, if it wins the licence. The investment is contingent on satisfactory due diligence and the execution of definitive agreements between the two companies. SMRT will work exclusively with OMG on its bid.

site_title: ECB holds key refi rate steady at 0.05%
summary: The European Central Bank held its key interest rates steady at 0.05% during its regular policy meeting on Wednesday. The decision was as expected, with the benchmark "refi" refinancing rate remaining at its all-time low. The ECB's governing council made no changes to its monetary policy stance, citing a strong economic outlook in the eurozone. The decision was made ahead of the weekend meetings of the World Bank and International Monetary Fund.

site_title: Greece's 2014 deficit more than double forecasts: official
summary: Greece's budget deficit for 2014 was 3.5% of GDP, more than doubling initial forecasts of 1.3% and the European Commission's 1.6%. The public debt reached 177% of GDP.

site_title: Singapore Airlines chalks up 1.6 percentage point rise in March passenger load factor
summary: Singapore Airlines reported a 1.6 percentage point rise in March passenger load factor to 76.6% due to stronger demand in South-west Pacific and West Asia/Africa, and capacity consolidation. However, East Asia routes saw a decline in load factor due to capacity growth outpacing demand. The airline also noted weaker passenger demand to the Americas. Despite the improvement, the competitive landscape remains challenging.

site_title: MH17 team gain access to new debris field, hope to find last two victims
summary: Nine months after the crash, investigators have gained access to the last unexamined debris field of Malaysian Airlines MH17 in eastern Ukraine. The Dutch-led team hopes to recover remains of the last two victims as heavy fighting has stopped in the area. The site, near Petropavlivka, is still littered with landmines, but security is now feasible. The team's air force commander, Theo ten Haaf, expressed optimism, stating that the front line's movement has made it possible for them to collect evidence safely. Recovery efforts are expected to begin soon.

images.alt_text: Nine months after Malaysian Airlines MH17 crashed in eastern Ukraine, investigators have gained access to the area where the last unexamined wreckage lies and hope to recover remains of the last two victims.

site_title: China aviation regulator to push for air space reform: paper
summary: China's civil aviation authority has promised to push for airspace reform, aiming to open up lower airspace for small planes. The Civil Aviation Administration of China (CAAC) will simplify flight approval procedures and encourage local governments to build airports, with estimated investment of over $22 billion. The move could boost sales for planemakers such as Bombardier and Textron. Currently, the military controls about 80% of China's airspace, and the CAAC has already relaxed controls in the past, including allowing private jets to fly in lower airspace.

site_title: US: Stocks rise on China stimulus hopes
summary: US stocks rose on Wednesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average up 72.60 points (0.40%) to 18,109.30, and the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index advancing 8.08% and 15.40% respectively. The gains came amid speculation of more monetary stimulus in China following the country's weak first-quarter economic report, which showed an annual growth rate of 7.0%. The report sparked concerns about the government's ability to support the economy, leading to increased investor optimism.

site_title: Beijing boasts economic predictive power, markets more sceptical
summary: Beijing's economic growth has matched its stated target for the 15th straight quarter, with growth closely aligning with market consensus. This rare streak has led some analysts to question the accuracy of forecasts, with some attributing the alignment to the molding of forecasts to match the official line. Despite this, economists remain skeptical, with one strategist stating that "we don't expect much in the way of surprises from Chinese GDP figures." The sustained growth has raised pressure on policymakers, although it's unclear how long this trend will continue.

site_title: India's wholesale inflation drops 2.33% in March
summary: India's wholesale inflation decreased 2.33% in March, the fifth consecutive month of decline, due to lower local food and manufacturing prices and slumping global oil prices. This is a sharper-than-expected drop, exceeding a 2.10% decline predicted by a Bloomberg survey. The decline follows a 2.06% drop in February, indicating a stabilization in India's inflation rate.

site_title: New York state manufacturing activity slows in April: NY Fed
summary: New York state manufacturing activity unexpectedly contracted in April, marking the third straight month of decline, according to the New York Federal Reserve. The Empire State general business conditions index fell to -1.19, the first negative reading since December, while the new orders index weakened to -6.0, the lowest since January 2013. Prices paid rose to a 7-year high, and employment growth slowed sharply. The index of business conditions six months ahead rose to 37.06, indicating a future expansion. The decline is a surprise, as economists had expected a rise to 7.0.

site_title: Sembcorp Industries expands renewable energy business in China
summary: Sembcorp Industries is expanding its renewable energy business in China through a 150-megawatt wind farm in Huanghua, Hebei province. The 1.3 billion yuan (S$300 million) project has received approval and will commence construction this year, with completion expected by 2017. The project will be funded through a mix of internal and external borrowings, with Sembcorp Industries' share of the equity investment amounting to around 0.2 billion yuan.

site_title: Nokia says too early to say how many job cuts in Alcatel deal
summary: Nokia CEO Rajeev Suri stated it's too early to determine the number of job cuts in its Alcatel-Lucent deal, which aims to achieve cost savings and synergy targets. While headcount reductions are expected, other procurement and costs can also be reduced. Suri expressed confidence in receiving antitrust approval in the European Union, China, and the US, with Alcatel CEO Michel Combes seeking clearance in nine countries.

site_title: Vallianz gunning for more, bigger contracts in Middle East
summary: Vallianz Holdings, an offshore support vessel owner, is in talks to secure multiple contracts worth over US$100 million each from a major Middle Eastern state oil company. The contracts are part of a larger deal with the company, which also owns a 20% stake in Vallianz. The joint venture with Saudi Arabian conglomerate Rawabi Holding generates most of Vallianz's revenue. The outcome of these negotiations is expected to significantly boost the company's revenue and growth prospects.

site_title: China hires seven firms to audit state firms' overseas assets
summary: The Chinese government has hired seven accounting firms, including PricewaterhouseCoopers, to audit the overseas assets of state-owned enterprises, valued at over 4.3 trillion yuan as of 2013. This move aims to improve transparency and combat corruption. The audit will focus on overseas assets and key projects, with the firms required to work within the Chinese legal framework. The 11.39 million yuan investment is part of the government's efforts to expand its anti-corruption drive.

site_title: CapitaMalls Malaysia Trust's Q1 DPU down 3% at 2.25 sen
summary: CapitaMalls Malaysia Trust (CMMT) reported a 2.1% increase in net property income to RM53.6 million for Q1, mainly due to East Coast Mall's asset enhancement works. Distributable income fell 2.9% to RM40.0 million, with a distribution per unit of 2.25 sen, down from 2.32 sen last year. CEO Low Peck Chen expects to complete a proposed acquisition, increasing property asset value by 17.3% to RM3.8 billion and total net lettable area by 21.6%.

site_title: Eurozone surplus widens but trade with Russia plummets
summary: The eurozone's trade surplus widened to 20.3 billion euros in February, exceeding expectations, as exports rose 4% and imports remained stable. A weaker euro contributed to the increase, offsetting a decline in sales to Russia. Adjusted for seasonal changes, exports rose 2.8% and imports increased 2.6%. The surplus is a sign of the eurozone's resilience despite global economic uncertainty.

site_title: Malaysia's MBSB sets 5-year time frame for conversion to Islamic bank
summary: Malaysia Building Society Bhd (MBSB) plans to convert into an Islamic bank within 5 years, after reviving plans following the cancellation of a proposed merger. The bank aims to transform existing conventional products into Islamic ones and introduce new ones. MBSB's CEO, Ahmad Zaini, stated this during a shareholders meeting. The move aims to close the gap with competitors and enhance the bank's Islamic financing capabilities.

site_title: Vietnam posts US$1.4b trade deficit in March: customs
summary: Vietnam posted a trade deficit of US$1.39 billion in March, exceeding initial estimates, with exports increasing 40.3% to US$13.344 billion and imports rising 40.6% to US$14.735 billion. This brought Vietnam's exports to US$36.3 billion in the first quarter, up 8.8% from the same time in 2014, while imports climbed 20.1% to US$38.7 billion. The trade deficit is below the government's projected 10% increase in exports for 2015.

site_title: OECD chief credits loose monetary policy for averting catastrophe
summary: OECD chief Angel Gurria credits loose monetary policy for preventing a global economic collapse following the 2008 financial crisis. He praises central bankers for supplying easy money to boost growth, but warns that governments must now address structural issues such as education, innovation, and regulations to achieve sustainable growth. Japan's economy is expected to expand 1.0% this year and 1.4% next, according to the OECD's report, which also calls for reforms to lift productivity and address the country's massive national debt.

site_title: Strong dollar's economic axe to fall on smaller US exporters
summary: A strong US dollar is expected to negatively impact smaller US exporters, particularly those selling specialty products for less than $1,000 per shipment. Companies with fewer than 500 workers, which account for about a third of US$1.6 trillion in goods sold overseas, are particularly vulnerable due to limited flexibility to hedge currency fluctuations and higher production costs. The dollar's surge may cut US growth by 0.5 percentage points this year, potentially reducing payrolls by 30,000 to 60,000 per month, according to Bank of America economists.

site_title: Samsung says demand for Galaxy S6 models much higher than planned for
summary: Samsung Electronics Co Ltd reported higher-than-expected demand for its Galaxy S6 smartphones, with both flat-screen and curved-screen models exceeding initial supply projections. The company aims to secure enough supply for global consumers despite short-term difficulties. Analysts expect the new devices to generate significant earnings momentum in the current quarter. Samsung's mobile chief, J.K. Shin, previously noted a near-term supply shortage for the curved-screen Galaxy S6 edge model.

site_title: China-led bank starts with 57 members, Norway included
summary: China-led bank Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB) has 57 founding members, including Norway, and excludes Taiwan, the US, and Japan. The 57 countries include four UN Security Council permanent members, 14 EU countries, and 21 OECD members. The institution aims to finance infrastructure in Asia, not poverty reduction, and promises a "zero-tolerance policy on corruption." Critics express concerns about its standards, which could rival the US-led World Bank and Asian Development Bank. The founding members will hold preparatory meetings and choose the first president by the end of June.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher
summary: Malaysian shares ended higher on Wednesday, with the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 0.52 points to close at 1,840.13. A total of 2.70 billion lots were traded, with 518 gainers and 307 losers.

site_title: Germany to cut public debt as finances remain in black
summary: Germany plans to reduce its public debt to 61.5% of economic output by 2019, exceeding the EU's 60% limit. The country aims to cut its debt ratio from 74.7% in 2014 to 71.5% in 2015, 68.75% in 2016, and 61.5% in 2019. Germany's public budget is expected to show a surplus of around 0.25% of GDP this year and modest surpluses in the following years. The country's robust economy and structural reforms have enabled it to keep its finances in the black.

site_title: Greece rules out early elections
summary: Greece's state minister Alekos Flabouraris ruled out early elections, stating there's no point in holding them as the government has a specific mandate from the previous election. The government is under pressure to reach a deal on reforms with EU and IMF lenders to unlock further aid. Flabouraris emphasized that the government will serve its mandate and does not need elections. This comes amid speculation that a snap election could be called if the government fails to secure a deal.

site_title: Indonesia's Sinarmas says targets coal miner to support power business
summary: Indonesia's Sinarmas Group plans to acquire London-listed coal miner Asia Resource Minerals Plc (ARMS) to support its power business. The potential offer of 41 pence per share represents a 173% premium. The acquisition aims to synergize ARMS' supply with Sinarmas' power plants. If successful, the deal could benefit Sinarmas' power business and outperform the Jakarta benchmark index.

site_title: Samsung said to create Apple team in displays to boost ties
summary: Samsung Electronics has created a 200-employee team at its Samsung Display Co to focus exclusively on developing screens for Apple Inc products. This move aims to strengthen business ties between the two companies, which had previously dropped lawsuits against each other. The team helps develop products and shares information only within the group, suggesting Samsung Display will win screen orders from Apple. This comes as Samsung relies more on its display and semiconductor units to regain leadership in the global smartphone market.

site_title: Nokia agrees 15.6b euro deal to buy Alcatel-Lucent
summary: Nokia has agreed to a 15.6 billion euro deal to buy Alcatel-Lucent, creating the world's largest supplier of mobile phone network equipment. The deal will be run by Nokia's current management team and is expected to save 900 million euros in costs by 2019. Alcatel-Lucent's research and development activities in France are expected to increase by 25%. The merger is seen as a significant boost to Nokia's market share, particularly in the mobile infrastructure business.

site_title: Axiata Group appoints new chief executive for Indonesian telco arm
summary: Axiata Group, a Malaysian telecommunications firm, has appointed Dian Siswarini as the new chief executive for its Indonesian arm, PT XL Axiata Tbk. Dian, the company's deputy chief executive, will succeed retiring CEO Hasnul Suhaimi. She is the group's first female CEO and will lead Indonesia's second-largest telecom operator, XL Axiata, which has over 200 million subscribers in Indonesia and Bangladesh.

site_title: Germany's economy likely cooled in the first quarter
summary: Germany's economy likely cooled in the first quarter, with growth expected to continue at a moderate pace. The economy ministry reported a 0.7% growth in the final quarter of last year, which may not be repeated. This slowdown is attributed to a decline in growth at the end of last year.

site_title: Australia: Shares tumble as soft China data adds to weak sentiment
summary: Australian shares fell 0.6% on Wednesday, marking the third straight day of declines, as China's latest data showed slowing growth, outweighing the benefits of rebounding oil and iron ore prices. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 5908.4, its lowest close since April 2.

site_title: Petronas CEO denies reports of staff pay cuts
summary: Petronas CEO Wan Zulkiflee Wan Ariffin denied reports that staff at one of its units were asked to take a 20% pay cut due to low oil prices. The company has had to cut capital expenditure and domestic spending this year, but there is no salary cut or retrenchment for Petronas staff. Petronas established bond and sukuk programmes to raise US$17 billion in working capital.

site_title: South Korea's Lotte Shopping drops bid for World Duty Free
summary: Lotte Shopping Co Ltd dropped its bid to acquire World Duty Free SpA after the Italian company rejected its offer and instead agreed to a majority stake deal with Switzerland's Dufry, valued at 3.6 billion euros. Lotte Shopping owns Lotte Duty Free, the world's fourth-largest duty free store operator.

site_title: Indonesia posts trade surplus in March; exports, imports fall
summary: Indonesia posted its largest trade surplus since December 2013, with a surplus of $1.13 billion in March. Exports fell 9.75% to $13.71 million, while imports contracted 13.39% to $12.58 million. The result exceeded analyst expectations of a $620 million surplus.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end higher after China data
summary: Hong Kong shares rose 0.21% to 27,618.82, driven by China's slowest quarterly economic growth since the financial crisis, raising hopes for further monetary easing. In contrast, mainland China's Shanghai Composite Index fell 1.24%, while the Shenzhen Composite Index dropped 3.68%.

site_title: Singapore non-oil exports seen down for 2nd month in March
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports are expected to have fallen 0.7% in March, marking a second consecutive decline, according to a Reuters poll of economists. This follows a 9.7% drop in February, largely due to decreased shipments to China. The city-state's manufacturing activity also contracted for a fourth consecutive month in March, with new orders declining. The trade data is set to be released on Friday.

site_title: SATS to improve Changi Airport's cargo handling productivity with e-Acceptance initiative
summary: SATS, a ground handler at Changi Airport, is launching an e-Acceptance initiative to improve cargo handling productivity. The system reduces human error, offers live tracking, and boosts security, aiming to boost productivity by 30% and save 600,000 sheets of paper per year by year-end.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close 0.20% lower
summary: Tokyo stocks closed 0.20% lower on April 15, 2015, due to profit-taking and a firm yen following a weaker-than-expected US retail sales report. The Nikkei 225 index lost 38.92 points to 19,869.76, while the Topix index eased 0.13% to 1,588.81.

site_title: China: Stocks post biggest fall in a month, small caps slump
summary: China's stock market experienced its largest one-day drop in over a month, with small-cap shares declining despite gains in infrastructure and banking stocks. The country's economic growth slowed to a six-year low, with a 7% growth rate in the January-March quarter, prompting calls for further monetary easing to stimulate the economy.

site_title: Toyota to move Corolla production to Mexico to cut costs
summary: Toyota plans to move production of its Corolla compact cars from Canada to a new factory in Mexico, citing lower costs. The move, expected to cost $1 billion, will begin in 2019 and result in the Canadian plant producing larger vehicles. This decision comes as Toyota seeks to reduce costs, following a self-imposed freeze on new investments. The new Mexican plant will enable Toyota to take advantage of lower labor and production costs, allowing the company to maintain its competitive edge.

site_title: Europe: Stocks dip at open before ECB rate decision
summary: European stock markets opened lower on Wednesday due to weak Chinese and US economic data, ahead of the European Central Bank's interest rate decision. The CAC 40 index in Paris rose 0.25%, while London's FTSE 100 and Frankfurt's DAX 30 declined 0.12% and 0.06% respectively. Nokia has agreed to buy Alcatel-Lucent for a multibillion-euro deal, creating the world's largest mobile phone network equipment supplier. The ECB is expected to announce no policy changes, but will highlight the positive effects of its recent measures, including a sovereign bond purchase programme.

site_title: Burberry to adjust prices to offset currency fluctuations
summary: British luxury goods maker Burberry plans to adjust prices globally to offset currency fluctuations and remain competitive with rivals. The company posted a 9% rise in second-half revenue, beating forecasts. Burberry's Chief Financial Officer Carol Fairweather stated that the company will maintain its price positioning relative to peers, adjusting prices up or down as needed. This move follows similar price adjustments by luxury brands such as Chanel and Cartier, driven by the rise of the US dollar and the euro's weakness.

site_title: Asia markets mostly down after China data
summary: Asia markets declined on Wednesday following disappointing Chinese economic data, with Shanghai sinking 1.10% and Hong Kong rising 0.20%. The slowdown in China's economy has raised hopes for more stimulus, while disappointing US retail sales dampened expectations for an early interest rate cut by the Federal Reserve. The euro gained support from upbeat eurozone figures, while the dollar struggled after losing ground in New York.

site_title: South Korea: Shares close at highest level since August 2011
summary: South Korean shares reached their highest level since August 2011, closing at 2,119.96, driven by hopes of emerging market investments and potential Chinese stimulus. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index rose 0.4% for a fourth consecutive session. The won depreciated 0.3% to 1,096.8 per dollar.

site_title: Singapore's retail sales up 15.8% in February compared to a year ago
summary: Singapore's retail sales increased 15.8% in February compared to the same period last year, with non-motor vehicle sales rising 14.8%. Retail sales of food & beverages, department stores, and supermarkets grew by 29% and 66.6% respectively due to the Chinese New Year period. Other sectors such as telecommunications, watches, and jewellery saw higher sales of 6.1% and 2.6% respectively.

site_title: Update - Quick take: China's Q1 GDP growth slows to 7%
summary: China's Q1 GDP growth slowed to 7% in the first quarter of 2015, down from 7.3% in the fourth quarter, according to the National Bureau of Statistics. This is the worst single quarter growth since 2009, and other key indicators also slumped to new multi-year lows. Economists expect further policy easing, with some predicting a benchmark interest rate cut and more expansionary fiscal policy to soften the pace of the slowdown in investment growth.

site_title: Asiana plane hits antenna in Japan runway undershoot
summary: An Asiana Airways plane crashed into a communications antenna at Hiroshima airport in Japan, injuring 27 people. The Airbus A320 overshot the runway, causing significant damage to the localiser, and deployed emergency escape chutes. All 73 passengers and crew members evacuated safely, but 25 were injured. The cause of the accident is under investigation, with Asiana Airlines cooperating with authorities. The incident echoes the airline's 2013 fatal crash in San Francisco, where a mismanaged approach was the probable cause.

site_title: Quick take: China's Q1 GDP growth slows to 7%
summary: China's Q1 GDP growth slowed to 7% in the first quarter of 2015, down from 7.3% in the fourth quarter, according to the National Bureau of Statistics. This is the worst single quarter growth since 2009. Economists' forecasts were slightly lower than the actual rate, but in line with the median forecast. The slowdown is attributed to weak momentum in key indicators such as industrial production, fixed-asset investment, and retail sales. Policymakers are likely to implement more expansionary policies to address the slowdown, including a possible interest rate cut.

site_title: Developers' sales surge 57% month-on-month to 613 private homes in March: URA
summary: Singapore developers sold 613 private homes in March, a 57% month-on-month surge and 28% increase from the same month last year. The median price was S$1,111 per square foot for Kingsford Waterbay and S$1,401 psf for Sims Urban Oasis. Including executive condos, developers sold 692 units, higher than February and March last year.

site_title: IEA sees Opec supply jumping most in four years on Saudi surge
summary: The International Energy Agency (IEA) reports that OPEC production increased by 890,000 barrels a day in March to 31.02 million a day, the largest monthly gain in almost four years. This surge was driven by Saudi Arabia, Iraq, and Libya boosting output amid a stronger global oil demand outlook. Oil prices have fallen 45% since last year, trading at $59 a barrel, as OPEC defends market share against US shale output. The IEA also cut its predictions for US and Canadian oil supply growth in the second half of the year.

site_title: Companies Act amendments to take effect by Q1 2016 amid delays in website revamp
summary: The Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority (Acra) in Singapore will implement 40% of the Companies Act amendments in two phases. The first phase, taking effect July 1, 2015, includes provisions broadening the criteria for exemption from statutory audit for small companies. The remaining 60% will be implemented in the first quarter of 2016, following a website revamp that is currently underway and expected to be completed by Q1 2016.

site_title: US becoming net energy exporter for first time since 1950s
summary: The US is expected to become a net energy exporter for the first time since the 1950s within 15 years, according to the Energy Information Administration. US crude oil production is forecast to reach 10.3 million barrels per day in 2025 and 9.4 million in 2040, exceeding imports. The shale boom, driven by horizontal drilling and hydraulic fracturing, is credited for the increase in production. The forecast does not anticipate a change in US law banning most crude exports, and the country is expected to become self-sufficient in energy by 2032.

site_title: Sing-dollar pulls back from rally against greenback
summary: The Singapore dollar (SGD) retreated from its rally against the US dollar after the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) kept its monetary policy unchanged on Tuesday. The SGD had gained strength earlier, but analysts predicted it would be temporary due to a stronger US economy. At 10:20 am on Wednesday, 1 USD was equivalent to 1.3622 SGD, down from 1.3605 SGD at the end of trading on Tuesday.

site_title: What Albert and Bernard should have done about Cheryl's birthday
summary: Albert and Bernard, newly friends with Cheryl, ask for her birthday but are met with a list of 10 possible dates. When told the month and day separately, they realize none of these dates are suitable for a date. Albert suggests watching Game of Thrones, while Bernard shrugs off the idea of waiting five more years for a possible date. The situation highlights the friends' uncertainty and disappointment in their unrequited interest in Cheryl.

site_title: Macquarie Singapore banking head said to quit after Asia cuts
summary: Macquarie Singapore's head of investment banking, Yung Chee Leong, is leaving the company after a recent decision to cut its investment banking operations in Asia. The move, part of CEO Nicholas Moore's strategy to shift focus to stable businesses, will result in up to 90 job cuts. Leong, who joined Macquarie in 2010, will leave before the end of May, with Anupam Garg handling his responsibilities. This follows other job cuts at securities firms, including Goldman Sachs' 30% reduction in its Singapore investment-banking team.

site_title: South Korea's jobless rate falls to 4% in March
summary: South Korea's jobless rate dropped to 4% in March, down from 4.6% in February, but remained higher than the 3.9% from a year ago. Unemployment among young South Koreans (15-29 years old) rose to 10.7%, while those aged 25-29 were at 9.5%. Despite relatively low unemployment compared to Europe and the US, the issue is more pronounced among young Koreans due to companies reducing hiring due to slowing demand.

site_title: China's JD.com sets up cross-border e-commerce platform in challenge to Alibaba
summary: JD.com, China's No. 2 e-commerce player, launched JD Worldwide, a cross-border online shopping platform, challenging Alibaba's Tmall Global. JD Worldwide allows Chinese shoppers to buy imports from US firms and those from countries like Australia, France, and Japan. The platform offers over 1,200 brands without requiring a presence in China. JD.com trails behind Alibaba in Chinese e-commerce, but the launch aims to expand its product range and compete with Amazon. The move comes as China promotes e-commerce and relaxes import restrictions.

images.alt_text: JD.com Inc, China's Number 2 e-commerce player, on Wednesday launched its JD Worldwide cross-border online shopping platform, a challenger to Alibaba Group Holding Ltd's Tmall Global service.

site_title: Hot stock: Otto Marine gains on delivery of vessels
summary: Otto Marine's shares rose 6.8% to S$0.047 after delivering four new-build vessels worth US$36.6 million to PT Pertamina Trans Kontinental. The vessels, including harbour tugs and anchor handling tugs, were constructed at PT Batamec's shipyard. Over 4 million shares changed hands in early morning trade, marking a 0.3 Singapore cent gain.

site_title: Temasek's CEO Ho Ching to take three-month sabbatical
summary: Temasek Holdings announced that its CEO Ho Ching will take a three-month sabbatical leave, during which she will continue with board duties and specific stewardship duties. Lee Theng Kiat, president of Temasek, will cover her responsibilities on all normal business activities.

images.alt_text: Temasek Holdings on Wednesday said its chief executive officer, Ho Ching, will take sabbatical leave for three months.

site_title: China's March industrial output up 5.6% on-year: govt
summary: China's industrial output rose 5.6% year-on-year in March, according to the National Bureau of Statistics. Retail sales increased 10.2% and fixed asset investment grew 13.5% in the same period. These data suggest China's economy is showing signs of stability. However, the article does not provide further details on the economic implications of these numbers.

site_title: STI up 10.74 points at opening, extending rally
summary: Singapore shares rose 10.74 points to 3,531.82 at opening on Wednesday, extending a rally on Tuesday. Banking stocks and the Singapore Exchange led the gains, driven by speculation of a potential Singapore-China stock connection. Trading saw 359 million shares worth S$176.9 million, with gainers outnumbering losers 133 to 59.

site_title: China Q1 property investment growth weakens to near 6-year low, sales drop narrows
summary: China's real estate investment growth slowed to 8.5% in Q1, the lowest rate since 2009, amid a housing glut and inventory clearing. Property sales volume dropped 9.2% from the year-earlier period, narrowing from a 16.3% decline in the previous quarter. The slowdown in property investment growth and sales volume poses a risk to China's 7% economic growth target. Despite government efforts to bolster the sector, the real estate downturn is expected to persist through the first half of the year.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Swiber, Ellipsiz, Otto Marine
summary: Stocks to watch include Swiber Holdings, which secured a $133 million contract in India, Ellipsiz Ltd, whose non-executive chairman resigned due to personal reasons, and Otto Marine, which delivered four new-build vessels worth $36.6 million.

site_title: Heeton again seeks single buyer for iLiv@Grange, appoints C&W for sale
summary: HEETON Holdings is seeking a single buyer for its iLiv@Grange project in Singapore's District 10, with an asking price of S$110 million-S$120 million (S$1,879-S$2,050 per square foot). The project, which received Temporary Occupation Permit in 2013, comprises 30 units, including one, two, and three-bedroom apartments, and two penthouses. Heeton has until October 2015 to sell all units under Singapore's Qualifying Certificate rules, and may seek permission for an extension. Cushman & Wakefield has been appointed to conduct an expressions of interest exercise.

images.alt_text: Heeton Holdings is again looking for a buyer to pick up all 30 units in its iLiv@Grange project, which received Temporary Occupation Permit (TOP) in October 2013.

site_title: Mapletree Commercial Trust's Vivocity adds 15,000 sq ft of retail space
summary: Mapletree Commercial Trust has added 15,000 sq ft of retail space at its Vivocity mall, set to open on Wednesday. New retailers, including American Eagle Outfitters, Etude House, and Innisfree, will occupy the space. The expansion brings additional shopping options for mall visitors.

site_title: Broker's take: CMC Markets sees potential upside for SIA
summary: Singapore Airlines shares have potential for further upside, according to CMC Markets analyst Nicholas Teo. Teo pointed out that SIA under-performed regional carriers like Cathay Pacific, China Southern, and All Nippon Airways, despite competing in similar environments and using similar valuation metrics. A chart comparing the two airlines' stock prices showed SIA's under-performance.

site_title: China's economic growth slows to 7% in Q1, six-year low
summary: China's economy grew 7.0% in Q1, its slowest rate in six years, as expected but still a concern for policymakers. Quarterly growth slowed to 1.3%, below forecasts. Factory output rose 5.6%, while fixed-asset investment and retail sales also missed expectations. The data supports predictions of China's economic growth to slide to 7% this year, the lowest in a quarter century, underscoring the need for policymakers to take more steps to bolster growth.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open 0.35% down
summary: Tokyo stocks opened 0.35% lower on April 15, 2015, due to a firmer yen following disappointing US sales data. The dollar remained weak, and the euro strengthened against the yen. The market reacted little to the International Monetary Fund's upgraded economic growth projections for Japan, which warned of the need to tame the country's massive national debt. US stocks finished mostly higher the previous day, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average rising 0.33% and the S&P 500 gaining 0.16%.

site_title: JPMorgan says banks may be making 'bad loans' as LBOs boom
summary: JPMorgan Chase & Co is scaling back from lending in the leveraged buyout (LBO) market, citing concerns about loans that fund smaller deals, which are considered hazardous due to companies' limited financial resources to weather a downturn. Despite low loan losses in LBOs recently, JPMorgan is becoming more selective about credit quality, and regulators share its concerns. The bank's caution may limit its participation in economic booms but help it avoid busts, making it more stable.

site_title: Culture clash as hip online firm Etsy hits Wall Street
summary: Etsy, a Brooklyn-based online marketplace for handmade and vintage goods, is set to debut on the Wall Street market with an initial public offering (IPO) expected to raise between $233 and $307 million, valuing the company at up to $1.78 billion. Despite concerns about the potential clash between social values and shareholder profits, Etsy plans to maintain its "unconventional operating philosophy" and remain a certified B Corporation, prioritizing environmental and social responsibility. The company's IPO marks a rare instance of a socially responsible business being publicly traded.

site_title: Non-landed private homes' rents down, volume up in March : SRX
summary: Non-landed private residential rentals in Singapore decreased by 0.4% in March, with city centre and fringe areas seeing 0.5% and 0.9% rent drops, respectively. Suburban areas experienced a 0.8% increase. The SRX Property Price Index report released in April 2015 showed the decline, contrasting with previous months.

site_title: EU to announce antitrust moves against Google on Wednesday
summary: The European Union is set to announce antitrust moves against Google on Wednesday, accusing the US tech company of abusing its dominant position in internet searches. The move could lead to massive fines and enforced changes in Google's business model, with EU officials citing Google's diversion of traffic from rivals to favor its own services. A formal charge sheet may not be ready until several months, with the EU imposing fines of up to 10% of global turnover, or more than $6 billion.

images.alt_text: The European Union will accuse Google on Wednesday of abusing its dominant position in Internet searches, opening the US tech company up to a risk of massive fines and enforced changes in its business model, the Financial Times and Wall Street Journal said on Tuesday.

site_title: Ellipsiz's chairman, independent director resign for 'personal reasons'
summary: Ellipsiz Ltd's non-executive chairman and independent director, Chong Fok Choy, and director Phoon Wai Meng, have resigned due to "personal reasons". The resignations come a week after CEO Chan Wai Leong sold shares to Lum Chang Holdings' managing director David Lum Kok Seng, increasing Lum's stake in Ellipsiz to 20.44%. No further explanation for the resignations was provided in regulatory filings.

site_title: Denver TSA agents targeted 'attractive' passengers for pat-downs
summary: Two TSA screeners at Denver's international airport were fired after a scheme was uncovered to conduct pat-down searches on attractive male passengers. A screener allegedly groped male passengers he found attractive, and a colleague helped by categorizing them falsely, triggering pat-downs. The woman screener admitted to participating in the scheme at least 10 times. The TSA removed the two officers from the agency, and the case is being reviewed by the district attorney's office for possible charges. No passengers were identified or charged.

site_title: HDB rentals flat in March but leasing volume up 29%: SRX
summary: HDB rentals in Singapore were flat in March, with a 0.1% increase from February, according to SRX Property Price Index. This marks the first time HDB rental prices have stopped declining since August 2014. Three- and four-room flats saw a 0.4% increase, while five-room and executive flats experienced drops of 1.3% and 1.8% respectively.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened 1.58 points lower to 1,838.03 on Wednesday, with 128 gainers outpacing 56 losers. The trading volume was 73.934 million lots worth RM33.28 million.

site_title: China, Australia to talk iron ore demand as BHP, Rio drive glut
summary: Australian Treasurer Joe Hockey plans to discuss iron ore demand with Chinese officials amid a global glut, driven by increased production from BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto Group. The price of iron ore has fallen below US$50 a metric ton, prompting concerns about tax revenues and forcing smaller miners to shut down. Hockey aims to ensure consistent and predictable supply to key markets, while Standard & Poor's has placed the credit ratings of eight iron-ore producers on "watch negative". China's iron ore demand is expected to be discussed in a meeting with Hockey in Washington.

site_title: Swiber wins US$133 million contract from repeat client in India
summary: Swiber Holdings secured a US$133 million contract in India for engineering, procurement, installation, and construction services for six 60km pipelines. This is Swiber's third major award in India in three months, bringing its order book to nearly US$2 billion. The project is scheduled for completion by Q2 2016, following previous awards from the same client in West Africa and India.

site_title: US airliners could be vulnerable to in-flight hacking
summary: US commercial airliners may be vulnerable to in-flight hacking, a federal watchdog agency warned. The US Government Accountability Office identified this risk as one of several emerging cybersecurity weaknesses in the aviation industry. The Federal Aviation Administration is working with government security experts to address the threat, which could be exploited by passengers using a plane's wireless entertainment system to access flight controls. Cybersecurity experts warn that onboard firewalls could be breached if flight control and entertainment systems share the same wiring and routers.

site_title: South Korean exports to keep falling for time being: trade ministry
summary: South Korea's exports are expected to continue falling due to low global oil prices, with the trade ministry predicting a decline in oil-related product exports and sluggish performance in other exports. Imports are also expected to fall at a considerable pace. Total trade value in 2015 is forecasted to be around $1 trillion, lower than last year's $1.1 trillion. This decline is attributed to weak global demand and heightened competition, with the Bank of Korea lowering interest rates and economic forecasts due to expected weak growth.

site_title: US military not ready to wage digital attack: official
summary: The US military's cyber command is not yet ready to wage digital warfare, according to Eric Rosenbach, the Pentagon's principal adviser on cyber security. The command lacks a robust capability to lead an offensive campaign, but is well-equipped to defend US networks. Rosenbach cited technical and manpower problems as the main obstacles, despite a lack of resources or funding. The Pentagon is reviewing a new cyber strategy and plans to increase investment in cyber command, with a goal of reaching 6,000 personnel by 2018.

site_title: Regulators want changes to short-term loans to handle 'too-big-to-fail' firms
summary: Global banking regulators are pushing for changes to short-term loans to address concerns about "too-big-to-fail" firms, which could pose a threat to the entire financial system. Regulators want to modify repo contracts and securities-lending agreements to give them more time to intervene in a failing institution. The plan involves waiving contractual rights, allowing firms trading with a troubled institution to temporarily suspend early contract termination. This move aims to prevent a financial crisis by giving regulators time to find a buyer or recapitalize the firm.

site_title: China Q1 GDP growth seen dipping to 6-year low, more policy stimulus on cards
summary: China's Q1 GDP growth is expected to slow to a six-year low of 7% due to faltering demand at home and abroad. This has led to concerns about a deeper downturn, potentially fueling job losses and debt defaults. The government is expected to roll out more policy stimulus to avoid a sharper slowdown, with economists anticipating increased fiscal and monetary support. The National Bureau of Statistics will release March activity data, which may offer clues on the economic performance in the second quarter.

site_title: Otto Marine delivers four vessels worth US$36.6 million
summary: Otto Marine delivered four new-build vessels worth US$36.6 million to PT Pertamina Trans Kontinental (PTK) from its PT Batamec shipyard. The vessels include two harbour tugs and two anchor handling tug supplies. Group CEO Michael See expressed optimism about fostering closer business ties with PTK and exploring more opportunities.

site_title: New Zealand food prices edge higher in March
summary: New Zealand food prices rose 0.1% in March, offsetting a 0.7% decline the previous month, to reach a 1.9% annual increase, the largest since December 2011. This rise is largely attributed to grocery prices, which make up nearly 19% of the consumer price index.

site_title: Australia's PanAust rejects US$844m bid from China's Guangdong Rising Assets Management
summary: PanAust Ltd, an Australian copper and gold miner, rejected a US$844 million bid from China's Guangdong Rising Assets Management (GRAM), citing its shares trading above GRAM's offer price. The company, which owns 24% of PanAust, had previously offered A$2.30 a share, but the board believes GRAM should pay more for increased ownership. PanAust is open to discussing a better offer, valuing itself at A$1.1 billion.

site_title: Workers plan limited strike at oil-storage hub in Netherlands
summary: Workers at Royal Vopak, the world's largest independent oil-storage company in the Netherlands, will start a limited strike at the Europoort oil terminal in Rotterdam from 9pm local time on Tuesday. The strike, involving up to 30 workers, is over pay disputes and could be followed by further action. The terminal, which stores about 24.6 million barrels of crude oil and refined products, employs around 250 workers. The strike is the second of its kind in the past 13 years.

site_title: More US poultry flocks infected with bird flu
summary: The US Department of Agriculture reported a rise in poultry flock infections with the deadly H5N2 bird flu, with Iowa identifying its first case and Minnesota confirming eight more. Twenty-two commercial turkey flocks in Minnesota, accounting for over half of the 43 nationwide infected, have been infected in about six weeks. This marks the 12th state to report poultry infections this year.

site_title: Job fears grow among British North Sea oil workers: survey
summary: British North Sea oil workers are increasingly concerned about job prospects, with nearly three quarters considering work abroad. A quarterly survey found nearly a quarter of respondents are not confident in their career prospects over the next five years. Energy giants have announced hundreds of job cuts due to high operating costs and low oil prices. The survey also showed workers are taking industrial action over changes to their employment terms, highlighting growing discontent among the workforce.

site_title: Gazprom plans US$4 billion extra spending in 2015 to target China
summary: Gazprom plans to invest an additional $4 billion in 2015 to prepare for gas supplies to China, following the EU's rejection of a proposed pipeline. The majority of the spending will go towards the eastern gas program, including field development and infrastructure. This move aims to strengthen ties with China, Russia's new main gas customer, after relations with the EU soured over Ukraine. The company's CEO, Alexey Miller, expects the deal to be signed by the end of the year, pending resolution of the price issue.

site_title: Five questions for Mario Draghi from Greece to negative yields
summary: European Central Bank President Mario Draghi is set to address concerns about tapering of quantitative easing, inflation forecasts, and the impact of negative yields on asset purchases. The ECB has been purchasing government and public-sector bonds since March, and Draghi is expected to highlight the positive effects of the stimulus measure. He may also address concerns about the Greek debt crisis and emergency funding for Greek banks. Draghi is likely to reaffirm the need for structural reforms in the euro area to achieve a sustainable recovery.

site_title: Ericsson, Juniper are next as Nokia wakes up industry: Real M&A
summary: Nokia Oyj has confirmed talks to buy France's Alcatel-Lucent for over $13 billion, a move that could trigger a wave of mergers in the communications-equipment industry. The deal would give Nokia a lead in wireless equipment sales and expand into wireline assets. Analysts predict Ericsson and Juniper Networks will need to acquire products to compete, with potential targets including Juniper and Ciena. A takeover of Juniper or Ciena could boost Ericsson's earnings, while Infinera may dilute its earnings. The deal could mark a new era in the industry, with companies seeking to be end-to-end solutions for carriers.

site_title: US seen becoming net energy exporter as shale boosts output
summary: The US is expected to become a net energy exporter by 2029 as shale oil production increases, according to the Energy Information Administration. Crude oil output will reach 10.3 million barrels per day in 2025 and 9.4 million in 2040. The development of shale formations in North Dakota, Texas, and other states has unlocked significant supplies, and oil companies are adapting to market conditions by focusing on shale production. This shift is expected to lead to US energy exports exceeding imports from 2029 through 2032 and 2037 through 2040.

site_title: IMF to 'closely' examine currency swings
summary: Top finance officials from leading economies will closely examine currency swings at IMF talks in Washington this week. The US Treasury has urged China to stop intervening in markets to let its currency, the renminbi, rise, citing its undervaluation. The euro has also depreciated against the dollar, largely due to the European Central Bank's bond purchase program. The IMF will discuss developments in these currencies, with no accusations expected from the US about the euro's value. The talks come ahead of the spring meeting of the IMF and World Bank.

site_title: Oil prices rise as US oil output seen dropping
summary: Global oil prices rose for the fourth consecutive day, with US prices jumping after a government report predicted a 57,000-barrel-per-day drop in US shale-oil production in May. West Texas Intermediate futures closed at $53.29 a barrel, and Brent North Sea crude settled at $58.43 a barrel. Analysts noted the drop in production could impact prices, but the global supply remains high, with Commerzbank analysts stating the drop would be a "drop in the ocean."

site_title: SpaceX bid to recycle rocket fails again
summary: SpaceX's attempt to recycle its Falcon 9 rocket by landing it upright on an ocean platform failed for the second time, despite a successful launch of its cargo mission to space. The rocket landed on a droneship but was deemed too damaged for survival. SpaceX aims to revolutionize the rocket industry by making equipment reusable like commercial planes, saving millions of dollars. The company has a 50-50 chance of success this time, but believes an 80% chance by the end of the year.

site_title: Fast-food workers to rally in 230 US cities seeking higher pay
summary: Fast-food workers in the US will hold rallies in 230 cities on Wednesday, seeking higher pay and union rights. The Fight for US$15 campaign, backed by unions, is demanding a minimum wage of $15 and unionization for workers. This is the largest action yet for the movement, which began in 2012. McDonald's recently announced plans to raise wages and offer paid vacation at company-owned stores, but organizers say this is not enough, citing the need for a $15 wage nationwide.

site_title: Lafley pivots from builder to demolition man as he shrinks P&G
summary: Procter & Gamble CEO AG Lafley is downsizing the company, shedding billions in assets to slim down to 65 leading brands, as it struggles to compete with cheaper brands and new rivals. Lafley, who has already announced plans to exit as many as 100 product lines, aims to divest at least $19 billion more in assets. The move is part of a broader trend among large companies to question the benefits of scale and focus on core products. Lafley's successor, David Taylor, will need to woo investors and customers to restore P&G's fortunes.

site_title: Dollar falls after US retail report disappoints
summary: The US dollar fell against major currencies after a disappointing US retail sales report showed cautious consumer spending in March. The dollar weakened to $1.0654, up from $1.0571, after the 0.9% gain was slightly weaker than expected. The eurozone industrial production rebounded 1.1% in February, gaining support from the European Central Bank's quantitative easing program, which is expected to influence the ECB's monetary policy meeting on Wednesday.

site_title: Europe: Stocks disconnect as Nokia rings up Alcatel takeover
summary: Europe's main stock markets diverged on Tuesday, with Frankfurt's DAX 30 index and Paris's CAC 40 index falling 0.90% and 0.69% respectively, while London's FTSE 100 index edged up 0.16%. The news of Nokia's proposed takeover of Alcatel-Lucent sparked a mixed reaction, with Nokia's share price plunging 3.60% and Alcatel-Lucent surging 16%. The International Monetary Fund raised its eurozone growth forecasts but warned of fragile growth due to the Ukraine crisis and Greece's uncertainty.

site_title: Mideast sovereign funds slash property buys amid oil price fall
summary: Middle East sovereign wealth funds (SWFs) significantly reduced their real estate investments worldwide, with outbound property investment dropping 31% to $5.84 billion in 2014 due to the decline in oil prices. This cautious behavior is expected to continue, potentially impacting investment in Europe, where a large proportion of investments were made. The decline in oil prices has led to a more cautious approach from natural resource-based SWFs.

site_title: Middle-aged capitalism
summary: The rise of mergers and acquisitions (M&A) in modern capitalism is a sign of economic weakness, as companies rely on external growth to compensate for internal stagnation. Despite M&A deals enhancing innovation for the acquiring firm, they don't significantly contribute to societal innovation, which is crucial for wealth creation and social progress. Productivity growth has been abysmal since the Great Recession, averaging 0.9% annually, and is linked to the decline of entrepreneurship and the rise of older, more entrenched firms. This trend threatens social and economic stability, as weaker productivity growth leads to slower wage and income growth.

site_title: India builds first "smart" city as urban population swells
summary: India is building its first "smart" city, the Gujarat International Finance Tec-City (GIFT), to accommodate its booming urban population, set to swell by 400 million by 2050. The city aims to provide modern infrastructure, including underground utilities, automated waste collection, and a dedicated power supply, at a cost of $1 trillion. The project is part of Prime Minister Narendra Modi's 100 smart city plan by 2022, aiming to attract investment and jobs. Experts, however, question the effectiveness of new cities, suggesting that existing cities need to be transformed instead.

site_title: US: Stocks mostly higher after mixed earnings
summary: US stocks finished mostly higher on Tuesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average rising 59.66 points to 18,036.70, and the S&P 500 gaining 3.41 points to 2,095.84. Earnings from JPMorgan Chase and Wells Fargo exceeded expectations, while Johnson & Johnson trimmed its profit forecast due to the strong dollar. Retail sales rebounded 0.9% in March, and oil stocks rose on rallying crude prices.

site_title: Temasek is single-largest foreign investor in Chinese banks: report
summary: Temasek Holdings, a Singaporean investment firm, is the single-largest foreign investor in Chinese banks, with combined holdings valued at US$18 billion. Chinese banks have outperformed regional peers, with the SNL China Bank index rising 34.71% in the past year, compared to 7.56% for the SNL Asia-Pacific Bank index. This success is attributed to Temasek's significant investment in Chinese banks, which has contributed to their strong performance.

site_title: MAS charts a reassuring, steady course in choppy waters
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has maintained its "stay-the-course" policy, leaving the exchange rate policy band unchanged from January. This decision was seen as a surprise by many economists, who had expected easing or a widening of the policy band due to global economic uncertainties and US interest rate hikes. However, MAS cited short-term factors such as oil price stability and domestic inflation concerns, and emphasized the need for measured responses to global stimulus actions. The policy decision aims to provide stability and consistency for businesses and investors.

site_title: Painting a deeper shade of green
summary: AkzoNobel, a specialty chemicals company, prioritizes sustainability in its business, aiming to increase revenue from environmentally beneficial products, reduce carbon-equivalent emissions, and improve resource efficiency. The company's "Planet Possible" approach seeks to deliver value with fewer resources, guiding its manufacturing, sourcing, and research and development processes. By focusing on sustainability, AkzoNobel aims to drive benefits to its customers while meeting its business goals.

site_title: Pope's iPad fetches US$30,500 at auction
summary: A Pope Francis-owned iPad sold for US$30,500 at an auction in Uruguay, with the winning bid placed by telephone. The iPad, complete with a Vatican certificate of authenticity, was given to a Uruguayan priest by the pope as a gift and later donated to a local school before being auctioned off to raise funds.

site_title: Amazon's cacay nut catches attention of cosmetics makers
summary: The Amazon's cacay nut, native to parts of Colombia, Ecuador, Peru, and Venezuela, is gaining attention as a key ingredient in anti-ageing facial creams, fetching up to US$200 an ounce in beauty shops in LA and London. New plantations are emerging in Colombia, providing a lucrative market for the nut's protein-rich oil, which contains antioxidants and retinoids. As demand rises, cosmetics makers like L'Oreal and Procter & Gamble are incorporating cacay into their products, with Kahai SAS, a Colombian company, playing a significant role in the nut's commercialization.

site_title: China lag unsettles copper industry as Goldman sees rout
summary: China's copper demand has slowed, unsettling the global copper industry, with Goldman Sachs predicting a price drop to $5,200 by the end of the year. The country, which consumes nearly half of the world's copper, is shifting its growth focus from industrial to services, potentially reducing its influence on global metal markets. Despite this, some industry executives, including Aurubis CEO Bernd Drouven, believe China's demand may still increase, but at a slower pace, and that the industry's aging mines will struggle to meet moderate global demand growth.

images.alt_text: Mining executives talking up copper's long- term prospects at this week's industry gathering in Chile are unsettled by the level of Chinese buying in recent weeks.

site_title: Exor offers US$6.4 billion for PartnerRe to break up Axis deal
summary: Exor SpA has offered US$6.4 billion to acquire PartnerRe, aiming to break up the reinsurer's planned merger with Axis Capital Holdings. The offer is US$130 per share, 16% above the implied value under the Axis agreement. The deal would create the world's fifth-largest property-and-casualty reinsurer. Exor, controlled by the Agnelli family, is seeking opportunities in the finance industry after selling its stake in SGS for US$2.1 billion in 2013.

site_title: SGX's shares surge to 5-year high on speculation of China link
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) shares surged to a 5-year high, reaching S$8.63, following a 10.5% year-to-date gain. The sudden interest in the counter has sparked speculation about a potential link between Singapore and China, with Macquarie Equities Research citing a "good relationship" and sufficient RMB liquidity as reasons for SGX's appeal. The speculation may be fueled by increased daily volume and the potential for a new CEO, which could benefit from increased volume in the China A50 futures contract.

site_title: Asian, African leaders heading to Indonesia
summary: Indonesia is hosting the 60th anniversary of the Asian-African Conference, a six-day summit starting on Sunday, April 13. Leaders from 109 Asian and African countries, including Chinese President Xi Jinping, Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe, and South African President Jacob Zuma, are attending. The conference aims to strengthen ties between the two continents and produce three outcomes: the Bandung Message, a strategic partnership, and a declaration in support of Palestinian independence.
