It provides technical and operational support to prevent and fight international crime, offering training, investigative support, and secure communications. The organization is governed by a general assembly and an executive committee, with member countries paying annual statutory contributions. Interpol's headquarters is in Lyon, France, with regional offices and national central bureaus in various countries. The organization aims to facilitate global police cooperation and combat international crime.

site_title: French air traffic controllers scrap planned strike
summary: French air traffic controllers called off a planned strike, set to begin Thursday to Saturday, after a "satisfactory" meeting with management over working conditions. The SNCTA union had demanded talks on working practices and retirement age, currently 59. The strike was initially planned for April 16-18 and April 29-May 2, during key holiday periods, but will not affect flights this week. The decision comes after last week's industrial action grounded around half the flights in French airspace, with minimal chaos for passengers.

site_title: Petrobras says board to discuss financial results on April 22
summary: Brazil's state-controlled oil producer Petrobras said it will meet on April 22 to discuss third-quarter and full-year 2014 financial results, following delays due to a corruption scandal. The company expects to release financial data pending board approval.

site_title: Keeping cyber security threats at bay
summary: Cybersecurity threats are evolving rapidly due to technological advancements and the blurring of professional and personal boundaries. Companies must integrate their security and IT infrastructure to better cope with cyber attacks. Advanced malicious tools and techniques, such as spear phishing and malware, pose significant threats, particularly to smaller companies with limited resources. A clear cybersecurity strategy, including a dedicated Chief Information Security Officer (CISO), is crucial for minimizing risk and becoming more cyber resilient. Organizations must prioritize information protection, raise awareness, and leverage security services to mitigate damage and prevent attacks.

site_title: US budget deficit rises to US$53 billion in March
summary: The US ended March with a budget deficit of US$53 billion, a 43% increase from the same period last year. Analysts had forecast a US$43 billion deficit. The current fiscal year-to-date deficit is US$439 billion. Receipts totaled US$234 billion, up 8% from last year, while outlays were US$287 billion, up 14%. If adjusted for timing-related transactions, the deficit would have been US$89 billion.

site_title: As Clinton eyes presidency, so does Republican Rubio
summary: US presidential frontrunner Hillary Clinton has few serious challengers within her party, but the Republican field remains wide open. Marco Rubio, a first-term Senator from Florida, has joined the race, along with Senators Ted Cruz and Rand Paul. Rubio aims to take voters beyond the dynastic Bush-Clinton dynamic and connect with young, Hispanic, or African-American voters. Clinton has started her campaign, hitting the road and striking a note of soft humility, while Rubio's entrance could lead to a duel with former Governor Jeb Bush.

site_title: UK retail spending rises at fastest rate in almost a year: BRC
summary: British retail spending rose 4.7% in March, its fastest annual rate in almost a year, driven by an early Easter and improving consumer morale. This is the largest year-on-year rise since April 2014. Retail spending in the first three months of 2015 increased 2.8% compared to the same period last year. Consumer prices are also falling at their fastest rate since 2006, with inflation forecast to remain flat for a second month in a row. The sector is experiencing "slow but steady growth."

site_title: Alaska Airlines flight makes emergency landing near Seattle after worker locked in cargo
summary: An Alaska Airlines flight made an emergency landing in Seattle after a worker was found trapped in the cargo area under the cabin. The worker had fallen asleep and was discovered after 14 minutes in the air. The pilot reported hearing banging from beneath the aircraft after takeoff. The plane returned to Seattle-Tacoma International Airport, and a ramp agent was found inside the cargo hold. No injuries were reported, and the cause of the incident is under investigation.

images.alt_text: A Los Angeles-bound Alaska Airlines flight made an emergency landing at a Seattle-area airport on Monday afternoon after it took off with a worker trapped in a cargo area under the cabin, where he had fallen asleep, the US carrier said.

site_title: New Zealand house prices and volumes rise in March
summary: New Zealand house prices reached a record level in March, with sales volumes also rising strongly, according to the Real Estate Institute of New Zealand. The increase was driven by Auckland's strong housing market, where prices hit a record. The Reserve Bank of New Zealand has expressed concerns about the renewed housing market strength, particularly in Auckland, and is considering changes to lending rules for property investors, which may lead to higher interest rates.

site_title: Singapore Q1 GDP grew 2.1% from year ago, exceeds market forecasts
summary: Singapore's Q1 GDP grew 2.1% from the previous year, exceeding market forecasts. This is the same growth rate as the previous quarter. The manufacturing sector contracted 3.4% on a year-on-year basis, while quarterly growth came in ahead of expectations. The Q1 growth is at the low end of the 2015 forecast of 2-4% growth.

images.alt_text: The Singapore economy grew by 2.1 per cent on a year-on-year basis in the first quarter of 2015 based on advance estimates, the same rate of growth as that achieved in the previous quarter.

site_title: Crossing borders quickly and safely
summary: Governments worldwide are implementing solutions to balance speed and security in cross-border movement, amid growing volumes of goods and people. Electronic tools such as ePassports with RFID chips and biometrics are being introduced to enhance security, while industry players develop new biometrics and passenger data systems to streamline processes. Integrated border management aims to minimize duplication and improve efficiency, with private sector solutions helping border agencies share data and connect with international organizations.

site_title: Citigroup names Asia Pacific chief Bird to head global consumer bank
summary: Citigroup has named Stephen Bird, its Asia Pacific chief, as the new head of its global consumer bank, replacing Manuel Medina-Mora. Bird will be based in Asia and will oversee the US consumer bank, which will be led by Jane Fraser, currently the head of the US consumer bank, who will also be based in Miami. The changes will take effect on June 1.

site_title: Dollar rises on euro ahead of US retail sales
summary: The US dollar advanced against the euro on Monday ahead of key US retail sales data, marking the sixth consecutive day of gains. A strong retail sales report could boost confidence in the Federal Reserve raising interest rates, but a weak report could reverse the dollar's momentum. Analysts will also be watching US inflation data this week for further guidance on the Fed's monetary policy. The euro fell to US$1.0571, with some predicting the greenback could soar to fresh multiyear peaks if the US economy shows signs of recovery.

site_title: Benefits of Integrated Border Management
summary: Implementation of Integrated Border Management (IBM) can optimize border crossings by streamlining processes, consolidating agencies, and reducing costs. This system offers benefits such as consistent processes, shorter processing times, and enhanced law-enforcement efforts through data sharing. Companies and authorities can enjoy lower costs and improved coordination, resulting in a more efficient border management system.

site_title: NZ business confidence eases in Q1: survey
summary: New Zealand business confidence eased slightly in Q1, with 23% of firms expecting general business conditions to improve, down from 24% in the previous quarter. Financial services businesses now expect domestic interest rates to fall over the next 12 months, reversing a previous expectation of a rate rise. The New Zealand Institute of Economic Research's quarterly survey of business option (QSBO) also showed moderating activity.

site_title: The US$9 trillion short that's seen sending the dollar even higher
summary: US investors are ignoring trillions of reasons why the dollar will continue to appreciate, according to former IMF economist Stephen Jen. The world is "structurally short" the dollar, with sovereign and corporate borrowers owing a record $9 trillion in US currency. This pent-up demand will underpin years of dollar appreciation, as borrowers must repay their loans in coming years. Jen's comments come as investors speculate that the dollar rally is fizzling out.

site_title: A medical dilemma
summary: Counterfeit medicines pose a significant threat, with an estimated 10% of all medicines being sold as fake in 2006 and 100,000 deaths annually in Africa. The global market for anti-counterfeit technologies, such as Radio Frequency Identification Tags, is valued at $152.2 million in 2014 and expected to triple by 2020. Efforts to track and trace medical drugs are underway, but the problem remains a growing concern, resulting in 700,000 deaths globally annually from counterfeit malaria and tuberculosis drugs.

site_title: Easy Taxi launches premium limo service
summary: Easy Taxi has launched a premium limo service in Singapore, offering six and seven-seater private cars to commuters for group travel, including family outings and business meetings. This move joins rival platforms Uber and GrabTaxi in providing private hire limousines. The service is available to those seeking more choices when traveling in groups.

site_title: US: Stocks sag ahead of first-quarter earnings
summary: US stocks declined ahead of the first-quarter earnings season, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 0.44% to 17,978.38, the S&P 500 losing 0.46% to 2,092.47, and the Nasdaq Composite Index down 0.15% at 4,988.25. General Electric's reversal from a 10.8% gain on Friday weighed on the market, while traders hedged their bets ahead of earnings reports from major companies.

site_title: High tech back-up for the police
summary: Interpol is boosting its presence in Asia to combat sophisticated cybercrime. Researchers at the Interpol Global Complex for Innovation (IGCI) in Singapore identified a vulnerable space in virtual currency transactions, allowing illegal data to be stored within encrypted transactions. This discovery was made in collaboration with Kaspersky Lab and aims to spread awareness among law enforcement agencies and encourage public support to find solutions. The IGCI provides cutting-edge research, training, and partnerships to help police worldwide fight cybercrime, with a focus on cyber threat intelligence and coordination of operations.

images.alt_text: The Interpol Global Complex for Innovation (IGCI), a cutting-edge R&D facility for the identification of crimes and criminals, innovative training, operational support and partnerships was officially opened yesterday.

site_title: Malaysians confused over whether GST replaces service charge
summary: Malaysia's hospitality industry is in disarray over the government's decision to allow hotels and restaurants to impose a service charge only if a collective agreement is signed between employer and employee. The 10% service charge, which has been in place for over 20 years, has been replaced by a 6% Goods and Services Tax (GST). However, the GST is being levied on the service charge, causing confusion among consumers. Some businesses have stopped charging the service charge, while others are imposing it, leading to frustration among consumers and businesses alike.

site_title: Securing the supply lines
summary: Global supply chains are vulnerable to counterfeiting, piracy, and smuggling due to their complexity, posing significant risks to consumers, companies, and governments. The illicit trade market is estimated to be over $650 billion, with serious health risks and damage to reputations. New technologies, such as serialization and mobile authentication, are being developed to secure supply chains and verify product authenticity. Organizations like Interpol and the Digital Coding and Tracking Association are working with governments and companies to combat illicit trade and employ innovative solutions to address this growing problem.

site_title: The safe city concept
summary: A "safe city" concept aims to enhance public security through networked security sensors and systems. The concept consists of five interconnected ideas: integrated systems, multi-agency collaboration, situational awareness, video and data analytics, and automated processes. This approach integrates law enforcement, first responders, businesses, and citizens to reduce response times and improve incident response. By leveraging advanced systems and data analysis, safe cities can better predict and react to incidents, ultimately improving public safety and security.

site_title: Oil prices in modest rise after last week's rally
summary: Oil prices modestly rose last week, extending gains from the previous week. US benchmark West Texas Intermediate closed at $51.91 a barrel, up 27 cents from Friday, while Brent North Sea crude settled at $57.93. The rally was driven by poor Chinese trade data and speculation of government stimulus measures. However, the market fell after data showed US crude oil supplies increased at a key storage hub, suggesting production continues to swamp the market. Key releases this week include China's economic growth numbers, US inventories report, and Opec's monthly market report.

images.alt_text: World oil prices modestly extended last week's gains Monday in cautious trade as investors digested news of another rise in US crude oil inventories in an abundantly supplied global market.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: PEC, a Singapore-based engineering specialist, has secured a contract worth S$176 million from a UAE client to build an oil storage terminal in Fujairah, UAE. The project, expected to be completed by March 2017, will provide engineering, procurement, and construction services. This is PEC's new contract from a UAE client, marking a significant win for the group.

site_title: Europe: Stocks hit by weak Chinese data
summary: Europe's main stock markets closed mixed on Monday, with London's FTSE 100 index dipping 0.36% and Frankfurt's DAX 30 index down 0.29%. However, Paris's CAC 40 index rose 0.26%. The poor Chinese trade data, which signaled fresh weakness in the world's second-biggest economy, had a negative impact on European stocks.

images.alt_text: Europe's main stock markets closed mixed on Monday as investors digested poor Chinese trade data that signalled fresh weakness in the world's second-biggest economy, dealers said.

site_title: Qualcomm rejects hedge fund call for split
summary: Qualcomm has rejected a proposal by activist investment firm Jana Partners to split the US tech giant into groups focused on chip manufacturing and licensing of its technology. Jana had taken a $2 billion stake in Qualcomm to press the company to break itself up, citing potential value for shareholders. However, Qualcomm's board and management concluded that their business model creates more value for stockholders than an alternative corporate structure. The company stated that synergies provided by their current structure outweigh potential benefits of a split.

site_title: It takes a party
summary: Hillary Clinton's presidential run has sparked debates about policy and unity between parties. Contrary to personality-based analysis, pundits are advised to focus on policy positions as they will significantly impact the outcome. The huge gap between Democrats and Republicans on key issues, such as healthcare, taxes, and climate policy, will likely be reflected in the actual policies adopted by the winner. The parties' unified positions on major issues have led to a level of polarization not seen since the Civil War.

site_title: Frasers Hospitality launches Capri by Fraser in Brisbane
summary: Frasers Hospitality has launched Capri by Fraser in Brisbane, its fourth Australian property. The hotel residence is centrally located in the city's business district, offering a range of hotel facilities and "e-efficiencies" such as iPad-activated check-ins and high-speed internet. It is within walking distance to major attractions, including Queen Street Mall Shopping and the Brisbane Convention and Exhibition Centre. This marks a significant expansion for Frasers Hospitality in Australia, providing serviced residences with modern amenities to suit business and leisure travelers.

site_title: China rejects Taiwan as founding member of AIIB
summary: China has rejected Taiwan as a founding member of the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB), a Beijing-led institution. However, Taiwan is still eligible to become an ordinary member in the future. This decision was confirmed by China's Taiwan Affairs Office, which cited a Hong Kong media report. The rejection comes amid tensions between China and Taiwan, with China viewing Taiwan as a part of its territory.

site_title: Tackling security challenges
summary: Governments and private sector organizations worldwide are gathering in Singapore for Interpol World 2015, a global event addressing complex security risks. Over 250 international industry players from 35 countries will explore innovations in cyber security, safe cities, border management, and supply chain security. The event, supported by Singapore's Ministry of Home Affairs, features cutting-edge technologies and showcases partnerships between public and private sectors to create innovative solutions. Interpol World 2015 runs from April 14 to 16.

images.alt_text: Thomas Herko assistant director, international partnerships & development, Interpol Global Complex for Innovation.
Jack Chia executive director, MP International.

site_title: Making sure the streets are safe
summary: Governments worldwide are adopting high-tech solutions to address security risks in urban areas as cities' populations continue to grow. By 2025, an estimated 4.8 billion people will live in cities, posing complex security challenges. Advanced technologies, such as integrated sensor networks and data analytics, are being used to predict and prevent threats, rather than just responding to them. Private sector companies, like Motorola Solutions and Thales, are providing governments with tools to manage security risks, with cities like Singapore and Mexico City leading the way in implementing "safe city" solutions.

site_title: Former Indian finance minister calls for rate cut
summary: Former Indian Finance Minister Palaniappan Chidambaram has called for lower interest rates, citing the need to sustain economic growth, which has recovered but remains sluggish. Chidambaram, who served as finance minister from 2004 to 2014, stopped short of endorsing the current administration's budget, criticizing its focus on revenue expenditure over capital spending. Finance Minister Arun Jaitley has also advocated for lower rates, despite giving the central bank a mandate to target inflation.

site_title: European banks seen selling 70b euros of property debt
summary: European banks and asset managers plan to sell up to 70 billion euros (S$101.4 billion) of real estate debt and foreclosed assets this year, aiming to strengthen their balance sheets. In the first quarter, over 12 billion euros of property loans were sold, representing a 50% decrease from the previous period. This follows a trend of European banks reducing their exposure to property debt. The sales are part of a broader effort to improve their financial stability and meet regulatory requirements.

site_title: VW chairman in power struggle after comments against CEO
summary: Volkswagen AG chairman Ferdinand Piech is facing a power struggle after making hostile comments against CEO Martin Winterkorn. Piech, 77, has been isolated by other power players at the company, which may mark the beginning of the end of an era at Europe's biggest carmaker. Piech's comments, made two years before his last term as chairman ends, have led to a rebuttal that could signal his loss of influence within the company.

site_title: Homegrown security innovators
summary: Two Singapore-based SMEs, V3 Teletech and TreeBox Solutions, are developing security-related technologies for organizations globally. V3 Teletech's V3NITY platform provides a comprehensive security system with features such as geo-spatial information, route planning, and surveillance capabilities. TreeBox Solutions offers secure mobile communications solutions, including its award-winning OnTalk secure enterprise communicator. Another local SME, Oneberry Technologies, provides specialized IT security solutions with its Oneberry Mobi-Cam surveillance camera platform. These companies are showcasing their products at the Interpol World Exhibition and are expanding their global footprint.

site_title: Pursuing the illusion of unending growth
summary: The International Monetary Fund's (IMF) managing director, Christine Lagarde, warns of the risk of a "new mediocre" of low growth, a concept she previously mentioned. Despite the global recovery, many people feel it's not enough, leading to a search for a "fix." Lagarde emphasizes the need to prevent this new reality, as it could lead to long-term economic stagnation. This suggests that the world is becoming increasingly reliant on the idea of continuous growth, making any slowdown feel disquieting and leaving a sense of uncertainty.

site_title: Lian Beng's Q3 net profit down 45.4%
summary: Lian Beng Group's third-quarter net profit fell 45.4% to S$18.4 million due to a 17.3% decline in revenue to S$202.3 million. However, the group's nine-month net profit rose 5.7% to S$53.9 million. Revenue growth was driven by construction projects, while property development revenue decreased due to the completion of M-Space in the previous year. New businesses, such as overseas property development, are expected to contribute positively to growth in the future.

site_title: Economy improving region by region: BOJ
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) raised its economic assessment for three of Japan's nine regions in its quarterly report, signaling a broadening of the benefits of its stimulus program. The central bank maintained its optimistic assessment for the remaining six regions, citing solid demand at home and overseas as drivers of output and job growth. BOJ Governor Haruhiko Kuroda reiterated the bank's resolve to keep its stimulus intact to achieve its 2% inflation target, despite private consumption remaining weak.

site_title: UK accelerator unveils 10 startups for inaugural S'pore programme
summary: Startupbootcamp FinTech (SBC) has selected 10 startups for its inaugural Singapore accelerator programme, marking the first fintech scheme in South-east Asia. Four Singapore-based startups, including Cryptosigma, Dragon Wealth, Kashmi, and Otonomos, were chosen from 300 global applications. The selected startups collectively raised over S$2.5 million and have 30% revenue-generating capabilities. They will undergo a three-month bootcamp with mentorship from over 100 industry experts and access to partners such as DBS and MasterCard. The programme aims to foster innovation in the financial industry and create knowledge and job opportunities in Singapore.

site_title: Global security firms strut their stuff
summary: International security firms showcased cutting-edge products and services at Interpol World 2015. Aware Inc., a US-based biometrics software provider, demonstrated its biometric authentication and search solutions, including software development kits and workstation applications. Aware has provided high-quality biometric software for over 20 years, complemented by technical support.

site_title: Japan, US aim for TPP progress before summit
summary: Japanese and US officials are set to meet to strike a two-way deal on the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) ahead of a leaders' summit in late April. Success depends on US Congress approving trade promotion authority (TPA) measures to ease passage of trade deals. Japan wants to protect farm products, while the US argues about non-tariff barriers in the auto sector. The talks aim to give momentum to the 12-nation free-trade pact, seen as central to the US "rebalance" to Asia.

site_title: Aussie profit-shifting tax tangle shines spotlight on Singapore
summary: The Australian Senate inquiry into profit-shifting by multinational corporations (MNCs) has highlighted Singapore as a low-tax jurisdiction used to minimize taxes. The inquiry, which includes major firms like Apple and Google, seeks disclosure of profit generated in Australia and moved to low-tax jurisdictions. Australian Treasurer Joe Hockey is under pressure to act, as the mining boom's end threatens public services. The government had previously withdrawn a law requiring public disclosure of taxes paid by companies with revenues over A$100 million. Singapore's tax regime, with a 17% corporate tax rate, is being questioned, with allegations that A$31.4 billion in profits was shifted to Singapore.

site_title: Founder returns to head troubled Kaisa as debt deadline looms
summary: Kaisa Group Holdings' founder Kwok Ying Shing has returned as chairman and executive director, three months after resigning amid a corruption probe. The move comes as the company faces a deadline to pay interest on US dollar bonds to avoid default. The Kwok family controls 49.3% of the company, and its return has boosted confidence in the group, with analysts suggesting it could present upside for bondholders. The appointment also follows changes in Shenzhen's government leadership, which may have improved relations between the company and the government.

site_title: Banking stocks set to be range-bound: JPMorgan
summary: Singapore banking stocks may experience range-bound share prices due to a delayed US Federal Reserve rate hike and slowing loan growth, according to a JPMorgan report. Analyst Harsh Wardhan Modi has downgraded DBS to "neutral" from "overweight" and maintained OCBC as his top pick. The report notes that the probability of a Fed rate hike in June has decreased from 24% to 7%, and loan growth is easing across the board. This may negatively impact DBS and OCBC's loan growth expectations in the first quarter.

images.alt_text: A roll-back in expectations of a hike in rates by the US Federal Reserve, slowing loan growth and a potential lift in asset deterioration could give some pause to investors looking at the Singapore banking sector, a JPMorgan report suggested.

site_title: Top forecaster sees RBA cutting rate to 2%
summary: Top forecaster Andrew Ticehurst predicts the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) will cut the cash rate to 2% in May from 2.25%, then maintain it for the rest of the year to assess policy's impact. The RBA has historically been reluctant to lower rates below a certain point, driven by concerns about the economy's other risks, including high housing and commercial property prices. This move would mark a significant shift from the RBA's stance, which has been to avoid fine-tuning the economy with monetary policy.

site_title: Groupon may divest 4 businesses: analyst
summary: Groupon may divest four businesses, potentially generating up to $730 million in cash, to raise funds for expansion into an e-commerce marketplace. Analyst Gene Munster predicts a majority stake in Ticket Monster could fetch $500 million, while smaller units could yield $30-$100 million each. Private equity firms are likely buyers. With a market value of $5 billion, Groupon needs to sell non-core properties to free up cash to invest in its marketplace initiative, currently valued at $1 billion in cash and cash equivalents.

site_title: Some pointers on how startups and corporates can team up
summary: Startups and corporations can form successful partnerships by developing inroads, allowing the corporate to leverage the startup's tech savviness and nimbleness. Startups should build contacts and relationships through networking, while corporations can hold competitions or have incubation programs to find the right partner. Startups should also be prepared for long lead times and fill gaps in the corporate's value proposition. Performance-based execution and tangible deliverables are key to ensuring the partnership's success, and both parties must pre-align priorities to achieve common objectives.

site_title: Keppel Infrastructure Trust posts 23% rise in Q1 earnings
summary: Keppel Infrastructure Trust reported a 23.1% rise in Q1 earnings to S$4.3 million, driven by lower electricity and trust expenses. Group revenue slipped 1.1% to S$16.6 million, with operation and maintenance income increasing 0.5% due to higher production of NEWater and O&M tariffs. No distribution was declared for the quarter. The trust expects stable underlying performance from its assets, with plans to evaluate asset enhancement opportunities and seek acquisitions.

site_title: Home service industry among last pots of gold on Internet
summary: The home services industry, valued at $400-800 billion, is being disrupted by online marketplaces connecting consumers with vetted service providers. Companies like Amazon, Google, and startups like Thumbtack and Pro.com are entering the market, offering efficiency and capabilities of the web to local services. Amazon's Home Services and Google's efforts aim to fill the need for installation and assembly services, while startups face challenges in getting traction. The market's growth has brought in new business for some providers, but also poses competition and price pressure, with some companies cutting prices to compete.

site_title: Ong Choon Fah named CEO at DTZ Southeast Asia
summary: DTZ Southeast Asia has appointed Ong Choon Fah as its new CEO, succeeding Ho Tian Lam, who is retiring. Ong will take the helm from May 15. She is the second woman to lead a major property consulting group in Singapore, following Pauline Goh of CBRE.

site_title: Looking ahead towards a full Asean Economic Community
summary: The Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean) is set to become a unified economic community on December 31, 2015, marking a milestone in the region's integration. The Asean Economic Community (AEC) will comprise 640 million people with a combined GDP of $2.4 trillion, equivalent to the world's seventh-largest economy. Despite progress, challenges remain, including free trade in food products and key service sectors. To achieve sustainable growth, Asean must maintain momentum on three interlinked priorities: trade connectivity, financial connectivity, and physical connectivity.

site_title: Opportunities improving for US graduates: report
summary: A new report by Georgetown University's Center on Education & the Workforce found that job opportunities for college-educated workers have never been greater, despite concerns about student debt and a tough job market. From 1967 to 2007, high-skill management and professional jobs rose 14% and now represent 35% of US jobs, while low-skill labor roles declined 10%. The report suggests that technological advancements have increased demand for educated workers, driving up wages for college-educated workers, but reducing wages for high school-educated workers.

site_title: Indonesian property prices, rents seen coming under pressure
summary: Indonesian property prices and rents are expected to come under pressure due to a luxury tax on new apartments and a surge in office space. The government plans to impose a 20% luxury tax on apartments worth over $158,500, affecting most new developments. Additionally, an estimated 1 million sq m of prime office space will flood the market, pushing up vacancy rates past 10%. This may dampen the region's gains and make apartments out of reach for many.

site_title: Pertamina takes hit on fuel cost as oil prices rise
summary: Indonesia's state-owned oil firm Pertamina is taking a loss due to the current retail petrol price of 7,300 rupiah a litre, which is 600 rupiah less than its break-even price. The government, led by President Joko Widodo, removed petrol subsidies in January and capped assistance for diesel, aiming to set a retail price that fluctuates with international prices. However, Pertamina is calling for a change in the situation, and economists say the government has been slow to adjust prices upwards, with the retail price increasing only 11% since January despite a 28% rise in Brent crude prices.

site_title: Keppel Reit Q1 DPU falls 13.7% y-o-y on Prudential Tower sale, lower rental support
summary: Keppel Reit reported a 13.7% drop in distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.70 Singapore cents for the first quarter, largely due to the sale of Prudential Tower and lower rental support. Net property income fell 12.4% to S$34.6 million, while total property income declined 9.4% to S$42.4 million. Despite a 13% quarterly increase in DPU, the Reit's DPU was pulled lower by higher borrowing costs, management fees, and trust expenses.

site_title: How much longer can Opec hold out?
summary: OPEC's 12-member group faces internal divisions and external pressures as it struggles to maintain its production strategy amid a global oil supply glut. With the Iran nuclear deal potentially increasing Iranian crude oil exports, OPEC's net oil exports could fall to $380 billion in 2015, down from $730 billion in 2014. Venezuela, Nigeria, and Iraq, among OPEC members, are urging the group to reduce production levels to stabilize prices and safeguard their economic interests. However, Saudi Arabia and other heavyweight members are resisting cuts, prioritizing their global market share. The June meeting of OPEC will be crucial in determining the group's response to the changing market dynamics.

site_title: Blackstone's property focus pays off
summary: Blackstone's private equity firm has secured a US$14 billion deal with General Electric to purchase a chunk of its real estate assets. This deal solidifies Blackstone's position as the largest private sector landlord in the US, with a total of close to 50,000 rental homes across the country. The firm's property division now oversees US$81 billion of its US$272 billion assets, with real estate accounting for 50% of its core profits over the last two years. The deal marks a significant shift in the power dynamics on Wall Street, with asset managers like Blackstone gaining prominence over risk-averse investment banks.

site_title: Will millennials boost Rand Paul's chances?
summary: Rand Paul, a libertarian Republican senator, believes that his party's nomination as presidential candidate could be boosted by young voters and the Tea Party movement. However, his inconsistent positions on issues such as climate change, foreign aid, and same-sex marriage may alienate conservative Republicans. Paul's attempt to appeal to a broad range of voters may not be effective, and his libertarian views may be at odds with those of some Republicans who share his desire for limited government intervention. The outcome of the 2016 presidential election remains uncertain, with Paul's chances dependent on a coalition of Tea Partiers and millennials.

site_title: Euro tumbles back towards US$1.05
summary: The euro has fallen to its weakest level in four weeks, dropping back towards US$1.05 due to the US dollar's resurgence as investors bet on a potential interest rate hike by the US Federal Reserve. The Australian dollar also plummeted 1.7% to a six-year low, following a contraction in Chinese exports.

site_title: S&P: India's fiscal improvements vulnerable to shocks
summary: India's fiscal improvements, driven by a 25% increase in capital expenditure, are vulnerable to external shocks due to "less than rock solid" public finances, according to Standard and Poor's. The rating agency warns that the government's spending plan could be impacted if divestment targets are not met, potentially leading to a cut in capital spending. India has a BBB- rating from S&P, with a "stable" outlook, and has a fiscal deficit target of 3.9% of GDP for the current fiscal year.

site_title: No immediate decision to demolish 38 Oxley Road: PM Lee
summary: Singaporean Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong announced that there is no immediate decision to demolish the late Lee Kuan Yew's home at 38 Oxley Road, where his daughter now resides. The elder Lee had indicated in his will that he wanted the property demolished after his death or when his daughter moves out. However, PM Lee emphasized that the government will consider the matter at a later time, following Dr. Lee's wishes.

images.alt_text: After Mr Lee stepped down from the Cabinet in May 2011, a bust of him, made several years ago by British sculptor Sydney Harpley, was displayed in Parliament House.

site_title: India CPI eases, rate cut expected
summary: India's retail inflation slowed to 5.17% in March, easing concerns about the central bank's rate-cutting plans. The rate cut expected as the central bank governor Raghuram Rajan waits for commercial lenders to pass on previous cuts. Rajan aims to keep inflation below 6% by January, and predicts that inflation will remain benign if food prices don't spike. This could lead to a rate cut by the end of March 2016, with some economists predicting a rate cut to 7%.

site_title: IFCA's software stock up 1,300% over the past year
summary: IFCA MSC Bhd, a Kuala Lumpur-based software company, has seen its shares surge 14-fold over the past 12 months, with earnings increasing just as fast. The company has taken an 80% market share among Malaysian developers and is expanding into China, with early adopters including billionaire Wang Jianlin's Dalian Wanda Group. IFCA's cloud-based software for property companies has performed exceptionally well, with a 1,300% stock increase over the past year.

site_title: Bill on HDB officers' powers, new penalties passed
summary: The Housing and Development (Amendment) Bill 2015 has been passed, granting HDB officers the power to enter flats by force in cases of imminent danger to public health or safety. Flat owners who break leasing rules will face variable penalty amounts, up to S$50,000, and the HDB will be able to enter flats for urgent repairs with a warrant. The Bill also introduces stricter fines and financial penalties for unauthorised renovation and stricter enforcement of renovation regulations.

site_title: New varsity index takes in Japan's hidden inflation
summary: A new index in Japan measures hidden inflation by tracking price changes of new products sold at retail shops, accounting for nearly half of goods sold. The index, developed by a professor and a Japanese association, suggests inflation is rising faster than the official rate, with a 4% increase in 2008 compared to the BOJ's 2% target. This gap could lead to less monetary stimulus, as further inflation could deter wage growth and consumer spending.

site_title: Brisk sales for local projects at recent launches
summary: Local Singaporean projects have seen brisk sales following recent launches, injecting life into the strata office sales market. At GSH Plaza, over 60 out of 100 units were sold in the first phase sale, a promising start. Similarly, North Park and Botanique at Bartley also reported steady sales. This upbeat performance is a positive sign for the market, which has been quiet in Q1, and could boost sales for upcoming projects.

site_title: China March exports in shock 15% fall
summary: China's export sales contracted 15% in March, the largest decline in about a year, as domestic demand and foreign demand waned. Imports also fell 12.7% from a year ago, the largest slump since 2009. A rising yuan is believed to have hurt demand for Chinese goods and services abroad. This contraction could heighten concerns about China's economic growth, which has been steadily grinding to its lowest in a quarter of a century. Authorities are urging action to arrest the export slowdown and protect jobs, which are a priority for the government.

site_title: Mega refineries require use of new oil products supertankers
summary: The growth of mega refineries is driving the development of new oil products supertankers, similar to those used for crude oil shipping in the 1970s. Traders require larger tankers to efficiently move oil products such as petrol, diesel, and aviation fuel to Europe, Asia, and Latin America. Vessels capable of carrying up to one million barrels are being purpose-built and have already been booked by trading powerhouses like Vitol and Shell. These tankers can meet a significant portion of Europe's daily diesel consumption, and their use is expected to increase as the product market grows.

site_title: Singapore firms to spend on expansion, IT: survey
summary: Singapore business leaders intend to invest more in new markets and technology despite reduced confidence in the economy, with 70% predicting continued growth over the next year. The majority (70%) cite entering new markets as the reason for increased spending, with Asia (excluding the Indian sub-continent) expected to see the largest sales increase. IT investment is also seen as crucial for productivity, with business intelligence and data analysis, enterprise-level systems, and cloud computing being top priorities.

site_title: Ascott's Citadines to open in Vietnam, Malaysia and UAE
summary: Ascott Limited has secured contracts to manage its first Citadines Apart'hotels in Vietnam, Malaysia, and the UAE by 2018. The 200-unit Citadines Regency Saigon will open in Ho Chi Minh City, the 253-unit Citadines Waterfront Kota Kinabalu in Malaysia, and the 81-unit Citadines Culture Village Dubai in 2017. This expansion brings the Citadines portfolio to over 12,000 units in 81 properties and 52 cities across Asia-Pacific, Europe, and the Gulf. The move is attributed to the rise of independent travelers seeking flexibility in their travel choices.

site_title: Wanted: Global buyers for China's 1.6 trillion yuan muni bond flood
summary: China's government is facing a record-breaking issue of 1.6 trillion yuan in municipal bonds, with yields reaching a four-month high of 3.70%. The government is seeking to attract foreign investors to boost domestic bond holdings, with regulators studying improvements to programs allowing overseas access to domestic markets. Despite rising borrowing costs, economists believe the yuan's low volatility and attractive investment opportunities will attract foreign funds, supporting the market in the medium term.

site_title: Leong Poh Kee, a low-key player in a glamorous trade
summary: Leong Poh Kee, a Singapore-based luxury watch distributor, is known for its cash-only transactions and impressive presence at the Baselworld watch fair. The company, founded in 1931 by Leong Poh Kee, has grown to include subsidiaries like SARCAR, a high-end Swiss brand, and Leonard Timepieces, which owns the Apple Watch trademark in Switzerland. Leong Poh Kee's managing director, William Leong, is believed to be the owner of SARCAR and Leonard Timepieces. The company has expanded its charity projects to Thailand and Bhutan, and is run by William Leong, the younger son of the company's founder.

site_title: Seoul bourse urged to extend trading to overlap region
summary: The Korea Financial Investment Association (Kofia) has urged the Seoul bourse to extend trading hours by at least an hour to overlap with other regional markets, such as Hong Kong and mainland China. This move aims to encourage foreign investment and support local share prices, which are expected to rise 2,500 points this year due to low valuations and improved corporate earnings prospects. Kofia's head, Hwang Young-key, believes this will provide foreign investors with better trading opportunities and increase the market's competitiveness.

site_title: Adrian Pang, Sharon Au as Mr & Mrs Lee
summary: TV actress Sharon Au has landed the role of Kwa Geok Choo, the young woman who captured Lee Kuan Yew's heart and became his wife, in the mega-budget musical "The LKY Musical". The musical, set to open on July 21, chronicles the early life of Singapore's founding father from his days at Raffles College to the founding years of modern Singapore. The production features a substantial cast, including Dick Lee, Adrian Pang, and Sebastian Tan, and is directed by Steven Dexter. The musical's score, composed by Dick Lee, is described as "chamber music" and marks a departure from his previous works.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Thailand's aviation industry faces safety concerns following an ICAO audit, leading to bans on new charter flights and increased inspections. Singapore Airlines and Tigerair are expected to see short-term negative impacts, while GuocoLeisure's shares are poised to break out with a target price of S$1.13. China Everbright Water's shares are recommended to buy with a target price of S$1.17, driven by the adoption of public-private partnerships and market opportunities in the Chinese water sector.

site_title: Enhanced rules to control drones
summary: Singapore is enhancing its regulatory framework for drones to curb risks associated with their operations. The Civil Aviation Authority of Singapore (CAAS) and the Singapore Police Force (SPF) introduced the Unmanned Aircraft (Public Safety and Security) Bill, which proposes rules to prohibit drones carrying dangerous materials, require permits for over 7kg drones, and restrict flying over protected areas or during major events. The changes are expected to take effect from June 1, with applications for permits available through CAAS' online system.

site_title: AXA to sell general insurance at 34 SingPost branches
summary: AXA has announced a partnership with SingPost to sell general insurance at 34 post offices across Singapore, expanding on life insurance options already available. The goal is to reach a wider customer base, including SMEs, overseas workers, and expats, and to generate approximately 25% of sales. AXA aims to expand to 44 branches and offer business solutions by Q3 2015, with the partnership seen as a way to meet customers face-to-face and provide high-quality products and services.

site_title: Disruption fears, Chinese stockpiling keeping oil prices off lows
summary: Oil prices remain relatively firm despite fears of supply disruptions in the Middle East and China's strategic stockpiling, which had been expected to drive prices lower. The Brent crude oil price has risen to $59.50 a barrel, 26% above its January 2015 low point, as traders are concerned about the potential for sudden supply disruptions due to conflicts in Iraq, Yemen, and Syria. However, the US Energy Information Administration predicts that oil prices will slump further in 2015, but could recover in 2016 if prices rise.

site_title: SPH Reit's Q2 DPU up 0.7% at 1.4 S'pore cents
summary: SPH Reit reported a 0.7% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.4 Singapore cents for its Q2 2025, driven by 2.8% year-on-year growth in gross revenue to S$52.5 million and a 3.7% rise in net property income to S$40.3 million. The retail trust's gearing level remains unchanged at 26%. Despite a challenging retail environment, the trust expects its two properties, Paragon and The Clementi Mall, to remain resilient and turn in a steady performance.

site_title: Hyundai is top mass-market car in China: survey
summary: Hyundai Motor surpassed Volkswagen and Buick as China's top mass-market auto brand in a state-backed survey. BYD Co ranked first among Chinese automakers, ahead of Toyota and Ford. The survey, based on 11,500 Chinese consumers in 30 cities, funded by the Ministry of Industry and Information Technology. Hyundai's deliveries in China declined in the first quarter, while Audi led in the luxury auto category. The survey aims to promote domestic brands and encourage consumer loyalty.

site_title: US: Wall St opens flat with earnings on deck
summary: US stocks opened flat on Monday, following three consecutive days of gains, ahead of a busy corporate earnings season. The Dow Jones fell 0.02%, the S&P 500 gained 0.01%, and the Nasdaq Composite rose 0.12%. Market uncertainty remains due to ongoing US-EU trade talks and tariff threats, but investors are optimistic about the corporate earnings reports set to be released this week.

site_title: Chinese hackers may have spied on S-E Asia, India since 2005
summary: Chinese hackers have been spying on governments and businesses in South-east Asia and India since at least 2005, according to a report by FireEye Inc. The operation, likely state-sponsored by the Chinese government, targeted those with key political, economic, and military information about the region. The hackers used phishing emails and reused malware dating back to 2005, managing and prioritizing attacks through a developed system. The attack remains ongoing, with FireEye continuing to see attacks against its customers, who are among the targeted targets.

site_title: AXA to provide general insurance at 34 SingPost branches
summary: AXA has partnered with SingPost to offer general insurance at 34 post offices across Singapore, expanding on the life insurance options available at the same branches since January. The partnership aims to target the mass market and specific segments such as SMEs and expats. AXA expects the partnership to make up 25% of life insurance sales and plans to expand to 44 branches by Q3 2015. The partnership is part of AXA's strategy to use the post office as a new channel to reach customers.

images.alt_text: SingPost and insurance company Axa announced on Monday that their partnership, AXA@POST, will now allow customers purchase general insurance at 34 post offices across the island.

site_title: ISS says Iceberg's allegations do not warrant an against vote on Noble's resolutions
summary: ISS Proxy Advisory Services has issued a report stating that Iceberg Research's allegations against Noble Group do not warrant an "against" vote on any of the resolutions at its Annual General Meeting on April 17. ISS found that Noble Group has provided reasonable responses and clarifications to many of Iceberg's claims, particularly regarding the significant gap between market and carrying values of Yancoal stake. As a result, ISS recommends a "For" vote on the adoption of financial statements and directors' and auditors' reports.

site_title: Tat Hong Holdings unit to sell Shah Alam property in Malaysia
summary: Tat Hong Holdings' subsidiary, Tat Hong Plant Hire, is selling its Shah Alam property in Malaysia to Hiro Food Packages Manufacturing for RM$17.5 million. The 8,166 square metre freehold land has a net book value of RM6.1 million and will result in a gain of approximately RM11.5 million after expenses. The sale follows the relocation of Tat Hong's core crane rental operations to larger premises in Kulaijaya, Johor.

site_title: East Asia must tap low oil prices to recast fiscal policy: World Bank
summary: The World Bank has urged East Asian developing countries to capitalize on low oil prices to reform their fiscal policies, ensuring sustainable growth. The region's developing economies are expected to grow 6.7% this year and 6.9% next, with China's growth moderating to 7% over the next two years. The report highlights the need for countries to reduce fuel subsidies, increase energy taxes, and invest in infrastructure and social protection programs. Despite projected growth, the region faces risks, including higher US interest rates and diverging monetary policies, which could reduce capital flows and generate financial volatility.

images.alt_text: Low oil prices will benefit developing countries such as Cambodia, Laos, the Philippines and Thailand, the World Bank said.

site_title: Apple likely to boost watch production quickly: analysts
summary: Apple is expected to boost watch production quickly after strong pre-orders for the Apple Watch, which reached nearly one million in the US on the first day. Analysts predict the company will sell 2.3 million watches in the April-June quarter, with BofA Merrill Lynch expecting 4 million shipments. Despite mixed reviews, the Apple Watch is expected to outsell similar watches from Samsung and other brands, with analysts predicting it will be highly disruptive to the traditional fashion watch market.

site_title: QE having a significant effect on economy: traders
summary: The European Central Bank's quantitative easing program, which began in January, is having a significant impact on the eurozone economy, according to a Reuters poll of money market traders. 14 of 21 traders said the program is having a meaningful effect, driving down real interest rates and inflation, and weakening the euro against the dollar. The program aims to bring inflation back to the ECB's target of 2% and is expected to allot 105 billion euros at its weekly operation. The euro has weakened nearly 7% against the dollar since the program's announcement.

site_title: M1 profit up 6.6% in Q1 with more customers
summary: M1, a Singaporean telco, reported a 6.6% increase in net profit to S$45.7 million in its first fiscal quarter of 2015, driven by growth in mobile and fixed services revenues. The company added 18,000 mobile customers and increased its mobile data contribution to 41.3% of service revenue. EBITDA margin was 40.8% of service revenue, and customer acquisition cost decreased 10.5% quarter-on-quarter. M1 expects moderate growth in net profit for 2015.

site_title: India's retail inflation slows to 3-month low of 5.17% in March
summary: India's annual consumer price inflation slowed to a 3-month low of 5.17% in March, down from 5.37% in February, as food prices moderated. This is lower than the predicted 5.5% by analysts. The easing of food price inflation eased to 6.14% in March from 6.88% in February. The data suggests a moderation in inflation, which could have a positive impact on the country's economy.

site_title: STI at 7-year high but penny stocks rule again
summary: The Straits Times Index reached a 7-year high, closing at 3,484.39 on Monday, driven by a surge in penny stocks. However, the STI's performance was overshadowed by the trading activity in these lower-priced stocks, which accounted for 90% of the market's turnover. Despite this, the STI's volume was just 15% of the total market business, down from last year's average.

site_title: Digital route to Singapore's heritage
summary: Startup Yeng & Leong is introducing 3D laser scanning technology to preserve Singapore's heritage, making it accessible to the masses. The company, founded by brothers Jason and Vincent Lim, aims to create a digital legacy of heritage sites and artwork. By offering 3D laser scanning services, Yeng & Leong hopes to provide affordable virtual tours and archives, allowing individuals and industries to build a digital time capsule of Singapore's heritage. The technology has the potential to revolutionize the preservation and accessibility of the country's cultural assets.

site_title: S'pore businessman trips up Apple Watch launch
summary: A Singapore businessman, William Leong, owns the trademark for "Apple Watch" in Switzerland, which could prevent Apple from using the name in the country. Leong's company, Leong Poh Kee, is a regional distributor of luxury timepieces and holds the trademark since 1985. The trademark is set to expire in December, allowing Apple to launch the Apple Watch in Switzerland. However, Apple has declined to comment on the issue, and intellectual property lawyers suggest the company may challenge the mark.

images.alt_text: This high-end Apple Watch, with a casing in 18-karat gold, is one among the range of Apple watches available from April 24 in nine markets - excluding Switzerland, where the 'Apple Watch' trade mark is held by a watch company said to be owned by a Singaporean.

site_title: Germany needs to significantly increase investment: experts
summary: Germany needs to significantly increase investment to ensure long-term growth and job creation, experts say. A panel of experts, led by Marcel Fratzscher, concluded that the country is suffering from a huge investment gap, with private sector investment being around 100 billion euros too low per year. The commission recommended boosting public spending, creating new instruments to mobilize private funds, and investing in areas like broadband networks, digital services, and energy systems. The government has agreed to examine the recommendations, with Economy Minister Sigmar Gabriel stating the commission's work was "excellent".

site_title: Opec publication urges non-members to help stabilise oil market
summary: Opec has urged non-member countries to cooperate in stabilizing the oil market, criticizing those that refuse to do so. The organization notes that it has shouldered the burden of ensuring market stability alone in the past, and now calls for a shared burden. Opec's call comes as the oil market faces uncertainty due to various factors, including tariffs, sanctions, and market outlook. The organization's request for cooperation is seen as a bid to maintain price stability and mitigate the impact of market volatility.

site_title: Singapore Wrap Monday
summary: M1 reported a 6.6% rise in net profit to S$45.7 million in Q1 2015. The Straits Times Index reached a 7-year high, but trading was dominated by penny stocks. The National Wages Council has a new chairman, Peter Seah. There's no immediate decision to demolish Lee Kuan Yew's house. LHN Limited shares retreated from early gains after debuting on Catalist. Meanwhile, Vietnam was surprised by the US Trump tariff announcement, and the Asian garment industry is bracing for higher US tariffs.

site_title: India core consumer inflation seen at around 4.15% in March: analysts
summary: India's core consumer price index (CPI) is estimated to have risen around 4.15% in March, accelerating from an advance of around 4.1% in February. This marks a slight acceleration from the three-month low of 5.17% in March compared to 5.37% in February. The increase is attributed to rising inflation.

site_title: Oil companies' profits hit by quest for crude price exposure
summary: Big oil companies' profits have declined in the past eight months due to a strategic decision to increase exposure to oil price fluctuations. The companies, including BP, Shell, and Total, have built more price-sensitive contracts into their portfolios, reflecting their historical views of high oil prices. This decision, made around the mid-2000s, has led to increased sensitivity to oil price changes, with profits sinking more than they would have five years ago. The impact is particularly significant for Shell, with a potential hit of billions of dollars a year due to the current oil price.

site_title: OKP Holdings's unit awarded S$20m contract for infrastructure work
summary: OKP Holdings' subsidiary Eng Lam Contractors has been awarded a S$20.38 million contract from JTC Corporation for infrastructure work at Tuas South Avenue 7/14, involving road, drainage, sewer, and soil improvement works. The project has two phases with completion expected by January 20, 2016, and January 20, 2017. The contract increases OKP's net construction order book to S$317.2 million until 2019.

site_title: Time running out on Greek debt talks, says top EU official
summary: European Commission Vice President Valdis Dombrovskis warned that Greece is running out of time to implement structural reforms and secure further financial aid from its EU/IMF lenders. The talks between Greece's newly-elected leftist government and its eurozone partners have been tense, and time is limited to prevent Greece from running out of cash. The euro's depreciation against the dollar reflects the differing monetary policy stances of the European Central Bank and the Federal Reserve.

site_title: Lian Beng Group's net profit in Q3 down 45.4%
summary: Lian Beng Group's net profit for Q3 2015 fell 45.4% to S$18.4 million, with revenue decreasing 17.3% to S$202.3 million. For the 9-month period, net profit rose 5.7% to S$53.9 million, while revenue increased 6.3% to S$569.9 million. The company attributes the growth to its project-based construction, recurring income, and mature stages of its newer businesses.

site_title: M1 net profit up 6.6% in Q1
summary: M1, a Singaporean telco, reported a 6.6% increase in net profit to S$45.7 million for Q1 2015, driven by a 22.8% rise in revenue to S$294.8 million. The telco added 18,000 mobile customers and lowered customer acquisition costs. M1 expects moderate growth in net profit for fiscal 2015.

site_title: Morgan Stanley says dollar parity beckons for euro by Q4
summary: Morgan Stanley forecasts the euro will drop below dollar parity by Q4, reaching 98 cents, driven by continued euro weakness from European Central Bank money creation. The bank predicts the pound will fall to US$1.39 by June due to UK parliamentary elections and potential fiscal austerity. Reuters polling shows the euro falling 2-3 cents to US$1.03 by March 2016.

site_title: Chinese hackers targeted SE Asia, India for last decade: report
summary: A cyber espionage group, dubbed APT30, has been secretly targeting governments and businesses in Southeast Asia and India for the last decade, stealing sensitive information since 2005. Sponsored by China, the group's main objective appears to be data theft, with a focus on regional politics, economics, and military issues. The group's sustained and planned development effort, coupled with its regional targets, suggests state sponsorship, with China denying involvement. The region has seen high levels of targeted cyber attacks, with many going undetected.

site_title: China to surpass US as top cause of modern global warming
summary: China is expected to surpass the US as the main cause of man-made global warming since 1990, with China's cumulative greenhouse gas emissions projected to outstrip those of the US in 2015 or 2016. This shift raises questions about historical blame and pressure on Beijing to act. China's rapid economic growth has led to a significant increase in emissions, and the country's per capita emissions are now comparable to those of the EU. The UN climate summit in Paris in December will discuss global targets for reducing emissions beyond 2020, with China having already set a goal to peak its emissions around 2030.

site_title: China's influence over AIIB a concern ahead of founders' meeting
summary: China is set to have a significant influence over the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB) due to a proposed shareholding structure. Under the plan, Asian nations are expected to own 75% of the bank, despite not having the largest economic weight. This has raised concerns among other member nations, including India. The issue will be discussed at a meeting of AIIB member nations in Washington this week.

site_title: China's Tencent hits US$200b market cap for first time
summary: China's Tencent Holdings Ltd reached a market capitalization of over $200 billion for the first time, surpassing US tech firms like Amazon, IBM, and Oracle. The company's shares rose 5.38% to close at HK$170.50, valuing it at $206 billion. This marks a 52% increase from the beginning of the year, rivaling the valuations of Facebook and Alibaba.

site_title: Taiwan rejected as founding member of AIIB: Beijing
summary: Taiwan's bid to join the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB) as a founding member was rejected by Beijing, citing Taiwan's failure to meet a key naming condition. The rejection comes despite President Ma Ying-jeou's statement that joining the AIIB would be good for Taiwan, but only if it is treated with dignity and equality. Taiwan has been seeking international recognition and participation in global agreements, but Beijing regards Taiwan as part of its territory and has historically opposed international recognition.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower
summary: Malaysia's shares ended lower on Monday, with the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index slipping 2.23 points to close at 1,842.08. A total of 2.12 billion lots, valued at RM1.87 billion, were traded, with 467 gains and 378 losses.

site_title: Italy Feb industry output rebounds after Jan drop, boosting recovery hopes
summary: Italy's industrial output rebounded 0.6% in February after a 0.7% drop in January, boosting hopes for economic recovery. This is the strongest monthly gain since June last year and the third consecutive rise in output. Industrial production, which shows a strong correlation with GDP, has risen 0.4% in the December to February period compared to the previous quarter. The data suggests that Italy's economic recovery is gaining momentum, despite patchy "hard" data on output and spending.

site_title: SPH Reit Q2 DPU up 0.7%
summary: SPH Reit reported a 0.7% increase in second-quarter distribution per unit to 1.4 Singapore cents, driven by a 2.8% year-on-year rise in gross revenue to S$52.5 million. Net property income rose 3.7% to S$40.3 million. The Reit retained S$1 million for future distribution. Rental income increased at Paragon and Clementi Mall, with rents rising 11.6% at Paragon and declining 8.8% at Clementi Mall due to tenancy adjustments.

site_title: Singapore: Penny stocks rule even as STI rises to 7-year high
summary: The Straits Times Index rose 12.01 points to 3,484.39, its highest closing in about seven years, despite a low volume of trading in major stocks, with only 15% of total market activity coming from STI components. Penny stocks, particularly those priced below S$0.20, dominated the market, with 17 of the top 20 most active stocks falling in this category. The Singapore Exchange (SGX) shares surged 2.3% on high volume, sparking questions about the sudden interest in its shares.

site_title: VW's Audi sales up 4.4% in March to record 177,950 cars
summary: Volkswagen's Audi division reported a 4.4% increase in March sales to 177,950 cars, the highest-ever monthly record. First-quarter deliveries reached a record 438,250 cars, driven by strong demand for the A3, Q3, and A6 models. This growth is attributed to increased demand for luxury vehicles, particularly SUVs.

site_title: Asia shares mostly up, China data spurs Shanghai rally
summary: Asia markets rose on Monday, with Shanghai rallying 2.17% after disappointing Chinese data sparked hopes for easing measures. Hong Kong advanced for an eighth straight session, while Seoul gained 0.53%. Tokyo ended marginally lower, and Sydney eased 0.14%. The gains were driven by positive Wall Street leads, boosted by merger announcements and asset sales.

site_title: Regulatory and permit framework for drones to be enhanced
summary: The Civil Aviation Authority of Singapore (CAAS) and Singapore Police Force (SPF) have introduced the Unmanned Aircraft (Public Safety and Security) Bill, strengthening the regulatory and permit framework for drones. The framework, set to take effect on June 1, prohibits drones from carrying hazardous materials, requires permits for flights over protected areas, and imposes penalties for offenses. The enhanced framework aims to address safety and security concerns, pending a government study on a broader framework for drone use. Permits will be required for drones weighing over 7kg and flying in certain areas.

site_title: GLP acquires land parcel in Sao Paulo
summary: Global Logistic Properties (GLP) has acquired a 818,000 sq ft land parcel in Cajamar, Sao Paulo, Brazil, to develop GLP Park Cajamar. The project is expected to be completed by March 2016 and will complement GLP's existing logistics portfolio in Brazil, which is 97% leased. The development site is fully permitted and located 30km from metropolitan Sao Paulo, providing access to major highways and logistics sub-markets.

site_title: Oil rises towards US$59, supported by US drilling slowdown
summary: Oil prices rose towards US$59 a barrel on Monday, driven by a slowdown in US drilling and increased bets on higher prices. Front-month Brent crude futures rose 82 cents to US$58.69 a barrel, while US crude rose 78 cents to US$52.42 a barrel. Speculators raised net long positions in US crude futures and options, and open interest in WTI strike options for US$60 and above has risen steadily since January. However, analysts warn that a big rally is unlikely due to a global market surplus and deteriorating fundamentals.

site_title: Statoil could cut over 10% of jobs: report
summary: Norwegian oil giant Statoil may cut 2,400 jobs, approximately 11% of its workforce, due to the plunge in global oil prices. The job cuts, targeting engineering and administrative staff, are part of a programme to generate $1.7 billion in annual savings. Statoil has already reduced its investment budget by 10% and warned of further staff reductions following an 8% cut last year. The company aims to bolster productivity and achieve the cost-cutting targets amid the current low oil prices.

site_title: Keppel Infrastructure Trust Q1 earnings up 23%
summary: Keppel Infrastructure Trust reported a 23.1% rise in earnings for Q1 2025 to S$4.3 million, driven by lower electricity and trust expenses. Group revenue slipped 1.1% to S$16.6 million due to a decline in finance income. Cash generated from operations decreased to S$13.5 million, mainly due to transaction costs related to a merger and acquisition. The earnings beat expectations, despite a decline in revenue.

site_title: Keppel Reit's Q1 DPU falls 14% on Prudential Tower selloff, lower rent support
summary: Keppel Reit reported a 13.7% drop in distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.70 Singapore cents for its Q1 2015, citing a 14% decline in Prudential Tower's value following its selloff. Net property income fell 12.4% to S$34.6 million, and total property income decreased 9.4% to S$42.4 million. The Reit attributed the decline to lower rental support and higher borrowing costs.

site_title: Foreign stock investors like Indonesia...but love Philippines
summary: Foreign investors, particularly from Indonesia, are flocking to the Philippines, with net foreign purchases reaching $1.1 billion in the first quarter, the highest in almost three years. Strong corporate earnings, government stimulus programs, and increased weighting in MSCI indexes are driving the influx. In contrast, Indonesia and Vietnam saw lower net foreign buying, while Thailand recorded net selling. The Philippine benchmark index has clocked 27 record finishes this year, driven by the consumption-driven economy and strong fundamentals. A US interest rate hike remains a risk, but analysts believe the country's domestic spending and fundamentals can mitigate this risk.

site_title: National Wages Council has new chairman
summary: Singapore's National Wages Council has a new chairman, Peter Seah, replacing Professor Lim Pin who led the council from 2001 to 2014. Seah, a DBS Group Holdings and DBS Bank chairman, was deputy chairman of the 2014/2015 NWC. The Ministry of Manpower expressed appreciation for Lim Pin's leadership and welcomed Seah's expertise, citing the importance of tripartite trust in guiding sustainable wage adjustments for Singaporeans.

site_title: No tension 'tolerated' as China limits visits to Hong Kong
summary: China has limited visits to Hong Kong, restricting mainlanders to one visit per week, amid tensions over congested public transport, emptying shop shelves, and increased prices. The decision aims to curb "parallel trading" of goods, with about 4.6 million travelers affected. Hong Kong's leader, Leung Chun-ying, warned against further protests, calling them "unruly" and "counter-productive." The policy was adopted by Beijing and aims to reduce pressure on the city's border.

site_title: Japan, US aim for Pacific trade pact progress before summit
summary: Japanese and US officials will meet to discuss a two-way deal for the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) free-trade pact, aiming for progress before a leaders' summit on April 28. Success depends on US Congress approving trade promotion authority (TPA) measures. Discussions will focus on remaining gaps in agriculture and the auto industry, with Japan seeking to protect farm products and the US arguing over non-tariff barriers in the auto sector. A strong showing by Japan's ruling bloc in local elections may help smooth the way for a trade deal.

site_title: Singapore business leaders to spend on regional expansion, IT: survey
summary: Singapore business leaders are slightly less optimistic about economic expansion, predicting 70% of the economy will continue growing over the next year, a 12-point decrease from 2014. Despite this, 70% of leaders plan to invest in new markets and technology. The survey, part of the American Express/CFO Research Global Business and Spending Monitor, found that business leaders in Singapore intend to allocate more funds to IT and regional expansion, reflecting their efforts to pursue growth in the face of uncertainty.

site_title: India's fiscal health remains vulnerable spot: S&P
summary: India's fiscal health remains a vulnerable spot in its sovereign credit profile, according to Standard & Poor's. The agency reaffirmed India's BBB- credit rating with a "stable" outlook, citing structural fiscal weaknesses. Despite strengthened budgetary performances, concerns over subsidies and heavy government debt persist. A financial or commodity shock could potentially unwind India's fiscal improvements, according to S&P credit analyst Kim Eng Tan. This warning comes as Moody's recently raised India's outlook to "positive", bringing it closer to a potential credit rating upgrade.

images.alt_text: India's fiscal weakness remains a vulnerable spot in its sovereign credit profile, ratings agency Standard & Poor's said on Monday, warning that a financial or a commodity "shock" may unwind fiscal improvements.

site_title: Easy Taxi offers private limousines for hire
summary: Easy Taxi has launched Easy Taxi Premium in Singapore, offering private hire limousines for hire. The service features six and seven-seater limousines with a base fare of S$55, plus S$10 per stop and S$10 per 15 minutes for waiting. This move joins Uber and GrabTaxi in providing private hire limousines to commuters, particularly during peak hours and weekends.

site_title: Dubai's DGCX to set date in two weeks for launch of spot gold
summary: Dubai's DGCX plans to launch a spot gold contract in two weeks, according to Ian Wright, chief business officer. The exchange is still in talks with a local bank, but progress is being made. The 1 kg, 0.995 purity gold contract was originally scheduled for last June, following a similar launch by the Singapore Exchange and Shanghai Gold Exchange in Asia. The move aims to give Asian countries more pricing power over gold, challenging the dominance of London and New York in trading. A launch date is expected to be announced in the coming weeks.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares end down 0.01%
summary: Tokyo stocks ended flat, dropping 0.01% on Monday, after reaching 15-year highs. The Nikkei 225 index closed at 19,905.46, down 2.17 points from Friday's close. Investors locked in profits after the recent gains, and traders brushed off new Trump threats to extend the stocks rally.

site_title: Parliament: Dr Lee Wei Ling to continue staying at Oxley Rd home
summary: Singapore's Parliament decided not to immediately decide on the fate of the late Lee Kuan Yew's Oxley Road home. His daughter, Dr Lee Wei Ling, will continue to live there, according to Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong's statement.

site_title: No immediate decision to demolish Lee Kuan Yew's Oxley Road house: PM Lee
summary: Singapore's founding prime minister Lee Kuan Yew's Oxley Road house will not be demolished immediately, Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong stated in parliament. Lee Kuan Yew's daughter, Lee Wei Ling, will continue to live in the house, and the government will consider demolition only when she no longer resides there, as per her father's wishes. The prime minister assured that the government will respect Lee Kuan Yew's wishes if Lee Wei Ling no longer lives in the house.

site_title: PEC clinches S$176m contract in UAE
summary: PEC Ltd has secured a contract worth S$176 million from a new client in Abu Dhabi to provide EPC works for a new oil storage terminal in Fujairah, UAE. The project is expected to be completed by March 2017 and is PEC's second major win from the Middle East this year. The contract is not expected to impact the company's earnings for the financial year ending June 30, 2015.

images.alt_text: Engineering specialist PEC has been awarded a new contract worth S$176 million from a new client in Abu Dhabi. The group will provide engineering, procurement and construction (EPC) works for a new oil storage terminal in Fujairah, the United Arab Emirates (UAE).

site_title: Parliament: Khaw explains how HDB flats are selected for Sers
summary: Singapore's National Development Minister Khaw Boon Wan explained in Parliament how the Government selects HDB flats for the Selective En bloc Redevelopment Scheme (Sers). Selection is based on suitable rehousing sites, economic viability, and financial resources. The Government assesses these factors to determine which blocks can be redeveloped under the scheme.

site_title: Europe: Shares halt rally after poor China data
summary: European shares halted their rally after poor economic figures from China, with the FTSEurofirst 300 index down 0.3% at 1,640.83 points. TGS shares sank 10.6% after cutting revenue guidance and laying off workers. The halt in rally follows recent gains, which were attributed to mining and healthcare stocks. The decline in European shares comes as US-EU trade talks remain a focus, with tensions over tariffs still present.

site_title: AirAsia to list Indonesia, Philippines units
summary: AirAsia, Asia's largest budget airline, plans to list its Indonesia and Philippines units through initial public offerings (IPOs). The move, announced by CEO Tony Fernandes, is subject to board approvals. Both AirAsia Indonesia and AirAsia Philippines are doing well, with great support from their respective governments. No timeline or value for the IPOs was provided. The plan aims to separate the two businesses, which will be listed independently once the approvals are granted.

site_title: Australia: Shares fall after weak Chinese trade data
summary: Australian shares fell 0.1% to close at 5,960.3 after weak Chinese trade data, with export sales contracting 15% in March and import shipments at their sharpest rate since 2009. The S&P/ASX 200 index earlier reached a 5-week high, but turned negative after the data release. The decline was attributed to concerns about sputtering economic growth in Australia's largest trading partner.

site_title: Interpol office in Singapore boosts fight against cyber crime
summary: Interpol has opened a new office in Singapore, the Interpol Global Complex for Innovation (IGCI), to combat cybercrime. The office, which was formally opened on April 13, 2015, will provide support to law enforcement agencies worldwide in addressing emerging cyber threats.
