According to Interpol's secretary general, Jurgen Stock, cybercrime has become a top priority as people, homes, and critical infrastructure become increasingly networked. The new office will help Interpol stay ahead in the fight against cybercrime.

site_title: China rejects Taiwan as founding member of policy bank
summary: China has rejected Taiwan's application to join the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB) as a founding member, citing the need for an "appropriate name" for Taiwan. Despite this, Taiwan is still welcome to become an ordinary member in the future. The decision reflects China's ongoing efforts to assert control over Taiwan, with the Chinese government viewing Taiwan as a renegade province.

site_title: BOJ sees economy improving region by region, keeps upbeat view
summary: The Bank of Japan has raised its economic assessment for three regions, signaling that its stimulus program is having a broader impact. The central bank maintains its optimistic view for the remaining six regions, citing solid demand at home and overseas. Despite a weak private consumption, the BOJ expects Japan's economy to continue recovering moderately, with Governor Haruhiko Kuroda reaffirming the bank's commitment to achieving a 2% inflation target. The BOJ will release fresh forecasts on April 30, with some analysts speculating that the central bank may ease stimulus if inflation forecasts are revised downward.

site_title: Dubai housing prices fall slightly in Q1: JLL
summary: Dubai housing prices fell slightly in the first quarter of 2015, with apartment sale prices dropping 2% and villa sale prices falling 1%. Rental values for both apartments and villas remained flat. JLL predicts residential prices will fall by up to 10% in 2015, citing a temporary factor that may lead to increased demand and higher prices in the future.

site_title: Proxy advisory firm ISS criticises Noble Group on audit committee
summary: ISS criticizes Noble Group's audit committee composition, citing the need for non-executive directors and a chairman not overcommitted to restore investor confidence. The ISS report comes weeks after Noble denied claims of improper accounting made by Iceberg Research. The proxy adviser's recommendations can impact shareholder voting, and Noble did not immediately comment on the ISS report ahead of its annual shareholders' meeting.

site_title: China's March exports down 14.6% as measured in yuan
summary: China's March exports declined 14.6% from a year ago, according to yuan-denominated data, while imports fell 12.3% in the same period. This suggests a lacklustre trade sector, contributing to China's slowing economy. A trade surplus of 18.2 billion yuan was recorded, contrary to analysts' expectations of a 12% increase in exports and an 11.7% drop in imports. The data raises concerns among policymakers about the impact on the economy.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks rise slightly; plastics, transport gain
summary: Taiwan's stocks rose 0.12% on Monday, driven by gains in the plastics and transportation sectors. The main TAIEX index increased 11.67 points to 9,629.37. Formosa Plastics Corp led the plastics sub-index with a 1.18% gain. The gains were a mixed performance compared to other regional bourses.

site_title: Yoma declares US fund as substantial shareholder since October
summary: Yoma Strategic Holdings announced that US investment firm Eaton Vance Corp has been a substantial shareholder of the company since October due to an error in its security ownership monitoring process. Eaton Vance has a 5.02% stake in Yoma, exceeding the substantial shareholder reporting threshold. The error was corrected following communication with an employee of Yoma, and Eaton Vance's stake remains unchanged at 5.02%.

site_title: Financial industry lobby seeks longer Seoul bourse trading hours
summary: South Korea's financial industry association is pushing for extended trading hours at the Seoul bourse, citing the need to attract more foreign investment. The current 3 pm local time closure is an hour earlier than mainland Chinese markets and two hours earlier than Hong Kong. Industry association chairman Hwang Young-key believes longer trading hours will allow foreign investors to better trade between markets in the region. He expects local share prices to rise 2,500 points this year, driven by low valuations and improved corporate earnings prospects.

site_title: Groupon market value seen as high as US$6 billion with divestments
summary: Groupon may divest four businesses to raise cash for its e-commerce expansion, potentially netting up to $730 million. Analyst Gene Munster estimates a majority stake in Ticket Monster could fetch $500 million, while smaller units could yield $30-100 million each. Groupon has struggled to boost sales and post an annual profit, and the company may sell non-core properties to free up cash for new initiatives. The sale of assets could help Groupon acquire online retailers or a payments business to compete with Amazon and eBay.

images.alt_text: Groupon could divest four businesses in the next two years, netting as much as US$730 million, to raise cash as it expands into an e-commerce marketplace, according to Gene Munster, an analyst at Piper Jaffray Cos.

site_title: Japan Feb core machinery orders fall 0.4% from Jan
summary: Japan's core machinery orders fell 0.4% in February, missing economists' expectations of a 2.8% decline, and following a 1.7% drop in January. This suggests companies are cautious about raising capital spending amid economic uncertainty. Compared to last year, core orders rose 5.9%, higher than economists' 3.7% forecast.

site_title: World Bank cuts East Asia growth forecast, warns of risks to outlook
summary: The World Bank has cut its 2015 growth forecast for developing East Asia and China to 6.7% and 7.1% respectively, down from previous forecasts of 6.9% and 7.2%. The cut is attributed to global uncertainties, including a strengthening dollar and higher US interest rates, which may raise borrowing costs and reduce capital inflows. The report also warns of risks to the regional outlook, including a slowdown in Japan and the euro area, and a significant slowdown in China, although policy buffers and fiscal room mitigate these risks.

site_title: Top China official goes on trial for graft
summary: China's former state assets chief Jiang Jiemin went on trial for corruption, accused of bribery and abuse of power. He is one of the highest-ranking officials to fall in China's anti-graft drive, and an ally of ex-security chief Zhou Yongkang. Jiang worked in China's petroleum industry for decades and rose to become chairman of China National Petroleum Corp, before being tapped to oversee state-owned enterprises. The trial marks the first investigation of a Central Committee member, amid President Xi Jinping's vow to root out corruption.

images.alt_text: China's former state assets chief Jiang Jiemin went on trial for corruption on Monday, one of the highest-ranking figures to fall in the country's much-publicised anti-graft drive and an ally of ex-security chief Zhou Yongkang.

site_title: Aussie dollar drops toward six-year low as China trade slumps
summary: Australia's dollar dropped to a six-year low, reaching 76.05 US cents, after China reported a 12.3% decline in imports and a 14.6% decline in exports. The decline was attributed to concerns about China's slowing economy, which may impact demand for Australian and New Zealand goods and services. Economists estimate China's economy expanded 7% in the first quarter of 2015, the slowest pace since 2009. The decline in China's trade also led to a 1% drop in the Aussie currency from the previous week.

site_title: Hot stock: LHN retreats from early gains
summary: LHN Limited, a real estate management services firm, made its debut on Catalist with an initial public offering (IPO) price of S$0.23. The stock surged 13% to S$0.26 in early trading before falling back to S$0.23. The IPO raised S$17 million, with 73.9 million shares sold to private investors. This marks the first IPO in Singapore this year.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks rally to seven-year high as volatility surges
summary: Hong Kong stocks surged to a seven-year high, reaching 27,881.85, amid rising volatility and speculation of stimulus from Chinese authorities. China's exports dropped 14.6% in March, prompting speculation of increased stimulus. Goldman Sachs raised its target price for Hong Kong Exchanges & Clearing Ltd, while China Merchants Bank Co announced plans to sell shares. The Hang Seng Index rose 2.2%, its largest daily gain since 2007, driven by increased investment from Shanghai traders via the cross-border bourse link.

site_title: Ascott to manage Citadines Apart'hotels in Vietnam, Malaysia and UAE
summary: Ascott Limited has secured contracts to manage its first Citadines Apart'hotels in Vietnam, Malaysia, and the UAE. The 200-unit Citadines Regency Saigon in Ho Chi Minh City and the 253-unit Citadines Waterfront Kota Kinabalu in Malaysia are set to open in 2018. The 81-unit Citadines Culture Village Dubai will open in 2017.

site_title: Broker's take: Some S-Reits may be hit by Shenzhen-Hong Kong travel restrictions
summary: OCBC Investment Research warns that S-REITS with Hong Kong retail exposure, such as Mapletree Greater China Commercial Trust (MGCCT) and Fortune Reit, may be impacted by proposed travel restrictions between Shenzhen and Hong Kong. The restrictions, which would limit Shenzhen residents to one visit per week, could reduce tourist numbers at malls like MGCCT's Festival Walk and Fortune Reit's Fortune Kingswood, which cater to mainland Chinese shoppers. OCBC estimates that these malls' business models are not heavily reliant on gross turnover rents.

site_title: Hong Kong stocks up 0.37% at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.37% at the open on Monday, following a rally in Shanghai that has seen it nearly double over the past year. The Hang Seng Index gained 101.94 points to 27,374.33, while mainland China's Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.95% and the Shenzhen Composite Index added 0.51%. The gains follow a strong start to the week for the Shanghai market, with the Shanghai Composite Index more than doubling in the past 12 months.

site_title: Twitter turns Clinton's "H" logo into target for ridicule
summary: Hillary Clinton's campaign logo, featuring a blocky blue "H" with a horizontal red arrow pointing to the right, sparked ridicule on Twitter, with many comparing it to FedEx's logo and a World War II-era Hungarian fascist party logo. The logo's design was criticized, with some suggesting it was a result of a misstep by the campaign team. The logo's similarity to other designs also raised questions about its originality, with WikiLeaks tweeting a logo with a similar arrow design.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 1.08 points to 1,843.23. Volume was 51.19 million lots worth RM14.18 million, with gainers outnumbering losers 112 to 47.

site_title: Kaisa founder Kwok returns as chairman as debt deadline looms
summary: Kaisa Group Holdings founder Kwok Ying Shing has returned as chairman and executive director, three months after resigning amid a corruption probe. The move comes as the company faces a deadline to pay interest on dollar bonds, and Tianjin-based developer Sunac China Holdings has agreed to buy the Kwok family's stake in Kaisa. Kaisa's bonds due in 2018 were little changed, and the shares remain suspended from trading in Hong Kong. Kwok's return is seen as an attempt to stabilize the company before a potential debt restructuring.

site_title: Germanwings plane evacuated after bomb scare
summary: A Germanwings flight from Germany to Italy was evacuated late Sunday due to a bomb threat, with passengers and crew vacating the Airbus A320 in an orderly fashion. The pilot received a call from the air traffic tower to abort the flight, and federal police received the threat. The plane was searched by sniffer dogs while passengers were offered alternative flights. The incident occurred just days after a Germanwings plane crashed in the French Alps, killing everyone on board.

site_title: Gold holds above US$1,200, but US rate hike worries weigh
summary: Gold prices remain above $1,200 an ounce, but US rate hike concerns weigh on the market. The Federal Reserve official Jeffrey Lacker hinted at a possible rate hike in June, and if not, gold could rise up to $1,250. Despite this, spot gold remained flat at $1,206.93 an ounce, and US gold for June delivery was up 0.2% at $1,207.20 an ounce. A delay in the rate hike has boosted bullish bets on Comex gold futures and options.

site_title: China allows mainland investors to open multiple A-share accounts
summary: China has allowed mainland investors to open multiple A-share accounts, effective Monday, to support capital markets development and innovation. The move comes after Chinese stocks reached seven-year highs last week, despite concerns over looming initial public offerings. The China Securities Depository and Clearing Co Ltd (CSDC) will strictly control the process, allowing only investors with real need to open multiple accounts. This change aims to cater to investors' varying needs and promote market growth.

site_title: Airbus needs more time to decide on A380 changes
summary: Airbus will not abandon its A380 programme despite slow sales, its CEO Fabrice Bregier stated. Emirates has requested engine redesigns, but Airbus plans to add seats and improve aerodynamics instead, aiming for the programme to break even by the end of the year. Meanwhile, the A350 model has seen no issues with Qatar Airways after two months of service, with Airbus aiming to deliver up to 10 A350s per month by 2018. The company maintains its financial performance and does not plan to spend indiscriminately on redesigns.

site_title: STI up 6.31 points at opening, following gains in US, Europe
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 6.31 points to 3,478.69 at opening on Monday, following gains in the US and European markets. The top gainers included Keppel Corporation and the Singapore Exchange. 110 million shares worth S$68 million changed hands, with gainers outnumbering losers 123 to 46.

site_title: Hillary Clinton launches White House bid to champion 'everyday Americans'
summary: Hillary Clinton has launched her presidential campaign, becoming the first female candidate to run for the White House. She has positioned herself as a champion of "everyday Americans" and will focus on building a grassroots organization and engaging directly with voters. Clinton's campaign marks a departure from her previous campaigns, with a softer rollout and a focus on middle-class families. She faces a bruising primary from Republican rivals, including Jeb Bush and Ted Cruz, who have already released attack ads. Clinton leads opinion polls among Democrats, but experts warn she must tread a fine line in aligning herself with President Obama's policies.

site_title: Manulife's bancassurance agreement with DBS Bank is credit negative: Moody's
summary: Manulife Financial Corporation has signed a 15-year bancassurance agreement with DBS Bank, covering four markets in Asia. The deal requires Manulife to pay $1.2 billion upfront and ongoing variable payments. Moody's considers the agreement credit negative due to the dilutive impact on Manulife's core Canadian market, where it has a strong presence and scale, and the more volatile international operating environment. This agreement weakens Manulife's credit profile, as it expands its international operations.

site_title: A dangerous imbalance
summary: Global financial markets face a dangerous imbalance due to growing assets and shrinking yields, forcing investors to take increasing risk. Central bank actions, technological changes, and demographic shifts are driving volatility, while low interest rates and currency fluctuations exacerbate the issue. The European Central Bank's quantitative easing has pushed European bond yields into negative territory, while the US Federal Reserve prepares for higher interest rates. This imbalance threatens the financial system, and policymakers must address it to prevent unfunded liabilities and asset-price bubbles.

site_title: Britain's Miliband seeks to bolster economic credentials in bid to win power
summary: Britain's opposition Labour leader Ed Miliband is set to unveil a manifesto on Monday, pledging to protect national finances, end tax avoidance by the rich, and build a fairer society. The manifesto aims to bolster Labour's economic credentials ahead of the May 7 election, where polls indicate a close contest between Labour and Prime Minister David Cameron's Conservatives. Miliband's plan includes reducing the budget deficit and balancing the books by 2020, a looser target than the Conservatives' aim of a surplus by 2018/19.

site_title: Amazon drones could deliver packages for just US$1: study
summary: Amazon is reportedly exploring the use of drones to deliver small packages for as low as $1, with deliveries potentially arriving in as little as 30 minutes. A study by ARK Invest suggests this could be a cost-effective alternative to existing same-day delivery options. Amazon has already obtained a waiver from the Federal Aviation Administration to test unmanned aircraft, and the company estimates it would need to spend around $100 million to buy drones and $300 million to deploy them annually.

site_title: Hong Kong tycoon urges city to welcome Chinese shoppers
summary: Hong Kong tycoon Ronnie Chan urges the city to welcome mainland Chinese shoppers, warning that turning them away could damage the retail industry and lead to job losses. Chan's comments come as protests against parallel traders, who buy necessities to resell in China, drive up local costs of living. Total visitors from China fell 12.4% during the recent Ching Ming and Easter holidays, prompting the government to consider curbs on tourist arrivals. Chan notes that discouraged mainland visitors could also lead to losses for Hong Kong retailers and the jobs market.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong should welcome mainland Chinese shoppers as turning them away will damage its retail industry and may lead to job losses, according to Ronnie Chan, chairman of Hang Lung Properties Ltd.

site_title: CFDs and their many attractions
summary: The global capital markets have seen a surge in growth due to central banks' efforts to drive economies through inflation expectations. Despite 25 central banks cutting interest rates this year, inflation expectations have not yet responded. This has led to rising inflation at an asset level, creating opportunities for traders and investors. Contracts for Difference (CFDs) have seen strong growth globally over the last 10 years due to their flexibility, access to a large range of markets, and low costing structure. CFDs are an alternative to traditional trading, offering leverage and the ability to sell short, but require a strong trading plan and risk management.

site_title: China developer Evergrande classifies debt as equity, cuts leverage
summary: China's Evergrande Real Estate Group has reduced its debt by a third by classifying some debt as equity, according to analysts' calculations based on its public filings. This move makes it easier and less costly for the company to borrow. Evergrande issued perpetual debt instruments and increased fair value gains on properties, resulting in a lower debt-to-equity ratio. The company is seeking additional funding to expand, and this strategic move is expected to help it navigate the market.

site_title: India's March consumer inflation likely edged up for fourth month: poll
summary: India's consumer inflation likely rose to 5.5% in March for the fourth consecutive month, driven by heavy rains that increased food prices. The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) kept interest rates on hold, citing inflationary pressures, but economists expect a rate cut by the end of June. The RBI targets bringing inflation down to 4% by 2017/18, but the current rate is within the 6% upper end of its target range.

site_title: Oil prices rebound while gold firms
summary: Oil prices rebounded last week, rising to $56.84 a barrel for Brent North Sea crude and $50.80 for West Texas Intermediate, driven by concerns over Iran's nuclear deal and a split among US Federal Reserve policymakers on interest rate hikes. Gold also firmed, supported by geopolitical and economic uncertainty, while certain commodities, such as copper and tin, fell due to swings in investor sentiment over China's growth outlook.

site_title: China, Russia and eastern Europe boost defence spending: study
summary: China, Russia, and eastern European countries significantly increased their defence spending in 2014, with China's spending rising 9.7% to $216 billion. Russia's spending increased by over 8% to $84.5 billion, while Ukraine's budget jumped by over 20% to $4 billion. The US remains the world's top military spender, but its budget shrank by 6.4% in 2014, while Saudi Arabia's spending rose 17% to become the second-largest spender. Global military spending totalled $1.8 trillion in 2014, a 0.4% decrease from the previous year.

site_title: Saudi Arabia bets price plunge will add years to the oil era
summary: Saudi Arabia's petroleum minister, Ali al-Naimi, has signaled that the kingdom will continue to pump oil despite falling prices, defying industry expectations. The move is aimed at protecting market share from rising US shale oil production and addressing concerns about flagging long-term demand due to climate change and increasing energy efficiency. Al-Naimi's strategy, dubbed a "war on shale," may have pushed prices down to a four-year low, but experts believe it could delay the demand peak by at least five years, buying time for Saudi Arabia to diversify its economy. The kingdom's reliance on oil exports is expected to remain a major challenge as the global energy landscape shifts towards alternative fuels.

site_title: Hamilton wins for dominant Mercedes in China
summary: Lewis Hamilton led a dominant Mercedes display to win the Chinese Grand Prix, his 35th career victory and fourth in China. Hamilton controlled the race from the front, while teammate Nico Rosberg finished second. Ferrari's Sebastian Vettel threatened early, but his challenge faded after switching to harder tires. Hamilton extended his championship lead to 68 points, while Vettel is now four points behind. The win marked a strong return to form for Mercedes, who had been expected to regain their dominant stride in the cooler Chinese conditions.

site_title: More two-tier offers possible - with caveats
summary: Keppel Corp's two-tier takeover offer for its listed property arm is the first such deal in at least five years, potentially sparking more similar bids. Industry watchers say such offers may suit firms planning to privatise a company with a controlling stake, where the target stock is highly liquid. The structure may not suit all situations and could confuse shareholders.

site_title: Greed never felt so good to Hong Kong bulls chasing stock rally
summary: Hong Kong's stock market is experiencing its largest rally in 7 years, with the Hang Seng Index surging 7.9% last week, driven by surging demand from mainland Chinese investors. The rally has been fueled by a widening valuation gap between Hong Kong and mainland shares, with dual-listed companies trading at a 20% discount. Options traders have taken note, with bullish calls becoming more expensive than bearish puts, a sign of strong demand. However, some analysts warn that the rally may be overdone, citing a technical indicator and the potential impact of US interest rate hikes.

site_title: Brazilians march against Rousseff government
summary: Hundreds of thousands of Brazilians marched against the Rousseff government, calling for President Dilma Rousseff's ouster and an end to corruption. The protests, which drew an estimated 582,000 people, were fueled by widespread discontent over government corruption, economic drift, and rising inflation. The marchers, many wearing yellow and green jerseys, also expressed frustration over utility bills and workers' rights. Rousseff's popularity ratings have crashed below 20%, with many Brazilians demanding her impeachment and investigation into corruption allegations surrounding the state-owned oil giant Petrobras.

site_title: California looks Down Under for help with drought
summary: California is seeking assistance from Australia in managing its scarce water resources due to a record drought. The US state has depleted reservoirs, fallow farmland, and billions in emergency spending. Unlike Australia, where water is tightly regulated and tracked, California's usage is unmonitored, and aquifers can be tapped by landowners with permits. Officials hope Australia's efficient water management system can be applied to California's situation.

site_title: Shareholder deadlocks: Complications for directors
summary: Directors of companies face complications in shareholder deadlock situations, where their fiduciary duties may conflict with opposing groups of shareholders. Three common complications arise: the director as shareholder, the nominee director, and the insolvent company. Directors must carefully navigate these situations, avoiding conflicts of interest and maintaining impartiality. They must act methodically, record valid reasons for decisions, and seek legal advice when in doubt. Failing to do so can result in breaches of fiduciary duties and potential personal liability.

site_title: The legacy of the sinking of the Sewol
summary: A year after the sinking of the Sewol ferry, South Korea has implemented numerous regulatory changes, including a law banning government officials from taking expensive gifts and stricter penalties for ferry crews and companies that violate safety rules. The government has also raised $27 billion for safety measures, but critics argue that these efforts are insufficient to address deeply rooted corruption. Thousands of people, including Sewol victims' parents, have protested for a new investigation, while the bodies of nine passengers remain unrecovered.

site_title: Stock buyback zeal undimmed by looming Fed rate hike
summary: US companies continued their aggressive stock buyback strategies in Q1, with pending and completed buybacks rising 45% to $179.7 billion, despite looming Fed rate hikes. This trend is expected to continue, bolstering earnings per share and potentially offsetting negative growth in the S&P 500. Companies like General Electric are taking advantage of low borrowing costs, with GE planning a $50 billion buyback. Analysts believe buybacks will remain a profitable strategy even with higher borrowing costs, with some predicting a 6% return on investment over the next 12 months.

site_title: Can the rebound for US stocks continue?
summary: US stocks rebounded last week after fears about jobs data, earnings, and the oil bust subsided. To continue the rebound, banks, tech firms, and housing-market data need to provide positive outlooks this week. After a shockingly weak March jobs report, traders questioned the reliability of the data, expecting a correction rather than a change in trend. The market's resilience was evident in major indices regaining lost ground, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records despite ongoing tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Shipping lines pull back from Yemen as conflict grows
summary: International shipping lines are scaling back or suspending port calls in Yemen due to the escalating conflict, putting pressure on food supplies. Yemen relies heavily on imports, with 90% of its food coming from foreign ships. Many shipping companies are unwilling to risk vessels, citing the risk of air strikes or naval action from the coalition. This has led to price rises in local markets, with wheat prices increasing by 23% and people buying in large quantities due to fears of shortages. Several major shipping companies, including Maersk Line and MSC, have suspended or diverted services to Yemen.

site_title: Why US middle class feels economically insecure
summary: The US middle class feels economically insecure due to stagnant median per capita income since 2000, despite a perception of being middle class. Factors contributing to this anxiety include lost jobs, stagnant incomes, and increasing income volatility. Experts say a sense of economic security is crucial for the middle class, but it has been eroded by rising costs of housing, college, and healthcare, as well as growing income inequality. The perception of being middle class is also driven by aspirations and social comparisons, making it a complex issue for policymakers to address.

site_title: Healthcare firms most favoured by analysts: survey
summary: Fidelity's survey of 17,000 meetings with corporate decision-makers found healthcare companies to be the most favored by analysts, driven by increased innovation and an aging population. 60% of healthcare analysts reported increased management confidence and expected rising returns on capital. IT companies also received positive views, while consumer staples companies are expected to benefit from reduced logistics costs. In contrast, the energy sector is expected to suffer due to the oil price crash, with 85% of energy analysts reporting deterioration in management confidence.

site_title: Thai Airways budgets 5.5b baht for early retirement plan
summary: Thai Airways has budgeted 5.5 billion baht (S$231 million) for its early retirement plan in 2015, aiming to cut 2,000 jobs as part of its plan to reduce headcount by 5,000 in the next few years. The airline has seen an improvement in passenger numbers, with a cabin factor of 76% in the first quarter, and plans to maintain this level through a marketing strategy in the second quarter. However, rising costs related to safety concerns may impact the airline's finances.

site_title: History comes to an end at Oxley Rd
summary: Singapore's former Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew's home at 38 Oxley Road will be demolished after his death, as per his last will and testament. Lee wished for the house to be demolished immediately after his death or if his daughter, Wei Ling, moves out. The demolition decision was made to respect his wishes, as stated in his will dated December 17, 2013. The house, which witnessed history, will now come to an end.

site_title: FDA warns researchers on claims of drug to detect brain disease
summary: The US Food and Drug Administration has warned researchers at UCLA that they improperly marketed a new drug, FDDNP, aimed at diagnosing chronic traumatic encephalopathy (CTE) through PET scans. The researchers, Gary Small and Jorge Barrio, claimed the drug was effective in identifying tau protein deposits in the brain, a signature of CTE, but the FDA stated that such claims and presentations were not allowed. The researchers were partners with the company Taumark and had given PET scans to former NFL players, leading some neuroscientists to question the premature marketing of the drug.

site_title: Yahoo announces major revamp of product teams
summary: Yahoo's CEO Marissa Mayer announced a major reorganization of the company's product teams, promoting Simon Khalaf, the head of recently acquired mobile analytics company Flurry, to senior vice-president. Khalaf will oversee consumer-facing products, including the Yahoo home page and portals, and Tumblr will report to him. In contrast, Tumblr's chief executive David Karp will no longer report directly to Mayer, reflecting the blogging platform's struggles to broaden its appeal. Other executives, including Mike Kerns and Adam Cahan, are taking on new roles, as the company aims to align product teams to drive innovation and deliver user-friendly experiences.

site_title: Keeping the edge in S'pore tourism
summary: Singapore aims to maintain its position as a top travel destination in the region with 3-4% annual growth in visitor arrivals. Experts recommend a shift from showcasing the city-state's attractions to highlighting its unique personality and quirky culture. The industry should focus on creating diverse experiences, such as eco-tourism, sports events, and cultural tours, to attract visitors and encourage longer stays. Affordable options, including regional tours and local experiences, are also crucial to attracting tourists. The city-state should also invest in customer service, sports tourism, and marketing campaigns to target new markets, such as China and India.

site_title: France's ultra-thin ideal is passe but not a problem, says plus-size model
summary: A plus-size model in France, Clementine Desseaux, argues that France's waif obsession is a cultural blockage, not a problem that requires a ban on ultra-thin models. Despite 40% of Frenchwomen wearing size 44 or over, plus-size models face limited job opportunities, and major fashion labels refuse to hire them. Desseaux is organizing a catwalk show, Pulp Fashion Week, to promote larger women in fashion and push French clothing stores to cater to larger sizes. She believes that the focus should be on promoting body positivity and inclusivity, rather than restricting models based on body mass index (BMI).

site_title: An innovation advocate
summary: Rosina Howe-Teo, a seasoned IT manager, has been appointed to lead Singapore's Smart Nation Urban Mobility Domain, developing strategic plans and a collaborative platform to address smart urban mobility challenges. She chairs the national Land Transport Innovation Fund, catalyzing industry partnerships to test-bed world-class transportation solutions and model sustainable urban development. Her role aims to leverage innovation and smart technologies to transform Singapore's e-government and urban mobility systems.

site_title: How long can the momentum in Hong Kong last?
summary: Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index experienced an 8% gain last week, driven by pent-up demand from China, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 gained 1.7% over the week. Momentum in the US market was also fueled by a 10% increase in GE's shares after announcing the sale of GE Capital. Analysts, including Schroders, attribute the Hong Kong rally to Chinese investors seeking to capitalize on price gaps between onshore and offshore markets, but note that valuations are becoming increasingly expensive, making caution warranted.

site_title: The hackathon fast track from campus to Silicon Valley
summary: A 36-hour hackathon, TreeHacks, was held at Stanford's alumni center, attracting 671 young software engineers from top universities. The event aimed to develop mobile apps, websites, and hardware projects, with sponsors providing code and resources. Participants, including students from the University of Maryland, spent long hours coding, with some teams struggling with basic carpentry and electrical work. Top prizes included a free trip to zero-gravity flight and admission to hackathons in Taiwan and South Korea. The event has become a hub for networking, job recruiting, and entrepreneurial pitching, with venture capitalists attending to spot emerging tech developments. Hackathons have become a focal point for recruiting top talent, with Silicon Valley companies seeking to identify the next Mark Zuckerberg and Jack Dorsey.

site_title: Social networks work on stealth advertising
summary: Social media platforms Twitter, YouTube, and Instagram are using stealth advertising, disguising ads as posts from listed contacts to avoid distracting users. Each platform has a team to advise brands on how to integrate ads into users' feeds, with a focus on respecting the community and integrating ads in a way that feels organic. The teams, made up of experienced marketers and experts in local markets, aim to stay up-to-date with the latest trends and communicate 24/7.

site_title: Buoyed by QE's debut, ECB meets this week
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) meets this week, following the successful debut of its quantitative easing (QE) programme, which aims to boost growth in the eurozone. Analysts expect the ECB to quash talk of premature tapering, with ECB chief Mario Draghi likely to emphasize the importance of completing the programme. The programme's success has led to a decline in government borrowing rates, a weak euro, and a potential boost to exports. However, some worry that the euro's weakness could push inflation above the ECB's target of 2.0%.

site_title: Ivory Coast gets US nod for direct flights
summary: Ivory Coast has received US authorization for direct flights, boosting the West African nation's efforts to become a regional transport hub. The move follows a decade-long political crisis and a renaissance under President Alassane Ouattara's leadership, which has averaged annual growth of around 9%. The direct flights are expected to attract more US investors and reinforce Ivory Coast's aim of becoming a major air travel hub in Africa. The authorization, given after 15 years of seeking it, is seen as a significant step forward for the country's economic development.

site_title: Millennials a mix of pragmatism, optimism in managing their money
summary: Millennials, aged 18-34, are a mix of pragmatism and optimism when managing their finances, according to two surveys. Despite being risk-averse due to their parents' retirement struggles, over 70% feel secure in meeting their financial goals. However, only 20% have a comprehensive plan in place to achieve them. Instead, they often turn to friends and family for advice, with 71% seeking guidance from a family member. Their top financial goals include increasing overall savings, saving for a vacation, and saving for a car. Almost three-quarters of millennials expect to work past 65 due to concerns over Social Security and healthcare costs.

site_title: China builds more infrastructure white elephants
summary: China has spent approximately 42 trillion yuan on ineffective infrastructure investments since 2009, with the country approving 1.8 trillion yuan in new projects in the past year. Many of these projects have underutilized airports, expressways, and stadiums, resulting in significant debt for provincial governments. The economy in Liaoning province, where Dachangshan island's underutilized airport is located, experienced slow growth in 2014. Experts warn of the need for discussions on the economic rationality of large-scale engineering projects, and the government is facing challenges in weaning itself off over-building, particularly in inland western regions.

site_title: The five minutes that made a big difference for KepLand shareholders
summary: A 5-minute window between 5pm and 5.05pm on March 26, 2015, could have changed the outcome for minority shareholders of Keppel Land, who received S$4.38 per share instead of the expected S$4.60. The delay in delivering shares due to Singapore's share settlement system, which typically takes 3 business days, meant that shares traded during this window would have reached buyers' accounts late on March 31, after the 5.30pm deadline. If the announcement of Keppel Corp's final extension had been made after 5.05pm, it may have prevented arbitrageurs from buying shares during this window, potentially changing the outcome for shareholders.

site_title: Power sharing, budget cuts help Rousseff in Brazil crisis
summary: Brazilian President Dilma Rousseff has made concessions to ease the economic and political crisis, embracing power-sharing deals and budget cuts. Vice-President Michel Temer, a leader of the Brazilian Democratic Movement Party (PMDB), has been given formal responsibility for negotiating with Congress, reducing tensions. This shift towards more market-friendly policies has led to a rally in Brazil's stock and currency markets, with investors hopeful for an economic recovery. However, challenges remain, including rising government debt and bleak economic prospects, and an economic recovery is not expected until late this year or early 2016.

site_title: US$ snaps 3-week loss as rate rise seems imminent
summary: The US dollar has ended a three-week losing streak as investors anticipate a potential interest rate hike by the Federal Reserve, driven by the economy's improvement. Jobless claims dropped to a 15-year low, boosting confidence in a Fed rate increase this year for the first time since 2006.

site_title: Nokia weighing sale of maps business to focus on networks: sources
summary: Nokia is exploring the sale of its maps business to focus on its wireless-network unit and improve its debt rating. The company has reached out to potential buyers including Uber and private-equity firms, with German carmakers also showing interest. Bids for the unit are expected as soon as this month. The sale would allow Nokia to concentrate on its core network business, which has been a significant contributor to its growth.

site_title: South China Sea disputes could escalate: report
summary: A Japanese defence analyst has warned that the South China Sea has become the most significant "flash point" for possible security incidents between Asian powers, citing incidents between Vietnam and China over territorial claims in 2014. The National Institute for Defence Studies report highlights the region's increasing tensions and disputes over maritime resources, with the US and China competing for influence. Analysts note that while some regional cooperation initiatives have been established, concrete mechanisms for risk management and mutual confidence have yet to be built.

site_title: AIIB will be lean, clean and green, says its interim chief
summary: The Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB) will be lean, clean, and green, its interim chief Jin Liqun said, playing down concerns over transparency and standards. The $50 billion bank, led by China, is expected to start operations by the end of the year and has attracted over 40 countries. Unlike the World Bank and Asian Development Bank, the AIIB will have zero-tolerance on corruption and promote economic growth. The US and Japan, which have questioned the bank's governance and environmental standards, are notable absentees from the institution.

site_title: Spotify seeking to raise new financing: sources
summary: Spotify is raising new financing, valued at approximately US$8 billion, according to sources. The latest round totals about US$400 million, backed by Goldman Sachs Group and an Abu Dhabi sovereign wealth fund. This valuation is double the company's worth when it raised money in November 2013. The move aims to further establish Spotify as the largest subscription music-streaming service.

site_title: Mexico is world's only 100-year bond issuer
summary: Mexico has successfully issued 100-year bonds in three different currencies, raising almost $6 billion, making it the world's only 100-year bond issuer since 2010. The government aims to avoid a repeat of its 1994 peso crisis by extending debt maturities and taking advantage of low global interest rates. Analysts attribute the move to a combination of PR and Mexico's unique financial situation, with interest rates in developed countries near zero.

site_title: Using data for a smoother journey
summary: Singapore's Land Transport Authority (LTA) has leveraged data analytics to improve public transport, with projects like Electronic Road Pricing (ERP) and the Bus Service Enhancement Programme. LTA's use of big data and analytics has enabled the agency to optimize bus allocation, predict traffic patterns, and improve service satisfaction. The agency has also partnered with IBM Watson to develop advanced analytics solutions, such as the Faster project, which combines data from LTA, public transport operators, and telcos to predict crowd levels and mitigate congestion.

site_title: De Niro partners make billions with boutique New York hotels
summary: Billionaires IRA Drukier and Richard Born have transformed their families' modest real estate assets into a lodging empire, with stakes in over two dozen boutique hotels in New York City, valued at around $2 billion. The pair, who started their careers as an engineer and doctor, abandoned their careers for real estate in the 1980s and focus on buying projects in need of renovations. Their boutique hotels, including the Ludlow and the Bowery, cater to a specific group of customers, with a focus on style and aesthetics.

site_title: Keppel Reit piano's grand swan song
summary: Keppel Reit is donating its Steinway grand piano to the School of the Arts (SOTA) after a two-year stint at the Ocean Financial Centre lobby, where it was loaned to ChildAid for annual concerts. The piano was acquired by Keppel Reit in 2012 to commemorate its name change and was used for office performances and charity events. The donation was made at a ceremony, with the piano set to be used in SOTA's Concert Hall, enhancing the school's music programs.

site_title: Afghan mine stalled by Chinese demands, rebels
summary: China and Afghanistan remain deadlocked over a stalled US$3 billion copper mine at Mes Aynak, five months after Beijing demanded royalties be slashed by almost half. The project, which won a contract in 2007, has been delayed since state-run China Metallurgical Group Corp (MCC) took over. The copper deposit, one of the world's largest untapped reserves, has been hindered by Chinese demands, further straining Afghanistan's efforts to support itself as foreign aid dwindles.

site_title: Japan's ruling camp wins local polls in 'Abenomics' litmus test: media
summary: Japan's ruling coalition, led by Prime Minister Shinzo Abe, won local elections seen as a referendum on his "Abenomics" economic drive, securing victories in all 10 gubernatorial polls and local assembly member elections. The coalition's success was attributed to voters' high expectations of economic revival, with the LDP and its junior partner Komeito winning key seats, including those of two pro-nuclear politicians. The outcome is seen as a boost to Abe's efforts to revitalize the economy before next year's upper house elections.

site_title: Bombardier looks to raise cash from rail business
summary: Bombardier is exploring ways to raise up to $5 billion from its transportation unit, which includes rail vehicles and equipment, amid huge cost overruns in its aircraft business. The company is considering a possible sale, initial public offering, or merger with another sector peer, such as Siemens or Alstom. Discussions are in early stages, and Bombardier may hold off until potential buyers have finished wrapping up recent transactions. This move comes as the company battles with the development of its CSeries jet, which has seen a 38% decline in its stock this year.

site_title: The S$ and the big MAS policy debate
summary: Economists are divided on the Monetary Authority of Singapore's (MAS) policy decision, which may tweak its Singapore dollar policy or keep the same stance. Three options are possible: a downward recentring, widening, or no change to the S$NEER band. The market is uncertain, with some economists calling for easing via a lowering of the policy band's mid-point, while others see no easing and a widening of the band to accommodate increased economic uncertainty. MAS's January policy statement, which decreased the slope of the S$NEER band, has contributed to the uncertainty, and economists point to the tight labour market and rising oil prices as factors influencing the decision.

site_title: Hotels snubbed amid China rally as expansion plans exceed growth
summary: China's hotel operators, Homeinns Hotel Group and China Lodging Group Ltd, have seen significant declines in shares amid a rally in Chinese stocks. The companies' expansion plans, which included increasing hotel counts by 40% and 20% respectively, have been hampered by lower occupancy rates and slower economic growth. Revenue growth is forecast to be lower than expected, with Homeinns anticipating a 50% decline in sales growth and China Lodging projecting a 10% increase. In contrast, online trip-booking agencies like Qunar Cayman Islands Ltd and Ctrip.com have seen significant gains.

site_title: GE to sell bulk of finance unit, return up to US$90 billion to investors
summary: General Electric (GE) is selling the bulk of its finance unit, GE Capital, and returning up to $90 billion to investors through share buybacks and dividends. The company plans to shed $275 billion in GE Capital assets, including a spinoff of its Synchrony Financial credit card unit. GE aims to reduce its finance assets to $90 billion and focus on its industrial businesses, with a goal of generating 90% of its profits from industrial operations by 2018.

site_title: Taiwan's ruling party chief to meet China's Xi
summary: Taiwan's ruling party chief, Eric Chu, plans to meet China's President Xi Jinping at a May forum in Shanghai, marking the first visit by a KMT chief since 2008. The meeting, between the two party leaders, is being arranged, although details have not been finalized. Mr. Xi heads the Communist Party and holds the presidency, further highlighting the diplomatic efforts between Taiwan and China.

images.alt_text: The head of Taiwan's ruling Kuo-mintang said on Sunday he plans to meet China's President Xi Jinping next month, in what will be the first visit to the mainland by a KMT chief since 2008.

site_title: Lee Kuan Yew's will: Oxley Road home to be demolished
summary: Lee Kuan Yew, Singapore's founding Prime Minister, had his home at 38 Oxley Road demolished in accordance with his last will and testament. The will, dated December 17, 2013, stated that the house should be demolished immediately after his death or if his daughter Wei Ling moved out. His children, Lee Wei Ling and Lee Hsien Yang, confirmed that their father's wishes were to be respected, and the demolition was carried out as planned. The executors and trustees ensured the house was demolished, in line with their father's instructions.

site_title: Tories pledge to raise inheritance- tax threshold for couples
summary: UK Prime Minister David Cameron has pledged to raise the inheritance-tax threshold for couples to £1 million (S$2 million) as part of his party's election campaign. The current limit is £650,000 for a couple, and the additional allowance will be £175,000 for each partner when passing on their primary residence. The move aims to break the opinion-poll deadlock between the Conservatives and Labour before the general election.

site_title: China-led AIIB will be lean, clean and green: official
summary: China's Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB), led by China, will be lean, clean, and green, its interim chief Jin Liqun stated. The $50 billion bank, expected to start operations by the end of the year, aims to promote economic growth while maintaining transparency and zero-tolerance for corruption. Over 40 countries have applied to join, with the US and Japan absent. The AIIB's establishment is seen as a potential rival to established lenders the World Bank and Asian Development Bank.

site_title: Greece may have blown best chance of long-term debt deal
summary: Greece's leftist-led government, led by Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras, has irreparably damaged its relationship with eurozone creditors, making a long-term debt deal unlikely. The country's public debt is 175% of economic output, and it owes 80% to official lenders. A proposed plan to pay off IMF loans early, redeem bonds, and extend loan maturity could save Greece billions, but is now a "political non-starter" due to Tsipras's denunciations of EU austerity and demands for German reparations. A referendum or coalition change may be necessary to restore creditor trust.

images.alt_text: Mr Tsipras's (left) denunciations of EU-prescribed austerity, demands for German war reparations and cosying up to Russian President Vladimir Putin (right), and Mr Varoufakis's foot-dragging on reform negotiations and initial calls for a "haircut" on Greek debt, have dried up the reservoir of sympathy for Athens.

site_title: More of the same Italian fare
summary: Two new Italian restaurants, Perbacco and Waterfall Ristorante, have opened in Singapore, but their dishes do little to raise the bar for Italian cooking. Perbacco's chef Marco Violano's serviceable cooking is marred by inconsistent ingredients, while Waterfall Ristorante's South Italian chef Marco De Vincentis offers a more credible effort with predictable yet satisfying fare. Despite their efforts, both restaurants fall into the "promising" category, with Perbacco scoring 6 and Waterfall Ristorante scoring 6.

site_title: Pound falls to five-year low as volatility jumps before election
summary: The pound fell to a five-year low against the dollar, dropping 1.8% to US$1.4648, as the UK election campaign entered its final month. Investors are bracing for a contest that may produce no clear winner, leading to protracted negotiations to form a government. The Bank of England kept interest rates at a record-low 0.5% and UK government bonds were little changed. Sterling may fall further, with some predicting a drop to US$1.43, and volatility surged to a five-year high.

site_title: Taking heart
summary: Singapore has launched initiatives to bridge the digital divide and improve healthcare access for low-income households. M1 is offering affordable high-speed fibre broadband to 8,000 homes for S$6 a month. Fullerton Healthcare Group is providing free consultation and medicine to over 400 lower-income citizens with chronic diseases. The Yellow Ribbon Fund, a charity supporting re-integration programs for ex-offenders, has been selected as the American Chamber of Commerce's Charity of the Year for the third consecutive year.

site_title: India's Modi visits French aviation hub Toulouse
summary: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi visited Toulouse, France, the hub of the European aerospace industry, on April 11, 2015. During his three-hour visit, Modi confirmed India's interest in the sector and confirmed a multi-billion-euro agreement for 36 Rafale fighter jets from France. The visit came after Modi announced the order the day before, which is seen as a positive step for economic diplomacy between the two countries. Airbus committed to "Make in India" and plans to set up final assembly lines and supply chains in India, supporting jobs and investments.

site_title: Oil storage workers poised to strike in fuel-trade hub
summary: Royal Vopak NV workers in Europe's fuel-trading centre are set to strike on April 12, affecting seven terminals and staff working shifts, including those in Amsterdam, Rotterdam, and Vlissingen. The strike, involving 550 workers, relates to a dispute over bonuses and holidays. The strike is the second of its kind in 13 years and could impact oil product prices, rather than crude oil costs, due to the Netherlands' central role in fuel trading.

site_title: China premier says economy faces growing downward pressure
summary: China's premier, Li Keqiang, stated that the country's economy faces growing downward pressure, which must be addressed to avoid impact on employment and incomes. The national economy is running smoothly, but downward pressure continues to grow. Li called for speeding up reforms in the northeast, a center of mining and heavy industry that has been lagging in growth. This comes as China prepares to announce first-quarter economic growth, which is expected to slow.

site_title: Japan holds local elections in 'Abenomics' litmus test
summary: Japan held nationwide local elections, seen as a referendum on Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's "Abenomics" economic drive, with the ruling Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) hoping to capitalize on its impact. The elections, the first of two rounds, will elect 10 governors and five mayors, with broadcasters' exit polls expected to give an indication of the final outcome. The polls are a key test of Abe's efforts to boost the economy through massive government spending, monetary easing, and regulatory overhaul, amid mixed success in addressing years of deflation.

site_title: Substantial Goldman data transfer prompted code-theft probe
summary: Goldman Sachs programmer Sergey Aleynikov is on trial for allegedly stealing the company's high-frequency trading code, a valuable asset worth decades of investment. A former Goldman Sachs managing director testified that the company lost information and began investigating after discovering substantial data transfers. Aleynikov, who has already spent nearly a year in prison, claims his actions were a civil matter and not a crime. If convicted, he faces up to four years in prison.

site_title: Yum's upmarket China diner seeks recipe for revival
summary: Yum Brands, the parent company of KFC and Pizza Hut, is reviving its China market by opening an upscale diner called Atto Primo in Shanghai. The restaurant is part of the company's efforts to bounce back from a 16% decline in same-store sales in China's largest market in 2014. Atto Primo serves as an "innovation lab" to test new menus and concepts, and gather feedback from sophisticated Chinese diners. Yum's CEO, Greg Creed, has prioritized reviving sales in China, and the company plans to build 700 new fast-food stores this year.

images.alt_text: Dimmed lights and colonial-style balconies give little indication that trendy Shanghai eatery Atto Primo is part of global fast-food giant Yum Brands, owner of the KFC and Pizza Hut brands.

site_title: China to curb visits to Hong Kong by Shenzhen residents: NPC deputy
summary: China plans to limit visits by Shenzhen residents to Hong Kong to one trip per week, from unlimited daily trips, following recent tensions over growing numbers of mainland visitors. This move aims to address concerns over shop rents and property prices, as well as harassment of tourists. The restriction could come into effect as early as Monday, and the Hong Kong government acknowledges it has proposed measures to adjust visas for Shenzhen residents. The move is seen as a response to growing discontent in Hong Kong over the influx of mainland tourists.

site_title: Sino Construction to propose another new name
summary: Sino Construction, a Singapore-based building construction and civil engineering group, is reconsidering its proposed name change to "Magnum Strategic Resources" after a string of cancelled mining acquisitions. The company will instead propose a new name reflecting its shift to micro power plants and reduced mineral portfolio. The Singapore Exchange issued a "trade with caution" on the firm's stock following heightened trading volumes, which closed 16.7% higher. The name change is seen as a response to the company's revised strategic direction.

site_title: The beat goes on at music festivals
summary: The music festival industry has experienced significant growth in recent years, with new events and festivals proliferating globally. Coachella, Rock in Rio USA, and Lollapalooza are among the most ambitious newcomers, offering a range of lineups and amenities to cater to different tastes and regions. Industry growth is driven by the preferences of the millennial generation, who prioritize buying experiences over material goods. Festivals have become a vital source of revenue and publicity for artists, with Eventbrite managing tickets for 50,000 music festivals worldwide in 2014, a 50% increase from the previous year.

images.alt_text: ROCKING GOOD TIME: Coachella, often considered the tastemaker of US music events, opens on Friday in the southern California desert at the start of the busiest season yet for festivals.

site_title: Petrobras said to consider prized oil area in divestment plan
summary: Petrobras is considering divesting its prized oil fields in the pre-salt region, marking a shift from economic nationalism to pragmatism amid low oil prices and financial struggles. The company, Brazil's state-owned oil giant, is exploring partnerships with global competitors like Royal Dutch Shell and Chevron to sell stakes in its deepwater oil region. Petrobras will need to weigh the benefits of raising cash against potential backlash from nationalists and the government, which has previously supported the company's focus on domestic oil production.

images.alt_text: Aldemir Bendine, chief executive officer of Banco do Brasil SA, speaks at a news conference on quarterly earnings at company headquarters in Sao Paulo, Brazil, on Thursday, Feb 17, 2011. Petroleo Brasileiro is considering including fields from its fastest-growing deepwater oil region in a divestment plan to raise money for expenditures and debt payments, six people with knowledge of the proposal said.

site_title: Hong Kong defends currency peg for second day as stocks jump
summary: Hong Kong's de facto central bank intervened for the second day to prevent the currency from rising against the US dollar, buying US$1.7 billion at HK$7.75 per dollar. The move comes as the city's benchmark Hang Seng Index jumped 7.9% this week, its largest advance since 2011. Chinese investors surged into Hong Kong stocks, using up their daily quota, and the Hong Kong Monetary Authority may need to continue intervening to defend the peg. The currency remained stable at HK$7.75 against the US dollar.

site_title: Blackstone swooped on regulation-weary GE to do mega real estate deal
summary: Blackstone Group has acquired most of General Electric's (GE) assets in its real estate unit for approximately $23 billion, marking the largest real estate deal since the 2007 financial crisis. The deal allows GE to break free from regulatory constraints as a systemically important financial institution. Blackstone's real estate business has grown significantly, from $18 billion in 2007 to $80.9 billion as of December 2024, and the deal is its largest since acquiring Equity Office Properties Trust in 2007.

images.alt_text: It took Blackstone Group less than four weeks after an approach from General Electric Co to clinch the biggest real estate deal since the financial crisis. Yet the seeds of that deal were planted seven years ago, during the crisis.

site_title: GE surge lifts US stocks
summary: US stocks rose on Friday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average jumping 98.92 points (0.55%) to 18,057.65, and the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index advancing 10.88% and 21.41%, respectively. General Electric led the Dow, surging 10.8% after announcing a $26.5 billion sale of real estate assets. Global equity markets hit all-time highs, with the UK, France, and Germany, and Japan's Nikkei 225 rising above 20,000 for the first time in 15 years.

site_title: Glaxo plans changes to compensation programme for US sales team
summary: GlaxoSmithKline is reviewing its US sales compensation model, known as the Patient First program, due to pressure on CEO Andrew Witty to revive struggling US operations. The program, introduced in 2011, shifted focus from sales targets to patient-centric incentives. A task force will provide a report within a month to explore "more comprehensive options" to simplify the program. The changes aim to address the UK's largest drugmaker's declining US sales, which account for almost a third of its revenue.

site_title: Oil drillers pull rigs out of US fields for 18th week
summary: US oil drillers have pulled rigs out of US fields for an 18th consecutive week, with 42 rigs removed, bringing the total to 760, the lowest since December 2010. The decline follows a more modest slide in the previous two weeks, and comes as US production drops and oil markets rebalance due to a collapse in crude prices. The country has lost more than half its oil rigs since October, with the Permian Basin and Eagle Ford shale formation taking the biggest hits.

site_title: Kraft, Mondelz wheat price manipulation hurt traders: US lawsuit
summary: Kraft Foods Group and Mondelz International are being sued in a class action lawsuit for allegedly manipulating wheat futures and options prices, hurting traders. The lawsuit was filed by futures trader Richard Dennis in federal court in Chicago, eight days after the US Commodity Futures Trading Commission (CFTC) sued the companies for similar allegations. The CFTC claimed that Kraft Foods bought $90 million of wheat futures in 2011 without intending to take possession of the grain, leading to price manipulation.

site_title: All fired up
summary: Three new grill restaurants, Tburu, FYR Cycene Ond Drinc, and Opus Bar & Grill, are opening in Singapore, catering to the city-state's love for grilled meats. Tburu, a Japanese restaurant, offers exotic grilled meats like pig intestines and ears, while FYR Cycene Ond Drinc features a Josper Charcoal Oven and grilled meats cooked with lychee wood. Opus Bar & Grill, an Australian-inspired restaurant, boasts a bespoke Himalayan salt-tiled ageing cabinet and a full charcoal grill, serving dry-aged prime meats. These restaurants aim to bring back the simplicity of ancient times, with a focus on charcoal grilling and healthy cooking methods.

site_title: Aviva will tide over loss of DBS business, say observers
summary: Aviva Singapore, heavily reliant on its bancassurance channel, may face short-term challenges after losing its partnership with DBS Bank. However, observers caution against writing off the composite insurer too quickly, citing the need for cost-cutting and finding new growth avenues. Aviva's life business generates more revenue than its general insurance arm, and the company may consider expanding its financial advisory channel or adopting an e-commerce strategy to mitigate the loss. Despite the setback, Aviva is expected to survive due to its large customer base and existing distribution channels.

site_title: European stocks power through to record as Draghi fuels recovery
summary: European stocks reached a record high, propelled by Mario Draghi's stimulus measures, as the Stoxx Europe 600 Index closed at 409.15. The index gained 21% this year, with a 0.9% increase on Friday. Optimism about the euro area's improving economy, driven by German industrial production data, fueled the rally. Investors expect euro-area growth to accelerate every quarter in 2015, as the European Central Bank's quantitative-easing measures take effect.

site_title: China-Led infrastructure bank keeps door open to US 'anytime'
summary: China's Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB) chief Jin Liqun stated that the US is "welcome to the kitchen to work with us" and may join the bank "anytime". The bank's founding membership is expected to be around 60 countries, with China itself not yet meeting the required threshold. Jin emphasized that China has benefited from contributions from the World Bank and Asian Development Bank, and now aims to contribute more to the region, potentially spilling over to other regions.

site_title: Apple watch deliveries delayed despite scarce crowds at stores
summary: Apple's new smartwatch has been delayed in delivery for some versions, despite relatively low crowds at stores worldwide, including in China, where the company had expected a massive turnout. Online pre-orders pushed delivery dates for some versions into June, with high-end models delayed until July. Analysts attribute the delay to limited supply, citing solid demand, while some consumers speculate that the price may be a deterrent. The watch's release is seen as a test of CEO Tim Cook's ability to innovate, with estimated sales of almost 14 million units in the fiscal year that ends in September.

site_title: TPP deal urgent with US election year nearing: PM
summary: Singaporean Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong emphasized the urgency of reaching a Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) deal, particularly with the US gearing up for presidential elections next year. The 12-nation agreement, covering nearly 800 million people and a combined GDP of $27.7 trillion, faces challenges if US Congress can't pass trade promotion authority legislation. Lee noted that convincing lawmakers of the agreement's merits is crucial for its success, as the TPP aims to link the US and Pacific Rim nations closer together.

site_title: Foreign PMETs not displacing local ones
summary: Singaporean PMETs (Professionals, Managers, Executives, and Technicians) are not being displaced by foreign PMETs in the local job market, despite the growth of the foreign workforce. The unemployment rate of Singaporean PMETs remains low at 2.9% and median income has increased by 2% per year between 2009 and 2014. Manpower Minister Tan Chuan-Jin emphasized the need for sustainable growth of foreign manpower and emphasized the importance of upskilling Singaporeans to take advantage of new job opportunities.

site_title: A fresher face
summary: The seventh-generation Toyota Camry has undergone a makeover, focusing on comfort and refinement while introducing a sportier look. The updated sedan features a bold front air dam, new headlamp clusters, and a capacitive seven-inch centre touchscreen with Air Gesture capability. The interior remains spacious, with excellent rear legroom and a flat floor, while the exterior length increases by 25mm. The Camry 2.5 retains its 6-speed automatic transmission and 178hp engine, offering a smooth drive and confident handling.

site_title: 'Underweight' call on industrial Reits (Amended)
summary: Maybank Kim Eng maintains an "underweight" rating on industrial Reits in Singapore, citing sub-normal demand but high supply. The analyst firm keeps its "buy" rating on Mapletree Industrial Trust due to upcoming BTS developments, while downgrading Ascendas Reit due to broad-based exposure to the supplied market. Cache Logistics Trust is also maintained as a "buy" due to its low tenant lease expiries and BTS projects. JTC's capping of land tenures at 30 years aims to keep Singapore competitive for industrialists and prevent speculation.

site_title: Tapping on South-east Asia's clean energy boom
summary: British-born Andrew Affleck founded Armstrong Asset Management, a Singapore-based clean energy fund, in 2012. The fund provides equity capital for renewable energy projects in South-east Asia, attracting US$164 million from investors including the World Bank's IFC. The region's energy demand is expected to increase by over 80% between 2013 and 2035, driven by urbanization and a growing middle class. Armstrong has committed to five businesses with over 20 renewable energy projects in the pipeline, aiming for a gross internal rate of return of 20% per year. The fund is expected to launch its second fund by end-2017, broadening its investments to Vietnam, Cambodia, Laos, and Myanmar.

site_title: A home to call their own
summary: The Trotter family, consisting of Greg and Anna, and their two children, Jack and Molly, have finally settled into their own home after 16 years of living in rented houses worldwide. The two-storey, 5,539 sq ft home in Leisure Farm Resort, Johor, was designed by Carol Bochsler of the Exhale Group and won the Architecture Single Residence prize in the Asia-Pacific sector of the International Property Awards. The family's efforts in designing their dream home have been a long-awaited milestone.

site_title: GM avoids recall of 2m trucks, SUVs over rusty brake lines
summary: General Motors (GM) has avoided a recall of approximately 2 million large trucks and SUVs due to rusted brake lines after a four-year investigation by the US National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA). The brake-line corrosion is considered routine wear and tear, primarily affecting vehicles in northern states where salt is used on roads in winter. The NHTSA recommends owners of 2007 or earlier models inspect their brake lines regularly, especially in states that use salt on roads.

site_title: Stamford Land takes A$265m loan to build Sydney project
summary: Singapore-based Stamford Land Corporation has secured a A$265 million loan to fund the construction of its Macquarie Park Village project in Sydney. The loan is a secured term loan facility and will be used to build a residential mixed-use development. The transaction has no impact on Stamford Land's earnings per share or net tangible assets per share for the financial year ending March 31, 2016.

site_title: Green rooms
summary: Several companies, including StarHub, have set up indoor gardens in their office spaces, adopting the community garden concept. These gardens feature various plants, such as orchids, African violets, and airplants, and are maintained by staff members. The National Parks Board's Community in Bloom (CIB) programme has encouraged this trend, providing workshops and starter kits for indoor gardening. Other organizations, like the Metta Welfare Association and Reach Community Services Society, have also incorporated green spaces into their buildings, promoting relaxation and community engagement.

site_title: Aussie debt proves too attractive in world of ugly yields
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) saw a record-breaking sale of sovereign bonds, with 120 bids for a $2 billion 2020 bond auction, three times the norm. This is due to a global demand for yield, with European bond yields dropping to negative territory. Australian bond yields of 2.38% and 2.865% make them attractive to investors, with 66% of Australian debt held by foreigners. This has put downward pressure on the Australian currency, which the RBA needs to weaken to cushion the economy from falling resource prices.

site_title: Noble recovers 3.5% after detailed rebuttal to Muddy Waters
summary: Noble Group shares rose 3.5% after releasing a detailed rebuttal to allegations by Muddy Waters, a US short-seller, that the company's business practices were misleading. Noble rejected claims of "massively misleading rebuttal" from Muddy Waters, stating its balance sheet has never been stronger and cash flows were negatively affected by strategic shifts. Muddy Waters plans to counter with a full rebuttal, but analysts say Noble's response did not address key questions, such as the company's continued negative cash flow.

site_title: SMRT in JV to offer MRO services for rolling stock
summary: SMRT Corporation Ltd has entered into a joint venture agreement with Faiveley Transport to market and supply maintenance, repair and overhaul (MRO) services for rolling stock components in South-east Asia, excluding Thailand, Taiwan, and Hong Kong. The 50:50 joint venture company, Faiveley Rail Engineering Singapore Pte Ltd, will provide services for brakes, HVAC systems, and other components. The move aims to improve train reliability and travel experience for Singapore commuters, with the JV expected to contribute to the growing MRO market in the region.

site_title: MPs to offer ways to honour Lee Kuan Yew in Monday's sitting
summary: Singaporean MPs will discuss ways to honor the country's founding prime minister Lee Kuan Yew during a session on Monday. Three MPs, Foo Mee Har and two others, have proposed suggestions, including designating a Founder's Day. The session will begin with Foo Mee Har asking Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong about the possibility of a designated Founder's Day to commemorate Lee Kuan Yew's legacy.

site_title: Shell's BG deal will test China's pledge on anti-trust transparency
summary: China's antitrust regime will be tested as Royal Dutch Shell's $70 billion bid for BG Group proceeds, following Beijing's pledge to increase transparency. The deal's impact on China's liquefied natural gas (LNG) market will be scrutinized, with Shell and BG Group holding a significant share. Despite criticism over the Glencore-Xstrata case, observers believe China will not raise objections, citing the country's desire to improve transparency and focus on competition threats. The deal's outcome may be influenced by China's changing political environment and increased international scrutiny.

site_title: Shaping management education in S'pore
summary: Asian business schools must leverage their unique identity to succeed globally, rather than simply competing with Western institutions. Key obstacles include the globalization of education, which discourages localisation, and the need for closer ties between business schools to share knowledge and best practices. To overcome these challenges, Asian schools must build stronger connections with industry and policy communities, foster intellectual curiosity, and create a more porous university environment. By embracing their Asian identity and collaborating with industry and government, Singapore's business schools can create a globally competitive and sustainable management education system.

site_title: China bears persist even as markets soar
summary: China's bear market is intensifying as short sellers face significant losses, with bearish wagers on the Shanghai Stock Exchange reaching a record 7.46 billion yuan. The benchmark equity index has surged 94% in the past nine months, making it difficult for short sellers to profit. Analysts warn that betting against the Chinese market is "suicidal" due to its high volatility and unprecedented debt levels. Despite technical indicators suggesting a potential reversal, many experts believe China's stimulus efforts will lead to an economic recovery later this year, exacerbating losses for short sellers.

site_title: HSBC faces criminal investigation in French tax case
summary: HSBC faces a formal criminal investigation in France for allegedly assisting wealthy clients to avoid taxes from 2006 to 2007. The investigation, conducted by French magistrates, is the latest blow to the bank's reputation, following previous disclosures about its Swiss private banking arm's actions. HSBC has been ordered to post a €1 billion bail and will appeal the decision. The bank has acknowledged previous "conduct and compliance failures" in its Swiss business and has overhauled its private banking operations.

site_title: Deutsche Bank close to US$1.5b deal in Libor case: sources
summary: Deutsche Bank is close to settling a multi-year probe into interest rate manipulation, with a UK subsidiary expected to plead guilty. The bank's UK unit, Deutsche Bank Group Services, is likely to finalize a settlement this month. This resolution comes after a probe by US and UK authorities into Deutsche Bank's alleged manipulation of the Libor interest rate. The exact terms of the deal are not disclosed.

site_title: Google's anti-trust foes see ally in new EU competition chief
summary: Danish politician Margrethe Vestager, the new EU competition chief, has given new hope to anti-trust foes of Google, who had been waiting over four years for a resolution. Vestager has indicated a more sympathetic approach to the case, which includes an anti-trust complaint by more than a dozen companies against Google. Google faces a potential fine of up to $6.6 billion and may have to modify its business practices if found guilty. Vestager's approach is seen as a departure from her predecessor, Joaquin Almunia, and has lifted optimism among companies that brought the complaint.

site_title: A serendipitous escape
summary: Sri Lanka's southern coastline remains a popular destination, offering stunning vistas and historical charm. Following a 26-year civil war, the country has experienced a relatively short recovery, with tourism booming due to its low cost of living and favorable currency exchange.
