site_title: Japan faces dilemma over plan to shut down nuclear reactors
summary: Japan's government faces a dilemma in deciding how to replace lost electricity generation from ageing nuclear reactors, which will eliminate 65% of the country's solar power output. The decision, made by reactor operators, will decommission five reactors dating from the 1970s. Despite the Fukushima disaster in 2011, environmentalists argue Japan can meet its energy needs through efficiency gains and renewables. The issue highlights the challenge of balancing nuclear energy with clean and safe alternatives, and its implications are global, with other countries like the US and Germany facing similar decisions.

site_title: Viva secures Decathlon as a key retail tenant
summary: Viva Industrial Trust (VIT) has secured Decathlon, a global sporting goods retailer, as its first retail anchor tenant under its asset enhancement initiative (AEI) at Technopark@Chai Chee. Decathlon will lease 35,000 sq ft of space for its first flagship store in Singapore and South-east Asia. The move aims to increase occupancy at the business park from 60% to 80% or more, with VIT's CEO confident that the remaining space will be filled. Decathlon plans to open four more stores in Singapore and has also decided to base its Asia headquarters at the business park.

site_title: Insurers China Life, Ping An invest in Boston waterfront project
summary: Chinese life insurance companies China Life and Ping An have invested in a Boston waterfront project, teaming with Tishman Speyer. The $167 million investment will be used to develop a 13-storey office building, a 9-storey residential condominium, and a parking facility. This marks the first time China Life and Ping An have co-invested in US real estate. The project, located in Boston's Seaport District, is part of a growing trend of Chinese investment in US property, with overseas investment reaching $16.5 billion in 2014.

site_title: Indian court convicts former chief of Satyam
summary: An Indian court has convicted former Satyam CEO Byrraju Ramalinga Raju and eight others of manipulating the company's books in a US$2.25 billion accounting fraud scandal, dubbed "India's Enron". Raju faces prison for breach of trust, with prosecutors saying the case caused 140 billion rupees in losses to shareholders. The verdict is seen as a significant victory in India's fight against corporate fraud, with a senior investigator calling it a "big deterrent" to others misusing shareholders' money.

site_title: Obama bets his presidency, and the 2016 election, on Iran
summary: US President Barack Obama's presidency and 2016 election are heavily reliant on his Iran policy. Obama's predecessors, including Jimmy Carter and Ronald Reagan, were either forced into or chose to engage in the Persian Gulf, with varying degrees of success. Obama's policy aims to reverse this trend by ending US military intervention in Iraq and opening a dialogue with Iran. However, this approach is being challenged by Republicans, who accuse Obama of "appeasement" and warn that lifting sanctions on Iran could embolden it to pursue nuclear ambitions. The outcome of the Iran deal could significantly impact Obama's legacy and the 2016 presidential elections.

site_title: Adapting your operating model to win customers
summary: A large company can claim to be customer-focused but struggle to deliver due to its outdated operating model. To truly delight customers, a company must align its organisational structure, accountabilities, governance, and capabilities to meet customer needs. Standardizing certain activities while empowering local teams can help. However, over-centralization can lead to lost frontline accountability. Companies must also foster a customer-centric culture by connecting employees to the impact of their work on customers. This involves giving employees autonomy to make decisions and solve customer complaints.

site_title: SSBs are welcome but other bond initiatives may be more promising
summary: Singapore's upcoming launch of the Singapore Savings Bond (SSB) programme is expected to appeal to savers with a low risk profile, offering accessibility and liquidity. The SSBs have a low indicative yield of 2.1% over 10 years, but investors should consider factors such as inflation risk and potential for loss of purchasing power. The programme may not be as promising as new corporate bond initiatives, which offer higher yields and potential price appreciation, but are often inaccessible to individual investors due to high minimum investment requirements.

site_title: Life in the slow lane
summary: A university herb garden in Singapore has become a global hub for medicinal herbs, attracting patients, researchers, and celebrity chefs. Since 2009, the NTU Community Herb Garden has given out over 3,000 types of herbs to more than 3,000 patients and visitors, with some reporting relief from symptoms. The garden grows 300 types of herbs over two acres and is maintained by volunteers, with the university covering most costs. The garden has gained international recognition and is now seeking public financial support through the NTU Community Herb Garden Endowment Fund.

site_title: Drought-hit California cutting water use by 10-35%
summary: California water officials have issued preliminary recommendations to cut water use by 25% to meet Governor Jerry Brown's mandate. 135 of 400 water agencies will have to reduce water use by 35%, while 18 agencies will see a 10% cut. Cities like San Francisco, Santa Cruz, and Los Angeles will implement measures such as reducing irrigation and strengthening enforcement of water waste regulations. Some communities, like Beverly Hills, believe they can meet the 35% goal, while others, like the San Juan Water District, are concerned about the severity of the cutbacks.

site_title: Kaisa says courts preventing full sales of Shenzhen projects
summary: Courts in Shenzhen are preventing Kaisa Group Holdings Ltd from fully selling its real estate projects, despite the lifting of a four-month restriction on some sales. The company has 111,833 square meters frozen by local court orders, and more than 900 homes sold but not registered due to blockages. Kaisa is negotiating with offshore investors to restructure its debt, a prerequisite for its largest shareholder to complete an acquisition. The court freezes add to the uncertainties surrounding the sale of the projects.

site_title: China tycoons approaching US$50b in gains on HK stock rally
summary: China's richest tycoons have gained approximately US$50 billion in wealth this year due to Hong Kong stocks surging to a seven-year high. Tencent Holdings Ltd, Dalian Wanda Group, and Fosun International Ltd saw significant gains, with chairman Ma Huateng's net worth increasing by US$1.2 billion and billionaire Guo Guangchang's wealth rising by US$850 million. Mainland investors flooded into the Hong Kong market, using the cross-border bourse link, which has made Chinese billionaires richer as most of them have companies listed in Hong Kong.

site_title: London's empty luxury homes become election issue
summary: London is grappling with a growing issue of over 460,000 vacant homes, with many luxury apartments left empty by foreign investors who view them as assets to appreciate. Politicians, including Tessa Jowell, are calling for penalties for leaving homes empty, while some London councils are exploring measures to make it a requirement for owners to use or lease apartments. Developers are also facing criticism for catering to foreign buyers, who often don't occupy the properties they purchase.

site_title: Top 12 media myths on oil prices
summary: The article debunks common myths surrounding the oil industry, highlighting inaccuracies in media reports. It disputes the notion that Goldman Sachs' forecasts are reliable, citing instances of incorrect predictions and exaggeration. Additionally, the article challenges the idea that "non-productive rigs" are the first to shut down, suggesting that rigs in areas with remaining contracts will continue to operate, and companies will apply pricing pressure to their drillers.

site_title: Delta Air objects to US terms for Haneda slot
summary: Delta Air Lines objects to proposed US terms for flying to Tokyo's Haneda airport, citing a "draconian" standard requiring a daily Seattle-Haneda flight. Failing to meet this standard could result in American Airlines gaining access to Haneda.

site_title: How Greece resembles East Germany
summary: Greece's debt crisis bears similarities to East Germany's pre-reunification tensions with West Germany. Both involve financial and political polarization between the creditor (Germany) and the debtor (Greece/East Germany). Greece's Syriza-led government has successfully highlighted Germany's historical responsibility for Greece's economic woes, while Germany's reluctance to criticize Greece reflects feelings of shared responsibility. The outcome of the crisis is uncertain, with Greece potentially remaining in the eurozone or leaving, driven by centrifugal forces that prioritize stability over economic viability.

site_title: Nurturing and tending buildings the Tadao Ando way
summary: Renowned architect Tadao Ando emphasizes the importance of nurturing and tending buildings to develop an attachment among users. He believes that architecture should be seen as a living thing that requires continuous care, rather than a static entity. Ando's approach is reflected in his projects, such as the Shanghai Poly Theater and the Museum SAN, which prioritize public space and organic settings. Despite being diagnosed with pancreatic cancer, Ando remains committed to his philosophy, which aims to pass on his approach to architecture and promote a culture of nurturing and tending buildings.

site_title: Hyundai Logistics to raise 40b won by selling bonds
summary: Hyundai Logistics Co plans to raise 40 billion won (S$49.6 million) by selling two and three-year bonds on April 10, halving its borrowing costs. This move is driven by record online purchases in South Korea, allowing the company to reduce borrowing costs. The bonds have a 2.698% coupon, significantly lower than 4.5% paid on similar notes in 2013. The company's improved financial situation is attributed to the surge in express delivery demand.

site_title: Forecasters point to sluggish Q1 growth
summary: Singapore's economic growth in Q1 is expected to have slowed to 0.1% year-on-year, according to forecasters, with manufacturing's weaker-than-expected performance tempering growth expectations. The median forecast of nine economists polled by Bloomberg puts year-on-year growth at 2.1%, unchanged from Q4 2014. Factory output rose only 0.9% year on year in January and contracted 3.6% in February, leading economists to adjust their Q1 GDP forecasts downwards.

site_title: Genting Hotel Jurong: soft launching at end of this month
summary: The 557-room Genting Hotel Jurong will soft launch on April 30 and officially open on May 27 in Singapore's Jurong Lake District. Located near the International Business Park and mass rapid transit station, the hotel features a "hotel in a garden" theme, environmentally friendly design, and MICE facilities. Guests will enjoy complimentary Wi-Fi, a gym, swimming pool, and shuttle bus service to Resorts World Sentosa. The hotel aims to boost room inventory and drive visitorship to the area, part of Resorts World Sentosa's business strategy.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: China SUV sales soar even as car market slows
summary: China's SUV market has seen a significant surge, with sales rising over 27% to 5.2 million units in 2015, outpacing the overall car market. Growing wealth and limited new license plates in cities are driving demand for larger, family-friendly vehicles. The shift towards SUVs is also influenced by demographics, as the relaxation of China's one-child policy has led to an increase in families with two or more children. Car firms are responding by developing more compact SUVs, targeting the Chinese market.

site_title: Indie romantic musical hits the high notes
summary: The Last Five Years, a romantic musical adaptation of Jason Robert Brown's off-Broadway musical, is a realistic and sincere portrayal of a failed five-year relationship. The film features powerful performances from Jeremy Jordan and Anna Kendrick, who sing their hearts out as they tell their sides of the story through song. The unconventional storytelling method, where each character sings their story in reverse, adds to the emotional impact. While the score may not be catchy, it's musically complex and suitable for those who prefer something less formulaic, earning a B- rating.

site_title: Mylan's US$28.9b offer to fellow drugmaker
summary: Mylan has offered to buy Perrigo for $28.9 billion, creating a powerhouse for generic medicine. The deal would add to a record period of consolidation in the pharmaceutical industry, following Mylan's $5.3 billion acquisition of non-US operations of Abbott Laboratories last year. Perrigo's board will discuss the proposal, with no certainty of an offer being made. The combined company would have around $15 billion in annual sales and would be led by Mylan CEO Heather Bresch and president Rajiv Malik, with Perrigo CEO Joseph Papa potentially becoming co-chairman.

site_title: India's US$33b cost overruns spur Srei to scout for deals
summary: Srei Infrastructure Finance Ltd is scouting for distressed investment opportunities amid India's US$33 billion cost overruns on delayed road and power projects. With about US$392 billion of stalled infrastructure projects, banks are hesitant to fund cost overruns, prompting Srei to step in. This move comes as the Indian government struggles to address the issue of stalled projects, which is affecting the country's infrastructure development. Srei's move aims to capitalize on the opportunities presented by these stalled projects.

site_title: CapitaLand spreading rewards programme benefits to more places
summary: CapitaLand, a real estate group, is expanding its CAPITASTAR rewards programme to Malaysia, Japan, and India by end-2015, allowing more shoppers to enjoy the benefits. The programme, which has 1.5 million members across 60 malls in Singapore and China, will also offer more benefits in China to celebrate 25 years of Sino-Singapore relations. Shoppers can redeem rewards for credits on a pre-paid card, and the programme has already generated S$1 million in redemptions in Singapore.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Daiwa Capital Markets has downgraded Singapore to an "underweight" rating, citing a slowdown in business conditions for corporates in oil and gas and financial industries. The company prefers property developers, particularly City Developments, Raffles Medical Group, and Frasers Centrepoint Trust. Meanwhile, Singtel is recommended to hold due to its acquisition of Trustwave and growth potential, with a target price of S$4.45.

site_title: Bourdain to open mega food court in NY
summary: Anthony Bourdain's business partner, Stephen Werther, reveals plans for a 100,000 sq ft mega food court in Manhattan, dubbed Bourdain Market, set to open in early 2016. The market will feature 100 international street food vendors, including Singaporean and Bolivian cuisine, and will be curated by KF Seetoh. The project aims to create a "United Nations of food" experience, with a focus on authenticity and cultural exchange. The market will also include a farmer's market, butchery, rooftop beer garden, and other amenities, with an estimated cost of tens of millions of dollars.

site_title: Don't give up on hawker centres
summary: The World Street Food Congress (WSFC) Dialogue 2015 in Singapore discussed the future of hawker centers, highlighting concerns over dwindling numbers of hawkers and a lack of appreciation for traditional food-making methods. Delegates suggested various solutions, including educating consumers about the effort and heritage involved in making traditional dishes, giving young hawkers notoriety, and teaching culinary students local cuisine. Experts also emphasized the importance of preserving the cultural significance of hawker centers and promoting their sustainability through education and crowdfunding initiatives.

site_title: Business as usual, say Aviva Singapore and DBS
summary: Aviva Singapore and DBS Bank will not renew their bancassurance agreement at the end of the year, but will retain existing policies and provide the same level of service. The 15-year agreement with Manulife, which ends in 2016, will be replaced by a new distribution deal. Manulife will pay DBS S$1.6 billion to distribute its products in Singapore, Hong Kong, China, and Indonesia. Existing policyholders will not be affected, and customers can continue to contact DBS for service and support. No disruption to new business or policies in force is expected.

site_title: Arts fest expands its scope and ambition
summary: The Singapore International Festival of Arts (SIFA) is set to expand its scope and ambition, featuring 65 events across three months, from June 16 to September 19. The festival, curated by Ong Keng Sen, will showcase a diverse range of works, including a four-hour play by Alfian Sa'at, a two-part play by Drama Box, and a collaboration between local dance pioneers. The festival's theme, Post-Empire, explores complex issues such as post-colonial politics and post-capitalism. Notable highlights include a theatrical piece from Chile, a dance marathon, and a music festival featuring local and international artists.

site_title: Natural born killers
summary: Two films, "The Look of Silence" and "The Act of Killing", will be featured at this year's Southeast Asian Film Festival, exploring the lives of men involved in state-sanctioned killings in Indonesia following the 1965 Suharto coup. The films, directed by Joshua Oppenheimer, delve into the aftermath of the massacre and its impact on those who survived. The films examine the psychological toll of committing such atrocities and the difficulty of living with oneself after such actions.

site_title: Economists see BOE extending record-low rates
summary: The Bank of England is set to keep interest rates at a record low of 0.5% for the 73rd month, potentially making British Prime Minister David Cameron the first since 1950 to serve a full term with no change in borrowing costs. Economists predict this will continue until at least February 2016, citing low inflation and economic uncertainty surrounding the general election. The decision maintains the benchmark rate since March 2009, a move seen as a sign of the UK's ongoing recovery from the financial crisis.

site_title: S'pore casinos feel little cushion from junket operators
summary: Singapore's two casinos, Genting Singapore and Las Vegas Sands' Marina Bay Sands, are feeling the financial strain from bad debts owed by Chinese VIP gamblers. Unlike Macau, where junket operators provide credit and collect debts, Singapore's casinos are directly dealing with the gamblers, making debt collection more difficult. The Chinese government's corruption crackdown and slowing economic growth are affecting these gamblers, who account for half of Singapore's gaming revenue. As a result, casinos are accumulating large amounts of receivables, with Genting Singapore reporting a record $787.5 million in outstanding debts.

site_title: City buzz
summary:
Key events and releases include:

- The global release of the original six Star Wars films in digital HD format, featuring special features and interviews, starting Friday.
- The Ultimate Star Wars Fan Experience kicks off in Anaheim, California, with a panel hosted by JJ Abrams and Kathleen Kennedy, and will be simulcast live in select international cinemas.
- The Zentai Art Festival takes place at Lasalle College of the Arts on April 11, featuring music, performances, and film screenings.
- The fifth season of Game of Thrones premieres in Singapore on April 13, with a Game of Thrones-inspired dinner series, "Dinner Is Coming," hosted by Geek Crusade.
- The $100 Gourmet dining program launches, featuring collaborations between Singapore-based chefs and overseas ones, with the first dinner set to take place on April 22.

site_title: Foreign banks opening branches in Myanmar for first time in decades
summary: Two Japanese and one Singaporean bank, the Bank of Tokyo Mitsubishi UFJ, Sumitomo Mitsui Banking Corporation, and Oversea-Chinese Banking Corporation, will become the first foreign banks to operate in Myanmar on April 23, ending decades of economic isolation. The country's banking sector remains ill-equipped to provide services due to mismanagement and Western sanctions. Nine foreign lenders were awarded preliminary approval, with six others expected to apply for final licenses soon. This move marks a significant step in Myanmar's economic recovery.

site_title: Fresh take on an iconic matriarch
summary: Singaporean actress Karen Tan delivers a fresh and measured performance as Emily of Emerald Hill, a penniless bride striving to rise in her Perakan household hierarchy. Directed by Alin Mosbit, Tan's portrayal is human and identifiable, bringing a new level of relatability to the iconic character. The production's minimalist set and thrust stage design effectively heighten the emotional impact of the 90-minute monologue, which explores the social milieu of the play. Tan's performance marks a welcome departure from previous interpretations, cementing her place as a talented actress in Singapore theatre.

site_title: Malaysia's Maybank submits registration for debut Samurai bond
summary: Malayan Banking Bhd (Maybank), Malaysia's largest bank, has submitted a securities registration statement to Kanto Local Finance Bureau in Japan for its debut Samurai bond offering. The deal's size and terms are yet to be disclosed, but it is expected to be subject to market conditions and regulatory requirements. Maybank has appointed Daiwa Securities Co Ltd, HSBC Securities (Japan) Ltd, and SMBC Nikko Securities Inc as joint lead managers, with BNP Paribas Securities (Japan) Ltd and Mizuho Securities Co Ltd serving as managers. This marks Maybank's second bond offering in Japan's Tokyo Pro-Bond Market.

site_title: Boeing-SIAEC joint venture gets the nod
summary: The Competition Commission of Singapore (CCS) has approved a joint venture between Boeing Company and SIA Engineering Company (SIAEC) to provide maintenance, repair and overhaul (MRO) services in Asia. Boeing will hold a 51% stake, while SIAEC will hold 49%. The joint venture will serve airlines, primarily those in the South Asia-Pacific region, and will take over Boeing's contract to service planes operated by Singapore Airlines and Scoot. The CCS cited strong alternative suppliers and considerable buyer power by carriers as competitive constraints, justifying its decision.

site_title: US$ strengthens, sterling volatility jumps
summary: The US dollar strengthened for a third consecutive day, driven by confidence in its year-long rally despite disappointing data. Sterling volatility surged to its highest in over three years due to uncertainty surrounding the May 7 parliamentary election. The cost of insuring against sterling volatility jumped, reflecting market concerns.

site_title: Celebrating theatre history
summary: Singapore celebrates its theatre history with the opening of "Theatre Memories: 50 Years Of Singapore Theatre" at the Arts House, featuring scripts, photos, and videos of theatre stars. The exhibition highlights the struggles of theatre under strict censorship regulations. Meanwhile, Centre 42 has launched an online repository of over 800 theatre documents, allowing visitors to explore the history of Singapore's theatre scene. The centre also hosts an open call for aspiring playwrights to participate in its Boiler Room programme.

site_title: Opec's no-cut strategy is not working, Iran says
summary: Iran's oil minister says Opec's no-cut strategy is not working, and the group's members should discuss production levels before its June meeting. Oil prices have halved since last year, with Brent crude hitting a near six-year low, and Iran hopes to boost exports by 1 million barrels per day if sanctions are lifted. However, other Opec members, including Saudi Arabia, show no willingness to cut supply, and the group's next meeting may have to accommodate Iran's return without causing a price crash.

site_title: US: Wall St ticks up at open as energy rebounds
summary: US stocks rose at the open on Thursday, with the Dow Jones industrial average up 0.25% to 17,947.48, the S&P 500 gaining 0.21% to 2,086.28, and the Nasdaq Composite adding 0.36% to 4,968.47. Energy shares advanced as crude prices rebounded from a previous session's decline, while healthcare shares also rose. The gains were partly offset by falling utilities shares.

site_title: Five local mobile games to celebrate SG50
summary: Five Singaporean mobile games will be available for free download from Google's Play Store and Apple's App Store from July 1, celebrating SG50. The games, developed by local game developers, focus on Singapore's history, culture, and iconic personalities. They include Building the Lion, KAN-CHEONG!Kopitiam Saga, My Singapore City, Rickshaw Rush, and Satay Club, which offer interactive and engaging experiences for players. The Media Development Authority of Singapore (MDA) led the initiative, which attracted over 40 entries and received funding for four games, with the fifth game being a volunteer effort.

site_title: ConocoPhillips sees oil recovery by end of year
summary: ConocoPhillips expects crude prices to rise by the end of the year, bolstering its shale oil investments. CEO Ryan Lance plans to spend 50% more on US and Canadian shale projects over the next three years, despite a decline in prices. This move underscores the company's confidence in the US oil market, with Lance staking a significant portion of ConocoPhillips' future on shale production.

site_title: Fed minutes put in doubt a rate increase this June
summary: The Federal Reserve is unlikely to raise its benchmark interest rate in June, with several officials expressing doubts during the March meeting. This decision is influenced by disappointing March job growth estimates and the sluggishness of inflation. The Fed's decision may also be affected by global economic concerns, including China's slowing GDP growth. As a result, the market is anticipating a mid-2026 target for the MSCI's global equity index, set by Citigroup at 1,150.

site_title: IMF's Lagarde sees 'new reality' of mediocre growth
summary: IMF Managing Director Christine Lagarde warns that mediocre economic growth could become the "new reality" if policymakers don't act, leaving millions stuck without jobs and increasing global financial instability. Global growth this year is similar to last year, with advanced economies growing slightly better and emerging markets slightly worse. Lagarde calls for structural reforms, including infrastructure investment and trade reform, and warns about the risks of sharp currency appreciation, low interest rates, and overpricing assets.

site_title: Financial risks rising amid 'mediocre' growth: Lagarde
summary: IMF chief Christine Lagarde warns that financial risks are rising, migrating from advanced economies to emerging markets, amid a "new mediocre" global economic growth environment. Risks include prolonged low growth, wide exchange rate movements, and solvency challenges for life insurers and pension funds. The IMF head also notes that structural decline in market liquidity and the potential for a bumpy ride when interest rates rise. Global economic recovery is moderate and uneven, with success requiring a recommitment to international cooperation to boost growth and generate confidence.

site_title: Myanmar farmers face hurdles
summary: Myanmar farmers face significant challenges in producing rice, a key crop for the country, due to infrastructure issues, voracious insects, and greedy middlemen. The country's rice industry was once a major contributor to its economy but was severely damaged after a socialist junta seized power in 1962. To revive the industry, many economists believe that helping farmers, like 40-year-old Than Tun, is crucial to alleviating poverty and turning around the country's fortunes. Experts agree that investing in rice farmers and improving productivity can drive GDP growth, increase exports, and reduce poverty.

site_title: Spinning yarn the traditional way
summary: Professional storyteller Kamini Ramachandran is promoting the lost art of oral narration through her organization, MoonShadow Stories. She conducts workshops teaching adults storytelling skills to pass on to their children, focusing on using one's voice, body, and breath to engage an audience. Ramachandran believes traditional stories foster community spirit, confidence, and a sense of belonging, and aims to revive Eastern literature in Singapore by sharing her own cultural heritage and others'. Her courses are frequently sold out, and she has performed at various venues, including the Esplanade.

images.alt_text: Ms Ramachandran runs MoonShadow Stories, a storytelling organisation, and is also the vice-president and founding member of the Storytelling Association Singapore.

site_title: Keppel DC Reit's maiden distribution beats forecast
summary: Keppel DC Reit reported its maiden distributable income of S$17.2 million for the period of Dec 12, 2014, to March 31, 2015, exceeding its initial public offering forecast by 1.3%. The distribution per unit (DPU) was 1.94 Singapore cents, slightly above the forecast. The annualised distribution yield rose to 6.92%, driven by higher net property income (NPI) and distributable income. The Reit's gross revenue and NPI were also above forecast.

site_title: Oil rallies more than 2% after slump but sentiment weak
summary: Oil prices rose more than 2% on Thursday, rebounding from a 6% slump triggered by US crude inventories and record Saudi output. Brent crude increased to $56.72 a barrel, while US crude rose to $51.45. Analysts say sentiment remains bearish, but traders see some recovery and rebalancing of positions. Industry data shows OPEC producers are pumping more than required, and Iran may increase oil output if a nuclear deal is reached, which could impact prices.

site_title: Foreign funds stay optimistic on Brazil, favouring buyouts
summary: Foreign private-equity funds remain optimistic about investing in Brazil, despite the country's economic and political turmoil. Executives at firms like Advent International Corp are discussing potential deals and business opportunities, including buying universities, primary schools, hospitals, and financial services firms. The Brazilian currency's 26% slump has made mergers and acquisitions more affordable, but foreign funds are focusing on resilient sectors and long-term investments. This optimism contrasts with local firms, which are cautious due to recent spending cuts and congressional approval.

site_title: Royal Group pays BlackRock fund RM388m for KL hotel
summary: The Royal Group has agreed to acquire the 540-room DoubleTree by Hilton Kuala Lumpur hotel for RM388 million from a BlackRock-managed private real estate fund. The acquisition is part of the group's plans to accelerate growth in the region. The hotel, located in Kuala Lumpur's Golden Triangle district, is expected to be a key addition to the group's portfolio. The deal is part of the Royal Group's expansion strategy in Southeast Asia.

site_title: Apple says smartwatch demand to exceed supply at launch
summary: Apple anticipates exceeding supply for its new smartwatch at launch, following "tremendous interest" from customers visiting stores and its website. The Apple Watch is set to be released on April 24, with previews and pre-orders available starting Friday. Despite receiving poor marks for battery life and slow-loading apps, the gadget could make life easier for people on the move.

site_title: LinkedIn buys education site lynda.com for US$1.5b
summary: LinkedIn has acquired online learning site lynda.com for $1.5 billion in a cash-stock deal. The acquisition ties the 300-million member social network with an educational group offering language training and courses. The deal aims to help professionals develop skills and accelerate their careers, with lynda.com's 6,300 courses and 267,000 video tutorials to be integrated with LinkedIn's platform. The deal is expected to close in the current quarter and will be valued at 52% cash and 48% stock.

site_title: Singapore's economic indicators
summary: Singapore's economy is expected to experience sluggish Q1 growth, according to forecasters. The country's GDP has shown early signs of improvement, with better employment rates among graduates. The government has also established a centre to advance sustainable aviation in the Asia-Pacific region. Additionally, Deputy Prime Minister Gan will visit the US for trade talks, and a new grant of up to S$100,000 has been introduced for tariff-hit businesses. The country is also seen as a potential hub for advanced chip packaging, according to a study. Workers are advised to future-proof their careers before a potential crisis strikes.

site_title: More HDB resale flats sold in March as prices continue to dip
summary: In March, 1,349 HDB resale flats were sold, a 17.5% increase from February and 5% less than the same month last year, according to SRX Property. This uptick in sales is expected after the Chinese New Year (CNY) lull, with one analyst predicting a pick-up in sales. Despite the increase, resale prices continue to fall.

site_title: US wholesale inventories rise in February amid weak sales
summary: US wholesale inventories rose 0.3% in February, following a 0.4% increase in January, according to the Commerce Department. This suggests wholesalers may not restock warehouses aggressively in the coming months due to weak sales, which fell 0.2% in February. Sales pace indicates it would take wholesalers 1.29 months to clear shelves, unchanged from January.

site_title: US jobless claims up; four-week average lowest since 2000
summary: US jobless claims rose 14,000 to 281,000 for the week ended April 4, slightly above forecast. The four-week average fell to 282,250, its lowest level since June 2000, suggesting a temporary slowdown in job growth. This follows a sharp slowdown in March, with nonfarm payrolls increasing by 126,000. Economists attribute the weakness to weather-sensitive sectors, and jobless benefits fell to 2.30 million, the lowest level since December 2000.

site_title: Thailand allows foreign firms to list on Bangkok bourse
summary: Thailand's securities regulator has allowed foreign firms to list on the Stock Exchange of Thailand, effective immediately. This move aims to promote Thailand as a fundraising hub for companies in neighboring countries and Yunnan, China. Foreign firms and local holding companies will be subject to additional investor protection regulations. The change is part of a broader strategy to increase Thailand's financial influence in the region.

site_title: HSBC ordered to pay US$1.1b in bail as part of French probe
summary: HSBC Holdings Plc has been ordered to pay 1 billion euros (approximately US$1.1 billion) in bail as part of a French criminal investigation linked to a tax-evasion probe at its private bank. The bank was placed under formal criminal investigation five months after its Swiss private banking unit was charged. HSBC stated that the decision is "without legal basis and the bail is unwarranted and excessive," and plans to appeal the decision.

site_title: Workplace can be a building block of society
summary: Singapore's outgoing Manpower Minister Tan Chuan-Jin emphasized the importance of viewing the workplace as a building block of society, not just an economic exchange. He called for a mindset shift to prioritize fairness, meritocracy, and social progress. The number of employers pledging to fair employment practices increased from 2,679 in 2013 to 3,779 last year. Tan noted that creating an inclusive workplace requires effort from both employers and employees, and that a virtuous cycle of values can be achieved.

site_title: Anti-austerity strike closes Eiffel Tower
summary: The Eiffel Tower in Paris was closed to visitors due to a strike by unions opposing the French government's austerity policies. The strike, involving 90% of staff, was part of wider industrial action by four unions protesting government cuts. The tower, a major tourist attraction, will reopen in the evening. This is the latest in a series of strikes, including one at Radio France and air traffic controllers, forcing airlines to cancel flights.

site_title: Indonesia's central bank bans foreign currencies for domestic transactions
summary: Indonesia's central bank has banned the use of foreign currencies for domestic transactions, effective July 1, to control onshore demand for dollars and stabilize the rupiah, which has been the worst-performing currency in emerging Asia this year. The ban aims to reduce demand for dollars and cut downward pressure on the rupiah, which has dropped almost $4 billion in foreign exchange reserves in March. Offenders will face a maximum fine of one billion rupiah or a ban from using payment clearing systems.

site_title: Oil find near Gatwick airport boosts UK's oil production hopes
summary: A small British oil producer, UK Oil & Gas Investments (UKOG), has discovered a possible world-class oil resource near Gatwick Airport, potentially containing up to 100 billion barrels of oil. The find, located in the Weald Basin, could contribute 10-30% of the UK's oil needs by 2030, but analysts caution that only a fraction of the oil can be recovered. The discovery has boosted UKOG's shares and sparked comparisons to the US oil boom in Dallas, but industry experts note that the oil is likely too expensive to produce at current market prices.

site_title: Tee International Q3 profit down 76.5%
summary: Tee International reported a 76.5% decline in its third-quarter profit to S$133,000, despite a 15.5% increase in revenue to S$43.1 million. The company's gross profit fell 3.8% to S$5.8 million, mainly due to higher cost of sales. Tee International attributed the decline to operational challenges and remains selective in pursuing growth prospects. The company's earnings per share decreased to 0.03 cent from 0.12 cent in the same period last year.

site_title: Credit Suisse may cut investment bank, Deutsche Bank says
summary: Credit Suisse Group AG's incoming CEO, Tidjane Thiam, may cut the investment bank further due to changes in risk measurement by regulators. Deutsche Bank analysts predict Thiam will shut down government debt and foreign exchange business and sell securitization business to a US competitor. This could also lead to scaling back the Swiss bank's fixed-income business in emerging markets, potentially putting pressure on its capital ratios. Thiam aims to rebalance risk-weighted assets between its money-managing businesses and the investment bank.

site_title: Royal Group to buy KL hotel from BlackRock for RM388m
summary: The Royal Group has entered into a sales and purchase agreement to acquire DoubleTree by Hilton Kuala Lumpur for RM388 million from BlackRock. The acquisition is part of the group's expansion plans across Singapore, Malaysia, Australia, and other regions. Royal Group chairman Asok Kumar Hiranandani expressed enthusiasm for the property, citing its strong industry reputation and potential for accelerating hotel growth in Asia. The sale follows the hotel's extensive refurbishment in the upscale Golden Triangle district of Kuala Lumpur.

site_title: Noble Group shares dive on critical Muddy Waters report
summary: Noble Group shares plummeted 5.5% on the Singapore Exchange after US short-seller Muddy Waters accused the Hong Kong-based commodities trading giant of borrowing and burning cash. Noble rejected the allegations, stating it was studying the report. Muddy Waters described Noble as "complex and opaque," raising questions about investor trust. The report follows earlier allegations of irregular accounting practices and Noble's lawsuit against a former analyst.

site_title: German aviation authority: crash pilot's licence in line with procedures
summary: The German aviation authority has concluded that correct procedures were followed when awarding pilot's licence to Andreas Lubitz, who crashed a Lufthansa plane in 2015, killing all 150 people onboard. Lubitz had previously told his flight school about a period of severe depression in 2009, raising questions about pilot screening. However, the authority had no knowledge of this at the time of his licence award. Lufthansa and the authority have agreed that Lubitz's licence was issued in line with procedures, despite the incident.

site_title: Bank of England leaves interest rate at 0.5%
summary: The Bank of England maintained its main interest rate at 0.5% in its last meeting before the British general election, opting for stability. The decision also kept the £375 billion quantitative easing cash stimulus at its current level. Analysts cited concerns over deflation and prolonged political uncertainty as reasons for not raising interest rates, which could delay any future hikes and dampen economic activity.

site_title: Genting Hotel Jurong to soft launch by end April
summary: The 557-room Genting Hotel Jurong in Singapore is set to soft launch by April 30, with a grand opening planned for May 27. Located near the Jurong Lake District, the hotel offers MICE facilities and boosts Resorts World Sentosa's room inventory. The Singapore government's development plans for the area are expected to drive greater visitorship, according to Resorts World Sentosa's vice-president. The hotel's opening marks a significant addition to the Jurong Lake District, a former industrial area being transformed into a business and leisure destination.

site_title: China eyeing Tibet-Nepal railway: report
summary: China is considering a railway extension to Nepal, which could include a tunnel under Mount Everest, with plans to be completed by 2020. The project, at Nepal's request, aims to provide a crucial link between China and India's markets. Chinese foreign minister Wang Yi's visit to Kathmandu in December sparked concerns in India about China's growing influence in the region. The project has raised alarms among human rights groups, citing potential "dangerous implications for regional security and the fragile ecosystem of the world's highest plateau."

site_title: OECD says eurozone economy accelerating, wider picture stable
summary: The Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) reports that the eurozone economy is accelerating, with France and Italy showing signs of better growth. The OECD's leading indicator rose to 100.7 for the eurozone, improving from 100.6 a month earlier. In contrast, China, Russia, and Brazil are experiencing slowing growth, with the US and Japan experiencing flat readings. India's prospects continue to improve, with an index of 99.5. The OECD's report suggests that the global economy remains stable, with the eurozone outlook improving and India's prospects strengthening.

site_title: Chinese tycoons nearing US$50b in gains as stocks rally
summary: Chinese tycoons are nearing US$50 billion in gains as Hong Kong stocks surge to a seven-year high. The Hang Seng Index gained 6.6% in the past two days, driven by mainland investors buying Hong Kong stocks through the cross-border bourse link. Top 17 Chinese billionaires gained a total of US$47.3 billion this year, with Chairman Ma Huateng's Tencent Holdings Ltd increasing by 6.7% and Chairman Jack Ma's Alibaba Group Holding Inc. closing in on China's richest man. The rally is attributed to easier cross-border transfer and extreme discounts to mainland peers.

site_title: Greece makes IMF payment: official
summary: Greece has made a 459-million-euro loan payment to the IMF, fulfilling a payment order. The move comes as the country's new hard-left government negotiates the terms of its EU-IMF bailout. Greece faces upcoming interest payments and treasury bill rollovers, including a 400-million-euro interest payment and 2.4-billion-euro bill rollovers. The payment is seen as a step towards avoiding a potential default, but the country's precarious finances remain a concern.

site_title: Euro zone sets Greece reform deadline ahead of IMF repayment
summary: The Euro zone has set a deadline of six working days for Greece to improve proposed economic reforms ahead of an IMF repayment on Thursday. Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras is balking at reforms, while creditors are using Greece's acute cash predicament to press for implementation. The Euro zone finance ministers' meeting on April 24 will consider emergency funding, and Athens must demonstrate progress on the stalled list of measures to make its public finances sustainable.

site_title: LHN Holdings' Catalist IPO raises S$17m
summary: LHN Holdings, a real estate management services firm, successfully raised S$17 million through its Catalist IPO in Singapore. The company offered 73.9 million shares at S$0.23 each and attracted strong interest, with shares fully subscribed. LHN plans to expand into other South-east Asian countries, buy properties, and grow its logistics services and facilities management businesses. The stock is expected to begin trading on April 13.

site_title: HKMA intervenes to defend Hong Kong's dollar peg, sells HK$3.1b
summary: The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) intervened in the currency market by selling HK$3.1 billion in Hong Kong dollars on April 9, 2015, to defend the local currency's peg to the US dollar at 7.8. The HKMA aims to maintain the currency band of 7.75 to 7.85. The intervention lifted the aggregate balance to HK$242.29 billion on April 13, as the Hong Kong dollar traded at 7.7500 to the US dollar.

site_title: UK trade deficit hits 7-month high as sales to US slump
summary: Britain's trade deficit widened to 10.3 billion pounds in February, the largest in seven months, as sales to the US and other countries outside the EU declined sharply. Goods exports fell 3.7% to 23.2 billion pounds, the lowest since 2010, while imports rose 0.8%. The UK economy's reliance on domestic demand and euro area sales may be threatened by the strengthening pound, which has gained 2.4% on a trade-weighted basis this year. Economists question whether trade will continue to contribute to economic growth in the first quarter.

site_title: 5 local mobile games to be available for free as part of SG50 celebrations
summary: The Media Development Authority of Singapore (MDA) has announced that five local mobile games will be available for free download on Google's Play Store and the iOS App Store from July 1, 2015, to celebrate SG50. The games, developed by local game developers, showcase Singapore's history, culture, and iconic personalities in an interactive way. The five selected games are Building the Lion, KAN-CHEONG! Kopitiam Saga, My Singapore City, Rickshaw Rush, and Satay Club, which was independently developed. They were chosen based on quality, entertainment value, and their ability to showcase Singapore's unique culture and characteristics.

site_title: India not out of inflation woods: central bank chief Rajan
summary: India's central bank chief Raghuram Rajan stated that the country is not out of the inflation woods, emphasizing the need to maintain vigilance in targeting inflation. The Reserve Bank of India aims to achieve 6% inflation by January 2016 and 4% for 2017/18. Rajan appreciated the government's efforts on fiscal consolidation and expressed collaboration on inflation targets.

site_title: Viva Industrial Trust secures Decathlon as Technopark@Chai Chee's anchor tenant
summary: Viva Industrial Trust (VIT) has secured Decathlon as its first retail anchor tenant for Technopark@Chai Chee, leasing 35,000 sq ft of space on the ground floor. This marks Decathlon's first flagship store in Singapore and South-east Asia. The new store will allow customers to make cash-and-carry purchases and is part of VIT's asset enhancement initiative to increase occupancy to 80% or more. Works are targeted to start in Q2 2015, with the goal of repurposing up to 15% of the property's 1.5 million sq ft gross floor area for retail and commercial uses.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks surge 2.70% by close on record turnover
summary: Hong Kong stocks surged 2.70% on Thursday, driven by record turnover and mainland investor influx. The Hang Seng Index rose 707.53 points to 26,944.39, marking a 3.80% gain on Wednesday. This is the second consecutive day of record turnover, with HK$291.53 billion traded. The surge follows a six-per-cent gain in two days, indicating a strong market momentum.

site_title: Asia: Markets mostly down but Hong Kong soars
summary: Hong Kong shares surged 3.80% on Wednesday, driven by mainland Chinese investors taking advantage of the Stock Connect scheme, which allows them to trade in the southern Chinese city. The scheme's expansion to more fund-management firms has seen activity surge, with turnover hitting a record HK$250.03 billion. Meanwhile, most other Asian equities retreated, with Tokyo and Seoul marginally lower, and Sydney losing 0.48%. The US Federal Reserve minutes revealed policymakers split on interest rate hikes, with some thinking June was too early.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower
summary: Malaysia's shares ended lower on Thursday, with the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index dropping 0.92 points to close at 1,849.39. Trading volume was 1.8 billion lots, valued at RM1.79 billion, with 479 gainers and 374 losers. The decline was attributed to a mix of factors, including bank and healthcare sector drag, with US-EU trade talks also casting a shadow over the market.

site_title: Centre of excellence to be set up for developing new e-Services
summary: Singapore is launching a Software Design and Development Centre of Excellence (CoE) to develop digital services for citizens, aiming to create a "Smart Nation" with user-friendly e-Services. The 13,000 sq ft research lab will be housed at the Sandcrawler campus and will provide facilities for user research, experience testing, and consultancy services to government agencies. The CoE will support the development of a strong core of coders and engineers capable of creating IT solutions within the Government. The centre will be launched by mid-July.

site_title: Keppel DC Reit's maiden distributable income above forecast
summary: Keppel DC Reit has reported its maiden distributable income of S$17.2 million for the period from Dec 12, 2014 to March 31, 2015, exceeding its forecast by 1.3%. The Reit's gross revenue and net property income were also above forecast. This was mainly due to non-recurring service income from two data centers. The Reit's distribution per unit will be added to its DPU for the next reporting period, with the first distribution to be paid by September 28, 2015.

site_title: Europe: Shares rise early, led by auto stocks
summary: European shares rose early on Thursday, driven by strong data from Germany and the auto sector's recovery. The FTSEurofirst 300 index increased 0.4% to 1,618.32 points, with Renault and BMW up 2.1% and 1.9% respectively. The auto sector's recovery broadened to France, while Spain, Italy, and Portugal recorded double-digit sales growth. Robust German data, including a 1.5% increase in seasonally-adjusted exports, also lifted the mood.

site_title: Singapore Wrap Thursday
summary: Key stories include Vietnam's surprise at US tariffs, the Asian garment industry's concerns, and Malaysia seizing RM3 billion of Daim Zainuddin's assets. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, while Citigroup predicts a 1,150 MSCI global equity index by mid-2026. Thaksin Shinawatra is confident of his daughter's suspension being cleared in the Thai ethics case. The UK economy shrinks for the second month, and Singapore remains the world's top port for 12 consecutive years.

site_title: German industrial production disappoints with small rise
summary: German industrial production rose 0.2% in February, missing analysts' expectations of a 0.8% gain, due to a 3.1% decline in the construction sector. January's production also fell 0.4% after initially being reported as a 0.6% increase. Despite this, overall production for the first two months of 2015 was above expectations, with forecasts of a slight increase in the first three months of the year.

images.alt_text: German industrial production increased only slightly in February, falling short of analysts' expectations and weighed down by a strong fall in the construction sector, data showed on Thursday.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's share prices opened lower on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 2.71 points to 1,847.600. Volume was 44.29 million lots worth RM17.38 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 111 to 61.

site_title: Chinese developer Kaisa says sales blockage lifted at eight developments
summary: Chinese property developer Kaisa Group Holdings Ltd reported that Shenzhen city authorities have lifted sales blockages on nearly all apartments in eight residential developments. The blockages were imposed in December, causing Kaisa to struggle with over $10 billion in debt. As of Thursday, only 3% of apartments were blocked, with the remaining 97% available for sale. Kaisa is working with authorities to free the remaining blocked apartments, while onshore creditors have filed court applications to freeze assets valued at $3.23 billion.

site_title: Gold prices to fall further this year before 2016 recovery: GFMS
summary: Gold prices are expected to decline to five-year lows this year before recovering in 2016, according to a report by GFMS at Thomson Reuters. The report forecasts a base-case average price of $1,170 per ounce in 2015, with prices potentially falling as low as $1,100 an ounce. However, a modest recovery is expected in 2016, driven by demand in Asian markets, with prices potentially reaching $1,250 an ounce.

site_title: Oil rallies 1% after slump but sentiment weak
summary: Oil prices rose 1% on Thursday after a 6% slump triggered by a surge in US crude inventories and record Saudi output. Brent crude was up 75 cents at $56.30 a barrel, while US crude rose 75 cents to $51.17. Despite the rebound, analysts say sentiment remains bearish due to high production and modest demand, which has knocked prices down around 50% since June last year. The market is expected to remain volatile, with investor sentiment remaining bearish as key oil producers pump more than required.

site_title: Singapore: Noble in focus after short-seller's report
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index declined 0.38 points to 3,460.30 after a short-seller's report targeted Noble Group, causing its shares to drop 5.5% to S$0.86. The market's high volume of S$1.35 billion was largely driven by cheap stocks. In contrast, Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index rose 2.7% after a 7% surge on Wednesday, fueled by hopes of mainland China's market catch-up. This has been the case for several sessions, with mainland money driving the rally.

site_title: 30,000 evacuated in China chemical plant fire
summary: A massive fire at a Chinese chemical plant in Zhangzhou, Fujian, was finally extinguished after nearly 50 hours, forcing the evacuation of approximately 29,096 people. The fire, which began on Monday, was initially put out on Tuesday but reignited on Wednesday, prompting a second evacuation. Six people were injured in the blaze, which was sparked by a proposal for a plant producing paraxylene, a flammable and carcinogenic liquid used in fabric production. The incident highlights concerns over perceived health risks associated with PX production.

site_title: Greece to make April IMF payment, but uncertainty reigns
summary: Greece is set to make its 459 million euro loan payment to the IMF on Thursday, despite uncertainty over its ability to honor its debts. The payment, which was assured by Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras during a two-day charm offensive in Moscow, follows days of speculation about Greece's readiness to pay its debts. Experts from the IMF and EU are scrutinizing economic reforms proposed by Athens in a bid to unlock another 7.2 billion euros in loans. The Greek government remains in a precarious position, relying on short-term bonds for borrowing and shut out from international debt markets.

site_title: China's environment ministry blocks hydro project
summary: China's environment ministry has blocked a hydropower dam project on the Jinsha river due to its ecological vulnerability and damage from construction. The 1,000-megawatt Xiaonanhai project is scrapped, despite China's overall dam-building plan remaining on track. Experts say the decision reflects a tougher stance on protecting rivers, but hydropower advocates question the legal basis of the ministry's decision. The project's blocking may lead to another company taking on the task, as China aims to raise hydropower capacity to 350 GW by 2020 to cut smog from coal-fired power plants.

site_title: Noble completely rejects Muddy Waters' allegations
summary: Noble Group has rejected allegations made by Muddy Waters Research, stating they are "completely rejected" and are studying the report in detail. Muddy Waters Research claimed Noble has been free cash flow positive only four out of 20 years and questioned Noble's management, citing issues raised by Iceberg research. Noble has previously rebutted Iceberg's reports as inaccurate and initiated a lawsuit against a former employee.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close up 0.75%, with Nikkei nearing 20,000 mark
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 0.75% on April 9, 2015, driven by a weaker yen, with the Nikkei index nearing 20,000. The Nikkei 225 added 147.91 points to 19,937.72, while the Topix index gained 0.36% to 1,594.19. This marked the first time the Nikkei index approached the 20,000 level since 2000.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks soar 3.67% at lunch
summary: Hong Kong stocks surged 3.67% at lunch, driven by mainland investors taking advantage of a cross-border investment tie-up with Shanghai. The Hang Seng Index rose 962.37 points to 27,199.23, despite mainland shares declining sharply due to profit-taking. This follows a 3.80% gain on Wednesday, as the Shanghai-Hong Kong Stock Connect sees increased activity, partly due to China's potential monetary easing measures to boost the economy.

site_title: Alibaba finance arm Ant Financial to launch online private bank in June
summary: Alibaba's finance arm, Ant Financial, will launch an online private bank called MYbank in June. Ant Financial will hold a 30% stake, with other shareholders including Shanghai Fosun Industrial Technology Development Co Ltd (25%), Wanxiang Group (18%), and Ningbo Jinrun Asset Management (16%). This move aims to expand financial services in China, traditionally geared towards larger businesses and neglected individuals and smaller enterprises.

site_title: OCBC eyes Indonesia's securities market, Indonesian unit unveils new HQ in Jakarta
summary: OCBC Bank's Indonesian subsidiary, PT OCBC Sekuritas Indonesia, has unveiled its new headquarters in Jakarta, reinforcing the bank's ambitions in Indonesia's securities market. The subsidiary, which has grown its securities trading active customer base by 160% since 2012, is well-positioned to serve the needs of Indonesia's corporates. With a stockbroking and underwriter licence, OCBC Sekuritas can provide securities trading services and financing solutions, and has participated in Indonesia's largest IPO in 2014. The move aims to capitalize on Indonesia's growing affluent population and increasing investor sophistication.

site_title: Moody's changes India's outlook to positive, affirms Baa3 rating
summary: Moody's has upgraded India's outlook to positive, citing increasing probability of policy maker actions enhancing the country's economic strength and sovereign financial strength over the coming years. The agency expects India's growth to be higher than peers due to structural advantages and benign global commodity prices. Moody's affirmed India's Baa3 rating, indicating a stable financial position. This positive outlook is seen as a boost to India's economy, which has been a growing concern for investors in recent years.

site_title: Smartphones boost US teens' connections: survey
summary: A Pew Research Centre survey found that 92% of US teens go online daily, with 24% saying they are connected "almost constantly" due to the growing prevalence of smartphones. 73% of teens have a smartphone, and 90% exchange text messages, with 30 texts per day. Facebook remains the dominant social media network among teens, used by 71%, followed by Instagram. More than two-thirds of teens use multiple social networks, with 66% preferring Facebook.

site_title: Worldwide IT spending squeezed by strength of dollar: Gartner
summary: Worldwide IT spending is expected to shrink 1.3% this year to $3.66 trillion due to the strength of the US dollar, according to Gartner. Initially forecasted to grow 2.4%, the currency shock from the dollar's rise has reduced growth to 3.1% in constant currency. This is not considered a crash, but rather a temporary adjustment, with the underlying demand still showing growth.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks higher as transport shares gain on weaker oil price
summary: Taiwan's stocks rose 0.79% to 9,647.99 on Thursday, driven by gains in transport shares following a decline in oil prices. The electronics and financial subindexes also increased. EVA Airways and China Airlines saw notable gains, while the Taiwan dollar strengthened to T$31.137 to the US dollar. Thursday's gains were broad-based, with the transport subindex rising 1.5% and the financial subindex up 0.7%.

site_title: Muddy Waters says it has short position on Noble Group
summary: Muddy Waters, a short-seller, has taken a stance against Noble Group, accusing the commodities company of aggressive accounting practices. Noble has been free cash flow positive only four out of 20 years, with a significant debt of nearly $4 billion. Muddy Waters claims Noble's management is opaque and does not provide transparent financial information, leading to questions about the company's true financial health. This comes after blogger Iceberg Research also raised concerns about Noble's accounting policies.

site_title: Japan parliament passes record US$801b budget for fiscal 2015
summary: Japan's parliament passed a record $801 billion budget for fiscal 2015, reducing new borrowing for the third year. The budget includes a record 31.53 trillion yen for welfare spending and 4.98 trillion yen for defence, reflecting Japan's aging population and Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's military ambitions. The public debt burden is over twice Japan's US$5 trillion economy, potentially leading to future spending cuts. The budget was passed after a delayed vote due to a general election.

site_title: Hot stock: SIIC continues rally despite 'trade with caution' warning
summary: SIIC Environment's share price rose 5.8% or 1.1 cents to 20 cents after a "trade with caution" warning from the Singapore Exchange (SGX) and strong early trading. The water specialist announced a sale and purchase agreement worth RMB1.55 billion in March, acquiring Fudan Water Engineering and Technology Co Ltd for a planned water treatment capacity of over one million tonnes per day. SIIC's shares were the most active with 109.2 million shares changing hands.

site_title: Samsung expects record Galaxy shipments, supply constraints
summary: Samsung Electronics Co Ltd expects record shipments for the new Galaxy S smartphones, driven by strong demand for the curved-screen model. The company anticipates meeting demand for the regular S6 but faces production constraints for the curved variant, which costs up to $120 more. This could boost earnings for Samsung's struggling mobile division and propel profit growth in 2015. The company's January-March operating profit reached the highest level in three quarters, with positive reviews for the new S6 models boosting hopes for an earnings recovery.

images.alt_text: Tech giant Samsung Electronics Co Ltd said it expects record shipments for the new Galaxy S smartphones that go on sale on Friday, but will have trouble meeting demand for its curved-edged model due to production constraints.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks surge 5.43% to new seven-year high
summary: Hong Kong's benchmark Hang Seng Index surged 5.43% to a new seven-year high on April 9, 2015, driven by hopes of fresh money inflows from mainland investors seeking arbitrage opportunities. The Hang Seng China Enterprises Index also hit a fresh four-year high, with mainland investors rushing to take advantage of the valuation gap between Hong Kong and mainland markets. This is the first time mainland investors have used the entire 10.5 billion yuan daily quota in the Shanghai-Hong Kong Stock Connect buying Hong Kong stocks.

site_title: Australia: Shares slip on weak commodities, NZ stocks also soft
summary: Australian shares dropped 0.5% to 5,932.8, weighed down by weak commodity prices and declining mining stocks. Fortescue Metals and BHP Billiton fell 3.2% and 1%, respectively. Energy shares also declined, while bank stocks softened. New Zealand's benchmark index fell 0.2% amid mild selling pressure. The decline follows a media report on US investors selling Australian mining bonds due to plummeting iron ore prices.

images.alt_text: Australian shares dipped on Thursday as mining and energy firms came under pressure on weak commodity prices outlook, though retailers and other discretionary stocks edged up.

site_title: Chinese stock futures rally in Hong Kong as HKEx surges
summary: Chinese stock futures in Hong Kong surged as investors speculated about the mainland's continued rally. The Hang Seng China Enterprises Index's April futures contract jumped 3.7% to 13,987, while the Shanghai Composite Index closed 0.8% higher at 3,994.81. The Shanghai Composite Index has doubled since January 2014, driven by record borrowing, new investor accounts, and government endorsement. China's March economic data is set to be released on Friday, with expected inflation and producer price data.

site_title: Taiwan's Fubon Futures becomes SGX derivatives trading member
summary: Taiwan-based Fubon Futures Co Ltd has become the newest trading member in Singapore Exchange's (SGX) derivatives market, bringing the total number of trading members to 49. Fubon Futures, a subsidiary of Fubon Securities, provides professional brokerage and clearing services in Taiwan. The admission marks an expansion of SGX's derivatives market, which also includes 27 clearing members and 11 clearing members for over-the-counter financial derivatives.

images.alt_text: Singapore Exchange (SGX) said on Thursday that Taiwan-based Fubon Futures Co Ltd has become the newest trading member in its derivatives market.

site_title: Obama and Castro to break Cold War ice in person
summary: US President Barack Obama and Cuba's Raul Castro will meet for the first time at the Summit of the Americas in Panama, marking a historic break in decades of Cold War-era animosity. The meeting comes as the US and Cuba have yet to reopen embassies and lingering differences remain, including Cuba's inclusion on a list of state sponsors of terrorism. The White House is seeking to ease tensions with Venezuela, where President Nicolas Maduro plans to bring a petition demanding the revocation of US sanctions.

site_title: Auditors issue qualified opinion on Sakae's FY2014 results
summary: Sakae Holdings' auditors Deloitte & Touche LLP have issued a qualified opinion on its FY2014 financial statements, marking a third consecutive year of audit qualification. The qualification stems from the company's accounting treatment for investments in associates, resulting in impairment losses of $6.64 million and $150,000. The auditors noted that insufficient audit evidence was obtained to determine the group's share of results and net assets of these associates.

site_title: China's IMF ambitions send warning signal to yuan short-sellers
summary: China's People's Bank of China is intervening heavily to stabilize the yuan before the IMF considers adding it to the Special Drawing Rights (SDR) basket in May. The central bank has spent an estimated $33 billion in foreign reserves to halt the yuan's decline, despite economists predicting a 7% weakening by year-end. China's economic growth rate slowed to 6.3% in February, and capital outflows totaled $356 billion since May. The yuan's inclusion in the SDR basket is a key goal for President Xi Jinping, who aims to challenge the dollar's dominance and promote China's economic influence.

site_title: Thai 2015 GDP may miss forecast, exports could shrink: central bank
summary: Thailand's economy may grow less than forecasted 3.8% this year, with exports expected to contract for the third consecutive year, according to a senior central bank official. February exports fell 6% and are projected to decline 0.8% this year, following a 0.7% growth last year. The economy has struggled since an army coup last May ended months of political unrest, and the central bank is concerned about the impact of the decline on the country's economic growth.

images.alt_text: Thailand's economy may grow less than the central bank's forecast of 3.8 per cent this year and exports could contract again, a senior central bank official said on Thursday.

site_title: Singapore Q1 GDP seen slowing, weakness in manufacturing hurts: poll
summary: Singapore's Q1 GDP forecast to slow, with a 0.5% annualized growth rate, below the 4.9% quarter-on-quarter growth in the previous quarter. The manufacturing sector is expected to be the main drag, with industrial production shrinking 1.2% year-over-year. The services sector, driven by financial services, is expected to help avoid a quarter-on-quarter contraction. The government's forecast for 2015 GDP growth is 2.0-4.0%, which may be slightly below the actual pace.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open 0.31% higher
summary: Tokyo stocks opened 0.31% higher on April 9, 2015, amid speculation over a US rate hike. The dollar held steady against the yen, with the Nikkei 225 index reaching a fresh 15-year high. The Federal Reserve's policy meeting minutes showed a split over interest-rate increase timing, countering market expectations of a June hike. US stocks rose on Wednesday, with the Dow and S&P 500 gaining 0.15% and 0.27% respectively.

site_title: JPMorgan CEO defends bank size and breadth of product offerings
summary: JPMorgan CEO Jamie Dimon defended the bank's size and product offerings, stating it's "not a conglomerate" and not necessarily more risky due to its size. The bank is facing tougher capital requirements from regulators and analysts have questioned whether it's better off broken up. Dimon argued JPMorgan's mix of businesses works for clients and shareholders, and the bank has taken steps to improve legal compliance. He also expressed confidence that JPMorgan would weather downturns better than estimated by regulators.

site_title: South Korea stands pat on record-low interest rate
summary: South Korea's central bank, the Bank of Korea, left its benchmark interest rate unchanged at a record-low 1.75% for April, as widely expected. The decision followed a 25 basis point reduction in March, reflecting concerns over slow demand and lack of confidence in the economy. The country's economic growth forecast was also lowered to 3.4% for this year, and inflation outlook was revised to 1.9%. The decision was part of a broader trend of low interest rates across the Asia-Pacific region, with other countries such as China, India, and Indonesia also easing monetary policy.

site_title: French TV5Monde hit by pro-Islamic State hackers
summary: French TV5Monde was hacked by individuals claiming to belong to the Islamic State group, who hijacked its TV channels, websites, and social media page. The hackers displayed claims of responsibility and posted documents purporting to be the identity cards and CVs of relatives of French soldiers involved in anti-IS operations. The broadcaster was unable to broadcast or control its online presence. The incident occurred on April 8, 2015.

site_title: Stocks to watch: GuocoLand, Ezra, Sakae Holdings
summary: Stocks to watch include GuocoLand, which reported a 130% surge in net profit for the third quarter, and Ezra Holdings, which saw a 99% dive in second-quarter net profit. Sakae Holdings is also mentioned but no specific financials are provided.

site_title: Optus' contract with Australian Taxation Office extended
summary: Optus has extended its managed services contract with the Australian Taxation Office (ATO) until June 2018. The contract covers voice and data communications, contact centre services, and videoconferencing, serving over 20,000 ATO end users across 35 locations. Optus Business Managing Director John Paitaridis stated that the extension demonstrates the company's ability to deliver high-quality services to large Australian organisations.

site_title: Alcoa now sees global aluminum surplus of 326,000 tonnes in 2015
summary: Alcoa Inc forecasts a global aluminum surplus of 326,000 tonnes in 2015, reversing its January estimate of a 38,000-tonne deficit. The surplus is driven by increased output in China, where smelters have been reluctant to cut production as prices recover. Strong global demand, with inventories at 66 days of consumption, limits the downside of falling regional premiums. Chinese exports of "fake semis" have also pressured premiums, prompting regulatory scrutiny and potential action from authorities.

site_title: New regime for corporate service providers to start from May 15
summary: Singapore's Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority (ACRA) will enforce a new regulatory framework for corporate service providers (CSPs) starting May 15, 2015. The framework requires CSPs to conduct due diligence checks and implement robust systems to prevent abuse of corporate vehicles for illicit purposes. To operate, CSPs must register as Filing Agents (FA) and Qualified Individuals (QI), and adhere to terms and conditions set by ACRA. The new regime aims to boost Singapore's reputation as a trusted international financial centre and raise the professional standards of the CSP sector.

site_title: Canada budget economists see 2015 growth at 2%: survey
summary: Canadian economists predict a 2% economic growth rate for 2015, with a slight increase to 2.2% in 2016. This forecast, based on a Reuters survey, is seen as a key factor in the federal government's budget planning. Finance Minister Joe Oliver has vowed to balance the books by 2015-2016, aiming to end seven years of deficits. The forecast is close to the Bank of Canada's 2.1% growth rate projection and is influenced by the stabilization of oil prices, expected to reach $65 a barrel next year.

site_title: France cuts 2016, 2017 growth forecasts
summary: France has revised its economic growth forecasts for 2016 and 2017, cutting its predictions to 1.5% for both years, down from 1.7% and 1.9% previously forecast. The country maintains its 2015 growth forecast at 1% and aims to bring its public deficit to the EU limit of 3% of output by 2017.

site_title: Fed's Powell sounds alarm on bond market liquidity
summary: Federal Reserve Governor Jerome Powell expressed concerns about the illiquidity in fixed-income markets, warning that the problem could take years to solve. The market's liquidity has decreased since the financial crisis, and a potential rate rise could exacerbate the issue, forcing retail investors to sell, leading to a potential bond market meltdown. The Federal Reserve and other financial institutions have warned of a looming crunch, with the International Monetary Fund and Bank of International Settlements predicting severe dislocation after a rate rise.

site_title: US: Stocks lifted by Shell, pharma deal news
summary: US stocks rose on Wednesday as Royal Dutch Shell's $70 billion acquisition of BG Group and a potential $28.9 billion deal by generic-drug giant Mylan to buy Perrigo lifted market gains. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.15%, the S&P 500 gained 0.27%, and the Nasdaq Composite Index rose 0.83%. However, concerns about weak earnings season and potential interest rate hikes by the US Federal Reserve limited gains, with minutes from the March meeting showing some policymakers favoring a rate hike in June.

site_title: Europe: Stocks down awaiting US rate pointer
summary: Europe's main stock markets closed down on Wednesday due to anticipation of US interest rate updates. London's FTSE 100 slid 0.35%, Frankfurt's DAX 30 lost 0.72%, and Paris's CAC 40 fell 0.28%. Traders awaited the release of US Federal Reserve minutes, while Greece's bailout repayment deadline loomed. Despite news of Royal Dutch Shell's $70 billion takeover of BG Group, investors were cautious amid mixed sentiment ahead of the deadline.

images.alt_text: Europe's main stock markets closed down on Wednesday as traders awaited an update on the outlook for US interest rates.

site_title: Modi out to woo investors on first Europe trip
summary: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi is on a three-nation trip to Europe, visiting France and Germany, to promote India as a major manufacturing and investment hub. Modi's visit comes after his landslide victory in last year's general election, which has led to a relaxation of rules for foreign investors. Despite being blacklisted by the European Union in the past due to communal riots, Modi is expected to receive a warm reception. He will also visit Canada to tout India's "Make in India" program, which aims to rewrite the country's reputation as a tricky place to do business.

site_title: CIMB's first collateralised sukuk will widen Islamic asset pool
summary: Malaysian lender CIMB Group Holdings plans to sell a sukuk backed by a pool of loans, becoming the world's first Islamic bank to do so. The offering of five-year notes aims to raise RM1 billion, diversifying funding options in the US$1.7 trillion Islamic finance industry. The collateralised debt is vetted by scholars to ensure compliance with Shariah law, reducing the risk of a repeat of the 2008 financial crisis. If successful, the issuance could be a trendsetter in Malaysia and potentially catch on in the Middle East.

site_title: US officer sacked after shooting black suspect dead
summary: A white US police officer, Michael Slager, has been fired and charged with murder after fatally shooting a 50-year-old black man, Walter Scott, in North Charleston, South Carolina. Scott was shot in the back after a traffic stop and was seen being handcuffed as he lay fatally wounded. The incident has sparked outrage and protests, with the mayor vowing to introduce body cameras to record police interactions. The US Justice Department has also announced it will take "appropriate action" in light of the evidence.

site_title: AT&T to pay US$25m penalty for data breaches
