summary: AT&T has agreed to pay a $25 million fine for lax security at its overseas call centers in Mexico, Colombia, and the Philippines, where employees stole personal data from 280,000 AT&T customers. The breach allowed unauthorized parties to unlock and resell stolen phones, exposing US victims to potential identity theft. The Federal Communications Commission (FCC) requires AT&T to offer credit monitoring and notifications to affected consumers, and the company must upgrade its security procedures and appoint a privacy compliance officer.

site_title: Singapore's STI opens 12.46 points higher
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) opened 12.46 points higher, or 0.36%, to 3,473.14 points on Thursday, driven by US stocks and Tokyo market's opening higher. The top stocks by value traded included City Developments, Jardine Cycle & Carriage, and Singapore Airlines. The market saw 122.1 million shares traded with a value of S$110.5 million, with gainers outnumbering losers 121 to 52.

site_title: Gaming group Zynga brings founder back as CEO
summary: Zynga, a struggling social gaming group, announced that co-founder Mark Pincus will return as CEO, replacing Don Mattrick. Pincus aims to "accelerate innovation" and focus on the company's founding mission to connect people through games. Zynga has been in retrenchment, cutting employees and closing operations in China, and lost $225 million in 2014. The company has new games in the pipeline, including Empires & Allies and FarmVille: Harvest Swap, which Pincus believes will drive growth. Shares slumped 10% after the announcement.

site_title: Oil dives 6% from 2015 high as stocks swell, Saudis pump
summary: Oil prices plummeted 6% on Wednesday, falling to a 2015 low, due to a surge in US crude stockpiles and record Saudi oil production. US crude inventories rose 10.95 million barrels, a record high, and gasoline inventories also increased. Saudi oil minister Ali al-Naimi's comments that the kingdom would only support price increases if non-OPEC producers joined also contributed to the decline.

images.alt_text: Oil prices dived 6 per cent on Wednesday after closing at their highest this year, as a mammoth rise in US crude stockpiles and news of record Saudi oil production scuttled talk of a sustained recovery.

site_title: Police hunt gang behind London deposit box heist
summary: London police are investigating a massive heist at Hatton Garden Safety Deposit Ltd, where thieves broke into 60-70 safety deposit boxes, making off with an estimated £200 million in cash and gems. The gang, believed to be a London-based gang, used heavy equipment and tunnelled into the building to access the vault. Police are contacting victims and conducting forensic examinations, which could take two days. The heist is considered the UK's largest-ever, surpassing previous record-breaking robberies in 2006 and 2000.

site_title: Fed split on timing of interest-rate hike: minutes
summary: The Federal Reserve was split on when to raise interest rates, with some members suggesting a hike as early as June and others until 2016, according to the minutes of its March 17-18 meeting. The Fed left its key federal funds rate unchanged near zero, citing weak inflation and a labor market that needs further improvement. The participants expected inflation to return to its 2.0% target over the medium term, but noted that the timing of a rate hike would depend on these factors.

site_title: Jury convicts Tsarnaev on all 30 charges over Boston attacks
summary: A US jury has unanimously convicted Dzhokhar Tsarnaev of all 30 charges related to the 2013 Boston bombings, which killed three people and injured hundreds. The 21-year-old former student was found guilty of carrying out the attack, murder of a police officer, and other crimes. The verdict brings closure to the families of the victims and marks the end of a highly publicized trial. Tsarnaev faces life in prison without parole.

site_title: China investors use full daily quota of HK stocks for first time
summary: China investors used the full 10.5 billion yuan daily quota for buying Hong Kong stocks under the Hong Kong-Shanghai Stock Connect scheme for the first time, boosting the Hang Seng Index by 3.7% and the Hang Seng China Enterprises Index by 5.7%. This follows recent signs of increased interest in Hong Kong stocks from mainland investors, partly due to relaxed regulations allowing mutual funds to buy Hong Kong shares.

site_title: Dollar rises after Fed minutes reveal rate debate
summary: The US dollar rose against the euro after the release of the Federal Reserve's minutes from its March policy meeting, which showed a split among participants on the timing of an interest-rate increase. Several participants believed the economy was ready for a June hike, while others thought it would be unlikely until 2016. The dollar strengthened to US$1.0780, as the market initially misinterpreted the minutes as indicating a June rate hike was off the table.

site_title: Reports on forex reserves overlook US$ strength
summary: Reports on global forex reserves have been exaggerated, with many outlets incorrectly attributing a decline in reserves to capital outflows rather than currency movements. The US dollar accounts for 63% of global foreign exchange reserves, and a 10% rise against the euro would only reduce the US dollar value of reserves by 2%. In reality, many countries have been adding to their reserves, albeit at a slower pace, and some have even intervened to stabilize their currencies. The true issue is the rising US dollar strength, which poses a burden on countries and companies with US$-denominated debt.

site_title: OUE sells five-year S$300m bonds at 3.8%
summary: OUE Ltd has sold S$300 million five-year bonds at 3.8% amid strong demand, with the deal being the year's largest non-bank, non-perpetual issue. The issue saw an order book of S$1.5 billion, five times subscribed, and 50% allocated to institutional investors. This is OUE's first bond issuance since 2012, following a successful roadshow. The local bond market remains bullish, with Singapore dollar bonds reaching S$3 billion in March, 20% higher than the same month last year.

site_title: BT bags two SPH Journalism Awards
summary: The Business Times (BT) won two SPH Journalism Awards, including Infographics of the Year and Special Award of the Year for its enterprise coverage. The Infographics of the Year award went to a piece titled "Squaring the roots of a nation" by Kenneth Lim, Simon Ang, and Kelly Tay, which chronicled Singapore's development since independence. BT also won the Special Award of the Year for its feature on Singapore's energy and chemicals sector.

site_title: In Russia-West tug of war, Moldova sees EU as only option
summary: Moldova, a former Soviet state, has strengthened its ties with the European Union (EU) despite Russia's sanctions, with its foreign minister stating that EU membership is the only viable option. The country faces economic and political challenges, including a pro-Russian rebellion and Russian troops stationed in a breakaway region. Despite these risks, EU grants of visa-free travel have attracted 75,000 residents of the breakaway region to apply for Moldovan passports, and the country has become its largest trading partner. Moldova's foreign minister aims to secure EU membership at the upcoming Eastern Partnership summit.

site_title: Banks go on hiring spree in Middle East
summary: Banks in the Middle East are increasing hiring at a rapid pace, with a 65% jump in job postings in March, according to Monster Worldwide Inc. The region's economies are improving, driven by infrastructure projects and government initiatives, prompting banks to renew hiring. The UAE, home to Dubai's financial hub, saw a 38% increase in financial job listings. This hiring spree is driven by the recovery of Dubai's economy and the opening of Saudi Arabia's stock market to foreign investors, with banks needed to help with financial planning of infrastructure projects.

site_title: Fed faces tough decision on US$4t Treasury debt maturing next year
summary: The Federal Reserve faces a decision on whether to begin unwinding its $4.2 trillion bond portfolio, which includes $216 billion of Treasury debt maturing in 2016. If the Fed chooses not to reinvest, it will increase the supply of securities and put upward pressure on yields. The timing will be tricky, with Fed Chair Janet Yellen concerned the economy remains fragile, potentially leading to a gradual or even pause in rate hikes. The Fed will allow its portfolio to shrink "in a gradual and predictable manner" by ceasing reinvestments and allowing securities to mature.

images.alt_text: "When the FOMC chooses to cease reinvestments, the balance sheet will naturally contract," said Mr Fischer

site_title: Pop-up retail to fill the gap amid weaker leasing
summary: Singapore's retail landlords are offering pop-up stores with leases as short as two weeks to boost occupancy levels amid weaker leasing demand. These temporary stores can fill empty spaces, raise retail traffic, and test new brands without long-term commitments. Pop-up stores have become a cost-effective way for retailers to differentiate themselves from e-commerce competition, with many using them to combine online and offline retailing. The trend is expected to continue, with landlords open to rental concessions to retain key tenants.

site_title: United Envirotech to be vehicle for all future Citic water projects
summary: Citic Group has announced that United Envirotech Ltd (UEL) will serve as its water treatment flagship platform for future acquisitions and projects. UEL has acquired a wastewater treatment firm in Hebei, China for 500m yuan, expanding its capacity to 3.5 million tonnes a day. The acquisition is expected to tap into China's growing demand for wastewater treatment services, with Citic Group's efforts to tighten environmental rules and regulations driving growth in the sector.

site_title: Information-rich smart screens coming to HDBs
summary: The Singapore government is piloting a plan to install smart screens in HDB blocks, providing residents with information on traffic conditions, bus timings, weather reports, and community news. Minister Vivian Balakrishnan announced the initiative as part of the Smart Nation program, aiming to use technology to build local communities and promote interaction. Preliminary trials have started, with lessons to be learned before scaling up implementation. The government also plans to explore IoT applications in healthcare, transportation, security, and other sectors, with a focus on open standards, data sharing, and national security.

site_title: BNY Mellon 'bloated' with excess staff, says hedge fund
summary: BNY Mellon, the world's largest trust bank, has a "bloated" workforce with 50,300 employees, 20% more than its rivals, according to hedge fund Marcato Capital Management. The bank's headcount has increased 3% since 2011, with Marcato estimating 10,000 "excess" employees. Marcato has previously called for the ouster of CEO Gerald Hassell, citing missed profit targets and unnecessary expenses. BNY Mellon declined to comment on the allegations.

site_title: Swiss police arrest aspiring jihadist at Zurich airport
summary: A 25-year-old Swiss man was arrested at Zurich airport on Tuesday for allegedly trying to join jihadists in Syria or Iraq. The man, from the Zurich area, was accused of having links to a banned group and supporting a criminal organization. The arrest demonstrates Switzerland's pursuit of jihadist terrorism, following similar cases last year. The move aims to prevent battle-hardened veterans from returning and unleashing terror attacks.

site_title: In brief
summary: Guocoland's third-quarter earnings more than doubled to S$49.5 million, with revenue increasing 21% to S$325.9 million. Noble Group launched a US$2.25 billion committed unsecured revolving loan facility. Orbis Investment Management became a substantial shareholder of Noble after buying 1.4 million shares.

site_title: Critics see AIIB as a China bank
summary: Japan's former finance minister Eisuke Sakakibara opposes Japan joining the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB), citing governance shortcomings and China's dominant influence. Sakakibara believes China's 30-40% shareholding would hinder the bank's ability to become a genuine international organization. Japan should wait for China to reduce its influence and allow other countries, including the US, to participate with significant shareholdings. Sakakibara also notes that the AIIB could evolve into a more transparent and governable institution if China makes concessions.

site_title: Car sales explode in Vietnam as bikers race to upgrade
summary: Vietnam's car sales surged 43% in 2014, despite Indonesia and Thailand experiencing declines, with major brands like Toyota, Mercedes-Benz, and Porsche reporting solid sales increases. The country's growing middle class, driven by 15 years of economic growth, is driving demand for luxury vehicles, with Porsche and BMW experiencing significant sales growth. Motorcycles, which were once a staple in Vietnamese culture, are seeing a decline in sales as car ownership becomes more desirable among the style-conscious population.

site_title: German factory orders fall in sign economy still prone to risks
summary: German factory orders unexpectedly fell 0.9% in February, marking a second consecutive decline, despite a strong economy and upbeat projections from the Bundesbank. Orders declined 1.3% from the previous year, contrasting with other reports indicating strength in the economy. However, sentiment indicators suggest a moderate upward trend in industry growth, and economists believe the economy is in good shape despite global risks.

site_title: Starbucks to pay full college tuition for eligible US employees
summary: Starbucks has expanded its college tuition program to pay full tuition for eligible US employees working at least 20 hours a week, a change from the previous partial reimbursement model. The program, which was launched in 2014, will now cover full tuition for students at Arizona State University's online program, in an effort to attract and retain employees in a tight labor market.

site_title: Record £100m gamble on British vote too tight to call
summary: A record £100 million is expected to be gambled on the May 7 British election, with bookmakers and gamblers risking their cash on the outcome. The election is seen as too tight to call, with neither the Conservatives nor Labour expected to win an overall majority. The Conservative Party is currently the favourite to win most parliamentary seats, but odds suggest Labour is most likely to form a minority government. Prediction markets are forecasting a Conservative win, with some gamblers betting on a hung parliament or a referendum on EU membership.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: US President Trump's 50% copper import tariff is expected to cover refined metal. Oil prices rose over 2% as investors weigh market outlook, tariffs, and sanctions. Stocks in Europe declined, with bank and healthcare sectors dragging down the market, amid focus on US-EU tariffs. US stocks edged down from records amid tariff threats. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss similar to H1. London's Heathrow plans to increase fees for a £10b upgrade.

site_title: Ridout Rd site gets nearly 10 bids, Gallop Rd GCB to fetch S$25.8m
summary: A 73,277 sq ft freehold Good Class Bungalow (GCB) site in Singapore's Ridout Road attracted nearly 10 bids in a tender, with the highest bid estimated at S$85 million. Meanwhile, a GCB at Gallop Road is being sold for S$25.8 million, equivalent to S$1,712 per square foot, and another property on the same road recently sold for S$24 million. Market experts expect a healthy demand for GCBs, with buyers seeking entry-level prices of S$25-30 million and those willing to pay up to S$40-50 million for larger plots.

site_title: WTA Finals tickets to go on public sale April 23
summary: The WTA Finals, a women's tennis tournament, will take place in Singapore from October 23 to November 1. Over half of the 9,100 VIP hospitality tickets have been sold, with regular tickets going on public sale on April 23, starting at S$16.90. The top eight female singles players and doubles teams will compete for a record US$7 million prize, with Serena Williams a hot favourite to claim one of the spots. Two "super sessions" will be held on October 26 and 30.

site_title: US$ falls against yen after BOJ keeps rates unchanged
summary: The US dollar fell 0.4% to 119.76 yen on Wednesday after the Bank of Japan kept monetary policy unchanged, despite slowing inflation. The decision was seen as a surprise, with some expecting further easing from the BOJ. The yen climbed as a result, while the dollar index fell 0.4% to 97.416. The US Federal Reserve's minutes and upcoming earnings season will also be watched for any signs of rate hike concerns.

site_title: RBI head brushes off talk of top IMF role
summary: RBI head Raghuram Rajan has dismissed speculation about his potential candidacy for the International Monetary Fund (IMF) top job when Christine Lagarde's term ends next year. Rajan stated that Lagarde is doing a fine job and that the position is not open, suggesting she may seek a second term. He also downplayed rumors of his future plans, saying he is not looking for new opportunities and that his term at the Reserve Bank of India ends in September 2016.

site_title: Buying Apple Watch? Go online to skip the queues
summary: Apple is shifting its approach to buying the Apple Watch, encouraging customers to purchase online to avoid long queues. The company has instructed sales staff to direct shoppers to its website, where they can pre-order the device starting Friday. This change aims to make the buying experience more efficient and to articulate the value of the luxury smartwatch. The Apple Watch, which starts at $349, will be available for sale on April 24 in eight countries and Hong Kong, with sales estimates predicting over 14 million units in the fiscal year.

site_title: India amends real estate bill to boost confidence, cut corruption
summary: India's cabinet amended a real estate bill to boost investor confidence and curb corruption. The bill, aimed at protecting home buyers and reducing "black money" in property markets, requires project developers and brokers to register with the real estate regulator. The new rules, effective for residential and commercial developments, mandate 50% of collected funds be used for project construction. The amendments are expected to promote transparency, accountability, and investor confidence, helping Prime Minister Narendra Modi achieve his promise of providing homes for all Indian families by 2022.

site_title: Tall Dutch due to natural selection, says study
summary: Researchers studying a Dutch database found that natural selection played a role in the country's tall population. The study, published in the Royal Society journal Proceedings B, discovered that taller men were more fertile and had more children on average. Taller women also reproduced more, with many having large families after successful relationships. The findings suggest that natural selection, combined with good environmental conditions, may have contributed to the Netherlands' exceptionally tall population, with men gaining 20cm in height over 150 years and women averaging 1.71m.

site_title: Global bond issuance heading for a record year
summary: Global bond issuance reached a record high in the first quarter of 2015, with US$777 billion issued, surpassing last year's total of US$2.49 trillion. The surge is attributed to quantitative easing, negative yields, and mergers and acquisitions, with US companies leading the charge. European and Asian issuers also saw significant growth, while Russia and Eastern European issuers were exceptions due to geopolitical fears. However, bond analysts have raised concerns about coupon rates and documentation standards, with Standard & Poor's warning that investors may face difficulties selling bonds if the market boom ends or a company's financial circumstances change.

site_title: Merc develops pickup truck with Nissan
summary: Daimler announced plans to develop a mid-sized pickup truck with Nissan Motor Co, targeting commercial and private clients in Europe, Latin America, Australia, and South Africa. The new Mercedes-Benz pickup will share underpinnings with Nissan's NP300 truck, aiming to narrow the sales gap with BMW.

site_title: Labour movement pays glowing tribute to Swee Say
summary: The National Trades Union Congress (NTUC) paid a glowing tribute to outgoing secretary-general Lim Swee Say, who is leaving the post on May 4 to become Singapore's new Manpower Minister. NTUC president Diana Chia praised Lim's contributions to the labour movement, saying he "spoke passionately for workers' aspirations and concerns" and "juggled many challenging roles" during his 19-year tenure. Lim will be succeeded by Chan Chun Sing, who will take over as labour chief on May 4.

images.alt_text: The National Trades Union Congress (NTUC) on Wednesday paid a glowing tribute to its outgoing secretary-general Lim Swee Say, who earlier in the day tendered his resignation.

site_title: Rinehart looks beyond China to beat iron ore gloom
summary: Australian mining magnate Gina Rinehart is set to begin shipments from her $10 billion iron ore project, Roy Hill, in September, despite 10-year lows in prices. The mine, Australia's largest single iron ore mine, will supply three major Asian nations, limiting exposure to the Chinese market. Rinehart has diversified her market, with buyers from South Korea, Japan, and Taiwan, and is on track to hit its planned capacity at the fastest pace in Western Australia's Pilbara region.

images.alt_text: Ms Rinehart's judgment on iron ore follows her acute call on thermal coal.

site_title: Penny stocks carry the load as blue chips falter
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) fell 4.94 points to 3,460.68 on April 8, 2015, despite the Hang Seng Index's surge of almost 4%. Blue chips, such as Jardine and Singtel, were the main contributors to the decline, while banks and Keppel Corp experienced rises. Penny stocks, however, kept interest alive, with 17 of the 20 most active stocks trading below S$0.50. The market's decoupling from Hong Kong and China events was attributed to Wall Street's expected performance.

site_title: McDonald's turns 'progressive': too little, too late?
summary: McDonald's, one of the world's most valuable brands, has struggled with failed product launches, social media mishaps, and declining sales. Despite its $92 billion worth, the company has seen a 15% drop in US operating income and has been criticized for unsustainable food practices and low wages. McDonald's has also failed to attract and retain millennial customers. The company's efforts to modernize have been met with resistance, with workers fighting for a $15 an hour wage. McDonald's efforts to turn itself "progressive" may be too little, too late.

site_title: ANZ Bank wins appeal on credit card unfair fees class action
summary: ANZ Bank has won an appeal against a court ruling that some of its credit card fees were unfair, dealing a blow to a class action involving almost 200,000 customers. The Federal Court of Australia upheld ANZ's honour, dishonour, and over-limit fees as legal, after the bank appealed a ruling that deemed the fees "extravagant, exorbitant and unconscionable". The win is a setback for thousands of customers seeking compensation for allegedly excessive fees, with ANZ's appeal likely to be taken to the High Court.

site_title: Ezra to cut jobs, boost focus on west Africa
summary: Ezra Holdings, a Singapore-based offshore services provider, plans to cut jobs and reduce costs due to a 20-25% decline in charter rates for vessels caused by the oil slump. The company aims to trim operating expenses and focus on long-term contracts in west Africa, with a backlog of US$2.3 billion. Ezra is also exploring equity fundraising options instead of refinancing its debt, with the goal of shrinking its net debt to equity ratio. The company reported a 99% drop in second-quarter net profit to US$138,000.

site_title: GrabTaxi to invest US$100m in Singapore R&D centre
summary: GrabTaxi, a ride-hailing app, is investing US$100 million in its first research and development centre in Singapore. The centre aims to enhance its offerings through attracting global talent and a mobile application using mapping and location-sharing technology. The investment will primarily focus on developing an app that assigns available cabs to commuters based on their location. This move is expected to sharpen GrabTaxi's services and position the company for further growth in the market.

site_title: Saudi Arabia lifts oil production to its highest level ever
summary: Saudi Arabia has increased its crude oil production to a record 10.3 million barrels per day (bpd) in March, surpassing its previous peak in August 2013. The move aims to maintain market share and keep prices stable, despite being in an oversupplied market. The increase is attributed to strong demand from foreign refiners and domestic refinery capacity, which has been boosted by new refineries. The kingdom's oil minister, Ali al-Naimi, has stated that production will remain around 10 million bpd, reaffirming Saudi Arabia's commitment to not cut production to stabilize the market.

site_title: Use KrisFlyer miles for vouchers on Scoot, Tiger
summary: KrisFlyer members can now redeem miles for vouchers on Scoot and Tigerair, the budget subsidiaries of Singapore Airlines. The vouchers can be used for airfares and selected ancillary products, with redemption rates varying from S$30 for 3,200 miles to S$100 for 10,500 miles. This move aims to align the benefits of the KrisFlyer programme across the SIA Group's airlines, enhancing the programme's value for members amid increased competition.

site_title: Two-tier office rental market likely: Colliers
summary: A two-tier office rental market may emerge in Singapore, with owners of older buildings offering better incentives or lower rents to retain tenants in newly-completed office buildings. Demand for office space in existing developments is expected to be supported by a "flight to quality" effect, driven by tenants upgrading from older buildings. Average occupancy rates for premium-grade office space increased by 3.6 percentage points to 91.8%, while average monthly gross rents remained unchanged at S$11.93 per square foot.

site_title: Asia-Pac execs expect more divestments over the year: EY
summary: EY survey reveals 47% of Asia-Pacific companies expect more unsolicited approaches by buyers in 2015, with 60% of regional executives expecting an increase in strategic sellers. Companies cited weak competitive position and shareholder activism as reasons for divestments. Proceeds from divestments are often reinvested in core businesses or used for new acquisitions, with 69% of regional respondents seeing improved valuation multiples. The trend is expected to continue, driven by mega trends such as sector convergence and technological change.

site_title: Why silencing short-sellers is futile
summary: Noble Group, a Singapore-based commodity trader, is suing former credit analyst Arnaud Vagner for allegedly conspiring to drive down its share price. Vagner was fired from Noble less than two years ago, and the company claims he worked for a firm called Iceberg Research, which published critical reports on Noble's accounting policies. The reports led to a 22% decline in Noble's share price, equivalent to $1.3 billion in market value. Noble's aggressive tactics to silence critics have been deemed futile, as the company's financial and legal firepower is not enough to stop the impact of short-seller attacks.

site_title: US dotcom bubble pales in comparison to today's China tech valuations
summary: China's technology sector is experiencing a surge in valuations, with the average Chinese tech stock boasting a 220 times reported profit ratio, surpassing the US dotcom bubble's 156 in 2000. The sector's growth is driven by government support, lower interest rates, and an influx of novice investors. However, experts warn of a potential bubble, citing high valuations and speculative behavior. The smaller size of China's technology sector limits the potential fallout from a reversal, but individual investors may still face losses.

site_title: Vietnam mends ties with major trading partner
summary: Vietnam has sent a delegation to China for a four-day visit, aimed at mending ties with its largest trading partner. The visit comes after relations frayed due to a disputed oil rig in the South China Sea, which led to anti-China riots and a decline in Chinese tourism. Vietnam's largest trade partner since 2007, China's withdrawal of the rig in July has led to a 40% drop in Chinese tourism to Vietnam. The visit seeks to restore the balance in trade, which has long been in China's favor, with Vietnam's 2013 deficit at $31.7 billion.

site_title: Kuroda defends policy direction, says Japan price trend improving
summary: BOJ Governor Haruhiko Kuroda defended Japan's monetary policy direction, stating that the broad trend in prices is improving, despite growing market doubts. The yen slipped to around 120 to the US dollar, indicating market expectations of further easing. Kuroda expects consumer inflation to start accelerating from this autumn, with a target of achieving 2% inflation by the end of fiscal 2016. Industrial output is picking up, and business sentiment is improving, according to the BOJ governor.

site_title: Vivendi may reach out to Sky to grow its TV group
summary: French media conglomerate Vivendi is considering a potential acquisition of pay-TV group Sky, with a possible bid valued at up to £28 billion. The deal would bring together Vivendi's chairman Vincent Bollore and Rupert Murdoch's Twenty-First Century Fox, but Vivendi's management is undecided and faces opposition from activist shareholder P Schoenfeld Asset Management. Analysts estimate Vivendi's net cash could reach £15 billion after closing pending disposals, but the acquisition's cost, including debt, may be too high.

site_title: DBS has big dreams for its Marina Regatta
summary: DBS Bank's Singapore country head Sim S Lim aims to make the annual Marina Regatta as famous as the Hong Kong Rugby Sevens. The event, which will take place over three consecutive weekends starting May 30, has yet to realize its full potential. The regatta will feature various activities, including sailing and entertainment, and will showcase the best of Singapore's maritime culture. With its current format, Lim hopes to attract a larger international audience and increase the event's visibility in the region.

site_title: US steel firms seek new rules to fight cheap imports
summary: US steel firms are seeking new rules to combat cheap foreign imports, citing record volumes of excess output and losses due to the strong US dollar. The industry wants Congress to revise how trade cases are weighed, considering factors beyond profit levels, such as lost jobs and production. Regulators would also need to consider punitive damages to help steelmakers catch up on losses. The US steel industry is struggling, with 32% of domestic capacity idle and 6,000 workers at risk of layoffs, and is pushing for changes to trade policies to ensure its survival.

site_title: Masagos made full minister; new roles for Chun Sing, Chuan-Jin
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong made several changes to his Cabinet, including promoting Masagos Zulkifli to a full minister with three portfolios, and appointing Tan Chuan-Jin as Social and Family Development Minister and Manpower Minister. Chan Chun Sing stepped down as Minister in the PMO and Second Defence Minister to become NTUC secretary-general, while Lim Swee Say handed over his position to become Manpower Minister. The reshuffle aims to build a "strong 'A' team" ahead of the next general election, set to be called by January 2017.

site_title: Two-day strike disrupts flights in France
summary: Hundreds of flights to and from France were cancelled on April 8, 2015, due to a two-day strike by air traffic controllers over working conditions. The strike, called by the main air traffic union SNCTA, resulted in around 40% of flights being cancelled, with Air France and Ryanair severely affected. The union wants to discuss the retirement age for air traffic controllers, which was pushed back from 57 to 59. Further industrial action is planned, with disruptions expected during key holiday periods.

site_title: SIAS unveils new governance ratings system for SMEs
summary: The Securities Investors Association (SIAS) launched GEMS, a new corporate governance ratings system for small and medium enterprises (SMEs) listed on the Singapore Exchange (SGX). Developed in collaboration with the Singapore Association of The Institute of Chartered Secretaries and data analytics firm Handshakes, GEMS assesses companies with market capitalisation below S$500 million. The system evaluates governance, remuneration, and shareholder rights, using data for three years instead of one, and assigns points for good practices and penalties for poor governance. The ratings system aims to enable investors to make informed decisions and identify well-run companies.

site_title: A divisive Republican nomination fight will benefit the Democrats
summary: Republican senator Rand Paul has announced his candidacy for the 2016 presidential election, joining a growing field of candidates, including Ted Cruz, Jeb Bush, and Donald Trump. The Republican field is expected to be highly competitive, which could benefit the Democratic candidate, Hillary Clinton. Historically, the eventual nominee in both parties' nomination contests has led national polls and raised more campaign finance than any other candidate. Clinton is the clear favorite to win the Democratic nomination, but a divisive Republican nomination contest could hurt her chances in the general election.

site_title: PM Lee's new Cabinet
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee's new Cabinet has been announced. The article does not provide information on the new Cabinet.

site_title: US crude oil stocks surge 11 mln bbls, biggest rise since 2001
summary: US crude oil stocks surged 11 million barrels last week, the largest gain since 2001, driven by a 869,000 barrel per day increase in imports and a 201,000 barrel per day rise in refinery crude runs. Gasoline stocks rose unexpectedly by 817,000 barrels, while distillate inventories fell by 250,000 barrels. The data contradicts analyst expectations, leading to a 25-cent drop in US oil prices.

site_title: Shell takes on Exxon with £47b bid for BG
summary: Royal Dutch Shell agreed to buy BG Group for £47 billion, the first major energy industry merger in over a decade. The deal values each BG share at 1,350 pence, a 52% premium to the 90-day trading average. The acquisition will bring Shell assets in Brazil, East Africa, Australia, Kazakhstan, and Egypt, including LNG projects. The deal is expected to boost Shell's proven oil and gas reserves by 25%. Shell's CEO Ben van Beurden described the tie-up as a "gasification of energy demand" and a gamble due to the current low oil prices.

images.alt_text: ROYAL Dutch Shell agreed to buy smaller rival BG Group for £47 billion (S$95 billion) in the first major energy industry merger in more than a decade, closing the gap on market leader US ExxonMobil after a plunge in prices.

site_title: UOB to reinvest wage credit in employee devt programme
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) will reinvest its S$3.8 million grant from the Wage Credit Scheme into a career development and wellness programme for 3,600 eligible employees. The announcement was made at an employee event, with 1,000 attendees. This decision aims to support employee development and well-being.

site_title: COE premiums soar across the board
summary: COE premiums in Singapore have surged across categories, with Category A COEs rising to S$67,749, Cat B to S$76,612, and Cat E to S$78,000. The surge is attributed to buyers rushing to book cars ahead of changes to the Carbon Emissions-Based Vehicle Scheme (CEVS) kicking in from July 1, 2015. The CEVS will reduce rebates for mass-market models and impose higher surcharges on bigger cars, prompting buyers to register their vehicles before the changes take effect.

site_title: Brent, US crude fall sharply after EIA says crude stocks surge
summary: US crude oil futures plummeted, with Brent crude falling $1.91 to $57.19 a barrel and US May crude falling $2.30 to $51.68 a barrel, after the Energy Information Administration reported a 11 million barrel surge in US crude inventories last week.

site_title: Informatica to go private in US$5.3b leveraged buyout
summary: Informatica Corp, a US-based business software maker, has agreed to be bought for about US$5.3 billion by private equity firms Permira Funds and Canada Pension Plan Investment Board (CPPIB). The deal values Informatica at US$48.75 per share, with the company's shares rising 4.5% in early trading. The acquisition is the largest US leveraged buyout so far this year, and Informatica's revenue rose 10.5% to US$1.05 billion in 2014.

site_title: Noble launches US$2.25b revolving loan facility
summary: Noble Group has launched a US$2.25 billion committed unsecured revolving loan facility, primarily for refinancing existing debt and general corporate purposes. The banks appointed as bookrunners include ANZ, Citigroup Global Markets, and others. This move comes after Orbis Investment Management became a substantial shareholder of Noble, holding 5% of its shares. The loan facility was not related to the recent news about US copper import tariffs or market outlook.

site_title: US: Stocks rise after huge Shell deal
summary: US stocks rose on April 8, 2015, following Royal Dutch Shell's $70 billion takeover of BG Group. The Dow Jones Industrial Average, S&P 500, and Nasdaq Composite Index gained 0.28%, 0.29%, and 0.33% respectively. Analysts expect the deal to trigger a wave of mergers in the energy industry due to the oil price drop. Petroleum producers Marathon Oil and Anadarko Petroleum also saw gains in opening trade.

site_title: Singtel snaps up stake in US cyber security firm
summary: Singtel acquires a 98% stake in US-based cyber security firm Trustwave for US$810 million, its largest acquisition outside the telecoms segment. The deal is expected to close in 3-6 months and will be funded via a mix of debt and internal cash. Trustwave will continue to operate as a stand-alone business unit, with Singtel leveraging its reach to grow in Asia-Pacific markets. The acquisition aims to capitalize on the growing demand for managed cyber security services, which is expected to reach US$24.2 billion by 2018, driven by increasing sophistication of cyber security attacks.

site_title: Putin says Greece has not asked for financial aid
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin stated that Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras has not requested economic aid during their talks in Moscow. However, Russia could provide credit for large joint projects with Greece in the future, with repayment expected through profits made on these projects. Putin also expressed interest in participating in Greece's privatisation tenders and hopes that Russian companies won't be disadvantaged.

images.alt_text: Russian President Vladimir Putin said Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras has not asked him for any economic aid during their talks in Moscow, but Russia could provide credit for some large joint projects with Greece in future.

site_title: Mobius says 20% retreat for China stocks 'very possible'
summary: Mark Mobius, executive chairman of Templeton Emerging Markets Group, warns that a 20% retreat in Chinese stocks is "very possible" due to the market's rapid rise. Despite this, he believes the bull market is intact and can last 5-10 years. Mobius attributes the rapid growth to excessive credit and a lack of regulation, citing a record 1.7 million new equity accounts opened by Chinese investors. He favors other emerging markets, including Vietnam and Nigeria, and advises caution in the short term.

site_title: Apple Watch sleek and stylish but not for everyone, reviewers say
summary: Apple's new smartwatch, set to launch on April 24, has received mixed reviews from critics. Praise for its sleek design and stylish look is tempered by concerns over its relatively short battery life, up to 18 hours, and reliance on an iPhone for most functions. The high price point, starting at $549, may also limit its appeal. Reviewers also noted that the watch's apps are not yet fully developed. For some, the Apple Watch is a "beautiful" piece of technology, but for others, it's not worth the investment.

site_title: MAS can be bolder in making changes to equity crowdfunding rules
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is considering changes to its equity crowdfunding rules, allowing retail investors to participate but within prescribed limits. The proposed framework would cater to accredited and institutional investors first, while a wait-and-see approach would be taken for retail investors. MAS aims to balance investor protection with providing alternative financing sources for startups and SMEs. However, critics argue that limiting SCF to AI investors may exclude retail investors, who could benefit from lower investment minimums. MAS should consider allowing retail investors to participate, but with financial limits and higher income requirements, to strike a balance between investor protection and access to SCF.

site_title: New urgency for governance reforms at IMF and World Bank
summary: The emergence of alternative multilateral financing institutions in Asia, such as the Asian Monetary Fund and the Contingent Reserve Arrangement, has raised concerns about the dominance of the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and the World Bank. Despite previous attempts to create regional alternatives, the IMF and World Bank remain under the control of industrial countries, threatening their influence over the global economy. The development of the BRICS development bank and other regional institutions suggests a shift in the global economic landscape, prompting calls for governance reforms at the IMF and World Bank.

site_title: Manulife ousts Aviva to clinch US$1.2b tie-up with DBS
summary: Canadian life insurer Manulife Financial Asia has signed a 15-year, US$1.2 billion deal with DBS bank to distribute its life and health insurance products through bank branches in Singapore, Hong Kong, China, and Indonesia, starting January 1, 2016. This exclusive regional deal aims to expand Manulife's market share in Singapore and tap into the region's savings-rich population. The agreement paves the way for Manulife to compete with incumbent Aviva in the market.

images.alt_text: CANADIAN life insurer Manulife Financial Asia has edged out incumbent UK-based Aviva by agreeing to pay local lender DBS bank US$1.2 billion (S$1.6 billion) so that it can distribute its life and health insurance products through bank branches in Singapore, Hong Kong, China and Indonesia.

site_title: Guocoland doubles earnings in Q3
summary: Guocoland's earnings more than doubled in Q3, with a net profit of S$49.5 million and earnings per share of 4.24 cents. Revenue increased 21% to S$325.9 million, driven by the sale of serviced apartments in Shanghai Guoson Centre. The group expects to remain profitable for the year, despite subdued buying sentiment for private residential property in Singapore, and remains optimistic for China's residential property market, which has seen government measures to ease the market.

site_title: Gems - a new corporate governance rating guide to investing in small, mid-cap stocks
summary: A new corporate governance rating guide, "Gems," was launched in Singapore to help small investors invest in listed small and medium enterprises (SMEs). The guide, a collaboration between the Securities Investors Association of Singapore and the Singapore Association of the Institute of Chartered Secretaries and Administrators, aims to provide a framework for evaluating the governance of SMEs.

site_title: Bankers set to reap US$155m in fees on Shell-BG takeover
summary: Royal Dutch Shell's 47 billion-pound acquisition of BG Group has generated a potential US$155 million fee for the three investment banks advising on the deal: Goldman Sachs, Robey Warshaw, and Bank of America. Bank of America could earn up to US$65 million, while Robey Warshaw and Goldman Sachs will split the remaining US$90 million. This deal is the largest takeover announced in 2015 and the oil and gas industry's biggest merger in at least a decade, following a robust year for M&A advisers with about US$327 billion in deals.

site_title: China lifts sales blockage on most Kaisa apartments
summary: Chinese authorities have lifted a sales blockage on most Kaisa Group Holdings Ltd apartments, removing a key hurdle for the proposed sale to Sunac China Holdings Ltd. The blockage, which affected around 10 developments, was imposed in December due to undisclosed reasons and left Kaisa struggling to repay $2.5 billion in debt. The removal of the blockage, along with debt restructuring, is a condition set by Sunac for the takeover.

site_title: UEM Sunrise unveils phase two of Nusajaya development (Amended)
summary: UEM Sunrise Berhad unveiled phase two of its Nusajaya development plans, focusing on Gerbang Nusajaya, a 1,840-hectare area to be developed over 25 years. The project has a gross development value of RM42 billion (S$15.7 billion). Key catalytic projects remain on track, marking progress in the flagship zone.

site_title: Update: UOB to use WCS grant for employee development
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) will use its S$3.8 million grant from the government's Wage Credit Scheme (WCS) to fund a career development and wellness programme for 3,600 eligible employees. The programme, called the Wage Credit Employee Development Initiative (WCEDI), will provide training credits for professional and personal enrichment courses, as well as healthcare and wellness options. This decision marks a long-term approach to nurturing employees, with UOB CEO Wee Ee Cheong emphasizing the importance of investing in employees as the "bedrock of the bank".

site_title: US office space rent rises at fastest clip in a decade: report
summary: US office space rental prices rose 3.1% in the first quarter, the highest quarterly gain in a decade, driven by stepped-up business hiring and demand from technology companies. Occupancy growth slowed to 6 million square feet, but development activity and rental growth accelerated. Key cities like New York City, Cambridge, and Austin saw high demand, while lower-quality buildings in suburban areas experienced low demand. This trend is expected to result in a tighter market for office space, with rents potentially increasing at double-digit rates over the next 18 months.

site_title: Opec should change course, cut oil output: Libya official
summary: Libya's Opec governor, Samir Kamal, urges the 12-nation group to cut oil supply by 800,000 barrels per day to prevent Iranian exports from weighing on prices. This comes after the halving of oil prices from US$115 in June due to global oversupply. The comments highlight Opec's divided stance on its 2014 policy shift, with less wealthy members outside the Gulf calling for production cuts. Opec meets again on June 5 to set policy, but a change is unlikely without support from Saudi Arabia and other Gulf members.

site_title: Singapore Wrap Wednesday
summary: Singapore Stocks: No notable stories mentioned. However, globally, Vietnam is surprised by US tariff announcement, seeking a lower rate; the Asian garment industry braces for higher US tariffs; China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers; Citigroup sets a mid-2026 target of 1,150 for MSCI's global equity index; Thailand's Thaksin is confident his daughter's suspension as PM in an ethics case will be cleared; ASEAN agrees Myanmar's election is not a priority; and the UK economy shrinks for the second month in a row.

site_title: World's banks are less global, more local than in '08, IMF says
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) reports that global banks have become less interconnected, with cross-border lending declining to 51% of banks' foreign claims from 57% in 2007. European lenders have scaled back global ambitions, while regulators have encouraged domestic financing through local currency loans. The trend is attributed to stricter regulations and supervision, with the European Central Bank's supervision of eurozone banks contributing to the shift. Asian banks, particularly Chinese and Japanese firms, have expanded abroad, while US and UK banks' overseas claims have partially recovered.

images.alt_text: Banks are making fewer loans across national borders since the 2008 crisis, as European lenders scale back global ambitions and regulators encourage domestic financing, according to the International Monetary Fund.

site_title: UOB to invest Wage Credit Scheme grant in development programme for employees
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) will invest its $3.8 million grant from the Government's Wage Credit Scheme into a training, development and health programme for its 3,600 managerial-level employees. The Wage Credit Employee Development Initiative aims to enhance employee skills and well-being, providing a comprehensive support system for UOB staff.

images.alt_text: United Overseas Bank (UOB) will re-invest its $3.8 million grant from the Government's Wage Credit Scheme into a training, development and health programme for its employees.

site_title: Alibaba to help Bigcommerce clients tap China supplier network
summary: Alibaba Group Holding Ltd has partnered with online shopping startup Bigcommerce to help its 70,000-plus clients tap into China's supplier network on Alibaba.com. The deal allows Bigcommerce customers to easily source products from top-ranked suppliers, including 300 "gold suppliers" initially. The partnership aims to provide merchants with access to the world's largest supplier network without taking on unnecessary risk or sacrificing margins. This collaboration rounds off Bigcommerce's services, enabling clients like Gibson Guitars and Ubisoft Entertainment to create and market e-commerce websites.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed at 1,850.31, down 6.2 points. The index saw 1.82 billion lots traded, with 427 gainers and 372 losers. No specific reason for the decline was mentioned.

site_title: Apple faces local battles as its prepares global payments push
summary: Apple is preparing to expand its mobile payments service, Apple Pay, globally, but faces challenges in international markets due to varying payment preferences, regulatory regimes, and local players. The company is expected to target advanced mobile markets such as China, Japan, and Britain, and aggressive adopters of new payments systems like Australia and Poland. Apple will likely approach new markets with preferred partners rather than a broad coalition of financial service players, and its rivals, including Google and Samsung, are also developing their own mobile payment offerings to compete with Apple Pay.

images.alt_text: Apple has made mobile payments look easy, after a decade of mostly failed experiments by banks, telecom operators and retailers to woo consumers away from cards and cash.

site_title: YouTube unveils tools to make mobile ads more interactive
summary: YouTube is introducing interactive tools for mobile ads, aiming to reduce errant clicks. The new features include "cards" to highlight related content and direct links to outside websites. Clickable links will be limited to boxes near the video player edge, making it easier for advertisers to create engaging ads on any device. This move follows a 45% increase in advertisers using TrueView ads, which give users control over promotional content, in the past year. The goal is to simplify ad creation across screens, allowing advertisers to create new assets for each screen without needing to recreate content.

site_title: Fed's Powell says rising dollar is restraining US growth
summary: US Federal Reserve Governor Jerome Powell stated that the rising US dollar is restraining growth, a trend likely to continue. This challenges the Fed's plans to hike interest rates amid economic headwinds. Additionally, Powell mentioned concerns over lack of liquidity in fixed-income markets.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end 3.80% higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 3.80% on Wednesday, the first trading day after a holiday weekend, driven by weak US jobs data and low expectations for an early Federal Reserve rate hike. The Hang Seng Index jumped 961.22 points to 26,236.86, with huge HK$250.03 billion in turnover.

site_title: United Envirotech acquires Hebei firm
summary: United Envirotech Limited has acquired Bishui Lantian, a Chinese wastewater treatment company, for 500 million yuan (S$109 million). The acquired company has two plants with capacities of 200,000 and 20,000 cubic metres per day. This deal is part of United Envirotech's expansion strategy in China's textile industry. The acquisition is expected to enhance the company's capabilities in wastewater treatment and recycling.

site_title: Hundreds of flights scrapped as French air traffic controllers strike
summary: Hundreds of flights to and from France were cancelled on Wednesday as air traffic controllers launched a two-day strike over working conditions. The civil aviation authority asked airlines to scrap around 40% of flights, warning of "disruption across the whole country". Flag carrier Air France warned of "very severe disruption" to its flight schedule, with medium and short-haul services badly affected. The strike was set to worsen on Thursday, with the authority calling for airlines to cancel half of their scheduled flights.

site_title: Manulife, DBS sign regional distribution deal
summary: DBS Bank and Canadian insurer Manulife Financial Asia Limited signed a 15-year regional distribution deal covering Singapore, Hong Kong, China, and Indonesia, effective January 1, 2016. The initial payment of US$1.2 billion will be amortized over 15 years, funded by Manulife's internal resources. The agreement marks a significant partnership between the two companies, expanding Manulife's presence in the Asian market.

site_title: Mercedes-Benz brand sales jump 16% in March to record 183,467 cars
summary: Mercedes-Benz brand sales jumped 16% in March to a record 183,467 cars, driven by record deliveries in Europe, China, and the US. This exceeds last year's record by 15% and boosts first-quarter sales to 429,602 models. Sales of Mercedes-Benz Cars, including Smart, rose 16% in March to 195,451 models, extending the year-to-date gain to 15%.

site_title: Plan for smart screens in HDB blocks to provide local information
summary: Singapore is piloting a plan to install smart screens in HDB blocks to provide residents with local information such as traffic updates, bus timings, and community news. The initiative aims to foster local communities and connect residents through shared experiences. Minister for Environment and Water Resources Dr. Vivian Balakrishnan emphasized the importance of using technology to build local connections and promote unity and cohesion in the community.

site_title: Europe: Stocks dip at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets declined at the start of trading on Wednesday, with London's FTSE 100 index down 0.14% to 6,950.41 points, and Frankfurt's DAX 30 down 0.11% to 12,110.59 points. The decline was attributed to bank and healthcare sector losses, with investors focusing on US-EU trade talks. The downturn was a reversal from previous days, when mining and healthcare stocks had provided support.

site_title: Singapore: Pennies in play as STI dips
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 4.94 points to 3,460.68, despite Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index surging 4% earlier. Penny stocks drove interest, with 17 of 20 most active stocks trading below S$0.50. Brokers attributed the local market's decoupling from Hong Kong and China events to Wall Street's expected performance. The 5-day rally was marked by a significant decline in STI, with 248 rises and 187 falls in turnover, averaging S$0.55 per unit traded.

site_title: Indonesian man survives flight in aircraft wheel well
summary: An Indonesian man, Mario Stevan Ambarita, 21, survived a nearly two-hour flight in the wheel well of a Garuda Indonesia aircraft from Sumatra to Jakarta. Ambarita, who had studied aircraft takeoff and landing, had learned how to hide in the wheel well and had made a previous attempt to hitch a ride. He was spotted staggering on the tarmac after the flight, with a bleeding ear and light injuries, and was taken to hospital. Ambarita claimed he wanted to meet Indonesian President Jokowi, indicating a possible motivation for his daring stunt.

site_title: China to loosen capital controls for foreign firms
summary: China will loosen capital controls for foreign-funded firms, allowing them to convert up to 100% of their registered foreign-currency capital into yuan to hedge currency risks and reduce costs. The change, effective June 1, aims to boost the yuan's global clout and follows China's efforts to further loosen capital controls. Foreign firms will be barred from investing yuan funds in stocks or repaying loans to other firms, but can buy stakes in domestic firms.

site_title: COE premiums jump across the board
summary: COE premiums surged across categories, with Category A rising to S$67,749, Cat B to S$76,612, and Cat E to S$78,000. The price hikes are attributed to buyers rushing to book new cars before the Carbon Emissions-Based Vehicle Scheme changes on July 1, 2015. Category C for goods vehicles and buses increased to S$64,001, while Category D for motorcycles rose to S$6,312. The price changes reflect the increasing demand for new vehicles ahead of the scheme's implementation.

site_title: JPMorgan China investment banker Philip Zhai said to leave
summary: Philip Zhai, a senior JPMorgan banker, is leaving the US firm to pursue other opportunities amid an upheaval in JPMorgan's Asian investment-banking business. Zhai, a managing director at JPMorgan's China investment-banking team, had worked on China Everbright Bank's 2013 share sale. The move follows other departures, including Todd Marin and Fang Fang, as JPMorgan faces a US criminal investigation over its hiring practices in Asia. The investigation has not accused any bankers of wrongdoing. Zhai's departure is the latest in a series of exits from JPMorgan's Asian team.

site_title: OUE to sell 5-year bonds
summary: OUE Ltd is selling 5-year bonds with an initial guidance of 4% per annum. The issue size is expected to be similar to previous OUE transactions, with OCBC Bank and Standard Chartered Bank serving as joint bookrunners. This is the first OUE bond issuance since 2012, following a successful investor roadshow. The bonds are unrated and off the issuer's S$3 billion multicurrency debt programme.

site_title: US regulator upgrades India's aviation safety rating
summary: The US Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) has upgraded India's aviation safety rating from category 2 to category 1, allowing Indian airlines to increase flights to the US. The upgrade follows corrective actions taken by India's aviation authorities to address safety oversight concerns. This move is expected to benefit Jet Airways and Air India, which currently operate flights to the US. The upgrade comes amid heightened scrutiny on aviation safety in Asia, following restrictions imposed on Thai airlines. The FAA commended India's efforts to address safety issues.

site_title: German industrial orders unexpectedly fall in Feb
summary: German industrial orders unexpectedly fell 0.9% in February, contradicting expectations of a 1.5% rise, due to fewer major contracts. Demand for capital and intermediate goods declined, while consumer goods rose 2.9% due to strong foreign demand. The January data was revised down to a 2.6% fall from an initial 3.9% plunge.

site_title: US mortgage applications rise in latest week: MBA
summary: US mortgage applications increased 0.4% in the week ended April 3, driven by a 6.8% rise in home purchase demand, the highest level since July 2013. Refinancing applications fell 3.3% to 57% of total mortgage activity, with fixed 30-year mortgage rates averaging 3.86%, down 3 basis points from the previous week. The survey covers over 75% of US retail residential mortgage applications, according to the Mortgage Bankers Association.

site_title: Malaysia's February factory output growth seen slowing
summary: Malaysia's factory output growth in February is expected to slow to 4.7% from a year earlier, down from a 7.0% surge in January. The decline is attributed to a 9.7% drop in exports in February, largely due to slowing demand from China. This marks the largest decline in exports since September 2009.

site_title: Chee Hoon Avenue bungalow put up for tender with S$25m indicative value
summary: A freehold good class bungalow on Chee Hoon Avenue in Singapore has been put up for sale via a tender exercise with an indicative value of S$25 million, translating to S$1,399 per square foot. The property, built in the 1960s and renovated in 2005, features a 3,300 sq ft built-up area with two bedrooms and a study room. The tender exercise closes on May 20, 2015.

site_title: Mobius says China stocks face 20% drop after rising too quickly
summary: Mark Mobius, executive chairman of Templeton Emerging Markets Group, warns that Chinese stocks face a 20% drop due to a rapid rise. The Shanghai Composite Index has rallied 89% in the past 12 months, prompting Mobius to become cautious. A record 1.7 million new accounts were opened to trade equities in March, and over $218 billion in borrowed cash is tied to the stock market. Mobius cites "too much credit" and restrictive regulations as concerns, which may lead to a market downturn.

site_title: China lifts sales blockage on most Kaisa apartments
summary: Chinese authorities have lifted a sales blockage on most Kaisa Group Holdings Ltd apartments, removing a key hurdle to its proposed sale to Sunac China Holdings Ltd. The blockage, imposed in December, had left Kaisa struggling to repay $2.5 billion in debt. Kaisa bonds rose as the news was announced, and onshore creditors may be able to claim assets. However, offshore creditors would still need to rely on Kaisa selling assets to raise funds, and restructuring debt remains a condition for the takeover.

site_title: Singapore Cabinet: Masagos made full minister; new heads for Social & Family Development, Manpower
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong made changes to his Cabinet line-up, promoting Masagos Zulkifli to a full Minister and appointing Chan Chun Sing as a Minister in the PMO. Chan will relinquish his existing positions and become Singapore's new labour chief. Lim Swee Say will step down as secretary-general of the National Trades Union Congress and become the new Manpower Minister, replacing Tan Chuan-Jin. These changes are part of "continuing leadership renewal" in Singapore.

images.alt_text: Masagos Zulkifli made full minister; new ministers for Social and Family Development, Manpower.

site_title: UK banks see demand for mortgages picking up in Q2: BoE survey
summary: UK banks expect demand for mortgages to rise in Q2, with lenders anticipating a slight increase in mortgage availability and a significant increase in demand from small businesses. Lending to companies remains stagnant, with no change in credit availability expected. Interest rates on mortgages and unsecured lending are expected to narrow significantly in the second quarter. This marks a positive sign for the UK housing market, which is regaining speed after a slowdown last year.

site_title: Oil prices fall before US data
summary: Oil prices declined on Wednesday, with US benchmark West Texas Intermediate falling US$1.13 to US$52.85 a barrel and Brent North Sea crude dropping 69 cents to US$58.41 a barrel. The drop occurred amid profit-taking after the previous day's sharp gains and expectations of rising US crude inventories. The declines were attributed to traders' concerns over US President Trump's tariff policies, which have weighed on market outlook.

images.alt_text: Oil prices fell on Wednesday on profit-taking after the previous day's sharp gains, while traders expected another rise in US crude inventories.

site_title: Update: Shell agrees US$70 billion deal to buy BG
summary: Royal Dutch Shell has agreed to buy BG Group for $94.7 billion, valuing each BG share at 1,350 pence. The deal will boost Shell's proved oil and gas reserves by 25% and give it better prospects in new projects. Shell will pay a dividend of $1.88 per share in 2015 and 2016, and plans to start a share buyback program in 2017 worth at least $25 billion. The deal will result in BG shareholders owning 19% of the combined group, generating pre-tax synergies of $2.5 billion per year.

site_title: Malaysia's i-VCAP launches first regional Islamic ETF
summary: Malaysia's i-VCAP Management Sdn Bhd launched its first regional Islamic exchange-traded fund (ETF), MyETF MSCI SEA Islamic Dividend, on April 8, 2015. The fund tracks Sharia-compliant stocks from Malaysia, Singapore, Indonesia, Thailand, and the Philippines, and is listed on May 7. This is i-VCAP's first regional Islamic ETF, adding to Malaysia's total of six ETFs. The fund is open to investors and follows religious principles such as bans on interest and gambling.

site_title: KrisFlyer miles can be used for flights on Scoot, Tigerair
summary: KrisFlyer members can now redeem miles for vouchers to travel on budget carriers Scoot and Tigerair, owned by Singapore Airlines. The vouchers can be used for flights and selected ancillary products. This move is part of KrisFlyer's expansion of redemption options, allowing members to redeem miles for more travel-related expenses.

site_title: JD.com sees growth in warehouse services after Uniqlo agreement
summary: JD.com, a Chinese e-commerce company, has secured a warehousing and delivery agreement with Uniqlo, marking its first international partnership. The deal will enable JD.com to supply its logistics services to other companies, expanding its business model similar to Amazon.com. As of December, JD.com operated 123 warehouses and 3,210 delivery stations, covering 1,862 counties in China. The partnership is seen as a growth opportunity for JD.com, and Uniqlo expects to benefit from the company's fast and trusted delivery network.

site_title: Manulife poised to sell insurance through DBS in Asia: WSJ
summary: Canada's Manulife Financial Corp is nearing a deal worth over $1 billion to sell insurance through the Asian network of Singaporean lender DBS Group Holdings Ltd, according to the Wall Street Journal. The multiyear agreement will see Manulife make payments to DBS over the contract's life. This partnership is part of insurers' efforts to expand quickly in Asia, with banks benefiting from selling exclusive access to their networks.

site_title: GrabTaxi invests US$100m in Singapore R&D centre
summary: GrabTaxi invests US$100 million in its first research and development (R&D) centre in Singapore, to be led by former Facebook engineer Wei Zhu. The 4,500 sq ft technology centre will focus on hiring talent worldwide. Most of the investment will go towards hiring staff rather than building new facilities. This move aims to boost GrabTaxi's technology capabilities and enhance its mobile phone transport app.

site_title: Hello Kitty owner probes possible leak of shareholder data
summary: Sanrio Co, the Japanese owner of Hello Kitty, is investigating a possible leak of shareholder data from its online rewards program, which may have exposed the names, addresses, and phone numbers of up to 6,249 participants. The company has asked Investor Networks Inc to look into the incident, following reports that some participants received investment offers from a third party who shouldn't have had access to their information.

site_title: US consumer delinquencies rose slightly in Q4 - bank group
summary: US consumer delinquencies rose slightly in Q4, but remained near record lows, according to the American Bankers Association. Delinquencies in seven of 11 loan categories fell, and consumers' financial discipline continues, with confidence regained since the last recession. A delinquency is defined as a payment more than 30 days overdue. The trend suggests a healthy economy and cautious consumer spending.

site_title: Taiwan launches water rationing to fight drought
summary: Taiwan has launched water rationing in major cities due to its worst drought in over a decade, following the lowest rainfall in nearly 70 years. The state water company cut supplies to around 800,000 households and businesses in Taoyuan city and surrounding areas for two days a week for an indefinite period. The government imposed the measure as the water supply situation became "urgent." Homes and businesses are adopting water-saving measures, and some businesses are concerned about potential losses if the rationing continues.

site_title: Singapore's STI opens flat ahead of BoJ rate decision
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) in Singapore opened flat at 3,465.29 points, following a decline in US stocks overnight ahead of the Bank of Japan's rate decision. Trading volume was 219.2 million shares worth S$74.4 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 125 to 47, with top stocks including DBS, UOB, Singtel, and Keppel Corp.

site_title: Australia: Shares rise on strong mining, energy sectors; NZ subdued
summary: Australian shares rose 0.3% to a seven-year peak, driven by higher oil prices and steadier iron ore prices, while bank shares remained soft. The S&P/ASX 200 index reached 5,944.6. New Zealand's benchmark index rose 0.1% to 5,855.5.

site_title: Shell agrees US$70 billion deal to buy BG
summary: Royal Dutch Shell has agreed to buy BG Group for $94.7 billion, marking the first oil super-merger in a decade. The deal, valued at 47 billion pounds, includes a 52% premium to the average trading price. Under the agreement, BG shareholders will own around 19% of the combined group.

site_title: Wilmar warns of potential Australian sugar production shortfall
summary: Wilmar International Ltd warns of potential Australian sugar production shortfall due to dry weather in Queensland, which accounts for 95% of the country's sugar cane production. The dry spell may impact global sugar prices, which have fallen to six-year lows. Australian sugar production was estimated to reach an eight-year high of 4.7 million tonnes, but the current dry weather may lead to a production shortfall, supporting global sugar prices.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open up 0.45%
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 0.45% on Wednesday, driven by a strengthening US dollar against the yen. The dollar gained against the euro and yen, lifting investor sentiment towards Japanese exporters. The Nikkei 225 index rose 89.16 points to 19,729.70. This follows a modest decline in US stocks on Tuesday, where cautious sentiment about earnings season offset major acquisition deals.

site_title: US: Stocks dip on earnings caution
summary: US stocks declined modestly on Tuesday, as cautious sentiment ahead of the earnings season offset positive news from FedEx and Informatica. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.03%, the S&P 500 dropped 0.21%, and the Nasdaq Composite Index shed 0.14%. FedEx rose 2.7% after announcing a $4.4 billion acquisition of TNT Express, while Informatica surged 4.3% after being acquired for $5.3 billion. The market remains edgy ahead of Alcoa's earnings report on Wednesday, which is expected to be a key indicator of the season's performance.

site_title: Singapore's Ezra looks to raise funds through equity
summary: Singapore-based oilfield service firm Ezra Holdings is exploring equity fundraising to refinance debt and improve its balance sheet. The company, which has borrowed heavily to expand its fleet, aims to battle the industry's downturn caused by lower crude oil prices. Stocks and debts of oilfield service companies, including smaller firms, have come under pressure. Ezra's move is seen as a response to the challenging market conditions, with the company's senior executive stating that equity fundraising is being considered to improve its financial position.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open up 1.71%
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened up 1.71% on April 8, 2015, after US jobs data tempered interest rate hike chances. The Hang Seng Index rose 432.60 points to 25,708.24. Mainland China's Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also gained, adding 0.36% and 0.32% respectively to 3,975.71 and 2,130.91.

site_title: Asian stocks gain before BOJ as Yen holds drop; oil snaps rally
summary: Asian stocks rose, led by Japan's Topix index, as the yen weakened, boosting shares before the Bank of Japan's monetary policy report. The MSCI Asia Pacific Index gained 0.3% and oil fell for the first time in three days. The BOJ is expected to maintain stimulus, while the Federal Reserve's minutes may provide clarity on US rate rises. Analysts predict the BOJ will expand stimulus by the end of October, amid global central banks easing policy to combat deflation.

site_title: Australia's ANZ Bank wins appeal on landmark unfair fees class action
summary: ANZ Bank successfully appealed a court ruling that some of its credit card fees were unfair, dealing a blow to a class action involving nearly 200,000 customers seeking millions in compensation. The case is one of several class actions brought by law firm Maurice Blackburn against Australian lenders. The ruling is a setback for the hopes of customers who claim they were charged excessive and unlawful fees.

site_title: Brokers' take: Citi keeps 'buy' on Noble, target price cut to S$1.31
summary: Citi has maintained its "buy" rating on Noble Group, but lowered its target price from S$1.48 to S$1.31 due to reduced return on equity assumptions. The analyst attributed the change to a reassessment of Noble's fair value, citing that long-term offtake agreements likely make up a smaller portion of its fair value. Noble shares closed at S$0.935 on Tuesday, up half a cent.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Singtel, Ezra
summary: Singtel announced its US$810 million purchase of cyber security firm Trustwave Holdings. Ezra Holdings reported a 99% fall in net profit to US$138,000 in its second quarter, despite stable revenue and increased costs.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks dip on profit taking in techs
summary: Taiwan's main TAIEX index fell 0.2% to 9,620.14 points, as investors took profits on tech shares following recent gains. Chipmaker TSMC was down 0.7%, while the electronics subindex and financial subindex also declined. The Taiwan dollar edged up to T$31.100 to the US dollar.

site_title: Simon Tay appointed independent director of LGT Bank (Singapore)
summary: Simon Tay, a Singapore lawyer and former Nominated Member of Parliament, has been appointed as an independent director to the board of LGT Bank (Singapore), the Singapore subsidiary of the Liechtenstein-based private bank LGT Group. Prince Maximilian of Liechtenstein stated that Tay's insights and guidance will be invaluable for the expansion of LGT Group's business in Asean and Asia.

images.alt_text: Singapore lawyer and former Nominated Member of Parliament Simon Tay has been appointed an independent director to the board of LGT Bank (Singapore).

site_title: Alibaba Group may inject entertainment assets into pictures unit
summary: Alibaba Group may inject entertainment assets into its Hong Kong-listed movies unit, Alibaba Pictures Group Ltd, amid accounting flaws. The assets include an online movie ticketing business and a financing platform. The proposal is non-binding, and there's no certainty a deal will go ahead. Alibaba Group bought an $800 million stake in the Chinese film company last year as part of Chairman Jack Ma's plan to build a movie and TV portfolio. The move comes after the company delayed earnings release due to possible misstated tax payments and lax internal controls.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close up 0.76% at new 15-year high
summary: Tokyo stocks reached a 15-year high, closing 0.76% higher at 19,789.81, driven by gains in the Nikkei 225 index. However, the yen's increase due to the Bank of Japan's decision to hold off fresh stimulus curbed gains. The Topix index also rose 0.63% to 1,588.47. The move follows a recent rally in Asian stocks, with traders brushing off new Trump threats to extend the gains.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 4.02 points to 1,852.49. Volume was 29 million lots worth RM11 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 91 to 60.

site_title: Shell in talks to buy Britain's BG Group: report
summary: Royal Dutch Shell is in talks to acquire Britain's BG Group, a £31 billion deal that would be a rare megadeal in the energy market. The acquisition comes as oil prices have plunged since last June, prompting BG Group to slash spending and write down the value of its oil and gas assets by almost $9 billion. The deal would solidify Shell's position as a major player in the energy industry, marking a banner year for mergers and acquisitions.

site_title: Samsung sees sunnier days ahead despite another fall in profit
summary: Samsung Electronics reported its first quarter earnings, beating analyst forecasts with an operating profit of 5.9 trillion won (S$7.4 billion), down 30% from the same period last year. Sales totaled 47 trillion won, down 12% from the previous year. The company expects earnings to beat forecasts, driven by better-than-expected early sales of its new Galaxy S6 phone and new demand for microchips. Analysts note that Samsung's new strategy to offer a single series of lower-end smartphones and its supply of microprocessors to Apple could help the company turn around its fortunes.

site_title: IMF sees low potential growth for world's economies
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has downgraded the world's growth potential due to ageing populations, declining technological innovation, and poor employment gains. The report suggests that interest rates will likely remain low for years, as economies struggle to grow without hitting inflationary speed bumps. This is a continuation of the slowdown in richer economies before the 2007-2009 financial crisis.

site_title: Selling activity among companies in Asia expected to rise: EY
