site_title: Malaysia passes terrorism law, raising rights fears
summary: Malaysia's parliament passed a tough anti-terrorism law, allowing detention without charge, amid concerns of a deepening crackdown on civil liberties. The Prevention of Terrorism Act has raised worries about human rights and democracy, with opposition lawmakers and rights groups denouncing it as a harsh blow. The law's passage follows a 2013 election setback for the ruling regime and a recent surge in Islamic State recruits from Malaysia. Authorities have arrested dozens of people suspected of links to the group, fueling concerns of a return to a previous draconian Internal Security Act.

site_title: In brief
summary: Asiasons Capital plans to sell a subsidiary to boost liquidity and reduce debt, with negotiations underway. The firm will also issue up to S$25 million in convertible notes. TREK 2000 International secured a US$50 million contract to supply proprietary Wifi memory modules to Mattel. Geo Energy Resources gained a new substantial shareholder, Heah Theare Haw, with a 5.58% stake. Asiasons Capital is also changing its name to Attilan Group Limited, with a shareholder approval vote set for April 29.

site_title: Samsung Electronics flags 30.5% on-year drop in Q1 profit
summary: Samsung Electronics reported a 30.5% drop in Q1 operating profit to 5.9 trillion won (S$7.32 billion), down from 8.49 trillion won a year ago. The company's mobile business continues to face stiff competition from Chinese makers and Apple. However, the estimate showed an 11.5% profit increase from the previous quarter, suggesting a possible turnaround.

site_title: Singapore to release monetary policy statement, Q1 advance GDP on April 14
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority of Singapore will release its semi-annual monetary policy statement on April 14, along with Q1 advance GDP estimates. Recent soft economic data has led some economists to forecast further easing of monetary policy, but others expect no change due to factors already factored in. The MAS manages monetary policy by adjusting the Singapore dollar's value against its trading partners, having previously eased policy in January to slow dollar appreciation. The statement will be released at 8am, with press releases available on the websites of the Ministry of Trade and Industry and the Singapore Department of Statistics.

site_title: EMAS Offshore Q2 profit surges on divestment, forex gains
summary: EMAS Offshore Limited reported a net profit of US$9.7 million in Q2 2015, up from US$4 million in the same quarter last year, driven by foreign exchange gains and a gain on disposal of an anchor handling tug. Revenue fell 10% year-over-year to US$60.9 million due to weakness in the AHTS and PSV segments. Despite declining revenues, the company realised cost benefits and operational efficiencies from the business combination and will maintain operational performance through cost-optimisation initiatives and focusing on operational excellence.

site_title: Viacom to cut jobs, abandon titles, reorganise network groups
summary: Viacom Inc, the parent company of Paramount Pictures and cable networks MTV and Comedy Central, is undertaking a restructuring process. The company plans to cut jobs, abandon acquired titles, and reorganize network groups into two new organizations to drive growth. A related pre-tax charge of approximately $785 million will be taken in the quarter ended March 31. The restructuring also halts a $20 billion share buyback program and spending on acquisitions anticipated in the current fiscal year.

site_title: US: Stocks rise as Fed interest rate fears ease
summary: US stocks rose on Monday as concerns about Federal Reserve interest rate increases eased, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average gaining 117.61 points to 17,880.85. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also rose, with the Nasdaq gaining 30.38 points to 4,917.32. Federal Reserve Bank of New York President William Dudley said a disappointing March jobs report suggests weak first-quarter growth, leaving the timing of interest rate hikes uncertain.

site_title: UK economy probably picked up speed in Q1, says CBI employer group
summary: The Confederation of British Industry (CBI) reported that the UK economy likely experienced a 0.7% growth rate in the first quarter of 2015, surpassing the 0.6% growth in the previous quarter. This upbeat assessment contrasts with earlier predictions of slower growth due to a fall in services output in January. The CBI's monthly growth indicator suggests a stronger economic recovery as the UK heads towards a national election.

site_title: KTL Global to relocate bulk of operations from Singapore to Johor
summary: KTL Global is relocating its bulk of operations from Singapore to Johor, Malaysia, with the relocation of its heavy steel rope and rigging production expected to be completed by June. The group plans to increase its manpower in Malaysia from 18 to 50 by the end of 2015, with the relocation expected to result in significant operational cost efficiencies, translating to improved internal efficiencies and rising cost efficiencies in the following years.

site_title: India seen keeping rates on hold, while signalling readiness to act
summary: India's central bank, the Reserve Bank of India (RBI), is expected to keep its benchmark interest rate at 7.50% during a policy review on Tuesday. This decision comes after the RBI cut rates twice this year, and the central bank is signaling its readiness to lower rates further if inflation stays within its target of 2-6%. The consumer price index rose 5.37% in February, staying within the RBI's target for the fifth consecutive month.

site_title: Hong Kong's PCCW ends bid for stake in Orange's Dailymotion
summary: Hong Kong's PCCW Group is ending its bid for a 49% stake in Orange's Dailymotion, citing French government preference for a European partner. The decision comes after Economy Minister Emmanuel Macron discouraged international companies from participating. Orange had been seeking a partner to fund Dailymotion's growth and development outside Europe. French media group Vivendi has made an offer of 250 million euros to buy out Dailymotion, which will be presented to Orange's board of directors.

site_title: US financier Rogers says now may be time to invest in Russia
summary: US financier Jim Rogers expressed optimism about Russia's stock market, citing a 20% gain since the start of the year. Following a 45% drop in 2014 due to oil price declines and Western sanctions, Rogers believes the RTS index is now an attractive investment opportunity. With oil prices having hit their bottom, Rogers sees Russia's economic prospects as promising, making it a favorable time to invest in Russian shares.

site_title: German aviation watchdog says it did not know crash pilot's medical history
summary: A German aviation watchdog stated it was unaware of co-pilot Andreas Lubitz's medical history prior to the Germanwings crash, which killed 150 people. Lubitz had previously informed his flight school about a period of severe depression, but the authority had no record of this. The crash raises questions about medical oversight of pilots and whether the Luftfahrtbundesamt's staffing shortage may have limited its ability to carry out medical checks.

site_title: Australia chases BHP, Rio Tinto on Singapore tax shelter
summary: Australia is pursuing tax claims against global miners BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto for shifting billions of dollars in iron ore profits through Singapore marketing hubs that pay almost no tax. The Australian Taxation Office is seeking over A$1 billion in base tax from 15 marketing hub cases. The companies claim their Singapore operations were set up to serve customers, but the tax office considers the arrangements tax avoidance. The dispute is part of a larger tax audit of over 15 marketing hubs used by resource companies.

site_title: In a sweet spot
summary: The S&P 500 has reached an all-time high, with valuations at an 18x price-earnings ratio, prompting investors to reassess their portfolios for more attractively valued investments.

site_title: Higher forex volatility driving more Europe firms to head abroad
summary: European manufacturers are reworking their strategies due to higher forex volatility, with many adopting a model where customers, suppliers, and factories use one currency. This approach, known as "natural hedging," can protect against exchange rate fluctuations. Companies like Volvo Cars, Asos, and food and drink makers such as Nestle and Unilever are exploring regionalization and local sourcing to mitigate risks. With the cost of hedging against future volatility increasing by three times, businesses are seeking to match currency receipts and outflows to maximize natural hedge benefits.

site_title: Two years on, Abenomics hasn't delivered
summary: Two years after the launch of Abenomics, Japan's economy remains stagnant, with low consumption, low investment, and modest growth. The Bank of Japan's monetary stimulus has not achieved its expected results, with inflation-adjusted GDP growing at around 1% and inflation well short of the 2% target. The "third arrow" of structural reforms has yet to materialize, and the credibility of Abenomics has been called into question. Analysts argue that Japan lacks a compelling vision for its future, and the country's aging population and dwindling workforce are hindering economic growth.

site_title: Doctor with heart
summary: Cardiologist Michael Lim was inspired to pursue medicine after his grandmother's death from colon cancer. He believes doctors can't cure cancer and patients suffer greatly. Lim's career change led to a passion for helping others.

site_title: Explosion at China chemical plant injures three
summary: An explosion occurred at a chemical plant in Zhangzhou, China, injuring three people, the second accident at the site in two years. The plant produces paraxylene, a chemical used in fabric production, sparking concerns over health risks and environmental impact. Protests have been held in the past against similar plants, with authorities now stating that construction must pass environmental impact assessments. The incident highlights ongoing environmental concerns in China, where rapid industrial expansion has taken a heavy toll.

site_title: Conservatives may yet derail the Iran nuclear deal
summary: US and Iran reach a framework deal to curb Iran's nuclear program, with the US and Iran agreeing to a 75% reduction in uranium enrichment infrastructure and a significant reduction in enriched uranium stockpile. The deal, which could pave the way for a final, comprehensive agreement by June, has raised alarm among conservatives in both countries, including Israel and Saudi Arabia. Despite this, US President Barack Obama sees the deal as a major foreign policy victory, while Iranian President Hassan Rouhani hopes it will boost his economy. However, opposition from the Republican Party and others could derail the deal.

site_title: Boeing clings to lead over Airbus in long-haul jets
summary: Boeing maintains its lead over Airbus in the long-haul jet market, with 55% market share, despite Airbus's efforts to gain ground with its new A350. The A350 is touted for its lightweight, carbon fiber composition, which can save up to 25% in fuel consumption, but Boeing remains confident in its lead. Analysts see a more competitive landscape, with Airbus having a foothold in the market for both the 787 and 777. Demand for jumbo jets is expected to reach 7,800 units worth $1 trillion in the next 20 years, with Boeing currently holding the majority of orders.

images.alt_text: Boeing is fighting tough efforts by rival Airbus to score big gains in the market for long-haul jets, a segment of the massive aircraft market that the US giant has dominated.

site_title: US wage growth pales relative to stock gains
summary: US wage growth has lagged behind stock market gains, with wages rising 2% annually and stocks increasing 20% over the last six years. This divergence is a concern, as the percentage of US families owning stock has decreased, and record stock prices have enriched households but not broadly shared. Despite signs of loosening purse strings, hourly pay has only risen 0.3% from the prior month and 2.1% from a year earlier. Experts attribute the gap to weak wage growth and strong corporate earnings.

site_title: Malaysian businesses: We're harder hit by weak ringgit than by GST
summary: Malaysian businesses are feeling the impact of the weak ringgit more than the new 6% Goods & Services Tax (GST). A survey by the Associated Chinese Chamber of Commerce & Industries Malaysia found that nearly 90% of respondents expect the ringgit to continue its downward slide against other major currencies. The ringgit has depreciated 14% against the US dollar since mid-2014, and businesses are struggling to pass on increased costs to consumers. Exporters have benefited from the surging dollar, but domestic businesses are finding it tougher to absorb the costs.

site_title: A cause worthy of a food rally
summary: Samsui Supplies and Services, a subsidiary of the Soup Restaurant Group, organizes food rallies to distribute food to underprivileged recipients. This initiative has been a core part of the company's mission and vision. By contributing to the community, Samsui aims to make a positive impact, demonstrating the importance of corporate social responsibility.

site_title: Huge collection of Swatch watches up for auction
summary: A massive collection of over 5,800 Swatch watches, including limited editions by artists, is up for auction at Sotheby's in Hong Kong, with an estimated value of over US$1.3 million. The collection, owned by Luxembourg-based collector Paul Dunkel, features a wide range of designs and is considered one of the largest private collections of Swatch watches in the world. Dunkel, a retired insurance broker, is selling the collection after dedicating over two decades to tracking down almost all Swatch watches created in its first 25 years.

site_title: British retirees find their sun in Portugal
summary: British retirees are flocking to Portugal's Monte Da Palhagueira, a retirement community offering a mild climate, lower cost of living, and tax incentives. The community, modeled after British towns, features English gardens, Anglican church, and British residents, catering to those over 55 with a significant nest egg. The properties, available from £79,000 to £350,000, come with a "loan and accommodation agreement" that allows for tax-free living and easy resale. The community's popularity has increased since Portugal introduced fiscal incentives for European retirees, with over 4,000 apartments sold to French nationals last year.

site_title: Dollar edges higher despite dovish fed talk
summary: The US dollar edged higher against the euro on Monday, trimming losses from last week's dismal jobs report, after New York Federal Reserve President William Dudley expressed dovish views on US economic growth. Dudley stated that the timing of interest rate hikes remains uncertain due to a slowdown in the economy. The yen also fell ahead of a Bank of Japan monetary policy meeting. The dollar's gains were limited by its weakness relative to recent weeks, with the euro trading at $1.0928.

site_title: Bullish oil bets by hedge funds up the most in four years
summary: Hedge funds increased bullish oil bets by 21% in the week ended March 31, the largest percentage increase since March 2011, as a preliminary agreement between Iran and world powers brought the Persian Gulf nation closer to increasing oil exports. Oil prices rose 13% from a six-year low in March, and US production growth slowed, signaling stockpiles poised to decline. Analysts say the Iran deal has likely been priced in, with no expected flood of Iranian oil into the market.

site_title: Understanding the need for outplacement
summary: Small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in Singapore face challenges in finding and retaining talent, as well as dealing with the difficult task of letting go of employees. Outplacement consultants can provide support to departing employees, helping them find new jobs and ease the employer's conscience. The industry has matured in Asia, but many recruitment firms offer outplacement services, blurring the lines between the two. Companies pay for outplacement services to preserve their corporate image and reputation, and to attract top talent in a competitive job market.

site_title: Ins and outs of forex trading
summary: Forex trading is a dynamic and testing journey, with key differences from equity and commodity trading. It offers excellent liquidity and 24/5 markets, making it appealing to technical traders. The market's volatility and leverage can result in significant gains, but also substantial losses. As a result, traders must be well-informed and prepared to adapt to changing market conditions.

site_title: Over-extended borrowers get more time to cut back
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has identified 84,000 over-extended borrowers, totaling S$7.5 billion in unsecured debt, making up 5% of total unsecured borrowers. To help these borrowers, MAS will phase in stricter borrowing limits over four years, with a limit of 12 times monthly income by 2019. The MAS has also introduced a repayment assistance scheme (RAS) with a lower interest rate of 5% per annum over eight years to help over-extended borrowers.

site_title: Greece reassures on crucial IMF debt payment
summary: Greece has confirmed it will make a 460 million euro debt payment to the International Monetary Fund on April 9th, alleviating concerns over the country's solvency. Greek Finance Minister Yanis Varoufakis met with IMF chief Christine Lagarde, agreeing on the payment and expressing the need for effective cooperation. The meeting comes as Greece seeks to meet its financial obligations and unlock the last tranche of its bailout package, with Eurozone deputy finance ministers meeting on April 8-9 to discuss reforms.

site_title: In transition
summary: Commodity markets were given a breather at the start of 2015 after a turbulent year in 2014, but a swift comeback is considered unlikely due to excess supplies. Instead, 2015 is seen as a transitional year with new projects being shelved, and lower prices providing a lift to the economy and demand.

site_title: Frasers Centrepoint guns for big North Park launch
summary: Frasers Centrepoint is launching its North Park Residences project on April 11, with nearly all 920 units reserved for the official launch. The developer expects a strong response due to its unbeatable proximity to Yishun MRT station and established shopping centre. In its soft launch, the project sold 313 units, with sales evenly spread across apartment types and 88% of buyers being Singaporeans. The project's average pricing is S$1,300 per square foot, with prices starting from S$612,000 for a studio to S$1.89 million for a five-bedroom unit.

site_title: LHN IPO decent; pity there's no public portion
summary: Singapore's first IPO of 2015, LHN Group, a real estate manager, has raised S$17 million through a private placement of 73.9 million new shares at S$0.23 each. The company is profitable, with a compound annual growth rate of 34.7% in net earnings from FY2012 to FY2014. The IPO price is fairly priced at a historical price-earnings multiple of 6.3 times, and the majority of the funds raised will be used for business expansion.

site_title: Cameron's party loses British election candidate to UKIP
summary: UK Conservative Party candidate Mike Whitehead has switched to the UK Independence Party (UKIP) ahead of the May 7 election, citing dissatisfaction with local Conservative politicians. This move is seen as a morale boost for UKIP, which wants an immediate British withdrawal from the EU. The defection is unlikely to cause a political upset, as the area is held by the opposition Labour Party. UKIP's leader Nigel Farage hailed the switch as a "hammer blow" to the Conservatives, while Labour said it was a blow to Prime Minister David Cameron's authority.

site_title: Finding the right fit
summary: Wealth individual investors are encouraged to make long-term commitments to causes they care about. Meanwhile, key economic indicators show mixed signals, with the Federal Reserve's independence being tested but no expected pivot. Asia is expected to drive dollar asset diversification, while retail investors are predicted to drive massive ETF growth in the region. Productivity gains are seen as crucial for unlocking wealth creation, and economic shifts, including de-dollarisation, are underway.

site_title: Bunching of AGMs unfortunate but alternatives impractical
summary: The bunching of annual general meetings (AGMs) in the last 10 days of April is unfortunate due to the April 30 deadline for listed companies with a December 31 financial year-end. Requiring companies to queue up for two-hour slots would be impractical. With 430 companies ending their financial year on December 31, allowing only five to hold AGMs in any one weekday would lead to AGMs taking place from January to April, with some companies holding them less than a month after their year-ends.

site_title: Indonesia to impose palm export levy to fund subsidies, R&D
summary: Indonesia, the world's largest palm oil producer, will impose export levies starting April 6 to fund biodiesel subsidies and replanting. Shippers will pay US$50 a tonne for crude palm oil and US$30 for processed products. The levies will be used to compensate price differences between regular diesel and biodiesel, as well as support research and development in the palm oil industry. Analysts warn that this may hurt Indonesian producers in the short term, but prices may recover if the biodiesel program is successful.

site_title: Proposed Australian tax reform could shift demand to bonds
summary: The Australian government has released a discussion paper suggesting tax reforms that could reduce demand for domestic equities and shift it to bonds. The proposed reforms include raising the aggregate tax burden and questioning the dividend imputation system, which provides refunds to shareholders. This could lead to a decrease in investment in domestic equities and an increase in bond allocation, potentially deepening Australia's shallow domestic bond market. Experts warn that removing franking credits would be "disastrous" for the local equity market, causing share prices to plummet.

site_title: Insurance is about forming long-term relationship
summary: Singapore's Insurance and Financial Practitioners Association of Singapore cautions against an over-enthusiastic view of digital insurance offerings, citing infrastructure and consumer education concerns. The association agrees that digital channels add to consumer choice, but emphasizes the importance of a long-term relationship with an expert to comprehend insurance needs. Regulators have restricted digital offerings to basic term and life insurance products, and insurers have implemented measures to compensate for the absence of financial advisers. The association believes that consumers must be financially savvy before rushing to digital platforms.

site_title: Big-bank brokers make exit under cloak and dagger
summary: A growing number of big-bank brokers are leaving major brokerages like Morgan Stanley, Bank of America's Merrill Lynch, and UBS Group AG to start their own independent firms. The Botkin Group, a team of Pittsburgh-based brokers, made a $1.6 million exit from Morgan Stanley by requiring non-disclosure agreements from contractors and keeping their new office's location secret. According to Cerulli Associates, independent advisory firms are expected to surpass the big brokerages in market control within the next five years, as 30% of wirehouse advisers consider going independent due to increased fees and minimum balances.

images.alt_text: Sara Botkin (right) left Morgan Stanley with her father and brother to start their own independent financial planning and investment firm. The Botkins went so far as to require non-disclosure agreements from contractors working on their new building.

site_title: 10-year rise of global foreign currency reserves at an end
summary: Global foreign currency reserves, held by central banks, have declined to $11.6 trillion in March, ending a decade-long surge. This marks a halt to a fivefold increase that began in 2004, as the strengthening US dollar reduced the value of other reserve currencies. The decline could make it harder for emerging markets to boost their money supply, adding to euro declines and dampening demand for US Treasury bonds.

site_title: Crude oil at week high as Saudis raise rates for Asia
summary: Crude oil prices surged to a week high as Saudi Arabia raised prices for Asia, its largest regional market, by narrowing the discount on its main Arab Light grade. The move, coupled with speculation that an Iran nuclear deal won't lead to an immediate increase in supplies, boosted futures by 3.7% in New York and 3.6% in London. Despite US inventories at a 30-year high and OPEC's refusal to cut production, prices rose 2.6% to $50.41 a barrel, with Brent crude also climbing to $56.73 a barrel.

images.alt_text: Saudi Aramco raised official selling prices for Asia for a second straight month as refiners that buy its crude earned more for turning oil into petrol and diesel.

site_title: Wing Tai surges on privatisation talk
summary: Wing Tai Holdings' stock surged 9.6% to S$2.11 on speculation of potential privatisation, driven by a report by RHB Research. The company's robust balance sheet and diversified property business were cited as reasons for the potential privatisation. Wing Tai has been engaging in active share buybacks and its major shareholder, the Cheung family, may make another bid. The report also mentioned Wing Tai as a top candidate among other property plays, contributing to the stock's significant gain.

site_title: Japanese centenarian notches up world record swim
summary: A 100-year-old Japanese woman, Mieko Nagaoka, has set a world record by completing a 1,500-metre freestyle swim in under an hour and 16 minutes. This achievement is expected to be recognized by Guinness World Records. Nagaoka, who started swimming at 80, is the first centenarian to complete the swim. Her record-breaking swim follows the success of 103-year-old sprinter Hidekichi Miyazaki, who holds the world record for the 100-metre dash in the 100-104 age category.

site_title: Seeking professional help
summary: Wealth in Asia is growing, with more families considering establishing a family office to manage their wealth. The article does not directly discuss this topic, but it does mention a related trend. Productivity gains are key to unlocking wealth creation, and Asia is expected to drive and benefit from dollar asset diversification. The region is also seeing significant growth in ETFs, driven by retail investors, and has become a top port for 12 consecutive years. Additionally, Singapore's affluents require $1.39 million to retire comfortably, and the country has seen significant developments in 3D printing and technology.

site_title: America updates rules on electronic voting
summary: The US Election Assistance Commission has updated guidelines for electronic voting machines to ensure they are secure and accessible. The updated guidelines allow manufacturers to test machines against modern security and disability standards, with the goal of improving the voting experience and reducing costs. The changes come ahead of the 2016 presidential election and aim to address concerns about security and accessibility. Technology can also be used to enhance voter registration, engagement, and data analysis, but experts warn that online voting systems remain vulnerable to hacking and manipulation.

site_title: Shades of grey in quest for yield
summary: The search for yield is becoming increasingly challenging due to the blurring of lines between fundamentals, valuations, and technicals in a globally distorted landscape with historically low interest rates and high liquidity. This has made asset allocation more difficult, with investors seeking alternative sources of returns.

site_title: Local companies tardier with payments in Q1 than in Q4 2014
summary: Singapore companies experienced a decline in payment promptness in Q1 2015, with less than 39% of total bills paid within the agreed payment terms. This is the lowest level since Q2 2012. The proportion of slow payments rose by 12.5 percentage points, reaching 51.4% of total payment transactions. The manufacturing sector recorded the highest proportion of slow payments, with sub-sectors like electronics experiencing a significant increase. The decline in payment performance is attributed to waning growth in consumer-related services and tourism, as well as cash-strapped local firms struggling to fulfill debt obligations.

site_title: SGX's securities activity stagnant as derivatives fly
summary: Singapore Exchange's (SGX) securities activity remained stagnant in March, with a 0.2% year-on-year decline in average daily traded value to S$1.14 billion. Securities daily average value (SDAV) has been flat for the past 2.5 years. In contrast, SGX's derivatives market saw a 46.2% year-on-year growth in average daily trading volume to 678,126 contracts. Analysts attribute the derivatives business growth to investments and product offerings, citing the launch of the Shanghai-Hong Kong Stock Connect trading link.

site_title: Ellipsiz up as major stake changes hands
summary: Singapore's semiconductor testing firm Ellipsiz Ltd saw its stock spike after CEO Melvin Chan Wai Leong sold a significant portion of his stake to construction company boss David Lum Kok Seng. Lum became the largest shareholder with a 20.44% stake after buying 100 million shares at S$0.15 each. The trades followed a UOB Kay Hian report that set a target price of S$0.171, labeling Ellipsiz an attractive M&A target due to its strong net cash and market share.

site_title: Stratech completes revamp, eyes overseas growth
summary: The Stratech Group, a Singapore-based company, has completed a restructuring and is now eyeing overseas markets to drive growth. The company, which provides solutions for homeland security, aerospace, and surveillance industries, has greater flexibility for acquisitions and strategic partnerships. It is targeting markets such as the US, China, and Europe, where its iFerret airfield/runway surveillance system has been certified by the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA). The company aims to secure contracts and maintenance agreements to provide a steady stream of recurring revenue.

site_title: Palm oil climbs to three-week high as crude oil prices jump
summary: Malaysian palm oil futures rose to a three-week high on Monday, driven by rising crude oil and firm US soyoil prices. Crude oil prices jumped over $1 a barrel after Saudi Arabia raised its prices for crude sales to Asia. The benchmark June contract on the Bursa Malaysia Derivatives rose 1.9% to RM2,233 a tonne. Higher crude prices could attract interest for palm-based biodiesel, but some traders noted the rise was "abnormal" and lacked fundamental domestic support.

site_title: Peter Seah to retire from CapLand
summary: CapitaLand Ltd announced that independent director and deputy chairman Peter Seah will retire from his position, effective April 30, at the upcoming annual general meeting. Seah, 68, has made significant contributions to the company over 13 years, and his retirement is seen as a strategic move to leverage opportunities for growth. The company's annual report also highlights its strong development pipeline, a strong financial performance, and plans to develop 12 integrated developments over the next three years.

site_title: Noisy O'Hare airport could decide Chicago's mayoral race
summary: Residents in Chicago's Northwest Side neighborhood are complaining of excessive noise from O'Hare International Airport due to a new runway and changed flight patterns. The issue has become a subplot in the city's mayoral election, with challenger Jesus Garcia focusing on noise pollution as a key campaign issue. Mayor Rahm Emanuel has responded to complaints, but some residents feel his efforts are insufficient. The noise problem affects a section of the city he won in 2011, potentially driving away support for his re-election bid.

site_title: Japan's Sharp seen spinning off LCD unit
summary: Japan's electronics maker Sharp Corp may spin off its LCD panel business and seek funding from the government-backed Innovation Network Corporation of Japan (INCJ). The move is part of Sharp's restructuring plan, which aims to keep a majority stake in the LCD unit. Sharp has been struggling with losses and is seeking a bailout, with its main lenders, Mizuho Bank and Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi UFJ, pushing for radical reforms. An INCJ investment of up to 100 billion yen (S$1.1 billion) could fuel speculation of a future deal with Japan Display, Sharp's 35% owned rival.

site_title: Record petrol output eats up biggest US oil glut in 85 years
summary: US refiners are poised to increase petrol production at a record pace this year, offsetting the biggest US crude glut in over 80 years. With refineries enjoying their best margins in two years, they will boost production to meet summer demand. Crude inventories have surged to 471 million barrels, the highest level since 1930, despite analysts warning that storage space may run out. Refiners have added 100,000 barrels a day of capacity since last summer, and production is expected to continue, making the glut less severe.

site_title: Detention of feminists in China sparks global outcry
summary: In China, two young feminist activists, Li Tingting and Wei Tingting, sparked a global outcry after being detained for their protests against inequality and domestic violence. The pair, known for their creative and fearless tactics, had been using guerrilla theatre to raise awareness about women's issues in the country. Their latest actions, including shaving their heads and protesting at public toilets, were met with international condemnation and attention. The detention highlights the challenges faced by Chinese feminists who dare to challenge the country's authoritarian norms and patriarchal society.

site_title: Indonesia property stocks gaining favour globally on building boom
summary: Indonesia's property stocks are gaining global favor due to a government-sponsored building boom, falling interest rates, and a growing population. The Jakarta stock exchange's property index has advanced 25% over the past 12 months, with top developers like PT Lippo Cikarang and PT Alam Sutera Realty having high analyst ratings. The government's infrastructure spending plans and central bank's interest-rate cut are also driving growth, with Singapore's sovereign wealth fund and Indonesia's state pension agency increasing investments in the market. Experts predict a 14% increase in the Jakarta property index over the next 12 months.

site_title: Cruising through 'Asia moderation'
summary: Asian equities have endured a challenging period due to economic restructuring and earnings downgrades. Ng Soo Nam, Head of Asian Equities at Threadneedle Investments, shares perspectives on the market and the Threadneedle Asia Contrarian Equity Fund. Despite these challenges, Asia is expected to drive and benefit from dollar asset diversification.

site_title: Property's star shining bright
summary: Wealth continues to grow globally, with the rich amassing fortunes in 2014 despite economic uncertainty. Knight Frank's The Wealth Report 2015 tracks the super-rich population in 108 cities across 97 countries. The report highlights the growing wealth population, but no specific figures are mentioned.

site_title: A solid foundation on which to build a nuclear accord with Iran
summary: A preparatory agreement between Iran and the US and other major powers has been reached, outlining key parameters for a final nuclear accord. The deal is considered the least-worst option to prevent Iran from becoming a nuclear threat. Negotiators aim to finalize the agreement by June 30, which could lead to lifting economic sanctions. However, critics argue that the framework falls short of goals, as Iran will continue to enrich uranium and not end its nuclear program, raising concerns about its intentions.

site_title: Japanese banks gain as state fund cuts deposit levy
summary: Japan's Deposit Insurance Corp (DICJ) has cut the deposit levy to 4.2 basis points, the lowest rate since 1996, reflecting the recovery of the local financial system. The move is expected to boost banks' profits, but savings may not spur lending. Despite this, banks' operating profits are at their highest since 2006, and non-performing loans have fallen to a record low. However, companies are cutting capital investment, and Japan's economy remains sluggish, with large companies planning to cut capital expenditures by 1.2% this fiscal year.

site_title: The guiding star
summary: The concept of family purpose is gaining importance in defining a family's identity and charting its future. Key events in the financial world include the Federal Reserve's independence being tested, but not expected to pivot, and Asia driving and gaining from dollar asset diversification. The S&P 500 has reached a record high, with productivity gains seen as crucial to wealth creation. De-dollarisation and shifting safe havens are also emerging trends.

site_title: Rouble's slump squeezes tourism in South-east Asia
summary: The rouble's sharp decline against the US dollar is affecting South-east Asian tourism, particularly in Vietnam, Thailand, and Cambodia. Russian tourists are reducing their travel plans due to the increased cost of trips, with a 43% drop in arrivals in Vietnam and a 51% decline in Cambodia. Destinations popular with Russians, such as Phuket and Pattaya, are being hit hard. This decline is expected to continue, with Thailand seeing a 46% drop in Russian arrivals in January. The decline is attributed to the depreciation of the rouble and Western sanctions.

site_title: Ageing S Koreans less inclined to spend savings
summary: South Korea's ageing population is affecting the country's economy, with 7.6 million Koreans aged 60 or over, who are less inclined to spend their savings. Despite the Bank of Korea's interest-rate cuts, consumption remains weak, and the household savings rate has risen to its highest level in 10 years. Demographic changes, including rapid ageing, are making it difficult for monetary policy to stimulate spending and price gains. Economists are studying the impact of ageing on spending patterns and the economy, with projections suggesting the ratio of people aged 65 or over will rise to 32% by 2040.

site_title: Triyards clinches new orders worth US$100m
summary: Triyards Holdings, a Singapore-based offshore engineering and fabrication firm, secured new orders worth approximately US$100 million, boosting its orderbook by about US$275 million since 2015. The firm's contract wins include a liftboat, a power plant project, and a high-speed aluminium craft project. However, its second-quarter earnings dropped 34% to US$5.1 million, largely due to the completion of significant projects from the previous year.
