This follows the award of provisional banking licenses to nine foreign banks, including UOB, in October 2014. OCBC's Yangon branch will be the bank's first entry into the country.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close up 1.46%
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 1.46% on Thursday, rebounding from two days of losses, despite a negative lead from Wall Street. The Nikkei 225 index gained 277.95 points to 19,312.79, driven by overseas investment and a shift in Japan's public pension fund towards stocks. The Dow, S&P 500, and Nasdaq fell on Wall Street due to a slump in US construction spending and slow manufacturing growth. Key stocks like Toyota, Canon, and Sony rose, while Nippon Steel & Sumitomo Metal fell on production cut reports.

site_title: Alpha Investment Partners puts its 50% stake in Capital Square up for sale
summary: Keppel Land's Alpha Investment Partners has appointed CBRE and JLL to jointly market its 50% stake in Singapore's Capital Square, a 16-storey office building with supporting retail amenity and heritage shophouses. The property has a total net lettable area of 388,215 sq ft and is expected to be sold for around S$1.09 billion. The half-stake is valued at approximately S$543.5 million, with pricing expected to be around S$2,800 per square foot. An expression of interest campaign is set to begin in April.

site_title: UK construction growth slows in March, confidence surges: PMI
summary: UK construction growth slowed in March, falling to 57.8 from 60.1 in February, due to concerns about national elections. Confidence in the industry surged to a nine-year high, but growth lost pace, particularly in civil engineering. Companies delayed spending decisions, and employment numbers rose at their slowest pace since December 2013. Shortages of sub-contractors and material supplies pushed up costs. Despite the slowdown, construction firms expressed increased confidence for the coming 12 months, with a nine-year high in optimism.

site_title: Chinese New Year boosts February air passenger demand: IATA
summary: Demand for air travel rose 6.2% in February, driven by the Chinese New Year holiday. International travel in Asia-Pacific increased 10.4% compared to 2014. Load factors rose 0.5 percentage points to 78.5% and capacity increased 5.6%. This boost in air passenger demand contrasts with a 4.5% rise in revenue passenger kilometres in January.

site_title: Australia: Shares rise as investors bet on rate cut
summary: Australian shares rose 0.7% to 5,898.6 on Thursday as investors bet on a potential interest rate cut by the Reserve Bank of Australia, expected to be announced on Tuesday. The S&P/ASX 200 index rose 37.8 points, while New Zealand's benchmark NZX 50 index fell 0.1%. The rate cut is seen as encouraging more borrowing, with bank stocks gaining.

site_title: HSBC's South-east Asia banking head exits after decade with firm
summary: HSBC's South-east Asia banking head Tou Chen Chang is leaving the bank after 10 years to pursue other opportunities. Wan Thonh Chow took over as head of banking for Singapore and South-east Asia on April 1. The move comes as banks in the region face a decline in dealmaking, with the value of announced acquisitions falling 42% to $24.6 billion in 2015. Alvin Lim has been appointed as head of banking advisory for South-east Asia.

site_title: Corruption in Singapore 'under control': CPIB
summary: Corruption in Singapore has reached a 30-year low, according to the Corrupt Practices Investigation Bureau (CPIB). In 2014, 736 complaints were received, with 136 leading to investigation, a 11% decrease from 2013. Of these, 15% involved public sector officials, while the majority were cases of private sector individuals offering or receiving bribes. The CPIB reports that the corruption situation is "stable and under control."

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares end 0.77% higher
summary: Hong Kong's benchmark Hang Seng Index rose 0.77% to 25,275.64 on Thursday, following a regional advance, as investors await US jobs data. The Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.41% in mainland China, while the Shenzhen Composite Index gained 1.86%. The increases were part of a broader regional trend, with stocks in other Asian markets also advancing.

site_title: ExxonMobil starts building of cogeneration plant in Jurong
summary: ExxonMobil has begun constructing a 84-megawatt cogeneration facility at its Jurong refinery in Singapore, set to increase energy efficiency upon completion in 2017. The new unit will boost the refinery's total cogeneration capacity to over 440 megawatts, meeting its internal power needs. The facility will utilize cogeneration, producing both electricity and steam from a single fuel source, and will complement the existing 360-megawatt cogeneration capacity.

site_title: Tumbling ringgit raises stakes for budget gamblers in Singapore
summary: Singapore's casinos face challenges due to the Malaysian ringgit's 17-year low against the Singapore dollar, limiting mass-market gaming revenues. The decline affects top mass-market foreign gamblers from Malaysia and Indonesia, resulting in reduced tourist arrivals and revenue potential. Analysts predict a 5% growth in mass-market volumes this year, down from 6% in 2014. Genting's new hotel in Singapore aims to boost appeal to mass-market players, but currency fluctuations pose a significant challenge to the industry.

site_title: Europe: Shares dip early; Marks & Spencer rallies
summary: European shares fell 0.1% on Thursday, trading in a tight range ahead of the Easter break, as investors focused on Greece's efforts to unlock financial aid. The country sent a new list of reforms to creditors, but officials said more work was needed. Meanwhile, UK retailer Marks & Spencer rose 4% after posting its best non-food sales performance in nearly four years. Markets will be closed from Friday to Monday.

site_title: TLAC pressures build for Asia banks
summary: Asian banks are bracing for the impact of new capital adequacy rules, known as TLAC, despite potential exemptions. Regulators in the region are considering adopting TLAC standards, which would require banks to maintain a sufficient capital buffer to survive a stressed scenario. However, some Asian regulators may implement less-stringent interpretations, such as raising capital ratios instead of introducing senior bail-in bonds. The global rules, which initially apply to global systemically important banks, will set a new benchmark for the financial health of all banks and raise concerns about funding costs and systemic risk.

site_title: India's central bank chief says banks too exposed to infrastructure
summary: India's central bank Governor Raghuram Rajan warned that the country's push to build infrastructure should not compromise financial stability. With the government aiming to invest $1 trillion in infrastructure by 2017, Rajan stated that banks already have too much exposure to the sector and need new funding sources to keep debt levels moderate. This comes as the gross bad loans ratio at banks could rise as high as 5.7% by March 2016, posing a challenge to India's banking system.

site_title: China to open water markets to foreign investors: regulator
summary: China will allow foreign companies to invest in large water projects, aiming to finance a massive infrastructure program to tackle chronic water shortages. The National Development and Reform Commission (NDRC) will permit qualified investors, including foreign and international joint ventures, to bid on and construct water projects. However, Chinese private investors will be favored in joint projects, and local authorities will use a government-backed business model to transfer stakes in state assets to private firms. China also plans to make local water prices more market-oriented to improve profitability in the sector.

site_title: US gives cautious welcome to Thailand lifting martial law
summary: The US has cautiously welcomed Thailand's lifting of martial law, but expressed concerns about the new security measures replacing it. The new executive order retains sweeping military powers and restricts civil liberties, including a ban on political gatherings. The State Department urged the full restoration of civil liberties, including the right to free expression and assembly, and called for an end to detention without charge. The US welcomes the lifting of martial law but is concerned that the new security measure does not address these issues.

site_title: Oil prices down in thin Asian trade
summary: Oil prices fell in Asia, with US benchmark West Texas Intermediate dropping 40 cents to $49.69 and Brent slipping 32 cents to $56.78, ahead of the Easter holiday weekend. The US Department of Energy reported a slight decline in US crude production, which may help alleviate the global supply glut. Talks between Iran and world powers remain ongoing, with a full agreement due by June 30, but no significant progress has been made. Oil prices are expected to remain volatile due to the ongoing negotiations and US tariffs.

site_title: Thai consumer confidence hits 9-month low in March
summary: Thai consumer confidence plummeted to a 9-month low in March, reaching 77.7, due to low commodity prices and economic worries. This marks the third consecutive month of decline, with the lowest reading since June 2014. The economy's 0.7% growth last year was the lowest since 2011, and experts predict a 3% growth this year, lower than the government's 4% target. Low commodity prices and high household debt have curbed private consumption, which accounts for half of GDP.

site_title: Singapore Power launches S$30m centre to drive energy development
summary: Singapore Power launches the Singapore Power Centre of Excellence (CoE) for Energy Development and Piloting with an initial investment of S$30 million. The centre, supported by the Singapore Economic Development Board, aims to develop, pilot, and integrate cutting-edge technologies into Singapore's infrastructure networks. The 20-man team will focus on developing expertise in new technologies, testing, and integration, with the goal of building future-ready networks and capabilities. This move supports Singapore Power's objective to achieve smarter and greener performance and adopt renewable sources.

site_title: Foo Chee Hock named judicial commissioner of Singapore High Court
summary: Foo Chee Hock has been appointed as a judicial commissioner of the Singapore High Court, effective April 1, 2015, for a three-year term. He will also oversee the development of the Singapore Judicial College. The appointment brings the total number of judges on the Supreme Court bench to 13, including the Chief Justice, nine judicial commissioners, and five senior judges. Foo Chee Hock was sworn in at a ceremony at the Istana.

site_title: Packed with health benefits, coffee gains ground with experts
summary: US dietary guidelines now recognize coffee as not generally harmful, even with multiple cups a day. Studies have found no negative health effects, and moderate coffee consumption may decrease the risk of heart disease, Parkinson's, Alzheimer's, diabetes, and certain cancers. Experts attribute the benefits to antioxidants like polyphenols, which are also found in red wine and cocoa, and caution against adding extra calories with cream and sugar. Pregnant women should limit themselves to 200 milligrams of caffeine per day.

site_title: China knocking on door of IMF's major league, US wavers
summary: China is closer to joining the International Monetary Fund's Special Drawing Rights (SDR) basket, which includes major reserve currencies, as the IMF considers including the yuan in the virtual currency. The US, however, is hesitant to add the yuan, citing concerns over its lack of full convertibility. European countries, including Germany and Britain, support China's bid, while Japan is more cautious. The IMF will discuss China's request in May, with a full review expected later in the year, potentially paving the way for the yuan's inclusion in the SDR basket.

site_title: France sticks to 1% growth forecast for 2015
summary: France will maintain its 1% growth forecast for 2015, considering the target as a "floor" rather than a goal, according to Finance Minister Michel Sapin. This decision comes despite improved consumer and business morale, which suggests the economy is starting to recover. France's economy grew only 0.4% in 2014, making the 1% target a cautious estimate.

site_title: Cityneon to buy exhibition producer Victory Hill, plans 1-for-1 rights issue
summary: Cityneon Holdings plans to acquire exhibition producer Victory Hill Exhibitions Pte Ltd for S$10 million in cash and issuing 45 million new shares. The acquisition aims to leverage Victory Hill's expertise in travelling exhibitions to enhance Cityneon's capabilities. A one-for-one non-underwritten renounceable rights issue of 88.53 million new shares is proposed to partially fund the purchase, raising up to S$15.1 million in net proceeds. The deal is expected to strengthen Cityneon's core businesses.

site_title: Portugal applies to join China-backed AIIB investment bank
summary: Portugal has applied to join the China-backed Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB), one of over 40 countries seeking membership. The US and Japan have declined to join, viewing the AIIB as a challenge to the World Bank and Asian Development Bank. Portugal, along with Iceland, Hungary, and Israel, is among the latest European, Middle Eastern, Asian, and African countries to apply. The AIIB's establishment is seen as a significant shift in global economic influence.

site_title: South Korea current account surplus narrows in February
summary: South Korea's current account surplus narrowed to $6.44 billion in February, its third consecutive month in the black, due to low oil prices and weak domestic demand. This marks the third year the country has had a surplus. The service account deficit narrowed to $2.06 billion from $2.38 billion in January. The surplus is bolstered by low oil prices, which contributed to a decrease in imports.

site_title: Australia: Shares rise on expectations for a rate cut on Tuesday
summary: Australian shares rose 0.8% on Thursday, reversing the previous day's fall, amid expectations of a rate cut by the Reserve Bank of Australia on Tuesday. The S&P/ASX 200 index climbed 45 points to 5,905.5, with bank stocks leading the gains. Energy stocks also rose, while iron ore miners declined. The rate cut is seen as a 70% chance, with investors repositioning themselves in the banks.

site_title: Double-digit wage increases slowing, says study
summary: A study by the 2015 Robert Half Salary Guide for Singapore found that double-digit wage increases are slowing, with expected increases below 10% in finance and accounting, banking, and technology sectors. Despite this, the number of companies making new hires is increasing, with 50% of companies planning to raise headcount in the first half of the year, the highest level in three years. The most significant increase in hiring activity is for technology professionals, with 50% of companies looking to employ more IT staff, up from 26% two years ago.

site_title: Asia: Markets higher ahead of US jobs data
summary: Asian markets rose on Thursday, driven by expectations of a weak US job report, which dampened hopes of a Federal Reserve interest rate hike. Tokyo, Hong Kong, and Seoul saw gains of 1.17%, 0.50%, and 0.42% respectively, while Shanghai advanced 0.33%. Analysts warn of rocky weeks ahead due to ongoing global economic uncertainty, including Greece's bailout reform and oil price volatility. The US job report on Friday will be closely watched for signs of a strong economy.

site_title: Tax hike still keeping Japan households from spending: BOJ survey
summary: Japan households remain hesitant to boost spending after last year's sales tax hike, with nearly 60% cutting expenses, according to a Bank of Japan survey. Despite improved economic conditions and rising income, households continue to withhold consumption, posing a challenge for the BOJ to accelerate inflation without cooling spending. The survey also delayed a second tax hike initially scheduled in October 2015, forcing Prime Minister Shinzo Abe to push it back by 18 months.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open up 0.52%
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened 0.52% higher on April 2, 2015, driven by anticipation of key US jobs data release at the end of the week. The Hang Seng Index rose 131.58 points to 25,214.33. Mainland China's Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also increased, adding 0.46% and 0.64% respectively.

site_title: Japan's mobile app Line reviving IPO plans: report
summary: Line, a popular Japanese messaging app, is reviving its initial public offering (IPO) plans, according to a report. The company, which claims over 400 million registered members, may launch a Tokyo listing this year and a separate New York listing, potentially valuing it at over $8 billion. Line was initially set to go public in 2014 but shelved plans due to disagreements with its parent. The company's sales reached 86.3 billion yen in its latest fiscal year, and it is known for its messaging service and "stickers" feature.

site_title: Otto Marine appoints new group CEO
summary: Otto Marine Limited appointed Michael See Kian Heng as its new group CEO, replacing Garrick James Stanley. Stanley will become president of the shipping and chartering segment, responsible for its performance and profitability. See will be supported by senior management team members. The appointments are effective immediately.

site_title: Singapore ethylene cracker complex successfully upgraded: Shell
summary: Shell successfully upgraded its Singapore ethylene cracker complex, boosting production by over 20% and reducing energy consumption by 7% and carbon dioxide emissions by 11%. The upgrade supports expansion of intermediates plants on nearby Jurong Island, solidifying Shell's refining-chemicals integration strategy in Singapore and its position as a leading player in the Asian petrochemicals market.

site_title: Singapore has not imposed any restrictions on Thai carriers: CAAS
summary: CAAS has stepped up surveillance and ramp inspections of Thai carriers' aircraft operations in Singapore due to safety concerns raised by an ICAO audit. Despite the concerns, CAAS has not imposed any restrictions on Thai carriers. Thai Airways and budget carriers like Thai AirAsia X and NokScoot were forced to cancel flights due to Japan and South Korea's blockade. CAAS evaluates foreign carriers' operations using a risk-based methodology, conducting periodic inspections and monitoring developments to ensure safety.

site_title: NTU scientists, Swedish institute discover new treatments for colon cancer
summary: NTU scientists and Sweden's Karolinska Institutet discovered a new treatment option for colon cancer through a five-year study. The existing chemotherapy drug, used to treat leukemia, reduced colon tumor growth by half. This breakthrough, published in Science Translational Medicine, offers hope for patients with this common and aggressive form of cancer, which affects 95% of colorectal cancer cases. Researchers are now exploring the possibility of preventing tumor recurrence after surgery.

images.alt_text: NTU scientist Dr Parag Kundu, the first author of the study, holding microscope images of the colon tumours in mice

site_title: Noble repurchases US$20m medium term notes issued in March 2013
summary: Noble Group, Asia's largest commodity trader, repurchased US$20 million of its 3.625% US dollar fixed rate medium term notes due in 2018. The notes were issued in March 2013 and represent about 5% of the total principal amount outstanding. The repurchased notes were cancelled on Wednesday, following the terms and conditions of the notes.

site_title: Oman Air says orders 20 Boeing 737s; to double fleet by 2020
summary: Oman Air has ordered 20 Boeing 737s as part of its plan to double its fleet to 70 planes by 2020, Chief Executive Paul Gregorowitsch announced. The order includes both current and re-engined 737s to be delivered from 2017 and 2019, respectively. The airline currently has 36 aircraft and plans to use the new planes to grow its domestic and regional networks. Oman Air aims to have 25 widebody planes and 45 narrowbodies by the end of the decade.

site_title: Broker's take: RHB issues 'buy' call on Croesus Retail Trust
summary: RHB Research Institute Singapore has issued a "buy" call on Croesus Retail Trust (CRT) with a target price of S$1.15. The trust's tenant renewal and asset enhancement exercise at Mallage Shobu is nearing completion, with 69 and 28 new shop transfers and 58 tenants with improved store facades by end-Q3 2015. CRT has a steady gearing ratio and fully hedged distribution per unit, with management expecting a 12-15% rental uplift. RHB is positive on CRT due to the Japanese yen hedging until end-FY2016.

site_title: Singapore's workplace fatality rate at its lowest but non-fatal injuries up
summary: Singapore's workplace fatality rate reached its lowest level of 1.8 per 100,000 employed persons in 2014, down from 73 workplace fatalities in 2013. However, non-fatal injuries increased by 9% to 13,535, with minor injuries rising 10% and major injuries climbing 5%. Experts warn companies to review work practices and implement measures to address existing workplace safety issues.

site_title: Singapore's STI opens up 0.04%
summary: The Singapore stock market opened 0.04% higher on Thursday morning, with the Straits Times Index rising 1.55 points to 3,448.57. The modest gain was despite a lacklustre US index close, following disappointing US jobs and manufacturing data. Gainers outpaced losers 82 to 69, with active stocks including CNA Group, Polaris, and Noble Group.

site_title: Singapore's customer satisfaction levels hit record high in 2014: study
summary: Singapore's customer satisfaction levels reached a record high in 2014, with the national satisfaction index rising to 71.1 points, a 0.6% increase from 2013. The finance and insurance sector, particularly life insurance, led the improvement, while the healthcare sector also showed significant growth. Despite this, tourist satisfaction fell in all four quarters of 2014, marking the lowest score at the national level since 2009. The Institute of Service Excellence attributes the improvement to strong ratings from these sectors, suggesting a positive indicator for Singapore's service competitiveness.

site_title: Australia job vacancies hit 30-month high in February quarter
summary: Australia's job vacancies reached a 30-month high in the February quarter, increasing 0.8% to 151,700 seasonally adjusted. This marks a 6.3% rise compared to the same period last year. The data from the Australian Bureau of Statistics suggests a moderately promising sign of improving labor demand.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open 0.56% higher
summary: Tokyo stocks opened 0.56% higher on Thursday, following two days of losses, despite concerns about the US economy. US data showed a dip in construction spending and a slowdown in the manufacturing sector, while a report on business hiring cast a shadow over markets. The dollar remained pressured against the yen, while the euro fetched a relatively high value. The Nikkei 225 index rose 107.09 points to 19,141.93, shrugging off US economic concerns.

site_title: Surbana to provide advice on Maldives airport expansion project
summary: The Maldives Airports Company Limited (MACL) has appointed Surbana International Consultants to provide project management consultancy services for the expansion of Ibrahim Nasir International Airport (INIA) in Maldives. The expansion includes a new international passenger terminal, cargo terminal, and fuel hydrant system. Surbana will also provide design and engineering review services for the project.

site_title: Target to close Canadian stores by April 12
summary: Target Corp's Canadian unit will close its last 133 retail stores on April 12, following a failed expansion effort since 2013. The closures result in 17,000 job losses and a $5.1 billion quarterly charge. Supply chain issues, poor communication, and new technology problems led to stores being poorly stocked and selection limited, disappointing shoppers. The company had previously closed its distribution centers and headquarters.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's stock market opened higher on Thursday with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 0.75 points to 1,827.06. Trading volume was 60.54 million lots worth RM30.91 million, with 119 gainers outnumbering 48 losers.

site_title: Broker's take: Maybank keeps 'buy' call on Cordlife, Ezion
summary: Maybank Kim Eng maintains "buy" calls on Cordlife Group and Ezion Holdings. Cordlife, a provider of umbilical cord blood banking, is expected to benefit from growth in underpenetrated markets, particularly India. The research house targets S$1.35 for Cordlife and S$1.83 for Ezion, citing strong demand for liftboats and stable earnings visibility. Maybank attributes Ezion's growth to secured contracts and stable rates, making it the top pick for offshore and marine stocks. The "buy" calls are driven by steady transformation into a multi-product healthcare distributor and maiden dividends from China Cord Blood Corp.

site_title: US Senator Menendez indicted for corruption
summary: US Senator Robert Menendez has been indicted on public corruption charges following a two-year federal investigation into his ties to a friend who contributed large sums to his re-election campaign. Menendez, the top Democrat on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, will temporarily step down from his role but plans to resume it once the proceedings are concluded. The indictment marks a significant development in the ongoing corruption probe, which has already led to the temporary suspension of Menendez's committee leadership role.

site_title: McDonald's to boost wages for 90,000 US employees
summary: McDonald's plans to increase wages for 90,000 US employees in company-owned restaurants, starting from July 1, with a minimum wage increase of $1 above local official minimum wage. The pay increase applies to full and part-time workers, but not to franchisee-owned restaurants. The company aims to raise average wages to above $10 an hour by the end of 2016, as part of a comprehensive benefits package.

site_title: Stocks to watch: CNA, Noble, KepCorp, Matex
summary: Noble Group repurchased $20 million of its US dollar fixed rate notes, while CNA Group signed a $70 million contract for a terminal complex in Vietnam. Keppel Corp's surprise takeover bid for Keppel Land failed, resulting in a 6-cent drop in its counter price. Matex International announced a $475 million reverse takeover to become an operator of four thermal coal mines in China through a conditional sale and purchase agreement.

site_title: As rice mountain shrinks, Thailand risks amassing one for rubber
summary: Thailand's military junta is shifting its strategy to buy more rubber amid a glut, but this move may exacerbate global market issues. Despite reviving domestic prices, the purchases are failing to reduce the global production surplus, which has entered its fifth year. The rubber glut is partly due to increased production and competition from synthetic materials. Demand in China, the world's top buyer, is slowing, and prices have dropped over 70% from their 2011 peak, with the market facing significant challenges.

images.alt_text: The rubber purchases revived domestic prices that touched a five- year low in October, they're failing to cut a global production surplus that is entering its fifth year, according to data from the International Rubber Study Group.

site_title: US auto sales edge higher in March
summary: US new-vehicle sales rose 0.6% in March to 1,545,802 vehicles, driven by luxury cars and big trucks. Toyota's sales led the gain, increasing 4.9% to 225,959 vehicles. Demand for trucks and SUVs is driving the market, with sales of Ford's F-Series pickup dropping 5% despite discounts. Analysts expect the second quarter to be favorable due to pent-up demand after a harsh winter, with the annualized sales rate rebounding to 17.15 million vehicles.

site_title: GoDaddy races higher in Wall Street debut
summary: GoDaddy's shares surged 31% in its Wall Street debut, closing at $26.15, after the company raised $460 million through an initial public offering at $20 a share. With a market value of $4 billion, GoDaddy's stock price sparked concerns of a bubble, as many tech firms have opted for private equity funding. The company, known for its provocative ads and sponsorship of Danica Patrick, aims to fuel international expansion with the IPO.

site_title: Australia inflation gauge stays benign in March: TDMI
summary: Australia's private-sector inflation gauge rose 0.4% in March, from a five-year low in February, as petrol prices rebounded. Core inflation moderated further, suggesting room for a potential interest rate cut by the Reserve Bank of Australia as early as next week. The annual pace ticked up to 1.5%, still below the RBA's target band of 2-3%. Markets imply a 60% probability of a rate cut next week, with the central bank's policy meeting scheduled for April 7.

site_title: EU membership not major issue to most Britons: poll
summary: A YouGov poll in February revealed that support for EU membership among Britons is at an all-time high. The poll comes ahead of a potential EU referendum, set to be held by 2017 if the Conservative Party wins the May 7 general election. This development could potentially force the country out of the European Union, reversing a long-standing eurosceptic trend in British politics.

site_title: Amazon launches gadget for instant ordering
summary: Amazon unveiled the Amazon Dash Button, a WiFi-connected gadget that allows users to instantly order household staples with the press of a button. The buttons, available for a limited number of items, can be hung in convenient locations around the home. Amazon Prime customers can configure the button to order specific items, with Dash buttons being free and available now on an invitation-only basis. The technology is powered by Amazon's Dash Replenishment Service, which aims to deepen customers' connection to the Amazon ecosystem and boost sales.

site_title: China to toughen inspection on air quality data
summary: China's vice minister for environmental protection announced a two-year inspection campaign to root out fake air quality data, criticizing some local governments for manipulating data to meet national standards. This move comes as China aims to improve transparency and compel polluters to provide real-time emissions data. The inspection will involve monitoring stations affiliated to the ministry to cross-check data from other stations. The government has also introduced measures to limit motorists on heavily polluted days and imposed criminal penalties for evading pollution monitoring systems, in an effort to tackle the country's severe air pollution issues.

site_title: Thai junta lifts martial law but retains key powers
summary: Thailand's junta lifted martial law, replacing it with new orders retaining military powers under Section 44 of the interim constitution. Special security measures, including a ban on gatherings of more than five people, will continue. The new measures aim to maintain national security and peace. The decision comes after the ailing King Bhumibol Adulyadej gave permission to lift martial law. Critics warn that Section 44 allows the junta to wield even greater powers, potentially leading to a "deepening descent into dictatorship."

site_title: China cracks down on manipulation at feverish over-the-counter stock market
summary: China's National Equities Exchange and Quotations (NEEQ) is cracking down on illegal trading on its over-the-counter (OTC) equity exchange, known as the New Third Board, amid concerns of market manipulation. The exchange, which has seen a surge in listings and trading activity, has investigated trading accounts for "seriously disrupting market order." The crackdown aims to protect investors and maintain the credibility of the market, which has seen its index rise over 70% in the first quarter. Regulators are also working to formalize a route for companies on the board to upgrade to main stock exchanges, further fueling growth in the market.

site_title: Japan PM Abe to craft war history comments with eye on US
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe is preparing to address Japan's wartime past on the 70th anniversary of the end of World War Two, with a focus on strengthening the alliance with the US and promoting a more assertive foreign policy. Abe has expressed reservations about earlier apologies, including those made by his predecessors, and is likely to issue forward-looking comments that avoid criticizing Japan's wartime past. US officials welcome Abe's push for a stronger alliance, but caution against stirring regional tensions, with some experts predicting that Abe's comments will be well-received in Washington but face criticism from China and South Korea.

site_title: Dollar eases after weak US economic data
summary: The US dollar weakened on Wednesday after disappointing economic data, including a slump in private-sector job growth and construction spending. The data raised concerns about the strength of the US recovery, potentially delaying interest rate hikes. Analysts expect the government's jobs report to show a slowdown in jobs growth, which could dampen rate hike expectations and weigh on the dollar. The Federal Reserve closely monitors the jobs market as it considers raising interest rates this year.

site_title: Europe: Equities enjoy bright start to second quarter
summary: European stock markets began the second quarter on a positive note, with London's FTSE 100 index up 0.54%, Frankfurt's DAX 30 index up 0.29%, and Paris' CAC 40 index up 0.57%. The eurozone's manufacturing data was upbeat, contributing to the market's gains. The European single currency also rose to $1.0771.

site_title: Japan Inc gloom signals bond rebound from first loss since 2013
summary: Japan's biggest companies predict a decline in business sentiment, signaling the economy's weakness, which may lead to a rebound in the nation's bonds. The Bank of Japan's Tankan large manufacturer index fell below estimates in March and is forecast to drop in June. Japanese bonds dropped 0.5% in the first quarter, their worst performance since 2013, as the central bank considers expanding monetary easing. Analysts expect the BOJ to act soon to revive inflation expectations and narrow the supply-demand gap, potentially boosting bond prices.

images.alt_text: Executives of Japan's biggest companies predict deteriorating growth in the months ahead, a sign of the economy's weakness that may help the nation's bonds rebound from their first quarterly loss since June 2013.

site_title: China PMI up in March but weakness persists
summary: China's manufacturing activity showed a slight increase in March, with the official Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) rising to 50.1, the first expansion since December. However, fundamentals remain weak due to an anaemic property market, growing corporate and bank debt, and industry plagued by overcapacity. The government may consider further central bank intervention to support the slowing economy, which is expected to post its first quarter GDP statistics below 7% this year, the slowest quarterly growth since the global financial crisis in 2009.

site_title: CNA explores stake in Vietnam's airport concession after deal on new terminal
summary: CNA Group has signed a Letter of Intent (LOI) to provide mechanical, electrical and plumbing services for a new terminal in Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam. The US$70 million deal is for a 30-year airport concession and includes a 39,500 sq m passenger terminal building, cargo terminal, and warehouse. CNA is exploring the possibility of equity participation in the concession to secure long-term recurring income opportunities. The new terminal is expected to be completed in 18-20 months and operational by early 2017, with a handling capacity of nine million passengers per annum.

site_title: US: Stocks fall on weak economic data
summary: US stocks fell on Wednesday for a second day, dropping 0.44% due to disappointing economic data. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 77.94 points to 17,698.18, while the S&P 500 dropped 8.20 points to 2,059.69, and the Nasdaq Composite Index fell 20.66 points to 4,880.23. The decline was attributed to weak economic data, with concerns about economic growth stoked.

site_title: US board may delay sweeping accounting rule change for revenue
summary: The US Financial Accounting Standards Board (FASB) proposed a one-year delay in sweeping new revenue recognition rules for US public companies, pushing the implementation date to 2018 and nonpublic companies to 2019. The delay aims to give companies more time to prepare and implement necessary systems, as some lack the required software. The FASB's revised timeline is intended to provide more time for companies to adapt to the new rules, which will change the way companies recognize revenue.

site_title: SPH forms new unit to produce golf content, run events
summary: Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) has launched a new unit, SPH Golf, to produce monthly golf specials and run golf events. The unit will be run by deputy editor Murali Subramaniam and will produce content from international golf magazine Golf Digest. The first issue of the monthly special, titled "Swing," will be published in April, followed by events such as the Business Times Corporate Golf League and the Singapore qualifiers for the 2015 World Amateur Golfers Championship.

site_title: China goes for statesmanship over US 'blunder'
summary: China successfully incorporated the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB) with a significant number of western countries as founder members, despite US opposition. The US Congress's refusal to ratify IMF reform and its concerns over the AIIB's governance are being downplayed by China, which is instead focusing on recruiting top international management and enforcing environmental and social standards. China's efforts to become part of the Special Drawing Right (SDR) may also be linked to the AIIB, promoting the SDR's adoption as the AIIB's unit of account.

site_title: US targets overseas cyber attackers with new sanctions programme
summary: US President Barack Obama launched a new sanctions program to target overseas cyber attackers that use "malicious" cyber attacks to threaten US foreign policy, national security, or economic stability. The executive order allows the US Treasury Department to freeze assets and bar financial transactions of entities engaged in destructive cyber attacks, and can be used against individuals, groups, and companies. The program aims to deter and punish cyber attackers, but experts warn it may be difficult to attribute hacking attacks and identify those responsible, and could result in a compliance nightmare for companies.

site_title: Latest BOJ tankan survey shows businesses still in the doldrums
summary: Japan's businesses remain cautious despite a sharp yen depreciation and lower oil prices, according to the latest BOJ tankan survey. The survey found that sentiment among large manufacturing firms remained unchanged in March, despite forecasted improvements. Companies plan to cut capital spending by an average 1.2% in the current financial year, indicating weak economic growth prospects. Analysts point to factors such as China's slowdown, US economic hesitation, and lingering domestic demand uncertainty as contributing to the cautious mood.

site_title: S$ bond issues hit S$3b in March
summary: Singapore dollar bond issuances reached S$3 billion in March, a 20% increase from the same period last year, driven by strong demand. The market remains volatile, with investors concerned about the duration of the debt rally. Despite this, DBS Bank led the market with 19 issues worth S$1.57 billion, followed by OCBC Bank. The market is experiencing credit-specific negative events, including rating actions and negative earnings surprises, which are impacting valuations and liquidity.

site_title: Transport union strike paralyses Argentina
summary: Argentina's largest cities experienced a 24-hour transportation shutdown due to a strike by transport unions, which began on Tuesday. The strike, which affected three million people, demanded tax cuts for low-income workers and put the government on the defensive ahead of general elections in seven months. The strike paralyzed Buenos Aires, emptying the streets and forcing many businesses to remain closed.

images.alt_text: Roads were deserted and businesses shut in Buenos Aires and other major cities as unions started a 24-hour shutdown demanding the government raise the income tax threshold. The strike is estimated to cause losses of US$340 million to the economy.

site_title: Plans to water down EC draft law to ban banks' proprietary trading
summary: The European Union plans to water down a draft law banning banks from taking market bets with their own money to avoid hindering economic recovery. The law, proposed by the European Commission, would require banks to isolate risky trading from other activities, but Latvia, the current EU presidency, suggests making the separation of proprietary trading non-automatic, allowing for more discretion from regulators. This move has been backed by France and aims to prevent liquidity issues in some markets, while the European Central Bank has expressed concerns about harming market-making and funding for businesses.

site_title: US pork belly prices likely to fall as deadly pig virus wanes
summary: US pork belly prices are expected to fall further into the summer due to increased supplies and controlled cases of the deadly Porcine Epidemic Diarrhoea virus (PEDv). The US Department of Agriculture forecasts a record 24.09 million pounds of pork production in 2015, with hog slaughter and pork output rising 11% over the previous year. Analysts predict pork belly prices to remain at around $99 per hundredweight from July to September, down from $154.45 last year.

site_title: Boeing lists workers eligible to vote on union drive
summary: Boeing has released a list of approximately 3,000 employees in its South Carolina operations eligible to vote on a union organizing effort by the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers (IAM) on April 22. The IAM aims to represent workers building the company's 787 airliner. Boeing is opposing the union drive in the strongly anti-union state of South Carolina, with both sides intensifying their efforts to sway public opinion through media campaigns and one-on-one outreach. The outcome of the vote will determine whether Boeing's South Carolina operations will be represented by the IAM.

site_title: Malaysia GST kicks off after years of delay
summary: Malaysia has implemented a goods and services tax (GST) after years of resistance, aiming to diversify revenue sources and reduce dependency on petroleum earnings. The new tax regime is seen as necessary due to the country's low tax payer base, with only 15% of salaried workers and companies paying tax. The introduction of GST is expected to curb the shadow economy and increase transparency in tax collection, but critics argue it will further burden lower to middle-income earners.

site_title: Macau's casino revenue expected to fall 21% this year
summary: Macau's casino revenue is expected to fall 21% this year, with a projected annual decline of 277.7 billion patacas ($47.6 billion), the smallest take since 2011. The decline is attributed to a lacklustre Lunar New Year, with analysts slashing their forecasts after a 40% drop in monthly casino revenue. The industry is expected to take until next year to recover, with VIP business potentially facing more trouble due to a proposed casino smoking ban.

site_title: In Brief
summary: Amara Holdings has opened its first hotel in Bangkok, a 250-room property in Surawong near key shopping and financial districts. The hotel is listed on the MAINBOARD and is strategically located near BTS Skytrain stations.

site_title: SGX steps up investor education
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has launched its online StockWhiz real-time trading competition to educate new retail investors. The contest, running from April 1 to June 30, offers S$2,500 in virtual currency to invest in over 400 stocks and funds. The overall winner will receive S$3,000 in cash, while top performers can keep their returns as real trading commission credits. SGX has also introduced new online tutorials on the SGX Academy website and TradeHero app, covering topics such as trading basics and stock valuation.

site_title: Managing AIIB won't be an easy task for China, say analysts
summary: China's new $50 billion Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB) has received applications from almost 50 countries, including four UN Security Council members and several major economies. Analysts say managing the multilateral institution will be challenging due to differing views on environmental and anti-corruption policies. The AIIB's founding members include countries such as Germany, Britain, and Australia, which may limit China's influence. The bank's governance and lending practices are expected to be scrutinized, raising concerns about China's intentions and the impact on the global economic order.

site_title: Private home prices slip 1.1% in Q1: URA
summary: Singapore's private home prices fell 1.1% in Q1, marking the sixth straight quarter of decline since the peak in 2013. Landed properties dropped 1.1% and non-landed residential properties also fell 1.1%. Experts predict further declines, with a possible 5-8% drop in prices for the year. The city fringe market saw the steepest fall, followed by the Outside Central Region and Core Central Region. Despite a slower price decline, some analysts expect the government to ease property cooling measures later this year.

site_title: Asia-Pac air cargo traffic grows at double-digit clip in Feb
summary: Asia-Pacific air cargo traffic surged 20.8% year-over-year in February, outpacing the global industry's 11.7% growth. Strong demand before the Chinese New Year and Japanese car manufacturers' air cargo shipments to the US drove the expansion. Despite this, emerging Asia and Chinese trade activity eased slightly. Global air freight traffic was also up double-digits, with a 7.5% year-over-year increase from 2014. IATA expects moderate acceleration in air freight growth, with some further gains expected alongside economic improvements.

site_title: RadioShack co-branding plan wins court approval
summary: RadioShack Corp has received bankruptcy court approval to co-brand its 1,740 surviving stores with Sprint Corp, salvaging its business. The deal, valued at $56 million, will preserve about 7,500 jobs and allow RadioShack to stay in business. Standard General hedge fund will occupy one-third of each space, while RadioShack will retain ownership. The sale follows a four-day court hearing, with RadioShack's largest lender, Salus Capital Partners, opposing the deal over a perceived sham auction.

images.alt_text: Founded in 1921, the chain was a go-to retailer for electronics before becoming increasingly irrelevant in the digital age.

site_title: SGX panel completes probe into trading breakdown
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has completed its investigation into the November 2014 trading breakdown, which was caused by a power outage at its data centre. The outage resulted in a three-hour shutdown of securities and derivatives trading systems. The SGX board committee of inquiry has submitted its report to the SGX board and the Monetary Authority of Singapore.

site_title: Russian GDP may contract by 3.8% this year: World Bank
summary: Russia's economy is expected to contract by 3.8% in 2015 and 0.3% in 2016 due to the impact of Western sanctions and low oil prices, according to a World Bank report. The report attributes the economic downturn to the need for Russia to adjust to the new oil price reality and the sanctions environment, with a continued lack of investment being a key policy challenge.

site_title: First TV debate of UK election campaign to pit Cameron against six others
summary: UK Prime Minister David Cameron will participate in the first TV debate of the national election campaign against six other leaders, including Ed Miliband, on April 2, 2015. The debate aims to present Cameron as a statesman amidst a close election on May 7, where neither the Conservatives nor Labour has a clear lead. The contest includes leaders of fringe parties, such as UKIP and the Green Party, on an equal footing with the main parties. The debate's format is seen as an opportunity for Cameron to establish himself as a leader capable of handling the UK's economy.

site_title: Top Malaysian fund shuns consumer companies
summary: Malaysia's top-performing equity fund manager, Eastspring Investments, is trimming holdings of consumer companies due to concerns about the new 6% consumption tax, which will fuel a decline in household spending. The tax, introduced in 2013, will take effect on Wednesday. The fund's chief investment officer, Chen Fan Fai, favors export-oriented companies and builders, citing a slowdown in retail sales and adjusted 2015 retail sales growth forecast to 4.9% from 5.5%. This move comes as consumer companies, such as Padini Holdings and Parkson Holdings, have struggled with declining sales and profit.

site_title: IMF gives Philippine economy upbeat assessment
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has given the Philippine economy an upbeat assessment, citing strong household consumption, fixed capital formation, and net exports as drivers of 6.1% growth last year. This year's growth is projected to reach 6.7%, driven by lower commodity prices, higher public spending, and continued strong private construction and export growth. The IMF notes that poverty remains a challenge, but unemployment fell to 6.8% and inflation is expected to remain low. The fund also highlights potential domestic and external risks, including asset price shifts and external demand risks, but notes the country's strong fundamentals and proactive central bank policies.

site_title: Scotts Square unveils new line-up of tenants
summary: Singapore's luxury shopping mall Scotts Square is reviving with a fresh line-up of at least five new tenants, including Alexander McQueen and Delvaux, following an exodus of over eight tenants in the past six months. The mall's new retail concept, Pedder Group, will feature over 200 brands across six zones, including a children's section. New food and beverage concepts, the London Fat Duck and Time & Flow Champagne, will also open in the third quarter. The revamp aims to boost the mall's tenant commitment rate to 90% and introduces seasonal campaigns and pop-up concepts.

site_title: Paying to make valuable investments happen
summary: Investment in advanced countries remains low despite low interest rates, with employment rates remaining stubbornly low. This is attributed to "secular stagnation", a term coined by Larry Summers, where people must be paid to invest due to low inflation and zero nominal interest rates. Conventional monetary policies, such as quantitative easing, and fiscal stimulus are proposed by Keynesians to stimulate investment, but may trigger asset bubbles or debt crises. The policy consequences of secular stagnation remain debated, with no clear solution to achieve full employment through investment.

site_title: S'pore carriers change cockpit rules after Germanwings crash
summary: Singapore carriers have implemented new cockpit procedures requiring at least two persons to be present at all times following the Germanwings crash, which killed 150. Budget carriers Jetstar Asia and Tiger Airways will have two authorized operating crew in the cockpit, while Singapore Airlines has strict procedures in place but does not comment on security matters. The move aims to deter malicious acts and follows a review of cockpit security procedures. All carriers must implement these procedures by April 1.

site_title: German farmers drink to end of EU milk quotas
summary: German farmers have begun ramping up milk production as EU milk quotas expire. The Heideland farm, home to 1,200 dairy cows, has implemented computerized milking systems and even massage machines to improve cow welfare. The move is part of a larger effort to increase production and capitalize on the lifting of quotas. This marks a significant shift for the German dairy industry, which has historically been subject to strict regulations.

site_title: Guess what? Lots more Singaporeans keen to go and work abroad now
summary: A survey by recruiter Hays found that 97% of Singapore job-seekers would consider working overseas, with the majority drawn to better job opportunities, career development, or lifestyle factors. This reverses the long-held perception that Singaporeans are reluctant to work abroad, with Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong previously expressing concern about this limitation. The findings also suggest that Singaporeans now account for a quarter of all Asian executives appointed to top boards in the US, Germany, France, and the UK.

site_title: URA revises private residential property price index
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) has revised its private residential property price index (PPI) to track prices of all private home transactions, including finer attributes such as floor level and proximity to MRT stations. The revised methodology aims to provide a more accurate representation of the market, and the expanded data will cover a broader range of properties.

site_title: S'pore grads seek work-life balance in career above all
summary: In a survey by Universum, Singapore's business and engineering students prioritize work-life balance as their top career goal, with two-thirds of respondents citing it as a top priority. Google is the top employer for both groups, followed by accounting and auditing firms. The survey also reveals that students value a friendly work environment, professional training and development, and high future earnings. In contrast, banks are falling out of favor, with local banks ranking lower than other top employers.

site_title: Blackstone bets on S'pore luxury property market
summary: Blackstone Group LP chairman Stephen Schwarzman is betting on Singapore's luxury property market, predicting that curbs on the market will be lifted after a 20% decline in luxury prices over the past two years. The firm has invested in high-end developments and bought several units, including a 10-storey apartment block and 18 units in prime residential districts. Analysts say the smart money has started to return to the market, with prices at rock bottom levels, and luxury home prices could rise 5-8% over the next three years.

site_title: GoDaddy set for trading after raising US$440m
summary: GoDaddy has raised $440 million in its initial public offering, pricing its shares at $20 each and valuing the company at over $3 billion. The company, which previously relied on risqué advertising, is rebranding itself as a leading technology provider to small businesses under new ownership. GoDaddy has expanded its presence in traditional technology hubs and now oversees 59 million domains, with website hosting and tools accounting for a significant portion of its bookings. The company aims to demonstrate its evolution as it begins trading on the New York Stock Exchange.

site_title: Make tactical gains from eurozone assets but don't over-rely on cheap money: UBS
summary: UBS sees a tactical opportunity in investing in eurozone assets due to the European Central Bank's quantitative easing program, which is having a greater financial impact than the US Federal Reserve's move. The ECB's program has led to a surge in asset prices, with European equity funds receiving over 35 billion euros, boosting German and Italian markets by 20%. However, UBS warns that investors should not over-rely on cheap money, as central banks may tighten policy again, potentially leading to major difficulties.

site_title: To Bordeaux for a first taste of the 2014 vintage
summary: Thousands gather in Bordeaux for the annual spring rite of en primeur, assessing the quality of the 2014 vintage. Overall quality appears good, but prices for the 2014s are uncertain, with some merchants warning that they may be too high to spark buyer interest. The euro's low value may incentivize US buyers, but pricing needs to be comparable to the 2008 vintage. Meanwhile, the withdrawal of wine guru Robert Parker from judging Bordeaux wines en primeur may lead to lower prices. Investors are advised to consider purchasing wines from the 2005 vintage, which is considered the best of the 21st century.

site_title: LHN breaks IPO drought with Catalist offering
summary: LHN Limited, a Singapore-based space optimisation specialist, has successfully launched its initial public offering (IPO) on the Singapore Exchange (SGX), ending a three-month new-listing drought. The IPO raised approximately S$14.4 million, with the group aiming to expand its services in the Asean region. LHN plans to pay out dividends of at least 20% of its net profit, and its shares are expected to begin trading on April 13.

site_title: China says Taiwan can participate in AIIB 'under appropriate name'
summary: China has agreed to allow Taiwan to participate in the Asian Infrastructure Bank (AIIB) under an "appropriate name", despite Beijing's opposition to international recognition of the island. Taiwan had submitted an application to join the $50 billion bank, which was seen as a counterweight to the Washington-backed World Bank and Japanese-led Asian Development Bank. This move is a rare concession from China, which regards Taiwan as part of its territory and has previously curtailed its involvement in global agreements. The AIIB is open and inclusive, according to Chinese officials, and welcomes Taiwan's participation.

site_title: OCBC tightens terms for 3% interest account
summary: OCBC Bank has tightened the terms of its 360 savings account, which offers 3% annual interest, by lowering the maximum bonus interest to 2% per annum. To earn the bonus interest, customers must use the account as their salary crediting account, make payments through the account, and spend money through an OCBC credit card. Two new categories will also be introduced, allowing customers to earn over 3% annual interest. The changes take effect from May 1.

site_title: Senior StanChart executive resigns to set up private equity firm
summary: Standard Chartered's senior executive V Shankar is resigning on April 30 after 13 years to set up a private equity fund, focusing on late-stage and expansion capital in South and South-east Asia, Middle East, and Africa. The decision comes as the bank faces a senior management exodus, including CEO Peter Sands' departure in June. Shankar's fund aims to raise $1 billion by Q1 2016 and make its first investment "very soon." The bank's board will have three executive directors after Shankar's departure.

site_title: Polaris soars as Softbank takes stake in associate
summary: Polaris Ltd, a Singapore-based mobile phone distributor, surged 31.25% to 2.1 cents after SoftBank acquired a 19.9% stake in its Indonesian associate company, PT Trikomsel Oke Tbk, estimated to be worth $120 million. This deal gives SoftBank entry into Indonesia's rapidly growing mobile phone market, with 280 million mobile phone users expected to reach 103.6 million by 2017.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Analysts from DBS Group Research, OCBC Investment Research, and RHB Research have made recommendations on three companies: Croesus Retail Trust, Ascendas Real Estate Investment Trust, and Valuetronics Holdings. DBS Group Research recommends buying Croesus Retail Trust due to its exposure to the Japanese retail market and sales growth at Mallage Shobu. OCBC Investment Research maintains a "hold" on Ascendas Reit, citing its slight positive impact on unitholders but unattractive valuations. RHB Research recommends buying Valuetronics Holdings due to its cost control and automation efforts, as well as a 36% upside target price.

site_title: Cosco down on rig delivery delays
summary: Cosco Corp shares slipped 1.98% to 49.5 Singapore cents after a customer requested a nine-month delay for the delivery of two jack-up rigs. The delay will push delivery dates to December 2016 and June 2017. Brokerage DBS Vickers warned of further contract deferments and cancellations in the rigbuilding sector, potentially triggering asset deflation. The company maintained its "fully valued" status and 12-month target price of S$0.49.

site_title: US$ eases as survey bolsters safe-haven yen
summary: The US dollar remained stable against the euro and yen on Wednesday, despite a soft Japanese business survey that negatively impacted Tokyo shares. The survey, however, bolstered the safe-haven yen. In contrast, improved European manufacturing data helped boost the euro.

site_title: CAG and STB in S$35 million partnership to lure visitors
summary: Changi Airport Group (CAG) and the Singapore Tourism Board (STB) have partnered in a S$35 million, two-year initiative to boost visitorship to Singapore and Changi Airport. The joint marketing campaigns will target key markets such as Australia, Indonesia, China, and India, and will feature local brands, cultural displays, and special packages with Singapore Airlines and travel agents. The partnership aims to achieve a sustainable annual growth of 3-4% in visitor arrivals over the next decade, following a 3% decline in 2014.

site_title: Big oil tanker backlog builds up at Iraq's Basra port
summary: A backlog of over 30 oil tankers, mostly supertankers, has built up outside Iraq's Basra port due to bad weather and possible oil quality issues, causing delays of up to three weeks to load oil. The backlog, with a combined capacity of around 50 million barrels, is expected to delay or limit oil export cargoes in April, potentially lowering tanker freight rates. Shipbrokers have seen a drop in cargo numbers being fixed from the Middle East, and VLCC rates have fallen by around $10,000 per day.

site_title: SME business confidence over next 6 months slips
summary: Singapore's small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) have displayed a more wary sense of optimism, with a slight dip in business confidence over the next six months. The SBF-DP SME Index fell from 54.4 to 54.0, despite remaining optimistic about prospects. Turnover and profit expectations have also decreased, with a 5.74 to 5.57 drop in turnover and a 5.54 to 5.47 decline in profit expectations. SMEs are expected to adjust their cost base and defend margins, with lower oil prices potentially leading to lower costs and a more positive profit outlook.

site_title: UBS says world economy just right, warns against complacency
summary: UBS Group AG's chief economist Larry Hatheway says the world economy is in a favorable position, but warns against complacency. He does not provide a specific timeline for when this complacency should be addressed.

site_title: The travel selfie: hey, I was here - give me a discount!
summary: Kimpton Hotels & Restaurants has started loaning guests selfie sticks, encouraging them to post photos on Instagram or Twitter with the hashtag #AdoreThySelfie. In exchange, guests may win a stick, a $150 gift card, and a framed selfie enlargement. This trend is part of a larger wave of brands offering selfie packages at hotels and resorts worldwide. However, some critics argue that the practice of taking travel selfies can be visually disruptive, hurt memory, and disrupt the experience for other travelers and locals.

site_title: Court orders Sukamto Sia to pay Indon coal tycoon S$132m for lost opportunity
summary: Sukamto Sia, a Singapore businessman, was ordered by the High Court to pay S$132.32 million in damages to Indonesian mining magnate Low Tuck Kwong for lost opportunity due to a defamation suit. The court awarded S$280,000 to S$200,000 for general damages and S$80,000 for aggravated damages, with the majority going towards lost opportunity damages. The decision follows a 2013 court ruling in favor of Low Tuck Kwong, who claimed Sia defamed him over a 50% stake in Bayan Resources, a coal firm founded by Low.

site_title: Abu Dhabi SWF in 70:30 JV with Lend Lease for Paya Lebar site
summary: Abu Dhabi Investment Authority (ADIA) has formed a 70-30 joint venture with Lend Lease for the S$1.67 billion Paya Lebar Central mixed-development site in Singapore. This project is one of ADIA's largest investments in Singapore, with an estimated all-in development cost of at least S$2.6 billion. ADIA will own 70% of the joint venture, with Lend Lease holding 30%. The project will feature office, retail, and residential spaces, marking the first time Lend Lease will develop homes in Singapore.

site_title: Charter to acquire Bright House for US$10.4b
summary: Charter Communications has announced a $10.4 billion deal to acquire Bright House Networks, making it the sixth-largest cable operator in the US. This deal signals a tough time for smaller cable companies as regulators approve megadeals in the US cable industry. The acquisition is part of the wave of consolidation reshaping the media industry, with the big players continuing to get bigger.

site_title: STI arrests slide, breaks even for the day
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) in Singapore ended the day with a slight gain of 0.01 point, closing at 3,447.02, after sliding for most of the day due to overnight weakness in US markets and below-average China PMI data. The market saw 15 losers for every 13 gainers, with Polaris, a Singaporean electronics distributor, being the top actives, gaining 31.25% after Japanese telco Softbank Group took a stake in a Polaris associate.

site_title: Sears forms Reit to raise US$2.5b in cash amid losses
summary: Sears Holdings Corp formed a real estate investment trust, Seritage Growth Properties, to raise $2.5 billion in cash by acquiring 254 properties, including Sears and Kmart locations. The Reit will lease these properties back to Sears, funded by debt and a rights offering. This move aims to fund a transformation into a leaner retailer focused on online sales and loyalty programs, as Sears seeks to end more than three years of losses.

site_title: Canon opens new printing facility at S'pore Sports Hub
summary: Canon has opened a new printing facility at the Singapore Sports Hub, providing a range of services including printing, mail management, and document management. The facility is expected to save the Sports Hub approximately S$2 million in efficiency and productivity over a five-year period. As one of the Sports Hub's founding partners, Canon will also receive branding, hospitality, and signage rights. The move is seen as a way for Canon to expand its services and solutions beyond printing, and to support the Sports Hub's goal of being a premier destination for sports, leisure, and entertainment.

site_title: Rate of HDB resale price decline slows in Q1
summary: HDB resale prices in Singapore declined 1% in Q1 2015, the smallest decline in 11/2 years, according to flash estimates. This marks the seventh straight quarter of price decline, with a 9.2% drop in resale price index over seven quarters. Experts attribute the slowdown to the Lunar New Year festivities, but warn that loan curbs and mortgage rate increases may continue to impact demand, with forecasts predicting a 4-6% decline in HDB resale prices this year.

site_title: Surprise outcome of KepLand offer splits views
summary: Keppel Corp's takeover bid for its mainboard-listed property arm, Keppel Land, resulted in a surprise outcome with 95.1% of shares accepted, just 0.4 percentage point shy of the 95.5% threshold needed for compulsory acquisition. The bid closed on Tuesday, saving Keppel Corp S$155 million on privatising Keppel Land, but leaving minority shareholders with a lower payout of S$4.38 per share instead of S$4.60. Analysts debate whether the deadline extension was too short, and whether Keppel Corp could have reached the threshold with a longer extension.

site_title: Latin oil bargains erode Saudi market clout in Asia
summary: Latin American oil producers are gaining market share in Asia by offering cheaper heavy crude to refiners, eroding Saudi Arabia's dominance. The discount to Middle East benchmark Dubai has widened to almost double the average of the past year, with Latin American shipments to South Korea increasing for the first time in over two decades. This shift is driven by the US shale boom, which has transformed the flow of oil to Asia and boosted demand for heavier crudes.

site_title: The stunning revolution of Asian bond markets
summary: Asian bond markets have experienced a dramatic revolution since the year 2000, with the total domestic market size increasing from approximately $500 billion to $9.5 trillion. This represents a 25% annualized growth rate. The growth is driven by the significant expansion of Asian economies, which have quadrupled in size and now contribute 30% to global GDP. Despite this, the bond market has grown nearly twenty-fold, offering valuable investment opportunities. The rapid growth is attributed to a combination of factors, including the size of Asian economies and other underlying drivers.

site_title: Maybank seeks to increase activities in Indonesia
summary: Maybank, Malaysia's largest lender, plans to increase corporate lending and investment-banking activities in Indonesia to mitigate slower economic growth in its home country. The bank aims to focus on large companies in transport, utilities, and consumer businesses, with an estimated 5.2% growth in Indonesia's economy this year. Maybank owns 79% of PT Bank Internasional Indonesia and is exploring expansion into banking in Thailand. The move is part of the bank's strategy to diversify and grow its market presence in South-east Asia.

site_title: US economic sanctions to target cyber-attacks and cyberspying
summary: US President Barack Obama signed an executive order allowing economic sanctions against perpetrators of destructive cyber-attacks and online corporate espionage. The move lets the Treasury Department freeze assets and bar US citizens and companies from doing business with those targeted. Sanctions will be used only if cyber-attacks harm national security, foreign policy, or the economy, targeting critical infrastructure, networks, and intellectual property theft. The administration aims to prevent large-scale data theft after major breaches, including those at Target, Anthem, and Home Depot.

site_title: Nomura research institute to set up Singapore unit
summary: Nomura's research institute, NICMR, is setting up a unit in Singapore to boost its financial research capabilities in Asia, focusing on Asean countries. Analysts from Tokyo will relocate to Singapore, establishing a new department to support Nomura's business in Asia. The move aims to enhance the company's competitive strengths through in-depth research and analysis of Asian financial markets and regulatory developments.

site_title: Matex Int'l spins into coal mine operator
summary: Matex International, a Singapore-listed textile specialty chemical maker, has entered into a S$475 million reverse takeover deal with Australia-listed Blackgold International Holdings to become a coal mine operator. The deal involves the acquisition of Blackgold's Hong Kong subsidiary, with Matex issuing new shares to its shareholders, LionHeart, and consultant Portman Capital Development Ltd. The four thermal coal mines in Chongqing, China, have "proved and probable" reserves of 100.7 million tonnes, positioning Matex as a "preferred coal provider" for Shanghai and other parts of the Yangtze delta.

site_title: Eurozone inflation falls for 4th month as unemployment dips
summary: The Eurozone's core inflation rate fell to 0.6% in March, the lowest level since 1997, as consumer prices dropped 0.1% from a year earlier. Unemployment rates in the region dipped slightly to 11.3% in February, the lowest since May 2012. Despite these positive signs, economists believe the data does not lift the threat of deflation, and the European Central Bank will continue its quantitative easing policy to raise inflation to its target of 2%.

site_title: Wealth funds turning to Tokyo property as land prices continue to rise
summary: Global wealth funds, particularly from the US, Europe, and Scandinavia, are investing in Tokyo properties to take advantage of rising land prices. The prices rose 2.9% last year, driven by foreign investors and stimulus from the Bank of Japan. Norway's US$870 billion wealth fund is preparing to purchase properties in Tokyo, while Singapore's GIC Pte paid US$1.7 billion for a building in the business district. Japanese real estate companies are able to box out overseas investors, but cross-border investment is still increasing, with 16% of deals over US$10 million coming from abroad in 2024.

site_title: US construction spending falls for second straight month
summary: US construction spending declined for the second consecutive month in February, falling 0.1% to $967.2 billion, according to the Commerce Department. January's spending was revised to a 1.7% decline. This slowdown could impact economists' forecasts for first-quarter growth, which is expected to range between 0.8% and 1.2%. Bad weather, a strong dollar, and weaker overseas demand are cited as factors contributing to the economic slowdown, with estimates suggesting a 2.2% growth rate in the fourth quarter.

site_title: French barley exports to China seen rising more than 20-fold
summary: French barley exports to China are expected to rise 20-fold to 2.19 million tonnes this season, surpassing Australia as the world's top barley shipper. China's demand for barley is driven by its high consumption of pork, with the country importing twice as much barley last year. European Union exports are also expected to increase, with 10 million tonnes forecasted to be delivered outside borders. This surge in demand is largely due to China's ban on genetically modified US corn imports and Ukraine's increased corn shipments to China.

site_title: Thailand's ruling junta lifts martial law: televised statement
summary: Thailand's ruling junta, the National Council for Peace and Order, announced the lifting of martial law in a televised statement on April 1, 2015. The law had been in place since May 22, 2014, following a coup that ousted Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra. The decision was made after consulting with King Bhumibol Adulyadej, and a new order will be implemented, retaining significant military powers.

site_title: Obama may need new spin on TPP
summary: US President Barack Obama's administration is facing a challenge in securing Congressional approval for the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) trade agreement, a key part of its global trade agenda. The TPP, the largest trade pact in history, involves over 40% of the world's GDP, but its approval is threatened by growing opposition from both Democrats and Republicans, who are concerned about the agreement's impact on labor unions, consumer groups, and US sovereignty. The White House is now expected to change its spin on the TPP, potentially framing it as a way to contain China's economic and diplomatic power in the Pacific.

site_title: Global manufacturing growth eased slightly in March: survey
summary: Global manufacturing growth eased slightly in March, according to a business survey, with JPMorgan's Global Manufacturing Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) dropping to 51.8 from 51.9 in February. This marks the 28th consecutive month the index has been above the 50 level, indicating growth. Output prices rose to just below the growth threshold of 50, with rates of expansion in output and new orders remaining steady. The slight decrease suggests the global manufacturing sector continued to make steady progress.

site_title: Malaysia's top banks offer US$865m Islamic financing for Cititower
summary: Malaysia's top banks, Malayan Banking Bhd and CIMB Group Holdings Bhd, signed a 20-year Islamic term financing deal worth US$865 million for Cititower Sdn Bhd's mixed commercial development project in Kuala Lumpur. The project, expected to be completed by 2020, will include an office and hotel tower. Cititower is a joint venture between KLCC (Holdings) Sdn Bhd and Qatari Diar Real Estate Investment Company.

site_title: Goldman economist says Fed hike likely late 2015 or early 2016
summary: Goldman Sachs economist Jan Hatzius believes the US Federal Reserve will likely raise interest rates late 2015 or early 2016 due to labor market slack and weak wage growth. He forecasts the first rate hike for September, citing it's not yet time for tightening monetary policy.

site_title: Lessons in growth for aspiring countries
summary: Singapore's first prime minister, Lee Kuan Yew, transformed the country from a Third-World economy to a developed nation through strong institutions and good governance. To replicate this model, developing countries need to improve the rule of law, reduce corruption, and reform public institutions. While reforms take time to show results, they are essential for sustained economic growth. Lee's development strategy focused on export-oriented growth, attracting foreign investment, and creating a business-friendly environment, ultimately leading to Singapore's success as a high-tech hub. His approach emphasizes the importance of a capable, committed, and credible government in delivering stability and economic growth.

site_title: US manufacturing growth slows to 22-month low: ISM
summary: US manufacturing growth slowed to its 22-month low in March, according to the Institute for Supply Management (ISM). The index of national factory activity fell to 51.5 from 52.9, shy of expectations and the lowest reading since May 2013. New orders and employment also slowed, with indexes at 22-month lows. A reading above 50 indicates expansion, but this was the 28th-consecutive headline reading at or above 50.

site_title: Greece won't repay IMF on time without extra funds: report
summary: Greece's Interior Minister Nikos Voutsis warned that the country won't repay the International Monetary Fund on time if no additional funds are received by April 9. Greece will prioritize paying salaries and pensions before requesting foreign creditors to agree on a debt repayment postponement. Voutsis stated there are sufficient funds until mid-April, but a deal is needed to avoid default.

site_title: Hungary to join China-backed AIIB investment bank: PM Orban
summary: Hungary will join the China-backed Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB), Prime Minister Viktor Orban announced during a visit to Kazakhstan. More than 40 countries, including major economies, have joined the bank, with Japan and the US being notable absentees. The move comes as China seeks to enhance its regional and global influence, following a March 31 deadline for founding members.
