Washington initially tried to dissuade its allies from joining, but changed its stance after many countries signed up for the AIIB.

site_title: India aims to double exports to US$900b
summary: India aims to double its annual exports to $900 billion in the next five years, from $469.5 billion in the 2013-14 financial year. Commerce Minister Nirmala Sitharaman announced the target, aiming to increase India's global exports from 2% to 3.5%. The government plans to encourage domestic manufacturing, focusing on sectors like defence and e-commerce, and address constraints such as weak infrastructure and red tape. Analysts consider the target ambitious, citing global trade growth and India's export non-competitiveness as challenges.

site_title: Tracking private home prices
summary:
Here's a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

US President Trump's 50% copper import tariff affects refined metal, while home prices are being tracked. Good Class Bungalows in Singapore face a Q3 wave of condo launches, potentially testing demand above S$3,000 psf. US mortgage rates have climbed after five weeks of declines, and Manhattan rents reached a record high with more increases anticipated. Goldman Sachs acquired a significant hotel and retail portfolio in Seoul, and UK homebuyer demand rebounded to a six-month high. China property assets are also being sold, with New World Group reportedly involved in the deal.

site_title: Keppel Land said to sell 50% stake in Singapore's Capital Square
summary: Keppel Land's investment company plans to sell its 50% stake in Singapore's Capital Square, a 16-story building in the financial district. The sale will be handled by Alpha Investment Partners, which will seek buyers for the approximately 340,000 square-foot property. No specific details on the sale price or timeline have been disclosed.

site_title: Smartphones a lifeline for many Americans: study
summary: A Pew Research Center survey found that 64% of American adults own a smartphone, with 15% relying "limitedly" on their device for internet access due to financial constraints. Around 10% have no broadband internet at home. Young adults, those with lower incomes, and those with lower educational attainment are more likely to be "smartphone-dependent." These users often struggle to pay their smartphone bills, and 23% have had to cancel or suspend their service due to financial reasons. Despite the cost, 93% of smartphone owners find their device useful, with 46% saying they could live without it.

site_title: Web hosting company GoDaddy's shares rise 34% in debut
summary: GoDaddy Inc., a web hosting company, made its public debut with shares rising 34% in their debut, valuing the company at up to $5.48 billion, including debt. The company raised $460 million after pricing its 23 million class A shares at $20 per share, above the expected range of $17-$19. The stock opened at $26.15 and reached a high of $26.84 on the New York Stock Exchange.

site_title: SGX panel completes probe into trading breakdown
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has completed a probe into the trading breakdown on November 5, 2014, caused by a power outage at its data centre. The investigation, led by a board committee of inquiry, reviewed the incident and recommended improvements to prevent recurrence and enhance crisis management processes. The report was submitted to the SGX board and the Monetary Authority of Singapore.

site_title: US private sector adds 189,000 jobs in March: ADP
summary: US private employers added 189,000 jobs in March, below economists' expectations and the lowest since January 2014, according to the ADP National Employment Report. February's private payrolls were revised up to 214,000 jobs. Economists expect total US employment to have grown by 245,000 jobs in March, with the unemployment rate remaining at 5.5%. The ADP figures precede the US Labor Department's more comprehensive non-farm payrolls report on Friday.

site_title: Greece denies will delay IMF payment without new aid
summary: Greece's government denied it will delay a payment to the International Monetary Fund due on April 9, despite Interior Minister Nikos Voutsis stating that the government would take such a step if no fresh aid is received from lenders by April 9. The government spokesman, Gabriel Sakellaridis, said talks with lenders have reached common ground and a positive outcome is expected at a meeting of eurozone finance ministers. Greece is rapidly running out of cash and must make a payment of about 430 million euros to the IMF next week.

images.alt_text: Greece's government denied on Wednesday it would delay a payment to the International Monetary Fund due on April 9, after the interior minister was quoted as saying Athens would take the step if it did not get fresh aid from lenders.

site_title: Update: Keppel Land's Alpha said to sell stake in Singapore tower
summary: Keppel Land's Alpha Investment Partners plans to sell its 50% stake in Capital Square, a 16-story building in Singapore's financial district, reportedly due to rising office rents. The property, valued at S$889 million, was purchased in 2011. The sale comes after a 14% increase in office rents last year, the largest in Asia. Tenants include Morgan Stanley, Citigroup, and Bloomberg LP. The company will seek buyers and make announcements as the transaction progresses.

site_title: Being a big global bank is not worth the hassle: investor poll
summary: A poll of financial industry investors by Morgan Stanley found that 62% believe the negatives of being a top 30 global bank outweigh the benefits, citing "overbearing" regulations. Only 28% saw the benefits as outweighing the negatives. Investors expect European banks to raise at least 20 billion euros in equity this year and for the European Central Bank to require banks to hold core capital of at least 11%. Many banks are simplifying operations and restructuring to save costs, with 10% of investors polled undecided on the issue.

site_title: India central bank says rupee transactions will not be allowed in international centres
summary: The Reserve Bank of India announced that banks setting up units within India's International Financial Services Centres (IFSCs) will only be allowed to transact in non-rupee currencies, exempt from reserve requirements. These units will follow Indian banks' rules regarding bad loans and asset classification. The move aims to promote financial stability and encourage foreign investment in IFSCs, with the first IFSC set to be established in Gujarat.

site_title: UK productivity worsens in last three months of 2014: ONS
summary: UK productivity fell by 0.2% in the fourth quarter of 2014, its first decline since mid-2013, as output per hour worked dropped. This marks the seventh year since the 2008 financial crisis that productivity has remained weak, with employment growth outpacing output. Overall hourly productivity grew only marginally in 2014, and unit labour costs rose 1.2% in the last quarter.

site_title: US crude in storage rises as gasoline stockpiles tumble: EIA
summary: US crude inventories rose by 4.8 million barrels, exceeding analyst expectations, while gasoline stocks fell by 4.3 million barrels and distillate inventories increased by 1.3 million barrels. Crude imports declined by 44,000 barrels per day. Refinery crude runs rose, and utilization rates increased. The Energy Information Administration's data also showed rising crude stockpiles at the Cushing, Oklahoma, delivery hub, a record high two weeks prior.

site_title: US: Wall St dips at open after ADP report
summary: US stocks declined at the open on Wednesday following a weaker-than-expected ADP report on private sector employment, raising concerns about the labor market. The Dow Jones fell 31.69 points, the S&P 500 lost 3.86 points, and the Nasdaq dropped 7.40 points. The decline comes ahead of Friday's jobs report, which may also indicate worsening labor market conditions.

site_title: Lockhart sees June-Sept rate liftoff even after softer data
summary: Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta President Dennis Lockhart stated that despite a slowdown in first-quarter economic activity, interest rates should still be raised from June to September. Lockhart maintained his view on timing, attributing the first quarter's slowdown to transitory factors. He expressed confidence in the US central bank's ability to raise rates during this period, despite softer data.

site_title: Malaysia's Anwar loses parliament seat after pardon bid rejected
summary: Malaysia's opposition leader Anwar Ibrahim lost his parliamentary seat after a royal pardon bid for his sodomy conviction was rejected. The King denied Anwar's request for freedom on March 16, and the disqualification took effect. Anwar was sentenced to five years in prison for sodomy in February. The Election Commission will meet on April 8 to discuss steps for a by-election for Anwar's Permatang Pauh seat.

site_title: LHN launches first IPO of 2015, to raise S$17 million
summary: LHN Limited launched its first IPO of 2015, raising S$17 million through a share placement. The IPO, on the Catalist board, marks the end of a three-month drought in new listings on the Singapore Exchange. The company plans to use the funds to expand its space optimisation and logistics services in the Asean region. LHN does not have a fixed dividend policy, but aims to pay out at least 20% of its net profit after tax. The IPO is expected to begin trading on April 13.

site_title: Automakers profit from luxury models, North America, China: McKinsey
summary: The world's largest automakers are profiting from luxury models in North America and China, according to a report by McKinsey & Co. Released on April 1, 2015, the report states that luxury models have become a key revenue source for automakers, with China and North America driving growth. Industry executives also expressed confidence in the luxury market, citing strong demand for SUVs and trucks in these regions. This trend is attributed to restructuring efforts by automakers and suppliers since the 2008-2009 financial crisis, which reduced production capacity and consolidated dealer networks.

site_title: UAE airlines say no safety concerns after air traffic 'incident'
summary: UAE airlines Emirates Airlines and Etihad Airways stated that an investigation is underway after two planes, one from Emirates and one from Etihad, flew too close to each other in Indian airspace on Sunday. Despite the incident, both airlines said safety was never compromised, citing onboard instrumentation and traffic control systems that ensured safe separation. The airlines are cooperating with authorities investigating the incident, which occurred during a flight from Seychelles to Dubai and Abu Dhabi. Neither airline disclosed the exact distance between the planes.

site_title: Bill Gross of Janus says funds he manages resemble Bridgewater strategy
summary: Bill Gross, a prominent bond investor, stated that the portfolios he manages at Janus Capital Group Inc. closely resemble the investment strategies of Bridgewater Associates, the world's largest hedge fund firm. Gross said unconstrained bond funds, which have gained popularity due to their flexibility to invest globally, share similarities with Bridgewater's approach. He also mentioned that corporate credit spreads are too tight, and investors should focus on leveraging assets that may remain artificially priced, particularly in the US and Europe. Gross expects yields to remain low due to Mario Draghi's quantitative easing program.

site_title: China says Taiwan welcome to join AIIB with appropriate name
summary: China welcomes Taiwan's application to join the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB) as long as Taiwan uses an "appropriate name", according to a statement from China's Taiwan Affairs Office. Taiwan has applied to join the bank despite not being recognized by most countries, including the US. The move has sparked debate in Taiwan, with some critics expressing concerns about closer cross-strait ties and unequal membership. China views Taiwan as a renegade province, but has seen a decline in enmity since Taiwan's president took office in 2008.

site_title: China expands investment scope of US$194b social security fund
summary: China has expanded the investment scope of its $194 billion social security fund, allowing it to buy up to 20% of local government debt and state-owned company shares. The move aims to diversify risk, improve returns, and help the central government manage local government debt. The fund can now invest up to 10% in trusts and certificates of deposit, potentially aiding in finding buyers for local government debt and bringing financial risks under control. This expansion is part of efforts to cope with China's rapidly aging population and shrinking workforce.

site_title: Malaysia scraps plan to find investors for 1MDB's energy unit
summary: Malaysia has scrapped plans to sell its energy unit, Edra Global Energy Bhd, after a lender, CIMB Group Holdings Bhd, was informed its services were no longer required. The Ministry of Finance stated that listing on the Malaysian stock exchange remains the preferred course of action for the unit's monetization. Edra is proceeding with plans to submit an IPO application, which could raise up to $3 billion, and is advised by Deutsche Bank AG and Malayan Banking Bhd. The decision comes after 1MDB announced plans to dismantle its assets amid rising debt concerns.

site_title: Brazil's Oi trims over 1,000 jobs in cost-cutting push
summary: Brazilian telecom group Oi SA is eliminating 1,070 jobs in a cost-cutting push aimed at reducing personnel-related expenses by nearly 20% this year. The job cuts, part of a broader downturn in Brazil's labor market, will result in a 6% reduction of Oi's 18,000 full-time jobs. The move is part of CEO Bayard Gontijo's turnaround strategy for the heavily indebted company, which also includes asset disposals and strict controls on expenses.

site_title: Lufthansa chief visits crash area as 'cabin video' emerges
summary: Lufthansa chief Carsten Spohr and Germanwings chief Thomas Winkelmann visited the French Alps crash site of their plane, where 27-year-old co-pilot Andreas Lubitz deliberately crashed the plane, killing 150 people, amid scrutiny over Lufthansa's knowledge of Lubitz's severe depression. A cabin video emerged, showing chaotic scenes and screams, but French authorities denied its authenticity. Investigators focus on "systemic weaknesses" in cockpit door security and pilot screening procedures. Lufthansa has set aside $300 million for damages and Germanwings will compensate families with 50,000 euros.

site_title: Oil holds around US$55 as Iran nuclear talks drag on
summary: Brent crude oil futures remain steady at around $55 a barrel as Iran nuclear talks continue, despite a Tuesday deadline extension. Iranian officials hope to wrap up talks by Wednesday night, but Western powers remain cautious. The US has warned of abandoning talks if an agreement is not reached, and market analysts predict a fragile and incomplete deal. Higher OPEC supply and US crude inventories also put downward pressure on oil prices.

site_title: Singapore Wrap Wednesday
summary: Singapore Wrap Wednesday. Notable stories include Vietnam's surprise reaction to the US Trump tariff announcement, Malaysia's agency planning to seize RM3 billion of Daim Zainuddin's assets, and China's GDP growth expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers. Additionally, Citigroup predicts a mid-2026 target of 1,150 for the MSCI global equity index and Thai PM Thaksin's daughter's suspension in an ethics case may be cleared by the court. The UK economy also shrank for the second month, and ASEAN agreed that the Myanmar election is not a priority.

images.alt_text: In a move to enhance the way private home prices here are tracked, the Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) said it has revised its index methodology and expanded its data coverage to capture all private home transactions.

site_title: Standard Chartered's Shankar resigns to open private equity fund
summary: Standard Chartered's head of Europe, Middle East, Africa and Americas, Viswanathan Shankar, has resigned after 13 years to start a private equity firm. Shankar will step down on April 30 and the bank has hired Jonathan Paul and Sumit Dayal as replacements. The new private equity firm aims to raise $1 billion and target deals in Asia, Africa, and the Middle East, where Shankar has extensive experience. The move follows a senior management exodus and efforts by the bank to overhaul its management and attract top leadership talent.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower
summary: Malaysian shares ended lower on Wednesday, with the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index slipping 4.47 points to close at 1,826.31. The index saw 2.91 billion lots traded, valued at RM1.57 billion, with 291 gainers and 478 losers.

site_title: Lufthansa CEO says will take long time to understand crash
summary: Lufthansa CEO Carsten Spohr stated that it will take a long time to understand the causes of the Germanwings plane crash, which occurred last week. Spohr refused to answer questions about Lufthansa's knowledge of Andreas Lubitz's mental health. Lubitz, the pilot, had informed a flight school of a "severe period of depression" after a break in his training. The investigation is ongoing, with Lufthansa saying they are learning more each day about the accident's causes.

site_title: Chinese New Year, US port delay boost Feb air freight
summary: Global air freight volumes rose 11.7% in February, driven by the Chinese New Year and US port congestion. Asia-Pacific carriers saw a 20.8% increase, while North American carriers reported an 8.7% rise. The growth is expected to be short-lived, with freight volumes forecast to rise by 4-5% this year. The International Air Transport Association attributed the boost to increased automotive exports from Japan to the US, shifting from sea to air. Business confidence improved slightly, and trade continues to grow.

site_title: Outstanding leaders needed to keep Singapore exceptional: PM Lee
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong emphasized the need for leadership renewal ahead of the next general election, set by January 2017. He urged the public to support a new team of leaders with high ability, strong character, and dedication to keep Singapore exceptional. Lee acknowledged the challenges of recruiting new people to enter politics, but stressed the importance of succession planning to ensure the country's continued success.

site_title: German cabinet imposes high barriers for fracking
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel's cabinet has signed off on a draft law banning fracking for shale gas, with the goal of protecting health and drinking water. The law will impose an effective ban on fracking in densely-populated areas and allow only test drilling under strict conditions. Commercial fracking could begin in 2019, but only in exceptional cases for deep-lying gas. Environmental audits and stricter rules will be in place for even deep-lying gas fracking, with the aim of preventing contamination of drinking water.

site_title: Malaysia's CIMB says no longer advising on sale of 1MDB power unit
summary: CIMB Group Holdings Bhd, Malaysia's second-largest bank, announced it is no longer advising on the sale of Edra Global Energy Bhd, a power firm owned by 1MDB, to strategic investors. The decision comes after the Malaysian Ministry of Finance informed CIMB that the sale would not be considered. CIMB was appointed as the adviser just a week prior. The 1MDB fund, which has a debt pile of US$11.6 billion, was planning to list Edra Global in an initial public offering expected to fetch US$3 billion.

site_title: Korean Air chief's daughter seeks leniency in 'nut rage' appeal
summary: Heather Cho, the daughter of Korean Air Lines' chairman, is seeking leniency in her appeal for a one-year prison term over the "nut rage" case, in which she was jailed for forcing a flight crew chief off a plane due to poor in-flight service. Cho admitted to abusive acts but claimed no intent to disrupt flight operations. The Seoul High Court hearing marks the opening day of her appeal, as her lawyers push for reduced sentence.

site_title: Germany says must study crash before considering air safety changes
summary: Germany will wait for the completion of investigations into the April 1 airliner crash before considering changes to air safety rules. The transport ministry's spokeswoman stated that the findings from the investigation will determine whether changes are necessary. The crash, which killed all 150 people on board, was attributed to pilot Andreas Lubitz's deliberate actions, who had previously disclosed his struggles with depression. The investigation's results will be crucial in deciding whether to implement changes to air safety rules.

site_title: Singapore bond issuances hit S$3 billion in March
summary: Singapore's bond market saw a significant increase in issuances in March, reaching S$3 billion, a 20% rise from the same period last year. Despite concerns about market risks and pricing volatility, investors continue to demand Singapore dollar bonds. Year-to-date issuance is still lower compared to the same period last year, with 44 deals worth S$4.78 billion in Q1 2015. Experts attribute this to market risks and the "take and hold" nature of the SGD bond market, with smaller deal sizes and lower volumes.

site_title: Willis Re says reinsurance rates to keep falling, sees more M&A
summary: Willis Re, a reinsurance broker, expects reinsurance rates to continue falling, fueling further mergers and acquisitions in the sector. The company's latest report notes that rates and terms are favoring buyers, with no signs of a reversal. This trend is expected to lead to more significant changes in business models, challenging previous views that size may be a barrier to M&A transactions. As a result, more mergers are likely, driven by the need for reinsurers to adapt to the changing market.

site_title: Hong Leong Asia Q1 net profit down 64.6%
summary: Hong Leong Asia reported a 64.6% decline in Q1 net profit to S$4.69 million, mainly due to lower profit from the Yuchai and Xinfei units. Revenue declined 13.4% to S$1.09 billion, with the consumer products unit experiencing lower sales due to weaker property markets in China. The commercial vehicle industry in China may remain affected by the country's economic slowdown, and the construction industry in Singapore is expected to face challenges despite a rebound in private sector activity.

site_title: Factory worker turned Apple supplier now China's richest woman
summary: Zhou Qunfei, a 45-year-old former factory worker, has become China's richest woman after her company Lens Technology's shares surged on the Shenzhen stock exchange, surpassing $8 billion in fortune. Zhou founded the company in 2003, supplying touchscreen glass to Apple, Samsung, and others. With an 89% stake, Lens Technology generates $3.3 billion in revenue annually, and its touch-sensitive glass covers are used in nearly 21% of the world's smartphones.

site_title: LHN Limited offers 73.9 million shares at 23 Singapore cents each for Catalist listing
summary: LHN Limited, a property management services group, is listing on Catalist with a 73.9 million share placement at 23 Singapore cents each, valuing the shares at 6.5 times earnings. The company plans to use net proceeds of $14.4 million to expand its operations, including space optimisation, facilities management, and logistics services. LHN manages a portfolio of 36 properties with a total lettable area of over 4 million sq ft and has seen revenue grow at a 9.9% CAGR and net profit at a 34.7% CAGR from FY2012 to FY2014.

site_title: Singapore shares flat on mixed China data
summary: Singapore shares closed flat on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index rising 0.01 point. Electronics distributor Polaris led gains, rising 31.3% after Japanese telco SoftBank Group acquired a stake in its Indonesian associate. Sino Construction improved by 6.4% after announcing a share placement. Losers outnumbered gainers 225 to 195, with a total of 1.2 billion shares worth S$954.5 million changing hands.

site_title: Getty heir dies in Los Angeles: reports
summary: Andrew Getty, a 47-year-old heir to the Getty oil fortune, has died in his Los Angeles mansion. At this stage, foul play is not suspected, and the cause of death has not been disclosed. Getty was a member of the Getty trust and a grandson of J. Paul Getty, the founder of Getty Oil. He was found naked from the waist down in the bathroom, with signs of blunt-force trauma. A woman in the mansion reported finding the body, and police are questioning her. The Los Angeles county coroner's office will release the victim's name and cause of death on Wednesday.

site_title: UK factory PMI rises to eight-month high in March: Markit
summary: Britain's manufacturing sector grew at the fastest rate in eight months in March, with the PMI rising to 54.4, ahead of economists' forecast. Output grew 0.6% in the first quarter, driven by strong domestic demand and a pick-up in export orders. This could help offset weakness in the services sector, which shrank in January. The growth is heavily reliant on consumer demand, but business-to-business spending and investment orders are providing support.

site_title: Abu Dhabi SWF in HK$18.5b Hong Kong hotels deal
summary: Abu Dhabi's sovereign wealth fund, ADIA, has agreed to buy a 50% stake in three Hong Kong hotels from New World Development Co Ltd in a HK$18.5 billion deal. The deal forms a 50-50 joint venture between New World and ADIA to pursue hospitality acquisitions. New World will receive HK$10.1 billion from the sale and use the proceeds for its Hong Kong property development projects. This marks the second real estate-related investment by a Middle Eastern fund in Hong Kong in the past six months, following Qatar Holding's US$616 million deal in October.

site_title: Standard Chartered Europe, Middle East chief Shankar resigns
summary: Standard Chartered Plc announced the resignation of Viswanathan Shankar, chief of its Europe, Middle East, Africa, and Americas unit, effective April 30. Shankar will step down from the board after 13 years of service. The bank hired Jonathan Paul as group head of financial markets and Sumit Dayal as group head of corporate finance. These appointments are part of the bank's efforts to overhaul its senior management, following the hiring of new CEO Bill Winters in February. The change aims to reduce the board's size to three executive directors.

site_title: Germany's overall debt ratio fell in 2014: Bundesbank
summary: Germany's total debt increased to approximately 2.168 trillion euros in 2014, but its proportion of overall output fell to 74.7% due to the country's growing economy. This decrease is in line with EU rules, which cap debt levels at 60% of GDP. Since 2010, general government debt in Germany has grown by 91 billion euros, primarily due to support measures for domestic financial institutions during the eurozone sovereign debt crisis. The debt ratio has decreased in the past two years, according to the Bundesbank.

site_title: Eurozone manufacturing picks up as weak euro boosts exports: PMI
summary: Eurozone manufacturing activity accelerated in March, with the PMI reaching a 10-month high of 52.2, beating expectations. This indicates a possible recovery in the bloc's economy, which will delight the European Central Bank. The stronger euro has boosted exports, contributing to the growth. This positive sign comes as the ECB continues its quantitative easing programme to drive up inflation and spur the recovery.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks up on China factory survey; start-up shares strong
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose on Wednesday following a better-than-expected Chinese factory activity survey. The Hang Seng index increased 0.7% to 25,082.75, with the Growth Enterprise Market (GEM) surging over 4% after China allowed insurers to invest in the city. The move is expected to narrow the valuation gap between Hong Kong and mainland Chinese small-cap stocks, with analysts predicting the A-H valuation gap to converge to zero by the end of the year.

site_title: Asian markets closed on Friday
summary: Asian markets are closed for public holidays in China, Hong Kong, Thailand, and other countries. Meanwhile, European stocks fell due to bank and healthcare drag, while US stocks edged down from records amid tariff threats. The US-EU trade talks are in focus. In Singapore, stocks rallied for a fifth day ahead of GDP data. Traders are brushing off new Trump threats to extend the rally, while several companies, including Singtel and PSC, are in the spotlight for upcoming announcements.

site_title: City buzz
summary: Casio's new luxury watch, G-SHOCK MRG-G1000, is available for pre-order in Singapore, featuring GPS Hybrid Wave Ceptor technology for accurate timekeeping. The watch combines metal aesthetics with ultra-lightweight titanium and luxurious finishing. Meanwhile, local theatre group Teater Ekamatra presents a double bill featuring Tart and Abu, while indie filmmaker Han Yew Kwang's comedy film Rubbers competes with blockbuster films at the box office. Vocal sextet Take 6 performs a cappella music, and weekend markets are held at D'Kranji Farm Resort and Bollywood Veggies, offering local produce and artisanal products.

site_title: Update: URA awards tender for Paya Lebar Rd/Sims Ave commercial site to 3 companies
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) has awarded the tender for a commercial site at Paya Lebar Road/Sims Avenue to Roma Central, Milano Central, and Verona Central, with the highest bid of S$1.67 billion. The joint venture will own 30% of the site, and the tender price works out to S$10,145.65 per square metre. Six bids were received, and the land parcel was offered for sale on a 99-year lease term.

site_title: The vinous virtue of patience
summary: Wine enthusiasts who invest in storage reap greater rewards due to the maturation process. Patience is crucial in wine-making and enjoyment. Soft, ripe, and fresh wines with minimal tannins are ideal for pairing with spicy dishes like Sichuan cuisine. A German Riesling or a soft, succulent red wine like a Southern Rhone can complement seafood and meat, respectively. Proper storage, such as a temperature of 10°C, allows wines to mature slowly, increasing their value.

site_title: OCBC tightens terms for savings account with 3% bonus interest
summary: OCBC is revising the terms of its 360 savings account, reducing the maximum bonus interest from 3% to 2% on deposits up to S$50,000. Two new categories will be introduced, allowing eligible customers to earn over 3% interest. The changes take effect May 1.

site_title: South Korea becomes latest to impose cockpit 'rule of two' after Germanwings crash
summary: South Korea has implemented a "rule of two" in cockpit crewing, requiring at least two people to be present in the cockpit of an aircraft in flight, following the Germanwings crash that killed 150 people last month. The rule, which takes effect immediately, applies to all South Korean airlines, including Korean Air Lines and Asiana Airlines, with internal safety plans to be aligned by April 10. The move aims to prevent similar incidents and ensure enhanced safety measures.

site_title: Greek factory activity shrinks in March as export orders weaken: PMI
summary: Greek manufacturing activity contracted for the seventh consecutive month in March, with the Markit PMI falling to 48.9 from 48.4 in February. Export orders weakened, leading to reduced production and new orders for the third month in a row. Employment in the sector grew slightly, driven by job creation in consumer goods firms. The decline in manufacturing activity is attributed to uncertainty surrounding Greece's bailout negotiations and fears of a "Grexit".

site_title: French manufacturing contraction eases in March: PMI
summary: France's manufacturing sector saw a slower contraction in March, with the purchasing managers' index rising to 48.8 from 47.6 in February. New orders shrunk at a slower pace, suggesting the worst might be over for manufacturers and employment in the industry. This improvement is seen as a positive sign for the French economy, which has been struggling with a long-awaited recovery.

site_title: Swiss manufacturing PMI edges up in March after franc shock
summary: Switzerland's manufacturing sector saw a slight improvement in March, with the purchasing managers' index (PMI) edging up to 47.9 points from 47.3 in the previous month. The stabilization is attributed to the stabilization of the exchange rate, following the Swiss National Bank's removal of its cap on the franc's value against the euro in January. However, the sector still contracts, with order books shrinking at a slower pace. The franc is trading over 10% higher than before the policy change, raising concerns for the export-reliant economy.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open 0.17% lower
summary: Tokyo stocks fell 0.17% at the open on Friday, following a sharp drop on Wall Street due to weak US data. The Nikkei 225 index dropped 32.78 points to 19,487.23, amid concerns about the world's top economy. Core inflation in Japan rose 2.2% year-on-year in March, the first increase in 10 months, but still short of the Bank of Japan's target of 2.0%. The yen strengthened against the US dollar, while stocks on Wall Street fell 1.08% on Thursday.

site_title: German manufacturing grows in March at fastest rate since April 2014 : PMI
summary: German manufacturing expanded at its fastest pace in almost a year in March, with the purchasing manager's index (PMI) rising to 52.8 from 51.1 in February. This is the highest reading since April 2014 and the fourth consecutive month above the 50 line separating growth from contraction. New orders and backlogs built up, leading to increased production and hiring. The stronger euro helped secure new contracts, but also pushed up import costs, with firms raising prices for the first time since October.

site_title: US expects Congress to pass fast-track trade bill within next month
summary: US officials expect Congress to pass the trade promotion authority (TPA) legislation within the next month, allowing for the speedy completion of free trade deals. Under Secretary of State Catherine Novelli stated that votes are available to move forward, indicating a strong likelihood of passage. This development casts a positive light on the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) negotiations, which are expected to be concluded in a relatively short time.

site_title: US upper Midwest factory activity contracts in April
summary: A private measure of factory activity in the US upper Midwest region fell to 48.08 in April, indicating a contraction in manufacturing activity. The production gauge dropped to 45.13 and supplier deliveries slid to 38.57, contrasting with a rise in new orders to 57.42. The regional activity index has been above 50 for 17 of the previous 20 months.

site_title: VW gets new supervisory board members after Piech goes
summary: Volkswagen appointed two members of the Piech family, Louise Kiesling and Julia Kuhn-Piech, to its supervisory board following the resignation of Chairman Ferdinand Piech. Piech's departure comes after a public row with CEO Martin Winterkorn and will be discussed at the company's annual shareholder meeting on May 5. The Piech family holds a majority of voting shares, and the new appointments aim to regain the initiative ahead of the shareholder meeting.

site_title: UOB to open Yangon branch in May
summary: UOB to open Yangon branch on May 4, following regulatory approval. The bank will focus on helping companies invest in energy, manufacturing, construction, and hospitality industries. This marks the bank's entry into onshore banking solutions for foreign enterprises and joint ventures in Myanmar. UOB has established a presence in the country since 1994 and previously financed projects in Yangon and Mon State. The bank's country manager, Harry Loh, expects a strong pipeline of foreign direct investment to flow into Myanmar.

site_title: Venture Q1 net profit up 5.8% to S$32.6m
summary: Venture Corporation, a global electronics service provider, reported a 5.8% increase in net profit to S$32.6m in the first quarter of 2015, driven by a diversified customer base and investment in R&D. Revenue rose 3% to S$608.65m. The company also generated S$40m in cash from operations and maintained a net cash position of S$264.9m. Venture attributed its growth to its strategy of building a healthy customer base and investing in R&D and engineering capabilities.

site_title: Opec output steady near 2 1/2-year high as Saudi pumps 10m b/d
summary: OPEC's oil production remained steady in April near a 2 1/2-year high at 31.295 million barrels per day, according to a Bloomberg survey. Saudi Arabia's production was trimmed to 10 million barrels per day, down 100,000 barrels from March. The move was seen as a response to higher-than-projected discounts for oil sold in March, the largest in at least 15 years. OPEC ministers are set to meet on June 5 to discuss market conditions.

site_title: EU banking watchdog mulls cap on sovereign debt exposure
summary: Europe's banking watchdog, Daniele Nouy, suggests that banks should limit their exposure to sovereign debt, which she claims is no longer risk-free. Nouy proposes that banks should back sovereign bonds with capital, as they do with other assets, to reflect their true risk. The Basel committee and European parliament are open to proposals, and the Single Supervisory Mechanism is taking steps to clarify the issue, which could send a strong signal to the market. This move aims to address the current treatment of sovereign debt on bank balance sheets.

site_title: J-pop star is a kabuki knockout
summary: Japanese pop star Hideaki Takizawa is set to export his modern take on traditional Kabuki theatre to Singapore. The show, Takizawa Kabuki, has been a decade-long success in Japan, selling out every year and featuring elaborate sets, acrobatic acts, and a mix of Japanese and Western elements. The 52-performance run will be performed at the Marina Bay Sands in August, marking the show's first international outing. The Singapore version will be altered slightly for an international audience, and Takizawa has expressed his excitement about performing at the venue, citing its size and potential for special effects.

site_title: UK retail sales growth eases unexpectedly in April: CBI
summary: UK retail sales growth unexpectedly eased to +12 in April from +18 in March, missing economists' expectations of +25. Despite this, retailers are optimistic about sales in the coming month, with a gauge of expected sales rising to +40, a three-month high. The decline in sales among grocers contributed to the overall decrease.

site_title: US labour costs rise solidly; wage growth picks up
summary: US labour costs rose 0.7% in the first quarter, the largest gain since 2014, driven by a 0.7% increase in private sector wages and salaries. This solid wage growth could support the Federal Reserve's decision to raise interest rates this year. Labour costs jumped 2.6% in the 12 months through March, still below the 3% threshold needed to bring inflation closer to the Fed's 2% target.

site_title: US Senate panel probing US$3 billion 'collusion concern' in spectrum auction
summary: The US Senate Commerce Committee is investigating potential collusion in a Federal Communications Commission auction of airwaves, worth US$3.3 billion, involving DISH Network and its affiliates. The committee is seeking documents related to the bidding strategies employed by the companies. Regulators have allowed critics to formally voice opposition to awarding small-business discounts to the partners of Dish Network Corp, which emerged as winning bidders. The investigation aims to determine if the companies' conduct adhered to the law.

site_title: McDonald's tests simpler version of custom-sandwich programme
summary: McDonald's is testing a simplified version of its Create Your Taste program, called TasteCrafted, which allows customers to customize burgers with fewer options at drive-thru locations. The program, launched in California and Oregon, uses a touch screen to let customers choose buns, toppings, and cheeses. The move aims to streamline the system and satisfy demand for custom options without overwhelming drive-thru windows. The test is seen as a lower-cost investment for franchisees and could be rolled out more quickly, potentially helping the company turn around declining US same-store sales.

site_title: Plenty of treacherous moments for rally this week
summary: US stocks rose last week to a record high, driven by the US consumer's ability to weather a global slowdown. The rally is seen as a sign of the economy entering a new phase, with consumer spending and services driving growth. The Federal Reserve's latest statement and Greece's clash with creditors are expected to pose challenges this week. Despite concerns, experts believe the dollar's impact on earnings was overstated and that the US economy has more than compensated for the negative effects of the dollar.

site_title: US jobless claims at lowest level since 2000
summary: US jobless claims dropped to 262,000, the lowest level since 2000, according to the Labor Department. This suggests March's job growth moderation may have been an anomaly. Claims for the prior week were revised to 292,000, and the four-week moving average fell to 283,750. The number of people receiving benefits after an initial week of aid declined 74,000 to 2.25 million, indicating an improvement in the jobless rate.

images.alt_text: The number of Americans filing new claims for unemployment benefits last week dropped to the lowest level since 2000, suggesting March's moderation in job growth was likely an aberration.

site_title: BP profit beats estimates as refining offsets oil-price plunge
summary: BP reported a 19% drop in adjusted first-quarter profit to $2.6 billion, beating analyst estimates. The company's refining and trading earnings offset lower crude prices, which have dropped 40% in the past year. CEO Bob Dudley is reducing spending and reviewing projects to prepare for a possible period of sustained low oil prices. BP plans to sell non-drilling infrastructure and has already offloaded $7 billion of assets in a $10 billion sale program.

site_title: Seoul: Won hits 6-mth high ahead of Fed meeting; shares down
summary: The South Korean won reached a near six-month high against the dollar on Tuesday, closing at 1,070.0 per dollar, driven by expectations of a dovish stance from the US Federal Reserve regarding an interest rate hike. However, the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) slid 0.5% to 2,147.67 points, with offshore investors selling Kospi shares, resulting in a net loss of 3.5 billion won.

site_title: Banking on life's lessons (Amended)
summary: Standard Chartered Bank's Asean chief executive Lim Cheng Teck emphasizes the importance of continuous learning and adapting to new situations. He shares his personal experience of learning new skills, including accounting and language, after being rejected by an investment bank. Lim highlights the need for relevance in the ever-changing world, stating "you have to stay relevant and you must have a hunger for continuous learning." He also notes that understanding regional nuances, such as market timing and cultural differences, is crucial for success in business. Lim's leadership philosophy is centered around leveraging the strengths of neighboring countries to drive economic growth, as seen in Asean's combined economy of $2.4 trillion.

site_title: Greek banks said to win more emergency cash as talks loom
summary: Greece won access to more emergency funding for its banks, with the European Central Bank raising the cap on Emergency Liquidity Assistance by about 1.5 billion euros to 75.5 billion euros. Euro-area finance ministers will meet on April 24 to discuss Greece's financial crisis and economic reforms. Greek Prime Minister Alex Tsipras is urged to commit to reforms to secure aid payments, with a 30% chance of Greece defaulting and exiting the euro, according to economist Holger Schmieding.

site_title: Powering India is a tough renewables act
summary: India aims to become a surplus power producer by 2025, but the goal is considered too ambitious given its limited carbon footprint. The country's reliance on coal, oil, and natural gas is high, with 1.5 billion tonnes of coal expected to be burned by 2020. To achieve its renewable energy target of 175GW by 2022, the government is incentivizing oil and gas production, creating a green corridor, and implementing a cost-effective fuel-pooling plan. However, the sector faces challenges, including inefficiency, theft, and political pricing, which disrupt power flow to factories and homes.

site_title: Interior design award for M&C's Japan hotel
summary: Millennium & Copthorne's (M&C) first flagship hotel in Japan, the Millennium Mitsui Garden Hotel, has received a silver award for interior design under the International Design Awards (IDA) 2014. The hotel, designed by CL3 Architects Limited, features 329 guestrooms and a unique "Bottega-inspired" exterior. General manager Ayako Iwasaki attributes the hotel's success to the yen's fall and eased travel entry for foreign visitors, with an 80% occupancy rate since opening. The hotel aims to attract more visitors from Singapore and the region, with plans to expand its guest list.

site_title: Forecasts shift to Labour success as polls stay tied
summary: Forecasts are shifting in favour of Labour, with polls remaining tied between the two parties, as the UK election approaches. Bookmaker Paddy Power has made Labour leader Ed Miliband the favourite to win, citing the Conservatives' failure to gain support. The SNP's potential to pick up nearly all of Scotland's seats also contributes to Labour's momentum, making it easier for Miliband to form a coalition. The Tories' recent policy shift has been met with little public support, and their inability to gain ground has led to a shift in the predicted outcome.

site_title: First foreign bank in decades opens in Myanmar
summary: Myanmar's quasi-civilian administration has welcomed the opening of Japan's Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi UFJ's Yangon branch, the first foreign bank to operate in the country in decades. The move aims to attract foreign investment and modernize the country's banking system. The bank will provide full banking services to foreign companies and domestic banks. Other foreign banks from the Asia-Pacific region are also expected to finalize their licenses within months, as the government lifts international sanctions and creates a surge of interest from foreign businesses.

site_title: Johor property slowdown expected to bite harder
summary: A slowdown in property demand in Iskandar Malaysia is expected to worsen in the second half of the year, with a pipeline of 2015/16 projects and unsold units from previous years contributing to a housing glut. Johor's existing residential units, 719,421, are expected to be further exacerbated by a huge pipeline of incoming supply, with 142,567 units under construction and 193,271 units planned. The service-apartment segment is particularly concerning, with 80,000 approved units and only 10,000 currently being built.

site_title: UK supermarket Tesco plunges into the red
summary: Tesco, Britain's largest supermarket chain, reported a record loss of £5.74 billion in the 12 months to February, citing a writedown on property values and an impairment of £630 million related to a Chinese investment. The company also revealed a £263 million accounting error that overstated profits. Despite this, CEO Dave Lewis expressed determination to turn the business around, with annual pre-tax profit of £961 million after stripping out exceptional charges. The company's share price fell 0.45% in early trading.

site_title: Asia, Americas drive Heineken sales at start of year
summary: Heineken NV reported 2.0% like-for-like revenue growth in the first quarter, exceeding market expectations with 4.34 billion euros (S$6.28 billion). The growth was driven by higher beer sales in Asia and the Americas, offsetting softness in Europe and Africa.

site_title: Japan, US hail tighter alliance as China military might grows
summary: Japan and the US have strengthened their alliance for the first time in almost two decades, amid growing Chinese military might in the Asia-Pacific region. New defense guidelines released in New York expand US-Japanese cooperation globally, including space and cyberspace. Japan will take on a more robust role in intercepting ballistic missiles and protecting ships. The move aims to counter China's assertive posturing, which has led to increased tensions in the region.

site_title: Hong Kong puts electoral reform package to legislature
summary: The Hong Kong government has unveiled an electoral reform package, which includes a public vote on two to three pre-selected candidates, to select the city's next leader. The plan, approved by China's National People's Congress, has sparked controversy among democracy activists, who claim it is too controlled. The proposal will be voted on by lawmakers in early summer, potentially reigniting political tension in the city.

site_title: More government support for SME human capital development
summary: Singapore's government has expanded support for small and medium enterprises (SMEs) in human capital development. Starting June, five SME Centres will have dedicated business advisers to provide HR and training advisory services. Additionally, SMEs can access professional HR advisory and management systems through Spring Singapore's HR shared services initiative, offering up to 70% funding support for qualifying costs. This move aims to address manpower challenges faced by SMEs.

site_title: SNB move on negative rates sends Swiss franc sharply lower
summary: The Swiss National Bank (SNB) reduced the number of institutions exempt from negative interest rates on cash deposits, causing the Swiss franc to sharply fall against the dollar and euro. The move increases the likelihood of the SNB lowering interest rates further, potentially in negative territory, amid concerns over Greece's debt problems. The dollar rose 1% against the Swiss franc, while the euro gained 0.8%. Analysts predict the SNB may take interest rates deeper into negative territory if the Swiss franc becomes a safe-haven currency.

site_title: Demi Moore's penthouse up for sale at US$75m
summary: Demi Moore's 25-year-old penthouse in the San Remo building on Central Park West is up for sale at $75 million, a record-breaking price for an Upper West Side co-op. The triplex penthouse features 7,000 square feet of interior living space, 1,500 sq ft of wraparound terraces, and panoramic park and city views. The asking price is significantly higher than the previous in-house record of $26.4 million set last year. The building has also housed other celebrities, including Bono and Steven Spielberg.

site_title: HK luxury home sales heat up as China investors splash stocks profits
summary: Hong Kong luxury home sales are booming as mainland China investors snap up million-dollar mansions, with analysts predicting a record year for home sales. The city's stock market surge has fueled the trend, with sales of luxury homes worth over HK$12 million jumping in the first quarter. Analysts attribute the surge to the ample liquidity in Hong Kong and the need for wealthy investors to park their money, despite the city's efforts to curb speculative demand.

site_title: German public banks near deal on deposit protection system: sources
summary: Germany's public sector banks are near a deal on a deposit protection system for landesbanks and savings banks. The system, which requires 0.8% of deposits to be held in liquidity, needs to be funded by 3 billion euros by 2024. A compromise has been reached, with wholesale-funded landesbanks contributing more than local home-loan banks. The deal may be signed as early as Tuesday, with rival public banks being the first to step in in case of a landesbank collapse. This follows a pattern seen during the 2008 financial crisis.

site_title: Viva Industrial Trust's Q1 DPS up 8.6% on higher rents, new contributions
summary: Viva Industrial Trust reported a 8.6% increase in distribution per stapled security (DPS) to 1.87 Singapore cents for its Q1 2015, driven by higher rents from new tenancies and additional revenue from recently acquired properties. Gross revenue rose 20.8% to S$18.1 million, with net property income increasing 25.8% to S$12.4 million. The Reit's stock price rose by one cent to finish at S$0.815.

site_title: Noble's AGM raises further concern
summary: NOBLE Group's annual general meeting (AGM) has raised further concerns about the company's accounting practices, following attacks from Iceberg Research and the Securities Investors Association Singapore (SIAS). Chairman Richard Elman dodged shareholders' queries on the issues, instead focusing on financial statements and director reports. Elman's responses were described as "insecurity and arrogance" by Iceberg, and SIAS president David Gerald urged the chairman to address shareholders' concerns. The incident has led to a 27% plunge in Noble's counter since February, despite an aggressive share purchase program.

site_title: Top commodity trading houses line up for Iran's return to market
summary: Top commodity trading houses, including Glencore, Vitol, and Trafigura Beheer, are eager to return to Iran's market once US and European sanctions are lifted. Iran, a major crude oil and fuel oil exporter, and a significant importer of food commodities, offers a significant trading opportunity. The companies had previously stopped dealing with Iranian oil and refined products due to sanctions, but have continued to trade food commodities. With the nuclear talks nearing completion, commodity traders expect a significant boost in trade once sanctions are lifted, with estimates suggesting Iran could become one of the world's largest trading opportunities.

site_title: BlackRock agrees to pay US$12 million over SEC conflicts claim
summary: BlackRock agreed to pay $12 million to settle claims with the US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) that it failed to disclose a conflict of interest involving a top portfolio manager, Daniel Rice III. Rice invested client money in a joint venture with a company he founded, which was not disclosed to investors. The SEC said BlackRock violated its fiduciary obligation to eliminate the conflict of interest. The company has taken steps to enhance its policies and procedures regarding employees' outside business activities. Former compliance chief Bartholomew Battista also agreed to pay $60,000 to settle claims.

site_title: Asia: Stocks follow Wall Street higher
summary: Asian markets followed Wall Street's lead, with Tokyo, Hong Kong, and Sydney rising 0.79%, 1.14%, and 0.93% respectively. Shanghai was up 0.72%, while Seoul was flat. The gains reversed losses from Monday due to Greece's debt crisis, which led to the euro holding its ground. Meanwhile, the US stock market saw gains, with the Dow, S&P 500, and Nasdaq rising 1.17%, 0.92%, and 1.27% respectively. Oil prices retreated, and the dollar edged up despite a possible rate hike being put on hold.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Japfa, Noble Group, Tat Hong
summary: Japfa, a leading Indonesian poultry producer, has issued a profit warning due to a weakened poultry market and a decline in purchasing power of low-income consumers. Commodity trader Noble Group's shares have plummeted 27% after anonymous attacks on its accounting practices. Meanwhile, short-seller firm Muddy Waters is also targeting Noble Group.

site_title: Star Wars trailer leaves US fans in raptures
summary: A new trailer for the highly anticipated Star Wars reboot, directed by JJ Abrams, has left US fans in raptures. The action-packed trailer features iconic characters Han Solo and Chewbacca, with Solo's signature voice saying "Chewie, we're home." The trailer was premiered at the Star Wars Celebration convention in Anaheim, sparking widespread excitement and anticipation for the film's release on December 18. Fans took to social media, with many expressing tears of joy and relief, using hashtags such as #Chewiewerehome and #StarWars.

site_title: US stocks join European equities lower on Greece fears
summary: US stocks declined sharply in early trading on Friday, mirroring European equities, due to concerns over Greece's negotiations with creditors. The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 0.76%, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index fell 0.57% and 0.74%, respectively. Negotiations between Greece and creditors will resume in Brussels on Saturday, with the IMF rejecting suggestions that Athens could postpone its loan repayment.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares end 0.31% lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended 0.31% lower on Friday, following a recent rally, while Shanghai stocks advanced 2.20% on hopes for economic boost measures. The Hang Seng Index eased to 27,653.12, while Shanghai Composite Index jumped to 4,287.30. This contrasts with the Shenzhen Composite Index's 0.48% gain. The decline in Hong Kong stocks comes as investors took profits, while Shanghai's gains are attributed to expectations of economic stimulus.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Singapore Airlines is recommended to be sold with a target price of S$11.20 due to a bearish Harami pattern and 21-day Stochastics forming a bearish crossover. DBS Group Research estimates a 9.4% return on investment for a potential fourth telco, while Keppel Corporation's Q1 2015 results were slightly below expectations. The company expects higher contributions from Keppel Land to compensate for its weaker O&M segment.

site_title: Valuations of Hong Kong's stock market operator go interstellar
summary: Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing Ltd (HKEx) has seen a 40% rise in shares over the past six days due to a surge in mainland investment in Hong Kong stocks. The operator has become the world's largest bourse with a US$43 billion market value, surpassing rival CME Group Inc. Its price-to-earnings ratio has jumped to 45 times, making it the highest in the Hang Seng Index. Analysts predict continued robust market trading and higher volumes due to the Stock Connect Program and improved market sentiment.

site_title: Brazil landowners group contests curb on foreign land ownership
summary: Brazil's Rural Society filed a case with the Supreme Court to overturn restrictions on foreign land ownership, which were introduced in 2010 to limit China's access to Brazil's farmland. The society argues that the restrictions violate Brazil's constitution and have led to billions of dollars in lost investments. The land reform agency Incra has approved sales of small parcels of land to non-Brazilians, but larger sales require Congress's approval. The case aims to allow foreign investors to purchase land, with the society seeking to reverse existing laws that prevent the concentration of large quantities of land in a single owner.

site_title: Taking heart
summary: PwC's skills-matching volunteering programme has seen over 40 charitable and welfare organizations sign up, offering 4,000 hours of pro bono training, services, and mentoring. The Salvation Army has received a new display area for its thrift store, donated by Plaza Singapura. Maybank and Etiqa have partnered to provide free personal accident insurance coverage for 3,000 low-income families in Singapore. Additionally, Singapore aims to sign a carbon credits transfer agreement with its first Asean country by the end of 2025.

site_title: Minister admits 1MDB debt 'burdensome'; Putrajaya to stop all new loans
summary: Malaysian Minister Abdul Wahid Omar admitted that 1Malaysia Development Bhd's (1MDB) huge debts are burdensome due to its failure to generate cash flow. The minister stated that the state fund expanded by taking loans and purchasing assets, causing debt to rise. As a result, Putrajaya announced to stop all new loans, addressing the debt burden.

site_title: Solar power costs falling as investors follow Google
summary: Financing solar power projects in the US is becoming cheaper due to increased investment, with returns ranging from 15% to 19%. Companies like Google are taking advantage of a tax benefit to invest in renewable energy projects. This trend is expected to bring costs down "a couple points" by 2017, as competition among investors makes tax-equity deals more accessible to corporations and regional banks. SolarCity Corp pays investors 7% to 12% for credits backing renewable energy projects, a significant decrease from the past.

site_title: GE's billions in finance castoffs are prize to banks: Real M&A
summary: General Electric (GE) plans to sell most of its finance assets, including a $200 billion chunk of lending, leasing, and related financial operations, to US banks and private-equity powerhouses. The divestitures, valued at $75 billion, include North American and Australian consumer lending businesses. This move is part of GE's strategy to slim down its empire and focus on industrial units, led by CEO Jeffrey Immelt. The sale is expected to trigger a bidding frenzy, with major banks and private-equity firms, such as Wells Fargo and Blackstone, competing for the assets.

site_title: Goldman profit gets boost from increased trading
summary: Goldman Sachs reported a 41% rise in first-quarter profit to $2.75 billion, driven by increased trading activity in January following the Swiss central bank's removal of a franc cap. Revenue from trading fixed income, currencies, and commodities rose 10% to $3.13 billion. This beat analysts' average earnings expectation of $4.26 per share. The company's net income applicable to common shareholders rose from $1.95 billion in the same period last year.

site_title: Ahead of UK election, Labour leads Conservatives by 2 points: poll
summary: The UK Labour Party leads the Conservative Party by 2 percentage points ahead of the May 7 election, according to a YouGov poll. Labour is at 35%, while the Conservatives are at 33%. The UK Independence Party remains at 13%, and the Liberal Democrats and Greens also see slight changes. The poll comes as the UK economy shrinks for the second month in a row, adding to the pressure on Prime Minister David Cameron's government.

site_title: Teaching kids the 'life skill' of cycling
summary: TWENTY young children in Singapore were taught how to ride a bicycle as part of The Business Times Cycle of Hope charity programme. The "Teach a child to cycle" initiative, held at the Singapore Sports Hub, aimed to teach basic cycling skills to children from the Singapore Children's Society, Thye Hua Kwan Moral Charities, and Yu Neng Primary School.

site_title: South Korea is told to wait to join TPP trade deal
summary: South Korea has formally requested to join the 12-nation Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) trade deal, but the US has told it to wait until the pact is agreed upon. The US is reluctant to allow another country to join the talks, particularly one with a history of aggressive negotiating stances, amid significant resistance in Congress. A Senate bill to grant the administration "fast-track authority" is set to be introduced, allowing the administration to conclude the deal with current members before considering new parties.

site_title: Advocate for action
summary: The Lancet's editor-in-chief, Richard Horton, emphasizes the connection between science, medicine, and social and political change. Horton believes that "health is political" and that medical professionals have a responsibility to use their knowledge to advocate for social and political change. He defends the journal's publication of an open letter criticizing Israel's actions in Gaza, stating that it was a "cry of anguish" and sparked a productive collaboration with Palestinian and Israeli colleagues. Horton also advocates for a new discipline of "planetary health," which seeks to link medicine, social sciences, politics, and government to address global challenges. He believes that the scientific community must use evidence to inform decision-making and that a new discipline is needed to address the complexities of the 21st century.

site_title: Literary geography from the pages of a novel
summary: A Stanford University research collective mapped Victorian London's "emotional geography" by analyzing 738 novels, categorizing settings as conveying "Dreadful London", "London in the Light", or "A Day in the Life of Old London". The project, part of a growing movement in humanities to harness digital technology for cultural analysis, used computational criticism to analyze literary passages. The results showed that fear was more associated with ancient markets and prisons, not poverty, and crowdsourced workers categorized over 4,000 literary references.

site_title: Indonesia posts higher-than-expected trade surplus
summary: Indonesia posted a trade surplus of US$1.13 billion in March, its fourth consecutive surplus, driven by a sharper decline in imports than exports. Imports fell 13.39% and exports dropped 9.75% from the same period last year. The surplus helped alleviate pressure on the current account deficit and the rupiah, which has been weakened by the US dollar's strength. Economists expect the trade surplus to continue supporting the rupiah.

site_title: Global migrant remittances growth to slow: World Bank
summary: The World Bank predicts global migrant remittances will slow sharply this year due to global economic problems, particularly in Europe and Russia. Remittances to top recipient countries, such as India, China, and the Philippines, will decrease by 0.9% to $440 billion, while global remittances will grow by 0.4% to $586 billion. However, remittances are expected to accelerate by 4.1% in 2016 and reach $610 billion, with total remittances reaching $636 billion by 2017.

site_title: Catalan statehood bid thrown off course
summary: Leaders in Catalonia's push for independence from Spain face a setback, with rising left-wing party Podemos potentially disrupting their efforts and centre-right Ciudadanos vowing to sink the secessionists. A recent poll showed 48% of Catalans opposed to independence, down from 44% in February, and the pro-independence majority may fall short of an absolute majority in the upcoming regional election. The Catalan government's "road map" for independence by 2017 is also facing opposition from within its own coalition.

site_title: Indonesia's palm levy still under discussion, government says
summary: Indonesia's government is still discussing a plan to introduce levies on crude palm oil and processed products, with a US$50 levy expected on every tonne of CPO shipped and a US$30 levy on processed palm oil product exports. The levies aim to boost palm oil prices, which fell nearly 15% last year, and fund biodiesel subsidies. The plan, initially expected to be approved last week, is still being finalized by the chief of the economics ministry.

site_title: South Korean shares touch near 4-yr high on fund inflows; won falls
summary: South Korean shares reached a near four-year high, closing 0.1% higher at 2,090.42 points, driven by fund inflows and hopes for continued global liquidity. Brokerage shares led gains, with Golden Bridge Investment and Securities Co Ltd jumping 14% and Hanyang Securities Co Ltd rising 13%. The won fell 0.3% against the dollar, amid a fifth day of losses, as companies including Samsung Electronics are expected to pay year-end dividends.

site_title: A long history of client-focused solutions
summary: ING Investment Management International (ING IM) rebranded to NN Investment Partners on April 7, 2015. The asset manager manages approximately 186 billion euros in assets, employing over 1,100 staff across 16 countries. NN Investment Partners has a deep heritage dating back to 1845 and is committed to investing responsibly, delivering client-oriented investment solutions and exceptional long-term risk-adjusted performance.

site_title: India seeks to woo German industry at Hanover Trade Fair
summary: India is seeking to attract German industry at the Hanover Trade Fair, with the Indian government promising economic growth, job creation, and infrastructure development to woo foreign investors. India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi and German Chancellor Angela Merkel jointly opened the fair, with Modi stating that India is a valued partner and symbol of technology, innovation, and quality for Germany. The two countries have a bilateral trade of 16 billion euros in 2014, with Germany exporting goods worth 9 billion euros and importing textiles. German companies see potential in sectors such as energy, environment, and IT, with exports expected to grow by over 10%.

site_title: Directors' purchases plunge while sales are flat
summary: Directors' buying activity on the Singapore Exchange declined in the second week of April, with 28 purchases worth S$1.16 million compared to 34 purchases the previous week. However, the number of directors selling remained flat at four firms with five disposals worth S$0.12 million. The majority of significant trades were purchases, with notable buybacks in First Ship Lease Trust and insider buys in Ossia International, VGO Corporation, and SHS Holdings.

site_title: Noble reels from new attack as Muddy Waters joins Iceberg
summary: Noble Group's stock plummeted 5.5% to S$0.86 after shortseller Muddy Waters questioned the firm's accounting practices, stating it "exists solely to borrow and burn cash." Muddy Waters also revealed a short position in Noble shares, citing concerns over the company's management's responses to analysts' questions. The report's findings come as Noble faces scrutiny over previous allegations by Iceberg Research, and analysts warn that the company's business partners and creditors may view its credit risk as a significant concern.

site_title: China to open 10 new air corridors to ease congestion: China Daily
summary: China plans to open 10 new air corridors to alleviate chronic air traffic congestion and flight delays. The corridors will allow aircraft to travel in separate lanes, reducing congestion on existing routes. The move follows the opening of the Guangzhou-Lanzhou air corridor last week, which can handle over 400 flights daily. China's fast-growing civil aviation market has led to military drills causing flight delays, with some airports experiencing a three-quarters reduction in air traffic capacity. The new corridors aim to ease congestion and address the problem of frequent flight delays.

site_title: BlackRock to close or combine some money-market funds: WSJ
summary: BlackRock, the world's largest money manager, plans to close or consolidate some money-market funds due to recent SEC reforms. The company aims to comply with new rules requiring "prime" funds to float values, rather than maintaining a stable value of $1 per share. This change will affect over $200 billion in client assets, leaving BlackRock with approximately 30 funds. The company has about 50 money-market funds and will likely reduce its lineup to comply with the regulations.

site_title: Private equity deals in Asia-Pacific hit new high in 2014
summary: Private equity deals in the Asia-Pacific region reached a record high of $81 billion in 2014, with 742 deals valued at an average of $110 million. China's largest market saw a 33% jump in deal value to $41 billion, driven by six mega-deals worth over $1 billion. Singapore and South-east Asia saw significant growth, with two mega-deals worth $2.3 billion. The region's overall investment value was slightly better than 2013, but still 7% below the five-year average.

site_title: 10-year SGS price rises and yield falls 8% in two weeks, back to Feb levels
summary: The 10-year Singapore Government Securities (SGS) price rose 1.4% in two weeks, returning to February levels, while the yield fell 8% to 2.02%, mirroring the US Treasury's response to softer economic data. This movement is attributed to underwhelming US payrolls data and a slowing US economy. Experts expect modestly rising SGS yields towards the year end, in line with a potential September US Fed rate hike.

site_title: Chinese citizens sue government over transparency on Monsanto herbicide
summary: Three Chinese citizens are suing the Ministry of Agriculture over transparency on Monsanto's herbicide, Roundup, which was approved 27 years ago. The plaintiffs, including GMO activist Yang Xiaolu, demand the public release of a toxicology report supporting the approval. The case, a rare example of a private citizen lawsuit against the Chinese government, comes amid concerns over glyphosate's safety and genetically modified food. The Ministry of Agriculture has declined to release the report, citing commercial secrets, but the court has agreed to hear the case.

site_title: RBA skips on rate cut; focus shifts to May
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) kept interest rates steady at 2.25% for the second month, defying market pressure for a rate cut. The decision was influenced by the expectation of a possible rate cut in May, when key inflation figures are set to be released. The RBA aims to assess the case for further easing of policy at its upcoming meetings, amid concerns about the impact of low rates on the local dollar and the economy.

site_title: Lowdown on the new savings bonds
summary: Singapore's new savings bonds program, set to launch in the second half of 2015, offers a flexible and risk-free investment option for individuals. Compared to 10-year Singapore Government Securities (SGS) bonds, savings bonds shine in a rising-rate environment due to their ability to be withdrawn with no penalty. The program's monthly withdrawal feature effectively removes interest-rate risk, making it an attractive alternative to fixed-deposit products and annuity or endowment products. A S$50,000 limit, or half the insured deposit amount, may be set to ensure the scheme benefits the general public.

site_title: Customer satisfaction levels hit new high
summary: Singapore's overall customer satisfaction levels reached a new high in 2014, with a score of 71.1 points, driven by strong ratings from the finance and insurance sector. The finance and insurance sector rose 4.7% to 72.4 points, while the healthcare sector climbed 1.6% to 71 points. This marks the fourth consecutive year of improvement, with only five sectors registering significantly lower scores, including private education and tourism.

site_title: HDB resale prices likely fell 0.8% in March: SRX
summary: HDB resale prices in Singapore likely fell 0.8% in March, according to SRX Property, with declines across three, four, and five-room flats. This marks a 6.6% drop from last year. Resale transaction volumes improved 17.5% from February, but remain 5% lower than the same month last year.

site_title: Indonesian inflation picks up in March
summary: Indonesia's inflation rose to 6.38% in March, up from 6.29% in February, mainly due to a jump in fuel prices and rice costs. The country's fuel subsidy regime change at the start of the year led to a brief decrease in pump prices, but the increase in global oil costs and distribution problems caused shortages in some areas. The rupiah strengthened to 13,027 to the dollar. This follows a 25 basis point interest rate cut by Bank Indonesia in February, which had initially put pressure on the currency.

site_title: The closing of a chapter
summary: British High Commissioner Antony Phillipson reflects on his four-year term in Singapore, noting that his time has "absolutely flown by." He emphasizes the strong historical ties and economic links between the two countries, dating back nearly 200 years to Sir Stamford Raffles' founding of modern Singapore in 1819. Phillipson aims to cement these ties before returning to the UK, leaving behind a mature relationship between the UK and Singapore.

site_title: OCBC gets nod for Myanmar branch; UOB next in line
summary: OCBC's branch in Myanmar is set to open this month after receiving final regulatory approval. UOB expects to open its first branch in the next few months, also with services including trade finance and cash management. Both banks will provide services to regional and global companies expanding in Myanmar, with restrictions on lending to foreign investors in foreign currencies unless partnering a domestic bank. The move comes as a significant number of Asian companies plan to expand into Myanmar this year, with 25% of Hong Kong businesses and 20% of Singapore businesses expected to do so.

site_title: Great Eastern launches up to US$568m New China Life selldown: IFR
summary: Great Eastern Holdings Ltd, the insurance arm of Singapore's OCBC, launched a US$568 million selldown of New China Life Insurance shares, offering 85 million Hong Kong-traded shares at HK$50.50 to HK$51.80 each, a discount of up to 4% to Monday's close. Credit Suisse is acting as sole bookrunner for the sale, which marks a significant move by OCBC in the Chinese insurance market.

site_title: More economists see BoE rates on hold until early 2016
summary: The Bank of England is expected to keep interest rates on hold until early 2016, with 75 economists polled by Reuters predicting a 25 basis point hike in early 2016. The median forecast is for a rate increase to reach 1.25% by the end of 2016 and 2% by 2017. Economists cite low inflation and a strong pound as reasons for caution, with the US Federal Reserve expected to be the first major central bank to tighten policy in September.

site_title: Record 2014 income on Fed portfolio seen dropping
summary: US Federal Reserve's net income from its portfolio of assets is projected to drop from a record $106 billion in 2014 to $35 billion by 2018, according to the New York Fed's annual report. This decrease is attributed to the Fed's expected earlier interest rate hikes, resulting in lower cumulative net income of $600 billion over the next decade. The Fed's portfolio is expected to reach equilibrium by 2020, with 55% Treasuries and 45% agency mortgage-backed securities. Annual remittances to the Treasury are also expected to decline along with net income.

site_title: Oil pares biggest advance in two months on US supply growth
summary: Oil prices fell by 1.6% in New York after the biggest rally in two months, as investors weighed forecasts of rising US crude supplies against signs of improved demand. Goldman Sachs predicted US stockpiles will reach "historically elevated levels" through 2016, keeping prices low. Saudi Arabia's decision to raise differentials for May shipments to Asia followed a recovery in refining profits, but oil is still struggling to sustain a rebound amid speculation of a global glut.

images.alt_text: Oil fell after the biggest rally in two months as investors weighed forecasts for rising US crude supplies against signs that Saudi Arabia is betting on an improvement in demand.

site_title: Go against property, offshore & marine flow: RHB
