summary: RHB unveiled its 2015 slate of small cap "jewels" in the property and offshore and marine sectors, citing depressed valuations as a contrarian opportunity for bargain-hunters. The firm believes oil prices will rebound in the second half of 2015 and predicts a 6-10% fall in Singapore residential prices. RHB also identified potential privatisation candidates, such as Wing Tai Holdings and Keppel Land, and picked companies like CDW Holdings and Lian Beng Group for their low price-earnings valuations.

site_title: Iceland to levy a 'stability tax' on failed banks
summary: Iceland plans to remove capital controls and impose a "stability tax" on failed banks' estates as early as June, with Prime Minister Sigmundur David Gunnlaugsson citing the need to finalize creditor settlements. The tax aims to recover US$85 billion in debt from defaulted banks, with creditors still waiting for final settlements due to the restrictions. Gunnlaugsson wants parliament to pass legislation on capital controls removal before the summer break on May 29.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open 0.30% higher
summary: Tokyo stocks opened 0.30% higher on Monday, following solid gains on Wall Street last week. The Nikkei 225 index rose 59.75 points to 19,967.38, driven by a boost from US stocks. The dollar strengthened to 120.21 yen, while the euro bought 127.53 yen. This follows a series of Wall Street deals, including a major merger announcement by Royal Dutch Shell and FedEx.

images.alt_text: Tokyo stocks opened 0.30 per cent higher on Monday after solid gains on Wall Street last week.

site_title: Indonesia Feb retail sales grow 16.5% year-on-year: central bank survey
summary: Indonesia's February retail sales grew 16.5% year-on-year, driven by increased sales of information and communication equipment, food, beverages, and tobacco. Retailers expect sales growth to continue in March, but anticipate rising price pressures due to higher fuel, electricity, and liquefied petroleum gas prices. However, these pressures are expected to ease in August after the Eid-al Fitr holiday, when demand is expected to return to normal.

images.alt_text: Indonesia's annual retail sales in February grew at a much faster pace of 16.5 per cent, bolstered by information and communication equipment as well as food, beverages and tobacco, a Bank Indonesia survey showed on Thursday.

site_title: Clearinghouses come under Fed scrutiny after JPMorgan raises alarm
summary: The Federal Reserve is reviewing the risks posed by clearinghouses, platforms that regulators turned to after the 2008 financial crisis to shed light on the $700 trillion swaps market. JPMorgan and BlackRock have warned that clearinghouses pose their own threats, including concentrated risk and potential for uncapped losses. Regulators are considering new policies to mitigate these risks, including increasing the capital held by clearinghouses and limiting their reliance on member levies. The review follows intense lobbying by the Clearing House Association, which represents Wall Street banks, and comes as more derivatives trades are guaranteed at central clearinghouses.

site_title: DBS chairman Peter Seah takes over NWC helm from Prof Lim Pin
summary: DBS chairman Peter Seah has taken over as chairman of the National Wages Council (NWC) from Prof Lim Pin, who held the post from 2001 until last year. Seah, also chairman of DBS Group Holdings and DBS Bank, was deputy chairman of the 2014/2015 NWC. The NWC will convene in April and May 2015 to develop its annual wage and wage-related guidelines. Manpower Minister Tan Chuan-Jin expressed appreciation for Prof Lim's leadership, citing his efforts to shift towards flexible incentives and variable bonuses tied to business performance.

images.alt_text: Mr Seah was deputy chairman of the 2014/2015 National Wages Council

site_title: Noble shares gradually recovering from sell-off
summary: Noble Group's shares gradually recovered from a 5.5% sell-off on Thursday after the company issued a rebuttal to allegations by US shortseller Muddy Waters, categorically rejecting the accusations as inaccurate and misleading. Despite initial losses, shares rose 1.16% to S$0.87 on active trade. Noble disputed claims of unsustainable debt levels and cash burn, citing a historic low in debt-to-capitalization at 38% as of 2014. The rebuttal came just two months after anonymous allegations by Iceberg Research also questioned Noble's accounting practices.

images.alt_text: Shares of Noble Group were gradually recovering in early morning trading following a rebuttal by the group of fresh allegations raised by US shortseller Muddy Waters.

site_title: Europe: Stocks ahead at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets rose on Monday, with the FTSE 100 up 0.53% to 7,031.84 points. The CAC 40 and DAX 30 also increased, despite investor concerns over Greece. Asian markets declined due to losses on Wall Street and restrictions on Chinese dealers borrowing cash. The Chinese central bank's decision to reduce reserve requirements was seen as a positive move, but the mainland's stocks still fell. The region's equities will be watched for signs of progress in US-EU trade talks.

images.alt_text: Europe's main stock markets climbed in opening trade on Monday, with London's benchmark FTSE 100 index up 0.53 per cent at 7,031.84 points.
